The city is beautiful, friendly and welcoming. The food is fantastic! I would go, even with what has happened in recent months! A wonderful place to visit. Give it at least 4 days.

Historic Areas. Beautiful city, you will never regret. Plan your trip. People, places food accessible area of town. I find Istanbul fun together with my friends a nice view at Night. Super amazing totally recommend.
All beautiful. The mosques, squares, streets, buildings and houses, the marketplaces, the Prince Islands and the see all are so interesting and oirental, in april full of tulips everywhere.

Old City is a rich and wonderful part of Istanbul. The Old City section of Istanbul is so rich in historical significance, as well as more modern-day sites of interest. It requires several days to fully appreciate, but we only had one day to tour the area, being with a guided tour group. Although it was a long day of walking, we were able to cover a lot of ground, visiting Sultanahmet Square, the Hippodrome, Sultanahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, the Basilica Cistern. Plus, we also went to the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar, albeit only briefly for about one hour at each place.
a beautiful city brimming with history. We had the help of an experienced guide to show us around and explain, which was very helpful, and we thoroughly enjoyed ourselves.
Gorgeous. A wonderful visit of one of the most famous places worldwide This historic area must be visited by every curious traveler.
Incredible place. Very friendly people, lovely atmosphere, no problems with anything and everyone so helpful. Best to just stroll around for hours to get a feel for the place.

One of the best places on earth!. Sultanahmet Old City, huge history just within a walking distance. Starting with Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet Mosque), Basilica Cistern, Aya Sofya, then Topkapi Palace, all within the same area. Basically you can cover those places in a day (one whole day from 8 am to 6pm for instance). But if you're so much in love with history, one day is certainly not enough (for me, Topkapi took half of my day to visit ; it's huge!) The famous Grand Bazaar, Spice bazaar, Eminonu & Suleymaniye Mosque are also in the Fatih area but it's on the other side (walking about 20 minutes). With this, I would recommend you to stay around Sultanahmet area so it will be easier for you to move around without the need to take public transport (saves some pennies). Don't worry about food, restaurants are just plenty & easily available all the time.

Absolutely Amazing. Istanbul has such a rich cultural and historical background. The social fabric consists of people of different religion and origin. All historical sites reflect this change and mixture. Most of the sites are well preserved and are very informative. I will have to go back again to Istanbul as i couldn't cover so many places during my first visit.

overrated. we found in general Istanbul to be overrated as a city and the historic area especially so. There are numerous cities that are nicer, and you do not need to fear both terrorism and take note locals local terrorism i.e. constant attempts by people to steal cameras and telephones and wallets, which we were told is the norm in this area. Therefore watch yourself and or choose a different city to visit.

What can I say that hasn't been saud...?. Been there twice and would go back in a heartbeat... and each time has been the same... walking around, getting lost, willingly, taking in the faces, the eyes, the colors, the smells, the flavors.... the memory of dates that melt in your mouth, of apricots so fragrant you think you've gone to heaven, of green peaches that taste like the first peach must have, all in the midst of houses and mosques that have endured the wear of time unscathed and faces that look older than time itself... that is Old Istanbul, the city I love, the melting pot... abandon yourself to it and you will be rewarded beyond dreams..

Site after sight of historical and architectural significance. So much in such a small area. Once Roman, then Christian now Muslim. The mix of cultures and history down the centuries is very evident. One of the must go to in my lifetime places.

Always a pleasure to visit.. No matter how many times you visit the city, there are places where you'd always find yourself hanging around, like the grand bazaar, the egyptian bazaar, the hanging bridge…

One of the Best Cities Anywhere. Before all the Us and Them and chop clop hate shop crap of nation states, Turks and Greeks and Muslims Jews Christians Sufis all lived together and GOT ALONG in this original cosmopolitan city. The hospitality is spectacular, the food divine. There is no hospitality like Turkish hospitality, and you will never step anywhere with so much blood and history in the soil. It is remarkable. But do scootch away from Sultenhamet and the touts to get into some really hospitable places....

Beautiful and magic place!. Istanbul is beautiful and extremely big- hard to see city borders even from atop of the hill! Much cleaner and more spacious than I imagined. Lots of beautiful, old architecture, not only this world renown. All historical places marked with obelisque-shape, lit in the dark posts with relevant description in few languages including English. It is very easy to get around, the best on foot as most attractions are walking distance from one another within a district. Between districts is good to take metro, tram or funicular. Lots of nice restaurants, I specially liked the ones with the buffet at the window, where one can choose whatever appeals the most. The meal is usually followed by free baclava! Loved shopping but as much as I recommend spending time in the Grand Bazaar which is beautiful and must be seen, I decided to spend my money elsewhere as the prices were much more acceptable. I recommend to make a trip by a cable car over the cemetery to the lovely historical cafe on the top of the hill- the views are amazing! Bosphorus trip is a must and area around Galata Tower is great for views, shopping- lots of small boutiques with very unusual clothes and accessories. Allow at least 3 hours for Topkapi Seray- we underestimated its size! Archeological Museum is amazing and needs at least 2 hours. Don't miss Basilica Cistern- very special experience! Don't hesitate to buy Museum Pass- it is really worth it, only 85 tl for 5 days allows free, skip the line entry to most attractions!

Walk everywhere and take it all in!. The fisherman, the birds, the stray but lovely dogs and cats, the smells, the call to prayer! Take a day to just walk from place to place throughout old Istanbul. Its so loveable.
Very busy and a true taste of Turkey.. The bazaar beside the blue mosque is not to be missed, everything on offer from clothes to curtains to shotguns!

history, history, history galore. My fav by far is the underground cistern which provided water to such a massive area. Topkapi is outstanding. Recommend, skipping the lines at the exhibit halls and going to the ones at the end first. Eat at Pudding Shop.

Excellent must visit place!. It's a excellent city, full of details and histories. Definitely, it's a very important city where you could learn a lot about how the cultures had mixed together y one point!

Be prepared . We arrived in Istanbul on a Sunday afternoon.Having looked at the map to find out the best way to get to our hotel, we plumped for the M1 train, changing at Zeytinburnu, transferring to the T1 tram to the stop nearest our hotel which was Beyazit.The plan was to buy a Istanbulkart at the train terminal…first mistake, they were not available there?We were standing at the top-up machine when this very nice young woman asked if she could help. We explained our problem and she then found out from the guard that they were not available, she then topped up her own card and proceeded to swipe us through the barriers, we offered to repay her, but she was having none of it, what a lovely gesture and much appreciated.At the cross over station, still no cards available, so we purchased a couple of tokens.When we tried to put them in the barrier, one of them didn't work!This time a nice young man stopped to help us and spoke to the guard to get us on the tram.The train & tram were packed and just when you thought the were bursting, more people get on at each of the following stations. You really do have to fight your way off when it is your stop. No one waits for you to get off before they try to get on…be prepared to push On another day, we were at Kabatas and boarded the T1 at the beginning, therefore getting a seat. Next to us were an Indian family. As the train went on, it got fuller and fuller. At one point, the Indian family (husband, wife, son & daughter) were all taken off their seats to make way for “locals” and not just elderly women!!! We were horrified!! One of the seats was taken by a middle aged local. At a further stop, a middle aged woman got on, ignored him, but expected me to give up my seat…against my natural instinct, I remained seated…he didn't move either!! What we found when travelling on a train/tram…if you are a foreigner, it is safer if you just stand from the start as the locals can be quite forceful, ignorant & rude if you are seated.We like to walk around on our city breaks, do a bit of window shopping and then doubling back when we decide what to buy.The shopping experience in Istanbul was an eye-opener!!It is impossible to stop and look in a window without someone trying to usher you inside. At first it was amusing but after a very short time it became waring and actually put us off even looking in a window…so much so, that we ended up buying next to nothing By the end of the holiday, we weren't even taking on the people trying to get us in their shop. What I did find was that they bothered you less if you wear sunglasses, I guess because they can't see your eyes?Having recently been to Budapest, where the people/transport/shopping/general feel of the place was EXCELLENT, Istanbul has been a bit of a wake up call and not for the faint hearted.My tip would be to buy an Istanbulkart when you can and take some of the ferries to the different ports, have a quick walk around (wearing sunglasses) and back on the ferry.Plan your sightseeing and stick to it, avoid the guys walking about who try and hustle you back to their families shop…after a few encounters, I just said to the guy I don't want what he is selling…he said “but you don't know what my family shop sells”…I said I don't care, I don't want it…”but we sell Viagra” was his reply…I shook his hand as that was a cracker There are some amazing sights, but make a plan and stick to it.If you do want to buy something, have an idea of the price you want to pay as nothing is priced.For me, this holiday was long enough in Istanbul, we arrived Sunday afternoon and left Wednesday morning!!!
it was the biggest empire at the time. i loved everything about the bizantine & ottomans, i knew that ataturk founded the moder turkish nation, but the amazing views i saw, never forget, never.

TURKEY - a must visit. I can't say enough how culturally enriching it was to visit Turkey. Istanbul was purely intoxicating, the architecture, city landscape was eye candy. Taking in the sights was overwhelming when you put it all the context, the age of the city, rich history of the Christians and Muslims. I must add that it would be a shame to only visit Istanbul. The rest of Turkey is just as beautiful, as are the people. I look forward to my next trip!

Bosforos journey. One of the world most magnificent place, water , culture, buildings, boats, birds, fish, every joyful things one can think about.By spending only 2-3 hours in the channel without feeling about time, you can convince yourself that the trip should last forever.
Istanbul is amazing. This area is very clean and nicely taken care. I was expecting it to be worse to be honest. People are friendly too.

Picturesque, highly animated and charming. Picturesque, highly animated and charming: the streets and historical buildings full of charm, the Bosphorus and the Golden Horn with their breeze and seagulls, the myriads of colours, are transporting the traveller in the Middle Age Constantinople-Istanbul.

Good overview of the city. Our tour group had a bus trip around the city, commencing with the "new city" which is 2000 years old! The Spice Market was closed due to a holiday. We saw a number of Mosques, the railway station where the Orient Express used to stop, the Old Wall on Kennedy Road (named after John F Kennedy after his assasination). From 395 - 453, this city was capital of the Byzantine Empire. It was a most interesting trip and particularly good if you only have a short time in this fascinating city. Later in the week, we did a further two bus trips, but independently, with taped information through headphones. We caught these two buses from Sultanahmet Square and both these trips were excellent too. One is the blue bus and the other the red bus. Cheaper if you buy the two at the one time, the evening before you want to use them.
One of the best City Break. I was in Istanbul for 3 days and I was very impressed of what I see there, if you go in Istanbul Istanbul you most go with the boat in the evening for a splendid sunset!

Awe inspiring!. Istanbul has so many amazing sights, the beautiful Mosques, the magical mystique of the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, the underground cistern, the spice market, the beautiful scenery inspired by the Bosporus! Just wondering around taking in the sights, via the warren of cobbled streets, a walk though the park, enjoying delicious food in one of many fabulous restaurants, the helpful friendliness of the people, all lead to a very memorable and soul soothing trip.

Beautiful!. I think Istanbul is one of the greatest cities! I really miss this beautiful city! I went there 2 times this year and I think I will choose Istanbul again as there are lots of places which I didn't have time to go to!

Spice Bazaar. If in Istanbul you must go to the spice bazaar the prices are comparably cheaper then the Grand Bazaar although the grand bazaar is much much bigger and full of jewellery shops along with all te other shops you can see in the spice Bazaar. Spice Bazaar is full of locals whereas the grand bazaar is full of tourists. The mannerism of the shop keepers is commendable. They are very welcoming, polite, understanding and are hospitable. Mind you you can bargain in these shops.I love the place and will be returning there next month with my family.

History Galore and Walkable. Staying at a hotel in the center of Istanbul insures a remarkable stay. It is possible to visit all sites by walking if advance planning is made, based on areas of the city and the times sites are open. The tram makes traveling easy if walking is not a good option.

Amazing History. Nowhere else can you be in Europe and Asia within one step!! So much to do 7 days was not enough good restaurants but if you don't like strong coffee stick to the tea!! Mosques were amazing and the Sulanhamet area great to visit. A must to go to the Grand Bazaar but if you want to be less overwhelmed and see all the same things, head to spice bazaar . beautiful historic place. It is very beautiful and interesting historic and beautiful new Experience. beautiful garden and yard nice view of the sea interesting Museum ..
Ancient sites. Step back in time. A history buffs dream. Ancient ruins, historical buildings and modern comforts. And affordable.

So much to do, so much to see in the historic area. There are so many fascinating places to see and visit in this area -- Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Archaeological Museum, the cistern, the Spice Bazaar, and so forth. If time is limited and weather permitting. be selective. Be aware of particular days when an attraction is closed, and check for admission fees.
Old city. Amazing old city. The mosque and Haj were very impressive. Everyone friendly there were no problems in the least. We really enjoyed our visit
Felt at home. Must have lived here in a previous life wonderful, exciting , place loads to do and see, have been about 3 times know and would go again.
Fishermen around. Very historical place, great city even in Winter. A lot of people fishing, a lot of things to see. Even locals unable to talk in English, they are very helpful in giving directions.

A secret turkey....they really delivered. I booked - a magnificent turkey - tour starting in Istanbul. The tour would stay at a different 5 star hotel each night. travelling ever westwards and southwards towards Gallipoli, then crossing the dardanelles strait to cannakale for the visit to Troy. Then down south to Ephesus ; Hierapolis/pammukale travertines and south over the snowcapped taurus mountains to antalya.Our guide Miss Renan Saylag (Reni) was extremely knowledgeable of the sites on the tour and she had an encyclopaedic knowledge of Turkey in general.Our driver Ahmed was good. Both were with us throughout the week and the customer service from them was first class.The coach was comprised of 25 passengers ; over 60s ; a couple who required assistance.. Brill guide and driver- cant praise them enough.The Istanbul Hotel ; I only got to see after midnight and in the early hours but that was because turkish airlines had cancelled my early flight but this was not the fault of -- a secret turkey/Hays--Indeed this meant that our guide and driver were also put out and could not get to their beds before 0100 am either.My first bad impression was changed when we visited the sultanahmet square, the blue mosque..beautiful. the historic hagia sofia...magnificent and the beautiful topkapi palace..a boat trip aalong the bosphorus towards the black sea ended the day, then off to our hotel incorlu, tekirdag. an excellent 5 star hotel with good food and acceptable wifi. Room standards in all the hotels were excellent but the hotels further south had poor wi-fi and food was not good.Lunch on the road however was really good every day.We visited the thought provoking battlefield of Gallipoli and then crossed the Dardanelles straits to Troy. There were some sceptics in the group but their input on Troy was well out of date.There isnt a lot there but I appreciated every aspect.I was disappointed.in that the wooden horse donated by the film company for the Brad Pitt movie was not to be seen as I expected from the company's pictures.Instead the unrealistic horse /shed was there on its own.As it was winter , Ephesus, that I had visited before was less crowded. So I got many photos and saw things I did not see on my first visit.Forgot to mention..winter in Istanbul.five layers of clothing , hat , gloves . scarves required... - 9 degrees c , extremely cold. so dont be fooled by previous summer visits.North of the south coastal taurus mountains, you might as well be in scandinavia, weatherwise.My third visit to Hierapolis and Pammukale. Still a worthwhile visit. I missed out the theatre that I'd previously seen; unlike my travelling companions who did not see it as well. it is up a steep hill ,having said that; and on very rough ground.The travertines of Pammukale on the slopes below the town are still a wonder.There followed the compulsory ; turkish government dictated tours to ljewellery leather and carpet shops and wine tasting.We then continued south through the taurus mountains to touristic Antalya for our last afternoon. All in all , a worth while and excellent value trip. A good guide can make all the difference. I once travelled to Israel on a russian tour bus and understood nothing. so I know.Thanks again Reni.
Loved it!. An incredible place to go! I will never forget it! Great views and lots of history... Everything is safe and cleand. And the Turkish people are very very friendly.
overall satisfied. my first visit to Istanbul gave a great satisfaction with a big feeling that i should go back in the near future.
Lovely Instanbul. Instanbul is beautiful city. Charming and lovely. I was very impressed when I entered Blue Mosque and St Sophia cathedral. Highly recommend it .
historic Istanbul. We are very experienced travellers and this city would have to be one of our favourites.The people the food and the sights are unbeatable
fabulous. I got a private tour for about $200-$250, and it was well worth it! The guide took me all over, and went at whatever speed I wished. he was fabulous!
Sultanahmet has it all. If you want to visit historic areas, just reach SultanAhmet distruct and you have a range of these places in this on neighbourhood.
Begin Here. This part of Istanbul ( Old Town/Byzantine) is where one should begin. Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar to name a few. Most probably you;ll need a full day ( at least..)

Thank you Metin Yilmaz. We did a walking tour of Istanbul with Metin Yilmaz from Chora Travel on the day of the bombing in Istanbul in January. We were all deeply shocked and saddened by this terrible event, however Metin is to be congratulated for the care and concern he took with us on that day. Metin is a wonderful, knowledgeable guide with a big heart. Thank you Metin.

As elegant as Europe at half the price.. I loved this part of Istanbul - the Blue and other Mosques with their distinctive many-domed style, the awesome presence of Hagia Sofia, the colourful Grand Bazaar, the ancient Roman cistern and so much else. The quaintly paved streets and street-side shops. If you are going from India, the currency parity is such that everything looks reasonably-priced and there is much you would like to buy. Ending the day with dinner at a pavement cafe. Amazing food.

Historic area of Istanbul. I never get bored from visiting those areas , especially the historical places around the Sultan Ahmed park . I love the old streets of the area and the small restaurants and bistros . I love the hospitality and the happy atmosphere all around . I love all the small businesses and the seriously professional people doing all kind of businesses from tourism to commerce . I love the small old buildings in narrow old streets turned into hotels and hostels . I love the " very alive " area , day and night , summer and winter , under full sun and under heavy snow . I love the historical mosques minarets always standing there ,for hundreds of years, overlooking the bosphorus . I love the smell of roasted chestnuts and baked corn . I hope Istanbul never changes , except for the best . I love you Istanbul and wish to live there .

Beautiful in the summer. We visited Istanbul for a weekend in August and were treated to a quick fire tour of the city. Dubbed the city "where east meets west", Istanbul has a fascinating history and various influences from both Asia and Europe.

Need you ask? One of the cradles of civilization. Something for art lovers, architect lovers, exotica, the Grand Bazaar, the spice bazaar, Galata Tower, wonderful cafes and restaurants, accessible by public transportation, ferry trips to the Bosphorus, the Edward Islands - I could go on and on... (stay away from the baths, we found them to be probably overly expensive and you can do better elsewhere... but that's a personal decision.) You can read lots about these sites. If you are wondering whether it is worth the bother, please don't hesitate - it is !! You don't need me to describe the sites.. You need me to tell you if it's worth the visit....
Great place to be.. wonderful historic sites tha tput you in a age of the Ottoman empire as well as the Byzantine era. If you love history this is the place to visit.
Mesmerizing. I have lived in Istanbul for a year and still when I went there about two weeks ago, I found it still enchanting. If you can go to this city, please go.
Hippodrome . We had a great tour of these historic sites . Our tour guide Ozzie was so knowledgeable about the area sites. What a great time.

all of it is beautiful. All historic areas of Istanbul are amazing. It's clean. The locals are respectful and it's safe. No burglars, no pick pockets. There aren't homeless in parks or streets. The only beggars we saw were refugees.
Where history of east meet west. walking in Istanbul, you can feel walking to the past. its like time traveling. this city has a lot to show you.

Amazing. I cannot begin to tell you how great these older parts of Istanbul are. Everyone talks of thieves etc around this area but if you are about during the day nothing happens. A city for the ages. One amazing thing about Istanbul is how many of the main sites are so close together. This makes it easy to see a it in a few days if you choose to. A city of many layers.. An ancient city at the crossroads of Europe and Asia, so rich in history, so lively. Walk along the streets with a smile, hang out with the locals: you will fall in love with Istanbul.

Great mix. If u some one who loves to see mixed sights I think you should visit this place because u will like alot Big likes to you Istanbul

Unforgettable City. We seldom re do many cities as there are still so many places to visit. But Istanbul is one city which we don't mind visiting again and again. There's so much to see and do. Great for sight seeing!. What a city, lots of history over the centuries, parts are still under developed and old fashioned but tourism has taken it's hold. Some locals welcome this, others not, part and parcel of history and cultural differences.

Old city istanbul . history-steeped city. a very old city. Eminönü Bosphorus is great. Serenity and a city that date. See the Galata Tower of Istanbul seemed beneath my feet. A truly unique city. everywhere smells Ottoman

Sultanahmet hosts the Hagia Sophia Museum, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern. The culturally rich Sultanahmet area is not to be missed. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Cistern can be visited in one afternoon. The Blue Mosque is active with prayers being said at various times of the day and respect for the faith, including a dress code applies to all visitors. Hagia Sophia is a museum and does not adhere to the strict ruling of no shorts and women's head coverings to be worn. The cistern is a must see and take the time to admire the Roman arches built in the 6th century during Justinian's rule. There are many coffee shops and food stalls in the area. Beware of 'tour' guides and people pestering tourists to buy their perfumes etc.

A city with a history. It is a city of interest if you are a Christian or Muslim. Unlike the Western world, they present the history as it is without political correction. If you do not belong to these religious groups, it is still a worthwhile visit just for the various historical sights. Foods are great and I recommend spending your money on smaller restaurant. Really no point spending big money on expensive restaurant. People are friendly but seems that everyone wants you to buy rugs from them.
Mesmerizing neighborhood!. Beautiful to walk through the historic buildings in the Sultanahmet area.I particularly enjoyed the Cistern-
Rich cultural places. Taksim aerea is an excelent point to explorer the principals historical places of Istanbul (Old Constantinopla).

Finding a new perspective. For many of us, Istanbul is the exotic centre of a different world we have only dreamt of. The history provides a different view of the world and will be challenging and enticing for most. I love this city and have been there five times over some years. Each visit provides a new perspective and it is fascinating to watch new developments emerge alongside the ancient streets and neighbourhoods. A trip on the Bosphorous provides a good overview from the water and some sense of the geography of the place. The grand market, Turkish Baths, old palaces and mosques are all part of the wonder of Istanbul.
You have to visit. Really nice area to walk around and explore. Shops, restaurants and just go there for an experience.
New year in Istanbul. Prices of drinks in restaurants on the Galata bridge are very unfriendly. Firework was very poor. But it was nice to see snow in Istanbul.

Things to do in Istanbul. Istanbul- there is no need for further explanations. The history this city provide you with is exceptional! The vikings called the city Miklagård. We bought a Istanbul card and went with the underground från Ataturk (change to tram no T1 at zeytinburnu) to Sultanahmet. We started off with a visit at the basilikum cicterns which was an marvelous experience. Next door you have the blue mosk and hagia Sofia. Behind Hagia Sofia you'll find the Topcapi palace with a lot of landmarks. We also had dome time left at our stop over to vidit the grand Basar ( if you like shopping snd barging). A great stop over snd all in 8 hours.

New year in Istanbul. A lot of historical places are concentrated in one district. This is very convenient! You can use tram T1 to get there or metro ( Aksaray station, but you will need to walk a little bit). Also you can buy special card for visiting museums. Such card will costs 85 tl and it gives you a possibility to enter different museums (except Galata tower and Basilica cistern) for free during 72 hours. It is very profitably.

Historic Quarter - visit to the past. Our private guide Zeki guided us through the historic quarter "feeding" us with historical facts, stories and anecdotes which made the visit very interesting and entertaining at the same time.
Great historic places to visit. Very well maintained historic places , Great access and displays. Very well preserved. even with a heavy load of visitors the places are well maintained and clean
lovely!. Sultanhamet is the historical part of old Istanbul with lots of Mosques (beautiful ones too) ….Roads are tiny and hilly and curvy …but very nice . lovely place to stay while in istanbul

One of the most mesmerizing cities on earth. We loved Istanbul and explored as best we could in three days. It is truly an amazing city packed with culture, music, art and picturesque views. The food is also amazing, delicious and healthy.

Fascinating history, beautiful for strolling. We stayed in Istanbul for 12 days. We never ran out of things to do and we never repeated anything except a quick market trip. And there are still things we left undone too! Rome may be the eternal city, but her twin has proven she's up to that challenge!

Very interesting . I booked a walking tour of the Historical highlights of Istanbul and thoroughly enjoyed it. It was a great way to spend a day in the city. I ended up walking around the Sultanahmed area after the tour and found the area quite safe. People were very helpful and friendly.
Awesome. This was one of the most beautiful cities i have been to, the combination of blue waters, land and mountains together is something one cant miss. Must vist!!!
interesting. it was so interesting. shops and people are good. metro is everywhere and you can also use bus. taxi is so expensive and are not trustworthy. but it worths indeed.
Colourfull. Historic areas of is Istanbul is very colourfull. There you may visit Grand Bazar, beautiful mosques and many places to see. in Grand bazar you feel the odor of spices.

Large, interesting.... We walked a lot around the historic areas and spend a lot of time researching. One cen never see everything here, especially not if you don't live or have a good guide to take you around. Fortunately, we got lost a few times and managed to see the markets used by the locals, and the residential areas of Istanbul :) It was rather interesting and nice!

Soul entertaining . From the eastern Rome until osman kings and atta turk here you can see what is the difference and what is common in all civilizations,you can feel your soul go through the history deep and come back to today, this city is a geopolitical place and all the powers have an eye on it.be sure about visiting mosques you can find Christian art and Islamic together.

Perfect way to spend a day or three. Lots to see and do in terms of markets, mosques and narrow winding streets with cute little shops and others full of tourist "treasures". Otherwise you can sit at one of the many little cafes or fruit juice bars and just watch the world go by. Great way to relax.

Beautiful City. Historic Areas of Istanbul is one of the most amazing area in Istanbul.... All the historical monuments is just near by .Very nice location in terms of entertainment and food..... plan your trip .... you ll never regret ...

Everything is so close and so lovely. People, places, food, sites are all here in a very accessible area of town. I find little to dislike about Istanbul and keeping all the fun together in a cozy section of town works for even the most inexperienced traveler. Especially with the Metro it makes it easy and cheap to get anywhere.

Nice place to stroll around. Nice area to take a walk, get som food or a chai or just smell the history, I was there during wintertime, so it was a little cold. I think it would have been amazing to visit this place during the summer.
Great!. Super amazing, totally recommend! Istanbul is absolutely beautiful, and this is definitely worth it to go.

Amazing History in Istanbul!. Many of the architecture in Istanbul is designed and built by Armenians mainly the Balyan Family! This city is naturally beautiful and with the amazingly historical structures that Armenians have built it is even more amazing!

Very beautiful, packed with the great historical sights. It is a very beautiful area packed with many historical and cutural sights.
Most places are easy to reach within walking distance.
Anyway walking around opens many beautiful views on the sights and lets you feel a part of Istanbul.
We recommend to have comfortable shoes with you to enjoy walking as much as possible.

Istanbul oozes of history...... the grand palaces, mosques, monuments from the Ottoman, Roman and Greek civilizations.... add to it, the markets and bazars and hamams.... its all make for a tourist's delight.....

All within walking distance from each other. The thing I appreciated most with Istanbul is that all the major attractions in the Historic Area are within a 5 minute walk - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Archeological Museum, Gulhane Park, Hippodrome (with the German Fountains and Obelisk)! Never have I been to a city with this many attractions within a square kilometer from each other. Lovely Istanbul...and that they were able to preserve these treasures is what makes it astounding.

Istanbul/ Constantinople IS History !. We took the Big Bus Tour and saw everything from the Blue Mosque, Hagie Sofia, Tarim Shopping, Doma Bachie Palace, Istanbul Mall, Galatia Tower, the wall, the Bhospors, Istanbul is history !

Walk around and enjoy the view. All the main attractions are within walking distance and public transportation using buses and tram is easy.Stay somewhere in sultanahmet to make use of the best spots. Enjoy turkish food and overcrowded markets. Foods to Try:-Baklava - a Turkish sweet Non veg - KebabsTurkish Tea, Turkish CoffeeKumpir - a loaded baked potatoTavuk Göğsü - Turkish chicken breast puddingBörek - a traditional Turkish pastry made of flaky doughLokum - Turkish delightAyran - national drink in Turkey and it is a cold yogurt beverage with saltDoner - a dish made with meat cooked on a spinning vertical rotisserieLahmacun - considered to be the Turkish equivalent of pizzaDondurma - Turkish Ice cream. Also known as MaraşPomegranate juice
A world center of great value. Embraces Asia in one hand and Europe on the other. A lot to do, so many places to see, amazing food. Travelled in 2013

Mesmerizing. Your experience is not complete unless you get a fish dinner under the bridge (or just enjoy the scenery with a tea, coffee or beer), eat a simit from a local vendor, and try your hand at haggling with the locals for that just perfect trinket.

3 day stay in Instanbul. We stayed in historic Istanbul with my husbands family. Great action destination. We walked or took the tram to all the must see attractions. Highlights include the grand bazaar and Hagia Sofia.
Love it. This mix of orient and western.The history if this city ..the people the food the call for prayers...simply great ilove Istanbul
istanbul attractions. a busy and bustling city, with plenty to see and do. all the main attractions are well worth a visit not cheap but you are in a city after all
Istanbul a magic city. What an exiting city, very crowded but easy too manage, public transportation is easy, great food. You will not regret expending a few days in Istanbul there is so much to see.

Walking to see past and present. We started at Taksim square and walked back to the tram down the hill from Galata tower. What a neat walk, a chance to see modern Istanbul along side some of its greatest traditions.

An ancient museum with real people and real life. This new European part of Istanbul represents the old being lived out everyday! We enjoyed the real street kebab under the Galata Tower, in the midst of noise from the streets.

Watch and talk to the locals. We walked from the Hagia Sophia to take a Bosphorus cruise. Along the way was the Topkapi Palace, Spice Market, the train station where the Orient Express comes into,and the Cisterns. Too much to see in a day. Just sit in one spot to watch the local activity or have a chat with a local. This is one city where I felt perfectly safe speaking to anyone.

stay in Old City part where most of the sites are. Beautiful atmosphere .Lots to see and to do .In December it was wonderfully relaxed. You should read up on your history before you arrive. You must bring an empty bag and buy all your clothes here . Wonderful cultural exhibits and a boat trip onto the Bosphorous is a must . Lovely people. Tram and Metro system is easy to get around with a card . Mostly we walked to everything to really soak up the atmosphere. Lots of cats and dogs lazing around too which is amusing .

Istanbul Stopover Tour. As there are so many great historic, colourful, beautiful and magnificent places, all in close proximity to one another, central Constantinople is a place you can easily make a light visit in a few hours, and yet, you can visit many times or many days without exhausting the tantalizing experience. Top places include:The Blue Mosque, the Haggia Sophia, the Hippodrome, the Basilica Cistern, the Baths, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Bazaar, the Galata Bridge (laden with seafood restaurants), the Topkapi Palace with its Museums, Gardens and Grounds.And there are lots of places to experience the traditional turkish meals; a delight to the palette any day.

open air museum. walked from Dolmebace through Taksim Square to the balata tower and bridge, the Spice market, and back towards to the Grand Bazaar and Blue Mosque area...people watching, the fishermen on the bridge, the floating kitchen boats, the hustle and bustle of commuters, the spice market and vendors- everything was mind blowing. Take comfy shoes and plenty of cash .

"...Romantic City...". Hi there,Istanbul is a city the straddles 2 continents. It is here that the charms of the Europes meet the mysteries of the Asias. If you listen carefully, you may actually hear the cries of the Roman Soldiers manning the City Walls against the constant attacks of the Ottomans. If you lucky enough, you may even “see Caesar travel with his procession back to Rome on the King’s Road.”Having returned from a 5 night trip to Istanbul, i present my account below.- We initially booked hotel transfers from airport. It was R 2,200.- I researched the net and found the tram a convenient way to travel from the Ataturk Intl Airport to the hotel (hotel reviewed) in Aksaray.- This cost me R 140 return for 2 adults. We only bought 1 Istanbulkart.- The train station at the airport is very easy to find.- Maps are easy to follow and boards are well marked.- Further the people are extremely friendly and will assist if you ask for directions.- It helps to learn very basic Turkish as well.- We got off at the train station and walked for about a kilometre to our hotel.- I highly recommend using the metro as it is reasonably priced, convenient and very easy to follow.- In my time there, we visited the following:1. Landed and checked in (17:00) - Day 12. Blue Mosque - Day 23. Topkapi Palace - Day 24. Sofia Hagya - Day 25. Hippodrome - Day 2 (came back as there was a marathon and could not enjoy the beauty of the obelisks.6. Grand Bazaar - Day 37. Spice Bazaar - Day 38. Eminonu (enjoying the views and snacks - Day 39. Bhosphorous Cruise - Day 310. Dolmabache’ Palace - Day 411. Galata Tower views - Day 412. Walked around Kadikoy and across Galata Bridge – Day 413. Theodosian Walls - Day 414. Basillica Cistern - Day 415. Turkish Hamman - Day 5(Went to Sofular Hamman, it cost TL 50 pp and we gave a tip as well. Truly authentic Turkish Bath experience. We don’t speak Turkish (except basic) and the staff do-not speak English. This added to the surreal experience of the trip. I highly recommend this as opposed to the Baths in the tourist places. Wife ensured that we found the “kesse” in the local markets, used in the bath to take back home)16. Grand Bazaar – last minute shopping17. Hippodrome - Day 5Prices of a Doner Kepab in Sultanahmet is +- TL 10. In Aksaray it was TL 3 for the same meal Same logic applicable to Turkish Delight.One would appreciate Istanbul more if they understand the History behind Constantinople, Roman Empire and the Ottoman Empire. It took us about 3 hours in Topkapi Palace and 3 hours in Sofia Hagia each due to the rich history attached to each building. The Hippodrome took about an hour, purely because I generally try to go back in time and imagine what it felt like to have been one of 100,000 spectators watching the chariots race passed. It is almost nostalgic to be looking at an Obelisk that was most likely gifted by Cleopatra (Pharaoh of Egypt) to the Roman Empire. Some much history, so much time had passed…..and yet I am only a metre away from it!Further, be adventurous. Try the simit, try the grilled figs, try the mealies, try the fish and bread etc. these are great wholesome and filling snacks at reasonable pricing. Istanbul is an excellent tourist destination.I planned this trip without use of a tour company or GPS to find my way. All I carried was a map book – sensing an adventure.In summary, special thanks to Enigma – my friend. Your information posted in assisting other travellers, assisted my wife and i as well. I felt almost as if you were with us on the trip!!!
Bosphorus area. so many things to see, experience, love, enjoy in this area, things won't be forgotten.I had lovely time there.
Well Worth the UNESCO Designation. The historic area of Istanbul is amazing and important. It's much like Rome, but less chaotic. There's a wonderful authenticity to the city, well worth the visit.

All in one area. As the Hagia Sophia; Basilica Cistern; Topkapi Palace; Blue mosque and Hodjpasha Whirling dervishes/cultural shows (after 6 please book)are all in the same area they can all be completed in a single day. Buy a pass with 4 or 5 monuments which u can complete together children require passes too.
Amazing city. Istanbul is a beautiful city. Easy to get around to all the attractions. Good food and friendly residents

Well worth a visit. Istanbul, and the historical parts around Sultanahmet, remains as one of my favourite cities and somewhere which makes for a great stopover whilst enroute somewhere else. Decent accommodation at reasonable prices, good food and plenty of interesting sites to see all in close proximity. I'll be back!
See the old stuff!. DO take the time to see the historic districts in Istanbul. Around each corner is a hidden mosque or tea seller that you'll miss if you race through the city.

really worth a visit!. There is so much to see.... particularly if you are into history... this area 'oozes' history! Everywhere you look, ancient buildings and history looks back at you. It is worth getting on one of the water ferries to see this area from some distance. There are also plenty of cafes in this area to let your hours pass-by.
Very picturesque and beautiful. Very picturesque , beautiful and romantic place. A mixture of Middle east and EUROPE... Lovely place.. A Must visit place !

Wow an underground city waiting to be explored. Amazing experience in history .
my kids and i havent seen anything like this in our lives and we were staying at a small hotel tight behind blue mosque, called Fides and the hotel educated us on sights to explore in Sultanahmet area.
So much to discover and cover.
History lesson

Lovely place. Istanbul is primarily known for its Byzantine and Ottoman architecture, but its buildings reflect the various peoples and empires that have previously ruled the city. Examples of Genoese and Roman architecture remain visible in Istanbul alongside their Ottoman counterparts.

"Istanbul" A heaven for Historic Places Lovers. Istanbul is just filled with historic places which are very well kept and maintained by the Turkish authorities while maintaining their Pace of Progress. There are so many museums, amazing palaces, bosphorus attractions.

Istanbul . Istanbul was on my to do list for so long now that it's done it is on my to do with no delay again!
Stayed at the Pera Palace, walked and walked and never got enough...

Awesome history . You really need a guide to uncover the absolute treasure trove of amazing ottoman history in the city. If you don't have a guide you can do it yourself - use books but it's half the fun.
Magical Istanbul. So much to see and do. The bustling city is the backdrop for a range of museums, markets and mosques. I can't wait to return for a longer trip.
Great. Its lovely very well organised and has allot of history to see. I dont think the time we spent was enough and i am sure we willl visit it again

Many historic sites to stop by in a walking distance. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Serpentine Column, German Fountain are all within walking distance. With New mosque, The Spice Bazaar, Galata bridge on the east, Grand Bazaar on the North in 15~20 minute walk, or 2~3 tram stops, Sultanahmet - Eminönü part of Fatih district would be one of the most condensed area, maybe comparable to a district in Rome, with historic sites worth visiting. Don't forget to stop by under the Galata bridge for a quick snack of famous Grilled Mackerel Sandwich, which is surprisingly interesting.
One of the best cities. It's really amazing.its full of history and culture.its one of my he places where you can come back all the time.all of the places are worth visiting.a lot of things to see.

Amazing Culture. When I decided to visit Istanbul I received a lot of negative feedback from my family and friends. With all the latest incidents in Turkey lately it was portrayed that it would not be a safe choice at the moment. But we decided to go along with our original plan and include Istanbul as our first stop of our European tour. After my visiting this great city, I have nothing but warm feelings for this place and the people! To begin with we felt safe at all times and there was no trace of what we heard about on the news. Extraordinary architecture influenced by the east and the west! Extraordinary cultural heritage as seen through the monuments and sights. We were fascinated by the simple living of the people of Istanbul. We collected memorable images such as the men who were fishing from Galata Bridge. Another aspect of our visit was the quality of food which was top-notch. The area where we found the many places to eat was Beyoglu. We enjoyed kebabs at local restaurants like Zubeyir Ocakbasi, but the best part was the deserts. Also do not miss out on the fresh stuffed clams which you can buy from a street vendor. Istanbul is a beautiful and culturally rich city I would definitely recommend visiting again.

The heart of Istanbul. This is a group of sites in the old city area of Istanbul, which are collectively referred to as Historic Areas of Istanbul . These areas were added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1985.To me,this was the most interesting part of Istanbul visit. It such a pleasure to walk down ancient alleys which are lined with historical sites all through. This area includes world famous structures such as the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, etc.

The city overall is incredible!. The city is a real adventure from special foods, shopping, touring. Everyone must do the baths, that is a must because it is fabulous . The daily adventure is never ending, the people in the hotel are wonderful to direct you to fun things to do during the day and to see . Your hotel and set up a tour guide for you if you would like that which is a wonderful thing to do some of the days. We had the whole family there and it was a great adventure for everyone. Traffic is congested so simply allow yourself time to get where you're going . Learn how to use the transit system, it's great. We cannot wait until our next visit.
Amazing, must see!. Amazing, loved everything in Istanbul, a wonder of the planet. Vibrant, all go, new and old, it's people incredible

Taksim Square. Do visit this and you can enjoy a tram ride to Galata Tower. Good shopping experience for shoppers. Reaching this place is easy using Metro which is quite fast. One good thing in Turkey is Public Transport is well connected and value for Time and Money.

Worth to see. The Historic Areas of Istanbul is a group of sites in the city of Istanbul, Turkey; these areas were added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1985.This World Heritage Site includes structures such as the Sarayburnu, the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Hagia Irene, Zeyrek Mosque, Süleymaniye Mosque, Little Hagia Sophia and the Walls of Constantinople.

An area filled with wonder and amazement . From the blue mosque to hagia Sofia and everything in between this area is one of the unofficial wonders of the world. The clash between culture's ,religion and contintents is everywhere you turn. All within walking distance and easy access by tram from different parts of this bustling city. A must for any decerning traveller with a love of ancient history

Impressive city. In combination with a business trip I had the opportunity to visit the impressive historic city of Istanbul. Guided by my Turkish colleagues visited the different buildings and landmarks. Learned the old and rich history of Constantinopel, the Orient Express, the Ottoman Empire and transformation to the modern city.Was impressed and looking forward to my next visit with my family.

Wonderful place to visit. Istanbul more than lived up to our expectations. So much to see. We visited the Basillica which was awe inspiring. Also visited The Blue Mosque and several other museums and places of interest while there. Unforgettable.

old Istanbul. all cities on the world has an old part where first accomadation started. and all that areas are telling real history of the city. thats why tourists go there to understand culture. this is it for Istanbul. Old Istanbul. go there and feel the history.

Much of the history of the Western World happened here.. From the first Greek settlement to Nova Roma, the Byzantine Empire, the Ottoman ascendency, and the birth of modern Turkey. A lot about each can be understood in this area of Istanbul. The Hippodrome is open to all, and is the best starting point.

Kiwi in Istanbul. Chora Museum is a must see, stayed at the Niles Hotel which is a quaint, boutique hotel near the city rail circuit, loved the cisterns for their link with 007 as well as their beauty.Take a brolly, visit the bazaar, enjoy the views.

Must see!. If you are in Istanbul, it is a must! Istanbul is all about history, but for sure even more than that. Still you need to start from somewhere and this is the best thing to do. You will understand much better the city itself later, as well as many other things around you.
Blue mosque. very very good and unforgettable experience to see this huge Blue mosque!!!! I have eager to see again Istanbul..

Romantic atmosphere. We toured Istanbul for several hours with a guide organised during our cruise stay. No sense of threat from anywhere and the variuous prime sites to visit were all worth the visit.

Everything is there!. This areas has almost all of the tourists attractions of Istanbul; Hagia Sofia,Eminonu square, Gand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Sultanahmet mosque, Galata bridge, Golden Horn and Bosphorus river pier meet here; Galata Tower is visible from a long distance. It is situated on a hill near Bosphorus river. Beautiful Bosphorus river is also visible. Many shops and restaurant are there around this attraction.All need to walk for hours to see all the attractions .These areas are very near to city center; it is very very easy to go by public bus or by tram. From airport taxi is the bets transport though a bit expensive, better to take taxi then change it at a metro station and then tram.

An eternal city. When you come to Istanbul you realise that this is an eternal city. This is were the first "immigrants" to Europe came, across the narrow Bosphorus, or even before there was a Bosphurus. Since then millions of people har traversed this place, lived her, marvelled her and sighed at both her charm and her hectic lifestyle. In the historical areas of Istanbul you will se both monuments and museum unlike anywhere else, but you will also be able to walk the street of old houses, now mostyle renovated and meet the real people of Istanbul.Don't be afraid to leave the wider tourist treks for more genuine streets. Here people will say hello and, of course, carpet sellers by the dozen will be your friend. Say no politely - or yes if I want a carpet - and there will not problem.This is a nice place, not so crowded as you may think (we were there in December, though, low season) and not as dangerous as you might think.
Wander the streets for the best experience. Wander by vendors, small community mosques, and beautiful architecture to get your taste of the city!

Most visit. i can't describe this city, one of my favorite destination, the history surround you, very romantic and amazing place its half European and half Asian which is make it unique, i love it and cant wait to visit Istanbul again its rich in historical areas.

All good. I was expecting Istanbul to be very similar to Marrakesh, though I was wrong. Istanbul is very developed and much cleaner than Morocco. There is a well developed tram system and it is very clean. The main souk does not have the rawness and filth of Marrakesh, and it is very well kept.

"Enjoy this vibrant City". I was a little apprehensive about visiting Istanbul because all the chaos in that region of the world, but after my visit, I just have great things to say about this amazing city, and its people. If you are thinking about joining the long Bosphorus tour, please reconsider it. After taking that tour, I would recommend you to take the short ride. There some other short distance tours you can enjoy on your own.

Istanbul is an amazing city - I was very impressed by it overall.. The people are kind and there is an energy here - it is very vibrant and busy. There are a few beggars which is sad but there are beggars in London too. We were never pestered by anyone and felt totally safe the whole time. It is culturally rich and exciting - the food was great and your money goes a long way. I definitely recommend a trip to Istanbul.

Great location to stay or at least visit. We stayed in middle of Sultanahmet and found it great as a central place to walk to most places and/or catch the trams (also good to take to airport as long as your don't have too many bags) which easily get you all around to most things on the list of things to do.

Take time to wander. We stayed near the Blue Mosque and walked around that lower area of the old city and did not get though half what there is to see - the cistern, Hagia Sophia, just the old streets and shops are fun to walk down and the main bazaar is nearby. I think you could easily spend a couple of days enjoying and appreciating what there is to see in this part of town - there are so many eating places to choose from. We plan a longer stop next time.
Galata Tower, best place to see the old city. Don't miss the fancy caffes, vintage shops on Serdarı Ekrem Street, take some nice photos on the top of Galata Tower

The place to see History!. All you need is a good map (or even without one!), a bottle of water and a good pair of walking shoes and then you can walk your way through this amazing part of the city of Istanbul.There are so many sights within this area - Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Islamic Art Museum, etc. are all within walking distance of each other. You can sit just outside the Blue Mosque and can see the nice waterfall outside and spot Aya Sofia at the same time.The Hippodrome, German Fountain and Serpent's Column are all on the same stretch.There is a free art museum near the Serpents Column - most of the art has been created by University Students - definitely worth a visit!Arasta Bazaar is also very close - but prices aren't great. I found the Spice Bazaar to have the best prices out of all the bazaars.I've been to Istanbul twice and I still have so much to do and see. Looking forward to my 3rd visit soon, I hope!

The Golden Historical District. Never, will you see so much history in one place as you see in the Golden Horn of Istanbul. You could spend one or two full days or even three days, depending on the depth you want to go to.

An amazing city - Constantinople - the heart of the former Ottoman Empire. The whole city on the European city is like one big museum. I recommend staying in Pera. Most tourists can be found where the churches, mosques and museums are. Sultan Ahmet area. Not for me. Pera is authentic where the people of the city can be found. Whirling Dervishes too!

WOWWW. Istanbul is beautiful and the historic area is magnificent. Full of amazing attractions. You can walk from an attraction to another. You must see Ayasofya, Mavi Cami (Blue Mosque), Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar and many others. You'll love this area.
very nice. h hope to visit it again , its nice peace great country i like it so mush , nice weather and nice food

Simply amazing. when you are in Istanbul you really wish to walk and just walk ...no taxi no car cos there is something amazing in each corner. It is full of old palaces and mosques and amazing architecture.

Unique place. Nowhere else can you experience the history and sociology of the world's two largest religions come alive like this, simply walking around. Seeing the organic shift from pagan Byzantium to Christian Constantinople and then Muslim Istanbul first-hand is truly staggering.

Visited the Blue Mosque.. Again has very beautiful architecture and indeed looks "blue" from a distance. The mosque is open to visitors of any faith, except during prayer times. Ladies are expected to wear a headscarf while entering the mosque and gents have to be properly attired.
A photographers's delight. The views are simply breathtaking... imagine a combination of the ancient world, the ottoman era and the modern era all blending into one

A nice mixture of cultures and ages. Collisions of East and West, of Islam and Christian, of ancient and modern coexist at the same time. This is a very attractive area with a strong taste of time but without lack of vivid life. Historical heritage, cafes, restaurants, parks, old residential areas, and shops are mixed very well.
Its Beautiful. Istanbul is beautiful and very much tourist friendly. Very clean city and many points to visit....a perfect combination of.History and modern.

History Everywhere. Sultanahmet is the place to start any tour by seeing Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, a collection of musea, the plaza between the great musea, and so much more. The area is vibrant, packed and picturesque.

Amazing city vibrant, full of culture and friendly people.. Where to start in Istanbul. There is so much to see and do. Just walking around this part of the city offers a glimpse of the endless possibilities that this city has to offer. Culture architecture religion food and atmosphere fantastic!!
Must do in Istanbul. I think Istanbul is all about these historical areas. It may need up to one week of compressed sightseeing, to cover only old city, Taksim area, Galata area and Besiktas area.

Istanbul is Top City for Visiting. Istanbul is simply amazing and awesome. From beautiful sights, to multi cultural experiences and heritages make this place simple stunning. The sights of Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace, the Bosphorus Straits, the shopping and not forgetting the food. Transport is easy and people are friendly and mostly english speaking. This is a must visit destination for anyone.
Worth a visit. A lovely vibrating and cosmopolitan city. Lots to see and do. Millennia of history. and the views from the old town are terific

A journey through time!. It is quite the experience just to walk through this area and see the heritage around.The Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome, the Topkapi palace all give you a view to what would have been. The area is great just to walk around and spend a day either admiring the architecture or finding a guide to take you on a journey through time.Highly recommended!

Civilization Revealed. The history of Istanbul can be a bit overwhelming at times as it spans thousands of years. We were in Istanbul for 12 days and I was frustrated that we simply could not take it all in, and I planned the trip for nine months! Every nook and cranny there are historic areas with their own stories to tell. Soak it all in!
The Best city Ever . You can see the ottomanish time , Byzantine time And also Genova history ..it is very easy to reach by Turkish airlines
Sultanahmet - Take the ferry up the Bosphorus. Take the public ferry up the Bosphorus. It stops for lunch at the end where you hike up the hill for a view of the Black Sea.

Calm n Quiet Cool place. Istanbul is full of history, calm n quiet soothing place especially the Fatih/ Sultanahmet areas. So many countless sites throughout the city, including Hagia Sophia Mosque/ Blue Mosque. Felt sorry that we were there only for 4 days!
Highly interesting active yet ancient area. Busy, bustling areas of trade alongside awe-inspiring ancient monuments all teaming with people both local & international - not to be missed.

Old City enough for a first trip if you only have a couple of days.... Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagai Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Spice Market and Turk ve Islam Muzesi plus a combination city and water tour were all we had time for in 3 days. If you take a taxi, find out (ask hotel concierge) how much you should pay, have your cash in hand and do not pay more. Every taxi driver we used that was not engaged by our hotel tried to double or triple the price..luggage, traffic, two people???.. none of these matter. They also told us places we were going that were close were closed (not) trying to get us to go further.

المنطقة التاريخية historic Area. منطقه السلطان احمد مليئه بالتاريخ العمراني. تاكد ان تاخذ خارطة الموقع للتتمكن من زياره كل الاماكن التاريخية Make sure to get the area map to cover all histroic spots .

Istanbul has amazing history to be enjoyed.. In an ancient city with over fourteen million residents there is bound to be quite a variety of attractions. The historic areas are too numerous to list and require some planning to maximize your time and minimize wasted steps.

Must see. Istanbul is such an historic city, literally multiple civilizations have left lasting impressions on the crossroads of civilization. You simply need to use your two feet and walk around the city, so much history, so many little places to stop and eat, shop, have a cocktail. Listen to the call to prayer, take a ferry to the Asian side and do the same there, less crowded, friendly people.

Tourism personified . Lasting memories:The visual images-mosques, bazaars, shops, restaurants.The sounds-traffic, horns, chanting over loud speakersThe cultural diversity of the peopleKebabs, salads, fresh fruitsThe incredible density-18 million people with constant traffic backups and overcrowded sidewalks

Istanbul. There are so many sites throughout the city its hard to pinpoint. From the "must see" early Christian Hagia Sophia Basilica, to the Roman arenas, turn around where the Egyptian obelisk stands, to the "Underground Basilica Cisterns" where it seems a whole city is, including a restaurant called the Cistern Restaurant, Istanbul has it all. Access to the Mediterranean as well as the Bosphorus River. There is the beautiful Topkapi Palace, where a rich industrialist and his family allows for tours, all the art work in various museums everywhere and wonderful food in this very cosmopolitan city European flavored city.

one tram ticket to history. This beautiful and amazing historic area can be an indoor or outdoor activity. with just one tram ride, you could already get to know a considerable amount of Istanbul gems. Best partnered with Istanbul Museum card if you are a history buff: 85TL for Hagia Sofia, Topkapi palace, chora museum, istanbul archaeological museum, turkish & islamic art, mosaic museum, hagia irene, etc.

See behind the scenes. Start From Start from blue mosque and go trough alleys. Having a GPS would help you to find points of interests and not to stick in alleys. If get tired go to a cafe or bar and start again.
The city is a museum. I enjoy walking the streets of the old town. There are multiple side walk cafes and lots of shops. People are friendly.

Public trasportation Transfer Ataturk Airport Hotel. Public trasportation is efficient and can take you at the most important sites in Istanbul.For the transfer from the Airport it is advisable to take a taxi . The cost is around 50/60 Turkish Liras .

A complete package-Tuekey!. I just came back from a great holiday in Turkey for 12 days - and each day was filled with a mix of adventure, leisure, history, shopping. You name it and Turkey as a country has that to offer you. Me and my friends covered Istanbul (for its enormous history and great shopping), Cappadocia (for hot air balloons and rock sites cum hiking), Antalya (for its beaches and pubs), Fethiye (for paragliding- a must for all who need adreline rush!) and lastly Pamukkale (the thermal pools). The city is so welcoming and hospitable to tourists. The only downside at some of the places was the locals not knowing English, which made it a little difficult to converse.Its one of those countries, which I would love to travel again with my spouse. Me and my friends have some great fond memories of this place which will always be close to our hearts.

ISTANBUL HAS ABSOLUTELY EVERYTHING. You need to spend a full week in Istanbul to scratch the surface of what exists whether it be old or new.This City has more than any other in my opinion, and I have visited 70 countries.Plan your trip very well and aplan A, B and C depending on the weather and the temperature.Do not forget to visit the Islands and make sure you take a ferry down the Bosphorus to the Black Sea. The City itself is enchanting by day or by night and even many of the Turks do not understand fully what they have in the palm of their hands.

A city with many faces . And you can get to choose which one to see. Or you can see all of them. History is around the corner, it's behind that street bench you chose to sit, it's right underneath your feet, it's everywhere. Close your eyes, think of the period of history you wish to visit and just jump in it. That easy

I have just returned from a one-week tour of Turkey with A Secret Turkey.. For value for money this company offers amazing tours around he ancient sites in Turkey. It was a whistle stop tour of Istanbul, Gallipoli, Canakkale, Troy, Ephesus and Pamukkale, ending in two days of relative 'freedom' in and around Antalya. There were visits to jewellery, leather and carpet factories as well as the more cultural visits.The guide and bus driver were friendly, knowledgable and helpful. All in all I can say that it was, without doubt, he best deal I've ever had.A Secret Turkey also offers a 'sister' tour which takes in other sites, such as Cappadocia.So, if you want something more from Turkey than a beach holiday....this is the one!I must add that, as we stayed in a different hotel each night, he accommodation and the food was top notch. We ate lunch in a different traditional Turkish restaurant each day too. We didn't have to pay for anything except drinks! Unbelievable value.
Amazing city.. I do love Istanbul and will be back again if i have a chance, every corner of the city itself is sooooooo nice.

Capital City of Emperors. There are lots of tourist attraction in Istanbul. Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and it’s famous square, Hagia Sophia, Suleymaniye Mosque, Galata Bridge, Taksim Square and Beylerbeyi Palace are among the most popular tourist attraction in Turkey. It can’t be possible to see every part of the Istanbul because of it’s very long history, more than 2500 years.

Culture and History!. Istanbul is easily navigated and full of history and culture. The Hagi Sofia, Blue Mosque, Cisterns, and Grand Bazaar, are all within walking distance of each other. Hotels and restaurants in this area are very nice and economical. A great two day rest between flights out of their wonderful airport!

Best guide for historical sites . We are a group of 11 traveling from ship. We used the guide Dr. Cumhar Erenal,a private guide recommended to us by a local friend. He was so knowledgeable about the history of The Blue Mosque,, Sofia, cistern, and others that he would have gone on 10 hrs but we were exhausted. Don't miss these sights as well a boat ride on the Bohfourse that was exceptional. Easy to do Grand Bizarre on own.

istanbul very nice city. old city is more histroical byzantine and ottoman. new city taksim is litle more new.. istanbul very nice city. old city is more histroical byzantine and ottoman. new city taksim is litle more new but also have historical place about 100 years.

Beautiful Istanbul. Istanbul was a surprise, it was not on my bucket list at all but winning ballot tickets to the 100th anniversary Gallipolli ceremony forced me to travel there, so glad I did. It is a fabulous, vibrant city with heaps to see & do - the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market just to name a few. The traffic can be very heavy at times but apparently everyone likes to get out and about so it's not such a bad thing.

Excellent. You know istanbul has 2 part : modern area and historical or old area . In my opinion historical area is more beautiful than modern . It gives you a different sense . You think you are walking in paris or rome ... a very good experience walking in old area . I promise you don't be never tired !!

This is a city of fascinating surprises. We did lots of walking in this very accessible city - we also used the very efficient local transport system to explore as much as we could in the short time we had here. Be mindful of rip-off taxi drivers - whatever you are quoted for a fare, offer a quarter and then you might have around the right figure! From Hafiz Mustafa Turkish Delight shop at the Taksim end of Istiklal to the incessant hawkers at the Grand Bazaar, Istanbul offers a great experience. Go to the side streets to find cafes and bars, and look for the almost invisible 'Pasaj's' on Istiklal to really get the flavour of the place. The traders in the passage arcades are a lot more friendly than in the Bazaar and you'll find exactly the same products without the hassle. Make sure to see the Galata Tower with its stunning irridescent blue nighttime illumination.

Beautiful views through long walk way. SO SO may things to see in Istanbul, I would suggest that you arrive as soon as this attraction opens at 08:45 hrs - you need at least 3 hours to go around this palace - it is absolutely beautiful though and well worth the time. The palace sits on the banks of the Bosphorus.

Istanbul: Crossroads of history, cultures and continents. Istanbul is a wonderful city. Beautiful city with a lot of museums, old East-Roman Imperial Christian and Ottoman culture and architecture. A must see for the history and cultural enthusiast. We enjoyed our city trip seeing so many architecture, historical places and meeting wonderful Turkish people, enjoying good food, drinks and company. Istanbul is worth going for a five days city trip. If you like history, Roman-Byzantine & Islam culture and good warm reception from the Turkish people, this is a must go!

Lots to see. We spent the whole day walking around this area. There's so much things to see if you like looking at old building. The archectiture here is wonderful. I loved walking the hilly, windy alleys stooping at cafes for breaks or window shopping. Visited the Galata tower. There was a bit of a wait but we got there after lunch. Mornings seems to be the best time to visit most of these sites.

Ther Best City in the World to Visit. If you like history, then you will love Istanbul. So full of historical treasures of every kind. Make sure you stay for at least five days to see a fair selection.

So much in close proximity.. There is so much to see in such a relatively small area. Easy to walk around and those that weren't free to enter were certainly relatively inexpensive. Guides were available, official and unofficial. We had a registered guide and if was well worth it so as not to miss the hidden gems and to get the timing right to avoid the crowds.

if Napoleon had conquered the world he said he would have made Istanbul its capital! Nuff said!. I went back for more Istanbul a couple of months later. So much history and so much going on. The Bospherous allows us to be in Europe and Asia in less than a half an hour. I loved it.

Beautiful views through long walk. Istanbul's so many historical points worth a walk to see and explore and I spent two days by walking and exploring specially Fatih district. It is amazing throughout all experience.

From Topkapi to the Blue Mosque you just lost in history. Amazing places you just get lost in the history. Topkappi, Blue Mosque, Hagya Sofia, just a few names to mention. Istanbul is a place for seeing histroy through your eyes.
Incredible city! Beautiful views!. Take a boat ride and use the audio tour headphones to hear about all the interesting buildings and sites

Dolmanbache Palace. If you have may things to see in Istanbul, I would suggest that you arrive as soon as this attraction opens at 08:45 hrs - you need at least 3 hours to go around this palace - it is absolutely beautiful though and well worth the time.The palace sits on the banks of the Bosphorus and there are exquisite views of the sea going vessels that transverse its waters.There is tight security with armed guards at the entrance of this attraction, a sign of the times I fear but it does not detract from the beauty of this palace. I would suggest that you start with the main part of the palace where you will have a palace guide to escort you from room to room. There are more than 300 rooms in this palace and the guide will show you around 20 of them. This is a very informative tour and you should pay attention to these very well informed guides as they bring the past to life. Very highly decorated in gold and crystal the palace is beautifully preserved.Your next stop will be a different guide in the harem, where all the wives were housed and indeed the kings mother. A very different story as far as the décor is far far more basis but the stories are quite intriguing. There is a lovely café and bathroom facilities on site and I would highly recommend this attraction.

A beautiful Walking City. Istanbul is an incredible city and everything is very accessible.If you have time, just walk around and get the feel of the old mixed with new. Then go into some of the landmarks that call to you.

Experience. Going to Istanbul was an eye opener to another culture. The people are holding onto the old customs and you can wander about and experience this. On a walk along the river you see the local people camped out for the day with their hammocks strung across the trees, their cooking pots on the fire and generally having a good time playing various instruments.

Fantastic !! Absolutely one of the best destiniations in Europe for a city-trip !!!. A city you must visit !!! Palaces, churches, musea, mosques, and much more are absolutely worth to see. You have a few of the most beautifull buildings (of the world) in Istanbul like the Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, etc. A lot of them you will also find very close to each other. Also don't forget to make a cruise on the Bosporus !!!Istanbul also offers fantastic shopping, great restaurants and a very good nightlife.We would certainly advice you to use a guide ... He will take care of everything for you and you will see much more and you will get much more information during your visit. We went for 5 days (1 day travelling) and that was perfect for us. Don't hesitate, just book :-) !!!!!!!!
Sultanate. It was like being transported to One Thousand and One Nights. One of the best vacations ever. We only stayed 10 days, and that was too short a time.

that 's why you go to Istanbul. just get lost in hte old and small streets of old Istanbul. The old wooden houses dating from 150 years ago, are very picturesque. Plenty of small restaurant, with great food, sisha and tiem to see the time pass in front of you.
What a City. Istanbul is mystic , magic, Arabian nights and European days: it's history and future... It's full of life and Joy and the most delicious scents on earth!

ISTANBUL, A MUST SEE CITY. Istanbul is a beautiful city to visit. It is crazy crowded, the traffic may be overwhelming for those who are not use to that kind of mess but still if you are a history buff, if you love shopping, eating and a little adventure definitely go to Istanbul. It is much safer than most people will think. I'll say it is as bad or as good of any big city like LA , NY, Paris or London. Museums, sites, shopping in Grand Bazaar, eating in a fish restaurant by the Bosporus is a must do at least once in a life time. Hook up w/a good tour group or find a good local guide, you won't be disappointed.

Continuously inhabited and adapted, rich in the present and in the past.. The vitality of history shines in its embrace by the present. Pieces of history are found around nearly every corner. And the monuments are all but unbelievable.

One of the best cities i have been to. Istanbul was very lovely. people were nice. good transport facilities and all the historical cites were easily accessible. the entrance to these places cost anywhere between free to 10euros. you need to buy a audio guide if u want for another 4-5euros. most of the interesting places are located in the sultanamet area. the restaurants were affordable. you buy a lot of things in the grandbazaar and spice bazaar but you need to be ready to bargain. overall a very lively city and i will definitely visit once more

A city steeped in history. Constantinople. Istanbul. This city has existed under many names, seen the rising and crumbling of many civilizations. Many have fought over the control of this city, and I can see why. But nothing will take away its eternal charm. You must visit the Topkapi palace, all the museums and mosques... and Haghia Sophia.
