These places will offer you a glimpse of the rich history that surrounds you in Istanbul.

Charming city. Charming city, very special tinge, history is every where, well developed public transportation, easy access to any distination, people are wellcoming, a trip to istanbul needs a minimumm three days, the best can be achieved with a five days tour, streets are wonderfull. Food is delicious with wide variations.

I loved Istanbul. Go if you can!. I can't say enough about this city- its beautiful, clean, accessible, friendly and most wonderfully historic. From its early Roman history through to the modern city, the whole history of the region is on view. Suggest starting at the old historic center and reacquaint yourself with the cities earliest history. The Hagia Sophia, the Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque are all so close together, though leave yourself lots of time to explore all of them. The Palace alone is worth 1/2 day, Also be sure to view the Hippodrome area. Get a good guide book to explain the history of these sites. From there you can gradually widen your circuit to see more of the beautiful mosques that make Istanbul a jewel.
this is one big city. Istanbul is an interesting place to visit due to its impressive history. Especially the area around the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace is worthwhile.

My experience with HISTORICAL Area of ISTANBUL. You Will love this place, if you like to walk around easily not rushing yourself.I might take a full day walking,Don't worry there are many places were you can enjoy a cup of Turkish coffee,sweets,light snack,or even good meal.Most Masjids has next to them clean restrooms and they charge one lira to use it.The ancient and historical buildings will make you feel and live the old times of the ISLAMIC OTTOMAN EMPIRE .Even if you do not know the history,you will feel the glory of that time.There are many shops with offering huge variety of items an souvenirs.(( You must be a very good bargainer to get a good selling price)).I can write much more but I think this is enough Good luck.

Busily Peaceful and Beautiful. Although the historic precinct of Istanbul is never short on tourists and locals bustling around, the sites themselves are surprisingly tranquil. Perhaps it's the thousands years of history to soak up or the beauty and grandeur of the architecture and design innovation - but there is something peaceful about the busy area. Must sees are the Underground Cistern, Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia. However, take some time to wander down the surrounding laneways and you'll find beautiful trinket stores, lovely homewares, Turkish fashions and most importantly delicious restaurants and cafes!
One of my favorite cities in the world!. Istanbul is beautiful, historic, easily walkable to see lots of sights like the Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sofia. Great affordable restaurants and shops.

One of my absolute favorite cities. I loved Istanbul so much on my first trip--two full days as part of a tour--that I went back six months later on my own and spent a week exploring it in more depth. It's a beautiful and fascinating city--the capital of two of the greatest empires in history. If you love great cities, plan to spend more than a few days.

Truly an enchanting city. This was my first stop in my Turkey trip. Nothing like a mix of old and new. Istanbul truly has it all. Love seeing all the ancient structures which are easily accessible by modern train system. It's quite a stunning city. My only regret is spending only 3 days in it!

Istanbul is full of agent very exciting history!. We had 4 days to experience Istanbul and we experienced most of the historic buildings on both sides of the city. I strongly recommend others to visit this city and experience the culture, history and weather of this beautiful place!
Bosphorus boats. To travel on an old boat on the Bosphorus and out and about was amazing and swimming in the Med was warm.

Fabulous history at the Palace, Hippodrome, Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque. What a wonderful day we had visiting all the ancient historical sights of Istanbul.
All these places are a Must-see.
The good part about going on a guided tour is that u skip the queue and transport picks up and drops off conveniently. Also the English speaking guide is a fountain of information about everything Turkish.
Wonderful sights. Lovely seeing Europe meet Asia. Do take a HALF DAY river trip. Wonderful to see so many amazing sites.

Vibrant City. Istanbul is a vibrant City! Really amazing. Everything is so magical and beautiful. Istanbul was one of my best travel experience ever! I love the food, the people, the historical sites ( specially the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia Basilica), the Islands. You need at least 5 days! I stayed 10 days and it was not enough to see everything, because the city have so many incredible attractions.

exotic east meets west. i should have spent 2 weeks here not 2 days. there is so much to see and such an exotic mix... i loved all the street bazaars and the mosques. fantastic food. dont miss a trip on the river to get your bearings of the city...
great city. should go to see quaint streets, little alleys, hidden wonders, stroll about have a turkish coffee pull a sheesha, enjoy life.

Strolling in the Historic Istanbul. The town of Istanbul is enormous (over 15 million paople) yet the historic portion is concentraded in a relativelysmall area around Topkapi,Aya Sofia and the <blue Mosque

Beatiful Historical Areas in the City. I went to Istambul with my mother of over 80 old and my sisters. We stayed near historical area Sultanahmet, Blue Mosque, Hagasofia. We walked around every morning. We visited Gran Bazaar and Egyptian Market. They are all beautiful and interesting.

Exquisite City. One of the best cities I have ever travelled, great architect, lots of places to eat great food, and endless places to see and visit.....no wonder 14 million people just live in this city......Not to be missed on anyone list......

Buy a museum card. We had a great long weekend stay and were happy with the museum cards we bought. Avoiding long waiting lines and well priced you are even on the 3rd visit.Also the tramcard system works great allowing single trips for only 2.15 TL ask your hotel to borrow 1

Beautiful city. İstanbul is one of the most astonishing European cities. Its variety of cultures, architecture, food and amazing historic places attracts millions of tourists every year. I have recently moved to Istanbul and even though I visited most of the landmarks tens of times before, I never get bored of looking at the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Galata Bridge and other places. I truly recommend visiting them at least once in your lifetime.

Amazing city. I went to Istanbul for a week with my mom and we had a blast. We went everywhere ourselves instead of joining a tour, which was great, because we did everything in our own schedule. We drank tea all the time and walked almost the whole city. We visited the Blue Mosque, the underwater columns, the castles...etc. I would definitely go back again!

Wear comfortable shoes. The old Istanbul is very hilly, you will be walking steep streets and up or down is sometimes a challenge especially if you have disabilities. Thanks to the current government, you can catch the metro to anywhere even straight to the aiport. Buy yourself a Metro card and top up as you go. Amazing sights.
Very historical. Turkey in general has many historical areas, especially Istanbul. But I think they are not as worshipped as they should be.

Fabulous city between Europe and Asia. This is a must do city to visit. It has so much to offer for anyone interested in culture and history. Best stay in the historical centre where all the sites are accessible by foot. Be sure to include a trip on the local ferries up the Bosphorus to have lunch.

We enjoyed visiting the Blue Mosque and all the sites in the historic section. Our hotel the Best WEstern Citadel was located close to the old section and historic area of Istanbul. We enjoyed walking to the Blue mosque

Rich layers of history and culture. This city is like one of those Sarah Lee cakes: layer upon layer upon layer. Multiple levels of history. Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman, Turkish, Modern. All vying for your heart and mind -. Every turn and every sight competes for your attention. All your senses are involved and fully occupied. There is an endless variety of attractions but in reality the whole is greater than the sum of the parts.Great.

Amazing Historical City. Wow! Such a beautiful city! It just amazed me - so much of history, beautiful architecture and yet modern on the other side. Great city to walk and see - lovely Marmara, Golden Horn and Bosphorus make it so serene and beautiful - Istanbul is a must visit. Their Mosques, Palaces are lovely. Bazaars very interesting. People are really nice too.

Istanbul Tour. Great City.. sign up on a 1 Day City Tour, Neon Tours assigned a tour guide Ms Gulay Gunay, great lady.Friendly and Well versed.Stayed in Alkocar Keban at Takim Square.. Excellent location, but a bit noisy at night.Wifi is weak, need to sign in , signal always dropped.

A Blend of Rich Ottoman Culture and Modern Lifestyle with a Historic and Natures breath-taking views. Istanbul & Turkey, the more you visit the more you fall in love. its just mystical.I stayed in Optimist hotel its a small botique hotel just in front of the Blue Mosque, the Staff is friendly and helpful. and metro and tram station is just 2 minutes walk from all this historic sites.

What an amazing city!. Istanbul was wonderful! I found all the sites to be well kept. The garment district was a little crazy, and there were definitely some dirty areas, but overall I enjoyed myself.I loved the spice market. Picked up some saffron!Beware of the Turkish baths. I loved it, my friend not so much :)

W hotel Istanbul. Great location, Hotel is an old town house from A past sultanate and is very nice. lots to take in in the area. the staff was great and service was good. They charged me for some very overpriced items from the bar fridge and are not reimbursing me!! Very annoying its not the money its the principle.
Town. You need to set at least a day of walking aside to see the history and sights of the old part of town. Lots of shops, restaurants and old buildings.

Amazing historical sites. If you like history, then this are is abundant with ones! Every other meter is full with stories and history. You can walk around, or take tram trips around with quite a reasonable budget.

Must see. Make sure you have the time to visit. They won't disappoint. Catch a tram if needed. We walked and visited what we had listed as it's wasn't possible to visit everything. We had 3 days here and it wasn't enough. Lots of photo opportunities of all the historic buildings and the area. Mike
Great visit. We all really enjoyed Istanbul, its vibrant, beautiful and very interesting, It has great transport system and also easy to walk around
The Old City. We stayed in the Sultanhmet area so we could easily explore the older parts of Istanbul by walking. There is a lot to see and experience here.

Most Intriguing city we have ever visited. What an amazing city. We attended 100 year ANZAC celebrations in Gallipoli and initially thought we would spend the time before in London, we are so glad we flew to Istanbul instead. We stayed at Retaj Royale Istanbul, hotel which was beautiful and used get to a taxi to public transport daily to venture into the city and explored the spice bazaar, the mosques and other points of interest. Everyone was very friendly and helpful. We took the local, government ferry on its run up the Bosphorus Strait where east meets west - and we even had a proper Turkish Bath in a traditional bath house - an amazing experience !!

A guide is important to visit the historic areas. We were fortunate to have our guide Emre Ozkara in charge of our visit to the major historic areas. We had a car provided by him as well and it was a very special experience visiting structures and past life histories of Sultans and palaces as well. I would recoomend two days for these tours and then two days to venture on your own. Try the Karakoy district for great cafes and places for intersting walks.

Best with a guide. There is so much to see here a guide can keep you on track and gives so much information that I know we would have missed had we done the touring on our own. Don't hesitate to visit this beautiful city.

Bucket list!!. Check into a small hotel in Sultanahmet and put on your walking shoes. There are so many interesting places to visit, wonderful restaurants and shops offering a wide array of goods. Drink tea with the rug merchants and don't be surprised when you purchase a carpet.

One of the most lovely cities. Live near the Bluemosque and Hagia Sophia. Take guide and go to all the sights including Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia and Hippodrome. This will take a full day if you want to really see and understand the richness and the architectural wonders. Keep a full day for the Topkapi palace as some rooms have long queues to get in especially the treasury and the relics. The jewels are jaw-dropping and the relics amazing.

It would be a serious mistake to make, if you never visited Istanbul. Our visit to Istanbul exceeded all of our expectations. The City is beautiful, fascinating, safe and fun. October is a perfect time to go. Warm enough, but not hot and uncomfortable. We spent 3 full days exploring the city, eating out and relaxing. I would recommend a 3 or 4 day visit, because you just wouldn't be able to see enough in 2 days. I will have no hesitation recommending or returning.
Just amazing. i walked everywhere that's how you find all the hidden treasures of this beautiful city!! Meet the local fishermen, bread maker, have some tea with the market vendors!!

Excellent boat ride on the Bosphorus. Definitely something to do with time in Istanbul. The boat ride gave us more sights and excellent viewing of Istanbul. I would recommend adding this to an itinerary.
perfect destination. the city is amazing,especially historical peninsula. if you stay on sultanahmet area, all the places walking distance. you should see before you die :)

"Walk, walk, walk and every step unfolds a rich history.". Istanbual is a city where you can walk for hours and hours. The water, the people, the parks, the aroma of food, the gentleman greeting you with hopes of selling their crafts of beauty made by the people of Turkey is invigorating, emotional and challenging. My companion and I were there for a week walking every where and felt completely safe everywhere we went. People were amazingly gracious and kind.

The Old City Istanbul. We have been to Istanbul 4 times now and part of each trip we return to stay in the old city, at a favorite hotel located 5 minutes walk from Sultanahmet Square and under the minarets of the Blue Mosque. We enjoy rambling through the cobblestones, past the wonderful mix of cultural and residential buildings, the street sellers, the picnickers in the square, the incredible diversity of tourists, the helpfulness and welcoming nature of the Turks, the accessibility of some of the most stunning and culturally interesting and diverse buildings in the world - Hagia Sophia, the Basilica Cistern, the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Archaeological Museum, Topkapi. All an easy walk or when tired, the tram service is frequent, clean, cheap and not hard to negotiate. May be very crowded at peak times though. Each time we explore a new district, more off the tourist track and continue to find the Turkish people wonderfully helpful no matter how far from the main spots we go. They have 'rescued' us a couple of times, noticing us obviously lost. A great part of the city to walk - take a hat and water for the hot days. Wendy and John, Adelaide Australia.
This may encompass the whole city>>>. We took an all day walking tour of the old part of the City. The guide (Atilla) was extremely helpful and knowledgeable.

Istanbul reprise. We visited Istanbul a year ago. We had a wonderful time and really enjoyed the mosques, museums, market places, cafes and river trips. We found the people friendly. Sadly since our trip the whole refugee crisis from Syria and war has erupted. This may worry some tourists but my recommendation would be not to worry as in this crazy world you can have a problem anywhere and the chances any tourist will be bothered are very low.
You live the history. If you love history, you will have a blast visiting Istanbul. Every stone has its own story. You can visit palaces, museums. mosques,relax in hamams and shop in old bazaars.

Too much to see. We tried to see as much as possible and did see the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar and took a cruise on the Bosphorus. We saw the Glatta Tower from a distance and The Maiden's Tower. There is so much to see.

Great City! Impressive and lively. The historic area of Istanbul is so full of overwhelming proofs of a powerful Empire, that it needs no recommendation! But dont miss out the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazar, Arasta Bazar ( a small very elegant and stylish bazar close to the Blue Mosque) , Agia Sophia, Topkapi palace, Dolmabahce palace and the Galata tower area!

Extraordinary!!!. As a whole, the old City in Istanbul is simply wonderful. So much to see and absorb. It can be done with guided tours or on your own. We always like to take the hop-on/hop-off for a general idea about a city, than explore on our own.
So many things to see. I wish I had more time to visit and see more of the history of the place and of course the shops. So many things to see and

So Much To Do!. There is really not much more to say. You can spend days here and not see it all. I spent 4 days and needed more. Leaving was hard to do. There is a certain romance to the age of this place. It draws you in and you just kind of marinade in it. There is so much to soak up. The culture, the hustle and flow of the people, the chaos of the bazaars.

Surviving Istanbul. My first trip to Istanbul but hopefully won't be the last. So many places to visit or just absorb the atmosphere - lots of smaller shops, the contrast between the different bazaars, the long and varied history, the people. Oh yes, be aware that some people are not averse to scamming tourists (e.g. 'accidentally' dropping a shoe-shine brush just as you walk along, or exchanging a whole handful of €2 coins for a €50 note). Be careful and enjoy a unique experience.

Hop-on Hop-off bus. With a little study before going, you could really make this a wonderful self-guided tour. There are many interesting things to see. You have earphones that plug into the seat in front of you and it has several language choices.

Great visit. Just made my second trip here; I had been here 35 years ago. I was happy to see a lot had remained the same. Only disappointment was the great bazaar which is now disappointing in its offerings and prices.
gorgeous. felt like i travelled back in time. Lots of little shops and lots of people rummaging through the streets. Definitely one of the coolest cities in the world.
back to roots. Even if you visit Istanbul for a number of times it is worth visiting historic areas because it is like traveling in the past

Worth visiting every site. So much museums, mosques and bazaars among other sites to see in Istanbul. Especially love the multi-culturality in a lot of the sites here of both Christian and Islamic influence.

The sights and the sites. An amazing mixtures of cultures. Four travellers in their 50's we never felt scared or intimidated. The locals we me or accosted (!) for directions were always friendly. A definite bucket list destination and yes we used busses and rail to move around.

A city full of history the I never get tired of exploring. I come to Istanbul often. Overtime I think I've seen it all, I find something new that interests me. This city is full of many cultures and empires history that you can spend a full month exploring it full time and still you find out more places to go!

In Love with Turkey!!!!. An amazing, enchanting land filled with discovery of ancient mystery.
Beautiful land, fantastic food, incredible palaces, however many still do
not like or the American people....so
be wary of body & belongings at ALL times.
Overall though we had a wonderful time

Simply an incredible district to visit. Loved the hustle and bustle of the city, the locals going about their everyday life and the tourists simply in awe of the place.
Excellent restaurants and food outlets everywhere, felt safe.

The Black colored Istanbul Museum Card. We researched the "black" Museum Card online and decided it was a good value but the website didn't allow us to purchase it. For convenience we chose to buy it at our Istanbul hotel but rather than 85TL we had to pay 100TL. It would have been better to buy it for 85 at the kiosk just outside the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art, very near the Blue Mosque. We used it for quick entrance to Aya Sophia, Istanbul Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art, Topkapi Palace and its Hareem.

East and West Converge. Istanbul is my favorite city in the world. It is a fusion of cultures from ancient to post-modern. I have never experienced more dense commerce than standing on the banks of the Bosphorus - people buying and selling, engaging in the most essential human transaction - negotiating prices. And the people of Istanbul are the happiest and most gregarious I have encountered in the world. They are not just selling you stuff - they are interested in a conversation. Boy can they talk...buy a cup of Turkish coffee and enjoy! The spice markets are a right of passage. Ataturk's castle tells the story of a people. The history of Roman engineering is clear in the aqueducts and great cisterns. The mosques at dusk are more beautiful than can be conveyed by the English language. In the grand collections of human endeavors, the City of Istanbul is among the greatest persistent marvels.
Excellent place for Tourism and Non veg food. Excellent river side view (Bosphorus river) between Asia and Europe. Excellent river cruise journey with dinner

Interesting Two Days. We both walked and used the tram in the two days and visited the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and the Grand & Spice Bazaars. We also had a most enjoyable lunch off the beaten track but I cannot remember the name of the restaurant which is a great pity as I would thoroughly recommend it. Istanbul itself is very, very busy with long queues for most of the popular attractions and we unfortunately ran out of time to visit the underground cisterns. The tram is very easy to use and costs 4 Turkish Lira for one journey, irrespective how far you are travelling. If you make a mistake, as we did, you simply get off at the next stop and change to the correct tram as long as you do not leave through the turnstiles. The Grand Bazaar is massive but we managed to find our way out by following our noses and with help of a local trader close to where we wanted to be anyway.

Interesting History. Quite surprising how nice this whole area was It reminded me more of the hilly areas of Paris . The mosques ,palace and the bazaar are all well worth a visit. There is the obligatory queues but unfortunately that's the way of the world Luckily the weather wasn't too hot when I visited. The bazaar deserves a special mention because it was nothing as I expected and the traders were not in my opinion to pushy

fell in love with Istanbul. Spent a week in Istanbul as our first stop on a 2 month trip and I am in love!The sights sounds food and people are amazing there is always another great find down the next ally!we spent hours just wandering around I can't get enough of this city!we will be back to discover the rest of turkey very soon!

GET OUT AND WALK. By foot (take a little map) visit beautiful mosques, palaces, museums, underground cisterns, bazaars (Grand and Spice) and chat with the people ... most are very friendly and a pleasure to visit with (and no, you don't have to by a rug if you don't want to :-)).

Worth visiting. We spent three days in Istanbul but this was the part of the city we liked most. Lots of history, friendly and helpful people. Once we got lost and thanks to a dustmam, who did not speak any english, we found our way back.

SOO much to see. Take a walk around. Follow the rail line around the area and you will walk by most of the major sites. Money exchange near the Basilica Cistern had good exchange rates. It is a walk thru the Grand Bazaar and the Spice market...nothing you will see in Canada or the US. They will barter on most items.Everyone has an uncle for sells carpets!!
cake turc. delisiouss'cafe. hôtel and tour à louer the ses yes Nice to go second tome. taxi and People good the Knowles. Taksim and ataturk aéroport. sublime yes

A hive for history buffs!. Istanbul as a top world destination is an understatement. The historic area is just so well preserved and are within near proximity of each other. Getting to each point is so easy with public transport. In the Sultanahmet area, the top attractions are within walking distance of each other.

We loved it!. We spent 7 days in Istanbul and stayed in this area. Every day we walked there and never got bored. The only negative is the constant efforts of the restaurants and the shopkeeper to lure you to their place,
Old monuments. Trail of Ottoman and byzantine heritage. Attractions around Sultanahmet square. All walking distances. two to three days visits time required and on foot most of the time.

Live the Ottoman Spirit. İstanbul is a very big city but when you get to European side to Eminönü, Galata, Sultanahmet and many other towns you will feel how long this metropolitan is alive.Since many years all those mosques, churches, bazaars and other historical places waited for you to visit them.

Explore Sultanhamet on foot for the best experience. Before exploring this beautiful city, do buy an Istanbulkart for transport and a Museumkart for multiple entries to the historical sites. Pretty much all of Sultanhamet is accessible on foot if you don't mind walking a lot and a couple of steepish hills. Maybe best done over two or three days, especially if the weather is very hot.The tram does run from the Grand Bazaar to the Blue Mosque then down to the spice market but you miss a lot by not walking.We took in the Topkapi Palace and Archeoogical Museum one day, with a walk down to the Spice Market. On another trip we went to the Ayasofia Museum, the Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern. The Basilica Cistern was the only one where entry isn't covered by our Museumkart but at only 20TL entry, was a delightful addition to our day out.A drink and snack at a nearby bar then a walk back to the Grand Bazaar and back over to Beyoglu where we were staying. All in all, we had an amazing trip and found our way around fairly easily desspite not speaking any Turkish at all.

It is lovely to explore the districts of Eminönü and Beyoglu. We loved to walk around the antique shops in Beyoglu, Cihangir. Narrow streets with very intresting shops, feeling the daily live in Istanbul. Between easy going and incredible hurry. In Eminönü, Tahta Kale you can find everything from typical oriental live until modern unnecessary trash. It was wonderful to eat fresh meals between locals and students in very small unusual fast food restaurants.

Amazing place steeped in history. The historic area of Istanbul is an amazing place to visit. There is so much history and culture just about around every corner. I found all of it stunning and breathtaking. Exhaling Wow! So many times at the number and quality of historic sites as I walked around. Highly recommended.
An old city of Istanbul. if you enjoy of walking in an old city and find a narrow allies with paving, look at small shops and galleries and have a rest in small warm cafe, go to Galata area

The best place to stay and go for the first time visitor. Safe area, many historic sites, nice hotels, friendly people, good foods, all within walking distance. Perfect place for first time visitors like us. You can basically cover several main important sites easily: Sultan Ahmet Mosque, Hagia Sophia Museum, Topkapi Palace, to Grand Bazaar, and many more. You can reach everything by walking or use the tram (IstanbulKart is the best deal). Wear comfy shoes as the roads are hilly and some with cobblestones. If you stay in the area it will be easy to arrive in the historic sites earlier to avoid lines (that can be long!).

Istanbul on foot. I suggest you do your homework and plan what you want to see. We were on a cruise and wanted to see several sites. Excursions are expensive on cruise ships but if you are unsure they are a safe bet. We took the metro up to the Sultanahmet walked over the hippodrome site and were at the Blue Mosque across the road was the Hagi Sofiya. We purchased museum passes which last 5days but we had our moneys worth as you pay to go into Sofiya, Irene and Topkapi Palace and extra for Harem it also covers many museums and sites. We spent about an hour in each and longer in Topkapi we regret not visiting the museum. We then went across the road to the underground cisterns which you have to pay for.The grand bazaar was not on the itinerary but we explored and visited the Sulimanya mosque which is beautiful and then to the spice market well worth a visit. You can buy a tram pass which is well worth it but we did a lot of walking and saw a great deal.

Istanbul a historic place. Istanbul is full of history. it is a blend of new with the ancient. So many places to see that even a week will not be enough. Must see are the Hagia Sophia, Blue mosque and topkapi palace
Enjoyed touring the historic areas of Istanbul, Turkey. Enjoyed touring the historic areas of Istanbul, Turkey. Had the best time ever in Istanbul. Food good shopping great!!!

Amazing. I came to Istanbul and was only going to stay 2 days. That was over a week ago. The city is beautiful, mosques and historical landmarks are everywhere and are astounding. You feel excited when you realize that 200 years ago, someone was standing right where you are. One other thing that is truly exquisite is the Bosphorus. A small sea that divides Asia and Europe from each other, the Bosphorus is really beautiful, especially when the sun sets. It's definitely a go-before-you-die kind of place

A Nice Place to Walk. One of the things you'll find by walking around Turkey is that the people are friendly and the streets are reasonably safe. Walk the historic districts to get a feel for the city.

so much culture, architecture sights and smells !. A city for all ages with so much to appeal to everyoneGood shopping from malls to marketsSo many amazing buildings from all agesEasy to get around using buses trams or boatsLots of wonderful restaurants catering for all tastes and all very reasonable compared to other citiesIts blend of Europe and Asia are very evident and make it very uniqueWe were only there for 3 full days and it was not enough, I'd recommend 5 days to do Istanbul justice
Cruize. The cruize is the cheapest mode to see the History and geography of Istanbul around see. A must for the tourist( My advise)

Istanbul is amazing city. Istanbul has many attractions: interesting history, beautiful buildings, famous museums, amazing views from hills, tasty food and the best tea in the world. There is nothing better then balik ekmek, hot tea and Bosphorus view.

Spice Market Quick Overview. If you don't have the time for the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul, then visit the Egyptian Spice Market. It is conveniently located and compact. Many stores duplicate their wares, but it actually helps if you want to haggle over the price.

History unveiled with every step you take. The Historic areas of Istanbul include: Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque - The Blue Mosque, the Hagia Irene, Zeyrek Mosque, Süleymaniye Mosque, Little Hagia Sophia and Walls of Constantinople.Everywhere there are historical sites so spending a full week in Istanbul might help you uncover all of them.If you have only one day or you are coming with a cruise ship just pick a tour that will get you to most of the places.The sites are accessible by foot and in relative close distance from each-other located in what is called the Old Istanbul. If you have days to spend in Istanbul just buy an Istanbul City Pass that will allow you to enter all the museums without having to wait in line. The ticket and the city guide will tell you which places are closed/ open and their visiting hours. On the long run it helped us see more and save time. Bring your camera because you will take a lot of pictures and be prepared to walk and spend long days out of your hotel.
All of it. Istanbul is all historic especially in the European side , the Asian side slightly newer but mostly the entire city is a walking museum
Takism square . Very beautiful , you find good resturant, shopping for clothes and shoes for Turkish brand , you can see a lot of tourists around Takism

History is everywhere. Istanbul is synonym of history! Everywhere you go, you can see something historical from different ages and centuries. It is amazing to explore landmarks from Greek, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman culture just in one place. You can touch, smell, feel the past. I love it!

All together and easy to get to. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace are all situated in a neat line together near the waterfront in Istanbul. I could see each one lined up from the cruise ship as it entered the city. Once you are in the area it is easy to get around and go from one place to the other. All 3 are different and well worth seeing, especially the first two. Access by wheelchair is possible around and into all of them although I did have to swap my mobility scooter for a provided wheelchair (and be wheeled) at the Blue Mosque and get extra help at Topkapi.

Walking Tour with a Guide is Best. Traffic in Istanbul is terrible, so I would recommend you use a guide and walk through the historic areas. You could take a taxi to your hotel or if you are tired, but be prepared to go slowly.Make sure you shop at the Grand Bazaar, which is pure chaos and liveliness.

LOVE ISTANBUL. ITS MAD İTS CRAZY İTS GREAT İTS CULTURAL.....GRAND BAZAAR TİP never pay the price they ask haggle. buy a gold coin relatively cheap keeps value and you can cash in when you are broke.drink turkish coffee....try the rakı eat everything. use the dolmus.
Amazing and wonderful. Our guide gave us such wonderful information about the sights. They truly are something special to behold. Istanbul has such a rich and varied history.
Historic city. City ​​that have been always a bridge between East and West, cultures and religions. I recommend to visit at least once in life

Walking back in hystory or in what remained from it: Fener neighborhood. If you like history, take your thoughts about Constantinople, Phanariotes and take a walk to the Fener neighborhood, in the Fatih district in Istanbul, Turkey. You can start from Ataturk foot bridge. With the Golden Horn in front, turn to the left on Abdulezel Paşa Cad. Not far, landmarks of both old history and new poverty will hit you. Aya Nikola (Agios Nikolaos Church, Sekban başısı gate, Church of St. George, Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, Phanar Greek Orthodox College, Saint Mary of the Mongols Church, but most of all a taste of old houses, some ruined some inhabited. If you are lucky, a cafe with Greek music, somewhere on the streets. And surprisingly, on the top of the hill, more traditional Turks than anywhere, surrounding Ismail Aga Cami. But YOU HAVE TO CLIMB A HILL SO please notice: you need good foots and comfortable shoes.

There is so much to see,stay at least three full days.. We took a tour with TSC agency,great and professionals.We went with the guide to Topkapi palace,Hagia Sofia,Blue Mosque,Grand Bazzar,Spice Market.

Boat trip. Golden horn and Bosphorus. Somewhat slow boat around Istanbul. Saw lots from the water especially fish restaurant under golden horn bridge. Going up Bosphorous and under Bosphorous bridge was highlight. Amazing palaces and mosques. Limited commentary with best sound on top open deck. Lower deck is enclosed. Serves hot coffee. And cosplay for photos. No I didn't dress up as a Sultan.

Museums and historical monuments. Overall the best city I have ever been to for historical value. So much from the Greeks, the Romans, the Byzantines, the Ottomans. Also amazing for religious history- particularly if you are interested in Islamic history and early Christianity.

An Exciting Experience. Istanbul is a wonderful city to explore as there is just so much to see and the public transport makes it easy to reach the places of interest. The Grand Bazaar is wonderful and somewhere to lose a few hours if you explore it all! Two days was not nearly enough time to spend here, we hope to return!

City with great history. Istanbul has many historic places to visit... Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia, palace, grand Bazzar .... It is the cross roads of East and west, Islam and Christianity ...One day will not be enough to see all sites.

Must do's for a first visit. Staying in the historic centre for a short break is probably a 'must' for a first visit. But it's very sanitized for tourists, except perhaps if you venture out to the grand and Egyptian bazaars, where you begin to see a little of Istanbul life - that whets the appetite to explore further and I'm already dreaming of my next visit, political situation permitting. I'd probably stay in the Sultanahmet area again but not visit the main attractions.

So much history. We stayed in Istanbul for a week in the heart of the old city. From our hotel we could walk to all the major historic attractions. Istanbul is an ancient city with many interesting sights. There is history wherever you go. We loved It all.

One of the great cities of the world. All my life I have heard and read about Istanbul (or Byzantium or Constantinople) as being this amazing crossroads of east and west. It is all that. The city is so vibrant, so chaotic, so alive. The only disappointment I had was that I only had three days there - all the more reason to return.
A must!. Safe and clean. Easy to navigate. City is lively and we loved to hear the call to prayer. It was very mystical.

Flying visit from Dalaman. Exhausting because of the early start and late finish but very worth doing.
Doing all the touristy things as you must in a day trip. Visiting the blue mosque, taking a Bosphorus boat trip (am I in Europe or Asia?), Topkapi Palace museum and the Hippodrome. Very much worth the visit.

Just walking is enough. Every area has its cafes, shops and attractions, plan to spend lots of time walking! We were able to see all the major sights on foot, although we took a tour bus the first day to get our bearings.
Vibrant. Our second visit to Istanbul as the first wasn't enough to see all the fantastic sites and sounds. Just, for me, one of the best cities on Earth.

A place of contradictions. Yes, it is a must see of Istanbul. All I ever heard is how great it is, but nobody told me everything. So the expectations were really high and guess what? Reality gap rather high. If you go there just be prepared for the cultural differences, super crowds, chaos, heavy traffic, noise, dirt, things to buy that look fake, etcAmong all this set up there are also the things to visit, most of them nice, good restaurants but you have to carefully select them (you need to find them - not every touristic area restaurant it is also good).If you are prepared for this combination then you are ready for the vacation.

Full of culture. Fascinating that is a melting pot of history of different culture. I wasn't sure what to expect in visiting but I found it fascinating. We were two women traveling alone. The only trouble we had was communicating with Taxi drivers. It was sometimes impossible to get them to take you where you wanted to go without an interpreter. Even then it wasn't easy.

Much cleaner that expected!. Most sites are located fairly close together. Walked a lot of places. Get a guide if you really want to get the history and explanation of these places. It's important in understanding their significance. Have left reviews for lunch places in other posts.

Unbelievable culture and history unfortunately with too many overly agressive hawkers. This is a wonderful experience that really takes a day or two to enjoy. Once you get the overly intrusive sales pests off your back, it is a very enjoyable experience. After trying to be polite, I have no problem making it perfectly clear I am not interested in shops, personal tours and the other things these guys try to push...so don't hesitate to get direct.Other than the pests, this is a great experience and history lesson with beautiful architecture and craftsmanship.
Historical Peninsula!. This is how we call it! This place rocks! It is full of historical museums, mosques, churches and so on. You should take 3-4 days to be able to go around as it is needed.

A history bar none. The Topkapi, water cisterns, taksim, Suleiman blue mosque are an attestation of the Ottoman elegance, architecture and art. You could spends days in tge Top Capi buildings and grounds. Tge kitchens are amazing. The various gates all have meaning. Tge water cistern is a feat unparalleled today. Ask about tge source of istanbuls water source and the story will amaze you!
The Spice Market. WOW! Luckily we had a guide who was knowledgeable. You can become overwhelmed by the hundreds of vendors. It is a one if a kind experience for sure.

Very Safe - Lovely People. Just take a taxi and then start walking around - this place is simply steeped in historyYou can spend a day just dawdling along seeing everything there is to see great little cafes everyone is most helpful tons to do lots of little shops and arcades

Beautiful city with lots of history. I found Istanbul fascinating and intriguing. It's a bustling city with lots of activity. It was hard to hail a taxi from the street so the best place to arrange taxi service is from the hotel or from a restaurant.

Grand Bazaar. A totally worthwhile experience. You can get lost easily in here. If you want to purchase anything learn to bargain the old way. Start at half of what they are asking. We went back another day and found it much easier having been in before.

Spend a few days in the heart of Istanbul, getting to know the history of the Ottoman Empire!. You'll need 3 days to do all the sights - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Top Kapi palace, Hippodrome, the museums - buy the Museum Card to save some dough and beat the lines!
Beautiful!. Such a beautiful place to just watch people passing by and see pure life! So much to see and hear and smell. Get one of the fish rolls from one of the boats! They are so good! :)

Great Place to Visit. Istanbul where East meets West a vibrant busy cultured historic it has everything visit the Grand Bazaar will take a couple of days to see everything the mosques ruins etc all great fun

Fascinating city, quick stop. As an architect, I've always wanted to tour Higia Sofia. Our tour guide was terrific, we visited the Blue Mosque and the Sultanhamet. Hagia Sofia is sadly neglected. The other mosques are strictly controlled, large but cold despite the heat. The majority of women were covered, perhaps 30% in full burqua. Although many people were friendly , I felt a tension, an uncomfortable feeling on the street. The blaring PA at prayer times contributed to that.
“Absolutely wonderful!”. A great landmark and easy to find. the history of it is excellent. I highly recommend. We were with a guide tour.

City with a great history. Istanbul is full of historical sights. The Historic areas would generally be the old city area, what was Constantinople, what is today Sultanahmet, Seraglio point, the Bazaar area near Eminonu and just across the Golden Horn Galata. Besides these there are a few areas outside this section like the area around the Chora church and Eyup.It's a very interesting city with lots of historic sights to see.

Awesome historical, architectural, cultural knowledge. Topkapi palace, blue mosque, food, cafes, gardens, hammams "traditional bathing. Safety and security all around.I disliked the tricky style of salesmen and tours providers, make sure to negotiate prices and tours in details.
Istanbul. We really enjoyed touring Istanbul our stops included Night Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Topieka Palace, The cistern, Hagia Sophia, and dinner near galata bridge

The Beauty of the Bosphorus. Sailing up the Bosphorus is an absolute must in Istanbul. The view from the water is breathtaking as you dial past grand houses, palaces and hotels. It's also a great way to escape the midday heat in July/August!

Another must. Istanbul must be unique in having so many of its must-see sights so close together. All centre around the Hippodrome and Sultanahmet Square and can be conveniently visited in even a very short visit.

One of the most picturesque ares I've ever visited!. Istanbul is, as advertised, the perfect blend of West and East. You can really see the blend in this area. I stayed in Istanbul for 3 days and it was too short for Istanbul.

A walk through history. I would suggest getting a guide and walking the city for a full day at least. We went to both the European and Asian sides. So many different neighborhoods and such interesting architecture.

Fun city . Istanbul is a great city for shopping, sight seeing and clubbing. Don't miss out on the clubbing scene if you're travelling with friends. There's a club called Reina which is the best club of Istanbul. Make sure you dress well too. Shopping in grand bazaar is great, for women. Lol, so if you plan on shopping for the women in your life you'll get a great bargain on the handbags, pashminas and home decor. Of course, you can gorge on the turkish delights and Baklava. Make sure you get a Hamam (turkish bath). No matter what you do- shop or eat always and always bargain because they increase prices by 50-70% than the actual cost.We also did a cruise to Prince Island which is 1.5 hours away from Istanbul on the bosphorous river. Its an island where no cars are allowed so you can ride a cycle all around or even take a horse cart. Obviously make sure to visit the historical and architectural marvels of Istanbul. They are all concentrated around the same area so getting there shouldn't be an issue. Weather in Istanbul is unpredictable because 2 days before we visited it was pouring heavily. And the day we landed it was pleasant during the day and cold in the nights. DO NOT visit during the summer- you won't enjoy the sightseeing.

Historic Istanbul!. This a an outrageously interesting city. Thousands of things to see and try and taste and visit. First get your map out and really figure out the various parts of Istanbul and then start to explore each area.

Take at least a couple of days (or a few) to discover all of Istanbul's wonderful history.... In peaceful times, Istanbul is a vibrant and fun city to visit, filled with wonderful history, and an array of old structures, some of them dating to the old Roman times.

Incredible Journey with a taste of the East. Many Many things to see and do. We made a cruise stop and then returned to see what we could for 3 days. I really believe you need a full week minimum to see everything and get the experience this world treasure deserves. Prices for USA are very affordable as of Oct 2015.

Worth the time.. There were just a lot of details and I felt like it was an information overload to see everything in a day. Please give these places at least 2 days to visit everything. One day's not enough.

My personal favorite CHORA (Kariye Cami). Probably as significant as Hagia Sophia but visited by only a few ...
This "chapel" size church has excellent mosaics & the best frescoes
in Istanbul. Plan your visit so that around 1 pm you'll have lunch
at the neighboring Asitane Restaurant which has an excellent kitchen
serving also ottoman recipes.

take it all in. exchange your money in counrty maybe get fifty dollars in lira to start lira dollars and euro all excepted but the exchange rate is differant all over check at your hotel also when you are leaving and not flying firest class the exit lines are long two security check points so give yourself at least three hours do not worry you can shop shop duty free till you drop also if you are flying first class tell you drive and he will drop you off past the masses that are exiting if you have the chance fly turkish airlines now if your a christian go to the church of st george head of the greek orthodox church i like to shop at the arasta bazaar it is right by the blue mosque it is smaller and less expensive then the grand bazaar you can get great gift and they will bargain with you if your a cat lover lots a cats for istanbul looking for a treat when at the square look up are find a roof top place to eat lunch adman have on of the best views the square is teaming with life and great people watching but you are also bombard by men touting out tour and places to eat ignore them or they will never leave them alone on of the lines are i know you from the hotel i work there go to any of the meat eateries just look what meats in the window look best they have all lamb gryos they are the best for great people watching grab a bit to eat or a smite sit in the square and just take all the exotic in love it

Good location!!. This hotel is very comfortable. The room was clean and tidy everyday. And all of the staff was cheerful and friendly the whole time!! They were so nice!! And then the hotel had very good location. This location is convenient for both shopping and sightseeing.And you can walk to the old city. it takes about 15~20 minute. So if you go to Istanbul, I recommend this hotel!!
Interesting and cultural neighborhood. Many interesting sights one should make a point of seeing. Can walk to most places the grand bazaar, blue mosque, topkapi palace etc.

Has to be on the bucket list. Amazing area based around the Sultanahmet tram stop, a truly great panoramic view. Lots to see and it is very pleasant walking around, generally you are left alone but I was repeatedly approached by well dressed men offering me information. One tactic is to offer you something and then draw you into a conversation but if you want a guide there are a lot of official ones to be hired and I would recommend this route. It is not the best place to walk to the coast from here, catch a tram for a couple of stops to Eminonu or Karakoy to see the cruise liners. There are lots of restaurants and street food with wonderful atmospheric areas to explore but you will pay tourist prices.
Beautiful country. We walked and saw so many wonderful sights. Restaurant choices were close to unlimited. Going to the mosque may be the highlight of this trip.

East meets West with elegance and style. Istanbul is a rare combination of East meets West, exotic meets classic. It is an exciting city with a heartbeat for people of all ages and interests. The food is excellent, the sights to die for, and the people very nice.
Try the Hop On, Hop Off Bus tour. the Hop On, Hop Off bus gives you a good idea of the lay out of the city and where all the historical sites are located (good for 24 or 48 hours).

Capital of 3 biggest empire in the history. Galata tower and surrounding area have mistic atmosphere, nice walking.You will feel that you are living the old history,and bosphorus view with peagons etc..

Galata Tower. Galata Tower - well worth the 25 lire for a trip to the top by elevator to take a 360 view of Istanbul from the external platform on the tower outside a really nice cafe. There is a full restuarant on the floor below

Neon Tours - above and beyond. We changed the habit of a lifetime and decided to get the most out of our four days in Istanbul by taking a few tours. Through our agent (British Airways) we booked a whole day tour of Istanbul with Neon Tours. Our guide, Gulay, was really fantastic. Informative, attentive, interested in discussion and clearly knew her stuff. Spoke very good English. Punctual. Courteous. Organised a really nice lunch with just enough time to rest. Very helpful on other issues too - like shopping ! I would highly recommend both her company and her. Thanks for a super time!!

Beautiful city. The city of Istanbul is magical. If it's on your "maybe" list for places to travel, reconsider. It should be on your "MUST" list! wandering along the windy streets filled with lively people, colorful markets, beautiful culture..it's a dream.
a Must see. Interesting place to meet. Our tour guide was amazing. Made me understand more about Islam and general culture.

so much beautiful culture and history. This is my favorite city in the world. Istanbul is full of history, beautiful architecture and culture. Many of the amazing things to visit are within walking distance of each other.
so much to see and do. we were overwhelmed with so much to see and dowe will have to come back to see St Sophia and Dolmabahce Palace once again

Amazing Istanbul. The historic áreas of Instanbul is the highlights you can see there. Its amazing time you take to enjoy with local food and local culture. Its incredible how you can enjoy in this place.

A day in Istanbul. At the end of our two week campervan trip in Turkey we spent the last day seeing the main sights of Istanbul. The main sites are all within walking distance to each other. We started at the bottom end of the Main Street and went to see the Roman cisterns first. This amazing underwater storage system is kept in good condition and tickets are 20EU per adult. The visit takes about an hour.We then walked further up the street to see the Hagia Sophia, one of the best examples of a Byzantine church. Fortunately the ticket line was not as long as when we came out. Tickets being 30EU per person. Walk up the ramp on the left hand side of the entrance to go to the second floor which has the most beautiful wall mosaics.While we waited for the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Mosque) to open after the afternoon prayers we enjoyed a typical Turkish lunch at one of the small restaurants. Non Muslim visitors must enter from the separate entrance around the corner on the right hand side. There is no entry fee but if you are not appropriately dressed you can borrow coverings from near the entry door. We also needed to remove and carry our shoes. The building was a disappointment as the outside appeared dirty and drab. The inside beautiful ceiling was totally ruined by a vast array of wires hanging from the ceiling to support the many lights.A must to complete our day in Istanbul was buying some of the most delicious Turkish sweets from a nearby sweet shop to eat after our evening meal.

Steeped in history and full of almost mystical magic.. I approached our visit to Istanbull with an eliment of apprehension in view of the current uncertainties and difficulties in this part of the world. Those fears were soon overcome by the warmth of the local people and the delight of finding we could walk very safely and freely around the Historic areas. It is a place of magical sites and wonderful things to see, and they are all so close to each other and within easy walking distance. Take time to sit and enjoy a Turkish coffee. Initially I thought we had arrived during a carpet sellers convention!! But once you relax into this world of carpet sellers and let the humour flow it can be fun. I told a few at my time of life I was down sizing and had a house full of carpets they could have at a knock down price if they paid the shipping and tax!My advice is if you get the chance visit, it is a wonderful part of the world.If you have a sweet youth and love "Turkish delights" you will have arrived in your. heaven!
Amazing experience !. the history of this city through the ages is simply amazing ! great to visit in the summer months, mystical to visit in winter time !

Not enough time. We arrived via a cruise ship so our visit was just a sample of what Istanbul is like and what we saw was really really nice, so much history and the grand bazaar was just another world!

Topkapi Palace & Dolmabahche Palace & Blue Mosque Area. Topkapi is the Islamic-ish Museum & Dolmabahche is the Fancy Ottoman era winter-palace.don't miss out on both, book early for dolmabahche as the queue can get up to 400 people waiting in line (be there at 10am maximum , otherwise wait in the queue). its really breath-taking.Blue Mosque area features another islamic city, with Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, ""Spice Bazaar & Grand Bazaar which both are nearby (10 mins walking)"".

amazing!. Istanbul is full of history, beautiful architecture and culture... right up my alley! All of the amazing sites were walking distance to our hotel: Basileus. I would recommend Istanbul to anyone wanting a cultural experience!

Historical Attractions of Istanbul...Like a Treasure Hunt!!!. Istanbul is one of the most ancient metropolis with its rich history and wonderful nature, also former capital of many different civilisations, like; Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman Empires. Byzantium, Agusta Antonina, Dersaadet, Asitane, Constantinople, Konstantiniye are the historical names of this cosmopolitan city.Located on two different continents, Europe and Asia divided by the Bosphorus. Here are few hints to help you to create truly special memories during your visit...Here are the main attractions; Hagia Sophia Museum / Church (Ayasofya), Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market ( Egyptian ), Sultanahmet District, Archaeological Museum, Maiden' s Tower, Galata Bridge, Dolmabahce Palace, Galata Tower, Basilica Cistern and many more...You' d be rather to plan first the itinerary and then enjoy your discovery-min 3 days needed...

A walk through the past. Historic areas are: 1) Sultanahmet 2) Ortakoy 3) Bosphorus strait 4) Galata 5) Taksim Square etc.You will need at least 3 days to check out these areas. They have major historical palaces, monuments, mosques, forts, towers and museums in Istanbul.
Excellant restaurant with Fantastic staff. Fantastic and very friendly staff, Cem, Ugur,Bedi and Ali were fanstatic. The food was Excellant. Excellant value. Will definitely go back when in Istanbul.

City of History. Loved the stay of Istanbul. The whole city was great. The transportation is very good and the food is great. There are many historic site of Istanbul which can be explored. Many of them are in Sulthanahmet. So, anyone staying there it's easy to move. Other attractions are also easily accessible from Sultanahmet.
Beautiful Place. This is main place to be. All historical place are near to each other. Must to see and is very clean
East meets west and co-exist. Sites were clean and well maintained. Security was good but not intrusive. Traffic can be a problem, walking from point to point can be better. P

the most amazing city!. I never dreamed this city could be so beautiful. People is nice, helpful, the city is spotless (with soooo many people in the streets, hard to believe!). The whole city is a museum. Fantastic. Will be back!

Worth a single visit. This bazaar is really world famous, and I had heard a lot about it so I had to go just to see what is was all about It really is an interesting place for those who love shopping or just savoring the atmosphere of an old enclosed market place. I took the tram from my hotel to the correct stop with no problem. Just don't show an interest in any item, or the storekeeper will be all over you! I looked at a single scarf, and in an instant it was tied around my neck, and I was shown three others that I also might like! The good part was that I learned 3 different ways of wearing it in about 2 minutes. Don't accept the first price you hear. Start to walk away and the price will go down. Same if you want to buy more than one. Also, with so many places selling the same items, you can compare prices. I wanted some of those Turkish charms that you see everywhere with the blue stones for cheap souvenirs for friends. They are supposed to be for good luck. On a key chain, the prices varied between 3 and 4 TL apiece. Buying 10 of them, I got them from one vendor for 15 TL total, and I'm sure he still made a profit, although he claimed otherwise. It was fun walking around for an afternoon, but I can see that many would not appreciate the hard selling from the merchants. Keep saying "no thanks" and walk on. Also, remember the number on the gate where you entered, as it very easy to get lost strolling down the myriad aisles. Although many places take credit cards, the price will always be less if you pay cash, so take Turkish lira preferably.

Second visit to Istanbul wonderful.Quite more expensive than six years ago but a lot of new good experiences. Will be ba. Quite more expensive than six years ago but a lot of new experiences. Will be back for more fun. Must visit the upmarket shopping centres as well as the local markets but don't miss REYNA the discotheque.
Interesting place!. Nice historic areas of Instanbul!We made a lot of pictures......It is worth it visiting this place if you like history and culture!

Walking the old streets and taking in the atmosphere. The old town is incredible. Two warnings first - scam 1- a shoe shiner drops his brush in front of you and it is deliberate to beg money from you. Scam 2- there are many people claiming to be refugees from Syria. ( some may well be). The grand bazaar is so established that I do not think you can get a genuine bargain. Example. Iznik jug in a shop with no bartering by blue mosque 180 tl. Shop in bazaar 425tl. If you offer half price you still pay more than you should. Highlights were wandering around the streets and seeing the different mosques , the Galata bridge with the fishermen selling their freshly cooked mackerel in bread. The spice market is a sensory revelation. The station is the end of the old orient express and has a lively cafe. Right next to the station is the oldest baklava house on the corner which is well worth a visit. Sunset and nighttime is great to go back to The Hagia Sophia and blue mosque to take pictures

Historic Areas of Istanbul. Did not see all historic areas but there is plenty enough to see. The Mosques are certainly worth a visit and are free but be mindful of local customs for atire as these are places of worship. The Topkapi Palace is worth a visit but some of the main attractions here have long queues. Aya Sofia museum and Basiica Cistern are worth a visit and reasonably priced. Grand Bazar is grand but expect to be occasionally harrassed by owners to view their merchandise.

The only reason to visit. The historic areas of Istanbul are the real reason for visiting. This city is large and overcrowded, with too much traffic, but that is more than compensated for by the wonderful history that takes you right back to the days of the Ottomans so that the overcrowding seems irrelevant.

A Great Mix. A very large city with a population of circa 15m (plus recent walk ins). A blend of modern and ancient adds greatly to this exciting city. Very much worth a visit and needs more than a few days to cover off especially if its hot.
So much to do and see. You will need a lot of days to really get to appreciate all there is to see and experience. The traditional must see(s) are fortunately close together in Sultanahmed

Put on your walking shoes!!!. Put on your walking shoes if you are really going to enjoy the sights in the historic area -- well worth every step. We used a private guide and felt it was worth every penny --Istanbul Local Guides
A blast from the Past. Fascinating place and i really love how they preserve all the historical areas, it's like a blast from the past! people are so very friendly and very accommodating.

The history of Istanbul is amazing. We booked a private walking guide - well worth we saw a lot of the historical sites of Istanbul - this place is amazing - it need all to be explained to you by a local otherwise you would miss out on it all - we will be making a return trip
The on and off bus was a bit expensive and not worth the money.. The markets are fantastic and great for bartering. Plenty of knock off items and nick knacks to get lost in.
A great neighborhood. Take in the many historical sites but also take in life in Istanbul. So much to see and experience. We found it safe and when we looked lost, someone always offered to help.
A vibrant city!. A stunning city with so many fantastic places to visit. All within easy reach of each other or an easy public transport journey.
Historical Istanbul. there are many historical areas in Istanbul and also in Turkey itself. Basically not a history buff but you come to appreciate history here.
Must Visit the lovely intersection of Europe with Asia. A city founded in around 650 BC or based on some excavations over 3000 BCE, history and historical artifacts can be found in abundance.

Galata Tower good. Stayed in the vincity of Galata Tower and although it was a nightmare for cabs to in and out of, I liked the area. The Tower at night is picturesque and the eateries around the Tower are nice and the food impressive.

History, art, architecture, religion.... Writing about historic areas of Istanbul would require thousands of pages, as practically the large part of the city could be defined as "historic" areas... From Fatih, Sultanahmet, Sirkeci... to Beyoglu and Pera Museum. From Topkapi to Dolmabahce... From Galatasaray to the islands... I loved it when I was a kid. I love and understand better the spirit of this incredible city. A world of its own !

2014. Toured all the historic areas, Top Kali palace, Tower of Galata's, Aghia Sophia, Blue Mosque and others with the help of a guide and private mini bus. Recommend that a traveler does it like this too.

One of the best in the world. Istanbul and history are nearly synonym :))
Historic Areas of Istanbul are the places you should see at least one time in your life time.
Amazing History. Istanbul is a very safe and wonderful place to visit with so much history. We spent 3 days in Istanbul and we wanted to stay longer.

Istanbul welcomes the world to its wonders !. Excellent city to visit ~ people come from all over the world and that's what makes it so exciting... So many places to visit ~ you need lots of stamina ~ you can visit 6 or 7 in a day if you are young and healthy. Older people can do 4 or 5 and have a leisurely lunch and then a shower and nap b4 dinner. So many choices everyone in the family will be mesmerized. I loved it but be careful walking some of the sidewalks are uneven unexpectedly.

Living history.... This city gives you very different feelings. You can understand when you come and take a breathe. I have worked in tourism ten years. And been here as a professional and a volunteer... Have seen many places but can't compare any of this with Istanbul...
In each Corner. In each corner of Istanbul there is many historic areas need to be discover and seen by tourist from old buildings and mosques

very colourful, busy city.. Istanbul is a most exciting city. Friendly people, great food & restaurants. Easy to get around on the public transport, or get the bid double decker red busses, hop on & hop off.
nice visit to istanbul. I have been to blue mosque and aya sofiya . the attraction are really attractive and deserve for visit. Grand bazar takes you back to 100 years of life living

Synergy of Cultures. I don't think that there is any need to elaborate more on Istanbul. This is a city where you will encounter a mixture of civilization, from Greek, Byzantine mixed Islamic. The location on the Bosporus adds to it's charm. A living city with a rich sites to see supported by excellent food, and services
Istanbul is an open museum. Just walk in Istanbul it is all history many many historic places with walking distance between each othersGood descriptions wrote on the historic places
tourist attractions. all the tourist attractions (mosques, churches etc..) in Istanbul are a must see at least once in a life time especially Aya Sophia
Good experience. Pudding Shop. Full of atmosphere. Good food at reasonable prices. Friendly service and full of history.

great vacation. istanbul is a city to visit once at least in life.city of multiple civilisations anc colores.I like most the sites touristiques as mosques,musiums,shoping areas,restaurants..I dis liked the crowed specialy at the entrance of the famous sites.

Istanbul is a wonderful place to visit. There is so much history to see and felt very safe.. Istanbul is a wonderful place to visit. There is so much history to see and felt very safe. We traveled there by ourselves 5 years ago and then decided to join a tour group to see Istanbul and all around the countryside. Ephesus is a MUST along with Gallipoli and Ankara.

An experience like no other!. They are too numerous to mention but right at the top is Topikapi Palace Museum which houses some of the most fabulous artifacts and gems that are absolutely stunning! There are long queues sometimes but the wait is worth it. Most of the other famous tourist attractions such as Hagia Sophia, Egyptian Obelisk, etc. are all within walking distance of each other.

Historic Areas of Istanbul is wonderful. Historic Areas of Istanbul is wonderful and easy to get to. A lot of people but still easy to walk around. Lovely atmosphere. A lot of sellers but they are not as offensive as in many other places.

History beneath evry stone. Lucky me before going to istanbul i watched the documentary called Byzantium: A Tale of 3 Cities bu Simon Sebag He describes how Istanbul became Islam's most powerful city.My advice is to watch it its free on youtube , just feel the history instead of just seeing it.To me istanbul,jerusalem and rome are open history book for us.I recommend to avoid summer visit ie june july august as its bit hot and crowded ...what you need is walk and enjoy.
must visit. There is so much to see & do in Istanbul....... highly recommend the cruise on the Bosporus..... but buy the ticket down at the waterfront near Sirkeci station

compact and fascinating history. the history speaks for itself. the main historical areas are close to each other and the tram system (if required) is good value and well run. Strong multicultural feel to the place without being intimidating
Historic Areas of Istanbul. What an experience to visit all these areas. The history that was made in Istanbul is absolutely mind-blowing!

Easy access to Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Palace, Sophia Hagia. Several great historic sites are within easy walking distance of each other, including Blue Moque, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sophia, Grand Bazaar and Spice market. Early morning visits to Sophia are recommended as it becomes very busy by noon. you can spend 2 days just exploring this area ....

The sense of history jumps off the page into real world streets.. The Old City of Istanbul and Sultanahmet is a true melting pot of history and the meeting of east and west is omnipresent. Just wandering the streets, let alone visiting the main attractions is worth the visit just to soak up the atmosphere. Beware the carpet salesmen that pounce on you before/ after visiting the mosques!

Crossroads of History. Turkey and Istanbul truly are the Crossroads of the World and the Crossroads of History. The scenery and sights were magnificent, the people warm and friendly, the food interesting, tasty and healthy, the history…well, it is all there from Hittites to Syrian Refugees. Really, it is an assault on the senses, in the very best way.

Magical place. There is a lot to see in Istanbul, we went in a cruise, and spent the day viewing the Blue Mosque, the palace, Haggia Sophia, The Grand Bazzar, the food is excellent and the people are very inviting, I love the culture, the old and new, it's a maggic place

Amazing not to be missed. Pls make sure that you visit the archeological museum when you visit Topkapi palace entrance is only 20 TL and fully worth the price. You can see all the historic monuments including some mummies the bust of Alexandra the great, unfortunately the museum dedicated to him was closed for renovations.
Takism and Goleta areas for shopping and restaurants. Stayed in the Taksim area where the nightlife and shopping can be found. There are a number of sightseeing venues as well.

Awesome place. Istanbul is just beautiful, the history, the food the marketing the buildings and the atmosphere. You don't need o go to fancy restaurant to experience a good traditional Turkish food because they are right there in front of you in the streets. So go in your pace, seeing things slowly and take time to enjoy it because you definitely will love every corner of that ancient city. ,

Exquisite and different. Istanbul has enough history to keep you busy for many days. The old town include the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi, Basilica Cistern, Archeological museums, Grand Bazaar, Egyptian Bazaar, City walls. Sultanahmet area is a good area to stay which allow you to walk everywhere.There is also the Golden Horn, Bospherus river, Galata Tower, Dolmabache palace.On the modern side there are the infrastructure and well developed technology that Ataturk leader of modern Turkey initiated from 1924.

A Lesson in History!. On our sight-seeing tour around the City we saw a large number of Historic "Sights" such as the 'Blue' Mosque, Hagia Sofia - a Church converted to a Mosque, the Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazar - probably the largest covered market in the World! This was like a lesson in history - the Romans to the Turks - spanning more than 2500 years!!
Unparalleled beauty. The Old City in Istanbul is magnificent! So many monuments of great historical,political and religious importance, gathered all together! Words are needless...

Haghia Sofia, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern. Blue Mosque and Haghia Sofia I do strongly believe do not need additional introductions, you must visit them, each is special in its own way. I would just like to add that local people are very friendly, helpful and that you feel welcome in Istanbul and all their historical monuments.Basilica Cistern is not maybe so famous as these other two places, but it is something you must see. Such place to exist under the streets of Istanbul is unbelievable. And it was build so long ago and it has survive all this troubled historical times...must see.Sailing on Bosporus with tourist boats, also nice experience, visiting Asia for few minutes. This town, people, food, they stay with you even when you leave.

A city that never sleeps. There is so much to see and do in Istanbul. We spent a wonderful afternoon viewing the Blue Mosque, Haggia Sophia Grand covered Bazaar and the Hippodrome and Obelisks. What a fun day!
An objective in life: Istambul. Wonderful, amazing, speakless. To be there is a total pleasure. There are not much places with so many different cultures, tastes, smells and colors.

Fantastic area Wonderful Sights. Istanbul has so many beautiful and wonderful sights a lot of which are located in this area. I would suggest taking a couple of days to just wonder around and take in the sights

Breathtaking and Magical!. Istanbul is simply magical.
The historic areas are just brimming was fascinating places everywhere you look - shops, mosques, restaurants, galleries, markets!
You could spend days wandering about - just pick a high landmark and what may seem daunting and confusing will seem less so in finding your way around.
Needs another visit solo. Fantastic places with greatness in history of islamic civilization with a smell of mixed different religion and people lived over there
Wonderfu travel. Wonderful touristic and historical sites as Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi, cistern and archeological museum

Asia meets Europe. Istanbul is crowded and spread out - it takes an age to get to the centre from the airport - but most things worth seeing are walkable from each other, plus there is a great tram service should your legs start to tire. Get the Istanbul card for access to most of the highlights. Two to three days is sufficient.
Perfect combination. A perfect mix of roman, byzantine, and muslim cultures is combined with beautiful views of Golden Horn. One of the cultural summits of the world.

Great place to explore. We were staying on the other side of the bridge (in Beyloglu). Our hotel owner suggested we walk over to the old city. Walking is such a great way to get to know a place.As we crossed over to the old city we noticed the Spice Bazaar straight ahead so we explored it and then headed to the Hagia Sophia Museum. This was the only place we visited that had an entrance fee (30 TL pp). They are currently renovating this so we didn't get to see as much as I suspect we would have otherwise. We stopped for a fresh juice there which was lovely but definitely pricey compared to what you can buy on the street.Next stop was the Blue Mosque which was beautiful and then on to the Grand Bazaar which is amazing. We only walked part of it on this day as we were both tired with all the walking. I am sure it would be easy to spend at least half a day here.I loved that there is very little hassling from people to buy their goods. The Turkish people are so friendly and helpful.I would recommend having a map but then just wandering around the Spice and Grand Bazaars and when you are tired of them asking someone to show you where you are on the map rather than stressing about where you are all the time. We spent most of the day wandering and occasionally checking the map to make sure we knew approx. where we were. Definitely make this part of your trip to Istanbul.

Great places. The area of Sultanahmet is a must. But be sure to get your tickets to Aya Sofia and Topkapi in advance. Otherwise be prepared to stand in a line for a Long time. Istanbul-card is a good idea. It gives you free ride in hop-on bus as well.

Topkapi Sarayi Haremi -- fascinating. The Topkap palace is a must visit--the harem quarters are just beautiful and full of such interesting history.
Wasn't as impressed with the Blue Mosque. Also loved Aya Sofya and the Basilica Cistern.

So many wonderful sights, too little time!. All of the major sights in the Old City are walkable, and Rick Steves' Istanbul guidebook was our constant and excellent companion. From the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market, to the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, Suleymaniye Mosque and Basilica Cisertern, we did it all in 3 days, plus a Bosphorus cruise!
Hello Istanbul !. Love the ambiance of two continents in one country. Beautiful old town areas. Would love to come back again !
A must see in Istanbul. Lovely place for a visit. it is located within walking distance. beautiful view nearby the jetty/river

What's not to love?!. So many sights and all within a very easy walking distance off each other. We visited the blue mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkaki Palace (and Harem), Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome (obelisks) and the Grand Bazaar over two days. No guide necessary (although we used the audio guides in most places). All within walking distance in Sultanahmet. Plenty of great restaurants as well (and some very average ones...).

Galata tower.
