By tramway and metro you can reach Taxim square and take a long but amusing walk through Istiklal street you can buy any thing to eat all the way to Galata area that is nice and crowded.The tower is ancient but great you can watch Istanbul from above.you can walk a steep road from the tower to the sea side where you can take a ride to your hotel.
Great weekend break. Lots to see and do lovely city to visit. We used the tour bus to see the city ad also did a river cruise. Enjoyed the shops and the Blue Mosque
A week in Istanbul. Employ a guide who should be able to bypass queues to museums etc and explain the wonderful history of this amazing city.

Bustle and haggle. The atmosphere is tremendous though heaving with people and chaotic. The Muezzin calling the faithful to prayer in a dozen mosques added to the bustle. We picked a four day public holiday to go by mistake although we could hardly change the date of my wife's birthday!! The Grand Bazaar and the Egyptian spice bazaar were closed for the whole time. There were plenty of other street bazaars and stalls everywhere to satisfy the most ardent souvenir hunter. Formal sites were aplenty in this World heritage site. Every restaurant we passed had a waiter trying to persuade passers by to enter. Very charming and no threat all. They often tried to flatter my wife by saying she looked 25. We laughed. All good fun. We had a magical time in Istanbul and it was sad to go home with so much unseen.

The heart of Istanbul.. This is the touristy part of Istanbul where you will find most of the historic sites. Hoards of tourists and shops selling cheap souvenirs. Lots places to eat. Has nice exotic feel to this area.

Lots of people and hills but at least the nain sights are close together.. Istanbul is a vast city but the classic historic parts are mostly in one area and can easily be reached by tram, on foot or by taxi. But beware, Istanbul is very hilly. A day of walking about, especially if it is warm, can be very tiring.

Extremely busy city, but worth the visit. Istanbul is a really busy city, but its still one that I wouldn't recommend missing out on. The historic areas of Istanbul has a lot to offer, and a couple of day tours with a good guide will have you covered. There are many interesting things to see, and a lot of them involve walking from one place to another. The city is very hilly, and if you plan to walk a lot, be sure to wear really comfortable shoes. It has a lot to offer in terms of its vibrant history and culture. My suggestion is that you go around and see some of the less visited places too. For example, although Blue Mosque is lovely, Rustam Pasha Mosque makes for a really nice visit too, because it has something different to offer. Spice Bazaar and Grand Bazaar are the places to visit, but I found some really nice items at smaller, less touristy bazaars at significantly lesser prices.A couple of bad experiences with taxi drivers in Istanbul over the first two days of my visit (they claimed they had no change, or something was wrong with the meter and took more money, or dropped us about a 7 min walk away from the Taksim square when we asked to be dropped off at the square) made us stick to Uber, which we were extremely happy with. Be sure to visit a public hammam while in the City; its one of those Turkish experiences you don't want to miss. Loved the city ! will be back
buy readymade garments and handicrafts. visit Grand Bazar it is a good place to bargain for all sorts of things like textiles and souvenirs.

A city full of history. Istanbul is full of history. You can feel the vibes while walking. Please try to read some of the city's history before or while visiting it. It would be extremely helpful and you'll love the city that way!

Eat,Pray,Walk n Love. Istanbul is a must visit for the cultural experience as much as for its historical lineage..Visit the Galata Tower for panaromic views that will get etched in your memories,forever...Seagulls flying over the towers,entire expanse of the Bhosphorous and splendid views of the entire city can definately uplify your mood...The spice market offers a feast for the eyes and puts your sense of smell in an overdrive...We purchased tasty rose n pistachios lokums(local delicacy) as well..Any visit to Istanbul is incomplete without a visit to the Grand Bazzar wherein we were spoilt for choice and the Bhosphorous Cruise...besides visting the renowed mosques take a walk down the sultanahmet area and also visit Hafiz Mustafa Bakers for a treat to your taste buds(Kunefe was Gr8)!!..Be prepared to be on your toes and am sure you will fall in love with this city,just as we did...Cheers!!

INTERESTING PLACE! WALK...WALK... EAT...ENJOY!. I visited Istanbul with my wife as her birthday gift. We stayed for almost 5 days in the other part of Istanbul which is not a busy place. Every morning we normally ride the boat to reach other destinations such as this historic places... we have to walk for the whole day, tiring but a lot of interesting places to see, a lot of things to try and food to taste. The market was awesome, my wife could have enjoyed her shopping if she didnt bring lots of baggage fom Dubai. The quality of clothing is good and the price is amazing. We were just thinking we might get overbaggage if we will buy so many things. You'll never get tired of walking coz you'll see so many different attractions, restaurants, and even street foods which you wouldnt miss.My advise, dont stay in hotels near the crowded places of Sultanamet, stay in the other side to enjoy the boat ride as well. and Dont bring a lot of things/ luggage so you will enjoy the shopping, Great experience, will definitely come back,

4 days in Istanbul. Day 1: We arrived in Istanbul around 4pm from London and managed to get to our hotel around 5pm (Muyan Suites – a fantastic place to stay – ranked 21 out of 11,000 places in Istanbul. They were ranked 3rd when we booked it at the time. The owner Aslan and Taner are fantastic people who made our stay a very pleasant one. I promised them that I’d recommend them to everyone – so here’s my recommendation!). We freshen up after having an excellent relaxing late afternoon at Muyan and decided to go out for an evening meal. We managed to find an excellent restaurant called ‘Rami’ where we were taken to a rooftop table with a very close view of the Blue Mosque. We had our meal there and we had a wonderful time listening to the prayers/music throughout. After the meal, we had a late night stroll around the shops and having a great time talking to the Turkish people. They are very friendly and respectful – they didn’t pressure us to buy things – it was just friendly persuasion to purchase things! After an hour we went back to the hotel to get some well earned sleep!Day 2: Our first full day, after an excellent breakfast at Muyan, we headed for the ferry to take a 2hr trip around the Bosphorus. When we purchased the tickets we were told we leave in 10 minutes and that there will only be 20 tourists maximum on the boat. Instead we found ourselves waiting on the boat for an hour before it departed as the boatowner was trying to squeeze in many tourists as he could which ended up around 40+! We forgave him quickly as it was a lovely sunny day and we had a great 2 hours going along the Golden Horn first before heading back to Ataturk bridge to venture the other end where we saw all the landmarks (Dol palace, Princes Island, Istanbul University, Modern Museum etc). After the ferry trip we decided to cross the bridge to go over to the other side where we found Galata Tower, we then found a nice place for lunch (meze) further up the hill. After lunch we then found Cukurcuma street where we found a lovely quaint museum called Museum of Innocence (past TomTom street). It was an excellent museum which lasted an hour. The Museum was based on the Novel (same title as museum) by the legendary Orhan Pamuk who wrote the book about Kemal and his love for a poor woman and they apparently met at the building (where the museum is situated). My wife got free entrance to the museum because she had read the book and took the book along with her to prove she had read it. The book get stamped and you enter the museum free – there is apparently a ticket on the back page of the book and it get stamped. I recommend people to visit this museum, not just because the museum is brilliant, but the location around it is quieter and the ambience is soothing. Afterwards we headed back to the other side and decided to visit the Spice Market. We bought Turkish Delights, Jasmine Tea and Saffron from Stall 51 (yes a specific stall – because stall 51 was filmed by the BBC last year for Rick Stein’s programme ‘From Venice to istanbul’ and we managed to find the lady who owns the stall – think her name is Bilic. She has great knowledge of the spices and we managed to have a chat with her while buying the ingredients there). Thereafter we then accidently bumped into the Grand Bazaar which we managed to get ourselves lost within it for 2 hours before finding our hotel again! After freshening up we then had our next evening meal and an excellent place (the name escapes me) where we had the best figs and cloves ever for pudding! Then we had an late evening stroll before heading back to Muyan.Day 3: We decided to do the old town and visit all the landmarks. We started off with the Blue Mosque which was a lovely place, the interior designs is amazing. Then we headed for the Basilica Cistern which is a real treat – I really recommend this place. It is an underground cistern that was built around 550AD by Justinian I and the place is amazing! It was very dark inside, but was lighten up with yellow lamps alongside the pillars of the cistern. We saw fishes swimming along the water which was breathtaking. We finally found the legendary Medusa head which is upside down and her ‘sister’ whose head is tilted sideways. After this, we then visited the Hagia Sophia which was a very interesting 2 hours – the mosaics was great to see after it was originally plastered away during the Ottoman period. We then had streetfood lunch – Simic and corn on the cob for a pricey 4 LIRA – just one pound! Great simple food. Then we decided to walk to Topkapi Palace and visit the park. After that we had Turkish coffee and baklavas at a café as a treat and to rest our legs. We then decided that no trip is completed without a Turkish Massage – so for 115Lira each, my wife and I had a traditional massage. It was a fantastic experience, a little painful but well worth the pain! I tipped the man 20 Lira and he seemed very happy with that tip especially after I had no idea what the going rate was for a tip. Feeling very refreshed we headed back to the hotel for a little rest before freshening up to go for the last evening meal. As expected – it was another great evening and we made sure we tried all the traditionals – sumac, suvec etc. Turkey do simple food, yet the experience is much better than these complicated fancy international cusine.Day 4: We had to go back to Ataturk Airport around 11am as it was the start of Eid festival and we didn’t want to be held up in traffic/delays. We were worried for nothing as there was no major traffic or delays and we managed to have a safe journey back to London which is 10 degrees colder than Istanbul. We both agreed we had a fantastic time in Istanbul as it was a magical experience and will recommend all friends to visit there and that they should have no concerns with the safety issues and the current political climate. The children loved our presents that we bought for them (evil eyes, bath robes, Turkish delights, bracelets etc).Lastly I want to thank the legenday Enigma2007 who I have secretly been following his comments on this forum for the past 9 months so that I could have a taste of what to expect in Istanbul. I recommend people to follow him – he has been very thorough and I hope that he enjoys my views of Istanbul. Happy Eid to everyone – Istanbul is a real treasure and we will visit again no doubt.To anyone who has any concerns about Istanbul in terms of safety – don’t – it is very safe and no more dangerous than London, Paris and new York. EVERYONE is friendly.
History are meant to be enjoyed!. Come here and enjoy every museum, dont just come here for a few good pictures! Every place has it's story to tell, and a history like here worth to be listened to!

Exciting, vibrant, interesting Istanbul. Three empires that left major imprints, many cultures, mercantile spirit and Mediterranean sea that opens mental vistas and expands views - that is Istanbul in a nutshell and it is unforgettable! We spent 5 wonderful days in this crazy city and already want to come back since there is so much more to see and experience. The heart of old town, Sultanahmet offers the best cultural and historical attractions as well as many options for great dining and entertainment. Just walking around we came across friendly, courteous, gregarious people, some of them merchants, politely but unwaveringly trying to lure us into their carpet or other shops that were hard to ignore and townspeople happy to socialize. The museums were fantastic, layers and layers of civilizations leaving their mark - Hagia Sophia's amazing architecture and mosaics was awe-inspiring and left us speechless, Topkapi Palace's gorgeous tiles from Iznik adorning it's walls with the genius of the architect Mimar Sinan's structures within the palace and little gems like the Haseki Hurrem Sultan Hammami just outside Aya Sophia also designed by Mimar Sinan brought joy to the beholder. The Grand Bazaar was an incomparable experience itself with trying to dodge merchants everywhere vying for your business. One thing is for sure - do not buy anything at first sight, there are no price tags so bargaining is implied. It is almost a battle of wits who will outsmart who: the merchant the shopper or vice-versa! This is a socializing event, too, it wouldn't be interesting if you just paid and walked away! Such fun! The experience of entering a mosque for the first time was unique, it was in the Blue Mosque-the Sultan Ahmed Mosque-lovely blue tiles adorn the walls thus the name, it is also an active mosque with strict attire rules of removing shoes and wearing clothes that cover knees and shoulders as well as head cover for women. You are given plastic bags in which you place your shoes while touring the interior. Be sure to wear socks!!! The carpet that lines the interior is definitely in need of replacing, the odor was bad. We stayed at the inimitable Four Seasons on the Bosphorus, an unforgettable experience in itself, so we had to take a taxi every time to get to the old town that was c. 7km away but it was well worth it, taxi fares are more than reasonable and function smoothly. We were told to always find a legal taxi, there are "wild" taxis that charge much more and to go to the Four Seasons in Sultanahmet where we were to ask the doorman to call a taxi. It is true because when we hailed a taxi on the street he wanted double the amount that we normally paid! All in all our visit to Byzantium/Constantinople/Istanbul is carved in our memory and hearts forever and left us with fond memories.

I would highly recommend hiring a tour guide to walk you through this place. Without the tour guide, you will likely miss a lot of the monuments and culture. AMAZING CITY. many place with beautiful decoration in here you can found..amazing trip going here and cant hardly wait to go back

Loved Istanbul. I had a fantastic time in Istanbul and highly recommend visiting. A lot of the best historical sites are mostly in a small geographic area so you can walk to them easily if you're in the Sultanahmet district. The Hagia Sophia is a must see. It was once the largest Christian cathedral in the world for many centuries. You also need to visit the Blue Mosque, a beautiful mosque from the Ottoman period. Other points of interest would be the Basilica Cistern, an underground cavernous area where you'll find a large stone upside down head of Medusa, and the Topkapi Palace with its many ornate rooms and gardens. You will have an amazing time!

If you like history, you'll love Istanbul. Walking into Haghia Sophia was the highlight. For over 700 years it was the largest building in the world and it was the Great Church of Constantinople. Another good thing is the Grand Bazaar....a little secret: the old part of the Grand Bazaar has the best food. The shwarmas are not cooked with gas or electric but with charcoal.

Americans need to smile more!. Istanbul is a city that will cater to each of your five senses and will make you smile as you take it all in. Despite the lateness of the season, there were still blossoms to be smelled in the gardens and spices to be savored in the markets. Everywhere you look there is history and this history is being preserved and incorporated into the tourist life blood of this wonderful city. Ataturk created this modern and secular nation-state and his wisdom is paying handsome dividends. Here the past is acknowledged and preserved for future generations to study and enjoy, in a safe and welcoming country. Visiting all of the attractions -- the Mosques & Topkapi and strolling the hippodrome are a "must do." So are the evening adventures. You have to visit the Grand Bazaar and just enjoy the sights and listen to the languages and see the rhythm of their lives. Get some Turkish coffee and smoke some nargilia (water pipe). Watch a football match in a cafe or play backgammon with some old guys. This is a great place to hang out and Americans need to hang out more. We were strolling across a plaza near the Obelisk and a street vendor called out "hello!" and I smiled and waved him off and he said "Are you from Canada?" I was curious so I said "Yes, how did you know?" He said "The Americans don't smile. They are always looking down." I told my friends and they'd agreed. They all started looking up (still watching for missing stones) but smiling more and relaxing. This is a safe city where the people are genuinely warm. Don't worry about the restaurant you pick -- they have over 11,000 so if you only go to the top 10% you still have over 1,000 choices that will be excellent. The food in this area is excellent - you're hardest choice is ambiance.

Constantinople. Istanbul is a trully amazing city. there is no feelings of animosity, despite some media suggestions. The place is a truly great place and a must for any discerning traveller. The food is equally as exciting as the city

istanbul. Istanbul in Turkey is a city that straddles Europe and Asia across the Bosphorus Strait. The Old City reflects cultural influences of the many empires that once ruled here. In the Sultanahmet district, the open-air Roman-era Hippodrome was for centuries the site of chariot races, and Egyptian obelisks remain. The iconic Byzantine Hagia Sophia features a soaring dome and Christian mosaics.Istanbul has a number of major attractions derived from its historical status as capital of the Byzantine and Ottoman Empires. These include the Sultan Ahmed Mosque (the "Blue Mosque"), the Hagia Sophia, the Topkapı Palace, the Basilica Cistern, the Galata Tower & bridge, the Grand Bazaar to name just a very few.
Great. Plenty of choice, we found an Indian restaurant called DUBB which we would recommended with plenty to cater for vegetarians

A beautiful city. A guide was recommended by the manager [A.J. alias Robert Downey Jnr!] for a very reasonable price. We were guided around the beautiful and inspiring Topkapi palace, the Agia Sofia and the Blue Mosque in the morning. Our guide then took us to a cafe which and left us for an hour while she went home to feed her baby. The food was excellent. On her return, we went tom the Grand Bazaar and a carpet showroom. An extremely interesting day, taken at the pace of our oldest member, a very active 87 year old. Being with a guide we were spared the hassle which is usual in this part of the world. I understand that in Turkey, all guides are university graduates, and our certainly knew her subject. Well worth the outlay.

Beautiful city with friendly people. Took the Big Bus Tour Hop on Hop Off bus. I think it's a great way to explore the city until the edge of the Asian side of Istanbul, you may take half day to do both Red line and Blue line offered. Try to avoid peak hours for the tours as traffic in the city can be tough during that period. Also don't forget to try the Bosphorus Cruise during sunset. Google for Turyol or another company (sorry can't remember the name) that also provides service for water taxi connecting Eminonu ( the main ferry hub situated besides Galata Bridge) to Besiktas or Uskudar. Those two are the cheapest option as they didn't come with foods or drinks but you can still purchase on your own right? Also do try the famous fish sandwich called "Balik ekmek" which are sold by few stalls at Galata Bridge for 8 Turkish Lira. Visited Istanbul in September and weather was great, not too hot and not too cold. Great to be outdoor on beautiful sunny season :)Do come to Istanbul at least once in a life time. Enjoy the journey through times and where east meets west! Try also the food and Turkish coffee and enjoy the Hammam experience.

Not to be missed in Istanbul. There is so much to see here. Please wear your walking shoes. A guided tour is a good start, and you might go back on your own to see more. For example, at the Aya Sophia, there is a free entrance along the side near Topkapi Palace to see many of the burial tombs that are quite striking and not on the paid tours. I used Efendi tours and was quite pleased, and I'm sure there are many groups that offer excellent tours of these beautiful sites.

If you are not that in to tourist shopping their is plenty of time to see the Grand Bazaar on the same day. If you want tourist knock off crap you may need more time at the Bazaar. On the second day see the Mosque of Suleiman the Magnificent, the Spice Bazaar, and the public ferry of the Golden Horn all on the same day. For hand rolled Turkish Delights go to Gozde in the Spice Bazzar.It helps greatly to read about these sights before you go or use Tours By Locals.

Istanbul: Two-Continent Trip. With its 8,000 year life span, Istanbul history is very alive and palpable. Museums -Hagia Sofia, Palaces -Topkapi, Mosques -Blue Mosque & Rüstem Pasha, Churches -St Anthony of Padua, Bazaars -Grand Bazaar & Spices Bazaar, hammams -Çemberlitaş, towers - Galata, the City Wall, Hipodrom, Tombs, Aqueduct, Anatolian Fortress, etc. Great city to live and recount history back and forth between Europe and Asia.

One of the great historic cities on earth!. This is a pretty generalized title, but if you are in Istanbul of course you have to see the historic areas. There are so many, it's best to discuss each in its own section.

Best don't stay here, just come for sightseeing. Historic areas, known as Laleli and Sultan Ahmet districts accommodate the few sights to be seen in Istanbul from Ottoman and mostly Byzantine times. Above the sights this is probably one of the most decadent areas of the city also hiding many tourist traps in terms of lodging, dining etc. I would highly recommend that you choose some of the nearby districts as Sisli, Besiktas or Otarkoy for lodging and take a ride to the historical sights. Australians visiting Istanbul – a few tips for 2016. We had never been before. We took a cabin on a 36 cabin boat from Athens through the Greek Isles to Istanbul – great cruise on the Variety Voyager. So Istanbul – we stayed near the water on the street full of old elegant bank buildings most of which are now hotels or galleries. It is the area between the Galata Tower and the water below it and sometimes is referred to as Karakoy. Tip #1 - Don’t get a guide . The quality of guides in Istanbul was so much lower than in the historical sites on the Turkish coast we visited as we came up from Athens. Two issues – they are just not well qualified – saying no more than in your guide book and next, a lot of your money goes on the lunch at a restaurant run by the bus company. Tip # 2 – get a tram pass – there is an excellent tram which runs from the Dolmabache Palace in the CBD end of the city, through to the area we stayed at and through to all the key sites in the old city. Clean, fast , efficient – it snakes right up to all the tourist spots you are likely to fit in. Alternatively there is the big open top bus – we did not but we saw it at every place we went so it would have been quite good. Tip # 3 – Museum pass – we didn’t because we unwisely booked a group tour, but it is a queue saver if noting else. Several locations though do not recognise it. Most sites you wish to see are only 10 to 15 mins slow walk apart and close to the tram stops.

The Meeting point of Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman era. The part of Istanbul where you will enjoy historical and cultural treasure from Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman era represents the huge Sultanahmet square. If you have limited time, make your priorities and make every minut of your visit worthy.HOW TO GET TO SULTANAHMET SQUAREIt is easy accesible by tram line T1 or metro line Zeytinburn-Kabataš /get off at Sultanahmet sq. stop/. A more beautiful option is drive by tourist buses get on&get off. They have stop in front of Blue mosque.WHAT TO VISITThe major attractions represent: Blue mosque (Sultanahmet mosque), Haghia Sophia, Topkapi palace and Basilica Cistern. These sights are located within walking distance. Only problem are long lines in front of these sights. For example, only visit to Topkapi palace involves four hours at least. Also, long lines plus visit to each of other mentioned attractions involve a half day.Walking along the narrow and winding streets of this area is really beautiful experience. I came across the charming traditional Turkish houses beautifully painted in blue, green, red color. Also, walk along Soqukcesme street, that runs parallel to the walls of Topkapi palace and you will find the wooden houses, typical examples of Ottoman architecture.I would like to mention two beautifully decorated fountains worth your admiration. The first one is the Fountain of Ahmet III in rococo style with adorable tiles and valuable inscription in front of Topkapi palace. The second one is the Fountain of Emperor Wilhelm II with polished granite columns and gold mosaic dome in front of Blue mosque. TAKE A BREAKWhen you get tired, and feel thirst and hunger, it is time for break. There are stands with refresments at Sultanahmet square. They offer traditional Turkish ice-cream, different kinds of fruit, freshly made natural juices.If you are in mood to have a break at table, don't miss cafes/restaurants located on the top of the buildings in this area. You will be rewarded with an amazing view.PAY ATTENTION TO:Be ready to wait in long lines in front of the attractions. Because, Istanbul is pretty warm and sunny city in September and October, don't forget to bring with yourself a bottle of water and the essential items as like a hat, a sun protection creme, a sun glasses and the city map.Enjoyable time quaranteed!

A city for your soul. "If one had but a single glance to give the world, one should gaze on Istanbul." - Alphonse de LamartineThis year, to celebrate our first wedding anniversary my husband and I decided to visit a place we had both long wanderlust-ed after - Istanbul. The world's only transcontinental city - the truest meeting of east and west. While we both looked forward to our trip eagerly and counted down the days to get there, we could have never anticipated our reaction to this breathtaking city. Long story short - we fell head over heels in love. Whether it was the innumerable shades of blue that colored the cityscape, or the lavish and delectable breakfast spreads, the hills that made our calves burn or the 14th century buildings that just seemed to pop out of every street corner, we do not know what made us lose our hearts to Istanbul. All we know is it has forever melded to our souls.The historic areas were an absolute delight. Couple of quick tips, make sure you pace yourself and don't try to do all of Sultanahmet at once, come back for a few hours every day - Istanbul is very easy to get around and its only when you do a few trips that you'll understand the layers to the city. Also, the monuments ( Aya Sofya, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace) can be completely overwhelming if you try to cram them into short periods, and being so majestic, they deserve dedicated time of their own. And finally, make sure you visit some of the lesser known monuments - they are treasures in their own right.

Get out on foot to explore this amazing city. Unique in all of the world .. Istanbul has thousands of years of history and you can get some of the sense of that impressiveness by just walking around the old streets.Up front I will make a note of security concerns. (I never felt unsafe at any time while walking in daylight - but I'm a man and I'm quite a veteran traveller.) During just 2 day I witnessed people selling drugs, police chasing illegal street traders, and gangs of children (presumably syrian refugees) bursting into the restaurant and snatching food from tables. Quite impressive for 4 hours.There is a clear need to be aware of the security situation if you are travelling to Istanbul. I doubt that I would let my daughter roam around freely in this city.Having said that - there are some amazing spectacles and the old town in particular is very easy to get about. Just walk!It's hot in the sun - so cover up and keep hydrated - but if you are an explorer like me then you can't help but be enchanted by the old and busy streets. This city is no relic - it's a living, breathing entity.

A city full of history, life, hospitality and beauty.. The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia were lovely and impressive with their endurance through history of Roman, Byzantine, Constantine, Ottoman empires, earthquakes and beyond. The Cistern was worth a visit and the Bosphorus cruise was a 'must'. Topkapi Palace is fascinating (where 24 of 36 Sultans lived). The people are very hospitable and tolerant of non-Turkish speakers. The food and restaurants are amazing. A night at Taksim is quite an experience as well. The Spice Market is a wonderful sensory experience as well as a place for gifts and purchases and to watch (and take part) in the bargaining. Marked prices mean nothing. The Grand Bazaar (world's largest indoor bazaar) is similar but with more goods than spices.

Istanbul is an easy city to negotiate since nearly everyone speaks English. They are a friendly, proud of their country people. We stopped to eat Turkish food at restaurants with outdoor seating at tiny alleyways throughout this part of Istanbul. The only complaint we had is that the Turkish people smoke like crazy. We had to get used to eating with smokers nearby. Cruise along the Bosphoros for 3Euro is such a deal!

We have come from iran . so i right english and then persian :The Hotel is located at a romantic place (istighlal .st ) and is easily accessible to places to eat, shopping, sight seeing, ect. Very helpful and friendly staff. Great rooms, we stayed in two different rooms as our baby was climbing the stairs in the first room. Everything was just perfect. We thoroughly enjoyed our stay here and highly recommend it.برای بسیاری از هموطنانم که قصد سفر به استنابول را دارند توصیه میکنم بجای انتخاب هتل از میان گزینه ها یی که تورهای ایرانی معرفی میکنند ، سری هم به این سایت یا بوکینگ دات کام بزنند و گزینه هایی را ببینند که بسیار بسیار متناسب تر از آنهایی خواهد بود که آژانسهای ایرانی معرفی کرده اند . یکی از این گزینه ها بوتیک هتل نورو زیا است که در قلب خیابان استقلال قرار دارد . اتاق های بسیار تمیز ، دکوراسیون بسیار بسیار شیک و مدرن ، کارمندان بسیار مودب و مسئول و پاسخگو ،نظافت اتاقها و هتل در حد بسیار خوب ، صبحانه مناسب . البته تنها اشکالی که میتوان از این هتل گرفت این است که بعد از دو یا سه روز صبحانه قدری تکراری میشود . لازم به ذکر است که این هتل با توجه به قیمتش گزینه بسیار مناسبی میتواند باشد .

Old town charm. Wonderful area to walk around. The cobbled streets with a mix of tourist hotel and residential neighborhoods with tons of stray cats is charming. Enjoyed walking up hill to the mosque areas and back down to the hotel.

Friendly scam warning. This area is brimming with superb places to visit some of which I have reviewed, but this is a scam warning. Beware of the "dropped brush". I fell for this on my first visit: A shoe shine guy will walk past you and drop his bush, and, being a polite sort, you shout him and point out his "accident". He is very grateful and offers a free shine, and will not take no for an answer. Having insisted on you removing your shoes to get a better job done he will then refuse to return them until you have paid a serious sum (in my case the equivalent of £20) IF A SHOE SHINE GUY DROPS HIS BRUSH IN FRONT OF YOU - IGNORE IT!! As a bit of fun I started to count how many times it happened : in 3 weeks, about 35 times!! They have some kind of trigger mechanism on their kit to release the brush which on one occasion I attempted to get an an explanation of - the guy was not to pleased, and by then 3 shoe shiners made it clear that my enquiry was very unwelcome. I doubt this is peculiar to Istanbul, but it is the only place I have seen it.
Historic Istanbul. Istanbul is a city of pleasant surprises and the historic district transported you back in time and place. Not to be missed. Plan several days to take it all in.

Visit Sultanhamet to see ancient and treasured mosques. Sultanhamet - how amazing to see mosques built centuries ago mixed in with the newer buildings. This area is a juxtaposition of everything, modern, old, classic, new. Its truly an area unlike any other.

Historical and interesting. We visited the historical section using a personal guide (which was previously discribed). It is perhaps feasible for some to self review this area by reviewing the interesting sights beforehand and having a verbal discription on your phone while viewing the areas.The area is full of rich history and is a "must see" if you are in Istanbul.

TURKISH DELIGHT. We stayed in the Sultanhammet area and it was the perfect launching pad for seeing the top sights. The hotel is in a pedestrian-only, narrow street which means a short walk with suitcases etc but the street is relatively quiet with some excellent eateries. You can walk to the main sights like the Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, the palaces and the Bosphorus River and its magical ferries. The staff at the hotel are very friendly and more than helpful with directions and suggestions. The accommodation and breakfast package was very good value but it is a good idea to get to breakfast early rather than late.

the heart of Istanbul. I recommend you stay in the Sultanahmet Area if you are visiting Istanbul for the first time. You will find all the major historical attractions within walking distance. There is plenty of shopping and restaurants in the area. You also have plenty of transportation options to visit other parts of the city. Get an Istanbulkart on your first day so you can travel easily around the city at a discount as opposed to buying tokens and tickets each time.
Must do!. Must do whilst in the city. Try to base yourself in sultanahmet, and you should be able to cover all the historic areas within a couple of days on foot.

Easy Access. This particular area of Istanbul has a predominance of great things to do and places to eat. It is available from all neighborhoods via the trams, trains and bus systems. If you will be in town more than a few days getting an Istanbul Card is essential. It works on all public transport and at reduced rates from buying single tickets. Once in the area walking is the primary means of getting around, which is fine as each attractions lies in view of many others. Look for the white Obylisks which are signage for important items you pass. If someone approaches you and their first question is "where are you from?" they are sales people. It is better to really enjoy what you have time to see than to flutter from one place to another and only get a skimming of the importance or depth of information available and possibly leave with a wrong impression.
a must see. the Galata tower is something out of history ,you have to see it to believe it. great way to see the suburbs by walking to it.
We were in the heart of the historical district. We were able to get around on foot, and use the metro line. We were able to see so many sites in the two days we were there.

Lots to choose from. My wife and I enjoyed the amount of places to visit, be it mosques, museums, monuments, squares etc. Lots of history and well mixed with a busy and populated city. Istanbul, like Cairo in Egypt offers a lot to go see for any tourist regardless of his/her tastes or wishes. Recommended

Great City to Visit. This is a very historical city that offers a lot to see from sightseeing to mosques, historical sites etc. It has a wide range of superb restaurants local and foreign cuisines. Worth visiting !

Istanbul Timeless City. You can not imagine how possible that many must see(places) in a city. your days will never be enough to see all in Istanbul even if you spend a month. But, be carefull of being cheated by TAXI drivers.

I Love Istanbul. There are so many beautiful and interesting historic areas of Istanbul it really is amazing. So worth a visit. So much too see...loved Istanbul and spent nearly an hour in the blue mosque alone ,its kept really clean, lots of signs to direct you to each historic building...but watch out for the guys wanting you to visit carpet shops,they get commission even thou they will say they own the shop ...they don't, the carpets are so overpriced if you want a carpet and know quality, price etc not to worry..but I think it kinda of ruins the whole experience and some people could be left conned...wake up Istanbul don,t let these guys ruin a beautiful city.

Istanbul for many more visits!. Al about Istanbul is just completely different form European style of cities...unbelievably open and diverse with all the mosques...the bays and open sea, lovely picturesque streets, etc.

Beautiful old city that has been the seat of two great empires. Where else in the world do you get this much history in one small old town.Very walkable old town that spans both Byzantine (eastern roman) and Ottoman empires. Make sure to visit sites from both periods.

Istanbul. A wonderful, historical city. Everything is in walking distance around Sultanahmet. Visit the underground cistern, the Topkapi palace, aya Sophia, Sultanahmet mosque and the hippodrome. Also the grand bazzar is not to be missed.
Great location and great food. I stayed at the Berce Hotel in old Istanbul from where I could walk to the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia and the bazaars really easily.

The Galata Tower - Imposing Structure Of Istanbul. The Galata Tower stands as one of the oldest structure and most photogenic and imposing tower in Istanbul. It is one of the most recognised structure of Istanbul and depicted in many souvenir forms due to its eternal beauty.The Galata Tower was originally built by wood and served as a lighthouse in 528 by Byzantine Emperor Anastasius Oilosuz to warn approaching ships. It was later rebuilt using stone masonry and Tower was refered to as Christea Turris or Christ Tower by the Genoese in 1348. The straights of Bhosporous is a busy lane for ships plying to trade.The Tower was then captured by the Turks when Istanbul was conquered in 1453 and the city Constantinople was renamed as Istanbul and some historians refered the original name of Istanbul after 'Islambol' or City of Islam.The Tower itself is 66.90 meters high from the ground level and 140 meters from the sea level. It has a measurement in diameter of 8,95 meters and thickness of the wall 3.75 meters. It is a must visit place of interest in Istanbul.It is best to visit in the early morning at 9.30 am when there is less visitors and a clear sky to have a 360 degrees view of Istanbul. There is platform to walk and view the city and marvelous view of the Bosphorus. They have opened up a cafe on top for visitors to have the taste of Turkish cuisine while enjoying the magnificient view of the city and the Bosphorus. There is also a photo studio to take photos well dressed like a Sultan and the Queen which is highly recommended and of course a souvinir shop at the base of the Tower. All round the Tower is full of cafes and dining establishments as well as souvenir shops selling made in Turkey products and popular for hang outs and those taking pictures.Galata Tower is a little down hill if you come from the direction of Taksim Square using the Istiklal where the oldest tram still running in the city from Galata Tower to Taksim Square and vice versa. Well get to Galata Tower when you are in Istanbul and you will never be dissapointed. We simly love it.Saharudin & MariamVisiting 22-26 August 2015Reporting 02 September 2014.
Historic city Istanbul. İstanbul is a city that in every corner there is a living history, history of almost all centuries. Galata Tover is one of them and Toplapı Palace is another one.

Istanbul- stand the test of time. We spent a full day exploring the old City and its most famous monuments; Ayasofiya, Blue Mosque, Topkappi -wandering and bargaining in the Grand Bazaar. A crash course starting from Constantinople and Eastern Roman Empire, through the Byzantine Era and then the Ottoman dynasty with its colourful characters, and finally the revolution and the birth of a 90% Muslim majority, secular republic in the 30s by Kemal Attaturk ; it is a city that has stood and watched time pass by. It is probably the only place where a 6th century gold mosaic of Madonna and the Child is next to the Name of Allah inscribed in gold on a 18th century plate - reflecting a high level of tolerance of faith.

Sultanahmet is one of the greatest places on Earth. Loved the visit to Topkapi & Ayasofia & the exciting piece of art "The Blue Mosque". Our kids loved to auto guide in Topkapi and they became our guides.
So close to all tourist sites. So close to all the tourist areas blue mosque,agai Sofia grand bazaar all within waking distance and many more museums etc around.
Ancient history. You must do on off big red bus. 100lira but it is for 24 hours, so we did red line today and we will do blue line tomorrow.

Soak up the history. We stayed in the historic area of Istanbul in September 2014. Within walking distance we visited the Cistern, Agia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque. Engineering?/architectural? places to see. Istanbul is magical and exciting city. What is worth seing in my opinion beside of most known are:

There are other three areas that corresponds to these hsitoric sites, one of it includes the Chora Museum, wich is very far from the Sulthanemeth district but a must visit for admiring its incredible frescoes! The Suleyman district with its respective Mosque and the Zyreik(?) area....undescribible !

A great experience to see historic Istanbul as well as the day to day life and streets of the local people. We spent 3 days in Istanbul.Here are a few suggestions if it helps anyone planning a visit.Chose your preferences: Are you the traveler who A. likes to tick off all "places of interest"B. likes to be lazy and self indulgent and curious about the local lifeC. likes cuisine and pub toursIf A. - definitely stay in the old part near the main mosque, plan the iterinary well since there are MANY places to see and there are queues and tickets everywhere. Chose early morning or evening times, buy the multi-ticket which allows many places to be covered. Buy audio guides for each museum etc since it definitely adds to the experience and knowledge. Rest during the day - it does get tiring. There are enough places to see - tripadvisor is the best place to know which they areIf B. prioritise 1-2 monuments to see based on reviews and a bit of google so you can be picky and choosy - no point in planning to see ALL worth-seeing places. Make a list of good local foods and desserts (YES this is a big set to chose from) - right from local street foods, to specific cuisines etc. Fit it into the schedule. Walk around and take local trams without any specific agenda and spend atleast 4-5 hours just walking. It gives a wonderful feel of the city. People going to work, children going to school, local shoppers, restaurant owners, street side vendors, etc. I would highly recommend a good 4-5 hours on local boats which go from one town to another on the Bosphorus - getting on and off wherever you fancy - eating street foods and sitting and watching people. Fit in local fruit juices, ice creams and desserts (from proper shops). Laze, read, walk, sit, watch, eat, drink.If C. focus on building up an apetite 3 times a day to truly enjoy the vast cuisine and restaurant options. I did enjoy the local fish sandwiches, the baked stuffed potato in jackets, the grilled fish, the meat roasted in the clay pots.... the kekab dishes seemed bland. There just is so much to eat and experiment - the trick is to be hungry enough!An observation I would like to share:I did not find the local people in hotels and restaurants very customer service and hospitality oriented. My explanation is that Istanbul gets so many tourists that there is a complacency and local people do not try too hard to be hospitable. If the tourism industry gets more competitive maybe they would try harder. Even average hotels get a lot of tourists without trying hard to be very nice to people.Also, the local Turks identify themselves with the Americans or at best the Europeans.. and feel superior as compared to some races. I noticed rude behaviour towards a Chinese group of ladies, a black gentleman, and sometimes towards brown skin people. Its subtle, but its there. That's strange because people thriving on tourism would normally be more practical about being benefits of being hospitable. Only in the small restaurants where is stiff competition to pull in tourists did I find the hospitality levels to match those in Asia.. in other places, it was very dependent on the specific personality of the individual you would be interacting with. All in all - the sheer beauty of the ancient architecture, clubbed with the scenic bosphorus, and the vast amount of foods and drinks to be sampled.. its a holiday to remember!

So much history, all within walking distance to one another. One of the great things about Istanbul is how close all the major tourist attractions are to one another. Within the historic areas of Istanbul you can find remnants of the Roman (Hippodrome), Byzantine (Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern) and Ottoman (Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace) empires. Hagia Sophia, one of the world's most amazing buildings is just 5-6 mins' walk away from the Blue Mosque (a masterpiece of Islamic architecture that gives Hagia Sophia a run for its money) and Topkapi Palace (where the sultans ruled one of the largest empires on Earth for over 400 years) is another 3 mins' walk from Hagia Sophia. You can also enjoy a very nice view of the Bosphorus from the Topkapi Palace grounds. While usually safe, just be careful of carpet scammers and because it is always crowded keep your wits about you. If you go in winter (went in February 2013) the crowds for the biggest tourist draws, in particular Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque are much smaller and you can enjoy taking in the sights a little better.
Istambul- Port. This site is a wonderful one. No One should miss this Crossing between Europe & Asia.. Several Ships & Boats travel through these under the Bridge.

Beautiful city with great people, food and things to see. Istanbul is a beautiful city with history and inspiring stories. I'd like to visit it again and again.
Istanbul in the evening. There is so much to see and do in the old part of Istanbul. I enjoyed the lovers' laterns in the evening.
Good place for history lovers. Good if you like to visit and are interested in historical places. The queues are very long at times during the peak tourist time.

Walking is a great way to see Istanbul~ Feeling Inspired!. I mostly walked to all interesting sites because my hotel was in the Old district and nearby. Although it was 45 degrees Celsius, and very hot (one day it got to 49C!) i didn't let the heat and humidity stop me from doing what i wanted to do and seeing what i came there to see. I highly recommend the Topkapi Palace but was not able to do the Harem Tour, ran out of time and it was separate to the general admission. I was disappointed we could not take photos of the incredible rubies, diamonds and emeralds in the Sultans palace, adorning everything from swords and weaponry to wedding garments and ceremonial gear. Make sure you look out over the harbour through the picturesque arches, wonderfully dramatic light and shadows there. I love the amazing skyline and the way the mosques and architecture cut such an impressive silhouette and will be including it in my upcoming paintings, very inspiring. I really enjoyed the Grand Bazaar and Spice Markets but would suggest you don't go on a weekend or when there are cruise ships in the harbour to avoid the crush of people. I really enjoyed the Aya Sophia and the Blue Mosque but it was too crowded the day i went. i really enjoyed the Pasha Rustem smaller chapel just as much and not crowded at all, beautiful array of blue, green and red tiles! Walking is a great way to see down all the little alleyways and really experience the local people going about their day.

Old quarters are great and reading history plus shopping is fun for me. Go on for a great visit, walking down the streets of Istambul: Start from my hotel Intercontinental I present the visit from the more recent to the oldest ...It's stunning way of reading the city and goes from the less important to the more heartful: 1) place Taksin nothing to see except the crow and think about the recent riots and claim for more freedom 2) descending the shopping street read the architecture instead of only shopping and eating... see the influence of French architecture in the street (buildings, architects, inscription, cultural exchanges) during the Ata Turk time when he started to open his country based on a great partnership with France 3) head to Galata Tower and enter the middle age and Ottoman Empire when Istanbul was taken lead in the region 4) reach out the Golden Horn and start to dive in Roman times and take over by Islam after crossing the bridge 5) climb up to Topkapi, Haya Sophia and Blue Mosque passing by the Grand Bazar ... feel the islam and arabic influences and keep for the end a bit of sad memories remaining of Byzance and Constantinople roman Empire that left few than showing is weaknesses here. The all ensemble is sinking in an ugly urbanization but try to over come this...even I couldnt do much as I m urban planner

Don't miss it. We visited Istanbul about this time last year as part of a cruise on the Regal Princess. We had a day trip booked Which was fine but didn't even scratch the surface. Luckily our agent had persuaded us to fly back to Istanbul from Venice at the end of the cruise and spend more time there as well as Cappadocia. Just as well we had done the Blue Mosque and other places of worship we didn't have to spend more time looking at churches. By that time of our trip, we were all churched out. If you go to the Grand Bazaar, venture right into the middle and you will find some fair dinkum wares. The stuff on the outside that is all aimed is stuff that is mostly made in China. Your guide will tell you that. There is so much stuff underground and you have to realize that it is around a couple of thousand years old. When the city got wiped out and covered by natural disasters, earthquakes etc, the next mob just built on top of what was buried. The underground is amazing with the Cistern being the highlight in my opinion. On the surface is the old Hippodrome, a la Ben Hur. Which you can walk around and imagine all sorts of wonderful things. The hotel we stayed in, the Erisen Crown Hotel is part made up with the Roman Wall that surrounded the whole city. In a small room on the ground floor, there is a hale in the floor, maybe one meter that has a glass panel covering it. At the bottom is a beautiful Roman Mosaic. History is every where. Across the road from the hotel there is a small restaurant. I forget but it is called the black something. The food is great and the beer is spot on. Driving around the city, there is always something to ooh aah at. The people are very good and will never fail to help if they can. Don't think about it, do it.

Can't miss - get the museum pass. Get the museum pass. If you go to Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace with Harem, it's only 10 lira more and you skip all the lines. (worth it). All three are in a row. You will do the most meandering at Topkapi Palace, so might be best to save for last and go at your own pace. Don't skip the Harem - it's beautiful!
Pleasantly surprised. Love Istanbul and it was a great surprise to discover every single corner of the city. Great people and food too
Must See.. Amazing to step back in time of the Ottoman Empire and see way this city was so important in history!

Great . A busy bustling place. Go there on a Sunday and you will see thousands of people enjoying this beautiful area. To see it properly you must take one of the many boat tours on offer. So many stunning buildings situated along the coastline.
Great Place to visit. Istanbul is a fun place to visit. Stay near Sultanahmet to get around city quickly, enjoy the friendly atmosphere.

Great City to explore.. I booked an hotel on line and was delighted with it. [The Senator]. I was within walking distance of the main tram line and within two stops of the Blue Mosque one way, and the Grand Bazaar the other way. So much to see and do and at the time I was travelling [June 2015] I felt completely safe, amongst friendly locals.
5 Days in Istabul. So much to see and do in this amazing city, spanning 2 continents! We enjoyed the historic sites, the traditional shows, and the modern night life in and around Taksim Square.

Hippodrome of Constantinople. Pretty cool area with three neat items, the Serpent Column, Obelisk of Theodosius and the Walled Obelisk. In a historic area where you can walk around and view all three from every angle.
Pleasant place. Fantastic place as the whole historical penninsula, full of things to see. It is interesting for just wandering around.
Great city. Such a beautiful city full of history and different influences in architecture Great people and food
Full of it ..loved them all. I have seen a lot ..loved them all ...and I want to come back one day ..loved all part of history of every thing I have seen ...hope you all do
Iiissstttaaannbbuuulll <3. I reaalllyy like istanbul is very good place where you can visit but not for longue time just for few days and that's all

Splurge on a local guide. So many things to see in such a small space. I recommend finding a walking tour with a local guide. The money is worth every lira. Local guides have the right to get you to the front of the line in many places. Saves a lot of time and makes the experience more enjoyable.

Beautiful and historical Istanbul. We stayed at the White House Hotel in Sultanahmet. Excellent location and great boutique hotel. We were within walking distance to almost all historical sights. Excellent guides who made history come alive and interesting. Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar and just walking around and talking with the very hospitable Turkish people. Fantastic vacation.

A lot of history in a small area.. An amazing amount of history from Greek, Roman, Ottoman through modern Turkey. Especially enjoyed the palace, the views from the hills, The cistern was surprisingly interesting. And Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are popular but must-do's.
Old Istanbul. Soul of İstanbul is here..not arabic not european it's totally Turkish..history, people, modernizm,local tastes..
get a local guide. be carefull of the hype ,if you can get a local guide as there is a hell of a lot more to see that the tourist guides show you ,

Main attractions in 2 days. We booked a full day sight seeing tour when we arrived in Istanbul , which did all the main attractions including cruise, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Grand Bazar also included lunch. Although you do all these by yourself and save money, your better with the tour mainly because of the guide which tells you all about what your seeing. The sights that weren't included ( Bascilica , the Palace ) these were easily done by yourself and although queues were long, they soon go down

A Day in Istanbul using a Tour Bus. We visited Istanbul end May 2015 and was travelling as a part of an eastern Mediterranean cruise. Trips booked on ship or be cruise lines tend to be expensive and we therefore considered this to be an excellent and less expensive alternative.We used the Big Bus Tours buses. The first circuit lasts about 2 hours and the second about 90 minutes. Your ticket covers both.Picked up bus just outside the cruise terminal. This is stop number 2A.Istanbul is always very busy so it is best to travel around early. Traffic and pollution increases by afternoon and everyone we spoke to had found it oppressive.It was a nice ride up to the The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia which lie opposite each other across Sultanahmet square. This is a very nice and lively area with fountains plus food stalls. Most people got off here as the Grand Bazaar market is a short walk uphill. There is a tram which would get you there in 3 stops if you prefer.The Grand Bazaar is a colourful market is always very busy, hot and you are most likely to be called into every shop to “just look” and buy. Stall holders however are very polite and a friendly “no” is acceptable.Crossing the Bosphorus Bridge was nerve racking as it was very windy when we crossed in both directions. Bridge is very high and a few people on the top deck looked quite concerned and worried. This experience was worthwhile as you cross over from Europe into Asia.Our bus was not too busy and no one had any problems getting on at any stop which was good as many stops had beggars, either some children or a mother and child.Would recommend this as a means to quickly see the city and note where next to go if you have time.
The Cistern is top of our list to visit. Visiting Istanbul is a fabulous experience with a huge variety of places to visit and glorious sights to see.
Istanbul. the historic areas in Istanbul are many you need to review before you go. otherwise you need one years to see all

Amazing Istanbul. So much to see, so much to do, so much to experience. This is the heart of Istanbul. Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, Galata Bridge and Tower, Topkapi Palace, the New Mosque, the Spice Bazaar....and the list goes on. There is SO much to do in this absolutely incredible city.
back in time. You really felt like you were back in time. I loved walking the streets and taking in the atmosphere. It's a really centre place to stay too

The Evening Boat Cruise is a MUST. The Blue Mosque and the area around it is a must see as well as all the other mosques. We used the Hop On/Hop Off buses to all the places of interests and also booked an Evening Boat Cruise which was divine as the lights throughout Istanbul is amazing at night. Food is plentiful on each corner so you will never go hungry. Try and buy cooldrink and water from the supermarkets tucked in the side streets near Taksim Square

Pleasantly surprised. We visited Istanbul from a cruise ship and it wasn't a port I was looking forward to. I was pleasantly surprised. From the port turn left onto the main road and just walk in a straight line unit you get the main bridge over the river Bosphorous. Its about a 15-20 minute walk. The people are very friendly and there are some wonderful sights. We had a two hour cruise down the Bosphorous where we got a better understanding of the size of Istanbul and appreciated the beauty of it. All for 12 euros each. You have to visit the spice market and Grand bazaar where you can easily spend another hour - or two if you want to shop. Try the Turkish Delight - it's awesome! And have a proper kebab. Nothing like the rubbish they serve in the UK! There were so many things we didn't have time to do but I'm glad we chose to wander round the city rather than go on a tour.

Charming city. It's a great city. A lot of history everywhere. The Galata Tower is just perfect for comtemplatin a wonderful sunset. Sultanahmet is an unbelievable area, its mosques. Watch out because you may fall in love of this city.

Just go. When you are in Istanbul its not like anywhere else you might visit. At first glance it seems similar to Cairo but spend a few days there and it is a wonderful and different experience. The carpet sellers can be tiresome but once you learn that you can politely tell them you are not going to buy they will sometimes take the hint, and if they dont, just tell them to stop pestering you. Its a small price to pay for this magnificent city.

Experta Tour Guides. We were in Istanbul or 4 days and covered a ton more ground with our wonderful guides from Experta than we would have on our own.Totally stressless travel where all we had to do was show up and they did the rest. Wonderful people and very knowledgeable too!

Here is the History. Turkey is a great mix of the east and west history with buildings and cities built 1000 years ago.Better to stay close to the old city. Also recommended to go to other cities like Bursa.
Amazing Istanbul. Get in early so as to miss the crowds but even though the line may look long it moves reasonable quickly

The Hag Sophia is breathtaking and I went every day. The Blue Mosque was divine as are all that can be see from the Bosu. A wonderful City. Full of fascinating facts and wonderful monuments. My whole experience was, however, marred by attitudes from men, being a lone traveller. They included remarks, sneers and intimidation. Such a shame as I loved the city. I stayed in the old quarter, and the personnel at my hotel The Al Meera, were professional and friendly. I booked the trip with Daily Mail Travel who proved to be via Broadland Travel....each and every facet I booked with them was incomplete or didn't happen at all. I shall retuen but with another company.

must see. must see the ancient historical touristic places located around here.the places are close to eachother,so don't hesitate to visit all of the places here.after my visit to istanbul,I felt very satisfied and relieved.

History. The cobblestone streets, the markets, the history, the people. A visit to Istanbul brings home to you how important this region has been to the development of the civilization we have today. I should be on everyone's bucket list.

A dream come true!. A trip to Turkey must include the historic areas of Istanbul. The Blue Mosque and Galata Tower are just two of the most fabulous buildings that we visited - and I can't wait to visit Istanbul again!

WOW!. The spice bazaar and the grande bazaar are amazing. Feel free to haggle prices. Sit down and have a cup of tea if invited, ask questions about the merchandise. You may learn some interesting facts. Stick close to your companions because if you lose them, you'll be lucky to find them again because these places are so palatial. The mosques are gorgeous. If you're a woman, you might consider bringing your own head scarf or else you will have to borrow one from the mosque's staff. Be careful not to take photos of people unless you have their permission. Have a nice, leisurely stroll across the Galata Bridge. Istanbul is the perfect place for meandering about. Around every corner is a treasure!
Visiting Istanbul. Istanbul has a lot of history, so much too see and absorb.Must go on the river cruise and visit mosques so much to learn.

Might beat Florence as my favorite city now. I loved it. The depth and breadth of history here is comparable to any in the world. Walk through a door and you move from one empire to another. Ride a boat and you're on another continent. It all lingers on in the million different faces of the peoples who still live here.
Beautifull. Istambul is a unique city. Full of attractions. I never feel unsafe, people are kind and friendly.I take a ride by boat by the Bosforo, it´s beatifull.
historic places. Advantage of the beautiful and historic places that tell the stories of the past and find popular markets and restaurants offer Turkish eating I love Istanbul

Go early when it not so crowded and hot. We saw the Blue Mosque , Gaia Sofia and Tokapi Palace all in one morning since they are close to each other. The great sense of history , religions and time was important to understanding the evolution of human thought.
City of Straycats. Huge city with lovely people, full of cats and music everywhere.In each street, you may encounter a lovely cafe with some perfect Turkish traditional food and tea and coffee...
Sightseeing. Really beautiful city with many things to do and see!! Agia Sofia is one of them, the Byzantine church, maybe the most interesting monument to see!!!
Great palsce to visit.. Lots to see in Istanbul a trip on the river is good value,the grand bazzar is a must,great food and plenty of places for a ber with great views.

Amazing sites seeped in History. Great historic sites to see, and nice wide open space to sit and relax and watch people go by.
Don't leave until you have been to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern
Great place must see. That was great to visit, you can discover the whole history of this city. We have spent two hours to see, but you should bring something to eat. It's expensive to buy food here.
Wow factor!. So much to see and far few hours to spend there. Topkapi Palace is a "must do". Sad I misses the underground up early, miss breakfast and don't miss out.

Love love Istanbul. The old quarter of Istanbul is amazing!! A must on everyone's bucket list. The blue mosque, Gaia Sohia, Topkapi palace, cisterns, grand bazaar. The Egyptian spice market and a Bosporus cruise is a must!!
was amazing. it was amazing you can't imagine how fun was it, I hate museumes but there you will experince something different

Istambul, a fairy tale. we were twice in Istambul , this time we visited the Topkapi Palace, Harem and Treasure as well as walking the site.
We also visit the Great Cistern. The next day , the historical Museum and the Spice market.

fight or flight. To begin with, historic areas of Istanbul are of course exciting, highly enjoyable and unique - that is, if you can make yourself to get to them through the most horrible traffic. Obviously, the lack of public transport, extent of jams and discomfort of hot weather at the same time is nothing new but in case of Istanbul, unfortunately seems to have acquired a whole new dimension. Beware, especially if travelling with small children or having any kind of health discomfort! It is probably best to choose accomodation within walking distance of the sights you intend to visit.
Istanbul. There is so much to see in Istanbul you need to plan for at least 5 full days just to catch the more important sights.

Not to be Missed!. The historic Areas of Istanbul is why you visit Istanbul! The Blue Mosque, The Hagia Sophia, Topaki Palace. All wonderful!!! The area is clean and beautiful. The people are friendly and most importantly I felt totally safe.
Been a long time gone, Constantinople. Istanbul is one of the wonders of the world. Historic nooks and crannies, an onslaught of color, an awakening for all the senses - that's Istanbul.

Exotic and historic. This is a hustling and bustling city. In the summer it is very hot and humid so be prepared. The attractions are wonderful and easy to find. It is very hilly and crowded if you are walking on the streets. The metro is easy to use and very clean.

Well preserved history. Stay in Sultanahmet, you will be able to see a lot of places in a little time. This area has many historical sites and good places to eat. Use Metro to commute, save money. Museum Pass is an added advantage.

Magical!. If you sant to describe magical then this place defines it! Ive been here a few times and i just couldnt stop being amazed with this place. The scenery, the buildings, the people, the feel while you walk around here and the smell from food, confectioneries, freshly pressed juice, the colours of the ceramics around here are just a few i can name on the things i find amazing. Istanbul is a lovely city i dont mind coming here again and again

So much to see. One of the most amazing areas. So much to see in such a small area. We actually went on a guided tour on foot. We had a fantastic lunch with a mixed platter. The history of the city is simply amazing. The people welcome tourists and we really enjoyed talking to them. Many of the locals spoke to us fondly about Indian Hindi movies. The baclava was great. The view of the sea front and the Blue Mosque from our hotel room is still etched in my memory.

Amazing city, but watch out. Amazing city. Every minute you will feel the emotion, the history and the culture tension. We travelled by taxi, were conned once (by Hamza, close to the Galata Bridge) and were dropped at the Topkapi Hotel, were we had plans to visit the Topkapi Palace, which was more than stupid. At the Juicy Bar in front of the Topkapi Palace we've got a false 50TL note back. Three incidents in only five days is simply too much.
Turkey as it all!. Exception!!! I will be returning next year for sure!! There is so much to see, it was quite difficult to cram it all in during a three-day weekend.
Great city. Historic part of Istanbul is very busy, there is a lot to see unfortunately their main tourist attractions are somehow poorly presented.

Great for history and sights, felt uncomfortable being 2 women without male company.. The history and sights of Istanbul are outstanding, Hagia Sofia being the highlight, haven't seen the inside of building that wowed me as much since. The bosphorus tour by boat was great, dolmance palace another outstanding tour, food fine in most places the only downside was the feeling of being the only westerners in most parts of the old city, felt very uncomfortable as 2 lone females walking around getting stared at. Glad of the experience though.
14 million and counting. Lots of tourists not counting the 14 million Turks living in Istanbul. Everyone wants to sell you something you don't want or doesn't fit.

Amazing piece of Human History. Istanbul has been a cultural and ethnic center. Therefore, there are many mosques, churches, synagogues and worth visiting historic palaces in the city. Among the main sites are the Hagia Sophia also called Church of the Divine Wisdom and Hagia Sophia (Ayasofya Camii). Today it is a museum and the Blue Mosque Sultanahmet Camii. The area is well kept. Very clean, and very well protected. You can go around without any worries. There are many shops, restaurants and tourist service all around the town. There are internal passages, full of restaurants and bars, but I speak of streets and allies that once inside you get lost and do not know where you're going to leave. The area is full of tourist and young people especially, the atmosphere is great, no "weird" things nothing dangerous, I assure you that is fascinating. Be prepared for long walks and drinking lots of water if visiting during summer. Dont forget sun screen lotion.

History at its best!. Sultanahmet, the area where you will find most of the historical attractions in Istanbul. The key ones that are a must visit are the Topkapi Palace. Rather than visiting this in morning, it is better to reach there around 3 pm, as the major rush is is in the morning. This way you will save on the waiting time. The Blue Mosque can be visited anytime you wish. Hagia Sofia also is a must visit. This is the old church turned to a mosque. This closes at 6.00 pm so select your time accordingly. The fourth key place to visit is the Basilica cistern. This will give you an idea how the water was distributed in the city. All these attractions can be covered in one day and they can all be covered by foot. Two other major attractions are the Dolmabahce Palace, which is situated near Kabatas, and the Galata Tower, which is in Beyoglu district. Keep around 2 hours for the Palace and around 30 minutes for the tower. All of these attractions have an entrance fee.

Something special in this city. Although I hate the drivers and really didn't understand the reason why most of the Turkish people sounds and seems a bit angry, I really enjoyed the city. There something different on the city's atmosphere that mix the old eastern culture with a busy european lifestyle. Anyways, the historic areas such as the surroundings of Haiga Sophia and Blue Mesquite are awesome. The walk through grand Bazar and the old streets of Instanbul is very interesting and inspire you to try the flavors of the famous apple tea, Kebobs and the turkish delights.
Blue Mosque. Amazing sites, all areas are well kept, clean. I was there during Ramadan so tables were set up at the Hippodrome for breaking the fast.
Live museum . Great historic & live museum ever see with several civilization crowded from almost all nationality to enjoy &learn from great people their. I highly recommend .Mahmoud Yamani Jordan
loved them all. easily accessible, be sure to buy the museum card, for visits to attractions a little further get the reasonably priced travel card for the very efficient trams and buses

Beautiful. Istanbul is a busy metropolitan city with so many wonderful sites to visit. Don't miss the Sultan's Palace or the Blue Mosque. Spend ample time walking around and shopping in the Grand Bazaar. You will can have a great time negotiating and buying clothes, handbags, leather jackets and more.
Speechless. Beautiful city ~full of history, wherever you walk, you will find a piece of history standing next to a modern construction! a Must !
Istanbul is a treasure. The Hotel Sultania is fabulous and a short walk from the Palace, Cistern, Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Hague Sofia.
Unforgettable athmospere!. That place make me calm and energy all together! Very beautiful buildings, ancient ambience, a lot of different but peacful people .... i like it a lot!
worth every minute and every penny. I have traveled around the world and many places do not impress me much anymore - yet Istanbul amazed me....
The old water works. The city is full of historical buildings, the spice hazard is a must, the trams are frequent and quiet handy

Excellent!. You will really appreciate this one! It is an absolute must see. If you love history, Istanbul Old Town is a wonderful place to visit. So much to see so plan at least a full day here. A trip of a lifetime! Highly recommend!
A must see place. A beautiful place to spend the afternoon between 2 continents, had a very good time walking around the historic buildings, great bazaars, unbelievably huge.

Best place for history addicts !. I am a student of history and the city of Istanbul was the best way to learn the history of the Ottoman Empire. Every and each building holds a very rich history of emperors which makes Istanbul one of the most fascinating cities in the world.

Beautiful, friendly and vibrant city to discover. Loved Istanbul so much history and so much to see and do. I had 11 days and probably only just scratched the surface. Saw all the usual sights, did a few tours but spent a lot of time using the public transport system which is just great. The Istanbul card can be used across all forms of transport from buses, trains, trams, ferries, tours etc. etc... and cheap. No favorites I loved the whole city. I stayed in Taksim, loved the vibrancy, did not seem as touristy and no hard sell shop keepers like in Sultanamet. Go you'll love it!

If you go there in winter time then definitely have a chay (tea) at local cafeteria.. I was there in winter time and also summer time. I'd recommend you to have a CHAY (tea) there. Its like a symbol of that area. Its like going to Germany and having a hot-dogs with german beer. View and sound plus taste of tea is just great, I felt like I'm having a time travel with enjoying the taste of tea.

2000+ years of history....right under your feet. Amazing experience, great food, shops, and historical places like Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Sulemaniya mosque, Galata tower...just amazing experience.I find shops in old city near Hagia Sophia to be much more reasonably prices as compared to the ones in The Grand Bazaar.
Istambul - city of variety. Great experience, great city, our second trip and we will come back for sure. History, food, variety of all in one city - from Asia to modern and luxury Europe

Istanbul Sightseeing. The Blue Mosque is worth the queuing for and the Church museum (Chora Museum) is just magnificant. My favourite though was the underground water cistern (Basilica Cistern). All in all lots of interesting things to experince. The Grand Bazaar has lots on offer but be prepared to be hassled by the store owners.

Istanbul Beauty. Must see- of course the Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace. The Grand Bazaar is like no other. You can easily get lost. Be sure to bargain. So much to choose from in all categories from clothes, jewelry, to household items and more. If you like Turkish coffee, bring some home. Istanbul is one of my favorite cities.

Visiting the Topcopi palace and blue mosqe. It was full of traffic and at times hard to get to places on time. The weather was too hot and every historical place was very crowded and had to wait in lines under the heat.

Great City. Excellent city with loads of attractions to see. Stay in Sultanahmet to be in the best location. Loads of great restaurants at good prices. Stayed for five nights and felt we could have done with at least a couple more. We enjoy walking and always felt safe even late at night.
Galata Tower has spectacular views. A tour to the top of the Galata Tower is a must - the view is spectacular. It is only 25TRY per adult and well worth it.

Beautiful Mosques. It was HOT at the end of July. I recommend going in the spring or fall because you will walk a lot. Hearing the call to prayer every day is the perfect soundtrack to the beautiful mosques.

Hagia Sophia - The most amazing place. The entire Sultanahmet area is amazing: a live museum. The Mosques, Hagia Sophia, the Topkapi palace museum, the streets full os interesting stores and people...

One of the cities you should have visit. In Istanbul the past and today, the east and the west, Poor and Wealthy, Europe and Asia, Religions and Cultures, they all meet in this town.The old town with many old buildings and museums until the famous market halls, even many hotels and restaurants will give you more than you can expect.

Many historic sites. An amazing collection of historic buildings in a small area allows easy access to many buildings of great significance. Unfortunately many are not as well maintained as you would hope.

I love/prefer the old historic area of Istanbul. Some people like the modern hotels near Taxim. Not me. I like walking outside and cursing an area where there are no big chain stores. The food, the bustle, the stores offer a vibe unlike any other big city.
