never forget. 10 days at istanbul aksaray visited sultanahmet area :blue mosque it was on friday muslims prayer Topkapı PalaceIstanbul Archaeology MuseumsSüleymaniye MosqueSokollu Mehmet Pasha Mosque Rüstem Pasha MosqueHagia Sophiaistanbul aquarium........etcit was agreat few days

Essential Istanbul. Such a clean city, the main historical sites all close together.
Walking distance. Amazing history and buildings.
Hammams a bit expensive and the sales people seem to increase prices when they see tourist.
Otherwise excellent

Wondrous Istanbul. A must to visit.. So much to see in so small an area. Such a contrast of buildings and sights. Such a rich heritage and fascinating history. All wheelchair accessible and good facilities all around such as toilets and cafes
Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Santa sofia. It is a must go visit. You can avoid queues to enter by buying the tickets from the automatic machines located at the entrance of these places and at the same rate.
a charming area. It's a charming area, a mixture between the noise from the tourist crowd and the silence from the mosque. It's something called a unique destination.

The Sultanahmet you can spend days at. You need to be ready to walk around, and perhaps dodge a few pushy tour guides or shop owners soliciting business, but spend some time here to see the historical attractions, and also to enjoy the atmosphere. Grab a coffee at one of the nearby cafe's and just soak it up.
So much to see.. So much to see inn chaotic city. It's good that t it is not too far to travel around and the bus system is good.. So nuch historyo take in.

A mega metropolis - both ancient and modern!. Istanbul has so many wonderful places to explore! It's fascinating place to be and just to wander. Absolutely everyone I met was not only friendly but helpful as well. It's history and historical sites are so interesting - its worth every penny to get a guide.

Istanbul Awes!. Old Istanbul is charming and vibrant! The Spice Market is a treat for the senses:) The Blue Mosque and Sophia Haggai are incredibly interesting and gorgeous to experience. It truly is an awesome city with something for everyone. I was there during Ramadan which made the city even more lovely.

Stay in Old Istanbul and walk to all the major sites!. Nix traffic woes and stay in Old Istanbul near the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi Palace. The Grand Bazaar is only a further 10 minute walk from these popular attractions.

It's a Must. If you're trying to get the feel of Istanbul, it's an absolute must. Yes, it's crowded and busy, but it's iconic. Just don't let the vendors hustle you out of your money. You can always find something comparable down the street for a much better price, and they know that, so they're willing to bargain with you.

Packed full of attractions and hidden gems. My wife and I visited for five days in June as part of a self-devised itinerary of four locations in Turkey and this is a place where we can’t wait to return. five days was just not enough as there is always so much more to do and see than first anticipated plus you don’t want to rush around Istanbul and found ourselves spending more than than usual just sitting, people watching and taking in the ambience of this great city. We stayed at Cheers hostel in the middle of Sultanahmet, the heart of Old Constantinople. Cheers is perfect for students and single travellers, in dorms, or couples, in the annexe a few streets away (see my separate article).Based on our experience, here is a list of things to do and see and some helps and tips based on our experience and wishing we had known before what we know now. Bear in mind that attractions in Sultanahmet are close together but allow time to sit, relax and enjoy the ambience. Some places mean you will need to either walk or use public transport and sometimes wait in queues for major attractions so allow extra time.ISTANBUL IN ONE DAYIf you only have one day, which is a shame, here is what I recommend.Sultanahmet SquareAya SofiaBasilica CisternBlue MosqueWalk around Sultanahmet backstreetsISTANBUL IN TWO DAYSAdd:Eminonu docksGalata TowerNew MosqueSpice Bazaar/Egyptian BazaarSuleymaniye MosqueIstanbul UniversityBeyazit ParkGrand BazaarHere is a full day sightseeing walk that we did using a local map and Lonely Planet book:Take the tram from Sultanahmet to Eminonu and walk up the pretty cobbled street to the tower which you can visit for a small fee and take the lift to the top to look over the Golden Horn and get a panorama over Istanbul. Walk back over Galata Bridge to Eminonu docks, watching the line of fisherman on the side of the bridge. Take in the views over the Golden Horn and the bustling crowds around the docks and the New Mosque. Down here you will also find the Spice Bazaar/Egyptian Bazaar plus the oldest Turkish Delight shop in the world. Walk up the hill behind the Spice Bazaar to the Suleymaniye Mosque where you can get fine views of the Golden Horn towards Galata and Beyoglu. This mosque is also much quieter than Sultanahmet’s Blue mosque. Walk over the road into the grounds of the 15th century Istanbul University, have a look round the campus and onwards through Beyazit Park with its magnificent tower that you can see from everywhere in Istanbul. Head towards the Grand Bazaar passing through the no-knock flea market. get completely lost in the Grand Bazaar for a few hours, try your hand at bargaining and take loads of photos of the colourful displays of spices and Turkish Delight. Don’t forget to take the view from the outside and the grand entrances. Walk to Beyazit tram stop and take the tram back to Sultanahmet.ISTANBUL IN THREE DAYSAdd:Big Bus Blue TourHop on and off around the Golden HornBosporus Cruise (2 hours is enough)Big Bus Red TourISTANBUL IN FOUR OR MORE DAYSAdd:Theodosian city wallsWalk around the backstreets of Sultanahmet to see the Ottoman Houses and Kucuk Aya Sofia (Little Aya Sofia)Princes IslandsFerry across to Asian IstanbulBus or tram to the districts of Beyoglu, Taksim, Galatasaray, Kadikoy.Dolmabahce PalaceHINTS AND TIPSGet an Istanbulkart at one of the various kiosks and put 10 lira on it. The Istanbulkart gets you almost half fare on the tram and can be used on all public transport. Whether you are a single traveller, couple or family, you will only need one card - just pass it back between you and each fare will be deducted. Top it up at any tram stop.Don’t just stay in Sultanahmet Square - wander around the backstreets and further afield. If you get tired, take the tram or bus back.Don’t just eat at night - walk into Sultanahmet Square and people watch. It is usually full of locals and tourists taking pictures of the illuminated buildings and having picnics.Getting around - Sultanahmet Square has the big attractions and is all pedestrianised and walkable. Disabled access in this area is also good but just ask about access for wherever you visit. to go further afield, use the tram, bus, ferry or simply walk. Eating - Istanbul is full of restaurants, cafes, locates and take aways so you won’t go hungry. Sultanahmet has an abundance of nice eateries in the little backstreets opposite the tram stop. Anatolia is particularly nice for an evening meal (see separate review). Best done opposite the tram stop is great for take away kebabs and you can either eat them outside the kebab shop or walk across the road to the park. Prices are on a par with other popular tourist destinations in Turkey (although Cappadocia is much cheaper) and main meals seemed to be between 22 and 35 lira with fish usually cheaper than meat.Drinking - Most restaurants serve beer and alcohol but if you are in Sultanahmet and want a couple of cans to take back to your hotel, there is a little off licence on Yurdu Sokak, again in the mix of backstreets behind the tram stop.Money - There are various ATMs on Divanyolu Caddesi that give the proper official rate of the day. There are also many exchange bureaus that give almost the same official rate for many currencies and if we had known this, we would have taken a wad of sterling. Many shops and restaurants are priced in euros but lira is still the best.Information - Tourist information is thin on the ground so pick up leaflets from your hotel. Better still, brush up your knowledge with the Rough Guide and lonely planet who publish great guides on both Turkey and just Istanbul. also, take note of what myself and others are writing in reviews and visit the Turkish Travel planner website at www.turkeytravelplanner.com. Maps are available at some places but again, get one before you leave home and brush up on your knowledge.To recap, just enjoy Istanbul, absorb it, do what you can in the time you have there… and return another day to do more.
A historical tour of the East side of the World. Every Mosque, bazaars, architecture and shops has a unique old story to tell. Do not miss getting a hammam in the historic Kiliç Ali Pasa Hamami

Peaceful, and a City easy to explore on your own. A city full of historical places, a beautiful mixture of Asia and Europe, and modern and tranditional civilizations. You can explore the whole city on your own, with the help of buses or Metro which is easily accessible.
Great to see the history. Stunning architecture easy walking so many different sights and cultures to view. One can spend many an hour walking round this area
Amazing City. One of the most amazing places I have ever visited! Friendly city and with so much to see and do. Amazingly clean and felt safe even on a night. One for the Bucket List!!
Must visit. Magnificent! Let me put it this way - once you've visited this place, 90% of the world's attractions are no long attractive.

Walk around to discover historical and cultural beauty/gems!. By walking around Istanbul historic areas you manage to capture and come across breathtaking views, roads, areas, buildings, everything! The culture and history about Istanbul is wonderful and a great way to capture it was by walking around and soaking it up. We discovered a lot of hidden gems by walking around the city!
Great place. Istanbul is a city that you will never get board off, The historical areas are so beautiful and you can spend days exploring the city

Hotel Dersaardet a Gem. This is a special boutique hotel, unique and charming. Upon our arrival we were served hot apple tea in a glass - most refreshing. A wonderful breakfast is provided on the top floor, where there is a panoramic view of the sea. And coffee is par excellence.The staff was knowledgeable and extremely helpful to us in planning our days. Our room was attractive and nicely furnished. This hotel is within walking distance of all the important sites, and is located on a quiet street. We would love to return.
Must Visit if in Istanbul. There are many sites to visit in the historic area that are a must if you are in Istanbul,. The Blue Mosque, St Sophia and Topkapi Place.

old quater of istanbul. the historic areas are tourist hubs located around the cities main attractions, you will find everything in these neighbourhoods english-friendly and easy to access, the waterfronts are beautiful to look over.the downside is that it is very, very expensive for hotels, food and activities relative to the other parts of town; and you won't find a single local here who isn't in the tourism industry.be sure to visit the smaller mosques (head-scarves for women and long pants for men, this applies for children also, but you can borrow coverings free from the larger mosques)the spice market is a lot of fun, try the fresh dessert shops that sell an array of baklavas, dried fruit and spiced nutsthe grand bazzar is a vast enclosed market that is well worth a visit, there are a few food stalls inside if you need to take a break, don't be too worried about getting lost because there are entrances on every side you can just walk straight till you find one, the surrounding streets are just as worthy as the bazaar itself for shopping many of the shops sell exactly the same thing and it's very difficult to get a fair price for goods, so get your souvenirs elsewhere, expect to be enticed into a great number of shops by people standing in front. the water in the fountains is not drinkable.plan to stay a day or two for easy access to the cities sights, then move to one of the friendly bohemian neighbourhoods in the citymuch of these areas is still cobblestone, so wear appropriate footwear.

Istanbul, Ephesus, the people super. The city naturally was very busy, cleaner than Athens, Ny, except for area around cruise terminal not well maintained. People were excellent. Stayed at Doubletree, clean, super staff., Very responsive and well trained. The meals were well prepared The bath area was very clean, but under staffed .

Istanbul is an unforgettable place. A must in Istanbul. Blue Mosque, Bizarre. The bridges nearby have the best food and views. The Horne is an awesome site. The castel at the border of the european and asian Istanbul is a beautiful site.

Like all great cities visiting once is like not visiting at all. Wanted to return and view again and again all the historic monuments and make more time for mosques. Must return to hamams and kapalı çarşı, even if I buy nothing. Next time I'll concentrate on Taksim, shopping and night life. Learn more Turkish, the people love it when you can say a few words.
Amazing sightseeing!. Bosphorus river cruise was a highlight! Blue mosque, Hague Sophia, Basilica Cistern and grand bazaar is a must to visit in the Sultanhanet areas.

Impressive Structures. A LOT of stuff to see around the city - most of them impressive structures. However, after visiting fantastic palaces around Europe, these presented themselves just about "OK" in terms of rating.

Put on your walking shoes. By staying in the old town area you are close to all the history that you could ever want. The cobbled streets, ruins of ancient buildings, mosques, palaces and exotic nightlife - around every corner there was something of historical interest.

Istanbul!. It was a great pleasure visiting Istanbul. Endless wonderful places to see. I stayed there for 10 days and would like to back again soon. I visited the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, and the Basilica Cistern in my first day. Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya definitely are worth doing, you could probably skip Basilica Cisterna as it is not all that impressive after you have been there a couple of minutes, but it is a nice escape from the heat.

Istanbul highlights. I have visited Istanbul 3 times and just can not get enough. Hagia Sophia is a wonderful building. Love getting on the local trams and buses and visiting different areas and just mingling with the locals. Fantastic history and always something else to explore and see.
the capital of historical places. Istanbul is the capital of historical places , promise you will find a good variety and enough places to fill your schedule

My favourite city. If there is a city i want to again and again-it would be Istanbul. The city where you meet East and West, where you can see beatiful mosques and churches standing next to each other and streets full of tourist from all over the world creating outstanding atmosphere. Was truly impressed with Topkapi and Haja Sophia. But highlight of my trip was Basilica Cistern.I was amazed to see the water system of Istanbul

History around as far as your eyes can see.... The hotel receptionist have booked with some travel agency a trip for 3 of us, the agency came pick us up and in once day we managed to see Sultanahmet Mousque, Aya Sophia, Little Aya Sophia, Top Kapi museum, Kapali Carsi, Carpet shop, Antique's/Art shop, Pierre Lotti, Dolma basce, Ortakoy Mosque and bridge crossing to Asian side where we watched sun set over the istanbul, all that included big lunch and coffee or tea. Since then I been trying to find this Grande Istanbul tour via net and suggest to my frineds but i was unlucky.
Istanbul in June 2015. Went to Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar and the Hippodrome.An awesome experience !Highly recommended

I've been to many cities...Istanbul is always my favourite!. Definitely walk around old town, all of the markets and the constant crowds. But don't miss going to Taksim square and walking through the streets down to the Galata Tower. The Galata tower climb is also a must, day or night! The Asian side of Istanbul is where the locals go for a good night...its definitely worth the fary trip!

Hop-On Hop-Off bus tour. We booked the bus because my friend had issues with her knees. The two routes were interesting, with the audio being very informing. Covered most of the the major interests for ost tourists and was very accessible. Big plus was the interior was air-conditioned!

Most romantic old city. For me Istanbul has always been the most beautiful, romantic old city around - more so than any other European city. Its mix of old and new, East and West, with all the centuries of history makes for a fascinating experience - everytime.

Museums. Most museums are nice and if you like gitorical artifacts. Get the 5 day museum pass as it is worth even if you use it at 2 of threes museums listed on their package. 85 lira for a 5 day pass. Make sure you buy the metro card, which you can use for public transportation. Better than catching a cab. As it gets costly.

Easy to see by walking and public transport. Do the major sights the palace Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia etc. then soak up the atmosphere walking through the grand bazaar and the coffee courts disguised as carpet showrooms. Take the tram to the seaside and join the locals for a fish roll - those cups of red stuff everywhere are pickles a must for your fish roll. Take an evening cruise up the Bosphorus to get a view from the water. Or just opt for ferry hopping. Wander the lane ways around the Galata tower and Beygalou. Then finish up with a Haman experience. The public transport is terrific- get an Istanbul card it's cheaper if you hop on the transport more than about 6 times. The locals are friendly and for a city it's pretty safe.
not that shiny !. interesting monuments but big lack of organization and facilities over there . long queues to enter all monuments, none of the staff deployed speaks English to help you.

The simplest pleasure in Istanbul. This is my favourite part of the whole world. Walking down the winding streets of Karaköy and seeing the Galata Tower is something not to be missed. There is a vibe, a throb of energy in the old city of Istanbul that I haven't found anywhere else in the world.
Istanbul!. Many sights to see in the old city. Park, museums, mosques, cisterns. Easy to walk. Multiple places to eat. Can be crowded. People were very friendly when we were there.

Lovely Istanbul!. You will enjoy the unique sights and sounds of Istanbul. Dive into history as you walk through the historic sections of Istanbul. People are friendly and helpful. This is a true experience of the senses.

Visit Istanbul/Turkey - Must see and Must do. Just came back from a wonderful week in Istanbul. The city was full of amazing flavors, colors, and an energy that I loved. We decided to stay a week in the city instead of going to other places to get a full taste of what this great place had to offer. I do not regret that. A week was perfect for us.These are a few tips on places to eat, what to see, where to stay, etc.Stay: We stayed at Corinne Hotel over at Beyoglu (this is a neighborhood in the new part of the city in the European side). This hotel was AMAZING!. I have only the best things to say about the cleanness, location, restaurant (OMG the breakfast is to die for), staff, customer service, etc. This was the best choice we could have made at a very reasonable price.To do: Spice Bazar: I liked the bazar. For us it was better to visit this one, before the grand Bazar. You will see a lot of spices, teas, perfumes, etc. It is a treat to the senses. However- we ended up spending more than what we would have paid for things outside. We made the mistake of stopping at the second stand, and although they were very nice, and it was quite an experience, we really ended up paying up almost double as what we would if we would have waited and shopped more. Mosques: Blue Mosque,Rustem Pasha and Suleymanie. This last one was by far the one that I liked the most, although is was not advertised and promoted as much as the others- not sure why. It was not crowded, it has a nice park to just sit and let everything sink in. There are visitor info guides that will explain about the history of the Mosque and Islam. They were very nice and the information was very helpful for our upcoming days. We visited this Mosque first.Grand Bazzar: Great place to go, to understand a bit the history and significance of trade in the city. In terms of buying… I wouldn't buy anything there. These are the same items that are sold everywhere in the city, at much higher prices. So go, spend some time looking, taking pics, talking to locals, maybe drink a chai, and leave empty handed if you can ;)Palaces: Topkapi and Dolmabache. Both gorgeous and very different. For Topkapi, we took a "tour". In hindsight, this was not a great idea. The palace is so big and full of history that I would try to hire an individual guide. Sometimes they are in the front to the palace, or you could check with your hotel, or online. The tour took longer picking up passengers, and only briefly talked about the actual palace (about 1 hr). Perhaps it was our guide, but I would recommend you do this another way. You can also look online for apps that explain something about the palace, that is a great idea.Dolmabache palace includes a guide which was very very helpful. The palace is gorgeous and in my opinion, a MUST in your visit to Istanbul. Plan for 3 hrs or so.Museums: We only went to Hagia Sophia (mosque/cathedral turned museum). This was obviously one of the highlights of the trip. We hired a local private guide on the entrance of the museum for only $25USD approx for 2 people. Amazing guide, answered all of my questions, and then some. Best thing we did to really get the ins and outs of this amazing place.Shopping: A great place and neighborhood for shopping is Galata/Beyoglu. There is a little street in front of the Galata tower. It has everything that you need and want at more affordable prices than the bazaars. It is near the street of Istiklal- the big street and great for getting a flavor of the locals, a lot of shopping, and great restaurants around.Bosphorus trip: We did the hour and a half trip for the Bosphorus. We didn't want to wait for the whole day, and for us, it was just enough to get a feel of the city from the ocean, but not spend the entire day. Prices are very affordable (I believe around 6 USD per person), and great for a privately owned ferry.Relax- We decided to spend some hours relaxing and doing a picnic on the park near to Topkapi palace…. great idea and views of the Bosphorus.I will post about eating places on another post, but hope these tips will help you in your travel! Istanbul is a great city to visit!

Turkish Culture and History. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Sofia Hagia, the Hippodrome are all great places to visit. The cruises of the Bosporous while touristy are a part of it - well worth the price.

Beautiful Istanbul. Come on, you're in Istanbul, how can you not be amazed? But the street hawkers are absolutely relentless. Prepare to have to be rude to get them off your backs. And watch for pickpockets...especially little kids ready to snatch anything easy to grab.
fantastic. Istanbul is a fantastic place to visit for all who are just a little interested in history. The Topkapi palace, Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia is a must see.

Many things to see. It was a great pleasure visiting Istanbul. Endless wonderful places to see. The weather is fantastic. Despite the heat, we didn't feel tired at all. Luckily I have an energetic daughter who was keen in the long walks along sultanahmed and grand Bazar. There are small market like within the main street. I got some silk scarfs ( haggling is a must) some souvenirs and some gorgeous lamps.The blue mosque and Hagia Sophia mosque are wonders mainly at night when they light up and when it is less crowded.

Old City / Citadel and Covered Bazaar are a Must See for World Travelers. Historic Istanbul (Old City) has to be one of the "Top 10" places to see for those who want to see the world. A little something for everyone. The city is lively and cosmopolitan, the people generally calm and friendly. Don't go to the Covered Bazaar without honing your haggling skills. It's more than half the fun.

Day One in Old Town. Spend a day here. For first time visitors, you have to do this. St. Sophia , Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, and Basilica Cistern. These are must sees. You could spend a day at Topkapi Palace so if you have more than a day or so in Istanbul plan on spending a 1/2 day here where the largest diamond in Europe is located amongst many other historical and religious information. Basilica Cistern you can do in 30 minutes without a huge crowd. St. Sophia and the Mosque is up to your own discretion but at least an hour or more for each one.

Trip of A Lifetime. We spent three days in Istanbul upon arrival in Turkey and it did not disappoint. I believe that Istanbul is the city that deserves the title "the city that never sleeps" in that there is always something going on. We hit the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, and the Basilica Cistern the day we arrived (we got in around 10ish in the morning). Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya definitely are worth doing, you could probably skip Basilica Cisterna as it is not all that impressive after you have been there a couple of minutes, but it is a nice escape from the heat. We ate at Khorasani that night, which was great. The next day we went to Topkapi Palace, the Archaeology Museum, and the Grand Bazaar. Topkapi was awesome, the Archaeology Museum was ok and if you are really into history will be especially interesting, and the Grand Bazaar should definitely not be missed. (Do not buy anything there, though, as the prices are insanely high.) We ate dinner at a little café in Sultanahmet that night that I cannot remember the name of sadly, but that was very cheap and tasty, with a cool atmosphere of locals hanging out. We had a glass of wine as a night cap at The Sunrise Café down the street from our hotel (Eresin Crown, which was awesome).The third day we hit Dolmabahce Palace, the most beautiful palace my husband and I have ever seen, then went to Kariye Museum. Skip Kariye unless you just love mosaics as this is extremely out of the way and not as impressive as you might think. We also went to the Heritage Nomadic Arts Center/ Museum right by Aya Sofya for a demonstration of the ancient Turkish art of marbling by Josh and then to see all the beautiful wares in the associated shop. This was a highlight and we are so glad we did it. This is actually where we ended up buying all of our souvenirs from the trip because they were so cheap and so beautiful. We had dinner at the Sunrise Café that night with our new found friends Hakan and Ercan (the owner). Staying in Sultanahmet is a must, as nearly everything you'd want to see and do is well within walking distance and easily accessible.
must see. beautiful and the culture is unbelievably deep and interesting. Everyone must visit this city in their lives.

Suleymaniye has great view and architecture, Topkapi Palace (personal belongings of Prophet Muhammad, Bursa). Do visit all the historical mosque such as Suleymaniye, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Nurulsmaniye, and more as the detail of architecture is amazing as well the endurance of its structure to survive through centuries.
Great city. Saw tokapi palace definitely worth the trip blue mosque also take some time for shopping at the grand bazaar

Full of ancient wonders.. I was amazed by the Harem wall tiles in the Topkapi Palace,
the size of the Haghia Sophia, the sound of the "call to prayer" heard several times a day, eating simits, drinking apple tea. These are the Turkish Delights I will long remember. But I do like the edible Turkish Delights as well.

Historic centre. Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia, and Blue Mosque all within short walking distance of each other. Easy to do at your own pace not worth joining a tour. If you get a museum card you can bypass all the long queues and spend as long as you like exploring
The Historical City. They have a lot of palaces, museum, good food, nice entertainment, beautiful sea view and plenty of attractions.

The history and civilization of Byzance and ottoman civilization. I like Ste Sophie , she's so beautiful and I appreciated so much to visit Topkapi palace and harem, you need at least 3 hours and a half to see ....So good ...
beautiful country. its really a beautiful country and it has plenty of amazing places to visit. Not expensive and excellent weather.

The place to be!. We changed out hotel to stay in this area after doing our research and are so glad we did. Everything is so close together and there is such a great atmosphere.
You can visit the cisterns, Aye Sofyia, Blue Mosque, Archeological museum and much much more.
2x tram stations in the area too so easy to get to

It can be a little hectic.... It is a melting pot worth seing.....Very very interesting. For us that had just two days was very worth it to have a guide....We could not have done it without him....Gave us time to see almost everything....If you do it by yourself is nice but would have taken us very long for lines,, etc.....

7000 years of history all in on place. Loved all little winding alies off the main roads. So much to see. You must beware of the carpet sellers. Just because he lays 30 carpets on the floor does not need to buy one. Even if you want one walk away the first time for sure

You never get enough. From Topkapi with fabulous Panoramam 1453 and the Chora museum, to Eminönü with the piers, Eyüp with the museum and the Pierrre Loti cafe, Aksaray and Yusuf Pasha where you eat genuine turkish food, the area is top attractive.

Can't wait to go back. Istanbul is a magical city. It has so much history that one can come time and time again. The famous bazaar is a must. But there are so many restaurants, cafes, stores.... I discover a new love for their blankets and kitchen towels. The quality of the scarves, amazing ceramics....

Everything so close together. We stayed in the old city and were in walking distance to all the historical sights. The historical area is very well looked after and easy to get around to visit all sights.

lots of MOsques. liked all historic places
i am sad that Dolme Bahche and modern art museum were closed at that time. unfortunately the museum card was not accepted in most museums!!!
Beautiful buildings. The Blue Mosque and Sophia Hagia were impressive. Many buildings with beautiful architecture. The hop on hop off tour gave a great overview of the city.

Excellent hotel. You can walk to ALL historical sites
Have never in any hotel experienced such helpful and friendly staff - especially Murat and Kadir Akain.

A weekend visit. Beautiful historical city with very friendly people; easy commute via tram and buses even in October.
Stayed with friends so unable to recommend a hotel. A fantastic melting pot of culture, food and beautiful people. Food was fantastic, sites were within walking distances

lots of major attractions. All reasonably priced or cheap, queues not too long either.
Remember to wear suitable attire. Give the Grand Bazaar a miss, alot nicer stall and shops near the Blue Mosque, less hastle from the sellers and nicer products too. Some great little bars and restaurants in this area too.
Breathtaking views. Just walking through the old Sultanahmet District and seeing the 2 cultures collide was amazing. You can see relics of the Byzantine empire and Ottoman empire next to each other.
Cool. Plenty of views and history to be seen , true that this is where East meets west and you can feel that divide going from one side to the other..

i went for the first time but its like i was there for ever.. istanbul for me was a great experience.i went there with two of my best girlfriends and we had excellent company .apart from that the city gave us a superb feeling and a nice aura .the food the people and the hospitality.the historic city is fantastic but not only.the new areas of the city and old meets the new in every part of the city.i would go there again and again in the following years..

Great Area to stay in when you are in istanbul. Awalking distance to every historic bulding in the city .... i would say this would be the best place to stay if you are there for few days . and a night in the taksim area . the blue moaq ajoysofia and the cesterns are all in this area .
Greatest city of Europe. The greatest city in Europe i ever visited. Lovely flair and a multicultural experience, i'll never forget.
Magic city, where ever u go you find Mosques only 300++. You'll love this city, come & visit all is here in the OLD city walking distance, you won't be disappointed I can promise
Top 3 of Istanbul near my hotel. Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar-what every traveler must see when they go to Istanbul. Im lucky to be near it
Waste of valuable time . My wife and I are not history fans, so we found the whole tour of sultan ahmet and aya sophia a waste of time, effort and money. We only enjoyed the Topkapi Palace tour

A very nice vacation. We enjoyed very much the trip to Istanbul. We stayed in the old city, very close to Topkapi. You have transportation that can take you everywhere, even on the Asian part with the Marmaray. We liked the mix of diversity, cultures and people. The food is very very good. We ate pide everyday and also drank Ayran. There is a small place in Eminonu that has the best pides ever. Drink the tea and the coffee, at home it doesn't have the same taste. Also, the ice cream is very good. I'd like to visit again Istanbul and I will advice my friends to do the same.
Great History. What a great City with great history attached to it. though the traffic is bad but the historical places like the palace, mosques are treat to eyes
old city. great place to visit allow a few days ,take your tie in the heat we went in july Get around n the tram its easy cheap and fun
Family friendly. Great mix of old and new and east and west. The attractions are well maintained, accessible, and confidently located to each other.

A Touch of Istanbul. Prior to our cruise, we were able to tour the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Grand Bazzar, and a number of local shops, all within walking distance from our hotel,the "Biz Cevahir".

Galata and Cukurcuma for unique souvenirs. The place I liked best was Galata around the Galata Tower and Cukurcuma which offered great opportunities for antique shopping! If you want to like nostalgic places, and want to take find unique design pieces to take back home, I really recommend these districts.

A lovely part of town. We lived in the centre of the old Town and really enjoyed it. Since our visit was at the end of ramadan, the whole Place was buzzing of energy and people having picnics in the parks. The small pathways full of restaurangs are so cozy.

A Middle Eastern Gem!. Istanbul was once the capital of great empire. The whole city is rich with historical places, castles and fortresses. Istanbul is one of my favorite destinations, I visit it early. This City joins the beauty of the east and west, the Islamic and Bizantine architecture, the modern and historic... simply Istanbul is a gem!

It Never Stops. Wandering in Istanbul through the obvious jewels of the city and the less obvious residential and small scale commercial areas is something everyone should do at some point in his or her life for there is much to learn about current day life and the ongoing force of history. No matter the challenges thrown at us by man and nature, Istanbul reminds us that time layers itself upon what has been and as Faulkner observes, the past is not past, it is all around us. Orhan Pamuk talks about the Turkish idea of Uzün, a kind of melancholy that pervades Istanbul especially at certain times. He says this melancholy is particularly poignant in the decaying structures and reminders of an earlier, greater Istanbul. Economic and cultural cycles aside, what is remarkable is that Istanbul never stops, it has a force all its own that will keep it changing and going and it is this force that gives certainly the visitor a sense that we may, despite our destructive angels, make it through!
nice historical walk. good organisation and available info for tourists which is provided by students walking around and ready to advice and help anytime
good. near to galata tower and istiklal street and dolma baqche , and can go any were by bus and metro from here
No crowds. Everything was very well organized-no rows or crowds, payment in cash or credit card, often with lyra, euro or dollar. Perfect for forigners.
The most historic city I have visited. Blue mosque,Ayia Sophia,Tokapi palace were brilliant.Also the museum of Turkish and Islamic art plus the Mosiac museum.Worth buying a 5 day pass .

Exotic city. Great sights lovely kind caring people everywhere we went in my wheel chair people helped us to enable us
to see the sights ,

Beautiful area, great things to see/do. Absolutely wonderful to walk through the ancient sites in Istanbul. It's amazing how many things there are to see in a small area. The Turkish people are warm and friendly.

Awesome! Definitely a highlight of the trip. Having seen ancient ruins in various parts of Italy, we were eager to see what Ephesis was like. It was awesome! We followed Rick Steves's audio tour that we had downloaded prior to our trip onto our phones and an iPod, and that helped us enjoy the ruins even more. There are audio tours available for rent there, too, so if you don't download anything in advance, you can still be guided through this ancient city where St. Paul wrote his first letter to the Corinthians.This is an ongoing archeological dig so in the years to come, more and more will be revealed. We took a quick flight from Istanbul, leaving there about 7 AM and arriving in Izmir about 8 AM. We then took a a train to Selçuk, the hour-long ride taking us through areas that reminded me of Tuscany, only with mosques. In Selçuk, we walked about 200 yards from the train station and hopped on one of the dolmus for the 3-minute ride to Ephesis, dropping us off at the lower entrance. Rick Steves's tour starts at the upper entrance so we hiked up the hill (about 15-minute walk) and began our tour. We spent about four hours at Ephesis and then retraced our steps with the dolmus, the train, and the plane, arriving back in Istanbul about 8 PM. This day-long side trip was totally worth it, and cost about US$200 total for us two. (Flight was US$75 pp rt, train was US$3 pp rt, dolmus was US$2 pp rt, tickets to Ephesis was US$12 each...see how inexpensive it all was?) BTW, we arranged our flight before we left the US as we were told that it would be cheaper to do that. That turned out to be true. The train tickets we bought on the spot, though, not in advance.Be sure to bring your camera, water, a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen as you're out in the open sun for most of the time. A small snack would be great, too, eaten halfway through your time in Ephesus. There's a clean bathroom at the lower entrance which you should use before you begin--it'd be a long walk back if you had to go in the middle of your tour.Final thoughts: Go. Just go to Ephesus. You won't be sorry.
Crammed with History. So much history has taken place here, so the place is loaded with Greek, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman and Turkish republican historical treasures.

How to get to the various Historic areas by train, tram, funicular, boat, including airport. Firstly public transport in Istanbul is the cheapest and safest, it very modern and is supported by a network of helpers fond at barriers, you are saving a lot of money and time using the road network, the train goes directly from the airpot, if you arrive at the airpot you can get to taksim square in 40 minutes for £2 per person (or £1 with Istanbul card) You take the red m1a line and change at Yenikapi (to a different level take green line) then you arrive at taksim, no fuss no traffic, an easy journey , we managed easy with a large case, as did many others I saw on the train, we stopped in this area so we did this, I have included a map of the train system but their are trams and boats, all linked vey easily. We took the public boat from Eminonu to Kadikoy the bus to the large Tuesday market Asia side, the boat journey lasted about 1/2 hour for £1 with Istanbul card the bus (I think we took the 19 at the but Station but people will tell you ) this cost 50p , great trip out too. All of the historic sites can be reached by the public transport, there are helpers in many strategic places with ASK ME t shirts.Lastly by an ISTANBUL CARD. For travel, you can share between as many people as you like they cow 6 tl, then you top it up , this will give you have price travel vey where including the public boats, real good value , by at the shops that look like a betting office if you can find one or people will direct you to small sops that sell them EXCELLENT VALUE , you can use as engrave to some public toilets too for 1 tl .In my opinion the public transport is the safest mode of transport, the roads are manic, lots of accidents just watch you bags always be aware of the people around you as in any city. I did not feel unsafe I this city 2 female travellers, mother & daughter

Tour guide of blue mosque and Ayasofya, Ozan. The guide was excellent, he know his stuff, when he picked us up he already had the tickets to get in Ayasofya and knew which attraction to visit first missing out all the other tour coaches. He gave us time in each location to view it our selves after a talk on the area. This guy is a must if you can get him, a good bit of walking to be done but that's got to be better than being stuck on a coach. Got some great pictures.

The history and its people make this city special. We spent five days in Istanbul exploring the cities amazing history and beautful mosques. What makes Istanbul stand out over other cities are it's people who are really friendly and special. Could not fault anything about the city, people, transport and the food. I hope I get time to visit again.
must see for everyone. Beautiful places, kind people everywhere, it is exciting to see the more than thousand years' architectural remains.

One of the most fascinating city on earth!. Out of the hundreds of city's from some 60 countries I've visit so far Istanbul is one of the few i want to comeback again and again. This was the 4th time i come back to Istambul believing there is nothing new to discover but i was wrong! This is one of the most populated citys on the planet with more than 14 million people and the only city seating on 2 continents. Historical area is an amalgam of Roman, Bisantin & Otoman architecture and infrastructure most of it integretated in the life of the city. To discover what is worth seeing this site gives you all the needed information. This is a city worth more then a weekend, you can easily spend a week.
So much to do. There is so much to see and wonder at.The secret is to be organised and know exactly what you want to see.Even then,there are not enough hours in the day!!!
Turkey: amazing country. One of the most beautiful cities I have ever been.Bosphoro ocean gives the touch to the city. Main attractions are blocks away from each other.

Istanbul is one of the most amazing cities in the world!!!. My wife and I spent three weeks of our honeymoon in Istanbul earlier this summer. Overall, this is among the most amazing cities we have ever visited int he world. That being said, watch out for schemers. We fell victim to a classic shoe-shiner scheme in which the shoe shiner will walk in front of you and drop a brush. You, the naive tourist, pick it up and run after the guy to return it to him. Him, so grateful for your caring nature, drops down on one knee and offers to shine your shoe, seemingly for free. After shining your shoes, however, you learn that it was not for free and that he wants 35 TL per shoe!! (Another classic scheme in which you ask for a price quote on a shine and they tell you 35 TL and then after the shine they claim the 35 TL price wad for each shoe.) In reality, I got my boots shined for 2 TL for both shoes later on in the trip.
Beautiful Istambul. This is one of the most beautiful, exciting cities in the wold.How anyone could not be impressed by what is on offer would be a mystery.

rich cultural history, quite superb!. imp to learn about one of the most important empire of the past and how turkey came into being. beautiful mosques and archtecture and very tourist friendly counrty!

This is a great place to walk and soak in the culture of Old Istanbul. The only way to enjoy this beautiful historic area of Istanbul is strolling and walking. You'll be approached by any number of hucksters wanting to sell you boat rides on the Bosphorus, carpeting at their uncle's rug emporium, and so on but that is part of the charm of the area. Don't miss out on the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market, and all the other interesting attractions in this area. The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are absolute musts. No visit to Istanbul is complete without visiting these two iconic attractions.

Certain few people ruin it for everyone else. This is a beautiful and historically relevant area at the crossroads of the world. Sadly however, sleazy touts, cab drivers, restaurant hosts and homeless people leave foreigners with a very bad taste in their mouth. Many Turks that I know both in and outside of Turkey are warm and hospitable, but for one reason or another, the touristy environment in the center of Istanbul draws some of the worst individuals the world over to prey on foreigners. I was there for three days, and by the end I just did not know which mode of transport to take anymore because they are all terrible. The metro/tram lines, while clean & efficient, are littered with gangs who act despicable towards woman and foreigners, and child beggars whose parents are within eyesight ready to take any money earned. After a couple annoying experiences with these types on public transit, we opted for a cab to Taksim Square. Bad idea. The driver informed us that there were riots and army activity in Taksim square and thus he could not take us. He proceeded to basically do circles around the city. We pleaded for him to stop and to just let us out but he declined because he claimed it was not safe for us (it was Istiklal street, one of the busiest and safest streets to be on). Finally after much pleading he dropped us off nowhere near the square. So me, anxious to see the riot, made my way towards Taksim square only to arrive at an empty square with zero signs of a protest or riot ever having taken place. It was only then that I realized the extent of the taxi drivers scam. I understand taxis are scammers all over the world, but this guy literally would not stop the cab to let us out essentially claiming that we'd be shot. This left us with only one other transport option, ferries, since car renting is out of the question. We were told Beyoglu wouldnt be as bad as Sulthamhet, that wasn't the case as Beyoglu was less crowded and thus offered a better opportunity for thieves. Istanbul really takes scamming to a new level
A beautiful & Interesting City. A beautiful & Interesting City.Shopping is wonderful, the people very friendly. A really enjoyable stay.
Beautiful Istanbul. Go to Istanbul - the historic areas are soooo wonderful, actually it makes you really feel like being back in time

History at every corner. This is a city that has history and culture hitting you from the very start there is so much to do and 5 days here would be the minimum stay. This city is targeted towards the tourist and sight seeing. The one really helpful point is that you will see students through-out the city wearing blue polo shirts with various languages on the back. Pick a language you know and ask any question. These are language students who want to improve their language skills and act as static guides to the city paid buy the local council during holiday periods.
fabulous and friendly. Liked Everything. Enjoyed all the sights and friendly people,All the historical sights were amazing. Learnt so much.

This is the best place to find accomodation in istanbul and to be able to walk around all monumnets that are in this area. awesome. a big dive in history , a lot to discover , a lot to remember , a lot to contemplate et to be amazed
Many attractions. The sites in Istanbulvare all good to visit but what is not well known is that it is the start of the roman road to Rome.
History happened here. This is where history happened. Read (or listen) to a few books about the Byzantine Empire before you come. On top of that, the Turkish people are very kind.
Old city Istambul. Long walks at Sultanahmet district, visits to the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Suleymaniye Mosque, Carpet Museum

East meets West!. You would never think that a short walk on a bridge crossing the Bosphorus could change your perception so much. The walk into the East is worth it as you are thrust into a totally different environment especially when visiting the market there. You are expected to haggle and some vendors get quite upset if you don't - be prepared for the cups of cha and a lengthy bargaining session for the more exprensive goods. Whislt there you HAVE to visit the Topkapi museum and the Blue Mosque. Like all busy cities take your own precautions for securing your purse/wallet etc but also bear in mind the friendlines of the people.
Classic, beautiful and elegant Istanbul !. he best part of Istanbul, would not go to this city, without visiting the beautiful old town area! Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque - by far the best !

Heart of History!. This city is over thousands year old. Built on 7 hills. Every corner you will find something from the history. Many cultures have past through İstanbul, so there is a piece of different cultures, religions, and more. Definitely worth sightseing.
Wonderful Turkey. Spent the day walking around Sultanahmet area as well as doing bospherus boat trip. Was excellent time
AMAZING ISTAMBUL. Wonderful sites to visit and all relatively close together. Easy to get directions. Good choice of public transport.Queues to some attractions can be off-putting !
Simply marvelous. Simply marvelous. Astonishing architecture, amazing history, a city alive with chatter, laughter, the smell of good food and exotic bazaars.

Better with each visit.. We have wandered around this compact ancient neighborhood of Istanbul's Old City several times since our first visit over 5 years ago, and with each visit I am struck by the majestic history around every corner, The number of ancient sites, both religious and secular, is amazing and most are open to visitors. Many do not require guided tours and so you can take in those sies at your own speed. Overall, this is one of the most historic compact areas in the entire world.
Amazing. This is a must in this beautiful city of Istanbul, Everything about Istanbul is fascinating and attractive, and the historic areas are of particular interest, and are quite enjoyable.

Relecting Back on Istanbul. It's now almost two years since we visited Istanbul, never before having seen such a city ! Every day I think about this city. Very few of those things seen in the United States exist there and yet a majority of things are familiar. No KFC on every third corner. This is refreshing.Stores ? Oh yes, they have stores. The Grand Bazaar alone, is a neighborhood of stores comprising in its totality, one of the greatest stores on earth.The history of the Ottoman Empire is fascinating to say the least. This city has had at least four names including Constantinople. Another...Byzantium.Constantine has a history here. So does Alexander the Great. A bridge carries you from Asia to Europe in two minutes. It is without a doubt one of the greatest cities in the history of the world. Three thousandMosques.In one city! Incredible.The waterfront, wih some of the heaviest marine traffic anywhere will reside in my memories forever. The colors and contrast of sunset fading into dusk as lights start to come on, are intense. In talking with friends who had been there said they felt the same way. Go see !

Big surprise. Enjoy walking around the central historic area of Istambul! See the colours, hear the noises and muezzins, smell the rosted peanuts and fruits! Don't miss the dance of the dervis, a glass of turkish tea and a waterpipe!

Never gets old. Sometimes I wonder if I'll ever see everything there is to see in Istanbul. Besides the old favorites, like the Blue Mosque and the New Mosque, plus the spice market and any bazaar isn't the Grand Bazaar, there are new favorites each time I visit Istanbul...
Incredible. Istanbul is an amazing city with a blend of beginning-of-time events and buildings with the very contemporary and modern.

This is the area known as Constantinople....which the Ottoman Turks conquered in 1453.. This is the most beautiful area in Istanbul in my opinion. I like to hang out here and just watch the people for hours (I'm an American living in Istanbul). You will see different people from all over the world, different languages, colors, clothing. It is like being at the United Nations...I love it. It has an electric type atmosphere. There are many restaurants, corn on the cob vendors, fresh squeezed juice shops, ice cream, etc. The area includes the Hagia Sophia, The Ayasofya Hurrem Sultan Bath 1556, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, The Hippodrome, and Topkapi Palace. If you only had one day to spend in Istanbul, this is definitely the place. It is especially good to visit during Ramazan.

Went on She Tours who have fantastic tour guides.. The 2 tours we went on were wonderful because the tour guides were so informative. The blue mosque tour was led by Yakup who holding his distinctive black umbrella aloft proceeded to give us a history lesson.

a must see!. There are 4 islands near Istanbul and Buyukada is the biggest. it was really beautiful and i think who ever goes to Istanbul must visit this paradise. There are no cars in the island and there are only carriages and bicycles. there are so many beautiful and cute bistros and cafes and restaurants. the nature is amazing. there are so many beautiful and dreamy houses there. you will fall in love with this island in an instant. i will visit it when ever i go back to Istanbul again. you can easily go there. you can take the metro and go to kabatas or karakoy and from there you can take the ship.

Yeldegirmeni street art: graffiti and murals. i am beyond surprised when I visited Yeldegirmeni a neighborhood in Kadikoy. I used to go to a public library when I was kid to get books , today I have visited the area for a graffiti hunt !!
What a change and I loved the new comers : hipster cafes, art shops, along with locals.
This is what Istanbul is all about!!. Lovely places to see, suleymaniye mosque,basilica cistern, dolmabahche palace...Lovely places and must visit

A must-see attraction in Istanbul. One of the most interesting places to visit whilst in Istanbul is the Grand Bazaar. Located in the middle of the city it is the largest indoor market in the whole of Turkey. The Grand Bazaar is reputed to have over four thousand shops, restaurants, market stalls, clothes shops etc. etc. I do not know it someone has actually counted these, but you get the idea of the sheer size of this attraction. Please see the attached two photographs of this historic attraction.

Hystorical zone of Hypodrom with all its masterpieces. A very easy acces from hotel to this zone,also a very good informations and acces to others...including The Bosphorus trip or a lot of others long or short opportunities,....
Excellent sightseeing. The Big bus tour is the best way to see the city. The Red route is superb, the Blue less so. Good value for money, and sure saves a lot of walking!
excellent. Istanbul is a beautiful, historic city that can be interesting for all tastesUrban cafes always awake and attractive landscape
Center of the Historic Istanbul. The majority of the historic sites in the old town are within walking distance of the main square. You will spend all day (if not two) in this area

I Love Istanbul!. I was expecting to enjoy Istanbul. It actually met my expectations and more. Everywhere I went I found some thing to delight my senses. Whilst the main part around the Palace, St Sophia & the Blue Mosque was superb, visitors should explore further a field. The local transport allows this.A particular delight was walking along the walls that fell in 1453 and visiting a museum locals had told me about, which pertained to the Wall and 1453.

So much to see. We spent a week in Istanbul, and I could easily have stayed quite a bit longer. There is so much to see; I don't think I got to half of the places I wanted to. I loved just walking around, too.

Amazing.. The Tokapi Palace, the blue mosque and the Hagia Sofia as well as the basillica sisterns are all located around a big square with fountains, restaurants, buses, tourists and scam artists...go on your own, spend as long as you like, don't get into conversations with the usual 'official guides' [they're not] they just want your money and they will say they will tell you lots of information which you won't otherwise get...you will, just buy the listening guide when you go in, simple. Don't get a 'special price' for a boat tour..go to the river which is about a 10 - 15 min walk from the square and get a ferry ticket for a circular tour for less than £3 each and it usually takes about one and a half hours and you will see everything. From your start point at the river you can easily visit the spice market and the grand bazaar. Comfy shoes and plenty of time required to fully enjoy Istanbul.

Visiting Istanbul old town without a tour guide. We took the metro to go to Sultahanet and explored the Old Town by ourselves. Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi palace are located within walking distance of one to another . Therefore, it is very easy to visit all three on the same day. There are lots of volunteers wearing blue Tshirts who are eager to give tourists directions. We also visited the Basilica cistern which is located near Hagia Sophia. The Medusa head sculpture inside the Basilica is very popular with tourists and is the most photographed sculpture inside the cistern. We had a great time exploring Istanbul Old Town and enjoyed all sights of Sultahanet.
Atmosphere . I really like the atmosphere here, visit here when you have plenty time I don't think you would be able to observe the life around you if you're in a hurry

Must see one of the GREAT cities of the world!. Istanbul really is a unique city simply because of its geography, and thus its history and culture. Being the biggest city in a Moslem country that is still secular in its politics makes it both safe for Westerners and exciting to visit. The historical places to see are very well taken care of and not as crowded as other places in the world I've been to, so GO! It is helpful to have a guide, as in any city, to save time and to bring you to see places at the best times and to bring you to the best places to eat!

See as much of the old city as you can~. Istanbul is one of the great cities of the world. The heritage, the beauty. Spend time walking and seeing the sites of the old city. Take your time and see all you can while there.

Istanbul with and without tour guide. A tour guide oriented us to the city, the main "don't miss" sites. We had five days on our own so we revisited the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market on our own. Also to a ferry to the Princes' Island area.

Incredibly preserved Museums/Palaces. The City has not been conquered since it was taken by the Ottomans in the 1400s. Therefore, many attractions are in excellent shape and access to the Mosques was easy. I would recommend a local guide.

Sophia Mosque and old city. A visit to Istanbul without viewing the old sites is an incredible loss. The whole country transports you back in history and helps bring to life anything you have read or seen in the movies. Safe to walk around alone - friendly people. Incredible experience

Istanbul Automatic Teller Machine (ATM) around Historic Area of Istanbul. I tried to withdraw some Turkish Lira by using one of the ATM outside the YAPI KREDI BANK, Divon Yolu Caddes (Street), Sultanahmet on 14 Jun 2015. I inserted my bank card into the teller machine but it some how got stuck half way in the slot. I withdrew it and tried to reinsert my bank card into the slot again. Suddendly one young man stand behind me and help me by holding on one side of the bank card and together with me holding on one side of the card and pushed the bank card into the slot again. I noticed the card have fully inserted and I then key in my pin number following the prompt on the screen. After I have key in the pin number, nothing seem to happen on the screen. I did not even key in the amount I wish to draw. I waited for about one minutes, nothing happened. I pressed the "cancell" button on the key pad in an attempt to retrieve the bank card. I waited for a while, but nothing happened. I waited beside the ATM machine for the bank card to come out from the slot. While waiting I received SMS from my mobile phone that someone have made withdrawal of 2,000.00 LIRA from my account. one minutes later, another withdrawal was made on my bank account for another 1400.00 LIRA. In total 4000.00 LIRA was withdrawn from my bank account within 4 minutes before I managed to call desparetely to my bank to terminate my bank account.Lesson learnt. 1. Try to carry enough cash in US $ or Euros and change to LIRA if you need some small notes in LIRA to use in Turkey. 2. Please do not use the ATM in Istanbul. I believed many of the machines in Istanbul have been tampered with. Scanner or pinhole camera installed to steal card information. 3. If you need to draw cash. Do it inside their Airport ATM. Safer because of the high human traffic and the ATM less likely to be tampered with. 4. Make sure no one stand beside you or behind you all the time while you are making the cash withdrawal. Cover the key pad with you palm while keying in your pin number. Walk away if suddenly there is someone standing behind you. 5. Never, Never let any one touch your bank card.I am in the state of shock and disbelieve. How the hell there are the criminals) are able to pull this off within minutes? Anyone have similar experience? Anyone can provide any logical explanation? All are welcome. Thanks. NT. I tried twice to make a Police Report at Istanbul. The Police just ignore you and said I told lie! They are very good at adding insults to your injuries!

aboslutely an experience to cherish. all the attractions in istanbul are very closeby. the mosques,grand bazaar, spice bazaar, cruise stations. it keeps you very busy through out the day with its variety. the culture of europe and asia meets in this place. not to miss it.

A trip to the past. We returned to Istanbul after a 40 year absence and what a change. The basar is still as commercial and expensive as it was - but just outside you can "haggle"for bargains. Save to walk the streets until dark - even for women on their own. Apart from some arrogant machos we had a great time. Wonderful historic buildings well kept + good food.
Istanbul. I'm a citizen of Istanbul. There are do many historical areas. It is not wrong if say all of Istanbul is historical place.

Full of sightseeing. I't true that (maybe) you can't see everything in one trip. Lots of sightseeing in every side of the city. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Galata Tower (a little bit expensive), Grand Bazaar, Top Kapi Palace (you need about 6 hours to see it all, and you can have a picnic inside! Big gardens everywhere) and more! IMPORTANT: look for the museum pass card to avoid the huge queues and to get a big discount for the tickets.

I can't believe I almost didn't go visit Istanbul as I was worried for my safety.. Wife and kids were a bit worried visiting Istanbul as it is close to Syria and we are from Canada and didn't know better. Istanbul turned out to be our favorite city of our entire trip and we want to go back for at least 2 weeks next year. The history of the city and the friendliness of the people is incredible. Not once did we not feel safe as and we visited the Spice Market, the grand Bazaar and the historic sites such has Sofia Hagia and the Basilica Cisterns. Our favourite moment was cruising up the Bosphorous and admiring the beauty and history of the city... A must do for any traveller. I would recommend Istanbul to anyone.

Well Maintained, Safe, Gorgeous. The Historic Areas of Istanbul are safe to visit, gorgeous to see and very well maintained. The whole city is very clean, but I was especially surprised at how amazing the landmarks were. Organized too.
A real treat. Although I had limited time to visit everything, One cannot go to Istanbul and not visit the Historic art of the old city. So much culture and history.

Not the bargain you are lead to believe. you must be a hard bargaining champion if you can score a real bargain in the Grand Bazaar. The traders are multilingual, quick to score and as I read before my first visit, and last, pay their rent in gold. Just remember they do this all day every day. Most is cheap tack ,you have been warned.

Enjoyed every second of this trip. We didn't book for any tours that charge for trips. We explored this city like any local by buying Istanbulkart which allows you to use the Metro,Tram and Cable car. Don't miss out on the trip to Terefrike by Cable car. Most of the Turkish people will help and give you information about where or what you're looking for, plus, the reliable and well-organized tranportation system makes it convenient to use even for tourists.
The historic area. The historic area was just a short walk from the hotel and was very special each time at a different time.

Step back in time. Great place to see and experience another culture and an ancient way of life! Only city I know that is partly in Europe and partly in Asia! I was wary of the safety aspects prior to my visit but gas no qualms while there. Just remember to respect their prayer times and give them the space they require, wherever and whenever they seek it, especessially at Ramadan in late June/ early July. Wander around and explore.
new place. It nice, full of people. not expensive at all. and you can go using the Tram, and no need to pay too much for a trip from the hotel
Many civilizations in one place. Wonderful and clean city. Be careful with traffic. Visit the city with a local guide. Is very interisting to understand local history.

Absolutely awesome!!. We loved the clean streets, the gardens with the flowers, all the trees, the families strolling around, the safety of the city and most of all the ancient relics, buildings, mosques---- so exciting, mystical, inspiring---one of the most beautiful cities I have ever explored. The people were friendly, helpful, humble. We loved every moment and plan to return again and again if we can!!
Be there early. The sight areas in Istanbul are magnificant. But be there early to avoid the crowds and long queues. Remember your camera.

Lots to See and Easy to See It. Istanbul is a far East as my wife and I had ever been and but even after we had decided to go, based on the concentration of sites to see, we were a bit apprehensive about getting around and handling transactions in a city of 17 million where Islam was the state religion. However, none of these concerns posed any problem: Istanbul has a world class, fully integrated, easy to navigate transportation system. Everyone spoke English. Hospitality everywhere was striking. The city was very clean, seemed very safe everywhere we went. And, to be sure the call to prayer, starting loud and clear every day took some getting used to but Islam and Christianity seemed to coexist remarkably well.
Awesome. The Historic sites are magnificent. There are so many museums and mosques to see. I loved the mosques and the museums which they were mostly located in European site.

Still exotic but clean and friendly. We stayed in a boutique hotel within a short walk to the BlueMosque, Hagia Sophia, and the Cisterns. As two women, we felt very safe but did use a car service to go to restaurants after dark. There are numerous outdoor restaurants. Don't be put off by the persistent hosts who stand outside calling you, encouraging you to come in their establishment. Almost everyone speaks some English and always offered assistance for directions, etc. We were never disappointed by the food in any restaurant but service is slow by U.S. Standards. They want you to enjoy a leisurely meal. There were a lot of tourists and of course lots of touristy shops. The Spice Bazar was amazing to look at but prices are cheaper in small shops on the side streets. The Blue Mosque was beautiful but remember to bring a head scarf and avoid sleeveless shirts, shorts or short skirts. If you are, they will provide you with a a drape but I heard people complain they were dirty. Beware of anyone offering to be a tour guide and take you through the line ahead of everyone. They will charge a lot after a very brief, worthless tour. Hagu Sophia is gorgeous but our favorite historic site was the Topaki palace. Go in the morning to avoid long lines. One can enjoy all of the sites without going on a tour. We navigated around this area without any difficulty.

Amazing sites but very crowded. It was a great place to see historical sites. Hagia Sophia was amazing. Lines can be very long to get in so we hired a private guide which was perfect. The Cisterns were OK, the Blue Mosque was really nice.
A must!. scads of history and wonderful architecture in this glorious city. So much to see so little time!Do whatever you can by boat it is fabulous

Life is everywhere. This area smells like a heaven.... You can feel life, love and energy in the air.... The area is amazingly attractive, to the extend when you walk, your head turns right, left and up automatically. You can't stop watching the perfect structure of the ares

Where past meets the present. Visiting and exploring the historic areas of the city are amongst the best things one can do in life. From the monuments to the hamams and from excellent restaurants to bazaars, there are so many things to do that it could days to completely experience this.
fabulous Istanbul. We have been so surprised by Istanbul. It is a large City and the traffic is challenging from a spectator point of view but the history of this City is amazing.

Best of the best. The hotel was small but big in every way. The staff was superb--up and down the line, from the TV tech to the concierges and the cleaning staff. I know their names. They treated me like I was a venerated member of the family. I will return!

Definitely not handicap friendly, but amazing if you can manage.. I loved my trip to Istanbul. It is the top city to see for good reason. It is definitely not handicap friendly. It is hilly, lacks real sidewalks, has zero bike lanes or extra space. I didn't see an elevator anywhere.

Exotic amazing Istanbul. I just love Istanbul with its wonderful mixture of exotic Arabic and European cultures, it's amazing history, bustling markets and fabulous restaurants. It really is a place where west meets east. My two sisters and I spent only three days in Istanbul but it really wasn't enough. We visited the usual places - Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar and the Spice Markets - all very worthwhile. We travellled across the Bosphorus and walked around a little on the Eastern side. We then travelled back to Taxim Square and meandered down the main shopping street full of well known clothing brands and more sophisticated clothing shops. Our very convenient Hotel Fehmibey was not far from the main attractions and we found some delightful shops and many excellent and reasonable restaurants within walking distance. All in all we thoroughly enjoyed our time in Istanbul but would love to have had more time to explore 'greater Istanbul' with its population of 14+million.

Istanbul needs to be on your bucket list. For history buffs, from the Byzantine to the Ottomans to the Turks and all the cultures in between, Istanbul is an amazing city. I traveled solo and felt safe, welcomed and just in awe....
Chora church. All the major sites are great but this is a real gem just out of the main loop. Outside is currently covered in scaffolding but inside he mosaics are amazing.
Explore this enormous and ancient city. Just explore, get lost and try things-- you can't go wrong! Instanbul is a giant and ancient city with much to offer.

Five hour guided tour of some great historical and religious sites of Istanbul. We would like to commend Neon Tours in general, and especially our wonderful guide, Gulay Gunay. She was fabulous. Not only was Gulay (pronounced "July") well informed and friendly, but she also helped us on the spur of the moment to gain quick access to the amazing Underground Roman Cistern. This was not supposed to be part of our tour package. but Gulay arranged for us to gain express entrance, and then catch a Neon Tours van back to our ship.http://www.tripadvisor.com/ShowUserReviews-g293974-d1946675-r283631880-Neon_Tours_Day_Tours-Istanbul.html#

A city like no other.. The intertwining of major cultures makes Istanbul Unique !The museums, markets, vistas of the Bosphorus all come together to form a cultural mosaic that makes this city a true wonder.

Beautiful city, sites, friendly people. Brush up on its history before going so you don't miss a thing.. Of all cities visited, this is one of the most beautiful, historic and unique. Worth the effort to visit, the mosques, history, and sites make for a memorable experience. Hire a local guide for a one-half or full-day tour and learn as much as you can about the city's mosques, buildings, sites. Ladies, be sure to pack a scarf or some type of head covering for when you visit holy buildings, although you will be provided one if you don't have your own. Absolutely make time for Topkapi Palace (closed Tuesday), Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia (closed on Monday), Hippodrome Square, Spice and Grand Bazaars, and visit a rug shop to see how they're woven, an intricate art.

mixed of asian and european. a very unique city. mixed between european and asian cultural. Also between catholic and islam. For my friends from the moslem community, this city is a must to visit....you have to see this city

A new experience , something different from what I had visited before. a well-planned trip , so that in three days we visited the objective importance ..Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque , Hagia Sofia , Arkeoloji Museum, Grand Bazaar, Hagia Sophia Little , Sultan Beyazit II Mosque , Kumkapi , Dolmabahce Palace, Spice Market, Atik Ali Mosque, Bosphorus ..croaziera city tour bus ..cost all flights , accommodation, tourist fare , souvenirs two people 800 euros

Beautiful Istanbul. Visit the Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar as well as the wonderful local restaurants around the Sultan Ahmet area, Istiklal Caddesi Street, Taksim (New City) for shopping, Bosphorus dinner cruise and Princess Islands for fresh fish.

Walking in history. Instanbul lives history and it has atmosphere and the local people are very friendly. Plenty of food choice and wonderful shopping everywhere beside the Grand Bazaar. It is also a city of endless options from seeing sites to boat trips to shopping.

Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya. The Blue Mosque is a must see! It is very close to the Aya Sofya, a 6th century Mosque. It is easy to walk around the area and really a short walk down to the Bosphorus area (sea). Walking down the main streets allows you to shop a little and surely to enjoy the local cuisines! We did and loved it.

Topkai palace. Topkai palace was amazing to walk round ,you can just imagine how life had been ,it took us at least three hours & we missed one part as the queue was just to long ,my husband had the headphones ,although very easy to follow as every thing is well signed . The blue mosque is a must but no matter what day you go you are going to queue , we ended up going around four in the afternoon & we walked right in ,all the cruise ships passengers are bussed there in the morning ,there was four cruise ships in port any given day ,so you can imagine the amount of people ,if you not on a cruise go later in the afternoon .we stayed in the old part of Istanbul four days before joining a cruise ,everything was within walking distance ,we did not need to taxi anywhere , you can walk about at night feeling perfectly safe ,one thing that is annoying you can't walk past a restaurant without being pestered to go in ,they won't take a no ,you just have to be firm with them .

Amazing Istanbul. All the historic areas are well looked after, well presented and good value for money. Hagia Sophia is my favourite. To think it was constructed approximately 1500 years old almost defies belief.
Topkapi Palace. The collections in the museum dates back to Moosa (A.S.) Many relics during the time of Prophet Muhammad (SAWS)

Mosques and museums. The Blue Mosque and Topkapi museum are a must visit and a cruise on the Bosforus strait gives a good scenic view of the city. Beware taxi drivers in and around main attractions as they will always try to rip you off. Do not get in a cab unless you have negotiated a price either in euros or lire. If the driver says taxi meter do not get in as you will be going the roundabout route or stung for 2 or 3 times proper fare. If browsing in the Grand Bazaar or other market stalls be prepared to be harassed by shopkeepers ,this is normal practice.

Amazing city. A must see city,friendly people,easy travel,lots and lots to see,we stayed for 8 days enjoyed every minute,we were fore warned about hawkers etc but didn't experience anything like we read about to be honest we enjoyed the chat and had great fun with the people outside their shops and restaurants lovely people don't just ignore them and walk on by engage and you will be bowled over by their natural warmth.
topkapı place. we lıke ewerytıng excalands beatuful grand baazar bassılıca cıstern blue mousgeı harem wery ıntersetıng
WOW. Absolutely amazing places to experience even if you are not into history. The Blue Mosque is breathtaking . Also a visit to the Cisterns underground are really interesting. Very busy everywhere

Finding your way around Istanbul. we spent four days in Istanbul, took tours,, crossed over to the Asian side, and used the hop on, hop bus and ferries, saw the Hagia Sophie, Blkue Mosque, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar,, Topkapi, ate great food at Mikla, and stayed in a fantastic hotel, Initially,the geography of hte city was confusing becaseu of the water and all the different districts, not to mention its size (15 milion inhabitants). Here's a simple way to picture the city and get some sence of where things are, Take your left hand, hold it in front of your eyes, palm facing you.
