Your forefinger is the Bosporus and your finger nail is at the entrance to the Black Sea. Your thumb is the Golden Horn, which is an inlet of the Bosporus which itself is a strait – not a river. Where the bottom of your hand joins your wrist is the Sea of Marmara which eventually joins with the Aegean and Mediterranean seas via the Dardanelles, another strait (which would be along the bottom of your wrist). Your other three fingers are the Asia side of Istanbul and the base of your thumb is Sultanahmet. Today, this is the “old town” where the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace are located and is small and easily walkable between sights. Hundreds of years ago, this area was the whole walled city of Constantinople. The “new city” is above the web of your thumb, forefinger. Getting around is easy. Taxis are everywhere (make sure it’s a yellow cab) the fare is usually shown on the drivers rearview mirror and they are very reasonable; ferries run up, down and across the water; and buses, trams, subways all interconnect, you can get a special transit card (check out the Istanbulkart, if you plan to use public transit a lot). If you are close to the old town, walking is the best option, and if you arrive by cruise ship, its maybe a 20-30 minute walk into the center across the Galata Bridge which will bring you to the Spice market. There are also trams right by the cruise ship dock and the Big Bus hop on, off stops there as well. it is a truly amazing city, the people are very hospitable, great hstorical sites to visit and excellent food
City Break. Well worth the trip - I wish I had decided to do this review my god T Advisor how many do's and don't do i have to do.. ? I am bored now !!!
Where the East meets West. No other city like it...you can just point your camera anywhere and shoot...so much going on and countless amazing sights

Gorgeous. Great food, amazing sights, smells amazing! Very beautiful, unique, and culturally tolerant place. My husband and I had a wonderful time exploring this area: especially because we're history teachers.
A great mix of history and future. Istanbul is a place to be experienced. Very cosmopolitan with a lot of heritage and history. We loved the river side as much as we did the palaces and mosques.
Amazing Istanbul. Busy, bustling, good value, amazing sights, Istanbul is our favourite city. Topkapi, Hagya Sophia, the Blue mosque, the cistern, its all there

Historical areas around Topkapi Palace. Historical areas around the Topkapi Palace are all within walking distance and can be visited in one day. There are kiosks selling Turkish foods around the area but the area can be be pretty crowded around spring and summer.

So much to see. So much to see, so many cobblestones to traverse. Istanbul has many historical sites, several clustered fairly close to each other. Walk by yourself or take a tour, you can't see everything, but soak it up - especially my 2 favourites - the underground water cisterns and the spice market (buy some dates, figs and nuts while you are walking through.)
Beautiful. Overwhelming how beautiful the historic sites are - massive impressive buildings with great interiors.

A walk to the history. The great historic sites at the old part of istanbul with steep walk to reach is such an experience definitely worth, even though taxi rides are also available, walking through the narrow alleys and exploring the architucture style is highly recommended.

Beautiful. We passed this part of the day and night and it is difficult to say when it is more beautiful and more interesting.Every now and then you need to stop, take pictures of something that you have never seen anywhere.

History of the World. Liked?? Istanbul, ruled by Greeks, Romans, Greeks, Seljuks, Ottoman Turks, has thousand-year monuments on every corner. The smallest churches have ageless frescoes, murals, grand architecture. Unlike other Islamic countries, the mosques are open to the non-Islamic public (and usually supply "suitable" clothing), and, many of them having been converted from Greek Orthodox churches, have their own images. A grand grand city to walk in. savoring surprises on both sides of the Bosphorus. Hint: Read your history before arriving!!

Excellnt historical buildings. There are many different historical buildings in Istanbul. But regard to time limitation, the best and most excited palace is Dolmabache palace that is located in Asian part of Istanbul.your visit prolonged about 2 hours but your time is unforgettable time. in comparison to Topcapy palace , Dolmabache palace is more interesting palace. in the other hand, there are many old and beautiful Mosque in Istanbul, i believed Sultan Ahmad Mosque is most beautiful in comparison to others like Aya Sophia Mosque. but these two palaces are just near together.

fascinating place and unforgettable impressions. historic areas of Istanbul are so rich in the places of interest, that you simply are at a loss, not knowing which place to choose to start your acquaintance with the city...that's why you should make a plan what places do want to visit and in what sequence...as for me i started with the Archaeological Museum and never regretted my choice..
Worth the visit. It's well worth the time to wander around this interesting City - one of the must see places in Europe

Quiet in spring season, it is worth to get a bath of history. It is worth the visit. Istanbul is not an expensive city compared with western Europe. Lots of history everywhere and time to spend with the family.Tourism police is around, so it is calm and you can walk with confidence.

Istambul is amazing!. My husband and I loved the city, the food, people are very polite.We had such a good time there and we were very lucky with the weather.We went in December and it wa 15 degrees and very sunny.If you go there don`t miss Topikapi Palace!

Walk by the Bosphorus. Be prepared to share your experience with thousands of people. However to walk where others have since the time of the empire is amazing. Lots of small cafes and bars bustling with business.

Perfect Blend Of asian and European Culture....Love it. Loved each and every corner of Istabul such warm people , so friendly... the city is mix blend of asian and European culture which makes it unique enough to visit...Delight for photographers every angle is picturous.....fashion , History , culture is flowing at eas...clubs and restaurants are worht visit and food is to die for.....given a chance must must must Visit Istanbul...

Old City Sultan(aaaaaaah)met. There is an expression which goes a bit like this.....aaaaaaaahhh. It's an expression which conveys an immense sense of awe and respect and one which is quiet often heard at the Old City Sultanahmet.From the moment you step out of your tram/ bus and see the minarets of the Blue Mosque right in front of you, to the time you leave the Hagia Sofia behind and walk on to the Basilica Cistern, you will be entrapped in a bygone era- one of the last bastions of ancient Turkey. At places like this, you feel the world is a small place indeed- no matter your caste, creed, religion or colour- you will utter the same aaaaah when you behold this spectacle the first time. Tip- After a long walk, unwind at Kilari restaurant right opposite the Bassilica Cistern- it is a trifle expensive but the Kilari Kebab is to die for!

Istanbul Welcoming . I genuinely loved spending time in Turkey. Went there on a Mediterranean cruise and spent one day in Ephesus and three days in Istanbul. I was not only surprised by how gracious everyone was, but was reminded of how wonderful it is to be treated with respect and manners. I totally fell in love with the country and it's people. And the history is almost beyond imagination. The architecture is stunning everywhere you turn. I would go back in a heartbeat.

Blue Mosque. Wonderful experience with a guide to explain the architecture, history, and customs. It is an amazing place - both inside and outside. Bring a headscarf and men should wear long pants out of respect, however they do offer cotton head covering for women and a cloth to cover men's legs.
Incredible Istanbul. We thoroughly enjoyed the historical sites, local colour, the people and the restaurants. A great experience.
One of the world,s great cities.. Istanbul is greatly enjoyed by everyone who visits it. If you want scenery, history or good food; go to istanbul
Great place to visit!. This is one of my favorite cities. I've never gotten to see everything even though this was my 5th time there.

First visit to turkey . Loved Istanbul, the Turkish coffee the raw almonds and nuts that they served around. Loved the food, and gallata tower, the green plums from Istanbul. I'll definitely visit again:)

Incredible City. We really enjoyed exploring the old areas of Istanbul. There is a lot of history and culture to take in. Every corner you take is something new to see. It really is beautiful and amazing to see how the city works. Would have been good to do a walking tour to get a better understanding as there is a lot to take in.

Istanbul prior to cruise. Istanbul is extremely clean, locals are friendly and helpful. Except for a lot of young men wanting to direct us to their "family's carpet store", city was one of our favorite European cities.

Europe and Asia randezvous. Amazing concentration of the many times architecture - the Roman Aqueduct and many structures from Roman era, imposing Mosques with glorious ornamentation and exotic atmosphere and the new age bridges (Galata, Bosphorus, The Golden Horn).

A facinating and very busy city. Although we only had two days in Istanbul a visit to the Grand Bazaar is a fascinating and a well worth experience that should not be missed.
The Blue Mosque is a must for anybody visiting Istanbul as are other Mosques as well the Topkapi Palace,

Tips for seeing old town in Istanbul. The old town of Istanbul has all the main attractions within walking distance of each other. I recommend that you re purchase your entry tickets to all the attractions you wish to visit. Pick the one you don't want to miss and do this one first and arrive early in the morning to get at the head of the queue, especially in the summer months, the lines are very long as everyone seems to prepurchase but the lines for purchase at gates are even longer.
Very interesting!. Beautiful place! Istambul has a lot of story and this place is the epicenter of it. Definitely its a must see region on the city.

Traveling back in time.... Visiting the historic areas of Istanbul was like traveling back in time. The abundance of top attractions makes it easy to walk around. The mosques were as beautiful as you imagine them and worth the wait. The Cistern is definitely worth a visit and a cool place in the summer. The Grand Bazaar was not my favorite because it was so crowded. I discovered smaller ones and did my shopping there. The smells draw you into the Spice Market, but I thought, the spices were overpriced. There are a lot of beggars, especially with all the refugees coming across the border now. Beware of the shoe brush trick. Do not pick it up when dropped. It is a scam. We were warned before our trip. All in all, the Historic City is a magical place not to be missed. Easily accessible by tram. What also impressed me was the cleanliness of the city.

History Galore.... The old Sultanahmet distric is a must see. Although I tend to escape from very turistic areas in favour of more authentic, local experiences, the old Constantinople obviously cannot be missed while in Istanbul. I visited the usual suspects so I will only highlight my favourites. I particularly loved Topkapi Palace and the Basilica Cistern. The former because I love Turkish mosaics and there are loads of them at the palace. Try not to miss the Harem. The Basilica Cistern is a magical place, just opposite the Hagia Sophia, it is a short visit, it takes no more than 20 minutes but there is something about it, the damp atmosphere, the columns, very peaceful (was not crowed at all when I visited it). Having seen souks and old markets before (in Morocco and Turkey), I found the Grand Bazaar and the Spice market were somewhat disappointing, but I guess if it is your first time you will find it exotic enough. There are some lovely, quite streets if you forget the map and just wander around. The area around Galata tower is lovely in the evening, with small shops and cafes open till late. I was on my own and felt very safe.

Beautiful city.. Did a day tour via custom coach and was glad I did. City is vast and having a local tour guide to narrate was a great benefit to understand the history of the sights. Istanbul is a beautiful city and people are very friendly. Just go with an open mind and know that this is the middle east so things are going to be different.
Nice places. The old places and the people everywhere walking and discover how beautiful are the history of Istanbul, it's such a reality of been living the moment.
amazing cultural mix. amazing cultural mix but the crowd of tourists can be very disturbing and annoying especially some group that voice up all the time. good touristic organization

So much to see!. The Sultanahmet district is loaded with historical places like the Blue Mosque, Hippodrone and Haghia Sophia all big triumphs of architecture, however my favorite attraction in the Basilica Cistern under the city. Located at 13 Yerebatan Cad., its subtle entrance is easy to miss, however, once inside you enter a vast beautiful piece of Byzantine engineering. The Ottomans didn't even know of the cistern's existence. Legend has it that it was rediscovered after people were found to be collecting water, and even fish through holes in their basements. A must see!

So much to see and appreciate. Throughout Istanbul you will come across structures of significance to different historical periods. Of particular interest are the Roman walls still evident throughout the historical areas. In addition, there are remnants of the aqueducts that carried water to the city. Look for markers throughout the area as the city of Istanbul / and the Turkish government have done an excellent job of identifying places of significance to their history.

full of history. historical mosques, shopping, the food displayed in shop windows was sooo creative ! sultanahmet is wonderful, there is a bit of harrasment from the restaurant owners, they have a habit of coming out on the streets to 'catch' tourists custom. they point you to a restaurant , than you find that it's another one tucked away in some darkened alley

Rich History at an easy pace. The geographical combination of Asia and Europe has seeped into the culture and character of the city and its residents as well who appear curiously Eastern and Western at the same time. Its a beautiful city with a great transportation system and most important historical places within walking distance of each other. Go to the central park between Aya Sofya and Blue Mosque to capture your framable Istanbul picture.
istanbul. historic sites in Istanbul , is the most attractive area all over the world , i think that is enough for you to discover by yourself what i mean
Topakapi Palace. Beautiful views from Summer House and cafe along with interesting displays, decoration and expansive grounds. Go early to avoid crowds.

A great city break . It got rid of our new year doldrums!. We stayed in January just below the blue mosque. An excellent few days out. The blue mosque and Hagia Sophia are essential visits. The underground cistens are a great visit too.Forget an organised boat trip. We jumped on the trip boat that cruises around and for just a few lira we had a superb 2 hr trip up the bosphorus.Visit the fish market and have a lovely fresh hamsi salad (whitebait). For great views the Galetta tower is good and no stairs it has an elevator.Just wander around and enjoy all the sights and smells.
history altogether . this was an amazing day spent! all the famous historic places in one big area. you need an entire day for just this area looking about. A lot of walking!

Escape from a crowded city. We went along the roads in Istambul, alone, without guide.. at a late hour. It was kind of fascinating..Nice architecture, nice illumination..Because I hate crowded places it was the perfect time to see the bay and ships on Bosphorus.

Grand mosques and a palace. The mosques dominate the skyline with their spires and domes. Architecturally marvelous inside and out. The palace is a must see in this city. Stunning views and interesting rooms and royal jewel collection.

Beautiful Istanbul. I can see Rotterdam, South London, Cologne and Brussels in Istanbul. No wonder people say 'once u been in Istanbul U wont go back to other city in Europe. I fell in love with this city. It was amazing experience. Its very beautiful..historical..magical. I feels i was travelling back to Ottoman century when i visited topkapi. I love the blue mosque. I had lunch on the boat while crossing the Bosphorus..its awesome! I took the train n i feels like i go back to Rotterdam. Also experienced the Haghia Sofia! Theres so many nice place to visit. U need at least a couple of weeks to explore Istanbul. Will definately come back here and i wana go Ankara n pamukalee..i juz felt in love in Istanbul.
Beautiful city. Loved everything about Istanbul - the historic areas are so enjoyable to walk around. Wear comfortable shoes though!

1- Sultan Ahmet Area very interest place to visit in one day, You will enjoy like you live that period of history. There are in Istanbul many places that make you live in the past fragrant, I would recommend all tourists of this city to spend a full day in the Sultanahmet district, where there are many historical buildings such as the Blue Mosqueو Hagia Sophie and the Islamic Museum and other buildings, I would also recommend having dinner at this magnificent placeزIt also recommended to spend the morning or the day in Amanino area and visit the historic mosque (yeni cami) near the market and then visit Egypt (Misir) market Egypt and the Grand Bazar market and buy some souvenirs.
Unforgetable vacation. We liked the old market, the mosques and the city tour by bus.The best of the best was city tour by boat.

PUT INSTANBUL AT THE TOP OF YOUR BUCKET LIST. Actually the historic area of Istanbul is not on the Asian side (as the photo shows), it is on the European side of the Bosphorus. Wonderful sites are everywhere in this ancient city and you will need to spend about a week here to really appreciate all that Istanbul has to offer. This is one of my favourite places on Earth.

Aya Sofiya. Wow! it used to be a church and now is a mosque must visit. you can feel both religions Christianity and Muslim Faith in one place. you can enjoy the court yard with cold and hot drinks. its very clean.
historical places. I saw the historical places in istanbul. But they were not butifull. I like historical places in Iran, more than Istanbul.
Must see. It's worthwhile setting aside a day to look around the historic area of Sultanahmet. You can walk or take the Red bus to different sites.
Historic scenery is rich in istanbul. Same as it's history istanbul is rich with its historical building and landmarks.and all within a walking distance of each others.

sensational and spectacular City. ﻿Istanbul is the only city embracing two continents: Asia and Europe. The Bosphorus, meandering through the heart of the city, combines the waters of the Black Sea and Marmara Sea.no wonder that so many centuries ago, people chose to settle on this extraordinary spot.

A feel of old Turkey. I liked visiting all the historical sights. They can get crowded so go early. What i didn't like was that the museum card is not valid everywhere and they only take cash at some places, not credit cards.

Soaked In History. Never been much of a museum buff, but converted now. The history of Turkey was so interesting, visited Blue Mosque, Cistern, Sofia Haig, A few palaces, museum, Grand Bazar, Spice Bazar, be prepared for lots of walking.
Mosque and more. The Blue Mosque, bazaars, sights and food all were within minutes of our hotel and the guide was knowledgeable.

Istanbul is a fascinating city.. You feel the presence of thousands of years of history on every corner. The public transport is excellent : clean & fast and it brings you to every corner of the immense city. Take a transport pass which you can reload in every station. We went there during ramadam.... there is less traffic during the day and the terraces are not all crowded before sun dawn.

Place to get lost and still enjoy it ;-). The largest Bazaar in the World. One would find almost anything in this place. This place is huge and amazingly pretty beautiful. I love the energy, good vibe, and crowd that is pulled by this place. I am not a shopper. I went here found a nice Cafe, bought some Turkish delicacy and Turkish Coffee, and watched tons of people walking in the alley.Just be careful with the haggling that goes with the shopping here.A must place to visit ofcourse to buy stuff and not just watch people. ;-)

Amazing!. All the major attractions are in Sultanahmet so very convenient to just walk around. The Haggia Sophiya, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Underground Basilica Cistern give you an insight into the times of the Sultans. Topkapi Palace is a veritable storehouse of history and very impressive. But one must give Topkapi at least two to three hours.

Great City. Istanbul its a great city and its historic areas are part of the heritage that the turkish people love to share. You would have hundreds of historic places to see and live..The buildings are amazing and the history fascinating.Very easy to get around.Turkish people are very helpful.I really loved the Blue Mosque and were impressed by the Roman Cistern. Topkapi is also a must visit but i suggest you get there early.Must see places!
great trip!. fantastic historical places,great hotel(rixos pera),good shopping,nice weather,beautiful seaside....

Worth seeing places. For those who visit Istanbul I would suggest that their tour won't be completed without visiting this place. A very well preserved historical heritage and one must not miss it. Loved it and really enjoyed the trip. One day is not enough to see and enjoy all its beauty.

All major sights well looked after.. Istanbul is a great city, so many sights of major importance are close together in the Old City. I found the entry prices to be very reasonable in comparison to museums in Britain.

ISTANBUL HAS A LOT TO SEE SOFIA, TOPAKAPI AND BLUE MOSQUE HEAD THE LIST. This is a happening place with a lot to see. It is very crowded and carrying water supplies was essential to us. The Blue Mosque is nice but not beautiful in my opinion.The Topakapi is about the same. Sofia has more appeal!BIG Tip--Expect to have long lines unless you can arrange a tour to get you to the front of the line. Our Celebrity cruise tour did not do this for us and this was a major disappointment. It is very hot in Istanbul and outside exposure waiting in a line is unpleasant. Carry ample supplies of water!

Istanbul -lovely lively City. The old town area is simply delightful and with a fabulous sense of history, great museums and mosques. The people are warm and friendly and there are an incredible number of places to eat. Some fabulous rooftop restaurants here like the Seven Hills where we stayed.

Historic Istanbul. The Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque are definitely a must see but don't miss the old Roman Cisterns. They were definitely something worth seeing. One of the best parts of Topkapi Palace is the Harem but it is has a separate entrance fee. Definitely pay the extra to see it.We bought the 3 day pass for the Topkapi Palace and other museums and it made it much simpler not to stand in so many long lines. Unfortunately though, we made the mistake of thinking it was an unlimited pass and we left Topkapi mid day to go rest. We thought we could return in the afternoon to finish our sight seeing. Unfortunately, the pass is only good for one visit per museum so no matter how tired you are, you need to finish the tour. Also, there are lots of hawkers that pretend they are tourists or regular locals and just want to talk to you, but they will always eventually lead you somewhere to sell you something. This is on top of the regular hawkers standing in front of stores and restaurants. It gets very tiring being constantly badgered.Overall it was an amazing trip with so much to see. We stayed 4 days but really needed more time to see the rest of Istanbul.

Culture and history. Although you will see more tourists than local people, the place is still very Turkish. Of course everyone wants your business and you get to be prepared. Walking is okay but it is very very crowded.

Past, present and future. In this part of amazing Istanbul you will find everything! Old, new and futuristic attractions and places worth visiting. Although the international atmosphere is highly present all around you still can be thrown way back in time just around the next corner. I love this city and all it has to offer! Go there and experience the Pearl of the Orient yourself! :)

Istanbul is just awesome. I liked everything about Istanbul except the traffic, The historical places are just awesome, Dolmabache palace & Topkapi palace are just too good, this city is a full of surprises.
Well preserved historical places. All historic buildings and places are very well preserved. The touristic agents are very well informed about the city history and past.
Awesome. Organized and safe for tourists, you can find all sorts of complementary services and the people is just great. All historical areas of Istanbul are well maintained, clean and organized.

Wonderful City. It's like walking through an outdoor museum. Every turn of any street and you are staring at culture and history that is unlike any that I had seen. Safe, easy to get around (taxi, walking, tram), don't fret straying West from Sultanhamet - was a highlight of ours -- the only Westerners walking around a local market in Fatih. A slice I suspect not many but locals see.

Fascinating history. The Mosques, the Markets, the people, the restaurants, the hotels...all were excellent. Great experience everywhere we went. Went early in June before the huge summer crowds but it was still busy. Lines were manageable and weather was perfect.

dont follow, find your own..... You can follow the crowds to many landmarks around this area, but I recommend just getting lost in the side streets of the historical district. I did. definitely worth to walk the off the beaten track areas.

Amazing place. From the magnificen Topkapi palace to the stunningly beautiful Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia Istanbul old town is an incredible place to visit. We spent two days in Sultanahmet and I could easily do another two days with that much history and culture.
When History more fun than ever. Explore the spice trails of Istanbul, meet the generous faces at Grand Bazaar and look for the Ottomani graceness in the Hagia Sophia complex

SPLENDID TOUR. We did the walking tour during the last 2 days of our trip. Our guide, Mustafa, was very knowledgeable. We toured the Blue Mosque, Haghia Sofia, Topkapi Palace and Hippodrome. Following this, the next day, we went on a cruise on the Bosphorus and finally did some shopping at the Grand Bazaar..

Istanbul is a terrific destination. Istanbul is one of the world's most historic cities. Take time to learn some of its history before you go. It is very easy to get around by public transit. The food is excellent. Go in mid-April if you want to see the city covered in tulips. Be sure to take in the public ferry ride up the Bosphorus to the Black Sea and back. We will definitely visit Istanbul again.

Only for one time is worth it.... I was in Istanbul for 7 days,went and see o lot of historic places,but I can't say that I was very,very impressed.The fares for entrances are very high(more that in Paris,for example),comparing with what you have to see,the mosques are blue(not only the Blue Mosque),not in very good shapes,but yes,for one time is worth it to see them.No one speakes English,very hard to ask any information.But I liked very much the Princess Islands.

Grand Bazaar and Spice Market a MUST. We spent a LOT of time walking around the historic areas. Our favorites were the Grand Bazaar which is amazing and the Spice Market which was also great, but very crowded! You could spend days and still not see it all!

Worth the trip.. I can not stress how wonderful Istanbul is. Make a special trip for this place. There are some dangerous fringe areas and if you are a timid traveler stay at an expensive hotel in one of the tourist areas, if you are bit more outgoing stay at a hostel. Either way there are dozens of interesting and wonderful places to see here. Haga Sophia, Blue Mosque, baths, The Bosphorus, I have been here 5 times and suggest two to three weeks per visit.

Popular Blue tile mosque is worth visiting!. The craftsmanship and historic tour by the volunteers is great! Many photo opportunities and remember to cover your head and shoulders and remove your shoes.

Old city mosques. Old city Mosques impressive but unlike cathedrals are fairly empty barns. Hagia Sophia is really interesting from a Westerner's viewpoint as they are undoing the Middle Age's Islamizing of it and though it will continue as a museum at least some of its origin is to be seen.
Living Ruins. Functioning Ancient CisternsMosques in use today, Palaces in amazing conditionHistory everywhere, walking distance.

Grand Bazaar. just walked through the Bazaar. Items were too expensive. More than London.
Passed through the Spice market at the same time. Again was too expensive.
Did not buy anything.

Loved Istanbul. Did a tour from cruise ship but you could easily do it on your own from port.
The blue mosque, cistern etc close to eachother. Grand bazar was great and we walked back to ship from here.

Beautiful and Interesting Sights. So many of the historical buildings are within walking distance to each other -Topkapi Palace, Aya Sophia, the Hippodrome and the Blue Mosque. Buy the extra ticket to view the Harem when visiting the palace. Be sure to visit the Basilica Cistern.
One of the worlds best places to Visit. A remarkable place with thousands of years of history. Go to the old quarter around the bazaar and just walk.

City of contrasts. Astonishing, mesmerising, haunting, spiritual, moving, awe-inspiring, slightly scary, can't-get-it-out-of-your-head memories of this beautiful city. The moment your boat pulls into the harbour with the sounds of the muezzins echoing from mosque to mosque around the city - the rest of the world falls silent around you. The scams in the bazaar and the restaurants ("Only locals eat here" - yeah yeah.... and you're too polite to leave once you're in there, and force yourself to pay for awful food in miserable surroundings, along with the other ripped off tourists...), the beautiful cats who are so friendly and then suddenly - all - disappear over night... the sinister back alleys, the graffiti, the inviting open parks where sad Shopping Malls are planned to be built to feather someone or other's nest... what a city of contrasts.
Wonderful City. St. Sophia is impressive. Suleymani mosque and Grand Bazaar also very nice. Taksim area and 360 restaurant is a must.

Istanbul : a must-see city to visit. Fist time in Istanbul and I LOVED it. It is such an amazing city! There is so much to visit from the grand bazaar or the Egyptian bazaar known for its spices and oils, the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque ... This is also the perfect place to try a tulip shaped glass of Turquish tea and the authentic Turquish cuisine.

Blue Mosque, Cistern, Aya Sophia. Blue Mosque alone worth the trip to Istanbul. Do not miss! Fabulous tiles an incredible space! Cistern may seem tacky, but is not. It is a great space, very peaceful.
Old City. I really enjoyed my visit to Istanbul Turkey. The people were fantastic and there is so much to see.
You must go to Istanbul!. This city is amazing from its history and architecture to the people. Highly recommend putting this city on your must-travel list.

Outstanding: UNESCO World Heritage. Istanbul is a city to walk and walk! The Historic Areas of Istanbul are strategically located on the Bosphorus peninsula between the Balkans and Anatolia, the Black Sea and the Mediterranean, Istanbul was successively the capital of the Eastern Roman Empire, and the Ottoman Empire and has been associated with major events in political history, religious history and art history for more than 2,000 years. The city is situated on a peninsula which is surrounded by the Golden Horn (Haliç), a natural harbor on the north, the Bosphorus on the east and the Marmara Sea on the south. The Historic Peninsula, on which the former Byzantium and Constantinople developed, was surrounded by ancient walls, built initially by Theodosius in the early fifth century. Some of the building around are:Hagia Sophia ,Topkapi Palace the Süleymaniye Mosque complex and Sehzade Mosque complex, works of the chief architect Sinan, reflecting the climax of Ottoman architecture in the 16th century, the 17th century Blue Mosque and the slender minarets of the New Mosque near the port completed in 1664.The four areas of the property are the Archaeological Park, at the tip of the Historic peninsula; the Suleymaniye quarter with Suleymaniye Mosque complex, bazaars and vernacular settlement around it; the Zeyrek area of settlement around the Zeyrek Mosque (the former church of the Pantocrator), and the area along both sides of the Theodosian land walls including remains of the former Blachernae Palace. These areas display architectural achievements of successive imperial periods also including the 17th century Blue Mosque, the Sokollu Mehmet Pasha Mosque, the 16th century Şehzade Mosque complex, the 15th century Topkapi Palace, the hippodrome of Constantine, the aqueduct of Valens, the Justinian churches of Hagia Sophia, St. Irene, Küçük Ayasofya Mosque (the former church of the Sts Sergius and Bacchus), the Pantocrator Monastery founded under John II Comnene by Empress Irene; the former Church of the Holy Saviour of Chora with its mosaics and paintings dating from the 14th and 15th centuries; and many other exceptional examples of various building types including baths, cisterns, and tombs.A must!!!

Awesome City, Clean and marvellous. This city is simply spectcular... Lots of history, nice places and things to do... Dont miss both Topkapi and Dombalache palaces... Very nice... Also the blue mosque is not to be missed... The underwater cisterns... The Bazzar... Then do NOT miss going to the Asian side... Cross the Bophorus bridge and you will be delighted... CLEAN crisp and beautiful! Go up the Camilica Hills and see the spectacular views!!

overrated, overrated, overrated!. I love using tripadvisor and have found it the most useful tool for booking, BUT, on this occasion, we just don't get it. Istanbul ranks no 1 city in Europe? Really? We cant wait to get out of here. We are staying in good accomodation in the old city next to Blue Mosque. We couldnt be better located? Walk out your door and get ready to be bombarded with sleazy, pushy sellers of everything you can imagine, most of whom are blowing smoke in your face and wont take no for an answer. Some nice buildings but no way does it compare to London, Paris, Rome, Praque or most of the other cities we have visited. HOW CAN THIS RANK NO 1? Dirty overated city. Ramadan is on at present so don't try and get a drink anywhere.

Loved our tour. No trouble with the language as we had a very capable guide who took us in a bus (I'm) sure every place. Without him, crossing the streets would have been an adventure I'm glad we missed. After Istanbul we were taken to see the battle sites from WW1.

Amazing city with thousands years of history. There is a point when you find yourself in Turkey, specially in Istanbul,and realize that this is the spot where lots of history was going on during Roman times, early christianity, Osman empire and till now. Turkey itself is an amazing country, really historicaly rich and Istanbul is like an cherry on that historical pie. almost every part of the city reveal you something old and interesting, but it doesnt stop there, for thoise who dont care much about history, there is plenty of modern things to see.Take your time for this city, it is really worth spending a lot of days here.

Amazing Buildings from a Time Long a Ago. Hagia Sophia Blue Mosque Tokapi Palace Cisterns Dolmabache Palace, the Bospherous add in the Acient Spice Market and the Grand Bazzar need I say more. Watch out for the Carpet Sellers who don't give up
After long trıp to Tanzanıa. the best offer for as street and historıcal location , 5 munıte from hotel to Hagıa Sophıa - Topkapı Palace

Amazing Istanbul!. Loved the amazing history of Istanbul! This city has such a great variety of things to see. Topkapı Palace is a must-see! Also, don't miss the Basilica Cistern. Was a little overwhelmed by the crowds in June!

Pay attention to all buildings. There are plenty of things to see in the city. But while jumping from one mosque to another or from the restaurant to a museum, don't forget to have a look at an ordinary builings where locals live. Some of them will capture your attention for a long time. And don't be afraid to be lost in one of a thousand small streets - this is how you'll know Istanbul better.

Istanbul a must see. Loved the historic areas of Istanbul. It is a busy, bustling place but it is exciting. We were on a Insight tour and saw all of the major sites. Before joining the tour we caught the local tram and had no trouble in getting around. Istanbul is a great place to explore.Love it.

Get lost for days around this area just fantastic. You can walk for ages with never ending sites to look at finish off with a stroll through the massive Grande Bazaar, photo opportunities abound, we just loved it
City tour. Nice if you like crowds and dogs. Was hoping to buy more stuff at the grand brazzar but most stores sell the same goods. Bargaining was not fun but is mandatory to begin with.
The Hagia Sofia. Fantastic museum - one of the best in Europe. Well-preserved mosaic pictures of the Jesus and Mary even during the Ottoman period.

Amazing Istanbul. There is so much to see and do with a long, dramatic history. Incredible buildings and treasures. Having a great guide who spoke English well and who really had an extensive knowledge made the visit unforgetable

Spice Market. This is an amazing place for anyone who is comfortable in the kitchen. A spice shop, about four stores in from the main entrance has the best Iranian saffron. I bought it for $33 an ounce and it is wonderful. They pack it in a tiny glass jar, easily packable and vacuum sealed it so it travels home easily. Please make sure that you buy from this shop. There are many and many are fake. If you like Turkish coffee, follow your nose to the shop that is grinding the beans, around the corner from the spice shop. My bag of coffee has the name Kurukahveci Mehmet Efendi written on it. And yes, both go through American customs without a problem.
Istanbul - my dream city. Istanbul has it all - the sights, the history, the culture, the food, the restaurants, the stores, and great, inexpensive boutique hotels!
Rich Hiretage. İstanbul kept and maintained its important places carefully.. you will never forget these places..Liked: everythingNot liked: Taxis in these areas not honest
Sultanahmet a must see. If there is only one thing you do in Istanbul, go to Sultanahmet district - the Blue Mosque, Sophia Museum, Topkapi Palace and the Grand Bazaar. Go early as lines can be long!

Historic buildings. The Topkapi Palace has attractive grounds and outstanding views of the Golden Horn and Bosphorus. The Basilica Cistern was very interesting. I was somewhat disappointed to find that the Hagia Sophia was undergoing extensive renovation and, therefore, there was a lot of scaffolding around.

A wonderful experience. My wife and I (I am 73 and my wife is 68) spent two and one-half days in Istanbul starting May 17, 2015. I had hired a private guide, Mehmet Tetik (guideturk@gmail.com) for two days. I had hoped to see the basic sites in the old town, but with Mehmet's guidance, we saw so much more. We basically were able to spend as much time as we wanted in all of the sites in the Sultanahmet (old town) on the first day, including Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, lunch at the famous pudding ship, Byzantine Hippodrome, and the Basilica Cistern. On the second day we went to the Grand Bazaar, the western wall, the Chora Church, the spice market and the New Mosque with a ferry ride on the Bospherous where we had lunch in a very nice restaurant on the Asian side. Istanbul is becoming a very popular tourist location, but we never felt it was over crowded (except in the Spice Market because we were there late in the day) and most of the tourists are from Islamic countries. We never felt unsafe, even though we took the street car once and the subway under the Bospheous back to the European side after lunch. We stayed in a hotel I found here on Trip Advisor, the Black Tulip, which is just five minutes from the Topkai Palace in the Sultanahmet. The hotel has all the lastest electronics, including electronic door locks, that with a screen outside our room with the room number and whether you are occupying the room or not. The rooms were immaculate, with marble baths, a big shower (large enough for two), and very comfortable beds. The staff was more than helpful. The breakfasts are lavish with multiple items, including some western items. We ate the Turkish breakfasts, which consist mostly of fresh vegetables. We took a cab from the airport to the hotel, which took about an hour, partly because it was a Sunday and you travel along the Sea of Marma, and there is a park all along the shore, and everyone was out having picnics parking their cars in the street, etc. It only cost about $12 though. You will love Istanbul, and if you are thinking of going, think about hiring Mehmet as your guide, you will not regret doing so. He is empathetic, college educated, speaks excellent American English, and has a depth of knowledge you will not get any other way.

You can't get bored in Istanbul!. If you start your tour of historic Istanbul at Sultanahmet square you will have plenty to see and do for several days. When just sitting at the square you will have amazing view of the Blue mosque (Sultanahmet mosque) on one side and Hagia Sophia on the other side. You definitely should visit both since those are symbols of Istanbul. Next to the Blue mosque is Arasta bazaar and although it is pricey, especially if you are on the budget it is nice to walk around. My favorite part there are drains that are decorated with Turkish design tiles. Really cute. If you continue walking from there to Hagia Sophia on a right side you will come across old wooden houses that are not well maintained but are still beautiful and worth seeing. I recommend visiting Topkapi palace and plan to spend up to 6 hours there. It is worth spending most of your day there. There is so much to see, you can sit and enjoy the view using outside benches, gorgeous view on the sea, several cafes to get coffee and snacks. Gulhane park is just outside of Topkapi palace and it is good place to walk around, sit and read book and just meditate for hours. You can buy also snacks there and drinks. Close to the tramp stop Sultanahmet are located Basilica Cisterns. Definitely visit them. It gives completely different feeling of historic part of Istanbul. If you walk further up the tram line you will run across Grand Bazaar (Kapali carsii) and you will be able to get trinkets or simply enjoy this place. From there you can walk directly to the Suleymania mosque which is gorgeous. There are so many things to see just in this part of Istanbul and to keep you busy at least for several days. My favorite was sitting in the Sultanahmet square and having Turkish tea. Try it :)

A great area to stay.. We stayed at the Golden Horn Sirceki, which is only a 5 minute walk along the tram line to the historic area where you find the Aya Sophya, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cisterne and many other lovely sights all within walking distance of the Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar - all so close together. If not on a tour, try to get to the attractions early in the morning or later in the afternoon to avoid the crowds. A great place to stay, with plenty of places to eat, sit, look around.... Istanbul is a truly amazing city!!
Things to see. Istanbul is an amazing city very easy to get around on public transport. We found everyone very helpful and honest

Beautiful city with good experinces. I spent 3-4 days in Istanbul during my trip to Turkey and this is very amazing journey to our family.It has so many historical places to see and of course a beautiful attaractions. delicious food and especially pomegranate juice.
interesting. worth the visit Istanbul is a very exciting city and the historic aspects are truly inspiring. I loved this part of town very much

Sultananahmed is nothing but incredible collection of history.. Liked everything ( I can't believe I am saying it). But it is true. From architecture to food to street vendors to political demonstration to friendly people - you will enjoy it all.

10 Days are not enough to enjoy Instanbul's Historic Attractions. After spending 10 days in Istanbul we had not run out of things to see. Till the end we kept running into more history even without trying. In one restaurant the kids discovered that the floor was partially made of glass and you could see down into archeological ruins of a Roman Palace literally in the restaurant's basement - which customers could explore for free. Amazing!

Historic Istanbul. There are so many exciting things to do in Istanbul! Of course, there are the main attractions such as the Hagia Sophia, Tokapi Palace, Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque - but if you have more than a day or two in Istanbul, take the time to explore more of the daily culture. We spent a couple hours sitting on a park bench in the harbour just watching the boats and everyday life. Also take the time to interact with shop owners and staff in the restaurants!
Interesting City where East meets West. Istanbul is a very mysterious city. You can feel the conflict and congruence of the cultures and religions.

Beautiful and interesting area to spend 3-4 days. Loved the people and the history. Food was fantastic, views were memorable. Doubletree Hotel Old Town was supurb. Shopping for carpets & scarves was fun.
:). great markets and crowded area with people from all around the world, good place for a good new experience

You are in Istanbul to see this.. Once you tell somebody that you are going to visit Istanbul that means you will see the history of the ottoman empire,mosques,churches,bazaars and much more,for a history lover like my Istanbul is a wonderful city,make sure to see the historic areas of Istanbul because it's almost every thing you will do there,ayasofia,blue mousqe,basilica cistern,grand bazaar,galata tower and much much more not to be missed.

Fabulously friendly people, colourful city, just a joy.. I wanted to revisit Istanbul since I first went as a teen in 1975 (yes I really am that old)! The thing I love about it is that it's just that bit different from most European life, to feel as though you have discovered something specia and a little differentl. I love the old world feel of some parts of the town. The steep winding roads and paths and the markets.Food is very good and the city is so much cleaner now than it was when I first visited way back. There is plenty of history and architecture to discover here too. People are no longer permitted to nag you to death to buy their goods so it is comfortable to just browse in shops. Hagai Sophia is a must to visit. The scale of the ceilings etc.are hard to grasp. We stayed a week and ran out of time to do everything, which was a shame, but on the last day we managed to spend some time chatting with a young local lad about photography, as he had bought his first decent camera with is hard earned cash. He invited us to join him for coffee but we were all out of time. Those moments are precious and I regret that we couldn't chat about how life was for him In such an interesting city.

Take a walk in Old Istanbul. If you're going to book a hotel in Istanbul, do it in old Istanbul. That way you'll be a short walk away from the Blue Mosque, The Hagia Sofia, the Basilica Cistern, The Grand Bazaar, the Egyptian Bazaar, and the Spice Market. Its an area of beautiful roads, wonderful restaurants, and places that history buffs with fawn over!

The East and the West. I love it I will be back again. There is no way to forget the historical events without relate them to our daily living. Through this trip people can see the relationships between different religion, faith community, and historical incidents which encourage us to reflect who we are. What we should do to make this world a better place for us to enjoy.
Must visit!. Just go for it!Istanbul with whole historic areas making a real masterpiece of Turkish culture. Want to go back as many time as I can!!!To feel to soak to try to discover!!!

Everything in one place. This is a beautiful part of the city to be in. Most of the sites that you have heard about are in this location, all within walking distance. The only reason I gave it four stars instead of five, is the often incessant hassling from vendors and store owners. (none that would cause any fear though)
Awesome. Probably one of the best spot in the world. Also for those that are not into churches and similar will like this area
My stay. I did not realise that most of the mail attractions were in such a small area. Very characterful even the carpet sellers make you smile !!!!

Visit of a life time. Istanbul was probably one of the best holidays we had.so much to see.The history is mind boggling.Places to see, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofiya, Blue Mosque, Dervishes, Basilica Cistern,Dervishes.Go there !
Great place to see. I like Sultan Ahmed Mosque (blue mosque), Hagia Sophia, topkapi palace and Gran Bazar. The things are cheap at Grand Bazar, carpets are expensive. Foods are tasty and affordable.

Best Historic Areas. I never knew such an interesting history in till I went to Istanbul, everything was just so interesting to the art, music, people, rulers, everything. Plus as you walk around in the historic areas there are many sitting places, photograph areas (a lot), and awesome people.

A place filled with historic wealth. Istanbul historic areas are great for history passionates! It is a city filled with all kinds of wealth, including historical and cultural wealth.
Definitely unmissable!

A World Treasure. Istanbul is more than the center of Turkish society. It has been the nexus of multiple civilizations, which is apparent as you tour the city. It would take months to explore all that Istanbul has to offer, but any attempt will be both enriching and life-changing.
A must see of the world.
Sultanhamet area. The Blue Mosque, The AyaSofia museum, the underground cistern, the Topkapi palace. A wealth of history, art, architecture in a small area

The reason for my trip. The Sultanahmet district is the reason most people visit Istanbul, with the 3 main attractions so close together and lots of accommodation in the area. it's ideal for a short break.

Excellent Hospitality. The tour of Turkey with my family has been one of the most fun and memorable trips. Not only did we get to see the key parts of Istanbul, the tour guide was very knowledgeable and made the bus trips entertaining. The food and hotel arrangements were excellent. This was our first time on an arranged tour, but the experience was so good that we are planning another trip with family through Trip Advisr.

A wonderful tour with rich history. Turkey was not on my bucket list , but a business trip allow me to fit in a few days of sightseeing. I was highly impressed on what the city had to offer. Wonderful rich historial sites. Clean environment and a easy efficient public transport system. Booking on the Internet for tours was effortless and safe. No prepayment was required. The airport shuttle was prompt and the transport vehicle was good. All the tours I booked was managed efficiently and was very informative. Istanbul is a very good place for South Africans to visit due to better exchange rate than the euro. The grand bazaar was amazing and sure to lighten your wallet.

Needs time to see it properly. We walked through this everyday whilst we were there and saw something different every day. We'd got a good map from the hotel so we made certain we marked each street when we did it. Even walking a street twice threw up something we'd missed. Needs time though, but if you have it its worth it.
Wonderfull. We liked the safety, conservation, mobile, accessibility, the respect with the tourist and the magic history around the old city.

Blue Mosque. Stunning. Must see. Istanbul holds a lot of history and the Blue Mosque is part it. A few minutes walk are other historical places you can visit like the Hagia Sofia Museum, Grand Bazaar (if you are a shopaholic you'll go crazy).
sen palas hotel - istanbul. amazing city with kind pepole, nice weather, excellent food, awful hotel with unqualified and unpolite personnel

Trip in time. Everything in Istanbul is incredibly old. I feel that if I were to pick up a stone and toss it, that it would hit something that has probably been there for centuries and probably has some interesting story behind it. It can be overwhelming with the sights, sounds, smell and people, but it is something that can't be missed.

buyuk ada/ princess island. so beautiful, lots of nature and also you can hire a bicycle or horse,it's got his own mother nature that make it a place where so many tourist will like to visit and also go out for sight seeing.
also it a lovely moment to spend on the ferry while making a trip to the island
History at its best!. Istanbul offers a great vision of what the Ottoman Sultanate was liek, luxurious and spectacular palaces all over the place!

Brilliant!. Must do! avoid hot summer months. The best time to travel April, May or September/ October.
Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Topaki Palace you can do in one go. Also, take a boat tour.

Wonderful Istanbul. Istanbul is easy to get around and there's so much to see and do.
Do not miss the underground Basilica Cistern.
Definitely visit a real Hamam for a great experience, the 300 year old Cagaloglu Hamam was fantastic.
We always felt safe.

What an incredible city!. Istanbul is jam packed with important historical monuments and museums. We felt we just scratched the surface. Topkapi Palace was a highlight as were the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia even though Aya Sophia was somewhat disappointing on the interior probably because much of it was covered by scaffolding as they renovate.We enjoyed the Basilica Cistern and the Spice Market. The Grand Bazaar not so much. A highlight was a ferry on the Bosphorus to the Black Sea. Definitely worth the day, although strictly speaking not part of the Historic Areas.This city is exotic, chaotic, historic and totally charming!
Beautiful Sultanahamet area. It's not the Istambul fancy area, but some Nice And much to see around, all historic buildings are here. So recomendable to Stay in a hotel around.

Thousands of years of history. Istanbul has more of history from more civilizations than any place I have been: Greek, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman, modern Turkey. A city in a strategic location. They have built a modern city on top of an ancient city, but have tried to keep every civilization alive for all to see. Kudos.
Historic. Beautiful Byzantine and Ottoman Structures. Prefer staying around Taksim or Sultanahmet.Full of historical places and monuments,amazing views...
the palace. palace and gardens well needed a visit it is not far from the hotel and a range of cafes around. also hop n hop off bus can be taken from here

The main 3 attractions Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. Though quite crowded there was still ways to beat the worst of the crowds with a personal guide and the historic details he provided were amazing.
Breathtaking. Istambul, in one word is breathtaking. The historical sights are numerous and very impressive. I recommend a visit to any history buff.

Historic Istanbul. Beautiful Byzantine and Ottoman Structures. The Suleymaniye Mosque, Hagia Sophia,Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and chora church were great to see. A boat ride on the Bosphorus and taking the train under the Bosphorus to Asia were fun.

A real mix. Istanbul offers a real mix of old & new, clean & grubby. New & old buildings. It's an Islamic country with a democratic & certainly on the surface a liberal culture. There is plenty to see & do from modern shops to the Grand Bazaar, museums & river cruzes, Would highly recommend the hop on off bus. Public transport is efficant & there are plenty of taxi's (although as in every country there are taxi drivers who see tourist as easy targets) Sitting outside a restaurant eating Turkish food & drinking a cup of tea I s a must to watch the world go by. Visiting major attractions later in the day means you miss the Cruze ship parties. Istanbul attracts the bulk of the Syrian refugees. It's a sad site, be willing to give but keep you personnel belongings close. Near the bridges a lot of locals fisherman, be aware it attracts a lot of cats & seagules .
Sultan ahmet. A must to visit ,historical places , traditional hand made antics, good restaurants with special Turkish flavor and real enjoyment

Must see. The old part of Istanbul is a must see, but go stay elsewhere to make sure you get real turkish food and peace and quiet. Transport is excellent and cheap so easy to get from one place to the other quickly and cheaply

Full of history. İstanbul is such a beautiful city that you can find out whatever you can imagine.Full of historical places and monuments,amazing views through beautiful Bosphorus.Very nice to walk down through the streets in the old part of the city.
See Everything!. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofis, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market. Take a Bosphorus cruise.
east meets west. istanbul is a place where east and west meets . It was wonderful to see byzantine and ottoman empire architecture
Amazing Structures. So much history , great food , easy public transport access . Amazing architecture, very clean and safe city , to much traffic congestion, overcrowded trams.

History as far as eyes could see. You don't have to go to Sultanahmet, though there are many historical sites and museums to browse there. Everywhere you look in the Old City you see evidence of its ancient past, but I stayed on 'the other side' and just strolling down Istiklal Street you have lovely old churches you can go in and visit at no cost. There are also old walls and aqueducts here and there; just open your eyes.

Living history!. There are many historical areas with their unique and distinctive characters to visit. Be sure that you also take a boat and make visits to the Asian parts of the city. I warmly recommend particularly Kadiköy!
Bosphorus Tour. Great things to see ,historic buildings, and beautiful sites... I enjoyed viewing The sites along the Bosphorus River. The boat ride was a relaxing and full of interesting tourists.

Once in a lifetime visit. Actually, I'm cheating because it's been a few years since we've visited Istanbul but all the memories are still there. We felt like we were on a different planet this area is so different than the rest of the world as we know it. Stuck in time and tradition. Wonderful experience. Just too bad it's so so far from home. Truly one of our most wonderful life experiences.

Fantastic. i loved every piece of it. I went mainly to re-discover the city. I did Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, grand bazar, Sultan Ahmet, Suleyman mosque, Meriem Mosque. Dolmabace. I loved the city, it is an outdoor museum. it is a must see at least once ni a lifetime.

Visited Istanbul in November. Family visited Istanbul in November last year and weather was similar to Uk, this meant there were fewer tourists at all attractions. City is still very busy. Use the ferries to travel around, you get to see the city from the sea and find new shopping areas. The shops are excellent, value wise and for choice, be prepared to spend spend. The grand bazaar is a whole days outing and again spend spend, deals are to be had and the people are very helpful, just make sure you know what you want and stick to it, even after many cups of tea/coffee. It is exhausting doing tours, lots of walking on uneven pavements and lots of hills but so worth it, make sure you have a central hotel for rest time. Cant wait to go back at a different time of year.

istanbul may/2015. first of all u will enjoy yout trip in istanbul so much, but iw ill tell you a little advice there:1) Buy ISTANBULKART from the machines u can find them anywhere in the stations of metroor trams it will cost u first 10 LT and it will be charged in 4 LT so u have to charge it more , u will need it alot and am sure u will charge it at least 50 Lt for 2 person.2) which one u prefer Taksim or sultanahmet i will tell if u like the night life and resturant and clubs if u are with ur gf go to taksim,, if u are intrested of history, calm place u can walk in the night and romantic and u u can find there nice resturants and a lot of visitors u will see all the visitors theree/3) i went to all places maybe i enjoyed all of them , but about princes island i tell everyone to make it the last one or not to do u need 2 hours at least to go and back u have to stay there 5 hours for nothing just seeing houses and green trees nothing special. when i was there the told me that istanbul municipality avoid to use bicycles so u have to use the (حنطور) (carriage).

Great place to visit. Fantastic place to visit round the year, but I think summer is the best time to visit, more sunshine. Excellent opportunity to see historical places, buy Turkish souvenirs and bring memories.

Rich in history. Amazing history to the place. Every building had a story to tell. Beautiful and amazing architecture. Best appreciated when there are fewer crowds of tourists. It would be good to visit the place during an off peak season.

Great walking city. Whilst you need to be reasonably fit due to the hilling train I highly recommend just walk around. Were ever we walked we felt safe and iMap took us on some very interesting journey's possibly miles out of the way but nevertheless interesting back streets. Don't limit yourself to the old city but cross the Galata bridge and head in any direction and you will find marvels of architecture and sites and sounds and for that matter smells.

the noise!. it was one of the most noisy places i have ever been, but thrilling at the same time, constant hustle and busle, trafic, people,music, everywhere.then suddenly a moments peace as the iman starts his prayers.

Summer 2014. It was wonderful seeing all these places, the palace of Top Kapi is amazing and the view from there is breathing. You relive the Sultan's era overlooking the Bosporus and get an idea of what the Ottoman Empire consisted of.

Awesome places. Way too many places to list,we stayed 11 days and never saw half of what we could.As a photographer this place is magic, so much to see day and night and around every corner.People are so friendly and helpful, food is varied and cheap and travel is so easy. Get an Istanbulkart and a map and away you go.

One week is not enough to take in the splendor of this beautiful city.. I liked everything about this part of the city. Just need more people in the service industry to speak more foreign standard languages, such as basic English or French.

Magnificent atmosphere. The historic areas are so old, us Australians need to experience them and are privileged to have the opportunity.Our Karavan Tour Guide, Er-Shan, was exceptionally good and arranged for us to visit with least crowds.

a total experience in a new culture. difficult to absorb everything there is to see. From enormous religious building to endless small lanes of shops. The bazara is a city itself and can be an entire tour

Historica' areas. We liked THE boattour of 2.1/2 hours starting at THE marmara see, to THE Bosporus, golden hor' and asian part. Costprice': 20 turkish lira with english speaking guide included. You can buy THE tickets in THE parc between THE blue Mosk and THE Aya Sofia

Rich cultural history. Loved the Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Bosphorus cruise, the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Bazaar, the Basilica Cistern. Our trip was enhanced by the fact that we were on a Tauck tour with Turkish guides who spoke excellent English. We received written information and excellent talks on everything we visited!

Simply awesome. While planning, we weren't sure if December was the right time to visit Istanbul. But boy, were we surprised with the historical heritage and a great life this city has to offer! It's especially great for all those who are into history and don't mind going to ancient ruins and museums to know the city. All those books won't help when compared to what you can know by visiting these places. Our favorite was the Topkapi palace though. My two cents, don't buy anything from the museum shops. Instead go to the shops along the road from Blue Mosque to Eminonu, they're great value and with little eye for detail and bargain you can get good stuff.

A Great Walk. Highly recommend that you stay in the Old City--lots of great hotels & restaurants & all major sights in walking distance. We opted to hire a guide and did an all day walking tour--a great choice. Not only was he knowledgeable about the sights, he was also able to adjust our tour around the cruise tour onslaughts, so waiting in line was kept to a minimum

Istanbul trip. Istanbul has lot to offer.I visited the Florence Nightingale museum.It is near the Harem ferry side.It is in the millitary barraks.You have take prior permission from the millitary authorities.Send request by Fax to 02165531009 & 02163107929 with passport copy and your local Istanbul contact no atleast 48 hrs in advance and Army office calls you back for appointment.It is very good and built in the same barraks where Florence Nightingale looked after patients.

Very Pleased with the service provided by TTG (Turkey Travel Group)...Ozlem Batal in particular. A very special Thanks to Ozlem Batal at TTG who organised and supervised my trip of 4 adults and 2 kids I would say she is very attentive and professional throughout taking care of each tiny detail; We spent 9 days in turkey visiting Istanbul, Pamukkale, Euphesus and Cappadocia. Our trip was very perfectly organised starting from initial inquiry till the end of tour. From airport pickup drop-offs, hotel transfers, pickup for tours, all the hotels were good providing good services. I am very much pleased with the kind of service provided to me and my family by Ozlem during our visit to Turkey I would highly recommend and be happy to book again should we return.

Sultanahmed. I was so positively surprised by the old city, its atmosphere. Once in a life you must visit this place. I went there in May, everything was in blossom. It is always good to wake up early and go there around 9am as many foreign people come after 10am and then you miss tickets or have to queue so long. I even walked only around and did not need any transport. Everything is close. People are friendly and welcoming. And what else, there is even Starbucks 3 minutes from Blue Mosque :)

Europe meets Asia. An incredible city that takes time to understand and appreciate. Visits to Aghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Spice Matket and Grand Bazar will fill you with the complexity of this ancient city. Be careful, because there are pickpockets around most tourist attractions. Be careful of what you buy - everything looks wonderful, from jewelry to carpets but it is hard to know who you can trust and if certificates of authenticity are really true. Especially be careful of shops selling the Turkish mined semi-precious gem stone Sultanate. Most of it is artificial - especially the larger stones - if they were real the price would be in the thousands of dollars!!Despite this, Istanbul is wonderful - try to fit in a Bosphorus cruise to see the skyline at its best

A fantastic day.. When we stayed in Istanbul we hired a personal guide for the day. I would highly recommend this to anyone who has limited time in Istanbul. We saw so much in the one day as we did not have to spend time finding our own way around. The guide took us to all the main tourist sites and we were able to jump the queues. He took us to great local spots to eat that were not ripping off tourists.This was well worth the money.

Well worth a visit. Really enjoyed this. Lots. Of people pushing bazaars unfortunately but the ambiance and sites more than made up for this. Highly recommend. Food outlets get a lot more expensive the closer you get to the palace. The Tutsi kebab was good. The dram of smashing the clay pot was fun
Amazing. The historical monuments are amazing and worth to see. Beside of visiting them you can see lots of people from different places in the world and can find new friends.
Satisfaction. Excellent service with good location location and all within walking distance. Amazing staff and amenities.

Stay in the Heart of History. You have to spend a bit of time in the historic parts of town. We spent a week and still there was more we wanted to see. A great way to emerse yourself in history. We will return.

Much to see!. There is much to see in the historic areas, besides the frenetic shopping that is one temptation after the next. I did some useful shopping but also some sight-seeing and had a great time

UNESCO definetely. Every building every ancient wall every corner has something to tell. I can just gaze at the sunset over the historical peninsula for all my life. İstanbul is not a city full of ancient monumental buildings. It is ancient ABD monumental itself. The texture, the design, the city as a complete living creature is beatiful and precious.

Lots to see in easy walking distances. How great to have the core of a historic city available in such tight quarters. You can walk from Topkapi to Hagia Sophia to Basilica Cistern to Blue Mosque in less than 5 minutes between each. The area is definitely deserving of its World Heritage Site designation.

Loved it . So much to do and see make sure if you stay in Istanbul you stay in the historic district it's the best.During the day so much to see in between blue mosque and the port, you can get lost in yourself as every street is just as spectacular and interesting, you can get hounding by people trying to sell you things particularly rugs but you get used to it after awhileAt night time place lights up with so eatery places.My advise is just walk around the smaller street as well not just the main road you get a better experience of the historical area.
Excellent!. Love the country, love the people, love the experience, love the city. Istanbul!Plenty to do, plenty to see, plenty to eat!
Quite Interesting. Two religions in one city and that to relatively nearby. Nice views and reasonable public transport.

Walking Tour of Istanbul Historical Sights. We were only in Istanbul for one day and we did not want to have the challenge of large crowds and 50+ people on a coach, so we opted for a private guide. We used Necip Edis. He was knowledgeable, friendly and more than happy to do whatever we wanted. He emailed an itinerary ahead of time and we were thrilled with all the historical sights he took us to. We saw the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Underground Cistern and Spice Bazaar. We had lunch at the Pudding Shop which was delightful and delicious flavoursome food. Also Necip had all our tickets beforehand so we did not have to stand in long queues for tickets. We were a party of four and we all enjoyed Necip and his tour immensely, so much so, we are all planning to go back to Istanbul for a longer visit and we will contact Necip again.
Almost Perfect. Istanbul has to be on everyones list to see, beautiful, friendly, and historical but we could do without the "helpful" people when you pull the map out to see where you are!

Lots to see within walking distance of each other. Once you are in the area of the Blue Mosque, you can walk to several areas, and have lunch in one of many restaurants. There is also a Bazaar to walk around for shopping just up the hill a bit. There are lots of vendors selling food and drinks on the way.

Exotic, vibrant, amazing!. The best way to see the historic area of Istanbul is on foot. Meander through the narrow streets throbbing with people to the Great Bazaar and the Spice Market. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, and Topkapi are all with a few minutes on foot. Take your time and wander up through windy streets to the giant Suleymaniye Mosque. The view from up there is worth the climb. Stop for a glass of tea along the way or a tasty kebab. Sample Turkish Delight at the Spice Bazaar. Walk across Galata Bridge and stop for a cold beer and some fish on the other side. The options are limitless. Love this city.
Outstanding. Amazing history, easy to walk to most sites, very safe, lots to see in a small area, something for everyone

If you are a real traveller , then it's perfect !!!. Position is perfect and the people are wonderfulllll!!!!stay here and you won't regret!you'll find everything downstairs from gift shops to little restaurants and typical bars!
Beautiful Istanbul. I fell in love with Istanbul. An old City full of character, history lovely hotels and wonderful shops. Turkey is a must for all travelers.

History, beauty, crowd all together. I liked the good state of conservation of the attractions and their historical value. I disliked the crowd everywhere and the lack of honesty of many taxi drivers and restaurant owners.

Ride the Tuk Tuk. We hired a TukTuk to travel around The City to see the sites. It's a fun and inexpensive way to see the sites. Our driver would wait when we wanted stop look around or shop. He also pointed out great places to eat. Bangkok is a bustling fast paced city but friendly and accommodating.
Water Reservior. Neat but not worth the tariff and waiting times. Nice part of the experience was having two large glasses of freshly squeezed Pom juice while waiting in the line
very interesting. It was very interesting. Our hotel was in the historic area and this was perfect. The ways were short und easy going. It was great to see all the famous buildings we heard bevor.

More than a glimpse into the past. Istanbuls Historic Centre still throbs like it would have decades ago. The crowds are made of both tourists and locals alike. take your time and come on the days that the Hagia Sophia and Blue Misque are closed to get a chance to wander when there are less people. make sure you rest in the park that surrounds the Palace as well.

Wonderful place to forget your own self. This is a place that every individual must see if he/she has financial means to reach there. Probably one of the best historic areas in the world. And a highly underrated and under advertised area. Such a beautiful historic place with some wonderful architecture, yet full of life / tourists as well as authentic Turkish people. Its a wonderful place to be. With iconic buildings like THE BLUE MOSQUE, HAGIA SOFIA, TOPKAPI PALACE, BASILICA CISTERN this place can outnumber any other attraction in the world on a list of top places.

So much to see. There are so many historic attractions very close to Sultan Ahmed you will be spoiled for choice. The Blue Mosque is iconic and free, others have ticket prices from 15 to 30 TL. The Spice Bazaar and Greand Bazaar are free and great entertainment even if you don't want to buy.

Historic building had high appeal in revealing the history of the country.. Blue Mosque, Sofia Hagia, Topkapi Palace in particular are worth visiting. Can get headphones and audio assistance at Sofia and Topkapi, but not at Blue Mosque, so read up or go with a guide to get the most benefit from your visit.
Short second stayover. Every thing is reasonably close, good shopping,great food places, lots of historic places to visit and take lots of photoographs
Magical. Fascinating glimpse into different civilizations. The structures are well preserved and some have become museums.

Too much to explore and enjoy within 1 sq km. Getting out of the Sultanahmet tram, takes you to an area filled with History. There is nothing in that area which one would count as not worth except probably the Mosaic museum which is not worth spending time for.
Let your feet take you to another world. An enthralling old world look and feel, many hours and days walking around this district absorbing it all.

Exhilarating, interesting and awesome experience. If you go to Istanbul and do not go to see the Historical areas of Istanbul, your visit is incomplete. The Topakapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque - All these are amazing places and show the rich history of Turkey. My tip: Get a tour guide to explain you all the places and their significance.

The Old City - intriguing and spectacular. Take a tour of the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia - a great taste of history and a departure from Europe - a fascinating bridge between Europe to the North and the Middle East to the South

Hagia Sofia - from Basilica to Cathederal to Mosque to Museum, Topkapi Palace,. 1- Over the centuries, there had been lots of developments, cicizational as well religious and political. Hagia Sofia, for example, 537 to 1204 served as Eastern Orthodox Cathederal, followed by Roman Catholic Cathederal from 1204 to 1261 and again Eastern Orthodox Cathederal from 1261 to 1453. It is still standing for the last 1478 years to recieve throngs of visitors from every corner of the world. 2- Similarly, Sultanahmet (Blue Mosque), as the Imperial mosque from 1935 to onward received the worshiper until it was declared to be a Museum. Almost for over 400 years these two Monuments have enjoyed the highest attraction. There are very important Christian period frescos on the second floor, don't miss it.3-Topkapi Palace Palace, the Harem and Gulhane Gardens are also a great attractions in this area as well as a few other mosques and the Mueum of Islamic History around.4- Sultanahmet park is full of historical places to draw crowds and

Fascinating History.
