Had a one to one tour of the area with a very knowledgeable guide called Nev who explained in great detail the history of the various places we visited. the Blue Mosque was very beautiful but my favourite place was the Hagia Sophia Museum, such a checkered past, once a Christain Cathederal, then a Mosque, now a Museum.The sheer majesty of the structure overwhelmed me as we stepped inside, it was not too crowded and with Nev pointing out diferent things it made for a truly memorable visit,Next was the Grand Bazaar I honestly recommend going round this place with a local I didn't get pestered half as much and Nev stopped briefly to chat to people he knew who were very welcoming.The Hippodrome is almost non-existant these days but the Obelisk in the centre tells an interesting tale. Istanbul is a wonderful City, I found it a little intimidating at first but once I got used to the pace it really enjoyed myself

you cannot turn without seeing history. The Historic areas in Istanbul are trylu 'historic'! the years of history that surround you are at times overwhelming.. make sure you take the time not just to look at the 'major' attractions.. yet also those that are just sitting there waiting for you to find...

The extraordinary city of Istanbul with so many historic sites/sights. We stayed five days on our third visit to Istanbul. There are of course the must see places of Hagia Sophia, with the marble walls, the Blue Mosque with the stunning blue tiles, the Basilica Cistern,with the 336 pillars, the Hippodrome with the ancient pieces,Topkapi Palace (dont miss the Armoury) and the Dolmabache Palace, but I would encourage visitors not to miss the Archeological Museum, the Suleymaniye Mosque and lastly the Yedicule Fortress, a stunning edifice and you will be the only person there!!
So much to see, it MUST take a couple of trips. Istanbul is such a treasure of history, religion and art that you may need more than one visit to see everything.
Long Weekend. Great experience visiting the historic areas of Istanbul. Certainly recommend for a long weekend and October was a good time to visit.

2 days satisfying my curiosity about Istanbul. I learnt nothing about the history of the Eastern Roman Empire and the Ottoman Empire at school, but as soon as I started reading about it as an adult I was fascinated, so I just had to go and see Istanbul for myself. I looked at organised trips to Turkey but found it impossible to choose between them, so I decided i should book a city break to Istanbul and see the things that were important to me. I spent 2 full days exploring Sultanahmet, the old city area of Istanbul and had a wonderful, unforgettable, time. I don't speak Turkish so I booked 3 guided tours. I have no regrets about this, my guides were all excellent, really knew their subjects and added to the experience, but it wasn't necessary; around Sultanahmet most people spoke fluent English, and all were friendly and patient, so language wasn't a problem.Having visited the sites that I was curious about I am really looking forward to a longer trip to see more of Turkey once I have learnt a bit of the language
Historic plethora. Really enjoyed the proximity of so much history in the centre Incredible sights and flowers were lovely...everywhere

Half day cultural tour with cruise of Bospohorous Straits. Brilliant. Wished it had been longer! The weather was a bit chilly on the cruise, so come wrapped up if you are travelling in May. It was a good opportunity to see parts of Istanbul that we may not have seen, for example the palaces and wooden houses. A full day tour may have been better

History and Culture.. The museums and palaces are fascinating, beautiful and educational. The turkish people are kind and pleasant to visitors, which is not always the case where tourism is the main industry.

Byzantine and Ottoman Histroy. The history is amazing ; there were a lot of people. We arranged a tour and as well because we know what we were looking at; got bite sized pieces of history and timings for entry were perfect.
ancient and touristy. Very touristy. Tend to be a tourist trap at every corner. Beautiful but lost a lot of its magic. Defenitly a place to visit though

One of my favourite cities in the world!. This was my 3rd visit (with my husband) in Istanbul. We only had a few days this time, at the end of a trip. It is a vibrant, exciting city full of fabulous historic sites! It is a wonderful mixture of Orient and Europe...I love its warm, welcoming people, and great food! It is also pleasant to walk through the various neighbourhoods and even to take the tram or subway, and even the ferry to go to the Oriental side of Istanbul or to explore the Bosphorus!
Everyone should go to Istambul!. Everyone should go to Istambul! wonderful, interesting city! with her own culture,fantstic places colerful atmosphere)

Istanbul land of tourist harassment. Istanbul, love it or hate it there is not much in between. We have travelled extensively and have never been harassed by so many con artists. We finally just ignored anyone who tried to speak to us.I thought the sights were interesting, but the tourist harassment ruined it for me.I know these people exist in all tourist towns but their presence was much more noticeable here. We will not go back.

Welcome to the History of An Ancient City!. Sultanahmet Area is one of the nicest areas in Istanbul with ancient Hagia Sophia and relatively newer mosques like Blue Mosque, Suleymaniye, the palace - Topkapi Palace and museums. You also gotta visit Basilica Cistern. Enjoy meatballs in Selim Usta's restaurant. Welcome to Istanbul!

Best Guide in the World!. The fates were smiling on us the day we landed Sibel Erden as our guide for a 2 week tour of Biblical Turkey. Sibel has got to be the best guide ever, not only in terms of historical knowledge and her ability to relate it, but in her consistently thoughtful, accommodating and kind way of dealing with her customers. Due to a mistake on my part, my husband's arrival in Istanbul was delayed by 4 full days. I explained to Sibel that this was entirely my fault and we understood that we would simply have to begin our tour where it was scheduled to be upon his arrival. Sibel was adamant in coming to the hotel to see me and determine the best way forward- she worked with the tour company, Meander Tours, and managed to minimize my self-inflicted damage to a loss of 1 day. Unbelievable. She also was determined that my unexpected extra days in Istanbul while waiting for my husband were not wasted. I cannot say enough good things about her. We are already planning on specifically requesting Sibel, when we schedule our next trip to Turkey.

Muzecart is a must! . Getting a Muzecart was the best thing we could have done. Even if you're only stopping by for a few hours I would recommend buying one of these cards.It's 85TL for a card which gets you into about 10 different tourist sites, bypassing all the very long tedious queues.You save on entrance fees and even better save on time! You can buy these cards at most museums, but have cash as most places don't take cards.It's currently valid for 5 days (instead of the stipulated 3 days), I think because a lot of the sites are currently under construction. Definitely our best buy!

Very nice walk into history. As I was only here for one night on a cruise ship (a Sunday) and one night in a hotel before flying home, I didn't go into any of the paid sites, but got plenty of photographs of the architecture that abounded. There was plenty of shopping to be done. The really only annoyance was the many guys who were trying to sell me carpet. Like really? Nice carpet, but no thanks right now. So just be prepared for the salesmen walking the area.

Go on the Big Bus. We took the bus around the city. You can hop on and off wherever you want. It takes you to all the attractions on both sides of Istanbul. There are two routes, red and blue, it costs 10 European or 30 Turkish lire. The ticket is valid for 24 hours.
Old Town is a must-see. The Hagia Sophia is amazing and far better than any gothic structure in Europe. The Blue Mosque is stunning inside as are the rooms at the Topkapi Palace.
good but one time visit. its great to see the historic areas what istanbul have to offer. but i wont go again to istanbul thats my humble opinion

Old City. I was walking distance from the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, Sultanahmet Mosque and Hagai Sophia. Food was wonderful, people were extremely friendly and I felt just as safe as any other place I visited in Europe. I can't wait to go back.
two days in Istanbul. We liked the city and the lovely sites especially a trip on the Bosphorous in the evening. The Blue mosque and Topkapi place are well worth visit.

cistern and the dolabahce palace. Mosques and Topkapi palace great but don't miss the cistern (underground), the Bosphorus boat trip (1.5 hours) and my favourite: Dolabahce Palace which was amazing (purchase a ticket for whole palace area for 40 tl which is about £10)

Sultanahmet Highlights. This old Otoman historic part of Istanbul / Constantinople is a MUST for ALL first ( and more-) time visitors.In a relatively small area you can visit/walk the Top-sight of this fantastic Metropolis.Topkapi-palace/museum and Harem, Aya Sofia-museum ( former church and mosque ), the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazar, the Cisterns, the Hippodrome. If you want to extend your range just take the TRAM which is frequent, fast, moden and cheap. This way you easily get to the Old Oriënt train station( Cirkesi ) and the area around : Spice Bazar, Galata Bridge, Ferries.All this you can visit on your own but don(t overdo it and take 2-3 days .ENJOY !!
Perfectly maintained. All historical areas in Istanbul are perfectly restaured and maintained. They are conveniently located very close to,each other an easy to reach with public transport
Istanbul visit. I stayed in Istanbul for 5 days, which is enough to see the main attractions, however would reccomend about 7 days to include longer day trips to out skirts of Istanbul.

Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. Walked around a few historic areas which included the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. Both areas are huge and will take an hour each to walk through. Good to see all of the colorful scarves and fabrics in the Bazaar. The Spice Market was great as well. The aromas and colors awaken the senses. The selections are each were not what I expected, but visit anyway as they are Istanbul classics.

Historic Areas in Sulthanamet. We visited all the important historical sights in sulthanamet. It was very nice. I didn't enjoy topkapi palace a lot, because there were a lot of tourists. The grand bazaar was also a little overwhelming, but definitely a must see
blue mosc. excellent view and maintain, yes there are many tourist. one of best its my favorite.. taken good photographs
historic sites. This is an ancient city and there is so much to see. Get a guide book to ensure you see them all. I also suggest a Turkish bath which is an experience of a lifetime.
Some of the best in the world. So many to see. Make sure to plan ahead and group by locations and check things are open. Checkout museum pass too.

enjoy every minute. You will enjoy every minute of the historical İstanbul,tram stations,restaurants,shisha bars,little boutiques,ice cream,apple tea,Turkish tea,all these are mixed with the soul of the old city...I am in love with Istanbul I can say...

Let it work it's magic. How long is long enough in Istanbul ? If you let it & it's people work their magic you would stay forever. We arrived during the Tulip Festival. The national flower of Turkey. It is represented everywhere, in the carpets in the mosques, on the ceramic plates you might like to purchase, on stained glass windows. The access road into the city was a blaze of colour, the leaves on the trees were barely out but the flowers were gorgeous. We drove under the Roman Aqueduct and along by Roman walls into the heart of the old city to Sura Design Hotel. Perfect location for the walking tour of the old city. Typhoon Yalcin a well respected guide of over 20 years, with a degree in both ancient & modern history had us wishing we had learnt a lot more history at school !!. We began at the huge Eygptian Obelisk that Constantine shipped in to Constantinople, the then Eastern capital of the Roman Empire. The column was placed at one end of the Hippodrome where thousands of spectators would watch chariot races and events from the stands which we saw remains of in the newly upgraded museum off to one side of the Hippodrome. Hagia Sophia is quite outstanding. It is huge & spectacular, now a museum, after first being built as a Byzantine Cathedral & then the Ottoman Sultan converted it to an imperial mosque. One must absolutely see this while in Istanbul, but you need your guide. The Blue Mosque is beautiful with its wonderful blue tiles covering the walls, blue stained glass windows, blue painted ceilings & 6 minarets. It is a fully functioning mosque so take your head scarf & don't wear shorts. We then visited Topkapi Palace. You experience the opulence of the Ottoman Empire & the Sultans' way of life. Overlooking the Bosphorus, surrounded by lovely gardens. Make sure you see the huge Topkapi Emerald and the Topkapi dagger. The crowds are big so just pick out the must see bits. We then went to the Basilica Cistern the largest of many ancient cisterns beneath the streets of Istanbul.where the Romans gathered and stored water keeping it safe from possible sabotage.Typhoon help me out. Who was the marble goddess ?? Time for a break !! The next day we explored the Grand Bazaar, & the Spice Market, where merchants culminated after trekking the Silk Road to trade and do business. Getting lost is not a problem you will come out at some point with a stack of purchases, if your not careful. The Turkish Delight is fantastic. Also amazing is the Chora Church, the early Christian Frescos are just fantastic. The new mosque Suleymaniye was built to be bigger and better than the Blue Mosque. Is it ? Not so sure. Make sure you take the cruise on the Bosphorus. It makes you aware of how strategic the Marmaris Sea, the Bosphorus & the Black Sea are to the trade links through to Russia, the West and the East.We walked into Taksim Square the social and cultural hub, where the people of the city demonstrated against the building of another supermarket to replace their green space in 2013 There are very few green spaces in the inner city. One beautiful park is Camlica Hill. It was packed with young families the day we were there. Have a Turkish tea near the old teahouse.Along from Taksim Square we walked Istiklal Street. Am I right Typhoon?? 4 million people walk this street on a daily basis. It is so hard for us to comprehend when we have 4 million people in total in New Zealand. Our lunch was at the Karakoy Wharf Fish market. Wow the best fish. Dining at night.Try Ataturks favourite restaurant in Sisli and if you have not tried Raki then do, it is and acquired but great drink, just don't mix it with wine or to many beers. We had 4 days in Istanbul in total. We would have liked more.
it would be so great to enjoy all the culture in peace. however, the constant bother of salesmen anywhere and about anything and anytime is a real pest and distracts from all the historic brilliance

Great lesson in History. Recommendd for history lovers. It was the most amazing journey through history. Absolutely top class> 3 days were not enough for me. I need to get back there and this time for atleast a week. simply too much to see. Stunning place.
living museum. Istanbul is like walking through an ancient museum. Fantastic! The ancient cistern is fascinating. You can spend a day in the wonderful archeological museum.

They were interesting. It was a long journey to discover this wise city but i may say it was my favourite to see historical monuments which were protected very well in the old city. It was like a big town from middle ages!
Too much history.. The age, the history, the people, the diversity, it was one of the most dramatic small cities we have ever seen. Too much to do and see in 5 days.

Istanbul, the fountain of history. Thriving since 600 BC,it is now a modern city connecting Europe and Asia. In no other city the history is as livid as Istanbul; originally a Greek Colony to site of mighty Byzantine Empire giving way to the great Ottoman Dynasty and now major city of Turkish republic.Simply awed to see a 1500 BC obelisk at Hippodrome, transported from ancient Egypt. It was erected here by Byzantine emperor Constantinius I(337-361 AD). Close by is imposing Hagia Sophia. Not only structurally imposing, its history is equally mesmerizing- served as church for over 900 years and as mosque for nearly 500 years under Ottoman rule. Now a museum. Just at the opposite end is the mammoth Blue Mosque. Besides these , the city is replete with many other monuments,palaces depicting twists and turns of history the city witnessed.To cap it all the fun and frolic the city offers are class in itself - dinner cruise along Bosporus strait,accompanied by ethenic dances; diverse cuisines of city restaurants, stroll around Grand Bazaar and Spice markets are other unforgettable experience.

Sultanahmet Area. Everything in walking area - Blue Mosque, Hagia Sopia, Topkapi, Cisterns (don't miss)... Take some time, really look everywhere. Tell the carpet salespeople abounding in area politely "no thanks". Reserve a table at Mikla Restaurant for dinner - overlooks city and all of its splendor...a bit expensive - but the food is a memory in itself! SO GOOD! But, reservations A MUST - and a bit more than casual. Don't wear stupid shoes when touring.

Istanbul city. A beautiful 'had been' city. However our experience was marred by pickpockets. It was worse as the Istanbul police was unhelpful and unfriendly. During our adversity we felt let down. Advise to tourist to be extra careful.

I never get bored from Istanbul. I liked the taste of Turkish foods, Whether, views, shopping, islands.
I hated the Traffic, barbers, taxi drivers
Old city. The Old city is full of attractions and history the people are helpful and friendly .The Blue Mosque and Grand Bazzar , Spice Market etc are quite unique.

Cistern was amazing. We had been told by friends not to miss the Cisterns near Hagia Sofia. We found them easily, lines were not long, price about 8 euros=-. I really didn't know what to expect, but I was very pleased we saw them. The interior is softly lit to show the details. Walkways were good, but could be wet and slippery. It was a definite highlight of our visit to Istanbul.
Sultan Ahmet. Romantic, very well maintaned, clean, very old, the most beautifull Mosques, historical places, lovely nerow streets, lots of restaurants, hotels, cofee shops.
WOW!. Absolutely fabulous! Everything I imagined and more. I can't believe it's free to enter the Blue Mosque .... make sure you leave a donation as you leave...

Careful NOT to mention a certain previous Prime Minister (M.K.)- you could end up in BIG trouble!. There is the Tourist Area on the Airport side of the Golden Horn Bridge - and the locals on the other side. My Guide summed it up, "Apart from picking me up at the end of a tour - my wife never comes near the place!"The tourists inspect the 3 huge mosques, Topkapi Palace, the shopping arcades and the Kapalicarsi Grand Bazaar. The mosques you have to see, so to Topkapi. I found nothing much to buy at the bazaar - though there is heaps of 'stuff' - but plenty of gold - if you're into gold.The yellow taxis I found were very reasonable - and there were plenty of Galatasaray soccor shirts every where. Enjoy your very sweet, hot Apple Tea.Brian, from Perth. W.Australia.
Join queues early or late. Liked : Sultans tombs, Topkapi Palace Harem, Church of St Saviour at ChoraEnjoyed travelling on trams
very busy historic area. very impressive and mostly well presented. It is very important to get the museum card to skip the crowds.

Dip into the past & present simultaneously. It's an amazing experience to be among the international crowds, and dip into the past together with people from everywhere in the world. Take lots of time not only for the mosques and museums, but also for the markets and simply of walking the streets.

About as Good As it Gets. One of the world's must sees and I don't mean by lining up with thousands for a 5 minute visit. You need to soak in the sheer magnificence of the sights over a period of days. Have an early start ( pre cruise ship hordes) and view the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque in serenity. Evening post hordes also spectacular .

Grand Bazaar - Grand Fun & Excitement. If you are stopping over in Istanbul, you MUST - I repeat MUST - take time to visit the AMAZING Markets of The Grand Bazaar. SOOOOO MUCH FUN & EXCITEMENT & an absolute myriad of alleys & lane ways to keep you guessing as to where to go next. You may also need another suitcase handy for all the bargains & gifts that you will want to buy. A truly fun experience !! ENJOY !! Tony

Crowded, but oriental exotism mixed with older history than the Istanbul itself. For those who don’t know, Istanbul is a very eclectic city and a pure oriental megalopolis. One can see here a great modern architecture building, next to a very old historical building, or to an ancient wood American old house style, or a skyscraper there and just few meters faraway a poor family barrack next to it, all in a mixture of pure occidental cleanness in front of a 5* international brand hotel, followed by pure oriental dirt and bad smell on the same trotuary just few meters away.But this makes Istanbul so flavoring and special.Also, is good to know that when the ancestors of the nowadays Turkey, the Ottomans, who were nomads with roots on the Mongolian areal, came to the place where todays lays Istanbul, they found the byzantine civilization’s capital – the Constantinopole, or Constantinopolis – which was so beautiful and so well laid down on the Bosporus shore as they immediately put in mind to conquer it. And they siege it and later they conquer it, finally.All so many beautiful architecture pieces the Ottomans kept it and they just turn it into their own view of Muslim changes, as it happened for instance with the Hagia Sofia orthodox cathedral which was turned into a mosque and later, nowadays into a museum.Many old byzantine are so valuable for the Turkish tourism, but in fact it has nothing to do with their own culture or is not their merit. Like the Cistern, like the city walls and old towers, like the very old citadels and so on and so forth.It makes great sense to visit the old Istanbul including the Bazaar, including the Topkapi, the sultanate palace, which in fact is not that fancy, thinking that it was for the sultans of the Ottoman Empire, but at least the Topkapi treasury museum worth the ticket, in my opinion.The Bazaar, seen from the constructional perspective it’s pretty unique and the content makes it in fact quite attractive to see it, at least once in a life time.I advise not to choose a hotel in the old Istanbul. They are small, cheap and not good in what it means good in the rest of Europe. Better a good hotel in the new Istanbul and drive by taxi.I recommend a Bosporus boat trip too, and one can have the chance to see many of the historical places on the long shore just enjoying the boat trip under the famous bridges too.It worth to visit the Orthodox Ecumenical Church and residential palace too – they long as the Byzantine time too.

Amazing history, people and food. You need more than a day to visit all historic places, experience the good food, drink a tea and buy gifts in Grand Bazaar. It's a magic place were you see that everything that you read at history books really happened. The Turkish delight and other desserts are mandatory.Be prepared to negotiate prices. Turkish are master on sales.

Really worth to visit. My first time in Istanbul. This city is really "tourist friendly". I recommend to use the Istanbul card - one can be used for more persons, rechargable almost everywhere. Perfect connection with metro & tram from the Atatürk airport to the old city. Still somebody cleaning the streets. Perfect food everywhere.

exiting...marvelous ....interesting. I like mosques, sea, hotels, tea, restaurantsboats, clima, air, baked goods, turkish delightsdislike - public transport, crowd..............................................................
The vibe of Istanbul. Nothing to complain. We loved the vibrant atmosphere, the quite corners with his cafés, the loud and busy street live.
Well organized tourist area. Once in a lifetime sites to visit; most very close to each other. Be sure to purchase a museum pass. It saves lines at the ticket booth!

like a fairy tale 1001 nights. Despite the fact that Istanbul is a city of millions, the time can be stopped.Small streets, magnificent mosques, large parks, bazaars, street sales and the smell of good food gives the city a special charm. At every corner you can hear the knocking teaspoons, which is a true sign that in this culture drink a lot of tea. At night the city glows in different colors and the water faucet fit perfect. :)

Sultanahmet area. The best area for being able to walk to major attractions such as the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the cisterns, Topkapi, Grand Bazaar and public hammams. The tram and hop-on hop-off bus can also be taken from the square. Good shopping also at the Arasta Bazaar which is much calmer than the other bazzaars.

all in one area. Visit early to beat the crowds and cuesall sites including the palace blue mosque and cistern well worth a visit. Audio head sets are worth hiring and we also purchased books to give us more facts on these sites. Dont miss the royal jewels in the palace these were unbelievably stunning

perfect historical places. cleanlines and reality of them, good staff but they are a little expensive and you should have strong legs to walk very much :) furthermore they don't have a free leader to explain you about historical places and you have to pay more to get a mp3 player that explain every where of a historical place

Walking to many fantastic sites !. It's wonderful to be able to be within walking distance to so many fabulous historic sites and to enjoy beautiful scenery, delicious Turkish food, and the friendly Turkish people.
Haglia Sophia. Amazing place,such history.busy & popular,photographers paradise.being restored.make sure u visit all the areas even if they are crowded.
Interesting Culture. First time visited Istanbul, the culture and people is truly amazing and as a Asian, the young kids will be more interested in talking to you.

Amazing architecture. Amazing architecture with an amazing story behind each attraction. The attractions were within walking distance and Easily access to walking tours provides access to the areas history.

INSTANBUL NOT CONSTANTINOPLE. We loved Istanbul there are so many historical sights, from Mosques, Museums, Art Galleries...
we spent 4 nights in the Europe side and 3 nights on the Asia side, they were both quite different to one another..
Istanbul. Love the city, love the history, hotel owner helped with reservations for dinner. He also gave us a bus pass and a museum card good for three consecutive days for a fair price

Downtown Istanbul. Amazing history and architecture. So many things to see within a short walk. A museum pass really cuts the wait time and I recommend getting the audio tours so you learn about what you are seeing.
Something not to be missed. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, and Topkapi Palace are must sees. One shouldn't miss the Grand Bazaar or Istikal Street.
Mosques and Byzantine buildings. The structures were in great shape and the tour guides were very good at describing the time lines and repairs needed. The tile work is extraordinary.
istanbul history. agia sophia, basilica cistern, agia irini, archaeological museum, blue mosque, pera area, moni choras, greek orthodox patriarcheio

Wonderful Areas except for the Cruise Ships. Wow, 5000 people get off a boat and take over the town. Wish the ships were restricted. People think they're seeing Turkey in one day, and push their way into lines everywhere.
Iconic. What mare can be said - this is the main reason why Istanbul is so popular. Most of the sites are within easy walking distance.

As expected. We had been wondering Istanbul, especially the Old City for a long time. It was extremely fantastic as expected! The mystic atmosphere of the mixed cultures of Ottoman, Bizantium and others were really attractive.

Great History. So much to see and do. Walk into Sultanahmet Square and look around, The Blue Mosque, Agia Sophia, Topkapi....... the list is endless. Just pick one and go, don't hesitate or else the queues can become very long, although they are well managed.

Fantastic experience!. Too many to mention but base yourself in Sultanahmet area, buy an Istanbul Kart (trams, ferries, funicular etc) which is a public transport credit card that you charge up as required. Its works out a half price on all your journeys and you can travel the full length of a tram line for about 50p, same on ferries. Avoid buses as they get stuck in the incredible traffic!Get lost in the backstreets and alleys around the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar for the true experience. Both the Bazaars are worth a visit but a priced for tourists (particularly the Grand) whereas the shops on the streets and alleys are where locals go to do their shopping.It is hard to say go here , go there because the whole place is just a fantastic experience jus go, wander and soak it all up.

If you love history, this is your place. So much history to be experienced first hand. I highly suggest hiring a private guide to navigate you through this area. They have priority admittance and know which places get the busiest first, so go there first. It is very tiring walking and having the shop owners and restaurants constantly in your face inviting you in. You are told to ignore them which is very difficult. Even a "no thank you" eggs them on.

Camii, miscit, Topkapi Museum, Miniaturk, Taksim Square, Bosphorus, HigiaSophia Museum etc. I liked what I saw and where I stayed. Nothing disliked as Turkey is my own. Its Great Bazar and Spicy Bazar are excellent. Sulemnia Camii is wonderful and must see place.
You should visit the Hipodrome. The Hipodrome area has 2 obelisks that can be missed by pedestrians walking to/from the Blue Mosque. It is worthwhile stopping to examine both obelisks.

5 day trip to Istanbul. Absolutely mind blowing city, whether you are interested in architecture or history or not.
Istanbul has something for everyone and I would recommend 100%

Princess Islands. From Kabatas you can take the ferry boat to Buyukada, which is the biggest one of the the Princess Islands. The trip takes one hour for a low cost 6TL and enjoy an amazing place in Istanbul walking around in its old streets and small houses.

The famous bazaar...again. Bazaars are wonderful to begin with and this one is beyond describing. A maze of little shops, a place to lose oneself in and dream of times past. Some shops better than others, one very old cafe with the most unbelievable turkish coffee, colors, smells tastes, polite shop owners willing to chit chat or offer you a stool to sit on. Next time I am in Istanbul I will definitely go there again. Do pay it a visit. You won`t regret it.
Museum pass. Get the pass; it is worth the money. Touts were friendly. Many cafes did not sell beer. Check first! Be prepared to walk and walk and walk.

A Walker's Paradise. Istanbul is a city where you can walk all day for a couple of months and not get bored because there is so much to see and absorb. It's history, the food, the mosques, museums and art galleries. The Historic Peninsula itself is highly recommended for every traveler offering so many places to see in depth. The Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, tombs, Topkapi Palcace and gardens itself take two whole days. I loved how they have preserved so many interesting things in the Palace. There is nothing to dislike about the place where Europe meets with Asia.Plan and trip and go there. Put on your walking shoes and let it capture you.

Impressive and on a grand scale. We walked the old areas a few times, especially near the Blue Mosque.There are a large amount of both local and international tourists around and the line management of the sites is excellent.For the sites that charge there is a way to avoid them queues with local guides charging 5 tl to do act as a guide and you skip the line.Get lost in Istanbul and don't have a care

Sultan Ahmet Mosque (Blue Mosque). Considering how old it is, it is quite well preserved and looks stunning. Dress code is enforced, you will need to be covered, they do provide scarfs at the entrance. Once inside will take you 10-15 tops to take photos and absorb the atmosphere. Worth visiting the area at night to take some nighttime snaps. This is adjacent to the Hagia Sophia.
Amazing!. Nice places, do not accept the first price.Try the local restaurants, maybe not kebab but curry. Besides that, the expresso Lavazza in Galata Tower is the best.

Vibrant atmosphere. A must visit in Istanbul, as it is the most interesting part of the sightseeing tours with it's rich historical background. It is very much crowded but interesting. One can understand more of the culture and religion of Turkey when touring these places.

Great City for History. The whole city is truly stunning and has such a range of historical place to visit. You have to see the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapı Palace. All 3 are stunning and worth seeing if you go to Istanbul.

This is why I came to Istanbul. Sultanhamet Square was an amazing experience. The major tourist and historical sites are within walking distance. Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Grand and Spice Bazaars all in a somewhat compact area. The day I spent there I was accompanied by what seemed like a million other tourists as there were 3 large cruise ships in port, but somehow this added to the frenetic fun of just being there. I felt totally safe even though you might find yourself fending off a vendor of some sort. I only wish I had several days to spend in this area.
Great Place. One of my favourite places in the world, always recommended to others. The historic areas of Istanbul are outstanding.

Great vacation in Istanbul. The Turkish people are very friendly and accommodating, great service at our hotel, the Best Western Home Suites & Spa. The historical sites are beautiful and awe inspiring. Love the outdoor cafes/restaurants, but the people smoking next to our table really bothered us.

Easy to go from one location to another. We found the public transport system easy to use and was very efficient. Wherever we went people were always friendly and helpful. The parks and gardens were beautiful as the tulips were in full flower. Crowd control was good when visiting the historic buildings. Three days was not nearly enough to see all the sights. Istanbul is such a beautiful and interesting city.

Great historic places. We enjoyed walking around in Sultanahmet area. Most of the attractions are close to each other. Don't miss to visit Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi palace, the Sarnici, the Hippodrome. Some attractions are free and some require a fee to enter. Also close by you can visit famous Spice market and Grand bazaar. I will also reccommend full day boat tour so you can see Istanbul from the water. There are many companies, ask in your hotel. They pick you up from the hotel and drive back at the end.
Living history. Stay central and walk everywhere. Do not do open top bus tour waste of time! Hire a local guide for the day then your set for thje week to visit the best places.

TREASURE TROVE OF HISTORY AND CULTURE. From the Hop On Hop Off Bus that we used to acclimate ourselves to the layout of Istanbul, to the sites we visited while there, one cannot express how vital these sites are to the history and culture of this window to the world in it's day! All the main sites are a must on your bucket list: Hagia Sophia, Topkaki Palace, Blue Mosque, the Bazzar,etc. but take the time to ride the tram that goes through the other areas of the city. Walk around Sultanahmet Square in the evening when the lights are on and experience the wonder of these sites with their beautiful architecture lit up to take your breath away. Experience a little store that is in a neighborhood right under a townhouse where it is so small you can't turn around but the proprietor is just so friendly and helpful (I had symptoms of bronchitis and it was a holiday where everything was closed; this little store was open and the owner gave me cinnamon in a bag to put in my tea to relieve symptoms and would not charge me! It was a lifesaver!!! The side streets held beautiful pashminas that were fairly priced and became treasures. The restaurants on the side streets were frequented by the natives and we LOVED the intimacy of the setting and friendliness of the patrons and wait staff. It all created lasting memories for a lifetime!!
Bosporus boat tour. A must-do event in Istanbul. The hotel books the tour and you get picked up and dropped off at the hotel. The 4 hour tour includes a visit to a city view-pont.

The old part of Istanbuls is packed with history. I loved to be able to walk between so many of the great historic monuments and not waste time on busses and trains. even waking alone as a woman, I did not feel unsafe at any time.

Old town Istanbul. Did a 1 day personal guided tour, best way to see the historic area around the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque etc. With a personal guide by passed the queues (and on cruise ship days they can be long).The area was excellent, so much history and having a guide to explain the detail really made the visit worthwhile.

Old city tour. Istanbul one of the best city as a tourist destination one of the best attractions is a walk around the old city where you can see and smell the history from shopping antique ,soviner local food ice cream just the best for all families members

Dolmabahce Palace. The line ups were long ( 2hrs to get into the place, then it was at least another 45 minute wait to be able to tour with and English guide in each of the sections of the palace!) However, once inside the palace you were awestruck by it's opulence!! one of the guides we had said the Sultan died of cirrhosis of the lung ( I had to correct whimper the benefit of the other people there) I would have appreciated having a headset and go at my own pace however maybe that would have decreased the number of visitors to the site.

Grand bazaar. A real shoppers paradise...wonderful displays of beautiful goods...gold and jewellry...beautiful leather goods, pearl backgammon sets...lanterns..turkish delight..spices..towells..luxury linnens..everything to nurture the shoppers soul...and more..a truly great experience...all under one roof formerly home to the ottaman army's horses....MAGNIFICENT WAY TO SPEND A DAY...OR A WEEK!!!!

Get an Istanbulkart and avoid the queues. We stayed for a week in Sultanahmet in the delightful Turkoman Hotel, one of the numerous old hotels in that area. We wanted to see the Hippodrome, the Blue Mosque, the Sarnici (cistern), the Topkapi Palace and the wonderful Aya Sofya Byzantine church/mosque, now a museum. We quickly saw that half the world wanted to be there too. Masses of coaches jammed the streets daily from early morning. Swarms of tourists in convoys meant seriously long queues to get in anywhere. Once in, you had keep your wits about you dodging the cameras waving in the air at the end of selfie sticks - the most annoying must-have accessory of the season. But if you don't want to spend your holiday standing for hours in queues, buy an Istanbulkart (excellent value with easy topping up at touch screen machines or kiosks) and take a tram or a bus or a ferry to the outskirts. There the crowds will be fewer, the restaurants cheaper and the air in cleaner. The 38 bus from central Eminonu will take you to the Kariye Museum in Chora where you can see the most magnificent frescos and mosaics, superbly preserved. Or take the 99a bus to Balat and wend your way uphill to the museum through narrow, cobbled streets lined with prettily painted wooden houses. Stay on the 99a bus to the Pierre Lotte cafe and take a ride on the new cable car, only 2.15TL (about 50p) with the Istanbulkart. From the top you'll have a breathtaking view of the city and the Golden Horn. Away from the multi-national tourists and their selfie-sticks, you'll be charmed by the real locals. And you wont be hassled to buy a carpet!
Spectacular city with wonderful historical sites. We have visited Istanbul several times and have used TSC travel to book a range of specialty tours coveting the jet sites
fabulaous. all the areas visited was fantastic clean and well kept a bit busy but our local guide had all our entry tickets ready so ya no ques excellent so much history

Great. Just walking around the historic areas is worth the time and often better than going into some of the attractions and there is great atmosphere and interesting architecture everywhere. make sure you have a good map and walking shoes.

Loving the History of Istanbul. We loved walking around the major sights of historic Istanbul. There so much to see even if you don't want to pay to get in anywhere. The Spice Market, the Grand Bazaar, the Blue Mosque can all be walked and cost nothing to enter. We went on Friday which was really fun as it is their holy day so there is loads to atmosphere. Calls to prayer from speakers on all the mosques is amazing and watching people come and wash themselves before praying while there is snow on the ground (we were there in February) was incredible.
In walking distance. Most sites of historical and religious interest were within a compact area. You could visit more than one in a day. However, get there early due to long queues.....
Perfect spot. Two minute walk to blue mosque, clean and comfortable hotel. Very friendly and accommodating staff. Taxis are readily available to get to other areas of interest rate n the city.
Wonderful. It wonderful to see the mosques.The ruins of the empire the river was awesome crooks the bay u in eurpoe and again cross u are in asia
Great historic sites . There are many things to visit if you are looking for sightseeing. But if you can't walk much or you prefer to relax, it may make you feel tired 😴

Ruins Everywhere. Istanbul is wonderful, history on every corner, magical I would truly love to live here, there are lots of restaurants & amazing cake shops, there was one near the Ayia Sophia the pastries & desserts could not be equaled in the best pastry shops of Europe, Loved the buzz of the area the food, people everything.
beautiful. Actually I liked everything. highlights: the blue mosque and the harem inside the topkapi, the grand bazar was nice too, but the stores looked the same

A wonderful experience. This was my first trip to Istanbul and I loved it. We toured all of the old city. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cisterns, New Mosque, Suliyamaniye Mosque, Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar, Carshambe Market, Carpet Museum, Topkapi Palace. The weather in April was great (not hotter than 70 most days). We walked almost everywhere (10+ miles/day). We stayed in a little apartment in the Fener Balat area that was in itself an historical area (former Jewish/Greek/Armenian neighborhood) and we went to one of the oldest baths in Istanbul there (not a luxury bath but quite and experience). The food from all the street stands and little restaurants was fantastic. I'm not sure I'd want to go in summer since you have to be somewhat covered up most of the time (especially females) and that could get hot but for our weather it was fine.

Everything worth seeing within a 15 minute walk. Istanbul may span two continents but all the great attractions are within a 15 walk from Sultanhamet where we stayed. The furthest walk was to the Grand Bazaar. The city is amazing to just walk around and shop (everything is negotiable) however the locals can be very annoying trying to get your patronage to the point of invading your personal space.

Glorious history. wonderful to see this fascinating area which ruled a large area and brought ?Christianity to a wide area of the world. And the changes by Attaturk that was so tolerant of all people.
history to be seen. all centuries old monuments and the history assosiated with it. disliked the crowd management. there are lots of travellers .
Must see. Every corner has a different story, a different smell of culture, leave enough time to breathe them completely... Try extraordinary food at one of the traditional and historical places...
Lovely city!. To many tourists, but it's is a great place to be a tourist. The bus, car drivers are trying to hit you with their vehicles.
East Rome. City,Culture,History .if the world were a single country,Istanbul would be its capital.(Napoleon Bonaparte)
Wonderful city. I am sure it has all been said before but for the record wonderful city great people and real tradition. East meets west and does it really spectacularly

History everywhere u look. Istanbul s treasures did not disappoint. Everywhere you walk in the old city there is a relic or architectural phenomenon from another time ; Egyptian . Greek. Roman. Early christian, ottoman and the colour and culture everywhere is mind blowing. The beggars and the persistent rug sellers are a bit annoying but one learns to keep walking. We managed to find a ferry with an English commentary from the Asian side of the Maramas sea for 12 lire to the Bosporus one night at six pm. much cheaper than the more posh ferries. But then we discovered there is also a ferry for the same price that leaves from the area in front of the spice market on the golden horn seafront. But it was fun to ferry with the locals to the Asian side . Avoid using the toilet on the ferry though. Not a great experience . I loved the city and will definitely go back to see what I missed. The harem at the Topkapi palace is a must see. Amazing

Full of magnificent places. if you are trying to find out more about ottoman kingdom, you can find great palaces, mosques, Bazaar and many great places in European part of Istanbul. in my mind, you could find everything in European Part and I'm sure you would like it.
smell history. walking the narrow streets, seeing the old building, smelling the history, feeling the soul of people lived there 100s of years ago with so much to do..I love this city

We visited the Blue Mosque, the Underground Cistern, Hipodrome, Hagia Sofia and the old city. We did not like the long waiting lines with people pushing in on our line. There was no order for the "waiting line" but in the end us Australians (our group) did not take it any more and asked the rude people to wait in line as we did for an hour.Our Guide was incredible and he was a book of knowledge. April was a very busy time. We loved and learned more about Turkey as every day went on.

Istanbul is the most fascinating and unique city that I have every visited.. My husband & I were in Istanbul for two days, but I could have stayed for a week as there was so much more to see. We did visit the Hagia Sophia Museum, the Sultanamet District, the Spice Market, Topkapi Palace & the Blue Mosque. My husband & I decided to splurge on a Turkish Bath as we had been traveling for nearly 3 weeks, and we were tired. The Turkish bath rejuvenated our weary bodies.

Istanbul in a Day. We had a wonderful private day tour arranged for us with Luxury Istanbul Tours. They had great communication and our guide Mr. Hakan was the perfect guide for our family. Very low key but kept us on track so that we saw everything we wanted to in one day! Highly recommend this. No transportation is required you can get around by walking from one attraction to the next.

Best location to explore Istanbul. There are so many touristic areas & thousands of hotels in Istanbul. If this is your first time there, then Sultanahmet is the perfect place to be. Everything is within walking distance; Sultanahmet Mosque, Hagia Sofya, Sulimanyah Mosque, Spice & Egyptian bazars, food & shopping. Everything is within walking distance. You can also explore the rest of Istanbul by Metro or Tram. Wear a very comfortable shoes.
Tulip time a perfect month to visit!. A lovely area to stroll--don't forget to stop in the gardens since they are wonderful. Everything is clean, easy to get around and the food is spectacular!

History touches you!. Istanbul is a fantastic city! You must visit the old town with the blue mosque and the Hagia Sofia Mosque. HSM is a museum nowadays and if you are observant you will find a pilar that has a hole in which you shall put a finger. If it gets wet your eyes will see everything clear and all diseases in your eyes will go away. Not far from the mosques is the grand bazaar situated. Don´t miss it! You can go inside for a week and not visit every shop! Do not forget to bargain! If they say 100 USD you say 10 and then start screaming to each other. You will get the piece for 15 USD mostly......Walk down the hill to Galata bridge. Under it are hang lots of restaurants. Point out the lobster you want and wait. WoW!

History In Istanbul. I like how busy and full of life the historic areas in Istanbul are. These places are full of history and endless stories. I believe that it is better to take a tour so that you can learn every detail about the historic areas. Also the food near these places are great!!

a city that plays in the big leagues. i loved the ambience in Sultanahmet. The smells, sights and sounds of Istanbul are unique. Excellent food. Magnificent views. Layers upon layers of history. Efficient transport system. Historical sites, art, crafts just amazing. Istanbul archeological museum a must. And most of all that sensation of being in two continents.

You are in Istanbul so do it all. The must do visits are the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace; wander through the grand Bazaar, do visit the Cistern - it really is amazing. Everywhere you go exudes history. One of the very best things at 90 Turkish pounds is the big bus tour. The ticket lasts for 24 hours and you can drop off and get on at any of the stops.

Historical Istanbul & Turkey. I live in a country that was only founded in the 18th century and in Turkey I explored sites from BC to early AD and you can only stand in awe at what you are seeing. Glad we did this tour of Turkey - our very first overseas experience for my wife and I - which was all because I was fortunate enough to be selected to attend Gallipoli 2015.

Hostoric areas. It includes structions such as the Sarayburnu where the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Hagia Irene, Zeyrek Mosque, Süleymaniye Mosque, Little Hagia Sophia and Walls of Constantinople.

Romans, Otomans and XXI Century together. I liked the preservations of all monuments, the cleaneness of the whole City. Friendliness of people all around.Do not liked the lines to monuments, and the fact that they dont accept credit cards to pay the tickets. very unconfortable if you are a group of five people as we were.

Visit to Key Tourism Sights in Istanbul. If you don't have the time and want to see the major tourism sites in Istanbul, you can do it in two days, however, you will be tired, and you will have missed many, many sites of this amazing city. Although I am staying for several days, I decided today to visit the major tourism destinations in Istanbul on foot: the Sultan Ahmed Mosque (the Blue Mosque), the Hagia Sophia Museum, the Basilica Cistern, and the Topkapi Palace Museum. After reviewing my day, I would have to conclude that although these sites are all within walking distances from each other, seeing all of them in one day was a bit much. In hindsight, the visits through the Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern where relatively short, and I realized that I should have done more research on the Blue Mosque (there is very little interpretation on this magnificent building), and gave myself more time at the Topkapi Palace Museum.
Spiritual. Tour guides are very friendly and speak different languages Transport is very clean the food is is great and all ways freshly mead

Topkapi palaca/Aya Sophia/Blue mosque. Impressing to see the style of the buildings and all the richness of the old days. You have to start early in the morning the avoid most of the crowd. Start with Topkapi palace because it takes more than 4 hours if you will see it all. The other two buildings can be done in less than an hour each.

lovely turkish architecture. we really liked the traditional turkish architecture at sultan ahmet and the hagia sophia with its blue iznik tiles, minarets etc. the blooming tulips added to the atmosphere.
area was quite crowded though

Sultanahmet - The place to stay and walk in Istanbul. If you are interested in History and would not mind a bit of walking, choose March and choose Sultanahmet as your place of stay. Nothing to beat that location which is the closest to virtually every single important monument in Istanbul. Well connected and March is wonderful weather too!

Hippodrome -- Off to the Races. Sultanahmet Park and the Hippodrome lie between Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern. Yes, it is not much to look at but this is a clear case of why you need to learn more to appreciate the significance of what you are seeing. How is the Serpent Tripod related to the Temple of Apollo at Delphi, Greece? The Hippodrome was a 100,000 seat venue for chariot races. BTW, the actual race course is many meters below the current pavement. In fact, where else could a riot have led to 30,000 killed and half of Constantinople burned down? How are the so-called Nika Riots related to Nike, the Goddess of Victory? And now, more significantly to us tourists, how did this lead to the building of Haghia Sophia? terraencounters.blogspot.com

Amazing a must do in your life time.. An amazing stunning place so much to see. Arrived by cruise ship. Got the "Big Red Bus" hop on and off, well worth the money. Took you to all the sites and you do two continents Asia and Europe. The Blue Mosque really stunning and free to get into, Haghia Sophia was stunning and a museum. The grand Bazaar amazing building and buzzing with shops and colour. People were friendly, food was really good and great value.We only really touched the tip of an iceberg two days here would of been great as there are many more things to see.
awesomeness. everything is close and there is so much history everywhere you turn...has easy and inexpensive metro
nice. ull of fascinating museums and places of interest, don't miss the underground cistern! Busy places are best seen early in the morning. There are lots of good restaurants and cafes

Greatest Imperial City, with Rome. The profusion of important sites...in a concentrated area...the only negative is the crush of tourists...it was not this way even five years ago...now it is on the "to do list"...good for the world, not so good for travelers as myself...

You need a week!. So much to see and do! Far more than I expected and the area seems safe and very clean. Topic Palace, Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque are of course must sees but access to other things is easy
Beautiful city. Loved everything- most popular sites are walking distance- buy the Tourist Muze card & save on wait times & admission prices.

Taken as a whole. The idea of reviewing the 'Historic Areas of Istanbul' is a bit of a tall order! In fact it is somewhat meaningless.Firstly there are three places basically every tourist is going to want to see and all three would rate five stars in their own right: The Blue Mosque, The Aya Sofia and the Topkapi Palace. Now they are all in very close proximity. The second tier of places to visit would probably comprise the Turkish & Islamic Museum, the Basilica Cistern and the Archaeological Museums. Probably with a stroll through Gulhane Park as an addenda to the latter. And you'd check out the Hippodrome as part of your walking about doing that lot.Third tier stuff might include checking out a nearby bazaar or even the Museum of Science & Technology in Islam which is at Gulhane Park.And that's before you strolled over (or walked to) the Grand Bazaar, thence to the Spice Bazaar and then on to New Mosque and the Eminono area. And if you have the energy for one more big ticket item head up to Suleymaniye Mosque (spelling?).All up without even crossing over the Galata Bridge and to the tower of the same name in the Golden Horn area you could easily spend three days checking out the 'Historic Areas of Istanbul' and that's before you head farther afield to the Chora Church or the Walls of Constantinople.Look.... seriously just go there. Before you shuffle off this mortal coil just go there.
Dan Brown's Inferno. For fun, read Dan Brown's Inferno before visiting the historic sites in Sultanamet, particularly before seeing Haghia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern. Trust me.

Blue mosque. I was impressed by the grandeur and beauty of the place.
The mosque was very impressive and reminds of the glory of Muslim past
Lovely City. Well worth a visit. Plenty of magical places to see and visit. Not expensive. Do try stop for Turkish tea.
Beautiful place. In Istanbul lots of historical places to see but very busy place to go. Must go to hagya Sophia,blue Mosque.

Complex history. Coming from the new world the history in the city and country is amazing, complex and fascinating. And very very long! Exploring the sultanamet area provides a great place to start, especially for those new to Turkish history like me. The ottoman era is obviously more accessible than the Byzantine, if the older era interests you don't miss the Mosaic museum (really, even our non-history travellers loved it). I want to go back some day and explore more....
Culture. This city is very young and full of life and wonderful culture with a modern vibrancy in ancient surrounds. Really where the middle east meets the west.

Amazing Istanbul. Fantastic City so much history. My favourite place was the Topkapi Palace the mosaics and tiles were amazing. Beautiful gardens so worth walking through. Spice markets so much easier to walk through than the Grand Bazaar.A lot of beautiful shops here. I am someone who loves Bazaars but this one drove me crazy. Just amazing. This is a place like no other. East meats west. Tradition clashes with modernity. Europe touches Asia. Islam and Christianity make for a unique blend.

The Blue Mosque is right across the Hagia Sophia, which is just behind the Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome and the Topkapi Place. One can have a fabulous view of the Bosphorus Sea from the Palace. Arasta Bazaar is just beside the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar is walkable too. There is Aya Sofya Hamami right next to Hagia Sophia. Beautiful mosques. I loved the historical sights and the history surrounding it. A must see is the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia and the Basilica Cistern.

Istanbul experience. Very foreign ,may sound strange but unlike many European countries that have that sameness about them Istanbul is different. If I had to find a dislike it would be the queues to all the major attractions.
Saw Heaps. Such a colourful city filled with friendly people. Great to wander around in May, perfect weather. Make sure dinner KumKapi and somewhere overlooking the Botherous

So much to see and do. The Grand Bazaar. You must go! It was one of the best experiences of our trip. For the most part, the merchants were friendly and helpful. I didn't feel like they were trying to take advantage of us at all. They were so very helpful when we were buying items to take home with advice on packing and durability. Every shop offered to bubble wrap or secure the items we bought. It is an overwhelming, sensory overload experience not to be missed.

Enjoy Othman's history. A lot to see in Istanbul one of the busiest city in Mediterranean like bazaars , history , food , shopping , Turkish bath & spa , also recommended for people who enjoy groups sightseeing.
Fascinating. Need to read up on history to appreciate this and get a good guide. Do not miss the cisterns -- amazing
great place to visit. it is a great place to visit, with lots of things to see. I didn't like that is was so crowded, so many people everywhere. It was like an ant's nest.

Travel back into time with Istanbul. Turkey is one fascinating country. We walked all around the Historic area in Istanbul with ease. I had been to Istanbul in 1973. It was a little scary for 22 year old. I thought is was unique then, but a little scary. I wanted my husband to visit the city. So we returning to the city in 2014. Our hotel was in the Historic area. This made it possible for us to traveled around by ourselves with out worries. We were careful with our purses and purchased items. The ability to wonder and enjoy the culture and friendliness of our hotel was wonderful. The city is very populated on both continents. Where we were, it did not feel crowded.

Istanbul. Istanbul in 1974 - we used Europe on $5 a day as a guide. Showed the book to a young boy and asked where hotel was. He took the book and ran away. I followed him and he had run to our hotel.We loved the Bosphorous River and took a cruise on it.

Excellent concentration of sites. There are a number of must see places. Tokpali Palace, Basilica Cistern, the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya. All great sites. The restaurants in the district are average. Great way to see the historic areas of Istanbul. We went on a sightseeing tour provided by our travel group. Visited the Blue Mosque, Topaki Palace, Hippodrome to name some. Very interesting way to learn the history of the city from our tour guide.Be prepared for crowds.
Best. very beautiful. i was very happy to see this monuments in Istanbul. i enjoyed it very much. i think i will come here again

So Much to See!. The historic areas of Istanbul offer so much to see and experience. You can spend a couple days just walking around and absorbing the atmosphere amongst the Blue Mosque & Hagia Sophia near Sultanahmet Square or visiting the bazaars. You've also got Taskim Square, Gatla Bridge (and Tower), various museums and palaces. Well worth a few days stay!

Glowing & Cautionary Words. Istanbul has many varied and wonderful sites to visit. Signage for most sites are friendly to the few major foreign languages. Be prepared for narrow streets, busy thoroughfares, uneven footpaths/roads and very little lights for traffic control. We familiarised ourselves with the public transport system (trains, trams, ferries) and we used these to get between points. Place names are in Turkish and not Arabic, so they are easy to read and say (with a little practice). There is a travel card requiring up front payment which covers all public transport and can be used for 2 people (our hotel had one immediately available).. Most trips are 2TL but if you pay at the turnstile it will cost you 4 TL. So there is an immediate 50% saving there for each trip.. There is a hop on and hop off bus service but when roads become congested (noon to 3pm, or soccer events) travelling time can blow out significantly.Like most Cities, Istanbul has those who like to take advantage of the tourist. Briefly these are - taxi drivers taking longer routes to destinations ( take a GPS map and track your route)......local tap water isn't safe but don't buy bottled water from roadside sellers..... buy a museum pass, this will get you into a number of major sites without queuing (our hotel had them available)........always be prepared to negotiate a purchase from about 50% of starting price....there are beggars who'll follow you everywhere if you give anything...... don't be conned into a picture with dressed up locals who say there is a fee once the photo is take........ for major attractions get an entry ticket the day before and go at least 30 minutes before opening time.
fascinating and crazy!. just wonderful wandering in this area, with amazing architecture and bustling surroundings. you can lose yourself for hours exploring and browsing.

Grand bazaar, Topkapi palace, blue mosque, new mosque Haga soph. All amazing things to visit, be prepared for crowds +++bring 1 lire coins you have to pay to use most WC.Drink lots of water, DO NOT use taxis they will rip you off the public transport is excellent and gets you places much easier and cheaper than cabs! You can get a card and load it up to travel on it or just buy tokens 2 lire each need three generally to get a reps town. People very helpful

Great guided tour by Shorebee/Curio. As we did not want to take the expensive excursions that the cruise ship offered, we booked a private guided tour through Shorebee.com. They gave us a guide from CurioTravel. She spoke very good English, and she was helpful and friendly. We avoided the queues at the Agia Sofia, as she had already purchased tickets. We only had limited time (around 5 hours), but we were offered a view of the Blue Mosk, Agia Sofia and the Bazaar, plu some more. I would recommend Shorebee and Curio if you plan a short visit to Istanbul.

Istanbul: ground 0 for ancient ruins. There is soooo much history in and around Istanbul. You could spend an entire week there seeing what it has to offer and still not finish. The Palace, hague sophia, basillica cistern, and museums were all stand outs. Amazing place.

Excellent experience - worth getting the museum card. If I ever returned, I would definitely purchase this card for a little extra money to avoid the 30-45 minute queues in the blistering heat.Overall though, these landmarks are a must within this beautiful city.
Historic insights. The sights offer wonderful insight of historic and cultural development. It helps to understand ancient history and appreciate mosaic, architecture and history even better.

Rich with History. Istanbul is not just part of the title of an annoying song (Istanbul - not Constantinople). The architecture and views along the Bosporus are breathtaking and well worth adding to your travel-bucket list.
Amazing. Istanbul is lovely - the mosques, bazaars, people, the back streets, cafes, restaurants. Just about everything. Go and experience it!

Cool. Impessive architecture, but a lot of walking required )) The weather was nice and sunny and warm, a lot of flowers everywhere

a new perspective. The whole atmosphere of this place is amazing. I spent a lot of time walking on the streets in Old Fatih and it was a worthwhile effort. There are so many mosques and old buildings spread everywhere that it feels like an open air museum!
Wonderful. Make sure and take a full day to walk around the old town of Istanbul including both bazaars. Wonderful people, food, and history

Must see if interested in ancient history and culture. Everything ... brilliant example of the historical takeovers/conquests of this city.
The Blue Mosque is magnificent.

a good place. reallly recommended to see this fantastic city's historical background. Because it had been the center of civiliation from all over the world and has heritage of all mankind

This area is easily seen on foot.. The area is full of fascinating museums and places of interest, don't miss the underground cistern! Busy places are best seen early in the morning. There are lots of good restaurants and cafes. The whole area is full of flower beds, trees and greenery. We last visited in 1995 and the change is amazing. There is so much to see that I guess most people just go to the main places, Topkapi, Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque being the principle ones. But the Archealogical Museums , including the Tile Kiosk are wonderfull and worth a whole day to themselves. There are smaller museums like the Mosaics in the Bazaar near the Blue Mosque.
