Last year we went to Turkey for wacation and this year we are going there again.Many things to see and you never have enought time for that.Like: easy going peopleDislike: some of restaurant behing Blue Mosque offers dishes not involved in menue and exactly that dishes are expensive by many times and makes your small lunch expense for more than 100 USD.ALL TIME CHECK MENUE and if they will bring something always ask is that what you have ordered?
Love Istanbul!. Other than the horrible salesmen that virtually attack you on the street every five feet, every other aspect of Istanbul was fabulous!
Beautiful. Galata is a beautiful area and the old town as well' b oth very lively you will enjoy them at their best on foot!
Make an early start. Historic sites are reasonably priced. However, make an early start to visiting sites as there can be a good waiting time to enter some sites.

PUBLIC TRANSPORT. TIP: I used public transport a lot in Instanbul. Do your self a favour buy an Istanbulkart (Metro Card) the trips are cheaper (you can buy and top up at any ferry, tram or train station - look for the machines with the yellow screens (make sure to buy the top up card, the BOTTOM most selection - the other card (upper most choice) can't be topped up and you'll go through it very quickly.))This is how the locals pay to travel and as only tourist will pay the high price for a single travel token. The token machine are ALWAYS surrounded by gypsies and beggers wanting money making traveling on public transport relatively expensive and inconvenient without a metro card.You don't need to buy multiple cards either, if your travelling in a group you can just pass the card back over the turnstiles to your travelling companion(s) and the card can be swipped again for the next person.These cards can also be used to access council owned toilets (WC) all toilet access is charged at 1 TRY and This card was quite handy when I didn't have change.

Istanbul is beautiful. I liked the roads they are clean and well maintained.one thing about Istanbul you get a strong Tobacco smell in many places.I am not sure whether smoking in Public is disallowed but I could see many smokers on the road.People are very friendly and nice.
Awesome days at a great city. We liked everything: the historic sights, the situation at the Bosphorus, the atmosphere, the cleanliness, the people, the food ...

A bucket list to see area!. Timing is all! April is a good month - pre main cruise season. Also the city is a mass of tulips & surprisingly green. A personal guide if, as we were, a group of friends was invaluable for beating the ticket queues & learning to work backwards through the sights! ie go thro the Topkapi Palace to far end & Treasury first. Beware larger group tours usually end with the 'shopping opportunity' - although not intimidating or hard sell it does waste time!

what a great town. instanbul would have some of the best sites in the world. the building are great and what history they have second to none. Istanbul is a must to go to . The people are fantastic and the food is great as well

Get the Museum Pass!. Buy a Museum Pass right away! You'll be repeating the same question every time you are walking past the many hundred feet long line waiting to enter an attraction while your Museum Pass takes you in without any wait. Enjoy!

Fascinating but perplexing at the same time. I wish it was the Orient Express That was chugging into Birkeci Station. Unfortunately it was the train from Edirne. Its a delightful small station with an original roof supported by three graceful rows of cast-iron columns that follow the curve of the platform. Our locomotive squeels to a halt, face to face with the man who created modern Turkey, whose gold painted head protrudes from a stone plinth inside the station, with his long straight nose and beetle-browed stare. He looks vaguely sinister, like magician. We leave the station down a flight of marble stairs and into Istanbul. The city doesn't immediately work its magic but one cannot fail to notice that nowhere do history and geography merge more spectacularly as they do here. Its an amazing location, at the end of Europe and the beginning of Asia, where the Mediterranean meets the Black Sea. Its really eye stopping to think, what city can heighten ordinary experiences, views, more dramatic departures and arrivals, more significant encounters, more promising awareness sharper?  Istanbul always makes us feel as a city with a foothold in two distinct worlds and i can't imagine it jumping completely onto one side or the other. We set out across the Galate Bridge, our backs to the great Ottoman and Byzantine monuments, heading up to Pera, once a colony of Genovese merchants. Fishermen line the bridge and flat-topped water-taxis slide beneath with only centimetres to spare.  Everywhere, huge posters quoting Ataturk with strident reiterations of Republican ideals. It seems to suggest that the populace needs reminding of them constantly. I wonder if they are under threat? Everyday we discover something new in Istanbul. We took the ferry into Asia and up into one of the many suburbs fanning out over the exposed hillsides on the eastern bank of the Bosphorus. I must say this is a new Istanbul without decay but also without character where everything is fresh out of the box. A boat up the European shore sharpens our senses while we scan the coast for the fast disappearing Yalis, the elaborately stylish timber houses built as water-front retreats for the city's prominant families. They reminded me of houseboats in Cashmire, delicately beautiful, made for pleasure not for permanence.  We dined on a plate full of kidney beans, ratatouille, red peppers, beetroot and a glass of aniseed-flavoured Raki. Salute Istanbul
Great but very, very touristy. Lovely sites, but too many people! Get up early if you want to really see this area. Or go out of season.
Sultanahmet. All attractions incredible however be warned the lines for Hagia Sophia can be over a kilometre long. Get there at opening for 9 am, line up by 8am
Amazing Istanbul . Great I advice every one to go to Istanbul and go to Princess Islands. And Masjed Sultan Ahmad (prayer center)

East meets West. Very interesting the mix of Eastern & Western history.
Many groups of people do not allow a lot of freedom to dwell at any one attraction.
The fact that cats and dogs roam freely (looked after by the local council/people) was interesting to us as animal lovers

Istanbul Beware of taxi drivers. I love the city and the people, I've been there 4 times already and always enjoyed it.This time though I had great disappointment realizing that some taxi drivers were actually playing me with an old trick. They get my money and quickly replace my note with a smaller one saying that my 50 Liras were actually five. The notes look very much alike and it was only on the third occasion that I realized I was not mistaken but being ripped off.So beware everyone, don't get distracted when you give them your money or you'll pay twice.Do not get suspicious with everyone though, there's a lot of good people driving taxis.
easy to be reached. It is just a 20 minute walk from every interesting place and from each place easy to find your way and if you are in a hurry just take the tram

Istanbul is gorgeous. The historic Sultanahmet district of Istanbul is not only packed with must-see sites like the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar but also with gorgeous galleries, gardens and boutique hotels (which is where I hope to stay if I'm lucky enough to visit Istanbul again), all within walking distance.

Never fails to amaze. Istanbul s a fascinating city. Where else would you find buildings standing for over 1500 years, having been once a church, then a mosque and now a museum. There is always something new to learn.
Full of beauty and history. Loved the history of the area and ability to travel around on foot to see everything. Heaps of places to eat and purchase Turkish gilders.

Amazing and unmissable!. If you're in Istanbul the only place to stay is the old quarter! I didn't listen to my friends and chose to stay at the Kempinsky Palace across the water from the historic district big mistake, the hotel was beautiful but I spent every day making my way to the amazing historic quarter. Traffic in Istanbul is ridiculous, a 15 min cab ride to the old town in the morning is a 2 hour + cab ride after 3pm - total gridlock! We relied on the water transport and did just fine once we worked it out.

Great history all within walking distance in the Old City. Haga Sophia, Blue Mosque, the cisterns, the obelisks, the Grand Bazar all within easy walking distance in the Old City (Sultanahmet). We had a guided tour but you really you do not need it, it is easy to get around and lots of English is spoken.From Istanbul we also travelled by local busses to Ankara, Cappadocia, Konya, Antalya, Pamukkale, Kusadasi, Pergamon, Troy and Gallipoli.All easy stuff, even for strangers.If you want to pre-book buses, our agent was www.ticketlineturkey. Huseyin booked them all as well as some hotels according to our wishes and did a good job. Of course you can also book them at any city, almost everyone seems to be a travel agent.I must mention RSL Tours, operating in the Istanbul, Gallipoli, Troy areas.They came to the rescue of two Mexican girls whose actual agent had booked them in a long lay over at a truly inconvenient and to the girls uneasy situation.RSL was just the sub contractor on whose bus we were riding but they spent hours on the phone, got new tickets issued and gave a free ride from Pergamon to Gallipoli to the girls and picked up the additional ticket costs because the girls had spent all their Turkish Lira.That is the kind of company I would book with for trips in that area.
Plenty too See. There is a lot to see so I suggest you pay for a walking tour and have every thing explained. This should be $US 50-60 for the day
Dolmabahçe Palace. Dolmabahçe Palace on the European shore of the Bosphorus in Istanbul is a collection of Turkish Art. Around the palace is beautiful and amazing for walking.

Inspiring Istanbul. We had a whole week to explore this wonderful city. 4 nights in the middle of Sultanahmet and 4 across the bridge in Beyoglu. In Sultanahmet we were able to move quickly between the major sights, Aya Sofya, The Blue Mosque, Toptaki Palace and the Grand and Spice Bazarres. We also visited the Basilica Cisterns which were fantastic - all within short strolls of each other. By getting out from our apartment early, we could beat the tourist crush and see these magnificent sights peacefully.Over in Beyoglu, we stayed in flats not far away from the main drag, but amongst intriguing laneways and streets filled with local eateries and antique shops. So atmospheric. The Main Street was quiet in morning times, but filled with the masses from 12 pm onwards, thriving to street music, food and ice cream vendors and locals going about their daily business. Great stuff. Side lanes held eateries, rooftop and terrace bars, fish markets and traditional Turkish taverns with shishas and live music aplenty. Enough to keep even the most jaded traveller entertained.To top all of this, we also enjoyed a day long Bosphorous Cruise - standard non-private tour option. Was fantastic to get as far as the entrance to the Black Sea and lunch in tiny village, before returning. A great day out. Istanbul - you are an amazing, thriving city filled with lovely people. A must visit!!!

Mysterical, amazing atmosphere as a metropol city with European and Asian sides.. Mysterical, amazing atmosphere as a metropol city with European and Asian sides. City is not like a muslim cultured and most of the population drinks alcohol and male-female relations are easily in the streets. So it is not like an Arabic Country but there are lot and lots of Arab tourists all around. Surian bagger also disturbing but Turkish peoples hospitality and service quality are the best in the World.

Worth to visit. Istanbul is really very beautiful city. We were quite surprised, we didn't expect that. The people were friendly, always ready to help. The town is clean and there are so many historic attractions there - really worth to visit!
The best part of Istanbul. There is so much history in the Old City. You can not go to Istanbul and go through the Old City and visit the historical sights. A must do.

Historic Istanbul. Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque are two must-sees. In April the tulip displays are eye popping. The square between the two mosques was stunning with all the blooming flowers and the fountains. Suggest renting audio tours for Hagia Sofia. Lots of street vendors trying to sell you just about anything. A polite brush off would usually get rid of them. Public restrooms often required 1 Tl so be prepared.
Take your time. So many places to walk, wander and explore. Side streets, markets, handmade goods as well as the architecture and picturesque scenes as you admire the history of Istanbul.

Great history. All the historic buildings are close together, queues to get in can look long but seem to go very quickly so don't be fooled by a "guide" offering to get you in anywhere quicker for more money

Superb!. Loved Sultanahmet district. Lots to see - our favourites were Topkapi Palace ,Blue Mosque & most spectacular of all was the Grand Baazar. Fantastic views of the Bosphorous! Stay in Sultanahmet area & travel on the cheap local trams. We had only a few days& it wasn't long enough.Road traffic was a nightmare, horrendously slow.
Great city. Interesting monuments and safe streets to walk in. April is tulip festival and there are beautiful displays everywhere
I wish weather wass warmer. I was and still amm blown away by the History of Istanbul. Where ancient needs modern. I cant wait to go back and visit more places.

overwhelming. We were on a guided tour and was taken to the grand bazaar and given free time to shop,this place is huge and very overwhelming and I would personally need a whole day to explore and find my way around ,jewelry, clothing, you name it you'll find it here,really ,colorful, noisy and crowded, I didn't buy anything, but others form my group did.its a worthwhile experience and if I had more time I would definitely shop and explore .

Visit with Family in June 2011. I visited Istanbul in June 2011 with my wife and two grown up sons.Here the month visited is only up to May 2014 and not before that ( this needs to be corrected in the first place as there would be people like me who have visited before the month and year mentioned ) secondly in type of visit says family with either young children or teens now I come in neither as I went with my wife and two grown up sons ( even that needs to be altered or corrected ) okay now coming to the review " Istanbul " the very name cases a magic spell over me as I have studied in history about Constantinople and the Ottoman Empire and have taken photos of all the places of historical interest visited in Istanbul namely : The Blue Mosque ( Sultan Ahmed Mosque ) ,Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace,Dolmabache Palace,The Grand Bazaar,The Egyptian Spice Market, A cruise over the Bosporus,A trip to Bursa, A trip to princess islands, would like to add all those candid snaps taken only of the mosques,the shops ( no snaps of my family ) and other snaps that I have posted on Google plus from my Travel Album of the various places that I have visited around the world.Dr.Javed Rasheed

History in the future. The historic Istanbul is a mix of history and the multicultural present day world. Very beautiful, within walking reach and a lot of options. Do whatever you want to and you are not just fixed in one thing.

A cultural awakening. To understand the culture of Istanbul, the deep seated historical value to the world is truly inspiring and awesome. The diversity of culture in the history can teach a lot of today's political leaders what diversity and unity can achieve.
Day trip. Everything around the area is interesting crowded variety of shops and places to eat and cafes, but also pricey

Sultanhamet. We enjoyed the Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia and the lovely gardens and fountains. By lunchtime it was crowded so we made our way down to the Bosphorus. Had a good meal in a restaurant under the bridge.

Has to be seen before dir. Istanbul old city is one of the most important place to see in the world . History of many cultures , architecture of different cuktures are together.... You feel east and west at the same time. I have been many famous places all over the world but Istanbul is realy different with it's colors, food, ambiance and soul... I advise all tripers Istanbul come and see this gorgeus city .

Terrific Turkey!. I had a magical time on Gate 1’s 13-day affordable Turkey! The tour started off in historic Istanbul and then traveled around the western and central part of the country. The highlights of the trip was exploring historic Istanbul, seeing the ancient city of Ephesus (optional tour), dipping my feet in the natural hot springs of Pamukkale, and visiting the underground city and rock formations of Cappadocia (optional tour). Some other highlights were leisurely spending part of the day in the resort town of Kuşadasi along the Aegean Sea, visiting an elementary school, and going to a traditional Turkish bath. The hotels were all good to excellent and each had its own unique character. The meals included were also tasty and delicious. Overall, Gate 1 gave me terrific value for my trip to Turkey.

A treasure trove of history, beauty and interest. Forget the crowds and submerge yourself in the magnificence of the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Bazaars and all. Be patient and be rewarded. You will be called upon to extract yourself from the traders demanding your attention, but be polite and enjoy the banter, they are a delight.

The Old Town area of Sultanahmet is amazing. Breathtaking buildings, but long queues for entry - go early as you can- it's worth an early start! Lots of guides offer to skip the queue if you sign up with them, but if you have a good guidebook you can easily do them yourself
Great Country. People, food, cleanliness, attractions ,weather, Mediterranean location by the Sea, dances, safety. Lots to do and see.
Success. Interesting historic buildings and places. Very kind people, except some taxi drivers. A bit crowded everywhere.

Gallipoli. Visited during the 100 year celebration and very much enjoyed the experience. Toured with Orion Tours and had an excellent guide named Erdal. Highly recommend. He also does his own tours around Turkey. Some for ten days. Very good information about Turkey and the 1st World Tour.

I can't describe, a must see. I can't describe, a must see.
You have to experience the old city.
What is also very nice, there are people from all over the world, which gives an additional experience
beautiful area. Great area just to roam or laze especially with all the flowers in bloom and the fountains on. Filled with hawkers trying to sell something though so be aware.

Historic Istanbul. Fantastic,easy to access and very interesting. Masses to see.
beautiful flowers, great trams, exciting food.

History heaven. If you like getting lost in mazes and finding little gems around each corner then the old city of Istanbul is the place to be. With shopping, historical buildings from grand to small and apple tea available everywhere it is possible never to leave the area during your stay.

Tour of Turkey with Gate1. Absolutely amazing itinerary. The points of interest were well planned and the accommodations were fantastic. Expert drivers and our guide Farouk made this trip very comfortable. Balloon ride and the bazaars were quite an experience. Gate1 came through as usual.

Get a map and start walking!. Safe and historically important area. Many shops and monuments. Homes and cafes. A 'stew' of centuries of the east and the west melting together into one neighborhood.
I recommend walking here in the early parts of the day. Beat the crowds and beat the heat.
Excellent Istanbul. Clean and beautiful city. Strongly recommend to learn few words of Turkey especially if you visit outside Istanbul like Antalya.
great to see. very enjoyable to see. to be able to touch and see places that are hundreds of years old is amazing.
Sultanahmet area is very beautiful!. Roam around in the blue mosque area - look at beautiful Tulip quarries, click the grand monumennts and look out for buzzing places to eat
Amazing. Way more different from what we are used to here in europe but it's simply stunning, sort of a melting between the "western" europe and "middle-east".
great place with deep history. Hagia Sophia has great history, Love the Blue Mosque and other mosques in Istanbul. Topkapi is a must visit.

Just so different from European cities. Bazar is no.1 thing todo, visit Taksim square late night to see how young people party or just walk next to Bosporus
But still very European compared to rest of Turkey.

Thirteen Day Affordable Turkey Tour. We took a Thirteen Day Affordable Turkey Tour with Gate 1 Travel in late March.This is our first time traveling to Turkey as well as with Gate 1 Travel. We traveled by bus from Istanbul-Cappadocia-Istanbul visiting cities and ruins along the way, such as Ephesus, Konya, Pamukkale, and Ankara. The tour guide, Erkal, was informative, organized, and managed to herd about forty of us through various sites on schedule and on time. We had excellent accommodations in each cities as well as breakfast and dinner when provided with our tour package. We would recommend Gate 1 Travel as well as in our future travel plan.

Byzantine Gold and Splendour. Our top favorites are: Topkapi and Haiga Sophie (We recommend "early bird" visits as even in April the cues were very after 10:30h) as well as the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar and the Sueleymanie Mosque+Cloisters (Here entry is free).For lunch/dinner and especially "sundowners" we loved the restaurants on both sides of the Galater Bridge (lower level).

must see for everybody. This part of Istanbul is where every single item has a long story. More than 2000 years of history starting from earlier eastern roman empire thanks to Constantine, Byzantine and later Ottoman Empire. Spend your time this area and enjoy the beauty mixed with history, culture, art, architecture, religion and much more...

the best city in the world is Istanbul. i love Istanbul. The best city in world. i would loved to live there if i can. Many diffrent culture mixed together Islam Othoman Byzantine Romanian Greek Asian European so magnificent. Very clean city. Everywhere gardens Trees and flowers around. Bosphore is amazing. Downtown is also great. Agia Sofia. Sultan Ahmed. Ble Jami. Nice food. we went one turkish restaurant in Taxim. we all dance together . Turks has respect . Nice music nice songs nice dance. We used tram around the city had fan. Live at nice hotels. Kapalacharshi Grand Bazar is excellent.

A must see area of Istanbul. If you are a first timer to Istanbul, stay in this area. There is so much to see and do, you need a few days, and if you stay in the area you can walk everywhere. The trams are great, but very crowded, so we found walking a better option. The people are very friendly, and although there are people who hassle you to buy things, it was no worse than many other parts of the world. We felt safe at all times here, just take normal precautions you would in any city in the world. If you are a museum buff then buying a pass is a good idea. They used to be for 72 hrs, but are now for 5 days, so you can see sights at your leisure. If you are more interested in walking around and just soaking up the sights, then just pay to go into the attractions you want. Most of them are 15 to 30 Tl.

Sultanhmet!!!. This is our first time visiting Istanbul. We split our stay in 2. First half in the Historic areas: Sultanahmet and the second half in the Galata areas. Both our teenagers love the historic areas for its beautiful architects and cultures. Restaurants are more pricey than the other side of the bridge and exchange (dollars to lires) value is also less than the other side of the bridge. We would highly suggested that you learn how to use the TRAM and obtain the Istanbul Card. This mode of transportation get you to many places and much more affordable and dare I say less stress than taking a taxi.Enjoy your travels!

2000 year old city, yet modern and vibrant.. The mosque's hundreds, the Sultans palace and grounds, the spice market (Egyptian Market),Bosphorus and Golden Horn Cruises all were excellent. The Grand Bazaar has gone to pretty much fixed prices, but I did haggle a great deal on a volume of scarves.(Key was use of U.S. dollars. Very touristy but the Hop on Hop off bus is a great overview first day choice.
Great. Lots to see but get use to hassle from those wabting to sell you something and begging...babies and children often used to ull on the heart strings.

It blown my mind. Such and intriguing city . My favorite city so far and by far! Love the cultural mix, the beauty of the sultanament, Blue mosque and Sophia . I could go on and on about this city , but there are no words to explain.

The place where East meets the West. Pros: A lot of history and monuments, still multicultural even within the local population, a variety of choices to watch, listen and enjoy. Difficault to be bored. Friendly and polite people.Cons: Driving is an experience to be avoided, better prefer to get taxis from hotels or ask for reliable taxi drivers from restaraunts and venues.

You have to stay in Sultanahmet!. You have to stay Sultanahmet - have to, if you are coming to Istanbul - especially if you are a first timer. I read a random review to that effect and BEST decision I made! Beautiful beautiful place. The History is all around you and great transport links...the trams are a great feature. Colourful, bright and brilliant value. Definitely use them as opposed to taxis to get around. Buy a transport card and you're on local as opposed to tourist rates from the get go.

Istanbul is Amazing. Istanbul is an amazing place to visit and don't expect to do everything in a day - defiantly give yourself 4 - 5 days and that's just to see the main tourist attractions. Try to find accommodation in the area near the Blue Mosque and you cant go wrong - everything is then in walking distance and if you travel further the transportation system is great. Istanbul is hilly so make sure you are a little fit and have good walking shoes.

Historical places and buildings... You can see many historical places and buildings around historcial peninsula of Istanbul. Many of them are really amazing. Especially Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Dolmabahce Palace and old houses at the bosphorus.

my second vstaying in maya hotel. Dear Traveler this is my second trip to Istanbul and the 2 Staying is Maya Hotel because the staff are helpful and did give u all the info that let your trip easier.i will be very thankful to Yusef.when u stay in this hotel u can reach the metro and the tram by 5 min walking.the hotel is clean and the breakfast is good.

Don't be afraid to venture out in Istanbul. As tourists you can sometimes he hesitant. Of venturing out ,but after a week in Istanbul we saw no crime no trouble never felt threatened and we're always treated courteously,Never ripped off or overcharged. In fact we could not believe how reasonable prices were Buy a multi travel instanbultravel card top it up with money when required ride the trams. buses ferries ans see the sights for very little cost ,Some museums are free. The military history museum off Taxim square is fantastic Ans at 3-pm there is a free military Mhetar band show with traditional Turkish military music Also some fantastic places to eat everyone very helpful with the choice of food generally half the cost of eating out in Europe so adventure out and see the city

Sites of old Istanbul. Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia and other historical churches were interesting to visit but we felt that the guides were rushed, disinterested in the history and gabbled off their Pre-learned scripts. Bospherous cruise was good.
Saw all the sites. Get a 72 hour pass for the sites, much cheaper. The big bus is very good as a way of getting around with hop on and off as many times in 24 hours as you like.

Beauty Istanbul. Istanbul is indeed amazing !It is a journey from Greek to Roman To Ottoman to Modern times !The History of Hagia Sofia, The Grandure of Blue Mosque, The wonder collection at Topkapi palace Museum and its location, all are simply unforgettable including Golden Throne from India and Topkapi Dagger. Turkish food was tasty.

Excitement and surprises. Because it was the capital of two great empires of history, Istanbul has great spiritual, historical, architectural heritage and offers its visitors the opportunity to discover these treasures! It is perfectly positioned geographically in the region and offers tours of historic attractions and excellent opportunity to taste dishes of Turkish cuisine!
Deep and Beautiful History. Lots to see and learn. May take several days to get to all the available attractions. Most places are a decent value for the price (compared to most locations in Europe).
Magical Istanbul. I liked mostly the Basilica Cistern - it was so mystical and beautiful and much larger than weexpected. So many tourists overlook this gem.
Steeped in history. Loved the juxtaposition of the oldness and the modernity. The architecture is beautiful and Istanbul's role in history is amazing.

Best part of the city. If you have never been or only have 1 day, this is where you want to be. Lots of historic buildings and things to see around Sultanahmet Square. You have the Egyptian obelisk and german fountain in the middle of the square in front of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Plenty of restaurants and places to shop as well.
Amazing history at every turn. Brilliant, I have always wanted to visit and am glad I finally have what an amazing cultural and historical trip

Excellent Islamic monuments. The Islamic monuments of the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Ztopkapi a Palace and Basilica Cistern are all very close together in the old city and all worth visiting but go early to avoid the queues, especially on Sunday.

Where East meets West. This truly is where Europe meets Asia. Istanbul historic architecture and culture mixes the history of Rome, with that of Byzantium and into modern Turkey. Worth a visit, generally safe with friendly people.

markets. we went curtain shopping, the area between the grand bazar and spice market. be prepared to go in narrow door ways and down stairs. honest, friendly, good deals we paid in Turkish what we would have paid here in £.no problem that they didn't spk English. no hassle. The grand bazar and spice market could be over priced

Lots of amazing restoration happening - beautiful sights.. If you stay in the Serkeci area everything is easy to reach and walkable. One has to be careful as the trams use the roads with the traffic and sidewalks are not wide. Lovely shops with delicious foods, beautiful soft leather products, handmade rugs and interesting silver jewellery at competitive prices. Friendly shop-owners.

Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet, also known as The old city Istanbul is very good place to stay in one out of many hotels located here. It's the home to all the most famous Istanbul attractions, from Topkapi palace to Blue Mosque

Two areas. The delightfulness of Istanbul is wandering the streets and getting lost as you go. There are two main areas to the Historic section of the city. The main part where the mosques and palaces are is wonderful, but very crowded (especially on a weekend). The Grand Bazaar is here as is the Cistern, the old city walls and the old aquaducts. The other section of the historic area is across the Galata Bridge and is home to historic areas, but a lot more modern things. Be wary of the crowds and the little urchin children begging for money. The other thing to be careful about are the trams that have to ring their bells in order to get down the street, but are conviniently located to most of the major sites.

Where do I start. OMG so many amazing places to visit & a lot of things to experience. Please plan & prioritise your visit because you will never have enough time in this city. My favs Topkapi Palace, Cistern Basilica, Blue Mosque, Taksim Square, Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar & Galetta Bridge at night watching everyone fishing!

Most amazing historical mix!. Istanbul is just like a cultural crossroad, a place where Europe and Asia meet each other. Unique experience. Must visit destination for anyone who likes history, culture, geography or shopping. Highly recommended!

east meets the west. Very tourist friendly and a great feel for history, the Ottoman rule and modern Turkey. The city bustles with life, tradition, modernity, and business. While the Old City is dense and crowded, the outlying areas are bustling with development. Traffic is horrendous.

Fascinating City. We had never been to Turkey so we took a break over Easter to visit. The city is fabulous with lots of things to see and do. We really enjoyed our time there and seeing the Eastern architecture and culture. We stayed in the old city at the Hotel Niles which was great as it was so easy to get to the main attractions & restaurants. To get around we either walked or took the Tram system. Here is our itinerary: Evening 1: stroll around the Sultanahmet area and dinner; Day 2: Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Eminönü area, Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar; Day 3: Topkapi palace, Gulthane Park, boat ride (ferry) on Bosporus; Day 4: Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Taksim, Shopping. Overall a very good trip and great experience, Temperatures in early April were mid teens, although it was rainy (the hotel lent out umbrellas or you can buy them for 10TL from street vendors). Easter is quite crowded as many in northern Europe get holidays then, but lines for the sights were not too bad... the maximum we queued was 30 minutes.

Feel the history. I liked the good services, affordable transportation, budget food and the hospitality of the locals. You can finish your tour and have lazy time in one of the cafes around. What I did not like lately is the big number of children and women asking you money, many of them at Sultan Ahmet garden.
Must See. I was so fascinated by this city! Unexpected experience and I'll be back for sure! If You have a chance, have to visit It! ☺

Unexpectedly fell in love. Istanbul, where East meets West, is perhaps the most intriguing city in the World. It's history and culture are fascinating with the Christian and Islamic influences at different times. It's wonderful to be able to walk these streets and get a sense of it today.

Nice but not eassy to walk. I travelled with a 1 year old baby, aond historical areas are not really prepared to do so. Specially trafic is quite complicated. However its a very beatigull urban landscape.

"Excitement for the Senses!". Istanbul Turkey!Are you interested in challenging your senses to its’ maximum potential? Istanbul, Turkey can be the exact place where you can excite them all! Your eyes will become busy picking up the contours and vivid colors as well as counting the majestic columns at the famous historical sites at Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque; while you can appreciate your listening skill to the rhythmic sounds of dripping water at the Basilica Cisterns! Equally your olfactory and gustatory senses will not be neglected at the Spice Bazaar and at the Eminonu Pier: You will definitely find your choice of sweet pallet through the mouth watering Turkish Delights! You will surely not be disappointed to the experiences harvested in Istanbul Turkey! Everywhere you turn there will be a mosaic of friendly faces looking back at you and wonderment of history no more, for this is where history is alive and evident; “West meets East”! Marie F. Anaheim, USAMarch-2015

Sultanahmet district. Our hotel (Esans) was in the Sultanahmet district, which is the heart of historic Old Istanbul. Most of the major historic sites are within walking distance. The signage is generally excellent, and the people are friendly and helpful. Since this a major tourist area, almost everyone speaks passable English. Places we visited in this area included Topkapı Palace, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia), the Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet Camii), the Byzantine Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Great Palace Mosaic Museum and Gulhane Park. The area is full of reasonably priced restaurants and little shops where you can buy bottled water, fruits and other snacks. From here, we took the tram, which was very easy and affordable, to other parts of Istanbul such as Chora Church, Dolmabahce Palace, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. We also enjoyed dinner along with a whirling dervish show at Mesale Cafe in Arasta Bazaar in SUltanahmet district.

Brilliant city - terrible traffic!. Great place for a city break or a long weekend, lots to do and see and the people are really friendly and helpful. Traffic is awful though and gets snarled up very quickly. Taxis are reasonable and most cab drivers use the meter, but avoid travelling during rush hour or if you have to travel then make sure you negotiate a price in advance.
Fantastic. The mosques and grand bazaar a must see for any traveler apart from our hotel and some of the yellow taxi drivers it was fantastic especially when we started using the metro

THE ATTRACTION THAT CALLS ITSELF ISTANBUL. 5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 13, 2011 There is no tour really needed to see Istanbul. Read a good guide book of your choice in advance, keep it with you and prepare to walk, uphill, down hill on historic cobblestones till your feet go numb. Stop for tea at a cafe, sit in any park, listen, watch, breathe it all in. Every corner you turn, every turn of the head fills your senses with this great city. You know all the sights to see...and dont forget to get off the main streets, be it in the old town or new. If you can do anything on your 1 st nite try for a rooftop restaurant in Sultanamet near the water with views of the Blue Mosque & Aya Sofia. We tried Teras, a little pricey but not bad and OK food but OOOH the romance and view. We were there for 6 full days & I suggest no less to do an unhurried ability to savor. A fun place that is easy to bypass with all that history out there is the Istanbul Modern. Great for a bad weather day but forget the highly touted Cafe..This review I realize was put under the wrong category originally. Just copied it over now.Visited October 2011

Mamutpasha. Head out of the Grand Bazaar through the No. 7 exit - Mamutpasha Gate. If you keep walking you will eventually arrive at Eminonu. Lots of little cobbled streets with shops that sell absolutely everything and a lot cheaper than anything in the Grand Bazaar.Lots of textile and clothing shops The shopkeepers are very friendly, not a lot of tourists about but you can safely stroll and shop or window shop for hours. A very pleasant experience and where the locals go to shop.
Wow. A lot of sites to see. Better plan it form home where you wanna go in istanbul. You will be amazed!!

STREETS OF SPICE. Istanbul is full of interest - with no shortage of historic attractions , mosques, markets and trams to explore. A real highlight is the Spice market and above that alleyway after alleyway of alternative shops and stalls. From ironmongery to weaving, stationary to spices and cheese its a joy,

one of the things you have to see. One of the most stunning places to see. Colourful with culture, architecture, people trying to sell their wares, haggling, spices and smells from the market, sounds... Breathtaking!

Thousands of years of history. If you like culture tourism and are a foodie, Istanbul is a must see place for you.
There are many Roman and Ottoman masterpieces to be seen.

Must see. ıt was the firts time in Istanbul.Everywhere is worth see.Turkısh people are hospitable.Their history is seen in every area.Topkapi, Dolmaabahca,pinces islands and everthing.We come again certainly

Family trip to Istanbul!. This was a great first-time visit to this wonderful city. The people are friendly and helpful. Istanbul is a city of rich historical relevance and a diverse culture. The local cuisine is full of interesting spices and flavors that will delight the taste buds.
Incredible history of Istanbul. Better reality than fiction.. If you forget about shopping and try to think about all different cultures inside the city you willl get involved and fascinated.

Great atmosphere. The Sultanahmet area is packed full of wonderful sights such as the blue mosque, Hagia Sophia, the palace, the Roman cistern to name but a few. There are open spaces around the sights so that they can be viewed at their best and there are great inexpensive restaurants and cafes to serve all tastes. you can wander around and people watch, discovering new things all the time.
I Love Istanbul. Nice experience of Istanbul, visit many places and enjoyed lot.All historical places are too good, Blue Mosque visit is memorable for life time.

great city. the city if full of historic places to visit, shops, restaurants , streets mosques and religion places are very well engineered by their historic founders which makes the city a big museum
Cultural rich. Join a tour or find a certified guide to bring you around the attractions point and enjoy the rich history of the attractions.
Very interesting!. A fantastic area with lots of history. Something different to see on every street and just walking around allows you to soak up the atmosphere!

Historically rich and packed. The main attractions in Istanbul are truly worth visiting, and are all pretty nearby so you can cover most of it in a few days. The Istanbul Pass is especially helpful in getting around cheaply. Places visited on Day 1: Dolmabahce Palace, Taksim Square, Istiklal Avenue, Galata Tower. Day 2: Topkapi Palace, Haghia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar. Other attractions: Maiden's Tower, Aqueduct, other mosques.

Istanbul, Turkey. One of the oldest cities on our planet, amazing history, excellent food and very friendly people. There is so much to do and see and really need about 20 days to see everything this city has to offer.

beautiful, historic, plenty of atmosphere, and crowded even in winter. Istanbul is a magical city and seems like it is always full of tourists and there are always lines and crowds. The museum pass is well worth the money.

Istanbul Old City and its seas. The old City is beautiful, Highly recommended is the Topkapi (although one can end up severely "tiled out" at the end), the Blue Mosque and the Cisterns. Try a Kumpi for lunch at a local café as well. You will never experience a baked potato like this anywhere else!!! Don't get on the scales too soon afterwards. Dodge the ticket touts and head for the dockside where you can buy a trip up the Bosphorus or Golden Horn for a few lira on a local ferry. Eyup is worth a visit altho' to Western eyes it is a little odd to find candy and food stalls up a mountain side that is in fact a huge graveyard. Somewhat sad to find that the bazaars were full of junk but the architecture was interesting.

Great tour!. The tour is historical,architectural tour.The places are so near that it is walking tour and worth visiting.We were lucky to have good and knowledgable guide from she tours ,who made it more interesting .we were taken to grand bazaar but the time was less to satisfy our need of shopping of the souvenirs . The next day we used the matro to move in Istanbul easily.first we learned how to draw jotun(coin) from machine with help of security. Travelled to grand bazaar in 4 lira from Gulhane station.Next day we went to Taksim square through metro by drawing Istanbulkart, really cheap and easy way to travel.if you take help of security they are always ready and understand English .

Amazing. The historic area of downtown Istanbul has more history that I have seen in years. It is a truly magical city with so many things to see and do. You will not be disappointed in the area or the city!

Breathtaking views!. Istanbul is a great city, being by the water and seeing so many different areas which so much history and beautiful designs. Love the food, the history, the culture and the breathtaking views from many of the rooftop restaurants in the area.

Great. So much to see and very close to each other. Did have a half day guided tour but disappointed because really only turned out to be an hour and 20 min of actual touring and then dropped at the carpet shop! So choose your tour wisely. Street food really cheap and delicious ( pretzel like bagel) and the freshly squeezed pomegranate and Orange juice mix for just over £1 was devine. P.s no stomach problems!

Some of the best architecture, history, food and people-watching in the world. Start early and pace yourself, as there is a lot to do here and you could get exhausted early. Aya Sofia if a must, as is the Grand Bazaar, and the Blue Mosque, plus lunch or dinner--or both--at one of the outdoor cafes on the side streets. We didn't have time for the Basilica Cistern, which was disappointing, so I wish we'd had another day to go back. You could spend a month in Istanbul and continue to be amazed every day. And you'd eat well and probably not gain weight because of the walking--and the basically healthy food options.

Great. Loved the visit very enjoyable and enriching the ahamad sultan area is definitely worth staying at for 3 days . It clean and easy to navigate, they need to improve directional signs; very few and and not easily understoodthe system is made for non turkish visitors to need a guide. you can do it you self but you need to be ready with enough research before hand and a good map still you would need to ask where is the entrance and things like these It was cold and raining so I would advise to avoid March if you can plan for April or May
Blue Mosque. A must on every travellers list of to-do things,Its sheer magnificence leaves you spellbound.Truly a masterpiece of architecture.
Cosmopolitan Istanbul. Cosmopolitan and lace with history. You cannot understand the Western Hemisphere until you visit this cross road city

Close proximity. To see most of the main sites in Istanbul, you can stay in one area. They are within easy walking distance of one another.Head for the Grand Bazaar and the Sophia Church and you'll find the rest.

Always good to pay a visit this area. Walking down through the little streets and roads in the historical areas of Istanbul means exploring the secret,beautiful parts of the city.With this occasion,many important sights of the city will be into yr path in any direction.You will also come close with different categories of shops and stores where you can also make good shopping (please do not forget to bargain as here barganing is a must and traditional way of shopping in most touristic places).When you are tired,you can also seat any of suitable cafes and restaurants to take some rest and dine&drink.Recommended.

Tagging is not new. The Hagia Sofia is a marvellous construction. Built 1500 years ago, it has survived wars and earth quakes and changing regimes. This is certainly a must. Being a Norwegian, I find it curious to discover that a fellow contryman tagged inscriptions in the railings on the gallery some 1200 years ago in runes. It is unclear what the runes reads (at least to me). It was signed Halvdan, however. Probably something like "Halvdan was here!".

beautiful. breath taking, interesting with a lot of important and world relevant history. I liked they have a pass for several museums and tourist areas are safe (according to me). They keep their historic areas well maintained.

Absolute fascination. Grand Bazaar..very busy but a must to view. Maybe early early in the morning.Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace..great gardensBlue Mosque, Spice Market and Galata Bridge all made for walking around

Magic. I ve been traveling a lot for my business and frankly speaking I love to travel and learn more thing's about new cultures. Obviously in every country has beautiful places to visit but there are very few places like Istanbul. When you get here you feel like in a tale or history book. Cultural heritage differences between modern life and traditional Turkish life. Roman heritage arabic persian heritage Islamic Jewish Christian heritage all of them here melted with love and Turkish hospitality.. if you haven't visited Istanbul that means you haven't traveled so far.

Istanbul clean up your touts. A transporting atmosphere with great building surrounded in history and unbelievable beauty until the locals touts assault you trying to get you into a shop to make their commission. One must become deaf to their harassment to enjoy all that is offered

Some of the best the world has to offer. Istanbul, or Constantinople as it was known during the reign of the Byzantine Empire, is steeped in history and has the buildings to prove it. Days can be spent in its historic areas, with lots of cafes offering strong Turkish coffee to keep you going.
Unique mix of Oriental and Europian culture. So many historical monuments in limited space. Good transportation options. Very friendly people who are ready to help you get to desired location.

Just could pass my whole vacation roaming through the alleys. one can just walk through the areas passing by the historical architecture. if you are on of those kinds who like to experience the life of an area, this is an absolute experience

Of Spices, carpets, bazaars and taxi drivers... The good, the great and the ugly. Let me say that Istanbul is a lovely city where the old meets new. I would like to review my experience 1. The good: the spice market is really a sight to behold especially if you are a foodie who cooks. I did my research so as not to be overwhelmed and get conned. Here are a few tips:  a. The most reliable whole seller is ARIFOGLU. If u go to supermarkets, u will see their products on the spice racks. b. Do not buy pre packed stuff.  C. Buy per gram and they will vacuum seal it for you.  D. BUy from inside the shop and not from outside on display e. Iranian. Saffron... This is the real deal. It comes in 3 jars from the most fragrant to the least, priced at 60, 40 and 20 TL per gram ! They will weight it infront of you and put them in small jars and vacuum seal it. The ones sold by others for Vy cheap are actually safflower as turkey does not produce saffron F. Buy dried fruits that are not cut up G. But shelled nuts as they are fresher H. Taste the Turkish delights before u buy themSit down and enjoy tea as they are doing your purchase, it's free because it is their custom to offer tea.2. The grand bazaar is really not worth buying from except for maybe leather, unless you want to be cheated and chased until u buy something. But if you do go, I recommend this guy near gate 2 called POSH bag, Mr Seckin Atag. He is the only one who will not force u and honestly tell u the faults and good about his products...they are good leathers. He will calmly let you go if u say u will be back and see other stores. He is a whole seller and people even imitate his imitation ! You can tell the leather is good.Other that leather...there is nothing else worth buying there. Also don't be fooled by people holding a lighter to the bag to prove its leathe.You will be better off with the Arastar bazaar beside the blue mosque which is smaller, less people harassing you3. The great: carpets and jewelry. THIs was a really good recommendation by our concierge from park hyatt (which is great by the way) as his only concern is that we find genuine turkish carpets and real jewelry and u won't be cheated.The carpet place is called Eginci and the jewelry store is Divas. They are both owned by 3 generations who know their craft. You won't find the finest silk carpets that u certainly know is genuin except here. Most will be claiming that it's turkish carpets, but really they are not. REal turkish carpets are expensive and if they bargain too low, be wary.omar, one of the owners speaks very good English and very knowledgeable.He will even show u how they make the carpets and once u see that most take about 1-2 years by hand, u know why the price is not possible to be cheap. They are also very pleasant to deal with. They. Will offer you a ride back whether ubuy or not if you come recommended by your concierge.3. THE UGLY: definitely the crupulous cab drivers. We foolishly rode a cab by the spice market, noticed something wrong with the meter that it is below, and he kept circling around. Then he made up an excuse to drop us off the corner from our hotel and pulled the "cash switch" ... I gave him 50 TL, because the fare was 43 TL (too expensive to begin with) then I saw him switch it with a 5TL and said I gave him only 5TL. I told him I saw him switch it but he insisted. Rather than get in trouble, we just paid and got out. So to avoid this, a few tips':a. Pick only cabs from your hotel or restaurantsB. If u have to get from the road, get the ones with cab logos on the door, not just the phone number c. The meter is digital and can be found on the rear view mirrord. Get the plate number of the cab and report it to your conciergeThe hotel we stayed on is fantastic...park hyatt and I will write a separate review.

Istanbul is full of very interesting history. This city is one of the best cities I've visited in Europe.. We visited the blue mosque, the Hagia Sophia Museum, the Topkapi Palace and ate at several excellent restaurants. It was easy to get around the city and the hotel we stayed at was very nice.

great idea for weekend if you are fond of history. If you are fond of history - Istanbul is a great idea for weekend. all the places of interest are situated nearby. this city is full of opportunities to learn something new. No need to overcome great distance to get all the museums/ mosques. I suggest to buy the museum cart - in this case you don't have to wait in queue + it will be cheaper

A must do city, but allow plenty of time to sightsee. A small group of us recently visited Istanbul for a three night break and it was probably one of the best city breaks we have done together, but in hindsight we should have made it a four or five night break as there is so much to see and do and you don't want to rush it. One of the main advantages is that most of the main attractions are located in or around the main square area in the old city, and they are easily within walking distance of one another. In fact if you stand in the main square you can see most of them.All the food we had during our stay was good, and its very reasonably priced too.The general advice, which I tend to agree with is to avoid travelling by taxi unless you want to get ripped off, and why would you want to go by taxi anyway when the trams are new, clean, reliable and cheap.We didn't see and graffiti and saw very little litter during our stay, which made the whole city seem clean. All the Turkish people we encountered during our stay were friendly and helpful.I also recommend a boat trip along the Bosphorus while you are there too, as you get to see both sides of the city from a different perspective.We pre-booked our transfers to and from the airport and our city hotel online before we flew, which proved to be a great idea. As the company were there to greet us as we came out of the airport and picked us up promptly from our hotel as arranged. All for 25 Euros per trip for four people. (we used Efendi Travel)
Steeped in history. Amazing historic buildings, very crowded, not easy to travel by taxi, use trams, plenty of lovely authentic bars & cafe's along the way!

İstanbul historical graveyards. İstanbul is full of historical graveyards and cemeteries showing the beauty of endengared Ottoman gravestones. Most of them are worth visiting in historical peninsula on walking distance of Hagia Sophia and Blue mosque. Çemberlitas Sultan Mahmut II shrine is an open air gravestone museum with wonderful graves and sarcophagus.

Very excellent hotel. I will start to speak about the reception staff, there is not enough words to express thanks and gratitude to them for tact, ethics, professional, Mr. Tolga, Mr. Sinan Ms. Toba and third person does not remember the name, and there is pretty nice and professional girl her name Jamela. Again Thanks and gratitude to all the hotel staff for the excellent in everything, thanks and appreciation for those who working in the kitchen specially for the delicious breakfast, The rooms are good hygiene, very excellent hotel

Nice, compact area, suitable for walking. All the attractions are near to each other in Sultan Ahmet, so one can just walk to all of them in a day. I walked to the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Gulhane Park, Eminou pier to see the Galata Bridge and Tower, and the Spice (Egyptian) Bazaar. I only went inside the Spice Bazaar, due to some attractions cost money and some are crowded. But I was able to take lots of good pictures on the way.
Love it!. I love the the mixture of old and new, Islam and Christanity, Europe and Asia, deep rooted culture and mordenism and is people.
Fabulous!. All of them are beautiful and full of history. So many Roman sites and the Ottoman empire architecture, it is truly amazing.

a new culture. Istanbul has history, as we all know, and it is nice to visit as much as you can, but at the end, I would have enjoyed just as much just walking on every possible street and feeling the vibe.

World Class heritage sights with easy walking distances. It can take several days to visit all the historical sights in the Old town. Best to hire a guide to explain all the hidden treasures within your sights. There is so much to see and do. Walking around the town and learning how to use the T1, M1 and M2 is best.

Ottoman Era. Istanbul is one of the most beautiful cities in the world specialy for history lovers.you can smell the history in every stone in this city.the goverment did great job by keeping and saving the old buildings and mosques.

A PrivateTour Guide is the best way to see and learn about the old city. We spent the day in the Old City with our private tour guide Gurzin Ertan. She speaks English, Turkish and Italian, by the way! We not only learned some of the history and cultural aspects of Turkey in general, but also about specfic sites such as the Hagia Sophia, Topkopi Palace, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cisterns, Gulhane Park, The Grand Bazaar, and the Spice Bazaar (ask about her favorite shops and she may be able to help you get top quality at a good rate.) The city is amazing and full of awe inspiring buildings and history. And Guzin was sweet, patient and full of knowledge. Look her up and you will have great tour.

Great place to visit ancient sites that influenced our modern day history. The historic sites in Istanbul is truly a must see and was the highlight of our visit. The ancient historical sites comprising 2 great empires were truly magnificent and everything was in close proximity of each other. The architecture and devotion to religious beliefs were clearly evident through the extremities of grandeur, from design to craftsmanship.
Agia Sophia. I visited the Byzantine church of Agia Sophia, the Prince Islands and Top Kapi. Great experience for Greeks and History lovers

Getting around in Istanbul or Constantinople. Loved the historic feel and the lovely roads and tram service. The spice market and the Grand Bazaar made one go back centuries with their display and aromas.
The river cruise on the Bosporus was exhilarating and an experience worth having.
The Blue Mosque was serene and a calming effect

Fascinating!!. Having the privilege to walk around the old parts of the city for a few days with various new friends added fresh perspectives to the ancient yet alive history of the absolutely amazing city. From the Egyptian pillar erected by Theodosius in 390 A.D. to standing inside Hagia Sophia and learning about all the changes and disasters over the centuries and seeing first hand the beauty and majesty of what still stands today. A return visit to this amazing city is still on my bucket list.

2-3 Days in Istanbul. Day 1: Plan for Blue Mosque(2hrs), Aya Sofia(3-4hrs), Caverns (1hr) and a nice stroll around that area. I don't recommend going to the topkapi palace on day 1, due to time crunchDay 2: Start early at 9:00AM and cover topkapi palace (5 hrs) and a nice walk or take train to Grand Bazaar. Don't buy stuff here. It is atleast twice of what you can get for elsewhere. Definitely don't buy baklava and turkish delight here. It is not good quality here.At night visit Galata tower and walk along istiklal street all the way to Taksim square (2 hrs)Day 3: Go for Bosphorous trip (3 Hrs). There are multiple options. Take the one that takes you to nice palaces around and into black sea (3-4 hrs). They start close to Galata bridge. Upon completing this, walk along Galata bridge to the awesome experience and view of seeing Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia, Blue mosque in one view. Note: For buying soveniers pashabashe in istiklal street is the best place. You can buy turkish delight for under 30lira at Haci Bekir (170yrs old shop). Best baklava in town is in Karakoy Gulloglu and Hafiz Mustafa. Buy some boreks (1-2 lira) or Simits if you want to munch on something every now and then
Neat Hustle & Bustle. A great place to mix ancient with modern. Great mix af shopping and sight seeing in an compact area. worth the cost to stay in the old city.

Bosphorus Cruise. Taking the long Bosphorus Cruise is a great experience, specially considering the price, only 25 TTL. Renting at least the audio guide to understand the buildings and process of the mixed architecture and a little bit of the rich history of Istanbul is mandatory.The people from the village of fishermen are lovely. The Yoros Castle not that special but the view is amazing. The place and surroundings are not well kept and loads of garbish in the surroundings make the experience disappointing.
So much to see. Istanbul is historically fabulous and encompasses many of the religions and major empires. There is still plenty evidence let to explore.

Must see before you die. This is one of the best places I've seen on earth. It is so beautiful; and everything is close to the metro and other historical sites. I highly recommend getting a Turkish bath while you are there.

One of the great cities of the world. More people than you would think - ever been to Japan? If you stay at a good hotel - they will help you get around. Be prepared for frequent solicitations by vendors. Far less poverty that I had anticipated.

Nice Country to visit. Great experience visiting Istanbul with beautiful panoramic views - lovely architecture, great imperial mosques and churches and many others places to explore.Be careful there are lot of beggars in the streets. There is no right or wrong giving money to them. I think it is human to feel the impulse to help such as giving them a lira or two. I do not give them $$ instead I fed the little kids with burgers, ice cream, bread instead.There is a language barrier when they do not speak English. If not I will have explore more in Turkey.I would recommend to those who are interested visiting Turkey to join a holiday tour organized by travel agents.
Such a lot to see. The area south of the Golden Horn is full of really interesting sites. I have been visiting since the 60's and am still not bored with it. Food is great too!
Awesome beautiful architecture. Lots of interesting historical places, such a bright contrast of modern and historical, rich and poor areas. There're lots of places for inspiration ...

Beautiful Sites to See. The historic areas of Istanbul are a must see for anyone who goes to Istanbul. The Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, and Topkapi Palace are all great places to visit along with Galata Tower, the New Mosque and Spice Market. Also make sure to tour the Grand Bazaar for souvenirs!
Full of history. Istanbul was the navel of the world for 2,000yrs. Being able to see this history first hand is exciting.
Blue Mosque. Very impressive and worth a visit. Right beside Aya Sofya and Topkapi, so you could combine all 3 in one day.

Overwhelming. Rich in culture and Beauty.
I'd suggest long walks through this part of town to get the feel for it. Do not miss the Grand Bazar. It's fun and you'll find beautiful pieces among all the bling bling and cheap souvenirs

Wandering old part of Istanbul. The historic sites are a wonderful place to visit in Istanbul. You can experience the changes that this city underwent over the centuries. Do little research if you have time before traveling the town, and you will really appreciate the sites.

Beautiful City. Everything about historic Istanbul is as we imagined it only better. The mosques, the waterways, the shops, the museums....really a wonderful place. It's a bit like finding an author you love for the first time who's written 50 books, so you can look forward to uncovering more and more of them without fear of disappointment.

The Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace a must. Can't say we dislike anything about Istanbul..at first all of the touts for restaurants, taxis and such like might intimidate you but AS LONG AS YOU HAVE A SENSE OF HUMOUR YOU'LL BE FINE!!
Main attractions to visit. All the main mosques, palaces, historical sites and trips were great and we enjoyed all. We took advice from our hotel manager which ensured we went on the right trips.
magical place. I really fall in love with sultanahmet district.. because of many historical places such as museums, mosques.. even the roads and buildings architecture.

Blew our mind. Where do I start? We arrived by cruise ship and knew we had only 48 hours to fit as much into this inspiring city as we possibly could. In hindsight, we really had no idea! We opted to take a risk and engage a local taxi driver to take us on a tour of this beautiful and historic city. East Europe, West Europe, where do you go, what do you see? Our choice to engage a local taxi driver paid off, we could not have asked for a better guide. The Turks are arrogant, but don't be afraid to haggle the price and stand your ground. We Are not ones to spend hours inspecting every single tile within the Blue Mosque. We let our driver know and he understood our requirements; shopping! The Gran Bazar and the Spice Market are a must. Don't be put off that you have to visit the fathers, brothers, cousins, sisters shop to view "antique" carpets before you get to your destination, it is all part of the experience! And don't feel obligated to buy. Just take a breath and soak it all up. Oh, and the food is to die for. A destination that we will return to and spend so much more time.

excellent trip. Isranbul the legacy ottoman hotel very nice,We visited the blue mosque,stunning decor.we also visited the Topkapi Palace,residence of the ottoman sultans.Next day left for Canakale arrived in Gallipoli to view the poignant battlefield s of one of wwI 's bloodiest campaigns.Continues to Canakale in northwest Turkey,hub of the nature along the sea side. Visit Troy while I. Kusadasi.Also visited the city of Ephesus where we spend the day touring Ephesus and the house of the Virgini Mary. The left for the hot spring in Pamukkale ,the hot spring are called cotton castle . Very beautiful. Then travelled to Konya and saw the whirling dervish and many more.then cappadocia and visited a carpet manufacture where every carpet is hand made. Also a pottery centre where everything is hand made hand painted, The shop is so breath taking. Please visit the grand bazar and spice bazar in Istanbul. Also take time to Rome the cities on your own . The are so lovely. The food is excellent many types of cheese ,olives ,bread ,Turkish delight, turkeys tea,Aplple tea and many more.

Lots of (whitewashed) history. Don't miss the historic sites but BE CLEAR, their history is a cleaned up government version. Whenever you hire a tour guide you'll get a 'government approved guide' The info I got is completely different that the info I got 20 years ago. READ before you go, know the history. This is a government that carried out a sadistic genoicide and today says it never happened, so go, enjoy the sites, but don't believe the guides. If you ask questions, they won't answer. Not their faults, there are plants everywhere that listen to them and they'll lose their jobs
Loved it💖💓. Was an Amazing experience taking a walk around the historical area.. Loved the architecture of each building .. Reminded of the great Empire that we had in the History

Istanbul is full of history. During my stay I've visited the historical places in Istanbul. It really amazed me how many different palaces, mosques and other monuments are here. Also how they were manage to build so big buildings in those ages. It is really a must to see!
Amazing. The city thrives with historic artifacts, Sultan Ahmed being the most iconic landmark, and visits are free!

Enough to fill a whole week just here. Between the markets, the mosques, the museums and palaces, Sultanahmet and the Historic Area offers enough to fill an entire week of tourism! Just be sure that you check which places are open when, as many of the major sights are closed at least one day a week. It would be a shame to come all the way to Istanbul and then miss Topkapi Palace or the Hagia Sohpia because of poor planning!

“It is amazing town”. So many different architectural monuments I haven’t seen in my life, very rich heritage. To look everything in this town takes you min. 5-6 days.What to see? Traditionally : Topkapi Palace (necessary for the audio tour ), The Blue, Sofia Museum, Dolmabahce Palace, the Galata Tower (visible from his fabulous urban panorama), an ancient underground water reservoir , technology museums Gulhane park and the park itself war museum, take a walk through the labyrinths of old city Sultanahmet, Yildiz park and situated in residence there, pass a hanging bridge over the Bosphorus, after it Ortakoj area to admire the sights and eat Kumpir. Taste nowhere more product not drink Boza. Float to the Princes Islands. Visit the Grand Bazaar and have the pleasure to get lost in it (I have such experience). Visit spice market . Enjoy the oldest Turkish hammam Çemberlitaş. Buy mini boat trip through the Bosphorus. After the Galata bridge to eat a sandwich with grilled mackerel!
Historical Sites. Close proximity to famous sights - Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Basilica Cistern. Museum ( All Liked).Close to Tram system which is EXCELLENT and value for money
Better from outside. Aya Sofia is under renovation, interior spoiled a lot. Blue Mosque is allrt, Topkapi treasures are very limited
Just facinating. If you have transport card and museum card, you can get as much emotions in every single day, as possible

Have a Guide, Bypass the waiting lines. Have a Guide, Bypass the waiting lines for the cistern, aya sofia, blue mosque, inner center etc - and they teach you the cheap way of using public transport instead of being tourist trapped for hours in a cab

Still a scaffold in Aya Sophia since my first visit in 1994. I'd not seen the lighting in the place during the winter time. I've visited during summer and fall with more access than this visit. But, the place still amazes me.

Istanbul vacation. Total different culture that was amazing to see. The carpet peddlers became annoying rather quickly. I think the trick to enjoying Istanbul is to not stay in the Faith district but spread out and see Takim square and the Asia part of the city too.

Must see. That's what you're in Istanbul for. The major historic sites are a must see for first time visitors. It's like traveling 1000 years back in time, yet you have the convenience of modern transport and shopping galore. The area is compact and walking is the best way around.
Istanbul Is lovely and Maintained Historical Place. Local guide, poice and citizen are very good and co operative its giving feel like we are at own home town

Travel from Asia to Europe by Boat. I mostly liked to Sea coast visit by Boat at Marmara Sea
I do not like the way people smoking here in public places at Istanbul, Turkey

Beautiful City. Istanbul was the starting and finishing port of a Mediterrean cruise and it was definitely the highlight of a wonderful cruise. The old city is stunningly beautiful, full of magnificent buildings and historic sites. It is definitely worth hiring a guide so you can better appreciate the history and relevance of the sites you will see. Should be on everyone's bucket list.
breath taking. Istanbul is a place rich with history, an absolute must visit at least once in any trip, I actually see my self visiting the area ,multiple times
super. for me the best ctiy in this World and most be capital ctiy of the allov the World has the best lokacion and a breege from eourup to asia süper

Istanbul. The beauty of the old city with old buildings, mosques and palaces cannot be described in words. See it for yourself.The food is one of the best I have tasted across the world.Bought a few beautiful Turkish chandeliers.Will visit the place again for sure.
Breath taking. If you like Islamic art then visit Istanbul! Go to Sultanahmet area to see all the historical places. You need at least a week to justify visiting Istanbul.
Amazing history. The Hagia Sophia is a must see! The entire old city is beautiful. I recomend visiting in March as the crowds are much less.

Historic areas are amazing - dating back over 1500 years ago. We loved seeing all the rich history of Istanbul in the historic area. Don't miss the Bosporus Cistern, the Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. Each one is closed on one day of the week so you really need a good week to see all of the amazing sites and soak up the rich culture.

loftyrob198. You can't go wrong anywhere in Istanbul - history is all around you. The Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar are particularly interesting as is the History of Islamic Science and Technology Museum just behind the Tourist Office in Gulhane Park.

Must Visit. Been back from Istanbul a week. An amazing city. Had an excellent 4 nights. Stayed in Sultanhamet district. I think the best place to stay if visiting the major sights is Sultanhamet. Felt safe at all times including a couple of quite late nights. They have finally got the money to repair the main sights consequently a small amount of scaffolding etc at some sights. Being English the bartering and in some areas the pestering is a little annoying but it is part of the culture so I cannot complain. My advice would be buy a good guide book and map and just wander. You cannot go wrong.
