it was a blast!. Istanbul was the first european city we visited and rightfully so. It sits between asia and europe and has a cultural blend of the two continents. it has so much to offer to tourists. wherever you stay in istanbul you will sure enjoy the myriad of choices from history to architecture, food and people. we stayed for 3 nights and were able to go to all major attractions. the streets were busy but it was easy to move around because the transport system was adequate. for any first time traveller, check out reviews of must-see, must-do and must-eat so you have a complete experience. our IT included Hagia Sophia, blue mosque, hippodrome, basilica cistern, topkapi palace, archaeological museum, eminonu neighborhood, galata bridge, galata tower, grand bazaar, spice bazaar, istiklal avenue, taksim square, dolmabahce palace, bebek and ortakoy neighborhood, camlica hill plus mt Uludag in the nearby island. it was a great short vacation and we planned the entire IT on our own except for the trip to Bursa/Mt Uludag for the ski experience. would love to go back in spring.
I love this place. It is an amazing place...very historical, friendly people, delicious food. I love this place! A must visit.
Istanbul never sleeps. I like it all!!! Istanbul is so mystical, full of history, and people very friendly, love the food b/c everything is so fresh
1st time in Istanbul. Easy to get around. Hotel was a great location. Generally friendly locals. Staying at Magnaura Palace Hotel was a delight..

nice city. very nice city, full of history unfortunately the constant solicitors make it a bit harder. good food! be careful with the men that polish shoes! and the people seeking money in the streets including small children!

Two days in Sultanahmet. Everything is within walking distance, but the entry fees do mount up. Visit the Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Harem, the Basilica Cistern and the Museum of Islamic Art, finish day one with a Hammam visit. Day 2 the Bazaars and a boat trip. Day three visit the Beyoglu district with a walk to the top of the Galata Tower and then on to Taksim Square.

Just my experience- Tips and Hints. This is not a guide, just an account of our experiences that may be useful on your visit to a truly amazing city.Prayer Times- Plan your visits to key places around prayer times, as this is when it can be quieter, however when prayer is over things can get very, very busy.Haggle- It’s not something us Brits are used to doing, but haggle, at first it feels weird but once you get going its quite fun. I found that when you ask a price, if you say nothing and walk away it shows your not interested, but if you respond with an offer this shows you want the item so the vendor will try to keep the sale. Start with offering a third of their original offer and work from there. Keep things fun, don't get too up tight but have in mind how much you’re willing to pay.Grand Bazar- Is very bazar, this is a place I can guarantee you will get lost and feel like you are walking around in circles. This is part of the charm and experience of the bazar. It's a bit like a Chinese finger trap, best thing to do is stay calm, have a cup of tea, breathe and then plan your escape route. You may get it right, if not stop for another tea and a kebab.Clumsy Shoe Shiners- This is a comical scam and funny to watch. There are quite a few shoeshine people walking about. As they walk past you with their little shoeshine box out falls one of their brushes. Oh no I hear you cry! So you pick the brush up and call after the guy, who is apparently oblivious to dropping the brush and now owes his living to you for returning it. He simply must repay you by polishing your shoes, trainers, flip-flops or toenails. However you end up paying him for this service. Everyone has got to earn a living and they are great actors but just look out for it.“I know you from the hotel”- as we walked about we were approached by someone saying they knew us from the hotel, this caught us of guard and being British and not waiting to be rude we would talk with them, this would then lead to questions about what we were doing for the day and amazingly who ever we were talking to they had a shop we should visit. Everyone has a shop you should visit. My advice: take it or leave it but the line about knowing you from the hotel felt like a conversation starter.Confusing Sweets- if you find all the different types of baklava, Turkish delight, puddings, teas and coffees mind blowing the best place to go is Edebiyat Kiraathanesi. Located off the tram at Sultanamet it’s on the main road just down from the tram stop. It is an amazing little place where you can sit down and you are given a menu that is like a catalogue with glossy pictures and descriptions of all 149 items they sell. Take your time and select one of two. This will not be the only time you visit this shop on your visit I guarantee it. Explore Everything- its tempting to stick to the touristy things in a city but I highly recommend the Two Continents Tour with My Local Guide Istanbul…. This took us around some parts of Istanbul that we had not been too, we tasted food we would never have been aware of or been brave enough to order in a restaurant or from a food market. We heard stories that you can’t find in the tour books and also tired the Hubbly Bubbly pipe in an authentic environment but with an excellent friendly guide. Well worth the price and only the price of a good meal out.Museum Pass- if you’re planning on going to a few museums then buying a pass works out much cheaper, this gives you 72 hours access to lots of places but there are some exclusions. You can buy these from dedicated placed located around the main areas off the Hippodrome.
SHOULD VISIT IT ALL. Especially Ayia Sophia it was the best for us really magical! its very beautiful to see Christians and Muslims mixed in one location.. i personally recommend it the most!

Use your cards. Make sure you buy the instanbulkart, your public transportation pass. It costs 10 TL (6 TL for the card and 4 TL charge) and you can charge it with any amount in almost every tram and metro station. It can be used by a group of people, so you can buy one and use it as many times as the number of persons in your group in each station. It is cheaper than the tickets (4 TL ticket, 2,15 - 2,75 TL with card every time). Also buy the museum pass (85 TL for 3 days, 150 TL for 5 days). You can visit most top attractions such as Topkapi Palace, Harem, Hagia Sophia Museum. Have a great time!

Take your time and appreciate this area. There are many little gems to be discovered in this area. Ask for directions or take a Lonely Planet guide book. But a word of warning - beware of the carpet sellers. Some can be quite unscrupulous.

Historic peninsula. As a resident of İstanbul, i occasionally go to old part of the city to smell the air of history. You can easily spend a couple of days on this peninsula, but if you are here for just two days, here is what you can do: start the day with Topkapi Palace. Then you can go on with Haghia Sophia Museum and the Cistern. The second day, spend your morning in Grand Bazaar walking along the narrow alleys. Then walk down ttowards Eminonu to see Spice Bazaar. Just dont forget to keep an eye on your bag as these are the most crowded streets of the old part. Dont forget to eat fish sandwich near the Galata Bridge. İf you still have time walk along the bridge to see Karakoy and Galata Tower.

Charging around in snow and polar wind. We did the usual tourist round - Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, and Egyptian Bazaar. This was Day 1 of an RBK coach holiday, and included lunch at a restaurant opposite the lower entrance to Topkapi Palace. There's very little chance to sit down and rest under shelter, when the weather is this bad - you just have to keep going! The more sheltered rooms of Topkapi were very full of tourists, but it was still a fascinating place. The treasures are awesome! If you're visiting the Blue Mosque, or indeed any mosques, make sure you're wearing shoes that are easy to get off and on again. The room for taking off shoes is very small and gets crowded, and people of limited mobility can be jostled. Once in the side-entry of the Blue Mosque there is no way to get out without going through the whole mosque, so be sure you want to go through the shoes-off, shoes-on again! Older people with limited mobility may find this difficult.Hagia Sofia is utterly gorgeous, a masterpiece of Byzantine glory, and the work to uncover and restore the original mosaics is most impressive. It is no longer a mosque or a church but a museum, and has very good historical presentations in the front corridor. There's even somewhere to sit! The cats are friendly as well. From previous visits I know the Museum at Topkapi Palace is well worth a visit - it was built to rival the British Museum, and in terms of public exhibition rooms it is certainly close in size. From Egyptian mummies to Assyrian tiled walls of winged lions, to ancient Sumerian cuneiform tablets, to a section of the original medieval chain that once closed off the Golden Horn to hostile ships - the amount and variety of the exhibits is stunning.By the time we'd slogged around Topkapi, Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosque the weather had deteriorated and only a few decided to brave the Egyptian Bazaar - doing all this on two hours' sleep wasn't a clever idea really.
Historical places at Istanbul. Most of them are not kept as they should have.. They should all be valued with more care and there are still much to learn about this. Visit them as much as you can...
Excellent. Everyone should see Istanbul and it's historical places.Especially arround of Sultanahmet and oldcity area.

Too much to see in toolittle time. Easy city to travel in, so many mosques, large and typical mediterranean markets, lots of choices of different food, old world charm with modern conveniences in one destination. Maybe I will manage to go there again.

Very enjoyable experience. Spent 3 days there and every day was as fun, exciting and interesting as the others. So much to see and not so crowded that it takes away from the experience. Most attractions there have an admission but discount combo or group tickets are available. Between the paid attractions, the open spaces are great to walk though and enjoy. Local people are very friendly and respectful. Ate at some attraction cafes because thats where our group was at meal times, but walked past many interesting restaurants in the area.

Very safe feeling. I got to visit all the historical sites in Istanbul. They were well worth the trip. My tour was organized by the cruise ship, but the guides were terrific. I started off missing my first bus, along with five other people. They put us in a mini van to catch up with the tour groups. They said not to worry people do this all the time. We met the tour in front of the Blue Mosque. There are 3 historical building pretty close together. Exciting to see. I was so busy trying to get just the right picture, and not listening to my ear buds for the guide, that I was left behind. I found the tour people and they had a young man walk me to the Palace where my tour group was now located. I was never afraid nor felt alone. I am a single woman and was not with anyone on the tour. (I do not usually miss my tours) we also saw the spice market. You do need to see this but be aware it is very, very crowed,and they said it was a light day.

Budget your time so you can wander. We picked a restaraunt on a small side street and wandered around till we found it. At night, the monuments are beautifully lit up and the effect is wonderful. There are explanations in English and Turkish in most places of the key sites as well. Don't rush it or you will miss something for sure.

Great place to walk around. Just amazing to walk around the area, all the historical site, people walking on the street...simply amazing. Good to spend some time for a Turkish bath, or hang out at the local cafe for some nice (and strong) Turkish coffee. However be careful of your belonging if you're a female tourist traveling in small group.
Magical!!. So much history, so much beauty everywhere you look! Love the ambience of it all! Will definitely be back to Istanbul!
one of the best. walking from one place to another in this area is amazing, it's atmosphere surrounds you.... it is just that, atmosphere and calm, but sometimes tourist sellers are really bothering
Nice places. All places in the historic areas are beautifull. If you want to go to Istambul you shouldn't miss it.

Worth travelling far. The Dolmabahce Palace, The Blue Mosque and Aya Sophia, including all the area along the Bosphorus are simply breathtaking. Their historic value is so important and various and the architectural work absolutely beautiful. I can't say I'm impressed with the rest of the city. It is dirty, expensive and over crowded. People are very kind but sometimes too pushy. Public transport is working well. If you ignore the occasional smells of some passengers it's the most efficient way to travel to some locations, but you can visit most of them on foot cause they are grouped in specific areas. While planning your trip be sure to check when different sights are open to visitors because you can miss to see some of them if you are not there for a couple of days. Bring your money, almost nothing is free.
Great experience!!!. The Blue Mosque,Hagia Sophia are marvels of architecture ,all preserved so well. Wortha visit,even if you have to stand in long queues !

Once in a life time visit to a beautiful and charming City. 3-4 days need to take it all in.. We keep coming back and find something new everytime. go for it on tours og by your self. No problems to find your way. take care not to be fooled by the different sales persons of all goods.
Beautiful Walking City. Istanbul is a beautiful city on the Bosporus! This is a must visit historic city bridging two continents. The people are always friendly and helpful.
So much history!. We were blown away by the historic attractions in Sultanahmet. Highly recommended. Take a look at Khan Academy for video talks of Hagia Sophia.

lovely Historic Istanbul!. I stayed in a hotel in Beyoglu near the famous Istikal street, lined with shops from one end which had the Taksim square to the other end of the street which has Bekistas and kardikoy on the other end.Along the way check the Galata tower, buy Turkish delight(beware of the cheap pre boxed sweets, rubbish!) Buy souvenirs like fridge magnets, key hobs, blown glass etc. Dont forget to buy squeezed fresh juice from the stalls and anchovy fish everywhere!You can take a train, or a boat or a bus anywhere on the route for 1 jeton(4TL). No where is far in this area.if you can take the Bosphorus cruise: straddle 2 continents at the same time. i have been on both the full cruise which took all day from the European side to the Asian side. Only one boat company does the full cruise ill put up the name when i recall it and they have limited seats. But you have to join a queue and stand for hours, the cruise starts at 10am and takes about 3hrs to get to the other side. The boat docks for about 2 hours then another 3 hours back. My advice, take the half cruise its equally as beautiful and you wont get so exhausted.Dont leave istanbul without drinking turkish tea, having some turkish delight and taking a turkish bath.visit as many historic sights and mosques as you can, beautifully preserved over the centuries.

Awesome architecture. I suppose the Blue Mosque has more frills, but architecture of this mosque is matchless. You may omit the Blue Mosque and go to this mosque directly. You will get a better experience and not wait in line!
My experience. Amazing architecture and history, good food, great views and rich culture.Salesmen can be aggressive and annoying, specially in the old market.
ISTANBUL MUST VISIT. A must see place ,rich in culture and beauty.October/November is the best time to visit and move around.Ibtiklal street visit at evening is must.

Amazing Istanbul. The historic areas of Istanbul are so easy to navigate. Make sure you get a good map and someone to explain the transport systems and off you go. If you have limited time in the city, then decide what is most important for you to see. Some of the places are so close, but you could spend 2-3 hours in each place, so make sure you divide your time in order of preference. The Turkish people are friendly and helpful. The public transport is easy to use and reliable. We came in February, we had some warm days, no coat needed, some very cold days, hats, scarves and gloves needed, and some rain, but we loved every minute of it. If you are in the Hagia Sofia/Blue Mosque area it can be a bit off putting with people asking to 'help you' all the time, or to show you their rug stores nearby, but a firm 'no thank you', or to just ignore is all it takes. We always felt safe. At this time of year we had no queues, anywhere. We tried many of the food outlets nearby and were not disappointed, whether for something to eat or just a refreshing cup of Turkish chay (cay). We stayed for 7 nights and would love to come back again one day, one of the best cities we have ever been to. Tip....stay in a hotel close to the historic old city, we stayed in the Amira and would recommend to anyone.

Turkey October 2014. Great trip and great country, the food, the history and the ambiance is breathtaking.

Treasure Trove of Sites. Istanbul's long history means myriad sites from the past that attract tourists. Sultanahmet -- the city's historic core -- brims with fascinating places to see. These include the Blue Mosque with its six minarets; Hagia Sophia, a Byzantine wonder; the eerily beautiful 6th-century Basilica Cistern; the Topkapi Palace; and the list goes on. Though I'm a history buff, I don't think one has to be in order to appreciate what attractions offer today in terms of architecture, religious significance, etc.Sultanahmet's historic sites seem to be on everyone's "must see" list so the lines can get long for admission. On our recent visit during the off-season, we noted a huge line for Hagia Sophia but walked right in for a repeat visit to the Basilica Cistern. When we've been here in the summer, though, extremely long lines appear everywhere. During that time, I was able to enter Hagia Sophia immediately by going as soon as it opened in the morning and essentially had the place to myself for about half an hour. I've seen all the sites so enjoy simply wandering around the clean, safe area, sometimes ducking into shops or going to one of the many cafes or restaurants.Because Istanbul is an old city -- kind of a living museum -- other districts also offer attractions of historic interest. For example, one of my favorites is the stunning Dolmabahce Palace, built in the 19th century during the Ottoman Empire. The palace stands by the water in the Besiktas District. I'm also attracted to the mosaics and frescoes in the Edirnekapi neighborhood's Byzantine Chora Church.For first-time visitors, I recommend a guide book and a look at Trip Advisor's list of Istanbul attractions. These will help narrow down what historic sites to see, based on interest and time available.

A remarkable experience. My partner and I visited most of the must-see attractions on the European side of Istanbul during our week-long visit there. The city is very old indeed and has a wonderful mix of Eastern and Western cultures, making it truly one of a kind. It's definitely one of my favourite holiday destinations thus far, although it might be wiser to visit during spring time (March / April) as our experience has taught us that winter in Turkey can be rather unpredictable (sunshine one day, snow shower the next). The top attraction ought to be the Topkapi Palace (30 TL for general entry & another 15 TL for the Harem, where the more interesting rooms are located). If you're really keen on learning about the history of the palace, sign up for a guided tour (approximately 40 - 50 TL/person) which lasts about 1 h and 15 min. The tour guides are everywhere, so choose wisely. If you don't mind paying for a guided tour, the trick is to sign up at the very last minute so you can "bargain" yourself a deal as they're typically interested to get as many people as possible to join the group. Alternatively, you can always pay for an audio guide which costs 20 TL.Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Basilica Cistern are all quite interesting. When you're done walking around the city, do take the official Bosphorus ferry tour run by Sehir Hatlari. It's the cheapest option and definitely the most reliable one. A short cruise will only run on the weekends during winter time (up to mid-March) whereas a long cruise (~ 1.5 hour one way from Eminonu to A.Kavagi) leaves the pier at 10:35 on a daily basis (15 TL one way or 25 TL return). The ferry will dock at A. Kavagi (there’s a fort that you can visit) for approximately 3 hours and you’re free to roam around the fishing village (which has been described by some as a tourist trap). The journey from A.Kavagi to Eminonu departs at 15:15.We got off the ferry at Sariyer instead (second last stop) and wandered around the little town before taking a bus (#25E to Kabatas or #25T to Taksim Square) to get back Istanbul city centre. The whole bus journey takes about an hour or so, as it cruises along the coastal road picking up and dropping off passengers along the way. Only choose this option if you’re in no hurry to get back to the city centre. In term of food, expect to pay around an average of 15 TL per dish if you’re eating in a restaurant, or even a local eatery. Most of our meals cost between 45 to 60 TL for two people. It’s not cheap but it’s also pretty standard throughout the city. We ate at a local restaurant that’s quite far from the city centre and thus, can be considered as “non touristy” but still paid the same amount as we did around the tourist epicentre.  On a slightly negative note, be extra mindful of the countless opportunistic crooks scattered around the city. On our first evening there, we were approached by someone who pretended to be a tourist looking for directions while we were out on a stroll. He was obviously trying to get us to follow him to a random place in town for a “friendly” but ultimately over-priced drink. Run a quick search and you’ll be amazed by the range of tactics used by the unscrupulous individuals there. We’ve travelled quite extensively but the petty crooks in Istanbul are by far the most aggressive. Hence, be vigilant if you’re visiting for the first time. Our advice is to decline unwanted offers politely but be firm. They’ll usually leave you alone if they sense that they aren’t going to get anything from you.

Stunning & historic. Istanbul is a city for treasure hunters- it is filled with history from the time when it was capital of Byzantine Empire & subsequently Ottoman Empire. Blue Mosque leaves you speechless, it's architecture is stunning and it's so spiritual from inside. It's free to visit, but as it's an operational mosque please give respect as per local culture. Note on Fridays, the mosque is very busy in the afternoon (inside and courtyard is full) with Friday prayers taking place at about 1 pm. The mosque will be closed to tourists during this time.Hagia Sophia was a Church in Byzantine times, a mosque during Ottoman rule and is now a museum. It's full of history with artefacts from it's Christian & Muslim pasts. Topkapi Palace was in use for 400 years by Ottoman Sultans and you can observe the architecture, artefacts (e.g. Sultan's thrones, royal flasks etc), a section is also dedicated to holy personalities of Islam (as Ottoman Empire was the caliphate, it had many holy relics of Islam) and there are great views of Bosphorus from the Palace courtyard. The palace is huge and I will recommend at least half a day for your visit. Note you will need a separate ticket to visit the Harem area of the palace (15 TL) and it's a must see.I bought 3 days Istanbul Museum pass (costs 85 TL) which allows access to Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace including Harem and other Museums (Museum of Islamic Science & Technology, Archaeological Museum, Museum of Turkish & Islamic Art, Hagia Eirene, Great Palace Mosaic Museum). If you plan to visit these other museums then the pass is much more economical and most of these museums are walking distance from each other. I really liked the Museum of Islamic Science and Technology which included sections like, architecture, physics, chemistry, medicine, geography though would prefer a guide for this as some areas were a bit technical so would be good if someone can explain in layman's language. This museum is situated in Gulhane Park.Grand bazaar is not only historical (built in 15th century), it is full of traditional Turkish shops. If you like shopping, you will be spoilt for choice. Also, I thought Grand bazaar had the best currency exchange shops with very good FX rates (I was changing GBP to TL).Overall Istanbul is on the top of my list of best places to visit.

Tourists beware. I was really looking forward to our cruise's 1.5 day stop in Istanbul. I was excited about seeing the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia as well as experiencing our first visit to a Muslim city. Our ship arrived at 1:00 pm and we scheduled the Bosporus Cruise for the afternoon. We were harassed by street vendors trying to sell us things the entire time we ventured from the ship. It really made any movement cumbersome. It was only when we were alone (free time on our tours) that we were less harassed. The street vendors in Istanbul were more aggressive than in any other European city we visited. They just don't take "no" for an answer and will follow you until you finally act mean. Being nice\polite will only make it worse. I am not aggressive or mean by nature and forcing me to act this way ruined a good part of our visit. Please note that most people\companies accept Euros, American dollars and Turkish lira. Ensure that you ask for change in the same denomination as you give them (before you make the purchase).It seemed that everyone we encountered wanted money. The Grand Bazaar was interesting but we could not pass a shop without the shop owners soliciting us. All we had to do was look at an item or stop at a shop window and they swarmed us. Nothing has a price tag in the tourist section of the Grand Bazaar and the initial price they quote is so high that bargaining is almost impossible (imagine something worth 5 euro on being quoted as 90 euro).If we ever revisit Istanbul, I will book tours with smaller Viator groups. Being in the large 50+ person groups made us targets for harassment. Also, you are less apt to find people who can speak English in Turkey.

Fascinating place. Lots to see, easy to get around. People are very friendly and helpful ( in our hotel) We had an excellent guide for a whole day. We toured many places in our own pace. Lots of history and other local cultural information. 3 days is not enough, at least a week would be nice.

A must !. Visited in may, Istanbul is on my top 3 cities. Strongly suggested is the boat in the morning, so that you can see the Mosque skyline. I took the ferry on the European side and the view was beautiful, it was like going back into history.... :) fantastic city!

haia sofia. I was disappointed with this attraction. Originally it was a catholic cathedral until it was invaded by the Islamics and turned I to a mosque. Unlike Anywhere I'd Ever Been. While Istanbul was much more European than I had expected, the historic areas were so incredibly cool and unlike anywhere I had ever been. Great city and culture!. Istanbul is where east meets west and not surprisingly is a very tolerant culture. Predominantly Muslim, the vast majority of Turks are respectful of others beliefs while enjoying the practice of their religion.There is so much to see and do in Istanbul. The city is full of amazing historical sites, great food, and shopping. I did not realize that Turkey was such a large producer of all kinds of products making it a great place to shop for bargains.One could spend 3-4 days (or more) in Istanbul and be thoroughly entertained.

The Grand Bazaar. We had heard about it and had been told not to miss it. However, we could not imagine how immense the area of the Bazaar really is. As far as your eyes can see, the Bazaar is simply one shop or store after another of the most beautiful, interesting, gaudy, and exotic articles we could imagine. At some point all the stores selling the identical items all look alike and all the items appear to be the same: jewelry, leather goods, apparel, electronics, souvenirs, accessories and food. When you finish going up and down one avenue of stores there is another. This is a covered, indoor souk (middle eastern market) and what impressed us the most was how clean it was. The Grand Bazaar must host thousands upon thousands of people every day and yet it is orderly and, as I said, very clean. At some point, we stopped looking at individual shops and stalls and just took in the atmosphere. Plan on at least two hours to browse unless you want to do some serious shopping here. If you do, you will need a long time to go from store to store and from stall to stall to compare prices and quality.

History comes alive!. Istanbul is a treasure trove of ancient history. There are sultan's palaces, mosques, churches turned into mosques, Roman ruins with stunning mosaics, gardens, a grand bazaar that goes on forever, a breathtaking underground cistern that has to be seen to be believed......all of this within walking distance of each other. A great resource in seeing all of the above is a web site: turkeytravelplanner.com Tom Brosnahan, author of many guide books, gives you a wealth of information on how to see this amazing city. He gives you background information on all the top sites, how and when to see them as well as restaurants and hotels. A top tip from him is to buy a "museum pass" before you visit the sites. This will save you a lot of money in entrance fees and time as you will not have to wait in line to purchase tickets. We purchased ours from our hotel....Dersaadet Hotel. Please see my review on Dersaadet. It is a perfect location to see all there is to see in Sultanahmet.

A Treasure of a City. The historical area of Istanbul is a fantastic visit. There are many attractions (mosques, palaces, gardens, Grand Bazaar) all within a short walking distance of each other. The streets are lined with boutiques, coffee shops, souvenir stores, restaurants, etc. The district is located on several hills, but nothing that would provide a challenge to your walk, but here also is a tram line. Signs are posted for major attractions. You will have business owners and shop keepers calling out to you to solicit business. As in most cities street venders are everywhere (don't fall for the shoe shine guy dropping his brush--just leave it and walk on). Enjoy the people watching, sounds (including calls to prayer), smells, and culture of this historic city.

Istanbul is a very big city .During the day there are so many people walking the streets and so many cars on the road .There is never a shortage of people want you to visit their shop ,eat at their restaurant or try to scam you .A good rule of thumb is to bargain, bargain, bargain. Also ask how much first before ordering at a restaurant .You can easily get around on the tram or by walking to your destination .There are bus routes for further places .Take time to see the grand bazar early as it gets very crowded and hard to walk around through all the people .Some shop owners will graciously offer you tea which is impolite to refuse. :-)At dinner time we found nice terrasses on quieter streets to enjoy great food and Baklava.

Mix of Christianity and Islam. Istanbul has been an interesting city for many civilisations and for the most recents of 2, Byzantium and Ottomans, she has been the most valued of all. Ottomans tried to protect the sacred Christian buildings and kept them erect along the centuries. Now you can see few of the good samples of both civilisations on the same location; the old town square Sultan Ahmet Meydani. The best of all are the Hagia Sofia Cathedral and The Blue Mosque. The Cathedral is magnificent with its size and architectural beauty. Although it has been sort of converted into a mosque after the aottoman invasion in 1453, it has not been destroyed at all. So you can still see the frescoes and mosaics on the walls, beautiful, next to big wooden plates of Koran verbs. It is a museum that shall not be missed and it is a life time beauty to see. Next to it you can visit the infamous Blue Mosque which was built by a famous Ottoman architect, Mimar Sinan, as a show case of his competence in building the most beautiful mosque of the Ottoman Empire. It is as beautiful as the cathedral and a must see place. You will get shocked with all the ingenious details thought by that architect. Your spiritual side will have a shower with all the blue glass windows and the amazing architecture. Then probably the same day you can have a quick visit to the Basilica Cistern in the same square. It is the under ground water reservoir of the Byzantine which has been turned into a museum with a medieval lighting atmosphere. Famous Medusa head column is what you must see there amongst all the others. The next day you can visit Topkapi Palace, the long used Ottoman Palace.With all the buildings to see, gardens, churches, mosques, artefacts, etc you better reserve one full day for this palace. Don't miss the restaurant within the garden, that serves authentic Ottoman food. Can be a little expensive for a lunch but worth. You can also go there for dinner. Well, this would be my short 2 day trip to Istanbul's old town centre. Bear in mind, it is a massive city and it requires a good 4-5 day trip for a good coverage of all spectacular locations. Hope this short description gives you some tips for what to expect and see in Istanbul. So go there and get amazed...

Love Istanbuls historic area. We were docked in Istanbul for 1 1/2 days from a cruise. On this port we decided to do our own walking tour. Taxis were available right across from the port exit. Prices were very reasonable going into Istanbul, outrageous coming back (walk if you can, or take the trolley).If you decide to go out on your own instead of booking a tour, here is a link to website that provided us with a good walking tour including, the Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Mosaic Museum (inside a small bizarre), Sultan Ahmet Park, Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and more.  http://www.bigboytravel.com/europe/turkey/istanbul/freewalkingtourYou will have people come up to you and ask if you need directions. That is code for I want to take you to my store and sell you something. No matter what we encountered, everyone was courteous and there was no real pressure, just a no thank you was enough.The area is very clean. We never saw any garbage on the streets. You will see many stray cats and dogs. They are fed and kept by the state and are in very good condition. They do not bother anyone, so don't be wary of them.Not far from the historic sites is the Grand Bazaar. A must see. We enjoyed this place immensely and had a great time bartering for our purchases. In general, pay about 1/3 the initial asking price. What an amazing place. Can't wait to return.

The sky line views across the city are very distinctiveI am increasingly uncomfortable with the anti American tone in the City and their pro Islamist leader. Like Cairo, the days of a safe visit maybe fleeting. Very sad.
History on a plate. The unusual and magnificent buildings and the fact that they date back to before Roman times and there is still so much to see and experience

Nice to walk around. I like narrow streets and historic buildings. The old area is very clean despite the crowds. Everything is well organised, a lot of security checks in hte main attractions though.

Lots to see and do. Most of the sights in Istanbul are located in this quarter and it also enjoys some great views over the surrounding Bosphorus river.Topkapi Palace is a must-see, the Hagia Sofia is worth a visit and the Blue Mosque is incredible from the outside (I didn't go inside). You could also check out the Grand Bazaar for a more hectic experience.Lots of places to buy a snack or coffee around the park between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia. There's a coffee shop at the turkish baths across from the Hagia Sofia which sells Turkish coffee, which is worth trying too. Intense flavour. Sip slowly and enjoy.Like most major European tourist hubs, there are lots of locals wanting to befriend (and inevitably profit from) you or sell you things, although - in my experience - they were never unpleasant or threatening.

istanbul is gorgeous. Which contains many historic, magnificent, precious treasure of history, time and space you are unable to make the distinction, so you can feel it.also try to make her melt every moment istanbul is gorgeous

PALACE WITH THE DIFFERENT. The archetecture of the palace is different from other European Palace. I like the biggest diamond and the jewel. Tourist friendly with toilet and coffee area. Dislike no enough time to see the place
THE place to explore. while strolling down the streets i wasn't expecting many things to explore, even if u don't want to buy anything. one can really have fun exploring the area.

Unbelievable beauty. We were privileged to view see the Blue Mosque, The Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi Palace all on one day - they are literally all close together across from the Sultanahmet Square. You have to see the beauty of these historical places to trully appreciate them. To jump the long queues buy your tickets from the kiosks at each one (blue Mosque entrance is free). The Dolmabache Palace is another must view, but can only be done on a guided tour. Be careful of the many guys that will approach you, wanting to assist you on a private tour !

Played Treasure Hunt with Team. Nice place on historical areas of Istanbul. Some famous Hollywood shootings happened there. The area where old bazaar was located was amazing. Traditional arts selling around.

Have fun exploring. Very enjoyable way to spend the a day exploring this area, take your time. Generally the locals are pretty helpful -- even if they do have something to sell and usually will stop hassling you after a few "no's", but remember to smile and have fun.

What a skyline!. We first viewed the old town from the riverbank on the other side of the Bosphorus and the skyline was breathtaking! When we made it across to the Blue Mosque, we hadn't expected it to be in such a beautiful, spacious and leafy area, which meant that although there were thousands of tourists, it still felt spacious and relaxed - just gorgeous. The trip to the Grand Bazaar similarly so (though we were there quite late on Friday afternoon), what we expected would be a frenetic experience really wasn't and we pottered up and down the vibrant aisles of stalls enjoying a pleasant banter with the stall holders (and had coffee and cake to die for when we fancied a sit down!)

absolutely beautiful. istanbul is such an amazing city,with architecture , history, art and culture combined with such friendly and pleasant people , cobbled streets, cafes, art galleries and such a mix of so many different cultures, churches, mosques palaces, jewish quarters makes it worth visiting again and again.

Beautiful. Amazing to walk around. The only thing that I don't like is the fact that its a tourist trap, cafe's restaurants are very pricey and not so good quality. We spent a fortune on rubbish food. There are some good restaurants. My tip is to avoid any restaurant were they try to beg you to eat there!
A beautiful mosh pit.. Lovely but very busy. I would try and do them all in a day then head to the outer suburbs like Balat.
Istanbul. The history of Istanbul and the things to see are incredible. The people are very friendly, the food great and cultural experience is fascinating.
Historic Istanbul. Simply appreciate where you are. Put away the camera and the iPhone and take it all in. Enjoy the sights, the sounds, the smells, the street noise.

Great way to see this amazing city. We were offered numerous boat trips by the touts all over the old town of Istanbul, however, this trip, albeit slightly more expensive than the rest offers a trip to remember, truly awe inspiring view of the city, informative and great service. Fully recommended.

must visit. do not go to egyptian souks. Nothing to see or buy. Not so clean.
I wanted to go out quickly from there.
Historical Attractions. You will like the historical places in Istanbul, if you're a history lover you will feel the passion.
A good day to spend. Some great glimpses of roman and ottoman history. The walks are good passing through nice shoos and very clean neat environment.

Just Walk to Enjoy. The historic Sultanahmet area is best enjoyed by just walking around at your own pace without time constraints of tour groups. In the evening we just sat outside the Blue Mosque and enjoyed the view and people though some beggars, especially precocious, can be demanding. Just ignore them and keep a close eye on your belongings.

Istanbul - absolute visit needed. Time in Istanbul provides a view of life so very different than in the US. First - please know that we, my wife and i, felt safe, non threatened in our week there. The "safe" was true during the day, in the crowds (always crowds - everywhere) and at night even for a walk along the Bosporus. True - we were in the heart of the city - but we were continually "in the middle" of significant crowds of people on the sidewalks, in the shops and just everywhere. A lot of tea was enjoyed - seemed you needed to have tea almost before talking to a merchant or a person when visiting. The "sights" are significant, impressive and unlike anywhere else in the world (Europe/Asia/Australia) we have been. Sights beyond the hallmarks of Europe - the Mosques, the Grand Basaar and the history at the crossroads of Asia and Europe.

Capital of empires. Historic areas in Istanbul? Well, Istanbul is a historic area! We should keep in mind that the actual city of Istanbul was the capital of two, or in other historians’ opinion, three empires: Easter Roman Empire, Byzantine Empire and Ottoman Empire. So it is normal to find here a lot of witnesses of history: monuments, buildings, artifacts … But there is an area in Istanbul where many of these witnesses of history are, in a way, condensed and the area is that one bordered by Ataturk Blv, Ragip Gumușpala Cd and Kennedy Cd. Here you can find many of the historic attraction such as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Suleymaniye Mosque, Rustem Pasha Mosque, Spice Bazar, Valens Aqueduct …Buy a guide with good maps take at least one week vacation and try to discover all these by yourself! It will be a great joy!

Where East meets West. Had a guide for the Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. On our own for Topkapi Palace and Harem and Hagia Irene, an amazing 6th century church within the Topkapi palace grounds. It is a museum but open on Monday, closed Tuesday. Only annoyance was the rug dealers at every turn...they are pleasant but fending them off gets tiresome.

Istanbul. Lovely to see the History, Culture, Shopping, Food offered by this city. People are friendly but be careful about duplicate stuff being sold be it fake perfumes or old coins. Preferable pre book your tours with your travel agency.
Inexpensive. Most of the attractions were for free. The Blue Mosque, Hippo., Aya Sofia was cheap and worth the visit.

Istanbul friendly city. I liked almost everything! Grand bazar, mosques, palaces, resataurants and shops, nice people, food, fruits, sweets, great atmosphere of great city, the sea and boats, open space, parks. It was nice to be there, walk around.I didn't like one thing. There were many small children begging. Organised.

Huge amount to see. If you are interested in history you will never run out of places to visit in Istanbul's historic areas. I was there for 3 weeks and barely scratched the surface! If you are there for a short visit be absolutely sure to plan what you want to see in advance. Fantastic place - wonderful sights, and an absolute breeze to get around - even if you are on foot. The city is surprisingly compact, even if it is so large (this sounds rediculous, but you will understand what I mean if you go there). The food is superb wherever you eat, and the people are friendly and helpful . I SHALL return!!

Fantastic day out. I done this tour with Neon tours/Viator on Thursday 6th November and had a fantastic day seeing all the sights of Sultanahamet.My tour guide Gulay Gunay was only EXCELLENT.I got picked up that morning at my hotel (Taxsim square)and headed to Sultanahamet. Gulay showed me around the Historic parts for the whole day-Blue Mosque,Hagia Sophia,Basilica Cistern,Topkapi Palace,Hippodrome,Grand Bazzar and in between we stopped for lunch which was very tasty and included in the price. Gulays knowledge was Amazing-got to learn lots about Islam and Istanbul`s history.She then brought me to a carpet shop and got a demonstration on carpet making by hand(these guys have some skill) the quality of the carpets was top shelf,I really enjoyed my day,thank you so much for taking all my photo`s Gulay,this is a must do tour.
Palaces, Mosques and More. An amazing, exotic city to visit. Istanbul is one place that should be on everyone's bucket list... it's truly unlike any other place I've ever been.

sights to photograph. Location great for photographers who like old buildings and quaint streets. Very busy, great variety of restaurants and cafes.You can walk everywhere, to Galata, Pera, and Taksim.

interesting place to visit. very beautifull place nice mosaic nice nature everyone must visit Istanbul. If you like historic pplaces you must visit suleiman mosque old hagia sophia , nice dolmabagche palace
You like history. Istanbul is great and if you are interested in historical things one of the best cities in the world!!
Exciting and vibrant city.. Nothing to dislike but lots to like from all the obvious historical sites to the excellent food and friendly people.

The Aya Sofya & Topkapi Palace. Both of these historical landmarks are a definite "must see". Incredible architecture! Also, the Blue Mosque was another incredible example of ancient architecture and history.

sight an smells ,spice market. the ride on the bosphorus to see the asian and european sideand all the lovely land marks seen from the boat..i walk with a cane so the steps were a bit much i managed. the spice market was something to see allthe stalls with spices and every thing else you could imagineyou want to buy.land

Good walking sites....all close. Buy a museum card, essentials are Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia and Topkai Palace but don't ignore the Galata Bridge and the ferry to Asia. The Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar are wonderful!!
historical places. all the historical places was great... they was clean but crowded... i love istanbul... the ticket was high for visiting

Worth it. Nice area, a must see because of all historic monuments. Very crowdy, you see everything: old people, very poor people, business people, banks, nice architectures, rotten buildings, a lot of small shops where you can buy everything, hand made soaps, wedding cards, vacuum cleaner ... We loved to spent hours walking and looking around.

Just as good as before. We were delighted to return to this magical area and see that it has not been spoilt by the passage of time..all the wonder has been retained despite the number of cruise visitors who have swamped the city.Everything we loved and discovered previously was still visible and enhanced.

Galata Tower. The view from the tower of Istanbul & the delicious restaurant.
Food very delicious especially roasted lamb meat & mezza
Amazing. This is a great area with so much to see. Istanbul is one of the best cities we have visited. Almost everything you will want to see is within walking distance of each other.

Great. Sultan Ahmad mosque was great. Wether was cold!!! Transport facilities was good. People of city were friendly and food was great. Our hotel was at taskim square but with very good transport facility we could go easily to center of city. Me and my wife had good time at Istanbul .

excellent. Wonderful area and visit places close by .. Hagia Sophia and brought me back to the past as if I live .. Excellent Sultanahmet Mosque wonderful Amrath and prayer ... I am delighted by the Topkapi Palace is the Caliph of the Ottoman and Byzantine Emperor Palace .. What a wonderful shared history .. many food places are present in suitable prices .. except thethe cafeteria in the sidewalk near Topkapi all well cheaters do not put prices on menau
Old Istanbul - fantastic mosques and museums.. So much walking on stones. Great pomegranate juice on the sidewalk corners. Wonderful smells. 24 million people and 67% under 35. Vigorous!

Look About You. When in Old Istanbul, nearly everything around you is historic as the city dates back to Greek and Roman times. It's important to keep your eyes open and look beyond the obvious historic sights. They are all impressive, but to think that people were living here thousands of years ago should make you stop in your tracks in sheer amazement.

Second visit, overwhelmed!. Istanbul is not like any other city, its the CITY, the capital of empires, the city where cultures have met, history has been re-written and the city where people from west and east meet, visit same places, eat in same restaurants and stay in the same hotels. My first visit was in 1993, but I did not enjoy as much as I did this time. Although the blue mosque is the same, hagia sophia is the same, sultan Suleiman is the same, but there are a lot more people, a lot more tourists and surely a lot more restaurants and hotels. This time I thought and felt that a week was enough, not too short, and not too long, so just enough to leave the city while feeling you have seen many things, but not everything so that you still want to visit again the future.The only thing I will do next time differently is to stay in a different hotel though!
excellent. worth every penny would recommend it to everyone. loved the old buildings and the atmosphere. the people are very welcoming and the food is great.
Istanbul. Rich cultural Heritage. Lots of history there. Unique blend of east and west. Friendly people and friendly culture. Highly recommended place.
Great Place to spend some time in the Past Centuries. Istanbul is one of the beautiful city of the world. Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia Museum, Topkapi Museum, Roman Structure are places of must visit.

History always in the making. Mosques, small streets, old and new buildings, bridges, train station of Orient Express,great palaces, restaurants and lots of shops and sellers, this is the old city that connects Europe and Asia for more than 2 millenia.

Old City is a tourist trap. Lovely places to visit but it is awful getting into each. There are hoards of tourists which is fine. The issue is all the locals begging and selling wasteful trinkets. Also, every shop is a repeat of one two doors down selling the same knock-offs. Fortunately Istanbul is inexpensive for Americans so you can't get into too much trouble.

Must see.... It is a very impressive church --now museum. This East Roman Empire (Byzantium) church has a big dome and well preserved tiles/mosaics, representing Saints, Kings/Queens who were sponsors. It has big and impressive doors. Its architects well deserve appreciation and admiration.There was restoration going on for a long time, I have not visited there for over a year so it might have finished already. Also you can have nice view of the historical place from the windows of the Hagia Sofia.

Go back to an era and try imagining.... Today's mosques which where used as church and confused people with constant rule changes Greeks / Romans / Mongolians, This place explodes information, it is great fun though a guide is good to explain things better.
Great city with old and new all in one!. Loved the friendliness in the people and the wonderful history behind all the palaces mosque and great experience at the Grand Bazaar

Istanbul. Blue mosque was outstanding well worth a visit the area around the mosque is full of people wanting to act as your tour guide ...you Do Not need them . The traffic and roads around Istanbul are jammed so you MUST use the trams they have that take you around the city very cheaply the hop on hop off bus gets snarled up in the traffic the trams are way better and they go to most of the famous sights

Central Istanbul. Istanbul is a walkable city with most destinations within easy reach of one another. I highly recommend this city for a more unusual city break, a friendly and buzzing centre which can be explored on a budget. Attractions around Beyoglu include Galata Tower, Iskitlal Street, with its historic tram route, and the waterside edge. Cross Galata Bridge and experience the wealth of bazaars and mosques including the iconic Hagia Sophia. Take a taxi to the outlying attractions such as Pierre Lotti Cafe with amazing views across the Golden Horn towards the Bosphorous or the characterful residential districts, such as Balat with traditional painted houses. The Asian side offers many further attractions, all visible and accessible via the busy local ferry network, a day of mini boat trips in their right. The waterways provide views of the city and the activities along the edges, fishing mainly, combined with the array of boats and shipping within the channels are all well worth the trip. Nightlife is superb, lively and very civil. Reina, an open air club set below the Bosphorous Bridge and its waterfront views, is an amazing night out.I resolve to find an excuse to return!

Must see!. All the useums and mosques. Grand Bazaar is definitely worth a visit and so is the bazaar behind the Blue Mosque. One of the cafes has free live music and whirling dervishes for customers and passersby to enjoy.

Mosques and Palaces. Great historical perspective on Turkish history. The architecture and scale of the buildings is very impressive. Not as sophisticated as the grand European cathedrals but still impressive.
Not to miss. Just be patient. The weather is perfect (in October) but a little crowded. The sites are breath taken.Don't forget to go to the second floor of Aya Sofia.
Great views and street food. Easy to access the old Istanbul area with tram.Major attractions just walking distance.Great food and shopping experience.

Byzantine by-gone era. For a history buff, this is THE place to be in.. at the centre of Byzantine empire. Full of places to see and stroll around on the large open areas, avenues, ancient structures, gardens and cafes. Its well kept areas, vibrant in every senses. my personal favorite would be definitely Hagia Sophia (be prepared to be awed by all its splendour) and Galata Tower.

Antiquity!. Marvellous and awe inspiring sites almost everywhere you look.From ancient Bysantium, through Constantinople, to Istanbul, so full of historic references. The underground cistern of Yeribatan is not to be missed.

My favorite part of Istanbul!. The historic areas of Sultanahmet is my absolute favorite part of Istanbul. In fact, I made myself walk by there at least for a few minutes every day just to take in the sights. I can't explain it but there's something about this area that makes me feel so alive...it might be because I was struck with WANDERLUST during my first trip to Istanbul 2 1/2 years ago. The Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, just to name a few, all are right there. Of course, there's too many other sites to name here. This area is my favorite place in THE WORLD out of all the places I have traveled to. One WARNING, though: be aware of "friendly" Turks who are trying to lure you to buy things or lure you to other shops. At first they appear to be friendly. However, their ONLY intent is to direct you to their local shops. They can be SO rude, annoying, and somewhat hostile. My advice is just to say you're in a hurry and move on. DO NOT FALL FOR THEIR TRICKS! This is the only downside to this area as everywhere else in Istanbul is fine. Besides this minor inconvenience, Sultanahmet and its environs are absolutely amazing!
Mosques are amazing. Likes the variety of restaurants and efficiency of public transport. Disliked poor quality of most goods sold to to tourist.

Makes you appreciate history class. Make sure to bring a good camera!!! And do a bit of homework before you go --- there is simply too much information for even the guides to relay. And most importantly - try all the street foods!
The Cistern. amazing palace hidden underground and just to store water for the Sultans ! Corinthian Columns enabling the storage of 100,000 tons of water in this unique and beautiful place.
Walk,don't drive.. 3000 years of history-do your homework before you go or you are going to be confused.Excellent viewing of 3 great civilizations.

AMAZING HISTORY. Blue Mosque, Sophia Haga, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum took you back in time of not just the Ottoman Empire but the Byzintine Empire.All those sites are few blocks apart.

Wonderful international city. Great for people watching if you don't want to stand in lines!. The city! The atmosphere, the tram system! The people as a whole. Dislikes: two disastrous taxi driver experiences and lack of options there. Some restaurant hawkers less than honest. Put items on table that were not asked for and then " overcharged". A meal we thought was going to be 20 lira was over 40 ( near hippodrome And tram). I had beans and rice.
Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cistern. I liked the narration of the Hasan Oral the tour guide, and how told us the history behind everything
Istanbul Attractions. Loved visiting all the historic attractions from the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. All very clean and easily accessible.

Istanbul has some of the magnificent historic sites and unique Islamic relics for tourists from arond the world.. I wish more locals spoke English. I also hope the Turkish tourist ministry introduces English language for tourists who buy tickets from automatic machine to travel on the metro....

Perfect tour of the past. Istanbul is a tourists dream with unbelievable skyline and so many things to see and do packed together. Great public transit, wonderful food and shopping, and I found everyone pleasant and helpful - even if I didn't want to buy in their shop!

So much History. Yasmak Sultan hotel was close to all the Historical Areas of Istanbul. Easy walking distance. Great. From the roof top restaurant you could look over the Bospherus and theBlue Mosque. The palace and gardens are easy walking distance. If you like history place to be.
Steeped in history. So much to see - mosques dotted around the city (Blue mosque and all others built by Sinan), major palaces.

Understanding the world. In Istanbul you literally live in history. The network of the tourist guides is probably the most effecient I have come across.All the historical monuments are well maintained.Byzantine architectecture is marvellous and the Cistern is proof of advanced designing skills existing during the Roman era.The bazaars and the food can still give us a taste of history.All in all a vibrant historical city where we can first hand experience the old with the new.

The perfect long weekend choice. Istanbul is the closest city to western Europe to offer such a great change to our everyday cities. Full of historic monuments, great views and excellent food, this city has a lot to offer.However a lot still has to be done for cleaning the street and especially to solve somehow the issue of those dozens of young child used as beggars.

Topkapi Palace. Absolutely awesome! The Harem area was beautiful! So much to see, you need a couple of days. THe Blue Mosque was beautiful but there was quite a queue to get in. Dont forget to dress respectfully.
History Plus. Istanbul is surrounded with history. We were most impressed with this beautiful, viberant city. The people and places make it all happen.

Istanbul - historic areas. There is so much to do in Istanbul, you could not be bored. Its not expensive, easy to get around. Good transport, good signs in English. Very helpful, lovely people. What more could you want! You can pack lots into a 3 day visit as many of the attractions are close to each other. Get a Istanbul Card and top it up to travel on the tram to get more sight seeing done.

Old market. The colours and sights and smells in the old market were incredible however it isn't to be compared to the soux in places like Morocco or Egypt. This is a well organised , well signposted huge shopping area full of shops rather than stalls ....a big difference .Totally safe and a pleasant place to visit .

Verry Beautiful!!!. You must plan a visit to all sites.
just a metro and it gets you to the historic centre.
you can see the Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque , Aiya Sofia and other .

Interesting. Everything located close in one small area makes it possible to do in one day. Contrasts between west and East, Churchill and mosque is very visible. Beautiful buildings, make sure to visit the old roman cisterne below

Many people but fast queus. Well manged tourists admittance in museums and well made automatics guides in Topkapy eich starts automatically when close to points of interests. Several palces (Glata TOwer too) doesn't accept credit cards

Istanbul. Everything is amazing. Subbahanallah, I come to praise you, Ya Allah. Thanks at all the beauty of human creation (Al-fatihah to all of them). Again and again Subhanallah, You (Allah) is the perfect creator. Allah, please bless all of us the ummah of Prophet Muhammad s.a.w.

Great Historical City. There wasn't much to dislike. Great mix of history and modern life. Two sides to the city, the old side with all the history and great monuments and the other side with shopping and nightlife.
Very insight ful. you do need a guide to show the place else you might miss the small things like the german fountain etc..
Awesome place for history lovers. Everything was interesting and picturesque. We stayed in European part of Istanbul and every road was a boulevard.

Historic wonders. So many amazing and beautiful sights all easily accessible. You need 3-4 days to see the top sights but you could easily fill a week in this incredible city. The Turkish people were friendly and open and English was widely spoken. October was a perfect time to visit.

Athens to Istanbul-Seabourn Odyssey. The sites, the history, the food was a delight. Was not happy with the cabs as they always seemed to want to cheat you but we were fortunate our guide warned us. The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sofia were world wonders. This is a city I would like to return to as our 2 short days simply were not enough. We stayed at the Hilton Conrad which was excellent but too far from the sites. Next time will stay in the Golden Horn. Our guide Serif Yenen was world class
christmas travel. i liked everything in istanbul food shoping people an of cource the coulors and the tastes of the instanbul

Loved it. Its simply amazing.... the energy the buzz is infectious... the food the people... just outstanding.
So much history..so much character... its just brilliant

You will should go there!!. Oh my. its kind of medieval.
if you like a culture of ancient turkey.
this place will be great and never forget place.
Go there and enjoy your trip. :D

A wonderfully atmospheric city!. Istanbul is a fascinating city with a wide and varied history. Take time to stroll around the streets off the main drag, such as in the Beyoglu district. More museums and sites than you can shake a stick at - you will need at least a week to see it all.

Excellent Trip. We loved the history, vista, and the people were very nice.
We did not care for the many encounters with men trying to get us to take a "tour" of one of the many historic sights only to find out they wanted to get us into a carpet store....this became tiresome.

Great places to visit. I liked seeing all the historic places around Turkey.
Especially the boat trip as you got to see Turkey's football team Galatasaray. I disliked the food as it was not so appealing to eat during the evening.

Wonderful History. There is so much to absorb in the old part of Istanbul. The museum card is a must if you are short on time and waiting in queues. Make a plan and then wander the streets. Stay away from the Bosphorus Ferry trips.
Breathtaking. The tours were magnificent. It is full of history and culture. It brought us back memories of the Anciet times. Well preserved sites.
Must stop in Istanbul. If you are visiting Istanbul, you do not miss this area. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi Palace are all crowded in this area and the view is just amazing.

Such a fusion of east meets west.... I always enjoy my time in Istanbul. What strikes me; as a regular traveller, is that considering not a very long flight.. This really is a an eye opener. The culture.. The history.. The traditions mixed with the modern day. It's a very bustling busy city.. A bit dusty. Be prepared to haggle and be ready for some unwelcome attention - if you are a woman. That said.. Enjoy the grande Bazaar .. The blue mosk.. And the hospitality.,try the apple tea.. The coffee.. The sweets.. And have a Turkish bath. It is a truly unique .. But enjoyable Turkish experience!

Has everything. You can find plenty of souvenir shops, the famous mosques and many other attractions all within walking distance. Enjoy the walk around the historical area - you can see the beauty of Istanbul and feel the local culture.

World class town, fascinating for any visitor. there is so much to see and do here..... from all the mosques, restaurants, shopping to the local boat rides across the water or long rides up the Bosphorous. Fish markets , outdoor restaurants ,Galati tower and the 2nd oldest underground tram after London, that take you up the Tunel.Just start I the Sultanahmet and work your way down to the Galata bridge. Check out the grand bizarre and the spice market. Plan to pay 1 TL To visit a toilet, pick up a bottle of drinking water for the walk, most people shouldn't drink tap water. Most street food is ok but I'd avoid those mussels with lemon

Wonderful place with its own atmosphere. This areas is charming place for long walks. There are lots of nice little cafes where you can have a snack. In August, we were in the epicenter of really tornado, and even that did not spoil the experience.

very interesting to see!. Be sure not to miss a visit to Beyoglu when in Istanbul. From Taksim Square walk down Istiklal Caddesi (main pedestrian shopping street), take the old tramcar and head towards Galata Bridge - you will be surprised by the number of shops of all kinds, restaurants and other attractions. Once you reach the Galata bridge you will notice the fish market on your right hand-side- enjoy a super-tasty fish sandwich in the company of seagulls and take in the beautiful view!
Stop over trip for shopping and eating. I like every thing , but don't use taxi as much as you can , use istanbul card for the transport much cheaper and easy life.
historical. ı like mosques in istanbul especially süleymaniye mosque and blue mosque and spice market and hagia sophia
lots to do!. centuries of history in walking distance and amazing history to see!amazing architecture and history without the overload

Sultanhemet square. We picked a weekend that was a four day holiday locally. This meant very long ques. We were not prepared to wait in line for hours. Decided to go to,less well,know but very beautiful mosques by the Egyptian market. We took the open top bus trip this was a disaster as the traffic was horrendous and took an hour longer than it should have, there was no seating inside and was very cold and blowey on the top accross the river bridge. Take a hat and scarf if you do this trip even on warm days it's windy.

Probably the best walks in the world: stores, art, restaurants. This is one of the great walks in any city. We walked up and down Istikal in order to find places and to shop as well as to eat. We also walked in a lot of the older sections of town known as the Istanbul Soho, where there are lots of stores and galleries. It is hard to find galleries in this city because they open and close all the time but it doesn't matter where you walk, there is always something interesting. We strolled from the Galata tower down to the Bosphorus and took a cab.
The heart of Istanbul city!. very pleasent walk to all the main attractions such as the mosques, fountains, parks.Good food and nice for shopping.Enjoy! :)

what a city-amazing.... It is a combination of European and Eastern. It is old and new...and it is just beautiful...The food did not disappoint either...The Spice Market is fun...the Grand Bazaar so so except if you know where to go for pocketbooks and scarves..what a city...wonderful

Must see. Don't go during national holidays. We went during Eid holidays and it was crazy busy :) and crowded. You can't enter the museums or the mosques. You can't find taxis and the boat ride is impassible :) take the bus hop on hop off. It is worth it
Beautiful Istanbul!. Love all the Mosques, the Topkapi Palace, Harem the best not to forget, Agia Sophia, the Bosphorous cruise, all the bazaars specially the spices one.

See history and cultures span across. It was great to observe history change over centuries but a distinct continuity which ensured prosperity to an ever increasing population.
Art and history is reasonably well preserved and explained.
A great place to see the link between the mysterious orient and the west

Visiting Istanbul. My favorite place to walk was Taksim Square! Beautiful buildings and they have a cable car that runs down the middle of the street. I also enjoyed visiting the Haga Sofia Museum. Incredible history. Gorgeous!! Trip of a lifetime, for sure!

Amazing!. I used to think thenonly site ti visit was the 'Blue Mosque'....but i have been here 5 days and its been absolutely amazing and only wish i had another 2-3 days because there is soo much to do and see. Beautiful city!!

Dream come true. touring the mosques, the bazaar and just getting lost on the many side streets in the city were great. My big dislike is the traffic, which at times is horrendous and can take hours to get places.

A city full of history!. The scale is great - all the fantastic historical attractions are within walking distance. Accommodation is plentiful and it is possible to get it for a reasonable price. The city has great tram and metro system that is very cheap to use. Eating out is easy and, in general, reasonable. No complaints!
historic areas. Go very early or late in the day to avoid the crowds. Hiring a private guide gets you to the front of the line.

Istanbul is an amazing place!. There is so much history in this city. From Byzantine churches to Ottoman Palaces, this is the place for any history lover. We spent eight days here and it was no where near enough time to see everything.

fabulous city. Palaces mosques where fantastic everything was stunning more than I expected easy to get about tram is 4 turkish lira and can go from airport to port with stops that include grand bazar

Breathtaking. East meets west, literally. The historic places are a must see including the Topkapi Palace, Basilica and Blue Mosque. There is construction going on in Hagia Sophia so its not really worth paying 30 TL to go in and see absolutely nothing.Get a Museum card if you can, you can save yourself a lot of time queuing up and money too.

Lots to see. If you like historic places with loads to see then Istanbul is the place to go. There are the most amazing buildings off the mainstreet and if you go over the river to the old town there is loads to see and most of it is free. Definitely worth a visit.
Amazing. We loved Istanbul all the attractions are amazing full of history, great selection of restaurants, shops, try the river boats amazing scenery.

Gotta Go There!. Istanbul continues to be a fascinating city that should be a must see for anyone who likes to travel. The people are friendly, the historic area are fascinating and there is much to see here.

amazing Istanbul love it. All the famous historical sites are, of course, amazing to visit in the flesh, so to speak, but the city is sometimes over-loved and the experience spoiled by too many tourists.
Must see. The Blue Mosque is huge, beautiful inside and worth the faily long wait in a que to get into. Of course there is much much more all around it to see as well.
Turkey with Serif Yenen. Not only did Serif made history come alive, as we visited Turkey, but he made sure we had delicious culinary adventures, too.
Fabulous. A lot of well preserved ancient buildings, beautiful legends, great history. All you read about it is true.

Our Amazing trip!. Brilliant city, full of historical interest. Nothing we disliked! People were welcoming everywhere and the restaurants were friendly places. Perhaps the long queues were rather unwelcome to visit the sites but once inside, simply amazing!

Impressive. The famous sites such as Aya Sofia and Topkapi are worth a visit but I found the modern city more interesting. The famous sites are huge and generally crowded. We also found with Sultanahmet that we queued for around an hour and then found it close for prayers for another hour. Check the prayer times carefully

Istanbul is heaven for history buffs and for shoppers. The sites that are easily available in the old town are the old Cistern, the Blue Mosque, the Aya Sofia museum, the Topkapi Palace and the Dolmabahce Palace. The Topkapi reflects the culture of the Ottomans, while the Dolmabahce is a Europeanized conglomeration of rooms presumed to be important to 19th century rulers. All are stunning.The Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar must be visited.

Istanbul, Turkey historical sites. What an amazing city, so many historical places to see and what a diverse culture that is fascinating to see. We took the ferry over to the Asian side and our hotel is south of the galata bridge(European side off istsnbul) near the Grand bazaar, the Egyptian bazaar which includes the spice market, the blue mosque and many other archeological sites. Public transportation is very impressive and inexpensive.
Beatifull. Beatifull. The AyaSophia area is excelent. Carefull with scams and kids trying to get money from you...

amazing!. visited all major tourist sights, Blue mosque, Topkapi palace, Aya Sofia. All were amaxing and filled with soo much culture and beauty. Really recommend these sights, as well as the Bosphorus cruise
Great Place to Stay for a visit to Istanbul. Just 5-10 min walk to Ayasofya, Tapkapi, Spice Bazaar, Galata bridge, etc. The staff are very helpful and professional from reception to house keeping.
Amazing. The bazaar and Bogaz river trip were our favourites.We also visited Sulaymaniye mosque which was beautiful.
beautifull. historic area of istanbul is very good. but i advise traveler to go independent to visit the all historical places.

Magnificent City. Istanbul is a magnificent city - both historical and modern. The mosques are stunning and give you the feeling that you are walking through another place and time. The palaces are fascinating and you sense the opulence and glory that they once were. The other historical sights were unique and worth exploring. The shopping was fun. The food was good. A lovely visit and would return to Istanbul - and to other parts of Turkey - in a heartbeat.
Worth the trip from Australia. The historical areas have a great atmosphere. Coming from a younger country the age and preservation of the monuments is over overwhelming.

Magical Istanbul. We went as a couple for our 3rd anniversary and it was the best gift one could hope for ! Would like to mention the walking tour of Istanbul by "Ugur Kilerci" - a very professional tour guide was quite good. Taking a private tour is one of the better ways of exploring Istanbul and there's a lot to see. Food in Istanbul is great and a lot of options are within walking distance.Its best to stay near the Sultanahmet area though with an Istanbul Kart (the combined metro / tram /bus transport card) it really doesnt matter.
Visit the mosques & bazaars. The mosques are beautiful, see the spice and grand bazaars. Keep a keen eye on what you buy and from where. One of the busiest ports in the world.
smells so goood. very old and well maintained really loved the smells around the cityI ate everything loved the baklava
Must see. The Hagia Sophia is beautiful and the number one place in my book for Istanbul. I was there last year and came back again this year.
Close to Hotel Niles. A lot of sites near hotel, a good walking tour for most, be sure to wear comfortable clothing and have your handbag close to you.

Fantastic!!!. I always want to see place like this and when I was there I really amazed with it's beauty. I spent more than 1 month in Istanbul and It was a awesome experience. Check out more at triphobo.com/istanbul-turkey
Great history and culture. Beautiful architecture and a wonderful energy. Like any other popular site, most restaurants and businesses are geared toward tourists.

Awesome. Istanbul is an amazing place full of culture & history. Historical sites are everywhere & very easy to get to when walking. Definately worth while reading about the history of Istanbul before you go to this fasinating place as you will enjoy it more.
Pleasant stay.. Within close proximity to all the highlights of the city. Walking distance to many restaurants and late night shopping.
Three days not enough. After 3 days, historic section full of things to see in every direction. Short walk to the Grand Bazaar is better than tram. Bazaar is must see and shopping is a trip.
Istanbul. The people are generally friendly as long as you are friendly, and especially the youth would like to strike a short conversation on your political opinion on their country

Blue Mosque. Interesing visit. Lovely blue tiles inside this impressive structure. I did not know that there are 3,319 mosques in Instanbul and 149 Catholic churches an 19 synogues. A tad disportionate but it is a muslim country.

Adorable. I have always loved Istanbul. I like the historical places the most. I would like to go there hundreds of times to set and observe. The only think that annoyed me this time are the Syrians. They are begging constantly and trying to offense tourists.
overloved city.. All the famous historical sites are, of course, amazing to visit in the flesh, so to speak, but the city is sometimes over-loved and the experience spoiled by too many tourists.

Blue Mosque, Dolmabache Palace, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazar,. I liked the spice bazar with all the nuts and spices. I liked the fact that you can actually visits most of these places on your own using the public transport and without the need to use the services of a tour guide.
