A tour guide is a bonus if you choose to for all locations except for Dolmabache Palace where you definitely need one

Amazing Istanbul sight seeing. This is a must see place. The area is full of historical monuments and history. The Blue Mosque or SultanAhmet Mosque, Aya Sofia, Top Kappi, Basilica Cistern, Serpient, Hippodrome, and many other things are all in one place. Amazing
Blue Mosque. Huge queues to get it so get there early, plagued by Syrian beggar children while in said queue but worth it once you get through the gates
excellent. everything was well explained, and very easy to reach everything with the public transports, always ask the taxi how much they charge before you heir them, specially the young men
Grand Bizzare. This place is amzing, so old and grand. very crowded but lot of great stuff to see, smell, buy.A must do while in Istanbul.
Fantastic city. Just a great place to visit lots of places to visit. plenty of places to eat & everyone is so friendly.

sounds and senses. Loved the culture and atmosphere, lots to see, vibrant and exciting.
Very safe no hassel, lost of choices for eating for all budgets.
Amazingly beautiful. All attractions so well preserved . Hagia Sophia my favourite but the cistern , blue mosque and the palace not far behind. Allow time for each tho!

The core of an Istanbul Experience. Even if you are not a culture buff and don't want to immerse yourself in the history of Turkey by visiting the numerous amount of well preserved, efficiently run and easily accessible (but quite costly) museums, palaces etc, you can't help by being impressed by just walking past them and gazing at their dominance on the landscape of Istanbul. The historic sights will get to you before you get to them
Great city!. The mix of Asia and Europe, the mix between culturas, races and religions is unique!A city to return again and again!Good people, food, monuments and landscape!

Fascinating sights and sounds. What a unique and great experience! Istanbul has it all! European boutiques, pastry shops, night life with the mysteries of islam and an organized chaos of the East. Loved it, very evocative and like nowhere else.It also has incredible sights that have outrageously long queues with little to no information in English , or any other language , for the tourist. It also sadly has horrid, hole in the ground toilets that you can queue for 30 minutes for and pay 2 euros for the privilege. After a week there we would recommend it to anybody but feel the turkish tourist board have a very long way to go to make it a better destination. We went in shoulder season, september, the weather was great but there were hoards of sight seers, especially at week ends. Language is a problem if you do t speak turkish. We do not recommend taking taxis on the street after several bad and pricey experiences. The Metro, which i would never normally take, unless kicking and screaming, was fast, efficient, easy and definitely a better transportation option.
Wonderful area full of historical significance. Could spend hours, oh and we did, just walking around. A new discovery around every corner! Many good restaurants.
Breathtaking..... We covered it all....don't miss a thing. Istanbul is beautiful with it's history and architecture. We had a wonderful experience..

Very nice and interesting. Istanbul is a very interesting city to visit and there is a lot to discover. Overall the people are very nice. However, one has to be careful for all kind of people who try to offer you their services. Not all of them have very good intentions. Enjoy!

Energised, full of history and friendly. We have spent 3-4 days here in town over the past fe weeks and have visited most of the mosques, temples, castles,bazaars, and many places to eat. We enjoyed both day time and night life felt very safe and only felt too crowed was in the Grand Bazzar. This place is very repetitive with same stuff in most areas the difference is how much u can barter. Many shops outside and beyond better to shop in. The river trip up the Bosphorus the long one is good if you have the time 6 hrs with 3 hrs at the top for lunch.
Autumn Travels in Turkey. Love Turkey..the people are friendly and the country is beautifulIstanbul has fabulous restaurants &'we loved the Turkish wine

Beautiful Istanbul. Magical historic sites. Sights and sounds and a visitors' dream. We loved the nights walking the streets and markets and seeing all the mosques at night. The Hagia Sofia and Basilica Cistern were magical.

Historical links. Loved seeing the influences from this very old city that live with us today. Eg: the tile patterns and how they were adopted by William Morris for his famous pattern designs in the19th Cent. Loved the architecture. the mosques, the food, the people. The age of things, the rich heritage,The custom of tea drinking was wonderful. Everyone genuinely wanted me to be happy with what they gave me or did for me. There was so much to see and do.Didn't like the traffic and the crush of people - I am not used to it.

Blue Mosque, Old Roman water reservoir, Old Bazaar. Blue Mosque was great and so was the Old Roman water reservoir. Old Bazaar was OK but targeted too much towards tourists and lacking any historical significance
So exciting!. The area where we stayed is in Europe - but still so 'non-European' which I thought was extremely interesting and amazing!

Walk through centuries of history. Very close together for a nice walking day are the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Roman Cistern, and the Topkapi Palace. Personally, I recommend 6 - 8 hours to really see everything. Be sure to check when these sites are open and closed as both Topkapi Palace and the Hagia Sophia are closed on Mondays and certain holiday days, Blue Mosque has religious services during the day for which the mosque is closed to visitors, and the Roman Cistern is closed at certain times. Check opening times of the Harem inside Topkapi Palace as well, which is a separate exhibition with different opening and closing times, and very worth while seeing. Enjoying a nice leisurely walk to and through the various highlights, with a stop for lunch, is a great 6-8 hour day, topped with an end of the day visit to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar, which both close at 7:00pm, (again check when open and hours for both Bazaars). At the Grand Bazaar, be sure to work your way into the original old bazaar, for what I think are very interesting old shops.
Lines, Lines, Lines. The cruise ships have found Istanbul. Expect very long lines at all the sites ( Topkapi, Blue Mosque, St. Sophia)
Westernised city. Former oriental city which now became totally westernised and lost almost all its oriental atmosphere. Only splendid Haghia Sophia is well worth a visit.

so much to see so little time. so so so much to see. soak it all in. thesis an incredible place. spent a half day in the hagia sophia and it went by too quickly. glad i spent the week staying in one spot.
a good reason to visit lstanbul. so many historic places to visit in a very small area. no cars , clean , a pleasure of everyday to walk there

A magic city. I'm visiting this city for the third time in 06 years!!! you can guess how much in love I'm with this city!!! it's litteraly a magic city. Behind all the famous monuments, you have all this small cities arround Istanbul that are not overcrowded by tourists and which are a real way to know more about Istanbully citizen. the best way to discover this city is to let yourself lost in it!!! the mix between the oriental and occidental culture, who said that being muslim and laic doesn't work, Turkey is the best exemple for that. I found it very safe city, with nice and helpfull people, something that we see less and less in big european cities. I highly recommend it for those who want to experience the mix between Orient and Occident!

More than plenty to see. Istanbul is a busy bustling city but most of the historic areas are easy to reach by public transport. Major must sees are The Topkapi Palace, The Hagia Sophia and The Blue Mosque. Also worth seeing are The Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar. Mosques are everywhere but some more important than others. I would recommend anyone to get a Istanbulkart (bit like an Oyster Card in London) You can use them on the trains, trams, buses and ferries. One card will cover up to 5 people and costs 10TL which includes 4TL of credit. Once you have purchased one just top up with increments of 10TL. I would suggest 20TL if two of you etc. The tram from Kabatas ferry terminal near the Dolmabahçe Palace is a good place to start. Just travel to Eminonu for another ferry terminal, the Galata bridge, Spice Market and a walk uphill to the Grand Bazaar.. A couple of stops further at Sultanahmet gets you near to the Topkapi Palace Museum, The Hagia sophia and the Blue Mosque
All mosques worth a visit. It is worth visiting all of the mosques in the area, they are all beautiful. The commitment to their upkeep is touching.

Typical Historic Area. Istanbul is very rich in history. Think about it the ottomans ruled the world for roughly 400 years. Remarkably they brought back souvenirs from every country they invaded and placed it in Istanbul. That's why there's plenty to see.On another note, everything is accessible via tramway ( make sure you get the istanbulkart)The only this that bothered me was loooong waiting lines for everything, but it's worth it.

Kadikoy market and the true Istanbul life!. The ferry from Eminou to Kadikoy was enjoyable with incredible view of the city. I bought a token (jeton) for 4 TL from a machine outside the Pier, embarked, disembarked and let myself wander and stop to try bites of specific dishes. I first started at Halil Lahmachun. A must! Crisp thin bread topped with beef, parsley and spices, helped by an Ayran. Then I saw the word Hamsi ( anchovies), a black sea speciality. I ended up trying marinated sea bass and Bluefish that was in season as noted by the restaurateur. I asked for very small plates as I knew I was not going to stop there. While mesmerized by the colorful sight of olives, dry vegetables and fish and just the mere energy, I kept falling on delicacies I wanted to try. Kokorec which is the tripes of the lamb was exquisite. I chose the plate as it was small and with no bread. I was starting to feel uncomfortable from all the food I ate but then I fell on Kumpir station, a baked potato, with the flesh removed, mashed and then an array of choices to top it including a type of bulgur, corn,pickles,... I asked the vendor to put it in to go container and I enjoyed its sight while I was satisfying all my senses with all random dances, chanting and music in the street. I had a smile for the whole time. Are you hungry yet?

Tourist attractions, nice place to be. We liked our stay in Istanbul, visiting the historic sites. In Sultanameth, Topkapi, blue mosque and Hagia Sophia and the cisterns are all very close to each other. We liked the proximity of these attractions. We felt safe in the area. Quiet at night.

amazing, so much history. so much history all in just a few blocks, a must see for urban and history lovers. there are also nice restaurants in the area to stand by while visiting the cultural spots. Cant miss Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Cistern, Egipcian Bazaar and sulmemaniye mosque.

Istanbul is the most amazing city in the world. There is nothing to dislike about Istanbul. It is truly a must. The people are very nice,friendly and helpful. Their train is very easy to use. Taksim is the best place to stay if you love shopping and eating at the fantastic restaurants. I would highly recommend this city to family members and friends.

Lovely Istanbul. We saw many if not all of the historic sights of Istanbul but at our own leisurely pace and only by public transport and walking. It is a relatively inexpensive city, and we loved the people and their generosity and warmth.

Nice Visit. Overall, we had a great visit to Istanbul. We went to many of the old sites of the city and were impressed how well things are explained and how the people are moved around. Most places are swamped by tourists (of course!) but still manageable.You need to spend at least 3 days (more if possible!) to see the bare minimum. Istanbul is a beautiful old city with lots of must see places!

Early starts are essential !. If you are only there for a few days ensure you have a list of what you wish to see. Bear in mind that the mosques are 'working' and frequently close for prayers/services, so visitors times are restricted. Bear in mind to that you will meet a lot of groups also visiting, particularly those from the huge cruise-liners which visit the city. So for anything of particular interest, I suggest you are there before they open.

Blue Mosque. Visited the Blue Mosque in 2003 and again this year to find that the place is overrun by tourists and difficult to photograph. I made this comment to our guide to be told that there are now 10 million tourists a year visiting Istanbul!

Sights of Istanbul, Old Quarter. Plenty of information and helpful locals. The city was clean, well laid out and full of beautiful buildings and history on every corner.Great food, well organised public transport, it ticked all the boxes as a destination.

Nice to see such historic area. liked how much history was in each corner, the amount of different ruling people came to change the place.. how long lasting this huge places. Desliked the Beggers trying to get you by any means

3 Day visit to Istanbull. Blue Mosque and The Cistern and Sophia. All the sights in tyhe old town of Istanbull and worth a visit. Also the Spice Market and Grand Bazaar are worth a visit, but be prepared to be hassled in the bazaar to buy
old centre Istanbul. fantastic old centre, stayed here 4 days and enjoyed the sights, food and ambience of the place, lots to see and do in a very small area

feast your eyes. hated having to queue! but that's unavoidable especially at peak holiday times
Loved the ceramics and the wonderful architecture, the little streets and laneways.
Amazing. So much history to see and learn about religion and architecture. Great shopping and outdoor cafes. If lines are long it is worth the money to use a guide.
the blue mosque. The hagia sofia, the blue mosque and the topkapi palace were all breathtaking and walking distance from our hotel

visiting historical sites. I liked to visit historical sites and the good food.
Whay I did not liked it is that is a very crowded city, you hardly can walk some times.
Exotic. old world and interesting, lots of culture .Don't take a tour you can walk this on your own with a map....disliokes, too many people and it was very hot

Everywhere you go is historic and beautiful!. A few days and a single trip will not be enough! Get a room near the Golden Horn and bring comfortable walking shoes and enjoy the history, signs, sounds, smells.

Peaceful and Tranquil. Expect everything to be bustling with all nationalities around the world. The historical sites are a must see: this is the byzantine empire meets the ottoman empire at its finest!
Istanbul breathes history. Being such an important city for several different reigns, this city breathes diverse cultures. The blend is just amazing.
At the entrance, Long Line on weekend. Sultanahmed camii is beautiful !!! Inside Ayasopha is too dark due to renovation. Topkapi is very big! It's very difficult to find a restroom.
Despite the Crowds Awesome. In the two days we spent time in the best known sights all were stunning in their history and architecture. Go early to avoid the busiest times
New perspective of time. Traveled with suberb Road Scholar guides. A guide is a must. Crowds were large but September is a popular month for travel to Istanbul.

Old town Istanbul. Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace -i went not later than 9:30am because it gets crowded around 10am with group tourist. mosque -go during lunch time. thats what i did and the queue is not long.Everyday I go to Gulhane park -Set Üstü Çay Bahçesi (cafe al fresco) to relax and give my legs a rest and enjoy the Bhosporus activity while sipping hot turkish tea. its my favorite place in old town.
sultanahmet. hagia sophia and the blue mosque were excellent. We had a lovely time exploring around the area. We visited many historical monuments around the area and some good eating places as well.

History and culture. Istanbul is one of the most fascinating cities I ever visited.It is a pleasure to walk and enjoy the view of the city on two continents.There are so many places to go that you need more than one visit to the city.The modern is entwined with the opulent palaces of the Ottoman era ; the bazars take you to the magic world of our childhood stories of 1001 nights, the traditional Turkish sweets and dishes are incredible, the town is a marvel.

Ancient City. Istanbul is an ancient city and has an air of history coming out of its old wall and traditional streets. It is fascinating. The majority of people are amazing but you will have a couple of rude and thick people who would ruin it for you. Ignore them and enjoy the city.
Walk walk walk. Marvellous City , so much culture to see. Cobbled streets and broken pavements plus mad drivers are to be watched carefully but it is a place to really enjoy.
Crowds galore. We liked the ambience, the busyness, Getting used to the ebb and flo of traffic.Easy to walk with no worry about safety
What a place!. I liked everything about Istanbul,from the bazaars to the mosques and museums, and would return in a heartbeat.

Sites to see. Lots of wonderful sites to see that you can easily walk to with the exception of the Dolmabahce Palace which you can get to on the tram. Don't hesitate in using the trams as they are clean, easy to use and very cheap.

Lots to see and do. All the touristy sites are worth a visit but beware of ordering fish at the under the bridge restaurants as whllst is is the 'in' thing to do it can be very expensive and as they and other Med countries have fished out the Aegean and the Med a lot of it is imported.

A Truly enlightening visit. A splendid work of art & unique architecture. We were amazed and totally on awe, stood gazing at the beauty of the paintings on the inside of the dome of Hagia Sophia. Also recommend a visit to ehe Elegant Blue Mosque and the beautiful Topkapi Palace a must see tour.

Grand Bazaar. Spend some time shopping in the Grand Bazaar. Pay attention to where you are because it can be confusing since it is so big. The bazaar is crowded and make sure you shop around. You can find some of the same items all over the bazaar at different prices. The waterfront is nice, but it is crowded and dirty. Lots of people fishing and it has a strong fish smell. Still, it is worth a visit.
Breath Taking. Always felt safe. Great history, the sights are well organised. Top restaurants and service. Open top Bus Tours are really worth doing 'The Big Bus' include the boat tour.

A Magical place to stay, so much history, such wonderful people.. Amazing historical places to visit. Everyone we met was so friendly and helpful. So much to see we used up every minute of our four days. Good food too.

Sultanahmet. From the water, the view of Topkapi, the Aya Sophia and the Blue Mosque is one of the most perfect sights in the world. At ground level, you are best off with a guide, to explain the complex history and help you dodge the queues. But do that, and spend a day in this fascinating area, and you will come out refreshed and re-energised.
wow what a city. just fantastic, go early to try and avoid crowds, check when cruise ships are in as the crowds are problem in all arears
Great city full of history. Mosques, Palaces, Historic places, Bospohorus, Black sea every thing you will love to experience. Its a beautiful city with lot to do.
quick visit to istanbul. Saw the great historic sites of this famous city. Turkish people are so courteous and friendly. Restaurants offer wide choice.

Kariye Camii. Do not miss this gem. Make sure that you walk through the narrow street lined with old multi colored wooden houses to arrive at the museum. You can get there easily by ferry from Eminonu. This is really the best way as the buses take much more time through miserable traffic. If you have to miss the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sofia to see this it is well worth it. Best church I visited in Turkey.
Too many cruise passenger tours. had to visit early to avoid the crowds, visited all we wanted by getting there early am but Topkaki palace was too crowded when we left Aya Sofia early am
Wonderful eye opening. We had a wonderful time. Windom hotel great, people very friendly and helpful. I'd go back in a minute
Great!!!!!. Cozy streets and original buildings. Smells of spices in the air everywhere!!! Exotic environment. Great place indeed!!!

I WILL BEE BACK. I visited Istanbul the forth time this summer, with my 2 daughters, and 3 grandchildren.Every time it is more and more beautiful for me. All of us enjoyed the trip. Like in the oriental dream, the nice mosques, museums, antic buildings, and the atmosphere of culture made us richer. all of us decided too be soon back.
Fascinating. Truly one of the five greatest cities in the world - so much history and beauty al within such easy walking distance
Wonderful, fascinating. Mad. chaotic, beautiful. Can be very crowded I queued for tickets early for the family and then went later on in the day.

Old Istanbul is full of cultural history.. Turkey is a country of culture and history. The people are friendly, progressive and tourist friendly. Istanbul was interesting and I would highly recommend hiring a guide to make sure you make the most of your visit!!

Amaising trip. For me was an amaising trip. All the places I've seen are great, with a rich history and culture. Beautiful historic buildings, nice restaurants with a very, very, very gooooddd foooddd. Their mosques are beautiful and big with a interesting desine. Good parks, big and nice aqua park and the best hammams. We had a boat trip and is very exciting, you must to try....About people, they are nice only if you buy or need something but in rest they are very rude and uneducated. I saw some women fight and I felt safe there. So you must be careful out there..

Istanbul for the 1st time. Grand Bazaar was something to see and experience. Shopping was not fun, hard sell everywhere and at very unrealistic prices, it's not my kind of shopping but it was good to see. Visit to Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Seraglio palace was just amazing and a night cruise on Bosporus is a must, enjoyed it all.
What's not to like. Beautiful historic buildings, busy markets, friendly people, great food, easy to get around. You need at least 3 days to see highlights but stay longer to explore.
A timeless Istanbul. An enriching mix of European and Asian culture. The people is what I like most. Food is good except that it lacks a little on international food e.g. Chinese, Western food.

just there a couple of days but want to go again. I was in Sultanamet (historic area), with lots of beautiful mosques, neat eating places with women making bread in front where everyone could watch, good food, great smells and lots of warmth from people. I was really impressed and wish I could have stayed longer

Istanbul always fascinates. For my wife and me one of the most impressive buildings in the world is the Higia Sophia. It is very hard to imagine that this spectacular building was built in only 5 years more than 1,500 years ago - a real monument to men's ingenuity and capabilities! But there is so much more to see. Istanbul is truly a melting pot of occidental and oriental culture and we only whish that we could spend more time there.

What a fantastic city. Traffic is horrendous, so use the public transport system. A ferry ride across the Bosphorus drinking cay is so civilised. The people are so kind and helpful - thank you Istanbul.
Lots to See. Loved the Grand Bazaar, Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Millon Stone, Palaces, and some great pictures.But very busy at all times
Blue Mosque AND Hagia Sophia. It was about a 5-10 minute walk from Hotel Amira. We felt safe to walk around. The Blue Mosque was fabulous but no one may wear shorts and women must cover their heads.

Wonderful Blue Mosque and feel History alive at Haghia Sophia. In addition to most famous monuments we liked specially the Bosphorus tour, both in the day and by night. the envoirnoment of restaurants at Galata Bridge by night is a delight.
Fantastic. If you like history with great food Istanbul is the place. Always stay in Sultanahmet area its where all the action is for 50+ people.

Interesting. Try the Spice Market, lot's of spices I have never seen before. The smells are awesome. The Grand Bazaar in the historice Ottoman market, is interesting., sells so many things, including jewelery.
Istanbul. So much to see, West meets East - this is what I found most interesting. One could be in a Western city until the call to prayer sounds out magically and changes the whole feeling.

So much to see. We had no problems finding the sights in the old city with the maps provided by the hotel, all within easy walking distance. We like to walk to discover a new city and it was comfortable here, despite the heat. The Bosphorus cruise was a cool and enjoyable interlude.

Gentrified, but still a world wonder. The connection between the hypodrome, hagia sophia and topkapi has been simplified and looks amazing, It really is one of the most amazing places to view.Access to Blacharnae could be better and also access to the walls could be better.I am also delighted to see the improvements in the security and maintenance of the Hagia Sophia in the last few years.
capital of the world. istanbul is dream. its more beatifull than paris trust me. its love. its fresh its osmanlı its republic. its istanbul :)
love istanbul. been here 3 times and love going back - the confluence of cultures, the history, architecture, FOOD makes us come back over and over again!

Good but crowded. Probably my own fault for being a late riser; but the palace was akin to rush hour on the London Underground. Would likely rate a 4 or 5 if I'd gotten up at the crack of dawn for a serene viewing slot.

Great city to wander in. The historic centre of Istanbul gives plenty of opportunity for sightseeing and pleasant meandering, viewing splendid architecture alongside the hustle and bustle of a busy city. There are plenty of pedestrianized areas, especially around the Blue Mosque and the hippodrome area. Topkapi Palace Gardens are very nice, giving views through the trees to the Bosphorus. Top sites are Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and Blue Mosque.

Wow!. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Aghia Sofia all within a few hundred yards of each other, it is almost too much! Cant tell you how much we loved these ancient and beautifully presented sites. Visit Istanbul as soon as you can!
Very beautiful city. Join the city tour and explore the beautiful city of Istanbul. Don't forget the shops that have a wide selection of souvenirs.
histroy color. brilliant food and black tea......bazzar and coffee...i love the blue mosque and St.sophi and i will come back in the near future with my parents.
Vibrant City. Always felt safe. Great history, the sights are well organised. Top restaurants and service. Open top Bus Tours are really worth doing 'The Big Bus' include the boat tour.

Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, and the Blue Mosque. The Topkapi Palace was our favorite attraction in Istanbul; the splendor of the buildings and grounds is without parallel. The Hagia Sofia was undergoing restoration and we were disappointed with all the scaffolding in the way. The Blue Mosque was a unique experience for us because we had never been in a Mosque before; our private tour guide gave an excellent explanation of everything we saw and translated the beautiful calligraphy for us.

istanbul is history. you gotta enjoy historic areasits very charming to look around and realize these building theses statues have been here hundreds of years ago if you enjoy history you will definitely enjoy the area

Istanbul Discovery Tour was great!. We packed a lot of sightseeing into three days, but enjoyed every minute. Transportation and guides were good,restaurants for lunchok,with a kebab restaurant on our walking tour day the best. We liked The Ferman Hotel in Sultanahmet,close to sites,restaurants and shops
Breath Taking. Hired a private guide for 2 days and had immediate access to all the historic sites with detailed history provided and a locals perspective.

My holiday in Istanbul. Enjoyed every bit of sightseeing. The old city had so many places to visit. The history and brilliance of the people of an era before Christ was magnificent. Nothing much to not like.

Blue Mosque. Well worth the wait in the long que. Fabulous mosque, cannot describe the fantastic titles nor the feeling of history found in the walls and floors. Thousands of visitors per day, organisation at entry hectic.
Must see. A definite must see, especially Sultanahmed. The Blue mosque, Haya Sofia, Topkapi palace, the hippodrome, bazaars... Also plenty of restaurants around to relax and get some rest.
Easy access. most main attractions are close together in Sultanahmet. guided tour added context which helped. public transport by tram/underground from beyoglu is easy.
Boat trip to rinces Island. We took he boat over to Princes Island, it was a great trip, took 90mins each way, the islands are very pretty

Pakwhite Laundry. Traveling can be a dirty business, especially in hot climates. Istanbul has no laundry facilities other than expensive hotel service. We searched for laundromats and laundry facilities and found a great laundry that charges by weight at very reasonable rates. NOT a dry cleaner.It's called Pakwhite Laundry. It's located in the Beyoglu district, not far from the Galata Tower.Located next to the Azze Hotel at KIblelizade Sokak No: 6 Beyoglu Istiklal - Istanbul / Turkey

Fascinating City!!!. This is my ideal city to visit!!! Full of history and full of vibe. We stayed for 5 days in Istanbul, our hotel was in the Historic downtown area.We loved the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque (Sultanahmet Camii), shopping in the Gran and Spice Bazaar area, the hop-on hop-off Big Bus Tour, the Bosphorus view from everywhere in the historic district and the Bosphorus cruise. We had an incredible time, the whole area was like a museum. The restaurants around the area and the dancing shows all fit together to give us a unique memorable experience.We are devoted Catholics and fully respect other religions, we were thrilled to listen to the five times a day "Ezan" (Muslim call to prayer) throughout the entire city. Every time it happened we were mesmerized. It was an incredible experience to listen to the powerful, beautiful and peaceful sound of the Ezan. Later we found out that each mosque has a person called Muezzin appointed to lead and recite the Ezan during the different times of the day. In the old days, the Muezzin was on top of one of the Minarets (Towers at the mosque) so he could be heard around the mosque. Now, mosques have loudspeakers mounted on top of the minaret, the muezzin uses a microphone, allowing the Call to prayer to be heard at great distances without climbing the minaret. When calling to prayer, the Muezzin faces the Qiblah, the direction of the Ka'bah in Mecca, while he recites the Ezan.We strongly recommend that if you are going to visit Istanbul, plan to spend a few days walking around the Historic Areas which are the heart of the city.
Wonderful. Has a lot of history and also a modern feel,so if your not a museum kinda person don't worry still lots got you to do
So Much to See and Do. Istanbul is a city full of history and would suggest that if you want to see everything and spend time in each location then a week would be necessary.

Great History. I'm fascinated with Istanbul, its history, its people and colour excitement. I will go back sometime soon. I was excited to go to the Asian side and come back to the Euro side for dinner, two continents in one day.
too crowded. So May Tourists! But, yes, I am one of them... but I would have loved to see the beauty of the buildings in a quitte way.Get a Museumcard to avoid the lines!

This city is a giant living museum !. There is too much history and culture to absorb in one week.
Be prepared for old fashioned WC's, bring your own toilet paper and coins to pay for access.
The public transit is excellent and most attraction are within walking distance. We walked 6-10 kms per day.
Breathtaking, chaotic and a thrill to the senses
Our European Trip. I loved all I saw in Istanbul, all the sights, the very friendly people. The grand Bazaar, The Med Sea, Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque and all the Mosques.
beautiful city. Istanbul makes you feel like you are at the cusp of the world's richest history and the pulsating heart of the contemporary
good, but crowds- get up early to aviod. We arrived early in Istanbul and so were able to see the historic area clear of tourists! set your alarm for a peaceful experience of the sites of sultanamet!
The Grand Bazaar Istanbul. A complete sensory overload with all the vibrancy, noise, people, colour, excitement and fantastic shopping all under cover. Go there you will love it!
Many centuries living toguether. I loved Istambul !! History and ruins, Art art crafts, mosques and churches, everything remarkable. Nice shopping as well !!

Sultanahmed Area. We loved the Hagia Sophia, shopping in the Spice Bazaar area, the hop-on hop-off Big Bus Tour, the Bosphorus Cruise and the little Arasta Bazaar as well as the Sultana Dance Show & meal.
Amazing place. All the major sites are well worth a visit. The istanbul museum card is worth getting if you're there for 3 days as it fast tracks entry to things.

Lalelei Area. Lalelei is not as bad as some of the reviews make it out to be. I spent a week at the Hotel Grand Washington in Lalelei and the area was quite vibrant and we felt safe there. Plenty of places to eat and not too far from the main attractions.

HISTORY. Many interesting free or inexpensive historical attractions within easy transport links. Too many would be 'companions/guides' near attractions. The main drawbacks were long queues, few staff able to speak international languages.

Old town with great sights. The Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Basilica Cistern, Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia) and Topkapi Palace are a must-see sights for anyone visiting Istanbul. Some people may not feel the 30 Turkish Lira charge for the Hagia Sophia (Ayasofya) is worth due to limited access due scaffolding erected for the renovation work. However, it is religiously historical to see.
Loved it here. Walked miles it is beautiful and welcoming city. We arrived midweek and it was significantly less busy than it was by Saturday. Lots of beautiful photos and memories.
Hagai Sophia Museum. A visit to this historic Museum is a must see if you are visiting istanbul. The paintings were unbelievable, this Museum was once a Mosque, a church and now a Muesum..
Crowded but beautiful. I love Istanbul however find it a very crowded city,a city that's never sleeping amazing food and friendly people
MUST VISIT. You can spend a lot of time here.Enough places to eat and drink.Take a taxi here because the parking charges are very high.

BASILICA CISTERN/SUNKEN PALACE IN SULTANAHMET. Despite a green wet looking marble column with tear drops engraved on it and upsidedown medusa head It did not feel spooky but it felt rather spiritual. Mystical music in the background was interesting. The whole cistern was more or less in it's original appearance apart from the decreased water level It was like going back in time to the 6th century, Byzantine of Emperor Justinius I. Good experience. If you go to Istanbul I highly recommend it.

Mosques and more Mosques. You cant miss them..visually and Audibly. Amazing structures and remarkable feats of engineering and construction considering the times in which they were constructed. A fascinating 'status' symbol of major personages throughout the ages..the oneupmanship tales are fascinating..and continue.. Markets are a must to visit..the range and amount of merchandise and foodstuffs bogles the comprehension.. a cornucopia of sights, sounds, smells and tastes. Istanbul is Amazing
Enjoy the traditional Turkish food in Top Kapi. Beautiful location, fantastic scenery and generous service. Prices reasonable. Liked food, Seatings overlooking beautiful view. Good service.

Back to the time of the Sultans!!. Loved Sultanahmnet! Definitely the place to stay in Istanbul!! Walking distance to all the historical areas like Topkapi place,Blue Mosque Basilica Cisterns,Hagia Sophia and also the must see Grand bazaar and Egyptian Spice market.I would definatley go back to this area again! 1 week is not enough!!

"Very impressive". The Blue Mosque has the definite "wow" factor. Truly worth a visit.Hagia Sophia is very historic.Topkapi Palace. Nothing like a European palace. It is more like a mini town. Well worth a visit.

Topkapi. This was the highlight of my trip, above everything else around Sultanahmet.Beautiful artefacts, not too many to become boring, fantastic architecture, tiling etc beautifully preserved and historically so interesting. Amazing views from the Palace over the Bosphorous and beyond.Wish there wasn't so many others, so busy. Buy a museum pass, it allows you to go to front go queue, need to get there earlyish too (by 10am) to avoid the worst and heat.

History at every corner. Istanbul has to be one of the Greatest cities in the World. You will be in awe as you walk from one historical sight to another. Get your cameras charged up with plenty of extra storage as you will definitely need it.
Real History!. Busy during September, tourist high season. But crowds were always manageable. I self-explored and still learned more than I expected.
So much history to absorb!. A gracious host to a huge summer crowd. Massive numbers of people everywhere we went but waiting and queueing time was always short.

Bus, tram, ferry and train have different ticketing. You need metal tokens for the ferries; plastic tokens for the trams; a ticket for the train - these are all 4 TL. The bus requires a multi-trip card. As a tourist there was always someone willing to use their card on the bus and I would pay them. The token dispensers for the tram and ferry looked the same to me and I purchased the wrong tokens - from then on I asked people. Public transport was very easy and quicker than taxis most of the time. We caught a train from Sirkeci under the Bosporus to the Uskadar on Asian side and a ferry back just above the palace at Besiktas - then caught a tram all the way back to Sultanahmet after touring the palace. The bus to the old Chora (Kariye) Church and back from Eminonu was easier than we thought as well.

Wonderful Istanbul. Loved the architecture and the general vibe of the city , some much to see and do . A must is to spend time on the Bosporus , doing that gets you to sea another prospective of the this beautiful city

Blue mosque, higia Sophia and old palace. We went there on Saturday, so crowded. It is a little bit stretchy if you want to see all of these in one weekend day. Suggest go to old palace and blue mosque in the early morning by 9am or late afternoon by 4:45. There is another one you can not miss. The museum next to the old palace, a lot of Lycian coffins, so delicate and vivid representing their life or fairy tales at that time. Food: very expensive, we tried some kababs opposite to the museum, not good.Water: bring your water.Mosque rules: no worries. Girls can get a light blue scarf at the entrance to cover the hair and all can get a plastic bag to wrap up your shoes also at the entrance. Gifts: you know it, not recommended here. You can go to spice market or grand bazaar.

Amazing City full of Surprises. Istanbul is a great city with so much energy. It is like a great organized chaos where modernity stands next to historic areas. Walk around, in the small street, you'll love it.
how to see Istanbul in Comfort. We liked everything we saw, we disliked the queues, crowds & heat which with Suzette's help we avoided the worst of it.
Walking in Istanbul. You can spend two days enjoying old Istanbul by walking to nearly every site. The Blue Mosque is a highlight as was Haga Sofia.

Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque. To do all of these in one day was a bit much, but each one is wonderful. Try doing them over three days if you have the time. Also, don't miss the underground cistern, in the same square.
Very informative . Istanbul is rich with history and plays a big role in mapping civilization which are generously found and preserved in the city. Very interesting.

Blue Mosque (Sultan Ahmet). Blue Mosque is located in the heart of Sultan Ahmet market place. Well connected by surface tram and taxis along with Big Bus. Worth visiting place to all travelers visitng Istanbul

Crowded, but fascinating. We stayed in the Sirkeci district, and found it to be very easy to walk to all of the important sites in the Sultahnamet. Just follow the tram rails, but watch out for traffic! It appears that the pedestrian lights are only used as a guideline, so be sure that you have a clear path before you cross the street. Better yet, just follow the lead of the locals in a group. The streets are quite crowded, and traffic is CRAZY, but we found everyone to be friendly. SO much to see in Istanbul-- an amazing city that I didn't know much about before our visit.

Do it on your own.. This city is alive with people. Nearly 18 million of them. We did a day tour, but found that we were waiting for so many people that we feel we wasted a lot of time. It could be done on your own with no problem. Everything is so close to each other that it is easy to find your way around the old city.

the whole city is like a walk-in museum. Istanbul has been the capital of 3 major empires: Roman, Byzantine and Ottoman. So, the whole city is like a walk-in museum itself. You will get overwhelmed seeing all the historic areas.

Enjoy your time exploring. Visit all that the area has to offer. If Turkish coffee is a little to strong or bitter, find a Starbucks on Restaurant Row (half way between the Blue Mosque and the Grand Bazaar).

A city of 1001 emotions. Istanbul is huge, in every meaning of the word. An enormous city with over 20 milj people. SO,... it's never really "quit". But still, if you avoid the tourist-season (july-august) and plan your stay in September or june you will have an wonderful holiday. Don't make your stay too short (most people only go 2-3 days, but relly that's a shame and an insult to the city. Don't be afraid you will bore-out after 3 day's but take your time in the musea, squares, mosks etc. Even take the day of and go on a boat tour to the Princess-islands and enjoy there the really quit life! When you book a hotel or stay, preferably do that in the old city. You'll be on walking distance of the most famous places. When you cross-over the Bosporus then, take the tramway. Almost free ( take a Istanbul Card and ride for 1,5 Lira or 0,4 €). When you take a boat trip. Avoid the tourist boats. They cost you al lot of money and you'll be treated like cattle. Better take the old ferry's and take a step in the Istanbul life. The boats are very cheap. You'll a lot of fun and ... finally you see more of the Bosporus than those tourist boats who rush over the water.
Beautiful Blue Mosque. Very quite emotional really looking around this amazing Mosque, don't forget to up at the Artwork incredible. - Toilets are the cleanest I've seen.
What an amazing city. The buildings, mosques, Palace, etc are all fantastic and very much worth visiting. Especially if you are at all interested in history and/or beautiful architecture.
One of Europe's greatest cities. Thread of cultures that occupied this strategic straight. Mostly respectful treatments of differing religions.
splendid!. I stayed there for one month, saw all historic places in Istanbul more than once. and would definitely visit again.

im in love with it. every thing is amazing in turkey. there is always something to do or somewhere to see!! also amenuno. i liked walking there from the taxim sequare to the Fateh area. i realy hate taxis there!!! i loved the spice market and the shops around there. im always in istanbul and can't get enough of it

Thank you for the reviews but beware of Taxi drivers. We came to istanbul last evening from Cappadocia and went to the Taksim square area in a taxi but when we were coming back in another taxi we were overcharged and also I handed over 2 notes of 20 Turkish lire each but he said I gave him of 5 lire each - which was not true at all as I had just taken out the cash from the ATM and did not have any 5s. Just be careful please and not have the same experience again. We are just going to the old city area and looking forward to seeing all the sites mentioned here. Cheers
Istanbul Visit. showcases the mix of European and Asian culture in the most unique manner. the co-existence of a multi religious society was also a revelation

Tourist-friendly, but language is a problem sometimes. Went with site-seeing tour organized by the ministry of tourism. It was a very good choice since we were able to go to Ayah Sophia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Bazaar all in one full day including transportation and lunch with a very reasonable price. We also visited Dolmapache Palace and Princes Island the next day on our own. In general, Istanbul is very tourist-friendly when it comes to transportation, people, site-seeing,and entertainment. However, we wouldve preferred if there were more signs other languages than Turkish (English for example). This wouldve been more helpful especially that most locals speak only Turkish
Historic Site. There was nothing not to like. Each site that we saw was more amazing than the next. To think that so many sites from the 6th century bc have been uncovered is mindbogling

Authentic. I wasn't sure if a wander through the old city district would be safe but I can assure you, I have never felt safer in a foreign city. Despite such a foreign language, it didn't take long to figure out signage and everyone was so friendly and helpful. If you had the foresight to book a hotel in the historic district, then you will find that everything is within walking distance, St Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, and so on and so on. Restaurants and cafes of all sorts abound and there is plenty of shopping areas close by if you're in the mood. If you don't stay in the historic quarter then not to worry. Public transport is inexpensive and plentiful. We have visited a number of "historic areas" in other cities in other countries and this is one of the best maintained we have been in.

Amazing!. The best part of istanbul especially if you are interested in ottoman history!I loved even just walking through the cobbled roads and sampling the local cuisine (which is also yummy) if you can, try to stay in this area rather than taksim for example as you really get a feel for turkish history and culture

Unmissable. We were in Istanbul just for a day, coming by cruiser, but managed to visit almost all the important sites due to good organization and excellent guide. Everything is easy to visit because most of the sites are very close one to another. It is impressive to see and feel the spirit of Ottoman empire along with roman and byzantine remains. People are very friendly and public transport is the best solution for going around.

Vibrant city with friendly people. Stayed at Pera district, walking distant to historical sites, shops bazaar and golden horn.
We were fascinated with what Istanbul (Costantinople) had to offer
Great trip. Wonderful history; great sites; interesting people; great food; everything you could want in a trip.

Magnificent!. The 'old' section of Istanbul--areas south of the Golden Horn primarily--is magnificent. The place reeks of history including roman, byzantine and ottoman empire remains that are simply breathtaking.Also important to me at least is that I found the Turkish people hospitable and friendly. I never felt the least threatened nor did I see any evidence of pickpockets or dangerous looking people. Frankly, Istanbul seemed safer than Rome.

Seraglio Point. Everything is easy to get to by just walking. Stretching the body relaxes the mind. Streets are narrow and quaint. A modern tramway connects the 'old' areas with the Bospherous and the Sultan's new palace. An easy way to get about. A fenicular at the end of the lime connects the Bosphorus with the shopping area.

Sultan Ahmed touring. If you are going to tour the primary historical areas of Istanbul stay in the old city,the Sultan Ahmed (Aakmed) area. There are some excellent hotels and you can walk or hop tourist buses to anyplace in 10 to 15 minutes.

Truly awsome. I thought we would be travelling all over the city to see everything we came to see but no. Everything was a tram ride and in most cases only a walk away from each other. Everything is clearly sign posted,and to see Istanbul at night and hear the call to prayer is truly an experience I will never forget.

Fascinating City with a Wealth of History. touring the mosques, the bazaar and just getting lost on the many side streets in the city were great. My big dislike is the traffic, which at times is horrendous and can take hours to get places.
you have to go. Why would you be in Istanbul if you did not see the historic areas? Get out there and see what Istanbul has to offer.

Places to visit in Istanbul Old Town. There is so much history within walking distance from the Cistern, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia. One can walk to Topaki Place and to catch a ferry for a ride on the Bosporus.
Nice to visit when is sunset. The view is amazing and you can enjoy the sunset there. Do not forget your camera, because you will record the great moment
well worth a visit. Just for the History but the queues on a Cruise ship day are long & the people trying to tempt you into buying Carpets/Rugs are far to numerous

Turkey. brilliant country with a history interesting to westerners. The history explains a lot about Christian and Muslim compatibility. The sites were fantastic and worth exploring. The gullet is a must to go from south of Turkey up to near Troy. Gallipoli and the other historical sites are all worthwhile. Food is surprisingly top shelf.

History of Istanbul.... You must go and visit Historical Areas of Istanbul because they are history of Istanbul. you need about 4 days to visit Istanbul most important historical places: Sultanahmet district (Topkapi Palace, Sultanahmet mosque, Hagia ayasofia museum, Basilica Cistern), Taksim and Kabatash (Dolmabahca Palace, Taksim sq, Istiklal street, Church of St. Anthony of Padua), Karakoy (Galata tower), Golden horn (Kizkulasi tower) Fatih/Aksarary (Kapali Carsi and Misir Carsi). An important point is you can visit this places using subway and tram and no need to taxi. Taxis in isanbul are very expensive. If you want to see most of Istanbul Historic places and shopping and entertainment you need one week to complete this trip.

Center of the Western World for Many Centuries. Istanbul has some of the most fantastic sites within a few minutes walking distance. We just finished our second trip and enjoyed showing the city off to some friends who came with us. It is definitely a long haul from the US, but worth it. Also we found the prices to be very reasonable at hotels and restaurants. Also, the people are friendly and the merchants are not aggressive, especially once you say no thank you, and have a nice day. This is priceless.
Just a nice dream. it was realy a nice dream while walking through those historic areas of Istanbul , Galata Tower , old market , Egyptian Pazar you will walk for hours and you will not get bored

Suggestions for Istanbul. Practical advice on places to visit in İstanbul in case you are going to stay for a short time in this historical and beautiful city. Here are quick tips for tourists sorted by number of days of visit:1 day: Hagia Sophia museum, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern or Sunken Cistern, Grand Bazaar. These historical Places are in the same area close to each other except for the grand Bazaar which may necessitate a short bus ride. 2 days: In addition to the above a sea cruise along the Bosphorus with a visit of the historical Rumelihisarı or Roumeli Hisar Castle and possibly Anadolu Hisarı or Anatolian Castle.3 days: In addition to the above a visit to the Süleymaniye Mosque, to Chora Church or Kariye Camii, the Galata Tower, the Taksim Square and İstiklal Caddesi.Each one of these places deserves a review which will be coming in the future. I hope these quick tips will be of help to visitors.
Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, Galata Tower. Beautiful historical features, and busy and bustling.Active spots, and must be seen. Enjoy it all, even the carpet salesmen... ciao

Amazing Architecture!. There is soooo much to see in a city steeped in history with mosques, museums and historic sights at every corner. Public transport is great and most of the popular sights are walking distance from each other.

must-see historical sites. All the usual landmarks - Topkapi Palace, Agia Sophia Musueum, Blue Mosque, but don't miss the Basilica Cistern - fantastic ancient underground reservoir, literally dripping with atmosphere

Historic Area of Istanbul. We used a taxi driver at the cruise terminal for a tour around Istanbul. He spoke good english. He took us to the Historic area to see the statues, shops and booths. Lots of booths selling flowers, especially roses and some of the roses were rainbow coloured pedals. Not sure how they do that but very impressive. The historic area has all cobble stones, and easy parking areas to see the different statues in the courtyard. It was nice to see and for sure stop to see on your next trip to Istanbul.
Great historic city. Liked almost everything. Great historic city. Disliked the so many street vendors. Liked the covered market and the Topkapi Palace.

Istnabul is a must-see. Mosques, Topkapi palace, Hagia Sofia. All ancient sites are worthy of time to visit. If you think Turkey is dirty, it is not; someone is sweeping all the time. Food is very good.
magical. sultana met area Istanbul is magical at night, great for people watching, promenading around the hippodrome, and sipping cool beer in any of the restaurants.

Istanbul Magic. Istanbul historical areas were surprisingly accessible -- the Blue Mosque, Ayasofya, Cistern, Topkapi palace, Spice Market and Grand Bazaar are all within walking distance of each other. Go when it isn't as crowded and take yourself back in history. It was truly magical. I felt safe, people were friendly and respectful, and it was beautiful. Truly one of those few places for a must visit.

Wonderful historic buildings. There are so many sights to see in the Historic part of Istanbul, many within easy reach of each other but make sure you allow enough time for each. The Blue Mosque was definitely worth the wait of an hour, Hagia Sophia fascinating but quite dark and brooding and the Topkapi Palace was really the icing on the cake. Not to mention the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. To fit it all into a weekend was a real challenge.

Awe Inspiring. The old city of Istanbul is a treasure trove of beautiful buildings, markets, small restaurants, crowds and little back streets. It would take years to really know this city and a week just gives you a taste of the possibilities.
Amazing Metropolis. Istanbul is such a stunning city, vibrant, hectic, historical, colossal, imperial and unique, nothing else to say, just such a wonderful place on the earth ;)
Authentic and wonderful. Istanbul is really half European and half Middle Eastern. It was fun to explore as around corners you could find the most interesting stuff.
We saw all the usual things. Blue Mosque, Haga Sophia, roman cisterns, Topkapi museum, all definitely worth seeing. But wear your walking shoes, it's a lot. And RUN from carpet salesmen
Nice. Interesting I like historic areas but it good for one visit only. if your staying in hotel in that area it will be great area for short enjoyment when your not up for long sight seeing
a must visit. needs half a day. prepare to queue. I honestly dislike the sunken castle. we visited blue mosque and topkapi, saved hagia sophia for another day to really enjoy.
Fairytail. There are beautyfull and really old buildings in Istanbul. In the evening when the blue mosque en Aya Sofia are covered in light it's like a fairytail.
History. Truly everything is great, the city is full of history and plenty of choices, its a big place to visit.
Great, but be careful.... A great place to spend the day, but beware of pick pockets as there are many suspicious people around. we had one try to distract us and bumped into us (but not so sure).

Istanbul - A City to remember. We had 4 brilliant days in Istanbul under the guidance of the excellent tour operators led by Adnan Koksal. Istanbul is a city of grand palaces, mosques blending with all the modern faciitiies. An excellent fusion of east and west. Unmissable. One should keep time in hand and enjoy this place of historical excellence.

All of Istanbul is historic! Pace yourself.. Visiting Istanbul is like visiting Rome or Paris; there is history around every corner. At peak season the problem is crowds. If you dont use a guide, plan wisely; go early in day and late afternoons, early evenings when it's cooler. Stop for lunch and tea breaks in the numerous parks and gardens around the monuments and mosques. Hospitable,friendly people are willing to help, but avoid persons whose motive is to sell you something. "I already have one, thank you", is a safe response.

Can't miss, even if it's just a long layover!. Istanbul's historic sites have so much to offer travelers! Most interesting to me are the rococo water fountains outside of the Topkapi Palace. The old town is very clean and there are tourism police everywhere. They can assist you with directions, calling a cab, and any thing else you may need. The historic areas all feel very safe and are well lit at night. We enjoyed walking around during an overnight layover. There is an easy train straight from the airport to the light rail, which will take you to the historic area. No attractions are open (most sites close at 10pm), but it's still beautiful to see.

Grand bazar and the Blue mosque. Visiting the grand bazar is a must , to walk in the most amazing market and pick up a souvenir to carry home is a pleasure you will remember for a long time . Bargain and have fun . If you like the home items then your at luck .Walk down to the Egyptian bazar and get local taste of cheeses and Lekum .The blue mosque gardens and surrounding is equally captivating , sit on a bench and watch the locals , it will give you a feel of real Istanbul .

Breathtaking city with very significant and important historic sites. Beautiful art & architecture all over the city. Well organized museums and tourist services. I felt very safe during the day & night. Lots of families with children in strollers spending quality time together, even late at night. Hagia Sophia is a must see. Also enjoyed Tokapi Palace & Basilica Cistern. Taking the 2$ ferry ride over the Bosphorus to spend the afternoon on the Asian side of Istanbul was also a nice experience. Grand Bazaar & Spice Market were also fascinating, but be wary of eager vendors wanting to sell you everything you don't need. It can be exhausting saying 'no thank you' all the time. But It's fun to just sit back at a cafe with a Turkish coffee & take it all in. Food in Istanbul was also great. From the small Döner Kebab stands to the gourmet restaurants. Hard to find a bad meal.

Memorable family reunion trip.. Istanbul, Konya and Antalya have wonderful sightseeing place. Great Turkish coffee. Since we were on the go and we were a large group of 45 restaurant food were not to my taste.

More than mosques. Yes, see the mosques, but also visit museums, Grand Bazaar, Turkish Baths, Camlica Hill, Cistern Basilica. I was there also in 1998 and Istanbul has grown, become even more modern and cosmopolitan than it was then.

Sightseeing in Istanbul. The City of two Continents, Istanbul is full of historic sites . There is so much history linked to Istanbul and visiting the Blue Dome, Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar and many more are a must.
The Real East Meets West Experience. Loved Istanbul, a real place of history for family and friends.We disliked traders ripping of tourists.

Need lots of time. We only saw a couple of the historic items of Istanbul for the simple fact of QUEUES even if you go for a private tour you have to queue and wait and wait. But what you see is incredible. And be sure to bring an umbrella and decent footwear as due to the city being built on hills there can be some incredible rainstorms and the streets then run like rivers we had to throw away our shoes after one such storm. Monday to Friday roads can be very hectic, we arrived on a Thursday afternoon and it took us nearly 1.5hrs from the airport to our hotel but on Sunday when we left it only took 20mins so be aware. But it's a lovely city and would definitely visit again.

Istanbul is a must visit. Istanbul is a must visit. It is so fabulous. There is so much to see. There is so much to do. There service is head and shoulders above the service you typically get in in other European countries.
Use public transport. Taxi drivers are not reliable. Also buy your museum pass for 3 days. Use cash tellers not exchange offices - you will save in fees.

One of my RTW highlights. Istanbul is a charming mix of east & west and old & modern. The historical sites are stunning, the food is delicious and the shopping addictive! The locals were friendly, helpful and welcoming. A definite must visit place!

The best part of this city. This is the best place to start when you visit this ancient city. So much to see in this small part of town. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Aya Sofia, the Cistern plus much more awaits you. The good public transportation and Hop-on Hop-off busses will then get you to all other parts of town. I try to say close to this area when I visit for the convenience and entertainment.

Sultanahmet The Old City. This is the best part of Istanbul. You experience the culture, history and the people in this section. Turkish men are very respectful of women, unlike Egyptian men. You won 't be ogled or harassed. The Hippodrome is the center of all the main attractions like the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia etc. The Big Bus tour starts here. You buy a 24 hour ticket and you can hop on and off wherever you want. The buses run every 20 minutes. So if you want to try the Taksim section and Dolmabache Palace, this is the way to do it.There are a mind boggling number of cafés and restaurants all over Sultanahmet. Don't be afraid to explore on foot. We never felt unsafe or unwelcome. Stop anyone on the street and they will happily give you directions.Absolutely wear good sturdy walking shoes. The streets are brick and surfaces very uneven.Your best value for seeing the attractions is to buy a 3 or 5 day museum pass. You save money and you won't have to wait in incredibly long lines to get tickets at each venue.

See the Real Istanbul. Pick either the Galata Area or the part of town around the Blue Mosque. Walk around late afternoon or evening when its cooler and the locals all come out for business or social reasons. It s fun to wander around little shops and restaurants and do like the locals. Buy an icecream and watch the locals watch you. See amazing street full of lighting fittings, plumbing supplies or guns.

Ah, Istanbul. I love Istanbul. Friendly people, colorful culture, delicious food and incredible history. So many important - and interesting - sites in such a small area make this a great place to visit. The attractions can be evaluated on their own, but basically you want to see them all. And then there's the shopping - another subject entirely. The tram makes getting around easy, although most everything is walking distance anyway. Just go!

Bricked houses, Castles, Shrines, and mosques. The old baked brick lined houses with samll streets and passionately designed masjids (rather all worship places) will make you feel yo're visiting 50s and snap you back in time when you'll be greeted by people with a mix of western liberal and eastern conservative touch.

You need time in Istanbul. Istanbul filled our hearts with delights and happiness . Take time to walk and see and feel. Must do things are the Bospherus cruise ,The Blue Mosque , Topkapi Palace, Aya Sophia, The basilica Cistern .

All fairly close. The best part is that everything that is sight seeing is pretty much close together. You can chose to walk or get on a train and get there in 2-3 minutes from one attraction to the other. Each place takes atleast an hour minimum to see properly. So plan accordingly

A city like no other. The historic part of Istanbul is filled with rich and diverse culture - from Byzantine, Roman and Ottoman. Istanbul is in every aspect a city like no other on earth! One leg firmly planted in Europe and the other in Asia, divided by the sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn.Do not miss a visit to the Basilica Cistern. The mystical grandeur of this architectural wonder with it's impressive columns is absolutely breathtaking! The orientation of the two Medusa heads (one placed upside down and the other one sideways) has been a question of much discussion. The Basilica Cistern was built in the 6th century AD by Byzantine Emperor Justinian. The cistern provided water to various properties.Escape the heat and marvel this absolute gem in Sultanahmet!The Hagia Sofia museum/church (Ayasofya) whose name means "Holy Wisdom" in Greek was built in the 6th Century AD. The Hagia Sofia is extremely rich and diverse in history, culture and architecture - from Byzantine Basilica (Greek Orthodox) to Mosque and since 1935 a museum.The building with all it's grandeur both inside and outside is truly spectacular and not to be missed! The tombs at the back of the Hagia Sofia are also very interesting to see.It is lovely to sit in the park next to the Blue Mosque on the benches with magnificent views of the illuminated minarets of the Blue Mosque in the evening. Men are not allowed to wear shorts and women's head, shoulders and knees need to be covered before entering the Blue Mosque. Shoes must also be removed and bags are provided at the entrance to put them in. I can strongly advise all women travelling to Istanbul to keep a scarf (pashmina) in their handbags. Not only do you need it when entering Mosques but it can be handy if you want to feel a little more "covered" while travelling in Turkey.Do not miss the "footbaths" on the park side of the Mosque.The Grand Bazaar is one of the largest covered markets in the world with 60 streets and 400 shops that has been an important trading center since 1461.The Bazaar is within 15 minutes walk from the Hagia Sofia & Blue Mosque. Follow the tram line straight up and you will find the covered market on your right.Yes, it is crowded with tourists, pushy salesmen and thousands of shops but with the right attitude and a sense of humor a visit to the bazaar can be fun (haggle for prices) and a unique Turkish experience.Take a picture of the entrance (numbered) where you enter the bazaar to make sure you won't get lost!My husband and I did not stay far from the Arasta Bazaar (Eresin Crown Hotel - proven to be an excellent choice) which is well worth a visit. The Arasta Bazaar consists of one street with shops on both sides. The quality of the goods on display are a cut above the rest in comparison to many other overpriced shops in the Sultanahmet district.Do not miss the Topkapi Palace! The Topkapi Palace was once the primary residence of the Ottoman Sultans for approximately 400 years - fascinating and intriguing! The Palace is situated behind the Hagia Sofia, within a 5 minute's walk.I can strongly suggest to stay in the Sultanahmet area as it is within walking distance to all the historic sites and gems that Istanbul has to offer.Do try the Ottoman cuisine at one of the many restaurants in the area. Cooked with love and care and bursting with flavor!Buy bottled water at supermarkets/cafes for it is much cheaper than at the stands surrounding the popular attractions. Wine can also be bought in supermarkets/cafes at reasonable prices. For those of you that do not know - liquor is very expensive in Istanbul.Do your research thoroughly before you visit Istanbul. It will help to better understand the rich and diverse history and culture that lies in the historic areas of Istanbul.We fell in love with Istanbul during our visit in June 2013. Two and a half days were not nearly enough to explore all the gems this marvelous city has to offer! On the other hand, it is a very good excuse to visit Istanbul again as soon as possible!We cannot wait to go back!
Blue mosque. The hotel did not tell us when we asked that the queues for getting into the mosque could be around 4 hours in the scorching sun.
Istanbul - historic sights. So many sights and places within a small area. Locals very friendly and helpful. No hassling if we didn't want to take up their offers. Stunning architecture and tiles.
Amazing. Window into the Ottoman Empire and the magnificent civilization of Islam. Breathtaking museums, mosques, and sites.
2 weeks in Istanbul. We visited all the recommended sites. We especially enjoyed the cruise on the Bosphorus and the new aquarium. We were not disappointed in any of the sites.
Go early to avoid lines. Very long lines at Topkapi (closed on Tuesdays), Dolmebahche, and Aya sofia. Go in early. Bebek neighborhood is definitely a must see

A well executed tourist trap of epic proportions. If you have it, you got to show it and Istanbul does. Tourists everywhere and a well oiled machine to take their money away.Can't blame them. Some of the tricks are a bit old and transparent but that brings stand up comedy to the streets. Enjoyed tricking the trickers. Crime seemed to be amazingly low. A place to go to at least once. Well worth it if you have sense of humor.

So much history to see one month is not enough. If you intend to visit Istanbul make sure you stay as long as you can or plan to visit a second time in the future. There is just not enough time to explore and see what this marvel has to offer. Fascinating!

Cradle of Civilization, Where to Begin?. We spent a lot of time planning for this 8-day trip. It was our first and we knew there was a lot to see. We were not wrong. This is one of the most interesting places I have ever been and we could not get everything we wanted to do completed in a week. We're coming back!There is so much history here one is overwhelmed with the available options. Take advantage of things like the hop-on-hop-off buses, guides, the tram lines, ferries and Metro. It will help your experience, but be sure to walk and see the great little surprises (and cats) the city has to offer! Get an Istanbul card (kiosk in Metro stations allow you to purchase cards for 10 TL - 4 for the card itself - have 10 TL bills if possible) and put money on it. It works on all public transit and will make your life much easier. Everyone is courteous, the food is some of the best in the world, and the views from all directions are incredible. Be sure to see Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi by night. It's incredible. We got an added bonus of a big, full moon. One important key to enjoying some of the historical places is to start early. Lines can get long, especially if cruise ships are in port. We did not get a museum pass which is a good idea. We had a guide so that took care of a lot of line issues for us. Also, be sure to respect the mosque rules and the local culture. It is important. This is one of the most culturally and historically interesting cities in the world.
amizing. Oh my god it was great and dazzling sightseeing landscapes recommended every body go and enjoy it . it was historical and beautiful city
Boats. Boats are very crowded and nobody interested in the sights our boat did not follow the map directions which caused a little confusion with the audio we had hired!

Historic places in Istanbul. This place has so much history behind it. It was amazing to explore hundreds of years of history covering two great empires. The locals here are extremely polite and courteous.

Blue Mosque, grand bazaar, Sultans Palace. An amazing tour through these places and to here some of the history. The day we visited these places was very busy with tour groups. What I didn't enjoy was the people pushing past to get better views., most of the time it was unnecessary.

Istambul is a city with a long history.. Great city with a lot of history. Visit the main sites for sure ( Blue Mosk, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace, etc..), Walk in the small streets, visit the Bazar. My only disappointment was that the Aya Sophia was still being repaired and not much ( in my opinion was progressed in the last 10 years). I was surprised that the acient Christian ( Konstantinople ruins and actifacts) are not well looked after and left without protection from the public that are using them as sitting areas, old ( empty) crusader tombs in a cafe, where they collect garbage, bottles etc.. With tourism being the main income, one should expect better care. Overall amazing city
You need to see. I enjoyed the whole experience. Aya Sofia is just amazing when you see it close up. Massive and of course the water cistern is also a must.

No city like it. I have traveled all over the world, and lived in Egypt for years. I consider Cairo a world historic treasure, adore Paris and treasure London. But there is simply no other place in the world like Istanbul. If the Nile is Egypt's gift, then the Bosphorus, the Sea of Marmara and the Golden Horn are Istanbul's absolute treasure. With the Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Dohlmabahçe Palace, Ciragan Palace, the Grand Bazaar, Taksim Square and (a real surprise) the Salt Galata Museum, you are immersed in a city of historic glory. I just got home from my 9-day trip and I am still in the afterglow of this city. People are easygoing with foreigners (and I traveled as a woman alone). And the food is amazing!

Historic Sites in Sultanahmet. The historic sites in Sultanahmet are very interesting and easy to purchase tickets. If you happen to enter the Blue Mosque wearing shorts or other inappropriate clothing, they have garments you can use to cover yours, out of respect for this active mosque.If you are in the area and have time, you should visit the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, and the Grand Bazaar. The Spice Bazaar is also worth seeing. If you start early, it is possible to see all of these in 2 to 2 1/2 days along with the Hippodrome and Milion. For the third day, I would recommend a ferry trip on the Bosphorus and/or Golden Horn and a trip to the Galata Tower. The tower has a restaurant at the top, but the real attraction is the view from the top of the tower.
Best City to visit. I love Istanbul, each time i visit it i feel like it's my second home and look forward to the next visit.

Nice but neglected. Historic areas in Istanbul are something magnificent and definitely worth a visit. However it is a pity to see that the whole are is neglected and some pieces of art are just left at the corner of some street in the dirt.
characteristic old city. loved the old city of Istanbul esp Topkapi, Grand Bazaar but also the little side streets where you can find some gems

What makes Istanbul, Istanbul. if you managed to visit Istanbul, and you MUST NOW! than later (i wont get into why not later) then Sirkeci area is the spot on place to be, next to Eminonu, you cant go wrong to book your hotel in this area. just make sure you have great walking shoes! and if not, you can always get to one of those turkish baths and relieve your achy feet and body.
filled with history. When visiting Istanbul you are steeped in history and it is a must that you visit some of the sights mainly in the Sultanamet area
Very interesting. Impressive! - many hundreds of years of history in these places, full of history that really changed the face of the earth!
The only place on earth. It is an incredible feeling being in a place where so much of import has happened in human history. I'm glad I was able to see it on my honeymoon.

3.000 or 8.000 years old - that is the question. Historic areas of Istanbul are not limited to where millions of tourists pour in, the area of the ancient hippodrome and around it - the space within the longest still existing city wall which is identical to the last resort of the Byzantine Emperor before giving up. The area is inhabited since the stone age. What I like is that the tourist area was a capital of two of the most importants empires for about 1600 years. E.g. Hagia Sophia, built in 532 is not even very old compared to the city. What I dislike is the crown during summer. If you wish to visit Topkapı you should go there is November to February. I also dislike that the Quadriga has gone forever. It is now in Venice and called the Horses of San marco.

very interesting. Every were you look in this area there is some were to visit,so many historical building from the mosques to the Cisterne, the palace, Many cafes restaurants carpet shops, the place is busy and interesting nice people.

City of civilization. This is my city. Beatiful Istanbul. Istanbul over the years have hosted many civilizations.Meeting point of civilizations. You can see traces everywhere of Ottoman, Byzantine, Roman Empires. Sea is close to old city. Istanbul is so cheap. Meals are very tasty. You should visit Prince Islands. Maybe a month is not enough for sightseeing in Istanbul.

Unique in the world. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace and Basilica Cistern are walking distance from one another and quite unique. Never seen a classic Islamic and classic Christian monument facing one another...
Amzing Historical Sceens. I enjoyed the histrocial mosques and the amazing history of the ottaman era. The Hammam was new and unique experience that I recommend every visitror to try.

Istanbul. Lots to see and visit in this city. I would recommend getting a personal tour guide. Enjoyed seeing the Blue Mosque, Sofia, grand bazaar, took a river cruise, and watched the whirling dervishes.

Sublime city!. Istanbul has it all, ultra modern in parts and ancient in others. Set against the Bosporus, the cities lifeblood, the old ares of Istanbul are filled with narrow streets, bustling markets and shops and restaurants. Tips: grab a ferry over to asian side, eat a Balik Ekmek (Fish sandwich) from a seller and a beer from a restaurant and watch the city "move"

all within 2 k in old Istanbul. Kebab at Hamdy restaurant the best of the best, also the Yeni Raki Allah is no 1, bargain and bargain, fake Lacoste very good quality, beware some Baklava pastry shop price is over exagerated,we attended an Anatolian show excellent,walking is safe after midnight, whitin 2 k u are within muséums, churches, mosque, and coffe shops
