Historical Areas. We loved the palaces, the mosques and catherals. Travelling on a ferry before sunset by two hours is wonderful. I do not recommend to travel during August as the weather during day time is too hot and high season as it is crowded.

A "Must Do" For A One Day Or Two Half Day Outings In Istanbul! :). The Blue Mosque, Topkapki Palace, Cistern Bascilica, Grand Bazar and Spice Market. All a must see. Experience the culture, learn about the history and religious influence of this country and its people. women must cover their heads and no shorts for men or women at the mosque. Two half days to tour these sites, some may want more time, but it is doable.

Historical beauty..2 continent one city..150 civilizations. Cheap..beautiful..too many attractions that not written here..tio many civilizations had lived..culture..hospitable people..delicious meals..bosphorus..i think thomas more depicted here as writing his book utopia...must be seen in three days istanbul than go to izmir ephesus. Too many Saint's places and Mary house..beatiful beaches south part of it..dont dead before see them all..
So much history.. Feel like you are going back in time to wander around this city. Such old buildings and so well preserved. But the city is so busty with people and traffic.

Istanbul is one of the great historical cities of the world. I liked the easy accessibility of sights in and from Sultanahmet. The tram system is easily understood and it is easy to find ferries to places on the Bosphorus.We found that it was expensive for a family of three to visit the museums.

The old charm. liked the still history, didn't like the crowd. relatively clean city but too many tourists like in NYC or London which is expaxtable. don't take your toddler and their stroller to this trip. they wouldn't enjoy it. Wear the most comfortable walkies so you are giong to walk a lot.

Istanbul, Turska. Many attractions outside Istanbul too. Ephesus, Bursa, Pammakule all - just sheer beautyalso. The Bosphorous...
more

Expected more. Istanbul is beautiful with nice ppl (most of them).. the historical areas are nice but i personally was disappointed as they aren't properly maintained and its more expensive than before. Nevertheless, one should visit it once in a lifetime

Fabulous. I had two days in Istanbul so took the hotels off of a trip round the historic views of Istanbul, the minibus from the hotel,decanted us at. Central point where we weed divided into languages and our guide spoke perfect English, mostly as a result of some years spent in England So we saw the blue mosque, Asia Naipaul, and err um lots of other places but a very good value trip.

So proud of my country. I just came back from a week in Istanbul. I am Turkish but lived in New Jersey with an American husband.My daughter asked me what I wanted for my 70th Birthday, I told her: "to go to Istanbul with my closest and dearest Friends".So it happened, 4 from the USA! Two from the UK, my three children and my four grandchildren and spouses. I made the plan to see the Old Town.First Day: Sultan Ahmet (Blue Mosque) - Binbir Direk (Water Cistern) - Aya Sofya (Santa Sophia).Day 2 - Relax and rest on a Turkish Gullet going up and down the Bosphorus.Day 3 - Misir Carsisi (Spice Market) - Rustem Pasa Mosque (my favorite mosque in Istanbul) - lunch at Havuzlu in Kapalicarsi (best restaurant of authentic Ottoman dishes in the Covered Bazar) Day 4 - Private Turkish Hammam experience at our fabulous Boutique Hotel, Sumahan on the Water - Visit of Beykerbeyi Palace.Day 5 - Yildiz Park - Dolmabahce - Suleymaniye - Tombs of Suleyman the Magnificent and Hurrem Sultan.Day 6 - Birthday Party at the fabulous Sumahan.Day 7 - We all left some to Greece, some back to UK, ourselves to Bodrum.What they didn't see and should be seen:Topkapi, somehow it didn't happen, it is closed on Tuesday and still being repaired. KARIYE Church for me almost more beautiful than Aya Sofya and lunch at Asitane.Eyup Sultan and visit of tomb of the Saint - walk up the hill among old tombs and tea or early dinner at Pierre Loti Cafe, best view in Istanbul - return by Ferry to see the Golden Horn.Buyuk Ada, the lovely and historic Princess Island.Ortakoy and it's great Fish Restaurants, also great shopping at lovely boutiques and galleries.The Koc Museum.Just to prove that one week in Istanbul is not enough!And I believe that seeing three sites is more than enough or you get what I call "Museum Indigestion"!I have been in 52 countries, Istanbul still is and remains for me the most beautiful, exotic and interesting city.
Cultural Harmony. Nothing to dislike about Istanbul.A fabulous place, friendly peopleGreat Food, easy public transport, and the best of it all are the ferries
Authentic. At fatih area where hagia sofia, blue mosque, grand bazar, topkapi palace, traditional restaurants and market are located you can really feel the essense of euthentic turkish experience

SO MUCH. More great sites within walking distance than most anywhere.
Mosques, palaces, markets shops, and lots of good reaturants to enjoy...wow!

Wonderful and interesting city to visit. I did not expect Istanbul to be so nice, modern and interesting. We were there 3 days and could have used at least three more to enjoy the many things it has to offer.
Old Town walk around. Amazing history and great sites - traffic was crazy but yeah thats small old streets for you. Countless street vendors but overall super friendly people
Fun trip!. Saw The Blue Mosque; Aya Sofia; Grand Bazaaar; Basillica Cistern; Topkapi Palace; Cruises of the Bosphorous strait; Galata Tower. Great Experience!

Pre-Planning is the Key to a Great Experience. We stayed in the Sultanahmet area to adsorb the splendour of the old city quarter of Istanbul. Can thoroughly recommend the Hotel Erboy for its location for these sites and the quality of the hotel and breakfast exceeded its 3 star rating. It was a mere 200 meters from the main square (Hippodrome) and a short further walk to the many sites that Istanbul's old quarter is renowned for.The words of warning are be prepared for long queues, some restricted opening hours, do not go near this area on any Turkish national holiday, the entry prices are steep and the walking and gazing in awe take a lot of time, so a number of days are required to do everything justice.You will, if visiting Istanbul for this experience, have planned for the main sites so do stagger your time and the days and plan the precise times to visit. You will take a thousand photos so new camera batteries (because many photos require flash photography) are essential, as is your water bottle and hat for shade. A suggestion is to initially take the Hop On Hop Off bus (2 hour circuit) between Taksim - Sultanahmet - over the Bosphorus and through fascinating neighbourhoods to orient yourself. Then you will appreciate the location of the sites / many mosques / palaces that you intend to visit. The local tram in Sultanahmet is a useful way to cover the area down to the Golden Horn ferries and further afield to the Grand Bazaar.This is a walking tour like no other. It will leave you spellbound by the sights, the architecture, the sheer expanse of the domes, the interiors and mosaics, the sheer colossal size of the structures, the extent of the Topkipi Palace (longest queues are here), and minarets are everywhere. Plan well and leave yourself time as rushing is not possible and will mean you miss so much if you perhaps only have the one trip to this huge city. The meeting of Europe - Asia is a reality in the historic area of Istanbul and this collection of sites and domes and mosaics is an equal of all that ancient Athens offers.
Amazing. History surround you continously all day long however many people try to sell carpets, souvenirs or asks for tip

Underground Water Cistern. Built in the 6th century, fascinating, must see.Sulemanlye Mosque, beautiful structure, must see.Hagia Sophia Museum/Church, most interesting, don't miss.Tokapi Palace, so much treasure, you eyes will be widen.

The definition of historic. More ancient history in 50 metres than in some entire cities. I'm particularly fascinated by the grave headstones that are 100s of years old in the ancient churches all through the area. The sea walls are fascinating. You are best to skip the taxi because the tram is fast and cheap; then walk around the oldest parts for the best experience. Leave plenty of room on your camera because you won't stop snapping.

Great location. The ancient walls of the city, Hagia Sofia, the surrounding gardens and palace including blue mosque was a great experience. The repeating questions on where are you from is after a while quite annoiying.

Must-see but very touristy. There is no denying that the Old City is a must-see in Istanbul-- the Aya Sofya and Blue Mosque are absolute givens. However, I just encourage everyone who visits the Old City to remember 1. Everything is overpriced because it is pretty much 100% a touristy neighborhood, and 2. PLEASE take time to visit other parts of Istanbul! There is so much more to this incredible city than just its touristy areas, and you would be doing a disservice to your trip if you didn't experience multiple Istanbul neighborhoods
Sultanhamet Square. Hagia Sofia was amazing! Nice restaurant right on the square or on top of the blue hotel nearby. Beautiful fountain and the Blue Mosque and Topkapi Palace are right there too!

Very large area great fun exploring. You can easily spend hours walking around exploring the historic areas of Istanbul. The combination of interesting shops, Islamic architecture, great places for food and beautiful scenery around the Bosphorus will guarantee a good time.
Fascinating. The old city is the place to be based and 5 days is about right to see the major sights. Certainly visit the Grand Bazaar but the Spice Markets are much more interesting.
Amazing History and architecture. Had a great time seeing the architectural highlights of Istanbul over 2 days with excellent Tour guides from TTG Travel (Turkey Travel Group). Thanks guys.

Use the light rail and 'Ask Me'. After reading 'The Tournament' by Matthew Reilly, the only place that was not on the our pre-booked small tour (with Istanbul Daily Tours - see my review) was the Basilica Cistern. After disembarking early we set off to exchange some Euros to Turkish Lira. Note to all travellers to Turkey's Karakoy port district. The only bank in a row of five that exchanges Euro is the Turkish Bank, and that is after you wait longer than time spent at any NSW RMS office. The good news the bank is across the road from the Ferry terminal and the light rail station of Kabatas Sea Bus Pier. When we arrived at the underground station, after missing the cars and buses on the busy road, there was an assistance ready to give locals and tourist a hand with the ticketing machines. She had to complete a questionnaire re: the quality of service of the light rail. This was a no brainer, as only Sydney builds a new Cruise Terminal without pubic transport link - you reading this Minister for Transport Gladys Berejiklian. For 2 TL each ($1) we were on the light rail to the Sultanahmet (the old area of Istanbul). On arrival there were met by high school students working as Tourism Ambassadors wearing T-shirts with the sigh 'Ask me'. Guess what I did, as we were free wheeling it - I asked for directions, they were very helpful and walked us to the entrance of the Cistern. Thankyou, Istanbul for a wonderful welcome to your country.Another bucket list location, Wow, what an experience, more columns, this time it was flood lit, underground, with a walkways over the water. The photos are from the iPad as Security Police Other Half did not want the pick pockets to take our camera. Low lux and no flash make dark and eerie photos.Please take the plunge and use local transport and all the attractions are in easy walking distance, The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and Hippodrome.

Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. We were visiting towards the end of Ramadan. Area was very active at sundown with the breaking of fast for the Muslims. It was all very interesting. It would have been nice to see the Blue Mosque with less people. Little Hagia Sophia felt more spiritual because of the crowds.
Great monuments and history. The areas around the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, and the Grand Bazaar are tourist friendly and provide a great canvas for picture taking and enjoying Istanbul.

Go out of town a little, the panoramio and the military museum are well worth a visit. Liked the tram system, didn't like finding a cruise ship in the harbour in the morning, this meant herds of feeding wilderbeest clogging up everywhere, an environmental disaster.

very nice walks. the area is steeped in historial buildings. unfortunately the people treat the area like a trash dump and toss garbage onto the street without hesitation. It would better if the people weren't so gross.

Charming Cobblestone Streets. I loved strolling through old town taking in the sights, sounds, and smells of the amazing city of Istanbul. The charming windy streets went on and on and the people are very friendly. I walked alone (during the day) and was approached by some men trying to sell me things. They can get aggressive, so you either have to be firm and keep walking or don't go it alone. I never felt unsafe, it was more of a bother than anything else. Overall, I loved my experience in Old Town and would certainyl do it again.

Istanbul - A great city like Paris or Barcelona. The historic areas are very tourist friendly, extremely interesting, and real cultural gems. That said, it is good to stay out of the Old City so you can experience other parts of this place.

lots to see. I loved the many things to see and do but make sure that when it is busy and hot (I was there in late July) you plan what you do when around the heat. Baslica cistern had really long queues in the soaring sun so we had to give it a miss, we went to Dolmabahce Palace first thing in the day and waiting outside to go in was bearable, but even then then it was close to unbearably humid and sticky inside. It is a nice place to walk everywhere or hop on a tram, and taxi's are cheap and abundant if preferred

Fascinating area. The history is fascinating, the architecture lovely. Areas are clean and well maintained. Not too many touts, and crowds have space to move. Some taxi drivers are dishonest - don't hail on the street or use a rank.

If you go once, you'll go again. The combination of history seen in it's most beautiful forms and the friendliness of the people. Strangely enough, it is the european side which is the most traditional and filled with history.

Sultanahmet old city. Sultanahmet old city is fantastic in culture and architecture. Many things to see in the area but to see everything you'll need at least 2 days. Areas can become crowded but queues do settle down very quickly.The Blue Mosque is close to plaza where you can eat nice food, Topkapi Palace is close by, this has many exhibitions so allow a couple of hours. German fountain and the Obselesk are within another plaza nearby and the underground, where James Bond was filmed (Goldeneye) is within the vicinity.

Well maintained. The historic area's are clean, well maintained, and reasonable priced. There are "Ask me" people around to help if you are not sure of directions etc. or where to take the best photo's.

Istanbul is magical.. If you don't have a trip to Turkey on you bucket list you must add it. This is a wonderful country filled with a peaceful, highly educated population. The historic area is home to beautiful Hagia Sophia (and the nearby Basilica Cystern), the Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, Harem, and the world's oldest shopping mall, the Grand Bazar. If you have fresh legs you can see it all in a day. Our cruise ship was in port for a day and a half so we just got a small taste of this country. We will be coming back for a much longer stay.

Lovely boutique hotel with great service!. Just a note of warning: If you are arriving from the Greek islands to the Sabiha Gökçen international airport, this hotel is at least an hour away. Our taxi driver got lost and we took 1.5 hour to get to the hotel. When we departed, to our relief, we were leaving from the Istanbul Atatürk Airport and that was only 25 minutes away.

The Sultanahmed area is splendid. One could easily spend a whole week in Istanbul. There are tons of beautiful sites to visit: even a shorter visit should include Hagia Sophia (and the nearby Basilica Cystern), the Blue Mosque + Hippodrome, the Topkapi Palace+ Harem, and if you like color or shopping, the Grand Bazar
Lots of monuments near each other. loved the fact that all the monuments are near by. Topkapi Palace's "Islamic Monuments" made me skeptic of there origin and validity.

Loved it!. We absolutely loved walking around the Historic Areas of Istanbul. While we only spent two days in the area, it was enough time to take in the Bosphorus, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, Haiga Sophia and all the magnificent mosques in the area. Highly recommended. My children still talk about our days in Istanbul more than any other place we have visited this year.

I love Stambul. Hospitality, ambiance, everything was so nice, you can enjoy the food that is excellent, the beverages, ice cream and pastries, you can visit the Blue mosque, Hagia Sofia, the Topkapi Palace, with a remarkable collection for the Ottoman Empire and the Sultan life,  take a boat to visit two continents and the Bosforo straight , the Gran Bazar with more than thousand beautiful stores, shop for your favorite item, jewelry , leather goods, serving sets of beautiful porcelain and crystal glasses,you name it. I definitive need to come back

Stay in the Old City. We opted to stay in the old city area while we were in Istanbul, and were very happy with our choice. The mosques and historic Sultan's palace were within walking distance. We also walked to the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar, which were longer walks, but still manageable. There is a commuter light rail that you can take which is inexpensive as well.

Both sides of Istanbul. We did a two centre holiday in Istanbul. The first week in the European side we stayed in a small, very friendly, very clean hotel, Tulip House Hotel. We arrived late at night and my wife uses a wheelchair. When the reception man saw it he said, I put you in a room with a lovely view on the fifth floor. He immediately apologised, and said he would find us better. So we were put on the third floor. I must explain that the reception on street level is up nine steps and represents the second floor. So we were on the third floor, up a further flight of stairs. Breakfast is served in and adjacent to the garden area on the first floor. It was a bit inconvenient and I mention this as it is not suitable for someone very disabled who cannot manage stairs at all. Fortunately with help we could do so. The men/boys running the hotel could not be more helpful, they carried the wheelchair in and out every time we needed to. Plus help us also, this was without asking them, they were always there waiting. Absolutely brilliant. They also advised us about getting about in Istanbul, we were just ten minutes from Sultanahmet the main area for the sightseeing. The Blue Mosque, The Koptapi Palace, the city bus tours and Bosphorus boat trips, those these go from many areas. The historic Cistern, and the tram stops. They advised us to get tram passes, similar to London Oyster cards. 7 Lira per pass, then each use is half price. The trams are modern, superb, every few seconds apart. Very well used and we used them a lot, very easy with the wheelchair, though sometimes a little crowded. We were out at least eleven hours every day, and as it was Ramadan, families in their hundreds gathered each night in Sultanahmet a truly incredible sight. All sorts of traders, like barrow boys were out all the time and a great party atmosphere. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar were just short tram rides away and fantastic places to visit. The hop on hop off buses were great too, two serperate routes and you could buy a 24 hour or 48 hour pass for these. The staff on these were very friendly and excellent, recorded commentaries in many languages are available in the price. Well worth doing first to get all locations in your sights for visiting later. Also the Bosphorus boat tours are very good too. There is a fantastic transport museum, which was a 15 minute bus ride away from the tram stop for the spice market, Eminonu. The Koch transport museum. Every type of transport here, Planes, boats, trains, trams, cars, tractors, a London bus and much, much, more. We spent three hours in there absolutely brilliant. This review cannot do justice to the things to see and do. Then we went to the Asian side where we stayed with a Turkish friend. This side was also very interesting but more modern, not quite the same history, but many beautiful areas. Uskudar and Kadikoy, Fenerbahce were the main areas we visited. Including Maiden's Tower and Princes Islands by boat. All in all a wonderful vibrant city, very safe and very friendly helpful people everywhere. Highly recommended.

History at the best.. If you love history, a visit to Istanbul is a must. Not only Istanbul has maintained the heritage, they have taken utmost care to ensure that tourists go back with a memory that last forever.
Read the guidebook. The sights are fabulous - don't miss the Blue Mosque, Ayia Sofia, Topkapi :Palace, Basilica Cistern etc. You don't need a review to tell you this!!
old Roman ruins.. Very interesting these and the Ottoman palaces.We developed a far greater awareness. Of the impact of theseTwo civilisations on the world.
History and luxury. Icons minarets churches sculptures. A peaceful place for an architect. Try Ottoman cuisine spicy and delicious. Be careful with taxi drivers
Amazing. Hagia Sophia is a kind of wonder. It is really amazing building which is 1500 years old building and still standing up as impressive as all time.

Very easy to walk it. The historic area is very easy to walk around. The furthest we had to walk was 10 mins to the grand bazaar, but that was also a pleasent walk. A good place to explore on your own.

History, Culture, Architecture and Religion, set amidst Nature. We stayed there in May 2014, in a studio apartment near Taksim, just off the Istiklal Street. The location is central, with access to public transport and good cafés. Day 1: Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia museum, Topkapi Palace with lunch at the Konak restaurant within the palace grounds. Tram to Grand Bazaar and then relax with the Bosphorous Cruise operated by Sehir Hatlari. Day 2: Princes' Islands by Sehir Hatlari local ferry. The smaller island of Kinaliada was more peaceful and less crowded than the biggest island. Took the Funicular from Beyoglu to Taksim. Shopping paradise with no traffic. Day 3: Galata Tower, lazy breakfast and beautiful view from the top of the tower. Has an elevator so a breather from walking. Lots of eateries and shops for picking up memories. Istanbul has good connectivity within the City and you can completely avoid cabs if you want for visiting the major tourist attractions.

Istanbul!!. There was nothing to dislike, I loved everywhere, everyone and everything! The monuments are sensational and beautifully looked after, the local people are kind, helpful and respectful.The food is marvellous. I have no adverse comments to make except I wish I had been there for longer!

return to istanbul. My husband was in the Navy and visited Istanbul many years ago so he always wanted to return to show me, his wife of 44 years the place he considered to be the most interesting city in the world The architechtural beauty of the blue mosque, the Topkapi museum, etc. I found it all exhilarating, A city bus trip stopping off at Taksim square, with its old tram winding its way down miles of shopping arcades. Eating freshly caught barbecued mackerel in bread under the Galata bridge. the buzz of all this was wonderful but the trams travelling around the inner roads of istanbul were a bit scary. Overall a great holiday destination.

Cruise excursion. We booked an excursion through our cruise line, Princess. Strongly recommend and excursion as the best way to see Istanbul in a day. I wrote reviews of the key sites we visited, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Topkapi Palace. The surprise for the day was the Bosphorous lunch boat cruise and Grand Bazaar. We loved the boat cruise. We had a guided tour throughout the lunch and had wonderful picture taking opportunities. We sampled some typical Turkish food for lunch and appreciated the respite on the boat. We also thought the Grand Bazaar was very interesting. We expected it to be outside and little huts. Instead, it was indoors and huge. We didn't have much time there, and while I'm not sure there were any great buys there, I would have liked to spend more time walking around and checking out the vendors. Istanbut was one of the highlights of our entire Mediterranean cruise!
History and culture everywhere. You can't help but run into history and cultural experiences roaming the streets. We always felt safe and we could walk to a lot of sites.

A brief synopsis of the historic areas of Istanbul. My wife and I took an approach that probably differed from what most people will do. We stayed in a quaint boutique hotel near the historic area and then wandered around the area for a day of our own relaxed sightseeing, with tips drawn from online reviews. Since we had visited Istanbul about 15 years previously, we went to some of the offbeat areas that most tourists don't go to.However, I had booked online a few small group and private tours weeks prior to our departure, so that we could bypass the long lines of ticket seekers at the main attractions and spend more time in the sights. It is well worth the money, as the tours include the entrance tickets, guide and lunch for the all day tours.I would highly recommend taking about 3 - 4 days to see the Basilica Cistern, Afa Sofya, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, the archeology museums, Suleymaniye Mosque, Galata Tower, Dolmabahce Palace, Grand Bazaar, and Hagia Sophia. Of course, pace your self so that you have an enjoyable time, good Turkish coffee and "delights," of course, and a wonderful lunch each day. If you are staying nearby, return at night to get some pics of the impressive buildings.

Lovely experience . Was in Istanbul for 10 daysLovely experience been to all major places liked the city in general great food and loads of funGot bored at the end but last two days were revitalised by planning more visits,
very attractive and interesting. it was hot at that period of summer and difficult to go around the historical area but is was possible.
a must do .... this is where the history of the city provides a magical and romantic view and makes you see beyond the surface
OF COURSE. Visit everything. That's why you go there. We liked the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia best. The Grand Baazar was like a giant Walmart...
Abundance. The choice is such that I'll need another life to see it all. We did a lot in a week but it wasn't nearly enough

sultan ahmet square. Location of Blue Mosque, Sophia Hagia and Topkapi Palace all within 1 block. We didn't enter the palace but wandered around the gardens and enjoyed that. Get in early before all the tourist buses and queues begin.
Gorgeous. So much to see. Wonderful historic sites close to each other. Shoppers paradise. We were chased by folk selling scarves or books in just about every place we visited.
Imperdible. You must take a full day there, blue mosque, aya sofia, top kapi, rushtem pasa moske, balat area, dolmabache palace, view from galata tower

Rich history. As you probably know, Istanbul is a city in two continents. The amount of commerce and trade in the rich history going back thousands of years is very educational. It also helps shed light on my understanding of the Bible.
A lasting memory. Agia Sophia is unique. You must dedicate at least one week in order to study and contemplate any detail of the miraculous precious masterpieces of Agia Sophia.
Must go. Its just the place to be to get around what Istambul is all about. The ports, the tower, the mosques...all there.
Sultan Ahmet & Aya Sofiya & Topkappi palace. Loved the history.... must visit places and make sure to buy a museum and Attractions pass, works out cheaper.
lot of history. a lot of beautiful history, all on a good walk distance. Not only Hagia sophia but more interesting mosuqes, like the Beyazit and the Eski Imaret Moskee .
Very near to historical areas.. Very near to historical areas as Sultan Ahmed mosque and Haggai Sofia Mosque and to the Topkapi palace.

Istanbul is just amazing. I have been in Istanbul many times. I have to admit that I felt in love with this city. So many historic places to visit. You can also find outstanding restaurants there. Just look out were the local people are going to eat. Avoid the restaurants for the tourists. You will find plenty small restaurants and there you should eat. The fish is just splendid there. But the cherry on the top is the hospitality from the Turkish people. We in western Europe can learn a lot from them. I am looking forward to go there again.
brief visit. beautiful areas, historic, lively, vibrant, beautiful crafts, the sea next to the city, the delicious food, the friendly peole

Full of energy. Istanbul! Istanbul!! Istanbul!!!Full of energy, the buzz in the air with lots of exciting things to do.I travel to Istanbul every few months but this is the first time that i have decent free time to explore and explore i did.All the historical sites within the vicinity and many places to visit; Grand Bazaar, Istanbul University, Calligraphy Museum, Beyazit Square etc

See the sites easily via tram & short walk. Buy an Istanbulkart card at the airport or tram station and add TL to it. You and your friends can ride to all the sites on the trams. You can even ride from the airport to your hotel for 6 TL ($3) and get there faster and a lot cheaper than a taxi.

When you see the blue mosque your eyes will tear. The beauty is unbelievable. The inner structure amazing art and skill to build the amazing mosque. Loved Istanbul what an amazing city and what amazing people

In love with this city!!!!. There are no words to describe this amazing city.we visited hagia sofia, hagia irene, sultan ahmet( blue mosque), suleymaniye cami, the arheological museum, gulhane park, galata tour, the grand bazar and went on a Bosforus tour! This city is full of life and the people are very nice! Hope to see you soon, beautiful Istanbul!

Visit Sulanahmet and see it all!. This is a lovely area to stay, one is close to the trams, as well as the Aga Sophia, the Blue Mosque and Topkapi, as well the Cistern. A perfect start for first-time visitors to this great city.
Sultanahmet. All historical sites are close by and easy reached by foot the cost of entry is also cheap and waiting times are very good

A very interesting City to visit. Old cobbled streets, the Blue Mosque, is spectacular. I took a private guide and spent time exploring Istanbul. One of the very attractive features is that all the major sites of interest are within walking distance of each other. I personally loathed the Grand Bazaar - in my opinion its a tourist rip off, but it is somewhere perhaps one has to visit and experience.

History at its Best. If you roam around in Istanbul you would find that Turkish government has done a nice job in preserving its historical heritage. I would advise travelers to diversify their experience especially in turkey most of the mosques look alike probably they were designed by one designer. If you have planned to come to Istanbul by your own car I would advise you not to come here. traffic is extremely difficult and it would be a punishment to drive around here even if you do come here your car would remain parked during your stay.

Istanbul is... unforgettable. History that comes alive, mesmerizing art and culture, panoramic views, great shopping... and adorable cats everywhere : ) This was our second trip and each time, this city just takes my breath away. Sultanahmet gets my vote for the most atmospheric area to stay in, and it's close to many of the historical sites as well. We passed the Blue Mosque and the Aya Sofia every day and always stopped to admire them. Istanbul is such an incredible blend of tradition and modernity. Best of all, it's clean, friendly, safe and so easy to get around. I miss it already...
So much history!. Being from the west coast of the USA, seeing a building that is 100 years old amazes me, yet in Istanbul there are so many things that are hundreds or thousands of years old!
Briliant trip. Historical explorer , we liked all tours including Bosphorus, Mosque, Palace, our Hotel Balkan Express is at nice position, very welcoming staff, clean.

wow. If you love history and culture then you must visit the historic areas of Istanbul. If you're travelling alone make sure to have read about the places beforehand to truly appreciate more the surroundings.
Do not miss them.... The history of Istanbul is so rich and worth doing the whole museum experience, but you also get a lot of the culture by just walking around.
The best of Istanbul. I liked everything. Be choosey which Turkish Bath House you visit. You get what you pay for, best to go by your guide's recommendation.

Fabulous buildings. An absolutely fascinating City with so many wonderful buildings and places of interest. Impossible to get bored and so varied with excellent integrated transport although its a walking city

Beautiful cosmopolitan city to walk around in.. Gorgeous monuments to see and walk through. Gardens in the city are beautifully kept. Don't pat the stray cats/dog - admire from afar. Locals are very friendly and kind.

Impresionante. This is a must when you visit Istanbul. An area you should not miss. The cross road of western and eastern culture. The history you cannot forget! To see, smell and experience the civilizations from the past to the present time. The traveler will be transported to times of the past and yet enchanted by this modern hospitable city. I was most impressed by the feeling of security when walking the streets to late in the night as compared to city like Rome, Madrid where you are picked pocket constantly.

Takes you back in time. Loved the atmosphere and authenticity. Really could visualize how things looked and were in the various stages of history. One of my favorite historic areas that I have visited. Can't wait to go back.

So much history and culture packed into this city. Istanbul is definitely a place to visit. On our second visit to this historic city we found ourselves astonished with the confluence of cultures with so much to see and do.The people are extremely friendly, helpful and hospitable. We also found the city, its restaurants, streets and transportation systems to be very clean and safe.The Blue Mosque and the old town in Sultanahmet had so much to offer. The Archaeological Museum in Gulhame is definitely worth a visit.I would recommend a stay of at least 3-4 days to be able to see and do enough in Istanbul.
Incredible city. So very much to see - needed all six days. Istanbul is fascinating and its history so very interesting. The architecture is extraordinary.
Lots to See!. You can spend a lot of time seeing all there is to offer. Lots of history here and a plus for us was finding cheap friendly little places to eat doner and grab a cold drink.

full of things to see. went during Ramadan, which was fine, just meant that there was less crowds, experience was great if you are into history and culture.travel was easy, stayed in the Sultanahmet and walked everywhere, however you can take tram/train around easily. Frequent tram service - easy to use, think next time I might get a travel card, however if you are taking one journey and switching from tram to train, they might charge you for separate journeys, so not like taking the tube/overground in London. Cheap to travel though, 4 lire for one journey irrespective of distance on the same mode of transport. if you want to go to the Asian side on public transport you can take the train for ferry, depending on which ferry company you use, prices vary.major sites in the Sultanahmet all worth seeing, but Museum of Turkish and Islamic was closed, so i think in Fairness, Turkey should have reduced the price of the Museum pass, a three day pass is priced at 85 lire. some hotels in the sultanahment are situated on slopes, so be careful if you are using a wheelchair or buggies.recommend: rooftop dinner so you can enjoy meal/drink with blue mosque and hagia in the skylinetea on the far side of Gulhane Park, great ocean views (food is ok, like eating in a greasyspoon)
November 1999. Wow. The Old City is incredible. So is the old Asian part of the central city. History, culture, incredible views, 11,000 restos, ferry or ride to Asia on a bridge. .

It is okay-ish. The area is fine, apparently plenty of thieves but we didn't have experience with that. Other than that, very touristy and the prices are set accordingly, with many turks trying to rip you off when they find out you're a tourist, but that's my general experience with Turkey, so not a particular flaw of this area.
Extraordinary and unique. Go early and don't do too much in any one day. Don't miss the Kariye museum (Chora Church) and the Ortakoy Mosque
Steeped in rich history. Many centuries of conflict, change and construction. The Old City is a fantastic mix of old, older and very old.

Less organized and too pricy.. We were disappointed in the historic sites in Istanbul. Perhaps we've traveled too many places and are spoiled from Rome, Paris, Moscow, etc. We found the sites unorganized, too populated, pricey and not as incredible as we expected.

Magnificent...Majestic. An amazing walk through the ages within a short distance. Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, The Palace Mosaics Museum, Hagia Irene, the Museum of Turkish & Islamic Art, the Archaeology Museum, the Hippodrome...Sultanahmet Park...all nearly at your fingertips...one from the other. Okay, it might take 10 minutes to get from one to the other, but no more unless you are a snail. In between: vendors selling roasted chestnuts and charcoal grilled corn on the cob...freshly cut watermelon to slake your thirst...and lots of Turkish treats.
ancient and beautiful. very very attractive and beautiful places that i have never experienced before, dont waste your time and hurry to visit this area.

Love those back streets and narrow alleys. Alleys in alleys, in side streets off back streets off side roads - what a great place to explore. Plenty to do for a weekend break, but three to four days is more than enough

Do it all, see it all and don't spare the legs. You need several days in Istanbul to see even the major historical and cultural sights. Don't shortchange yourself. Do it all and see it all. If you go in high season be prepared for hoards of tourists. Everywhere is extremely crowded but don't let that put you off. The mosques, the bazaars, the palaces, the museums, the old back streets of Sultanahmet are all must do's. Istanbul is modern yet ancient and has so much for everyone. It is so easy to get around on public transport using an Istanbul card but be prepared for hills. They are everywhere. If you love old towns, ancient cultures, ancient ruins, amazing architecture include Istanbul in your travel plans

people, people everywhere. I think I would have truly loved Istanbul--the exoticism, the meeting of cultures--were it not for the massive crowds everywhere. Tour groups, independent travelers, millions of residents. When I was younger I probably would have enjoyed the action more...now I want less tumult. Long lines at all the big attractions, traffic jams everywhere....it made NYC seem almost pastoral in contrast. But others might love the buzz...although probably not the queues.

So much to see. We enjoyed everyplace we visited including the Grand Bazaar as well as the Spice Market. The Spice Market had what we found to be the best prices for things we wanted to bring home. You could find it fast so that you could,spend your time touring the historical buildings.

A great city to explore in a few days. Love the ease of access and the endless streets to wander. History by the ton! Shopping and restaurants are plentiful though you do have to look a bit harder for the good restaurants.

Family holiday. Historic areas are all close together. Go on a tour small if you can. The crowds are very large. Very clean and very safe. You can buy water very cheaply. Good food available and tourist type shopping. Stall holders very friendly. It is a credit to Turkey the way these areas are presented. Was very hot. Turkey has 25million tourists a year!

Wonderful area, full of history and beautiful buildings. For our first trip in Istanbul, this Sultanahmet area with all the historical, beautiful buildings of Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace are wonderful. Hope to be back some days.
Will not disappoint. Loved the mosques, didn't enjoy the Grand Bazaar which is simply too crowded. Liked the sense of safety walking along quiet, hidden streets. People generally friendly.
Blue Mosque and old town. Lots of history , Ottoman empire times well worth spending a couple days looking around . Places are well signed and easy to walk between the sites
Beautiful landmarks. I liked the city but disliked the Almina Hotel. Try to avoid the cabs , you can use the subway or the tramway.
So much to see Topkapi is beautiful, haggis Sofia all great. Jewellery and clock exhibition at Topkapi, roman Cistern was really impressive, definately not to be missed

the best one. do not leave istanbul before see them
Sultanahmet, Ayasofya and Topkapı.. and many more.. and of course Cistern!! u can buy for all this museums one ticket for 3 days! istanbul pass , just ask it at the entrance of Hagia Sofia!!
Magic Istanbul. That was our first time in Istanbul. Hope we will come back soon. You can walk day or night time safe. Beautiful places to visit and Wonderful people around.
Amazing. So much to see. So much history. Vibrant. Romantic. Definitely worth a visit. A definite must and well worth the trip to Istanbul.

Fantastic old city. I am no history buff but I love old architecture and old streets and Istanbul has both old and new with a great tram system that links easily with the funicular railway to give easy access to all the city.We got the tram and funicular up to Taksim Square and then walked for hours visiting the Galata Tower, back across the bridge somehow going through the antique district and the man caves with all kinds of tools and equipment and on to the Blue Mosque, the Cisterns and Hagia Sophia. Especially loved the open spaces that have fountains that are illuminated at night.The Cisterns, Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia are all in the same area and easily visited together. Loved the Topkapi Palace - just make sure you go early as you will want to spend longer than you imagine.

Lots to see. Loved shopping in The Grand Bazaar and spice market. It's also worth a walk across the bridge to the Asian side. It was a lot cleaner than I thought and we didn't see any flies. People were friendly but a bit pushy when trying to get you to buy or eat in their restaurant - you kind of get used to it in the end though, we were always polite when declining.The mosques were stunning as was The Gulhane Park - a beautiful place to cool off in the shade and peaceful.

Old City. I recommend the Rick Steve's book walk; it hits all the sights and gives geat insights as well. Don't mind the hawkers, and don't get involved in conversations, most want to sell you something. It's all good natured, though.

Great place to visit. All the sights Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Galata Tower, Church at Chora, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market etc etc as well as the excellent food this clean, friendly city is certainly worth a visit. An assault on all your senses. Public transport is outstanding with trams, buses, trains and metro covering most areas of Istanbul. (Get an Istanbulkart - inexpensive way of getting around and you can travel on virtually all public transport with it) Never felt threatened although we tended to walk a lot in all sorts of areas. We were struck by how clean this city is. If you want to visit an exciting city - try Istanbul!

A mystic blending of cultures. The historic areas of Istambul are the place to learn about the meeting of Europe and Asia, Christianity and Islam, ancient and modern, rich and poor, exotic and standard.

It's what Istanbul is all about. Everything is walking distance.... So much to see and do. Get a map of attractions and start at the Bosphorus and work your way from Topkapi to Hagia, to the cisterns to the Blue Mosque.... Then go to the grand bazaar.... All so close to each other. Absolutely fantastic

Istanbul. What a city, it was wonderful. I will go back. There is so much to see. The trams are very reasonable and efficient but do get very crowded. I am in my late sixties and never went further than one stop without someone giving me there seat. I felt very safe.

There are to many places to see. Dolmabahce Palace, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosqueand many countless places are worth to visit. Istanbul is a great city for history, culture, food, romantic views and many other reasons. It is safe and very modern. Actually this city is the only city in the world rests in two continents Europe and Asia. Culture is a good combination of west and east. Turkish people are friendly and very helpful and carpet sellers are very persistent! Food is excellent. City is crowded but not dangerous. Enjoy this great city-Istanbul in many ways..
The scale and beauty of the buildings. Advise hire a guide and U will jump all the crowds and save a lot of time We had a 6 hour booking that cost 130 euros.

Istanbul - What A City!!'. I have visited Istanbul on a number of occasions both personal and whilst on business. Itv ever ceases to amaze and excite me. If you have never visited Istanbul then please find time to do so - I promise you will not be disappointed.
Must see in Istanbul. Please hire a guide or joining a walking tour to explore the historic areas of the City. It is worth the extra cost!
Pick a side. Really on the wrong side of the Golden Horn, but a cheap, short cab ride to the attractions on the other side.

Must do. Important historical sites are a must see while in Istanbul. Liked Sultanamet area and associated historical sites. Disliked the touristy feel and crowds in summer, but that is part of the deal

Mostly in sultananhmet. Most of the historic areas are in sultanahmet. You can usually walk to most of the tourist sites or take the tram everywhere. All the tourist sites are not open everyday. Please take a look at the websites and the forums on here for the days that they are closed.

Main reason for visiting the city. Liked: all the main attractions, Blue Mosque, Ayia Sophia, the Cistern, Bosphorus, Golden Horn, Hippodrome, Grand Bazaar - all in four days. Some were very crowded but by visiting mix morning and mid afternoon we managed to avoid queues. Cistern was, in my opinion, the most unexpected and dramatic sight. Beautifully lit, full of intrigue. The Bosphorus cruise left us wanting more.
incredibly. all monuments fantastique out of the world nothing to dislike take all excursions possible you find yourself in another world!

History and Cultue in Istanbul. I love this place!!! I cant say any bad things regarding Istanbul!! All are pretty amazing. the people are very generous, kind and Hospitable. The places are beautiful. And the food ohhhh I definitely love it!!

A wonderful city. Wondering round the historic areas of Istanbul is a joy! There is so much to see, it is like a living history lesson at every corner! Photography wise, the area is rich in photographic opportunity, and for the historians amongst you, you won't be disappointed. Visit as much as you can, and absorb the atmosphere, but try and set off earlyish in the morning, as the areas so get very crowded!
Made history come alive.. Loved the local people. Very friendly. Enjoyed comparing cultural and religious perspectives. Very knowledgeable tour guides. The underground cistern system is unbelievable.

So Much To See & Do!!. There's way too much going on here to sum up in a small review. This part of the city has it all, from museums, mosques, beautiful gardens, great bars and restaurants and so much more. Very easily accessible too by tram/bus/metro. I absolutely loved my time here - never a dull moment.
BEST EVER. The city is wonderful. Such wonderful people and sights. The fragrance of their glorious food cooking surrounds you. An old city full of life,

Istanbul = History. Istanbul is a city which was found thousands of years ago. It was capital city for Byzantium, then conquered by Ottomans in 1453 and become capital city of Ottoman Empire. It is possible to see places from Byzantium time, Ottoman Empire time and also early years of Turkish Republic. From one site city is getting improved with building high ways, malls, stadiums, parks, skyscrapers etc from another site historical parts remain.

Great Sites to Visit. Take a day to see all that Old Town has to offer. Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, and Hagia sophia are a must. Went thru Efendi Travel to arrange day trip and our English guide was great. Lots to see and great history. Grand Bazaar is not what it used to be. 4000 stores but all are the same basic 10-15 types stores. not worth more than a hour or two as you see same stores over and over. Enjoyed Spice Market much more! Take time to see it!

History, food, and shopping. A year later we still talk about how we enjoyed the old part of Istanbul near the Hippodrome. Grab a Shawarma and a seat on a bench near the Blue Mosque and just feel the air and the sounds that fill this area.

Istanbul history. The historic area of Istanbul is quite fascinating! It's amazing that miles and maps originated here. Or that this is the beginning of the silk road trade routes. That you can see the actual Cistern's from when Constantine first began to populate this city is awesome. The city is just mystical!

Must do visit. If you are on holiday then you must visit the historic centre of Istanbul. The palace, museums and mosques can be done in one or two days with careful planning. Very hot at this time of year, so plan for drinks & rests.

Amazing whereever you go and look. There is so much to see in the old part of Istanbul. You cannot make it in three days. Especially the old basar is the biggest and best one I ever saw in my life. You get alsmost lost in there, so many shops and offers. You should really think what you gonna buy before you enter because if you do not know before you have planty of coices.

Nothing bad to say.... The historic areas of Istanbul, by which I mean the 'old town' , is a fantastic place to explore on foot! I loved everything about Istanbul, and if you stay in the old town, everything is within walking distance. Sultanhmet Square, Hagia Sofia, Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque, the Bosphorous, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar, and of course Topkapi Palace. Don't miss the Süleymaniye Mosque, which is comparable to the Blue Mosque in magnificence but way less crowded.There are many places to take a load off and sit in some shade and people watch. Don't let the spruikers put you off, every man and his dog is trying to sell you something, or get you to eat in their restaurant, but if you have been to South East Asia, Istanbul will be a piece of cake!There are plenty of great photo opportunities, but go to the main attractions early in the day to beat the crowds, then chill out in the afternoon with a cold drink and watch the frenzy. Then head to the Grand Bazaar late afternoon. I think you need at least three days to explore properly.

The best part of Istanbul. Istanbul now fits the cliche description of a 'sprawling metropolis' since it houses more than 10 million people. For this reason the historic areas of the city, the Byzantine churches, and the Ottoman palaces and mosques are the salient features of an otherwise modern skyline and various shiny shopping centers.In the Sultanahmed district alone there's an embarrassment of riches: The Hagia Sophia museum, the Archaeological, the Hagia Irini and a trio of great mosques, the Suleimaniye, the Blue Mosque and the Sehzade mosque. And not to be missed, Justinian's 6th-c. A.D. Basilica Cistern --a real gem.

A must in Istanbul. One of the high lights of my visit to Turkey in June 2104 was walking through the historic areas of Istanbul. There was so much to see and I specially liked the architecture. Blue Mosque, though I could not see much blue colour was beautiful inside. Hagia Sophia had beautifully painted high ceilings. Beautiful jewellery and clothing on display at Topkapi Palace took ones breath away, specially the Spoonmaker's diamond 66 carat diamond. I enjoyed just walking around the surrounding area and the sky line with the beautiful buildings and minarets were a photographers paradise.

shop till you drop!. Just wander into the Bazaar and enjoy the atmosphere, it is hassle free, great place to just look and dream. Purchased a gold bangle and enjoyed the experience, not ripped off and the knowledgeable gentleman behind the counter made the day more interesting. We talked about the changes taking place in Istanbul and just chatter that you would not normally have with a person in your hotel. Made the day to speak to the locals

Well maintained. Istanbul is fulled with all sorts of historic sites. Driving along the Bosphorous you see the signs of ancient rome, the walls and stone work. One of the things I like doing is walking of the beaten path and exploring the city. You make a lot of hidden discoveries as you do this. Plus the adventure of arriving at an ancient building without looking at a map is alway a thrill for me. Go check the city out, explore.

Totally interesting. There is nothing I dislike about Turkey or Istanbul. I love it all! So interesting and historic. Great fun picking a restaurant each night. The Grand Bazar is worth the trip all by itself. I have been to Istanbul three times now and have had a Turkish bath each time. Wow! a definite must for the Turkey traveller. I WANT TO GO BACK!!!

We stayed in the Historic Area for the first time. Loved it, loved it. Could walk almost every where - to the Cistern which is a must, the Blue Mosque, the Haj etc. Fascinating city, incredible area - a must if you are in Istanbul
Beautiful Architecture and History!. Blue Mosque, Hyga Sophia, The Cistern, the Hippodrome, Grand Bazaar, Galata Tower. This are the places to visit in Istanbul!
History alive. If you walk on the street of the old city you'll see many historic places full of tourists, Blue Mosque, Aya Sophiam Topkapi Palace are really beautiful.
History at its best. Need to spend a couple of days atleast in the area to view and visit all the areas. Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Balisca Cistern & Grand Bazaar all top class
A must visit. This is the part of Istanbul that can't be missed. With all the major sites. Take at least 2 days to see everything.

Exotic Istanbul. The food was remarkable, the people of Istanbul kind and helpful, and the sites so remarkable. The only downside was the stories we heard about the taxi drivers in Istanbul, but we asked for recommendations from the clerk at Sari Konak Hotel and had wonderful cab drivers.

Excellent Historical Artifacts. I liked the brilliant paintings inside the mosques which have still been very carefully preserved. The tour guide was also excellent. However , quite a lot of people didn't know english
Istanbul is an amazing place to visit!. We loved everything about our trip, mostly due to our fabulous guide and amazing hotel. I never knew that Istanbul as half in Asia and half in Europe!!

So much to see & all so amazing!. The mixture of Byzantium, Constantinople & Ottoman is fascinating & many visitors never make it out of the historic area of Sultanahmet as there is so much to see there! It is probably worth hiring a guide or going on a day tour as this really brings it all 'alive'. Even after you have seen the major sites, there is so much to see by wandering the streets, going to restaurants & walking along the road with the Marmara Sea on one side & the Roman walls on the other. As 2 women on our own we always felt quite safe here, although we made sure to keep to the main roads at night!
good vacation. I was expecting more to see from grand Ottoman Empire, but Topkapi and mainly Sultanahmet is a good trip too. I guess many more places could not be preserved

Definitely worth taking the appropriate time to see. I have just been to Istanbul for three days and there is so much to see that I feel three days weren't enough. We visited Hagia Sophia, The blue mosque, Galata Tower, Topkapi Palace, The Bosphorus, The Basilica Cistern and the Gran Bazaar. All in all we managed well however some of the attractions might require more time to really appreciate them.

Blue mosque. The building is beautiful and the walls amazing, but the exaggeration of religious zealots, who had a problem because part of my hair was showing was way too much.I know I am in their country, I respect their religious beliefs completely, but too much is too much, people should feel welcome to the site and not unwelcome d.This reflected the current issue in Turkey, of a past very secular country dealing with the new strong islamic current. If you visit this site, you will be encountering this dilema.Very crowded when I visited. Not sure it was enjoyable for me.Visit is short,beause of crowds.
Loved the Square. Beautiful area of Istanbul. Easy access by foot, safe and clean city. So much history can spend days!
Istanbul. Very friendly people, but you have to get there early otherwise the queuesare long. Would recommend you get a guide

Must see this area. It's what Istanbul is all about....the people
The feel and of course the food.
We felt safe and the locals were more than
Helpful even with the language barrier.
need a couple of days. The history of this area was great and definitely got the cistern it was incredible. It is busy but safe.
Incredible History. Easy to access and very friendly people . Beautifully kept historical sites . We enjoyed every aspect of our experiences .

Bizantium, Constantinople, Istanbul - Europe and Asia - lots to see. It is impossible to write a review for the historic areas of Istanbul since there are so many amazing things. Please check the reviews of the attractions.You can restrict your visit to the well-advertised attractions where the travel agencies take their crowds (Haggia Sophia, the Bazaars, the Blue Mosque, the Golden Horn). But you can also discover little gems such as the Mosaic museum, the Küçük Ayasofia mosque (not her larger sister), smaller streets and mosques. And there are also immense sections of the city walls from the roman times that few people go to.There is a lot of history is the streets of Istanbul.

Istanbul is always worth a visit. Blue Mosque ( especially the Islamic Presentation Center is well worth the time) Grand Bazaar, Spice Market and Taksim Square are musts. But the Orthodox Patriach Church and Chora Cloisters equally interesting. Boat cruise unforgettable.

This wonderful vibrant city. A charm that is breath taking. A must on any travelers "things to see". So much to see and do. The people just so incredibly friendly, the food so yummy. The Boutique hotels I stayed in perfect. the staff so wonderful. I went alone a single aged lady and felt no fear what so ever. A place I want to go back to over and over again

Great place but only takes a day or two to see it. We stayed in the old city of Istanbul and were absolutely thrilled with where we stayed and found all of the sights to be very interesting. We went to all of the major sights and they were all an easy walk. We hired a personal guide so each of the sights came alive as she told us the history and different stories behind each sight. There are more great restaurants in the old city than you could ever hope to visit and the shopping is all over the place. I am not sure there is enough just in the old city to do if you stay more than a day or two...but you can go to the new city, Asia or many other place
So much to see!. We liked that it is all so close but didn't like having to fight our way through the hawkers! But you quickly get used to it!

GREAT ATMOSPHERE. It was so wonderful.I loved the historic area of Istanbul so much. All of them in Sultan Ahmet area the grandeour of Blue Mosque, the vastness of Ayasophaya and the multifaced Topkapi palace, all in vicinity and yes of course the Cistern.
Old city. The history is amazing. It was very crowded but we could walk or take the tram anywhere we needed to go. Shops and restaurants everywhere. The local cuisine if delicious.

people are rude, good for shopping. Nice place if you like history, many things to do. I found it expensive. Bargaining is everywhere, Aya Sophia and Blue mosque is worth watching. Grand Bazaar is over crowded. I loved Taksim Street its a fun place, lovely cloths, so check the shops inside which are really good stuff at a discount. The shops on the main street are usually expensive.For the Cruise please be careful they charge you 20 TL at the counter for a 5 hours cruise whereas if you book online or through the travel agents they may charge 30Euros. I had a bad experience on the cruise they charged me for 5 hours and were fooling us by bring us back within 1.5hours.I seriously didn't like the people of Turkey they are kind of rude, language is a major issue since they speak only Turkish.wear your backpack on the front, too many thieves around, you gotta be careful Shop from Sisli, Taksim and Blue Mosque area for better pricing. Grand Bazaar is expensive in comparison.

Istanbul Great place to visit but keep it short. I thought Istanbul was beautiful and fascinating. However, it is exhausting. Everyone has an angle. You can't ask directions or glance at something you like without being pounced on by aggressive vendors. Even buying a tram token a little boy inserted himself to push the buttons and "help" us. When finished he wanted us to buy something from him. We saw a kid working the street for 12 hours selling stuff while his Father looked on from his own street purse sales area. Around the attractions were fake guides trying to take your money to get you in. We were at the Blue Mosque and were approached by many. The attraction is free and the wait time is short. While standing in line I observed some of them. They would take money from the tourists and walk them to the head of the line and they would simply push them to jump the line. I think it might be somewhat tolerated by the official staff, but not sure. I wanted to shop more there, but the aggressiveness was totally offensive. I personally would have bought something if they weren't so pushy. I travel with my Sister and this is one of the few cities I did not feel comfortable in. No matter where we went men would try to strike up phony conversations. Where are you from? Do you want to go to my shop to buy something? Like I said "exhausting", staying vigilant against the scammers and pickpockets. I'm not saying not to go. Just be aware!
So much and so little time. So many museums, the Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar - so huge , its impossible to cover it in one day. Hagia Sophia. A blend of so many empires.
wonderful off course. I loved the historic area of Istanbul so much.There is everything; Western and Eastern atmosphere.I'll go there again and again.It was so wonderful.

Just Fascinating. All of them in Sultanehmet area the grandeour of Blue Mosque, the vastness of Aayasophaya and the multifaced Topkapi palace, all in vicinity and yes of course the Cistern.All in midst of old town gardens, fountains, eateries and pleasant walks.

Spice Market. Get Iranian Saffron and Turkish Delight, and a myriad of other spices; this place is wonderful. We went to a stall which is well-known and is the stop for the leading government vips; it is called Caviar. I liked it because we weren't harrassed, and they offered us free bottled water and samples of the Turkish delight flavours.
Hagia Sofia and Cisterna. A must! We traveled with 2 families consiting of 6 kids and they loved the cisterns. Our guide was really critical in pointing out the significance of both attractions.
Lovely historical Istanbul. To experience historical Istanbul is just something you need to do. Regardless if it is the Blue mosque or Aya Sophia, the atmosphere of everything :-)

istanbul app for tourists. hey y'all!!
i've been downloading an app to help me move thought istanbul,because it's our first time there,and we wanted not to miss anything...so the name is mtrip istanbul...we payed for it so we can have it offline...shows,info about the touristic attraction,opening hours,entry fee,how to get there,and what else its around...i'll keep u updated how was my adventures trip!

Fascinating city. Didn't know much about Istanbul's history and in 5 days we barely scratched the surface. A fascinating city, lovely people and interesting food. Will be back as our stay wasn't long enough.
Must see. Brilliant city. The historic bit still feels really historic. There are no high rises and there's something for everyone here.
Amazing. Most of the locals speak enough English to point you in the right direction.Awesome beautiful architecture and lots of interesting historical places. I would definitely recommend

Must see everybody. Istanbul is a beautiful city with at least 2000 years of great history. If you choose to visit, you need at least 4-7 days to understand, feel and get in love with this city. The hype, mystic atmosphere draws you immediately. The historical places, architecture, wonderful wellcoming people is a must see show for every human being.

take your time. This isn't the type of city that you can breeze through. Take your time and don't worry if you get lost. Most of the locals speak enough English to point you in the right direction. If all else fails the taxi service is just about everywhere so you can always get back to your hotel We usually take a guided city tour wherever we go to get an overview of the area. In this case the 'hop on hop off' bus was awful. the city traffic is so bad that there is no way the recorded guide could sync up with the sights and the bus was sitting stuck in traffic or going 70 or to get back in time. Take the excellent city transportation, a taxi, or walk. Have fun and look around and have fun. If you are trying to stick to a strict schedule this isn't the place for you.

Amazing mixture of historical and modern. Awesome beautiful architecture and lots of interesting historical places. Such a bright contrast of modern and historical, rich and poor areas. There're lots of places for inspiration

Awesom. Cannot add anything that hasn't already been said - it is the #1 attraction in Istanbul after allWhat was a standout for my wife and I was the unbelievable tour guide - Sema from UTS. She added so much value through her passion, knowledge and unbelievable network of connections around the key sites that made everything run smoothly - and quicklyIt does cost a bit more, but having a great guide adds so much to your trip here - and I would definitely recommend Sema!
Istanbul. Wow, this is the second visit to this wonderful city and it's historical sites. The food is great and so were the people. Always helpful and welcoming.

Magnifique.... Istanbul its a great city and its historic areas are part of the heritage that the turkish people love to share. You would have hundreds of historic places to see and live. You would love to see most of the place more than once and when you leave you are hungry for more and you want to come back. Thats Turkey, go and check it out....

Truely wonderful. So much to see and explore.The buildings are amazing and the history fascinating.Very easy to get around.Turkish people are very helpful and friendly.We spend 3 night and 2 days here.3 days would have been better.
Sultanahmet. In this big city,be sure to save time queueing at the big attractions by buying a museum's pass from the mosaics museum,where there are no queues.
Charming . It is a very nice area with the most historical places to visit , the blue mosque aya Sofia , and a lot of places and attractions to visit there , you can have there the big bus
Everything. see hotel review for Istanbul info: The sites are marvelous and re full of history and art, color and sounds that make you always aware you are a part of both Asia and Europe.
Hipodrom and horse square. I loved everything thats all..Square ,view, full of the touristic caffee and Bodega & Bar. From very cheap one to..expensive establishments

One thousand and one nights. Since my first trip to Istanbul 20 years ago I have dreamt of going back. It is living, breathing, history. Wear comfortable shoes and just wander around taking in the atmosphere, marvel at the mosques, the Ottoman houses, the places, bazaars. It's impossible not to love it!

Outstanding. The Historic area is not to be missed in any circumstances and even if the cultural scene is not really your thing you could easily spend a few days seeing the sights
We really loved the Blue Mosque and were impressed by the Roman Cistern. Topkapi is also a must visit but I suggest you get there early
5minutes to Taksim Square(Istiklal street). The best touristic place for pubs,bars,clubs and for shopping is Istiklal street. The hostel is 5minutes by walk.

Bazaar overrated. We just had time for the Bazaar. We got ripped off in a restaurant, around 30 euro each for kebab and a soda(alcohol is banned in the area).In the Bazaar they all sell the same stuff, a lot from china. So it is practically like any other market/supermarket in the world. A few things seemed to be authentic but not much. A lot of the stores sold exact similar items so I guess the owners of the stores are just employees and that the buyins for the bazaar is handled in bigger scale. Boring.

Must see!. A beautiful mix of old and new Turkey. We visited a few places. Hagia Sofia (closed on Mondays), Topkapi meusum Palace (closed on Tuesdays), Taksim Square. All these are either close by and easy walking distance or the tram and underground metro station is a easy way to get there. Must see places!
ancient city. i like this city but path away and streets is not clean. cigarette butts is everywhere. Taksim is full of life & crowded. ships and boats traffic & Bosphorus strait is very nice

Great for spending an afternoon walking around and getting lost. I would recommend discovering this area on a whim, not so much following the beaten track. Just see where the narrow streets take you and pop into any stores, cafes and shops that seem interesting. Best way to discover!

Tips for historical visits. Most important reason of Istanbul is it's historical values which has matchless attractions for visitors from all over the world,city consist of three parts European side the historical Peninsula to the south of the Golden Horn and the Galata District to the north and the new city on the Asian side.European side of the city is a trade and business center, where as Asian side is more of residential area, Istanbul is established on the both sides of Bosphorus which connect the Black Sea n Sea of Marmara separates Asia n Europe. The city has a lots of finest monuments and museums , Istanbul may also b compared with Rome coz so many similar historic characteristics

Galata and Ortakoy. These two regions of Istanbul should be example to all of us. Here, in this neighborhoods you will find local Turkish people who have different ancestries like Greek, Armenian, Sephardic, Levantine and so on. These people are completely respectful to each other and do not have an iota of prejudice against their neighbors and anybody else. I wish whole world was like them....
Istanbul with Sinan Erol. Roman Walls are interesting. Chora church has the best mosaics outside of Ravena. A must for Christian scholars.

Very old mixed with modern. You can visit most of the historic sites: Blue Mosque, New Mosque, Cistern Basilica, Topkapi Palace, Grand & Spice Bazaars (see separate reviews) and the Hagia Sofia Museum (closed on Mondays), very easily as they are all within a short walk of each other.This part of the city is within easy reach by tram especially if staying across the Golata bridge (Taksim Square side) and is a wonderful mix of very old Istanbul and new, modern Turkey. There are many, many fine restaurants, shops etc and the whole area has a great buzz - but avoid visiting over Turkish bank holiday weekends and go as early as possible to beat the crowds.

Fantastic history. There are so many great historical places in Istanbul, countless palaces and mosks, historical and art museums.The city is the history itself. Old narrow streets coming to the sea. Nice old houses in a pure ottoman style.
enjoy a rich a cultureful experience. Its a must do but do get ourselves a guide as it does help. Getting around the city might take sometimes as the roads are very busy as with any big city

Ancient Land. Flying into Istanbul, you sense that this is an ancient land. On the ground, you see evidence of the Romans, the Hittites, Ottomans, and the new era of Ataturk. Rustem Pasha Mosque is high on my list as is Topkapi Palace and Hagia Sophia.

Beautiful City. We had a great stay in Istanbul, what a beautiful and interesting city. Steeped in huge amounts of history you could let yourself believe you were wandering around a thousand or so years ago
Great place!. So much to see, history, old stuff, should be on every ones list of places to visit, but don't drive!

topkapi palace. Brilliant, but come early very crowded, you can pass along the treasury chamber onla very slowly, the hagia sofia is the most impressive bzilding I saw in Istanbul, very good mosaics from the early centuries after christ birth, also nice the blue mosque

Well worth a visit. You can't say that you have seen Istanbul if you haven't visited the historic areas of Istanbul. There is so much culture and the archeology is there in front of your face. I did all the usual sites such as Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, underground cistern, Topkapi Palace in one day and the Dolma Bachi Palace is definately worth a visit. I really enjoyed the cruise on the Bospherous and the trip to Pierre Lotti and the short cable car ride back down the hillside. We hired a guide for the first day to visit the main four attractions and probably paid over the odds (100 British pounds). We were later told that we could have gotten a guide for about £ 50 however we didn't need to wait in lengthy lines with over an hour wait for each attraction. The museum of archeology is undergoing some restoration work at the moment but is well worth a visit. You can see everything from Roman and Greek statues to Asyrian artifacts and tombs and Egyptian sarcofagi. Very impressive. There's simply so much to see and do here you can't possibly get bored.
so much to see. History lovers will never see it all. Loved exploring this area. Hagia Sophia, Underground Cistern, Grand Bazaar my favourites
Historic Istanbul. Love the ancient buildings like Saint Sophea and the Blue Mosque. The Bosphorus cruise was a breathtaking experience. Abhorred the traffic jams though...worse than the ones in KL!

Wonderful Architecture. Plan enough time to spend some time inside the Blue Mosque. It is free and do not go on a Friday or Saturday because of prayers. Spend at least a full day at Topkopi Palace. Get there early enough so that you can spend the end of the day at the café with the most amazing view of Istanbul. Save enough time to LINGER! Bosphorus boat ride was great! Yet, do not purchase it from your hotel. Go down to the Oblisque and look for a tour there. You should be able to find a two hour tour for $25 US. You do not need to pay more than this. Also, take the public ferry to Princess Islands...go to the last stop and enjoy the horses! Make sure you have dinner with all the Turks on the Island and do NOT MISS THE LAST BOAT. It is probably about 830pm in the summer. ENJOY, ENJOY!!! Plan your time as to how much time you are willing to listen about carpet. It is fun, yet there is a LOT to do. (Hagia Sohia, perhaps get in line before 10am to avoid some crowds.) HAVE FUN!

Magnificent Istanbul. After tourning the historical sites in Greece we visited Istanbul and were blown away by the histroy and granduer of Istanbul. The city is so rich in culture and history. We stayed in the Sultanamet area and were close to many magnificent sites. the landscape is astounding and the morning call to prayer just adds to the richness of the experience. I would recommend a boat ride along the bosphorous. You do not need a guide as there is a ferry that is cheap with explanations of the many impressive sites along the river.
Blue Mosque. loved the whole of the area, across the road is Aya Sofya, all very impressive. But steer clear of the street traders - they will hound you

Amazing - like stepping back in time. Loved the bazaar, Cozy Restaurant with roof terrace, tea shop in the park outside Topkapi Palace overlooking sea, and especially the smoking room we stumbled across full of locals on shisha pipes!

Wonderful sites....must see!. Amazing experience seeing the historic areas of Istanbul which are all mostly walking distance. It is a safe environment to walk around in and spend some quality time having a look around.

Greek city, Turkish nation. You can see the architecture and influence of Greeks in here because it was main city in the past which was stolen by Turks in the war. Even the name of the city Istanbul comes from Greek language εἰς τῆν πόλιν eis tén polin which means to the City. Unfortunately a lot of architectonial monuments were destroyed by Turks so you can see just the rest that survived. It is for sure great to see this place.
Amazing. Exploring this historic area of Istanbul - one of the world famous area was totally amazing. You has to be here to understand.

Everything I expected it to be, wonderful atmosphere!. Beautiful, filled with people, clean, and with a sense of the more than a thousand years of history all around you....not to be missed. The Turkish people here are friendly and kind, although quite good salesmen! Lots of young people and students along with the tourists gives the area a lot of atmosphere. My husband was here many years ago on business and he wanted us to go together as this was one of his favorite cities on earth (he has been nearly everywhere)....I can see why now and am very glad I didn't miss the wonderful experience of their long history and culture. We had a private guide and driver, worth every penny as we got to the head of every line and got to know a lot about Turkey and its people as well as history.

Too many things in too little time. I like the view, the photographers, the crowd, our guide, the informations, like walking in the world ancient history books and be part of it.
