Perfect for those who love to visit museum, enjoy the sceneries and walking or hiking. Make sure that your are enough to cover all sites and keep up with the pace of the guides. Alas, just take a walk and enjoy observing the beauty of these places.

Where cultures clash. From its earliest days as Byzantium, no city has experienced as much religious and cultural strife as Istanbul. The Persians, the Greeks, the Romans, the Christian Crusaders, the Rus, the Muslims, the Seljuk Turks (from what is now Iran) and the Muslims all took their turn at raping the city. The Greeks and Romans each in their time made it a Capital. The Ottoman Turks greatly expanded it. It's all there to see. Hagia Sophia, the architectural marvel of its age, the Basilica Cisterns and the remnants of the Roman Hippodrome, the beautiful Blue Mosque with its blue tile, the Chora church with its modest exterior and stunning mosaic filled interior, bejeweled Topkapi Palace and the 19th Century Dolmabahçe Palace all lie waiting for the visitor. Istanbul is a cornucopia of attractions befitting its most famous water way, the "Golden Horn". It's Paris without the snootiness.

Sultanamet area. Everything within walking distance. The area was kept clean despite the crowds. Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Mosaic Museum, Topaki Palace, Archeological Museum, Grand Bazaar, etc.

Istanbul the magnificent!. I have travelled to many places around the globe. Istanbul is truly one of the most amazing cities on earth. So much to see, so much history, such wonderful people, delicious food. It is clean, people are respectful, very little smoking anymore. Great transportation (if no crowded), good humor and civility on crammed trams. Just beyond expectations on every level. It isn't hard to see why this was chosen to be the seat of civilization, it's location is beautiful! Gorgeous people friendly parks everywhere. It is just plain awesome and any world traveller should not miss it. The museums and sites are incomparable, well maintained and signed. Nothing like it...nothing!

NICE BUT NOT ASTONISHING. Returning from my long journey to India and Nepal I stopped in Istanbul to meet an old friend who took me around the city which is very nice, clean, safe and with many places to visit. Food is awsome almost everywhere and service quick. People also nice but they rarely speak english which is very bad for such an internationl city. Same at the airport. It is a GO.

Centuries of HIstory. In a very close area you can visit and experience over three centuries of history. All within walking distance. All Turks were most friendly and English as second language is widespread.

Absoulutely Amazing. This City is gorgeous, with so many attractions to see all within walking distance. If your hotel is in the the old city then you're in the perfect location. On that side of the river you have the; Grand Bazaar, Egyptian Bazaar, Sultanahmet District, Seleymaniye Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, New Mosque... I could keep going on. A tram line gets you to most of these places, if you dont feel up to the walk, and only costs TL3 per trip per person, however the tram is always full to the brim. So I'd recommend taking a nice leisurely walk, following the tram lines. Tram comes quite close to walkway at some points, so keep an eye out.

Private guide enables you to skip to the front of the line. Seeing the traditional historical sites helps one to understand the complexity of this modern city. A private guide is well worth the cost. Our guide was able to explain context and nuances that would otherwise have been missed. A good guide knows how to avoid the cruise ship crowds and can take you to the front of what can sometimes be long lines for entry.
breathtaking. we stayed here for 5 days and every time we came across the blue mosque and Aya Sofia it always took my breath away - I came here on honeymoon and would recommend Istanbul to all.
Atmospheric, amazing, fascinating and exotic. Make sure to visit the Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi Palace, Palace Mosaic Museum, Archaeological Museum and Hippodrome

NICE HOTEL. Location is really great - in the heart of an old city; staff was very helpful; room clean; perhaps not so big but for us ok as we were travelling all the time spending only nights in a room. Summing up - I would recommend this hotel for stay.
Wonderful turkey Trip. Excellent Food Hotels Attractions and Travel Agency Tours, airport pick up and return allways on time. Magnificent Travel i Super Organized.

Wonderful. A lot of interesting old buildings to see,almost all of them at walking distance one to another:Galata Tower,Galata bridge,Spices bazaar,Blue Mosque,Ayasofia,basilica Cistern and many other(Topkapi and Dolmabahce palaces),.A lot of restaurant,cafes,souvenir shops,scores of barrow-men.Very crowded.A minus - no touristic indicators in english.

Touring round Istanbul. I recommend you hire a guide to go round old city as everything is within walking distance and the guides are so knowledgeable. As they are official guides you go straight to the front of the queues which means you don't waste time waiting to get in. We only had 2 days in Istanbul but managed to get to a lot of the sites. It has made me determined to do a return trip for a longer period.We also took an formal tour in a bus but as the buses are mini buse the most people on tour is about 16 and we got to go further afield this also included a trip on the Bospherus and a cable car ride. Definitely to be recommended

Incredible city. Walking around and getting lost and finding mosques or markets was the best of the trip.The worst by far were taxi drivers who refused to drive us to specific addresses. They just want to take you to a hotel and they don't charge you by the clock.

A must-visit. The Sultanhamet area (there is a tram stop) is a must-see when you are in Istanbul. We visited the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern in one day and found it very manageable. The Museum Pass gets you access to the Topkapi Palace (including the Hagia Irene and Harem which are extra if purchasing a standard ticket to visit the Palace) and Hagia Sophia together with other attractions, and lets you skip queues - very handy in the sunshine! You can buy it online or at those attractions. There are some nice restaurants and cafes in the area, so it's a good place to start your visit.

Awesome!. Istanbul is filled with history and the best glimpse of it is in Sultanahmet area. Most of the sites are in here and therefore if its your first visit to the city, its advisable to stay in one of the hotels here. Then everything can be easily covered by walk.One can start with the Hippodrome, followed by Blue Mosque, then the Hagia Sophia and finally end with Basilica Cistern. Topkapi Palace is right beside the Hagia Sophia but my advise is to keep a major part of the day for it and not to club it together with the rest. You can finish at the Grand Bazaar, the day you cover the mosques and the Cistern. The charm of Istanbul lies in Sultanahmet. When you are not doing the historical sites, you can enjoy its numerous cobble stoned paths and the cafes there in. We loved it........
Second Trip to Istanbul. It was great to be back and to see what I missed the fist time. I went to a Turkish bath which was lovely. I had not done that before.
Magical Feeling. Blue Mosque & Topkapi palace was just incredible! It's two of very amazing & important places that everybody need to visit!
Spectacular!. Do not miss the Cistern, the best of all. You can skip the Blue Mosque if the queue is too long :-=)
Fantastic city. Wonderful culture, history, food and people. I highly recommend a trip to Istanbul. Give yourself enough time (> 3 days) to RUN through the myriad sites. Make it 10 to do it right.

The City. Beautiful! You can walk around, take the tramway, feel at home. No need to take tours. All attractions are very close if you stay in the Old Town. All visits, early, before the cruisers. Santa Sofia, Topkapi, The Blue Mosque, the Bosphorous...beautiful! Don't miss walking along the left bank of the Bosphorous, the New City, full of trees, flowers, cafes, restaurants, new buildings. You need to take the boat for this. Skip Sundays, full full of people. Safe city.
a lot of places to see. Dive in into centuries of history waiting for you on streets of the old city. See magnificent old mosques and palaces, narrow streets and beautiful green parks.

A must see definitely.. I really enjoyed my trip to thsi wonderful city. It has a different mood and energy. I feel like I can live there for ever with out getting bored. Bosphorus is great in a sunny early morning time and all those historical buildings and especially mosques are a most see....Looking forward to go again...

Exploring Istanbul. The only thing we really disliked was the hassle from shopkeepers,restaurant staff and Guide Book sellers.We found a shop near the hotel with a "hassle free" we spoke to the shopkeeper and he felt he sold more by allowing people to browse freely.We asked him to open a school to educate the others!!!

Historical Istanbul. Must see for everyone who wants to understand and feel today's Istanbul... All the different civilisations and empires put another mosaic stone up to today's modern metropolitan city and life of Istanbul.
very nice place to see. Its soo cultural, have bit of exotic feeling.. niceAnd most of must see area are in close distanceNow istanbul has old city and new city..should check both

Must do in Istanbul. Dolmabahce Palace and Chora church are must see the mosaics at Chora are divine. Also strongly recommend Badilica Cistern most tour will not take u there but well worth the effort.

booking a tour is a waste of money. the tour guides barely "guide". they simply drop you off and let you roam. the tours are very expensive (100$ for a whole day tour) and the lunch provided was minimal
>>. Within easy walking distance to all the historic sites. Recommend getting a private guide to skip the lines.
great town . You can buy anything , very friendly place, nice people , ALWAYS offer a smaller price :) they will agree , visit blue mosche and subteran water reserve

A wonderful place. I loved Istanbul, it is one of my favourite places I have ever visited. The people are friendly and helpful and they take pride in their city. Always have a smile on their face and are willing to go that extra mile to help you out. Which isn't always the case in a lot of places. Its vibrant, exiciting, friendly, spiritual and rich in history, a wonderful place to visit and I will definately be going back.

Easy to get around. Nothing to dislike. Only pay 1 turkish lira for turkish tea as that what the locals pay. Mosques and palaces were brilliant. The bazaars were fantastic. Bargains can be had with the right amount of haggling. No fears of safety.

Istanbul rich in history. There's never a dull moment when visiting the historic areas of Istanbul with its rich history. Whether you on a family holiday, on honeymoon or on business, a visit to the historic areas of Istanbul is highly recommended...

Istanbul ist the nicest city in the whole world!. The scenic view of the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Bosphorus, the Süleymanie Mosque, the golden Horn and the Galata tower is breathtaking!

Istanbul is wonderfull town with friendly people. We stayed now 4 days in Istanbul and I can only recommend it to everybody, fantastic experience, or old oriental city or modern buildings, for everybody much fun!

so many sites, such little time.. My only regret with this trip is that we didn't spend more time in Istanbul. What an amazing city! We loved the ease of getting around and the friendliness of the people despite the size of the city. I loved both palaces and the river tours are nice for a relaxing time after walking all day.

A lot of history packed in Istanbul !. The blue mosque is grand and imposing and unlike other monuments,access to it is easy as one does not have to wait in long queues.The story of Sofia church has parallel to India's Babri masjid where the invading moghul rulers turned a hindu temple into a mosque. The Sofia Church met with a similar fate!The Tokapi palace has invaluable collection that will be of great interest to muslims.The Kings Palace and harem are also magnificient and well preserved.One had to wait endlessly to get a ticket into these monuments.So if you are not part of a pre arranged tour, request your hotel to arrange in advance for entry tickets to these crowded sight seeing places.At the Grand Bazaar, be at your negotiating best to get a bargain deal.Beware of touts from carpet shops who will sweet talkk you into their shops and waste valuable time.

nice place. You go to Taksim Square and you get the train to the Old area , it is just 10 to 15 minutes ahead , you can see the Marmara , Golden Horn , eat ekmek balik (fish sanduich ) under the bridge.

The Grand Bazzar (a shopper's paradise). This place can be intimidating when you first get there, and the maze of shops can be daunting to any first timer here! Afraid of getting lost? you most probably will! but don't panic, you'll probably find your way out as easily as you got lost.Try and get a bearing on the main drag as soon as you get in, and try your best to work the place in a grid fashion. It won't take you long to get the hang of it.The best deals are deeper in the bazzar where the faint hearted tend not venture into. Start off at 50% of the asking price and move up as quickly or slowly as the vendor does. Be prepared to walk away from the deal if it's not going your way. There's a good chance the shopkeeper will give in if he sees that you were interested in the article, but are not prepared to pay any more than your best offer.Once you have bought something, it's best not to comparison shop or you'll be disappointed! If you want to comparison shop then do it before you buy something.If you really like it, then buy it right away, cause trying to find the shop that offered the best deal may take you a lot of time.Probably best if you take a break part way and come back, and shop some more.If you go to the places that sell food outside the gates, just make sure that the menu they show you has prices on it. It's a scam! If you make the mistake of ordering from the menu that had no prices beside or below the menu item, you'll end up paying between 3-5 times the price.The Grand bazzar is a blast! and an experience not to be missed when in Istanbul.Happy shopping!

Galata, Sultanahmet, Fatih, Istiklal Avenue. For the atmosphere I have to say that Galata was my favorite place on a Saturday Night, it felt almost festive but subdued enough to be comfortable. Lots of people about, tourist and locals.I enjoyed the atmosphere in Sultanahmet also but it is almost all tourist of course. Beware the Carpet Store Salesman... be firm and walk away! Istiklal is a great festive atmosphere and certainly has as many locals as tourist if not more, long walk and very crowded at night. If you are into architecture, go during the day and enjoy the buildings as I did. My only trip to Fatih was to see the Valens Aqueduct, and it is definitely not a tourist spot, all locals and a long walk from the Tram, and toward the end you have to pass under the road down some steps.

Off the beaten track, Balat and Edirnekapi. Great way to see real, non touristy Istanbul, you can do it on your own. Start your tour from Fener that is ten minutes away from Eminonu, wander in the narrow, hilly streets of Balat, check great red brick monument, Greek Orthodox College. Then head to Carsamba, you may think you are visiting somewhere in Middle East, one of the most conservative neighborhood in Istanbul. Chora Museum takes 10 minutes walk from Carsamba, mosaics and frescoes are well preserved, worth for a visit. You may check the link for mor information about route;http://backpackingistanbul.com/balat-edirnekapi-route.html
One of my favorite trips of all time. Wish we could return and spend more time there. Three days was certainly just the tip of the iceberg for us.

Overdose of excitement. Istanbul to me is like a royal flush in a game of poker and I wished we had more time than just 4 days.Here's my itinerary that made my stay memorable:1st day: wake up early and be at the blue mosque before 9 am,head to Hagia Sofia afterwards,basilica cistern later and hang out in the hippodrome until dusk where you enjoy the view,the people and enjoy a nice meal in a restaurant of your choice.The views of the blue mosque and hagia sofia are totally different at night.(you don't want to miss it)2nd day: Grand Bazaar where you can easily spend the whole day believe me.Take the ferry to enjoy the Bosphorus at dusk especially when the bridge are lit up and have fish for dinner at the harbor.3rd day. Topkapi palace in the morning then head out to the Galata tower in the afternoon to enjoy a view of the city from the highest point in Istanbul.Enjoy the restaurants by the Galata bridge including watching the ships and fishermen as well as the view of the city at night,don't worry Metro runs till midnight.4th day:Take the metro to the tunnel and walk Ishtikal street towards Takshim square where you can shop and enjoy the food for the last time.
Istanbul- a haven for history lovers. Milleniums of history - mix of cultures - amazing - if you love Greek- early Christian and Islamic history - you must visit historical centers in Istanbul

Well worth a visit. Istanbul is geared up for tourists, and getting between the various historic sites is very easy. Recommend a "Big Bus" tour if its your first time. The whole "hop on hop off" trip takes 2 hours and allows you to decide where you want to return to. Outside of the obvious sites, strongly recommend a boat trip down the Bosphorous....from 6TL return if you know where to look!

Beautiful. I visited IStanbul for 5 days recently. I wouldn't be very interested in history etc but enjoyed it very much. I did a day tour as recommended by my hotel which was a long day but included most of the historic sights and main attractions of Istanbul. The Blue mosque was lovely, The Palace was beautiful and the restaurant inside is breathtaking with amazing views. I enjoyed the Grand Bazaar also being a big shopper,but have to say the Princes Islands were by far my favorite attraction, we got off on the first island and did a bike trip and then a full island trek by horse and cart. There are no cars on the island and the views were spectacular. If you're going to Istanbul, definitely visit these.

Mesmerising. The historic sights of Istanbul had me awestruck. This place is still so rich in culture. The calls from the mosques, the range if different smells in the air, the mix between the old and the new, it's amazing really. The best area to experience the best of old and new is near Galata bridge. From one side you will look over and see a side of the city covered in mosques and ancient buildings and the other side, you're a close walk to Taksim square which is quite modern. Such an amazing city!
turkey history. turkey has so much of history that it was great to actually see all the places where historical moments happened
Ancient Istanbul. Easy access to historic sights. Wonderful architecture, beautiful tiles and frescoes. Helpful English speaking guides.

A walk through history. I liked the Turkish/Ottoman sites with their opulence but I disliked the neglect of the Byzanthine/Roman/Greek sites, e.g. decaying roman ruins and a great but unmarked roman column along the Yenicerler Ave., a huge but decaying aqueduct.

Obviously a must see. If you're coming to Istanbul then it's a given you'll end up in the historic area of Istanbul. Needless to say you will not be disappointed.All the sites live up to the hype. I spent 3 days in the city and saw everything I possibly wanted to see.Topkapi was a personal favorite and I would recommend the audio guide
Absolute must. Layers of history; contrast between Islam and Byzantine Christianity as faiths; architecture; beautiful tiles

First trip to Istanbul. The Hagia Sofia and the Mosaic Museum near the Arasta market bazaar. The Galata Tower was a must for its views, but the long queue- when you reached the top of the tower before you could even step out onto the viewing area -was an unexpected nuisance. The Spice and Grand Bazaar were brilliant, though you need to take care not to lose your family for ever in the enormity of the Grand Bazaar.
Great place to visit!. When you are visiting istanbul, you should check and visit this area. The area shows the best of views of istanbul and you will enjoy the day by spending the time over there.
great history. its nice to walk on these streets but avoid going to shopping in narow streets during weekend as you will not be able to shop or walk even

Ancient Wonders in the Old City. When visiting Istanbul when of my favourite routes to the old town is to take a tram from Taksim all the way down Istiklal street to tunel - where a 60 second carriage takes you down to Galata bridge. Walking across the bridge head to the spice market. From there a number of ancient delights are just waiting to be discovered from the stunning Blue Mosque to the meditative splendour of the Basilica Cistern.
Out of the history pages... Well maintained and worth visiting.. The Aya Sophia is awe inspiring and the grand bazaar is an experience on its own.. The topkapi palace is beautiful

The Old Town!. Thinking about the parade of history seen here in the heart of the old town makes you wonder about the lives of the people. East meets West! Camels replaced by cars and buses. Food changes with each new caravan. Spices from all over the world found in the bazaars. Trade was king.

Very historical city. İstanbul...We can write down many things about this fantastic city which holds a very rich history during many centuries.Through different cultural effects since beginning of the city,you can always come close to very different historical monuments and&or ruins from any time of the past.To move around in any part of the old city will show you how beautiful this city is with its rich cultural heritage.It is very much nice and benefit to yr side to stroll the streets at yr own and feel it yrself.This is something else.Very much recommended.

The Mosaic of Byzantine and Ottoman ,Hagia Sophia and on. There are numerous archeological and historic sites in IstanbulTo name a few ;The Galata Tower,Hagia Sophia Museum ,Basilica Cistern andSultan Ahmet Mosque ; that are exiting to rexplore , will take you back in time to the traces of Early Greek settlements to Byzantine structures and further on to Ottoman monuments

LOVED Istanbul. Much like J J's review as far as attractions and local foods. All good! We loved Istanbul and the old city, where we stayed for 4 days. Not one minute is waisted because there is so much so see. We visited: Bleue Mosque, Ste-Sophie, Palace Topkapi and Acheological Museum, which are all close by. My favorite list goes like this: 1- Ste-Sophie (magnificient), 2- Acheological Museum (so much to see and how interesting), 3- Topkapi (Very nice and interesting), 4- Blue Mosque (... did not like it that much). As far as Mosquee, there are a bunch of other Mosquees nearby that is worth visiting much more and Blue. Having said that, Blue Mosquee looks magnificient from the outside.
wow. “Like all great travelers, I have seen more than I remember, and remember more than I have seen.” – Benjamin Disraeli

The tulips were in full bloom. I traveled with Smithsonian Journeys. Unforgettable experience! We spent four days in Istanbul before the trip down the coast line and the organisation was impeccable. So far - the best trip in my life!

Exotic Old City. I spent 3 1/2 days in Istanbul which was the perfect amount of time. In Sultanahmet, the old city, there was so much to look at and so much Ottoman culture and history to soak up. My favourite sights would be the Basilica Cistern, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace. I also enjoyed the Spice Bazaar but thought the Grand Bazaar was a bit of a disappointment. It was just so full of touristic junk.

Awesome!. LOVED everything about the old city! We spent 4 days in Sultanahmet, enjoyed it all, even in the rain! Must sees: Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Bosphorus cruise. We ate dinner on a rooftop to see the gorgeous view. Prepare for vendors everywhere. In the rain they sold umbrellas, at the mosque they sold scarves. Note: At the Blue Mosque it is free, they do have a donation area at the end if you choose. Clothing to cover arms, legs, and scarves for women is required, but they have those for you free when you enter if you come unprepared. Aya Sophia, Topkapi both require tickets - try to get at a booth outside instead of waiting in line. Or get the day before. I recommend trying some of the foods/drinks from the standing vendors. Nice to try something different! BEWARE: Some attractions are closed one day a week, may be different from another. I missed the Archaelogical Museum and Florence Nightingals Museum because of this. Check ahead. Also: Tourist areas have regular toilets (WC signs), but occasionally you will run into the "hole-in-the-ground" ones only. Be sure to "go" when you have a toilet convenient to you that you like.

Amazing. The city's old areas are thriving and there is excitement day and night. It is easy enough to get info in English and to navigate using buses and trams and trains. People are very helpful.Easy city to get around, many of the sites are all together. I highly recommend a visit to Istambul.

Glad I've been. Always wanted to visit theirs historic city and was impressed. Having said that three hours seeing what I wanted to see then leaving suited me fine. Blue mosque stunning sat opposite hagia Sofia also great architecture. Topkapi bit difficult if in wheelchair and quite expensive for what it is. Saw beautiful views both in the sultan Ahmet district and looking back towards it from Asia. Great experience but wouldn't return.
amazing. touching 2000 years of history, very helpful guide, extraordinary place and welcoming locals. Avoid café at main museum which is poor quality. otherwise food is very good

Steeped in history. Very atmospheric, with amazing architecture. A real assault on your senses. Make sure you get up early to visit any of the most popular sites such as the Blue Mosque as queues can be very long

Liked all, except TopKapi. We liked & enjoy all the historic places as couples, except Topkapi palace.make sure you read something before you going into any historic places, it will help you to watch more interestingly.

The tourist trail. Main tourist attractions are all within walking distance and so worthwhile.Downside - the queues, Booked to see the whirling dervishes at the Galata museum - tickets are limited so go early on the day of performance to buy. No children under 7 and no flash on cameras allowed.Galata tower is a good way to have a 360 degree view of Istanbul.Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar are good to visit too.Buy a Jeton token for tl3 and jump on a tram which are very efficient.Take a boat trip up the Bosphorous you can get cheap deals where the ferries dock.

Unplaaned Visit But It Was Worth It. Will visit again & stay @ same hotel again.. Tours were real good but including a visit to the Leather Factory was un-necessary. Overall? Excellent. Plann'g to go back. :-)

Centuries of history. This area in the old town is a must. You should have at least a day to see everything there and to drink a coffee on the beautiful cafes at the square between The Saint Sofia church and The Blue Mosque

Ottoman history. We took a private tour of the Old City.....walked all around the area. It was interesting and worth seeing. We also visited the Grand Bazar....didn't care for the crowds and selling pressure. At the Spice Market our guide had a connection (don't they all? with one of the nice shops and we tasted and bought spices.

A great city for a short break. We spent 4 nights and intend to go back. Very friendly people, good value for money, with good food andgood local wines. We stayed at the Tashkonak Hotel in the Sultanahmet district. Most of the historical sites are within walking distance.

A first visit... An historic and beautiful city ... but dislike the continual hassling to buy....it great city to walk around. Most tourists seem to see everything through a camera ... but look around and visit place off the beaten track!
amazing. A must for a visit, gobsmacking buildings, the view of the golden horn from the cafe in Topkapi palace is to die for.
A nice place to walk about. It's just an interesting place to walk about. There isn't much more to say. The sights are all in this area.
sultanahmet. great place,all the important atractions near by.Aya Sophia.Topcapai Palace,Blu Mask by wolking,good for a whole day.must come with scarf for ladies...
Wonderful Historical Turkey. Everything about Turkey was fantastic. We had no bad experiences, not even slightly bad. Fantastic all the way with Ozan Baykara and Travelshop Turkey
Unbelievable hostory. Just loved the magnificent architecture of all the buildings and the history. So much for the senses and to absorb!!
good walking tour. meet the people and see the sights. a bit hilly, not unlike san fancisco, but worth it. a great, vibrant city and fun for westerners

from Musems to Churches. From the mosques to christian churches, galleries and musems something for everyone.
a very busy nosiy city but if you like cities then that will not bother you.
Food a bit limiting vegatarians beware!

Fantastic area. So much to explore and view just wandering around is fantastic. There is always so much going on and hearing the call to prayer is great too and just adds to the experience. The area is filled with restaurants, cafés and amazing places to explore like the blue mosque, aya sofya, basilica cistern and topkapi to name just a few!

History in abundance. Istanbul (Constantinople of Byzantium) is one of the most historical cities in the world. The old city and Sultanahmet area is where to start. This is where the Sultanahmet mosque (Blue mosque), the Hagia Sofia mosque/museum, Topkapi palace, the Basilica cistern, the Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar are situated, and one is only a tram ride away from the Bosphorus riverside (tram station Eminonu).This a bustling area with lots to see and places to stop for a snack or lunch.

A wonderful City. There is so much to see it is worth having some knowledge of the City's history and to plan which sites you would like to visit in advance. You will not be disappointed but be prepared for large numbers of people at the most popular attractions. Early morning visits are probably best.
What a lot of fun!. There is a surprise around every corner - cafes, restaurants, tourist attractions, carpet shops, bazaars - and all within walking distance or by tram.

Sultanamhet. My third visit to historic Istanbul, this time with my teenage daughter. Sultanhamet is where you want to be if you want to see Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque or the Basilica Cistern. It's a wonderful bustling part of town, filled with tourists and locals, who are mostly trying to sell some snacks or cheap goods. The tram that runs on the street is useful to take you to the Grand Bazaar as well as Eminonu where you can either catch a boat to the European side or go for a cruise along the Bosphorus. You can also catch the metro over to Taxim Square and go for a walk on the very modern Istiklal Cad. I love the place. So much history, so much to see, not too expensive if you shop around and barter. Easy to navigate, with reliable public transport (don't forget your city card). Top it you and use it on tram, metro, buses, and some of the ferry's. On the minus side, they hard sell you at the restaurants that line the street, the food may taste good but the portions are tiny and expensive. Also I'll never get over the little kids begging, but I suppose that happens in a lot of places.

It's a World Heriage Area for many reasons. The Spice Market, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sofia and the Topkapi Palace are all well worth visiting. The first two are free, with appropriate clothing necessary for the mosque. The others have a fee - but get there early (eg 9 am) if you want to avoid long queues. History is all about you.See the Grand Bazaar but don't buy anything there. Also, try to avoid the pesky souvenir salesmen who pester you everywhere!However, definitely try the hot salep drink, made of dried powdered roots of a mountain orchid, milk, sugar, cinnamon, rose water and sometimes coconut. delicious and different.

Roman remains. It is hard to picture whatConstantinople would have been like with its huge palace, hippodrome etc. Part of the hippodrome remains, and wonderful mosaics from the palace are to be seen in the mosaic museum near the Blue Mosque. The Million Marker does not look remarkable but is is incredible to find that it was. 4th century distance marker to places in the Roman Empire.

So much culture.... So much to learn about this fantastic city called Istambul or Istanbul in local language. Definitely a plus to visit the major areas in the old town: Grand Bazaar, Spices Market, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, etc.

fascinating. Loved the history hated the constant hassle from people trying to sell stuff. Most of the main sights are close together but the queues are a bit off-putting though proved quicker than expected.

The most amazing place I have ever been. Istanbul is phenomenal. I have traveled all over the world and visited many places, but Istanbul literally took my breath away. The sheer magnitude of history that has happened here is almost dizzying. If you love history and culture and food, this is the right place to visit. The 4 days that I was able to spend in this wonderful city were not enough and I cannot wait to go back and see more. I am truly in awe of this marvelous city.

Don't miss it. All the major attractions are within walking distance. Visit the impressive Basilica Cistern, the Hagia Sofia, the Topkapi palace, the Blue Mosque, the hippodrom.... Everything is absolutely worth to be seen.
Vibrant and Friendly. Public transport is easy and safe.Shop assistants are friendly and keen to assist.Istanbul is not an expensive City.

very short trip. We only had one day in the city so were only able to view a couple of thing, the Sofia Mosque and the Blue Mosque. Long queue for the former as you have to pay. Difficulty in buying an Istanbul travel card, but fascinating to witness another culture.

Plenty to do!. There is never a lack of anything to do in Istanbul as the entire city is rich in historical areas. Personal favorites were the grand bazaar and the basilica cistern. Would highly recommend immersing yourself in the grand bazaar and ordering yourself a coffee or tea while people watching. Haggling is of course encouraged. The city of istanbul is a bit tricky to navigate around with some traffic problems. Be careful with taxi drivers offering "alternative" routes as they will take you for an expensive ride.
Mosques, etc., in Istanbul. Some of the mosques are very beautiful but so many are like each other - concentrate on Blue Mosque and Aya Sofia. Topkapi Museum is a must!

3 days plan!. First of all stay in Sultanahmet to be close to all sightseeing places.1st Day: Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Grand Basaar then down the hill to Eminenu through Spice market. Have some Grilled fish near the ferry terminals (fish is freshly fought from the see and grilled in front of you on a small boat). Then get back to the hotel have rest and go to the restaurant for a dinner!2nd Day: Bosphorus trip. Same Eminenu embankment. At 10.35 a ferry goes from there to the very top of Bosphorus, to the black sea. (You need to get there not past 9.30 or you risk not to get a place with a view on a ship). You go to the last stop Anadolu Cavagi, past Sariyer and go see the old castle overlooking the mouth of Boshorus there. Have lunch and at 15.00 the same ferry goes back to Istanbul to arrive there at 16.25. Get some rest and go to a good restaurant for some good local food.3d Day: Topkapi palace, Suleimanie mosque with the tombs of Suleiman and Roksolana and off to the Taksim square in the newer part of Istanbul to walk on the Istiklal street. In the evening find yourself a place to eat with a good view over the city to have some food and wine and complete your stay in this magnificent city!

huge city needs help to see the sites. Be very careful with belongings here, loved the Grand Bazaar, the Topkapii Palace, the Blue Mosque. The Grand Bazaar has every thing you could want to purchase, and terrific Turkish coffee shops. Coffee was served on silver platter with amareto and water in tiny cups elegantly placed.

Loved the Historic sites, Energy and People. We had spent all the 5 days of our Istanbul stay in the Sultanahmet area which has the maximum concentration of the famous historic sites in Istanbul – Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and next door Archeological museum, Basilica Cistern and many more. You can also take the tram from there to Kabattas station to visit Dolmabahce palace – a truly ‘don’t miss’ attraction. Few tips about Sultanahmet area if you are planning to take accommodation – the hotels behind Blue Mosque though are in quieter area but the Prayers from the Mosque will penetrate through the walls of the hotel rooms very easily and multiple times in the day, evening and night. We had spent the 1st four nights there and experienced it, we were on the other side of Sultanhamet square towards Grand Bazar on our last day ( for reference check this address - Rast Hotel - Binbirdirek Mah. Klodfarer Cad. No:4 Sultanahmet ) and that location is much better , every attraction of Sultanahmet is easy to reach from there besides you are steps away from the Tram lines, main street, local food options and the shopping options including the Mega hub of Grand Bazar. Loved the energy and people of Sultanahmet area. One more thing: the queue to the major sites such as Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace is always a very long one – you will save a lot of time if you buy a Museum pass (available right in front of Hagis Sophia or you can buy online and get it delivered to your hotel in Istanbul ahead of your arrival as I did) . Suleymaniye mosque is another attraction around that location that you should not miss if you are in Sultanhamet , plan to cover this mosque when you are visiting Grand Bazar because it is somewhere close – we asked people and found our way though we had to walk for about 20-25 minutes. Another historic site worth visiting is the Chora Church ( or Kariye Museum ) – the Church of the Holy Saviour – we took a cab to reach there for about 15 Lira – be careful about the Taxi drivers – they can really take you for a ride unless you negotiate a fixed price before you get it. That’s it from now….. I just shared my experience from our very recent trip to Istanbul – hope you find it useful.Regards,Ujjwal MukherjeeBangalore, India

Visit to friends. My visit is many years ago, but the city impressed me. The hustle and bustle combined with e friendliness of the people. Fortunately, having Turkish friends there I was taken to the main places of interest and given a local's insight into its varied past. Topkapi, the Blue Mosque were fascinating, but the market with its carpet and jewel leery stalls really caught the imagination.
Weekend in Istanbul. Wonderful city. Lots to see. Easy to get around.Best value was the Bosphorus cruise which cost only 12 Turkish Lira!

Wonderful Treasures of Awesome Sites. Istanbul is a wonderful city with lots of rich history. All the sites were beautiful! However, be preapred for long lines and aggressive sales tactics (which is customary for this region). Plan your site seeing strategy, entrance fees and take a lot of patience with you. It is all worth it in the long!Sites of interest are the Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, The Cistern,
Historic area. Many people...lots of energy...it's best to have a guide...long lines to get into the places you want to see without a guide...

Istanbul May 2014. Visited for 3 days. As expected main tourist attractions awesome. Who wouldn't like Blue Mosque, Ayasophia and Topkapi? A neat little find was the railway museum (free entry) at the main station. Lots of artefacts from the Orient Express. Very atrmospheric.
actually I visited historical places in June 2012. I liked Hagya Sofia, Dolma Bahche, Top Kapi, Some mosque near Hagya Sofia-do not remember name, Eminyonu Mosque

A fresh view on history. It will take You at least a week to soak in all of the sites from the Istanbul historic areas. MAKE SURE to by a Museum pass from official Istanbul Museum Pass site or vending machines. Trust me, it will cut Your waiting time by 90% and save You almost 50% on entry fees!
A must.... So many awesome sights..you have to see Hagia Sofia from the inside...Topkapi Palace...Basilica Cisterna..Blue Mosque and of course the Golden Horn

One of the must-see places of the world. Pretty well everything is withing walking distance in the old city, and a good map will help you get about. Get a museum pass so you don't have to queue endlessly.

Amazing but be streetwise. It is an unbelievable experience to see the magnificent museums, palaces, mosques etc. so I will not repeat what has been written.It is exceptionally busy so book accommodation early to stay at a gorgeous boutique hotel in Sultanahmet for easy access to the main sites. It is wonderful at night when the building are lit, there are fabulous restaurants and coffee shops and lots of touristy shops.Book a tour or preferably a guide to avoid the exceptionally long queues. (It looked as though one could spend the entire morning in line)Be exceptionally careful of the taxi drivers. Know where you are going and how much it should cost. In one night we were about to be conned in two separate incidences and jumped out of the taxis. Apparently not all the taxis belong to an organisation. Ask the concierge to order a taxi if you are leaving from the hotel.Every carpet store seems to have a tout outside. Don't show an interest. If you look lost you will also be guided to a carpet store. Most people, especially in the stores are very friendly.This area is the highlight of Istanbul.
vibrant. Roaming through Kadikoy, Gulhan park and the streets around Topkapi palace was discovering the real Istanbul.

The wait is worth it!. Wonderful city great Mosques and Museums there were long queues at most, but they moved at a reasonable speed and as long as you were patient it was no problem. Everything is within walking distance in the Sultanhamet area, but if you want to explore further afield the tram and ferries are easy to use and I would recommend a day on one of the Princes Islands chose any one you will not be disappointed. It is also a way to escape from the carpet sellers - although there were still hawkers on the ferries even!

Lots to see.. Allow time to go through Harem and Topkapi palace - you could spend a whole day there. Also Hippodrome, Haghia Sophia, Sultanahmet mosque, Grand Bazaar and Spice bazaar - all worth a look!
Amazing experience. I like the city. Nice streets, good restaurants and really friendly people. Only the taxi drivers are thiefs.

The historic city that joins Europe to Asia. We were very impressed with the quality of so many Historic sites. The Blue Mosque, Sophie, the Sultans palace, the Museum of Science were very impressive.

Museums & Palace. Visited 2 museums and 1 palace in the old town of Istanbul. All very nice, but very busy with many tourists. The lines are very long, so I would suggest going with a tour so you can bypass the entrance lines. Once inside, there is a que as well so you must stand in line to see the various rooms, etc.

Cool City. There are mosques everywhere - truly stunning. I got too many cat calls from men, especially Hey Black Lady or Hey Beyonce, but that was the only downfall. The food was amazing, people were helpful. There was lots to do and always something going on. There are lots of tourists but to leave some behind head to the Asia side or non touristy parts of the city.

Visa requirement for cruise passengers visiting Turkey. We recently visited Izmir and Istanbul on a cruise (sleeping on board the ship).Before departure we searched the net whether a visum was needed for cruise passengers.Everywhere we were told that such was the case, preferable to be arranged by internet.In reality everybody got a boarding card and passports were not even checked.Buying a visum for Turkey (at $15 each) appeared to be unnecessary!

so much to see. where to start.... take your time, walk and walk and walk. We loved venturing around the narrow streets and alleyways, finding the tiny mosques and coffee stops. find a vedor buy some street food and stand in the line to visit the cisterns and other major attractions, but theres so much more to this city than just the tourist areas. defiantly get yourself onto a rooftop bar or cafe and enjoy the view.

Crowded & Chaotic, But A Must See. Istanbul has about 11 Million tourists a year, and it seems that all of them are in this area when you are there too. The local authorities and the security services, as well as people running the sites, must do much better job in organizing the ticket sales, waiting lines, public toilets, guides, peddlers, movement of the crowds to and from the sites. So, once you've armed yourself with extreme patience and tolerance for the "different", this is one of the most exciting places: you can see in its full size and glory a 6th century basilica (Hagia Sophia), which remained the biggest building for almost 1000 years! You can see the treasury of the sultans (Topkapi Palace), and the first imperial mosque (Sultan Ahmet). The cistern is also a surprise, you would never expect to see such a big water tank furnished with fancy Corinthian pillars hidden right before the eyes of thousands of people!

Amazing history. If you are interested in seeing architecture and it's clash of cultures and ideas, then this is an amazing place to go to. Sooo much history, and each era had so much longevity to make their own individual contributions and impact.

Unforgettable. One of the great cities of the world with a stunning historical centre.Full of tourists but still feels very authentic.Great sites.....the archeological museum a standout of the lesser viewed sites.Local food is yummy.Bazaar the centrepiece but very aggressive selling inside.Walked the area every day for nine days and never bored.

Well just amazing. Some tips- Go for dinner after 9, places open and lots of tourists already gone.-Take public transport, very efficient and will save you lots of money. Some tours are a rip off-Dont take any cruise tours, do it yourself in public boat, tickets cost a few dollars.
Worth a visit. Do visit the historic areas of istanbul, it is really worth it. Even if you are not a history buff. Especially the Tokapi and the two large, and, famous mosques is very interesting.

Istanbul Captured Me. I was captured by the beauty of Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet Square, Topkapi Palace, people, atmosphere, food, ferry trip to the Asian side of Istanbul, and I also liked Cobbled streets etc
Visit 25 28 April 2014. Istanbul is a fascinating place and we enjoyed Topkapi Palace and Museum; Hagia Sophia Museum;Basilica Cistern.

When you see an entrance/gate in a wall, always go in!. *as long as there are not police and armed guards telling you otherwise. I stayed in the historic area for 8 days and passed the entrance to the topkipa palace everyday, but never went in, I missed out!! This whole area is so rich with history!
Full of history. Lovely area, very crowded with long lines but worth the time and the sore feet from all the walking. We were glad we had a tour guide.

Highlights of Istanbul. Loved-Blue Mosque/ Cistern/ Hagia Sophia/ Galata Tower.
Had a shave; simply the best value 30lira.
Shopping along Istinkil Caddessi was amazing

I never thought I'd find mosques impressive!. And it's not just the Hagia Sofia and Blue Mosques, there are about 6 huge mosques, impressively lit up at night. My favourite was the Blue Mosque. Get a boat (or the new metro Marmary train tunnel) across the Bosphorous for the best night view.
Places to see moer than once !. I cannot get enough of the varied architecture and history in the historic areas of Istanbul, I will go again !

So much to see and do!. Lots of stunning historical sites to see. Very hilly so wear comfortable shoes!The queues are a lot shorter first thing in the morning so to avoid waiting for 45 minutes+ for each attraction plan in advance and get there for 9am. Personally we didn't think the Museum Card (50TL) to jump the queues was worth it and the additional 85TL for entry to most of the main attractions is only really saving you money if you plan to do absolutely everything, or visit the same place more than once. Save your money and instead buy some souvenirs!

Beware of Scamming Taxis. Istanbul as always is a wonderful place place to visit. The people are friendly and helpful. It's shopping haven. There is never a dull day here with all the museums and other local attractions to visit. However, your visit can be spoiled by scamming taxis. If possible try to travel by bus or train which is cheaper and can be crowded during certain times of the day. If you must use a taxi, trust your gut instincts and follow my tips. Here are some tips: ask for cost of trip to destination before getting into taxi. If they can't give you a set price and claim they have to use the meter then find another taxi. If you know it will cost you an average amount to get to the destination it should be the same returning. If you are quoted a price twice that usual amount, find another taxi. Most taxis will give you a price like 30,35, 40, 45 TL and et cetera but if you get a number like 69 TL the taxi is trying to scam you. For example, you give him 50TL and two 10 TL he will do a switch and say you only gave him a 5 TL and two 10 TL to confuse you and hoping you will pay more money. I have been to Istanbul many times I knew the average cost of fare plus I didn't have any 5TL in my possession so I didn't fall for this scam. What you should do if you feel like you are being scammed, don't pay while you still sitting in taxi. Get out of the taxi and give him the usual fare you pay and quickly walk away. If you are at your hotel and there is a doorman nearby call him over if the taxi driver continues to argue with you. You can also pretend you are calling the police or Jandarma this will settle the "argument" real quick and he will leave.If the taxi claim he will need to drop you off few blocks from your destination because there is too much traffic.Tell him no or hayir and have him take you directly to your destination. Anyone who have been to Istanbul many times it doesn't matter what time of the day it is there is going to be traffic. Don't fall for that excuse that it is too much traffic to be drop off directly at your destination.If the taxi initially agree to a set price then change it upon arriving to your destination. Give him the agreed set price. There is also another way you could get scammed in stores at the mall where the business will say your card is not approved or was declined after swiping your credit card. If you know that is not possible, make sure you check your bank account to make sure there was no charges. If there are then dispute them immediately. Usually they want you to pay in cash that is why they say the card was not approved. Keep your receipts. Other than that, enjoy Istanbul and don't let the few scammers ruin your visit. Always trust your instincts.

Beautiful city with lovely attractions. Beautiful city with many attractions in one area…. Sultanahmet or the old city is the home of The Grand Bazaar, The Blue Mosque and the Aya Sophia which are all a must. Best till last though is the amazing Topkapi Pace which is truly beautiful and has amazing views over the Marmara which is also a must see by taking a boat from the port near the spice market near the golden horn bridge. Will definitely go back.
Istanbul in general. Istanbul is always worth a trip, even if the weather is bad. Fantastic sights, good food, lots of history
Major Sites. All major attractions worth seeing .Buy an Istanbul Card for 85 TL to save money and a lot of time queing

Great sights within walking distance in Sultanahmet. the tram was great but the bargaining with the market vendors was not!
Take good walking shoes with you
A lot of tourists

Unique Worl Culture City. The most exciting city in the world!One of my favourite places in Istanbul is Eyup. This is one of the holy places of Islam; the tomb of Eyup Ensari, a companion of the Prophet Mohammed, is a site of Islamic pilgrimage. Take the ferry from Eminonu up the Golden Horn, a great trip in itself. Walk up to the Eyup Camii and visit the tomb and mosque with the faithful. It is a wonderfully moving and memorable experience. You are always welcome but you must be respectful and follow strict dress codes (ladies should always carry a headscarf with them in Istanbul).Continue your walk up to the beautiful Eyup cemetery for wonderful views of the Golden Horn. If you really want to see Islamic Istanbul, don't just go to the Blue Mosque. Visit other mosques around the city which are not full of visitors.

Nice city. One of the most beautiful and historical enrich city.The city offers a huge array of important historic buildings including the Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. It has a wealth of archaeological monuments as well as a vibrant and colourful local culture of tea gardens, taverns, and markets such as the spice bazaar and Grand Bazaar, 'the world's oldest shopping center'.
Very Good and Must watch. I like culture, people are good in nature, and pick and drop facelity from hotel to spot is world class, combination of Asian, europe cit, history lover must go and visit.
Exotic europe. The historic center of Istanbul is full of wonders to discover and enjoy. The Bosphoros is a magnificent boat highway and an obligatory trip.

topkapi palace. the nicest thing you can see in istanbul, full of history! amazing....It is like stepping in 500 years back. loved everything there , to avoid the queue better have your credit cards and take your ticket from the machine next to the ticket windows.

Fantastic. As this was our second visit to Istanbul and we had already visited amazing Agia Sofia , Top Kapi , Blue Mosque and other famous sights , we decided to spend our time visiting the markets ,the small sidestreets and lovely parks and coming into contact with the local people. We loved the contrast of the old with the new and the fabulous views. Would recommend the evening boat trip starting from the Blue Mosque.

Interesting and great day out !. We loved our visit to the old part of Istanbul-the Hagia Sophia was an amazing experience. The Blue Mosque is right next to it and you walk through the Hippodrome square to get there. The Blvue Mosque is one of the most revered Mosques in use, so ladies take a scarf to cover your head and all need to go with an attitude of spiritual tolerance. You take your shoes off to go inside. If you'd like a lovely Turkish Steambath Hamam experience the Ottoman Hamam right on the Hippodrome is well worth it. The Grand Bazaar is a great place just to stroll around and check it out and have an apple or Turkish tea in and pick up a few prezzies for the folks back home; haggling is normal so go prepared for some gentle fun.

Sultanhamet. This old part of town is fascinating with many attractions. Take a boat trip up the Bosphorus. The new part of the city (European side) is worth the visit at sunset to look across at Sultanhamet - would particularly recommend Mikla restaurant for its view and fabulous food!
A Must!. No visit to Istanbul is complete without visiting the historic sights in the city. Use Trip Advisor to make a list before you go so you won't miss places.

A Must See!. We were on a Gate 1 tour so we were able to see a lot in one day without hiking. Istanbul (old town) is incredible. There is so much to see. I was so exhausted but it was worth the walking and seeing!
Wonderful. Chose to skip the Topkapi palace due to time constraints. Also, the Basilica Cistern has very long line-ups so we had to pass on that sadly.

Must see while in Istanbul. Most historical attractions are located in one area that you can cover walking but not in one day. Old Istanbul area includes: Aya Sophia, Sultan Ahmet (blue mosque), TopKapi Palace and Basilica Cistern. Grand Bazaar and Suleymaniye mosque are also close but on top of the hill so be prepared to walk up the hill or take a short taxi ride.

Stunning City!. Istanbul is such a beautiful contrast between the old & new cultures, it's amazing. Everything is so clean and you feel safe walking around the Sultanahmet area day or night. Most of the sights worth seeing Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Museum are all within a 10 minute walking distance of each other around a square garden so easy to plan a day out. We were only in Istanbul for 9 hours on this trip and we managed to see everything and shop around the grand Bazaar in this time quite easily. Wonderful place & people.

Amazing Istanbul. The historic area is just amazing, everyone will fall in love with Istanbul. It has a unique atmosphere to it and you can see there all religions and nationalities, without judgement.

TK 12 Feb 2014. Great country to visit full of historical values,great food.A very clean country indeed.Knowledgeable Guide and Helpful Airport porters take pride in their job esp helping out my wheelchair bound Mum

Istanbul short break. Great city to visit. Plenty to see and do though not particularly good for children. Try to stay near The Hippodrome where all the main sites are situated. Very safe though some annoyance from touts. Don't miss the Bosphorus Ferry Trip and a fish butty for lunch!

A melting pot of eastern and european cultures. Istanbul is a destination not to be missed.We visited during February 2013,and even though it was cold and rainy,we were still able to visit some of the tourist highlights of this amazing city-Aya Sofia,Topkapi Palace,Blue Mosque,Basilica Cistern, Gallata Bridge , are must see places if you are on a short visit,like myself.Dont book the Bosphorus cruise via your tour guide. There are many people offering the same guided cruise, which your guide might persuade you to take for a fortune, from as little as 8 Turkish Lira.In Istanbul,if you stay in the historical quarter on the Asian side,most of the tourist sights ,including the famous bazaar are within a walking distance.We enjoyed the food from the small cafes,as well as some of the street food. During winter the small fish served with a large flat bread and salad,which we bought from a street vendor was most enjoyable. Turkish food is not only Sheesh kebab,the fish served in a toasted flat bread with salad is absolutely delicious..Turkey has a wonderful array of food available.We bought fresh baklava and turkish delight which is far better than the prepacked ones, to take home.The Turkish people are very warm and hospitable people,despite not being fluent in English..Whilst in Istanbul dont forget to visit the Spice Bazaar where you can buy lemon tea,a cure recommended for coughs and colds ,by the Turkish people .I am definitely considering a visit to Turkey again.

East meets West. The main historic sites are stunning and well worthwhile the visit. Give time for each as there is much to see. There are long queues, so buy the Museum passport for 3 or 5 days that allows you walk straight in without queuing - brilliant and good value.

No Regret to be here. There are so many monuments where one can learn and feel history and culture of Istanbul rather than Turkey.
Well recommended to visit once a life time!

Mecca for History. Istanbul is the # 1 visited cities for tourism. East does meet the west here. Such a cool area of the world. 3 bodies of water, 2 continents, 2 major religions that ruled this city and the food is amazing. English could be a struggle at times here but signs are clear.

museums are excellent.. I like everything dislike nothing is a magig old city.I did feel save and again pelople are always trying to help and languages are not a problem I speak spanish and by my surprise that was not a problem found plenty turkish people able to comunicate in my language bello.

Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia, Dervish Lodge and Topkapi. All of these sites were great! Beware of the guys selling rugs (very aggressive!). The restaurants that are off the beaten path are better and there is no bait and switch with theprices.

Fascinating and historic. We had a guide for the duration of our stay and we where overwhelmed at the historyI also did a culinary walk through the old city which was fascinating behind the scene experience . Culinary walks Istanbul with Semma E as my guide
Sulanahmet. Blue Mosque, Aya Sofia and Topkapi are absolutely stunning. Surroundings also very smart compared to our last visit 4 decades ago!

All the big sights. The Blue Mosque and the Haghia Sofia are the sights that everyone goes to Istanbul to see, both are well worth a visit and you will not be disappointed but the queues can sometimes seem never ending best to get there early before they start to build up at the Hagia Sophia guides come along the line offering their services and they fast track you into museum well worth the 30TL pp we paid as the information they gave us we would never have known otherwise even with a guide book, you can also hire a headset but you can't ask that a question like you can a person and they fast tracked us into the musueum so no hanging around. also worth going to is the Basilica Cistern, just opposite Suleymaniye Mosque just on the hill away from the other attractions.The Topkapi Palace also has long queue but these move quite fast, allow a full day here to get the best out of the attraction.

A great City with history. We have travelled many big cities in the world specially in Europe & USA but Istanbul is one of the best. A walk from Taksim Square to Karakoy tram stop which is a pretty much straight road is a must which will give you the opportunity to see & feel the real Istanbul with different old buildings, shops, bars, & restaurants. You will walk through the street Istiklal Caddess which is the backbone of the Beyoglu area. Galata tower will also be on the same path & it's about half an hour walk with very slow pace. Blue mosque,Hagia Sophia museum & Topkapi palace all main three attractions are next to each other located very close from Sultanahmet tram stop. Grand Bazaar is only two tram stops away which is Beyazit & spice Bazar also on the same tram line next to Eminonu tram stop. Tram is the best way to get round the city because you will not be stuck in horrendous traffic; it's dam cheap costs around 65 pence per journey with Istanbul card. Don't even think to hire a car which you will regret because the city is gridlock & I gave up my plan as a result.
Don't miss. Istanbul is amazing. Spend at least 3 days to get the sites and enjoy the food. Avoid expensive restaurants. They are tourist traps.
great. l lıked istanbul it is everythıng ok l dont thınk bad somethıngthey should go taksım istiklal street and old city they should not forget bosphorus

Awesome!. Area was too crowded but it can be managed. Better that you go early in the mornig so you have plenty of time to see the places especially as the museum closes at 4.30 pm. We enjoy spice & grand bazaar! When buying i advise that you use turkish lira instead of euro or dollar. It's a lot more cheaper trust me. ;) You should be smart enough when when it comes to bargaining as they are giving high prices on each item.

wonderful place for a walk. We came in spring, so lots of tulips blossoming, nice walking area, enjoying every corner of this old city. Just be careful there is trolley train passing by every 5 mins, very close by .
Beautiful. I loved everything about it. They were so quaint. The tiles in the mosques were beautiful. The Cisterns were really really pretty, even though it was dark underneath.

Historic Areas of Istanbul - 5 Stars. We went through the Historic Areas of Istanbul and major attractions nearby includes Haggia Sophia, Tokapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Grand Baazar and so on. Overall: 5 Stars

Ancient meets Ancient. There are so many sites to choose from and from different cultures. Most of the sites are world class historical sites and some are built on a colossal scale.The downside is crowds and queuing, Topkapi palace especially.

Sultanahmed Square is Fantastic. Sultanahmed Square has the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. The square is fun to just sit and watch people. The Big Bus starts there and the shops are great places to eat or have coffee. It is close to the Topkapi Palace and the Gulhane Park.

Beutiful area. A walk along Sultanamet is very interesting. A line of restaurants serving different cuisine. Shops selling local handicrafts. Visiting the tombs of Ottoman kings , going for hamam at the oldest hamam spa of Turkey.
Istanbul with friends. Like the town,historic areas, nice food, Bosphor tour with boat, night clubbing, dislike the crowd at the spice bazar

Beware of a lot of traders trying to fleece tourists off. Be careful of a lot of traders who will tell you something is one price but triples it when you are about to pay especially if it is something you cannot return eg food. One trader charged me five times the price of a kebab and there is nothing I can do because I have eaten it. Best thing is to insist of paying before you eat and demand take away.

Walk everywhere. To see the best of Istanbul walk and use the tram system. The colours, noise and smells are magical. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market both need to be visited - just be hardened to the constant approaches for you to buy something. However if you do barter hard...there are some great bargains to be had.

Must see point in Istanbul. Just like when you travel in Turkey, Istanbul is a must see point. When you travel in Istanbul, this area is a MUST see point as well. It's not a long way to walk, so it's very easy just walk there to visit Museums, Churches, Mosques, shopping mall, etc. etc. A through ticket is highly recommanded. Also you can try the BIG BUS for easy to visit different hot points in Istanbul.

Walking through history. Easy to walk to all the historical sites in Sultanahmet, lots to see, eat, snack on. It was crowded on the weekend with lines at most attractions. It is all worth seeing, and the cost isn't too high. I enjoyed the Basilica Cistern and the Archeology museum with the Alexander sarcophagi. The museum is under renovation but still is a beautiful place to spend an afternoon. Be sure to try the simit, a sesame covered ring baked crisp on the outside and tender on the inside....addicting.

Impressive. Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi palace are all adjacent - avoid visiting at weekends - mobbed! Mosaic museum really worthwhile and well-presented. Yerebetan cistern well worth a visit. You'll need the best part of a day to get round the Topkapi palace. The displays of flowers everywhere we went were absolutely stunning - spring is definitely the best time to go.Worthwhile considering a museum pass (NB not valid for all museums - check the list.Walking from the Galata Bridge to the Galata Tower is quite a climb - you'll need a beer at the end! Tour of the Bosphorous/Golden Horn was a bit disappointing - very little historic detail from the guide so take a book with you. Our tour included a cable-car ride up to the Pierre Loti viewpoint, worthwhile, but we could have passed on the extensive lecture on the intricacies of Islamic headstones during the walk down through the cemetery.

Topkapi palace. It'd be advisable to get to Topkapi palace early in the morning around 9am if you want to fully explore and admire the home of many Sultans and Sultanas. There is so much to see and learn from that you can't simply breeze past the artifacts that tell history of centuries. You have to spend reasonable time to absorb the history with true feelings. The Topkapi simply is a special historical spot that will continue to attract tourists all across the world for centuries to come.

partially closed. The paintings are amazing considering the period to which they belong to. The place is under restoration and was open only partially, but we still had to pay the full entry ticket price!

If you can ever get to Istanbul then do!g. The historic attractions of Istanbul are varied - mosques, palaces, basilican cistern, grand and spice bazaars - and are all within easy walking distance of one another.On our first afternoon we went to the Hagia Sofia, Cistern and Grand Bazaar; the next day we ventured over the water (walking) to the shops around Taksim square, then went to the Spice Bazaar, lunch and a boat trip on the Bosphorus (2 hrs, 10 TL each). On our last morning we went to the Blue Mosque and the Topkapi Palace, lunch again and then back to englandA brilliant few days - do try to stay in the city - its really quiet and pleasant.

So much history in a small area. The historic area is large compared to other cities yet very manageable on foot. The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia are divided by a very attractive outdoor space with fountain and flower beds and the option to wander and relax. However, in the main part of the day it is too crowded. Go at 9am or 4pm to enjoy it. The queues for the sites are very long from 11 till 3 so go either side or go with a walking tour. So much fascinating history. The grand bazaar was a bit overwhelming but worth a visit. The Basilica Cistern was fascinating. When wanting a break, head downhill a little to gulhane park. Beautiful and restful.

Amazing attractions but watch your surroundings.. The Cisterne, Hagia Sofia, and Blue Mosque are all in the same area and are easily accessible by public transportation (dark blue line). Make sure you see all of them. If you go early you have a high possibility of missing the tour buses who arrive in the early afternoon (around 1100). Just be careful when moving from one attraction to the other as people will talk to you, ask you to visit their shop, and tell you that you are the most beautiful women in the world. Just hold your ground and keep walking to the next attraction.

stay here. I fyou want to save time and walk to all the historic areas stay in the old town area. I especially recommend The Blue House. Great view of the Blue Mosque and convenient to everything you want to see in the heart of historic Istanbul by foot.

Great walk. All are very close to each other, food its amazing, lots of olives that I love!!! Small Bazaar next to blue mask its nice, but the lare one its huge and you will get lost in it... you really have to bargain to get good prices....

Best use of a six hour layover ever!. Using Delightful Istanbul Tours ( www.delightist.com ) to visit the Sultanahmet and Hagia Sopia was clearly one of the best decisions we could have made. Their name is most appropriate. Emre was a "delightful guide". He picked us up at the airport and we went directly to the Blue Mosque. In our case we knew that during the evening hours it would be closed, but that should not stop anyone from going. Both the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque were spectacular and lit beautifully at night. Emre was profoundly knowledgeable and his English is terrific. After touring we went for dinner on Kumkapi Street: a fantastic street filled with restaurants and musicians. Very popular with locals. The fresh fish was AMAZING. The starters were also delicious. After dinner we returned to the airport all with enough time to catch our flight. We felt badly for all those people who spent the entire layover at the airport. We actually felt energized by the entire experience (even with having been on the first flight for almost 13 hours) We loved our mini excursion to Istanbul and know that we would be delighted to return. Emre created such a hospitable atmosphere, one where we never felt rushed but it was clear he kept his on the clock so we could be stress free.

Absolute must see/ must do. Enjoy the people, colours, noise and buildings walking around in this great area. Ignore the guys who want to sell you all kind of things, laugh friendly and they will leave you alone.

do it all!. don't miss the underground cistern and the view from the Galata Tower.The mosques are magnificent but expect queues at weekends.Very busy expect high volumes of people everywhere.Do not purchase in Grand Bazaar go to outside markets higher up prices much less.

Sultanahmet, Istanbul, Turkey. Entire area has a lot of history. Beautiful mosques, great restaurants, beautiful fountains, many flowers. Great area, easy to walk and take in all the sights, trams are convenient and easy to take.

Istanbul Revisited. Revisited Istanbul after a 15-year hiatus.Nothing to dislike if one retains and maintains a sense of discovery and adventure. The Sumahan on the Water Hotel was a unique and most welcome refuge on the Asiatic side of the Bosphorus. The historic/Byzantine sites on the busy European side were amazing, especially upon venturing far off the beaten track. You don't really get to know the city until you get lost walking in it.The tram, funicular and Metro systems permit easy travel to more distant points without getting jammed in the incredible traffic on the streets. Terrific local seafood restaurants along Bosphorus on Asian side.Ataturk airport clean, safe and welcoming to both, arriving and departing passengers. Food at the airport was amazing in selection and quality. Reassurance: Bathrooms, whether in hotels, airports, gas stations on the highway or public ( 1 TL per use) were exceptionally clean and well maintained in Istanbul and well beyond in Cappadocia and beyond.Tourism is a substantial contributor to Turkey's GDP, with an expected 30-million visitors this year. I daresay they are well prepared.
Great City, WOW. Visit all the HOT SPOTS, like the Blue Moskee and the Hagha Sofia, all great. Walking is the best way to see the City, so take good shoes!
Great restoring works. Great restoring works continues, also the gardens are taken good care of. It was easy to visit the museums, because almost everything was explained also in English.

Spice Market & Grand Bazaar. Easy to take Metro from Taxsim Square and it is cost only 1 TL.get off the Metro (ask for assistance if not sure) and walk across to Spice Market and as you walk through, eventually you will reach The Grand Bazaar.

Wonderfull mixed of cultures. The Ottomanians mosque are huge but not so historical important. The greatest & most saced piece of the city is Hagia Sophia , wich originally belong to the Byzantine ages.
safe and easy. Sultanahmet is full of history, safe, and easy to navigate. Plan time to just wander and experience te city.

Hagia Sophia. This time of the year is much more crowded than in the summer, but weather is more welcoming. It looks like the price has double in 7 years for the security and renovations. Suggest moving through the Hagia Sophia, backwards to avoid the tour bus tourists

Well kept Historical Buildings. This historic district is just wonderful with the buildings. I stayed 2 minutes walk from the Blue Mosque and enjoyed every moment of it. The Tulips flowers were impeccable and the area is always kept clean.Some things that irked me:People are constantly trying to see travel books and it can get bothersome at times. I was surprised though at how little to no English was spoken being that area is so heavily visited by tourists.Please beware of people who strike up conversations only to get you to go to a restaurant or buy some carpets. I had two bad experiences with tax drivers. They charged my 20 TL from hotel to the ferry which was literally 4 minutes driving. They refused to turn on the billing monitor. Surprisingly, none of the drivers spoke English and most were ready to fight with you if you showed them your displeasure.If I asked a question, I generally found that people were misleading, pointing you in directions just to get you off their backs. Unless you speak Turkish, be prepared for a run around.Great history but the feeling that people are out for your money can take away the pleasure of such a beautiful place.
Nothing compares!. Turkish people are very friendly and there's a lot of lovely scenery : )Lots and lots of sightseeing available. It's like a piece of Eatern Europe with an oriental touch

Amazing sights with some fun. Strolling through the Historic Areas of Istanbul is a pleasure not to be missed. Around every corner there are amazing views of the Ayasofia and the Blue Mosque, we couldn't stop taking pictures. This part of the city is also very pretty and very walkable - some hills, but that is why you also have the views you do. Don't forget to take your sense of humor. Everyone you meet will be super friendly, very helpful, and have something to sell. Everyone wants to direct you to their carpet shop or restaurant, or book you on a boat or a tour. A firm, yet friendly no thank you always did the trick....just keep on walking. I never felt threatened, and many of these people helped us with directions, hailing taxis or translations. We started collecting our favorite lines. My personal favorite is still, "How many camels for your daughters?" lol
6 days in istanbul. people very friendly & helpful, flowers beautiful. all historic sites were very clean and well maintained
call to prayer. Just a fascinating place to visit, the mosques,palaces, the friendly people..worth a visit ..Take a scarf just incase you want to visit a mosque..And take a walk around the waterfront

Terry & Angela - Istanbul. Golden City hotel, good location close to all transport facilities, trams, metro and buses, city is easy to get around. All historic sites a must to see, and the Grand Bazaar is amazing you are not constantly pestered, vendors are all very polite. A really enjoyable break.

Shoes Off & Covers On. If you go to The Blue Mosque in the colder months remember to wear warm socks as everyone is required to remove their footwear (boots included) prior to entering the coolish Blue Mosque. Most women know to wear a head scarf (great reason to buy a nice one at The Grand Bazaar :-). However, I was surprised during our warm weather visit that I was required to cover every inch of my arms for which I was not prepared so I ended up being required to wear a plastic sheet over my shoulders.Those minor details aside - we were very glad for the opportunity to view the serenity of this almost cavernous place of worship - every inch of flooring covered with beautiful carpets and numerous exquisite examples of tile work on the walls & ceiling. We were allowed to stay and drink it all in for as long as we liked - taking numerous photos. We tourists were advised to avoid going to The Blue Mosque on Fridays around the noon hour as more of the faithful attend prayers then than any other time.
