Tourists are kept outside during scheduled prayer times although one can see people praying in the mosque outside those times as well.

An amazing city surrounded with historical artifact. The Blue Mosque, the Aya Sofya, Topaki Palace, the Archeological Museum and so much more. Easily accessible. Museum pass available for access to all sites of interest.

Walking distance everywhere. The historic areas is centered around Golden Horn, European side of Istanbul. There are tons of great tourist objects like Sultanahmet mosque, Aya Sophia, Obelisks, Grand Bazaar, Egyptian Bazaar, Suleymaniye Mosque, and many others.

must go. Blue Mesquite, Haya Sophia, Grand Bazaar, Cistern, among others, are a must go. If you are a shopping fan, take a look at stores with displayed prices before going to Grand Bazaar. If you like bargaining, this is the place to go. If not, it will be a hateful disaster.Food is not a highlight in Istambul. You can find the same food for different price ranges in the Sultanahmed area. Try the Turkish Delights and other sweet delicacies, but don't be cheap and buy the really good ones. The taste difference is huge.

Rest and Enjoy. I would honestly probably avoid the Hagia (Aya) Sophia and just sit and rest in the Blue Mosque. The Aya Sophia was so dark, and under contruction. There were few mosaics left -and you had to hunt to find them. We got to overhear a guide in the Blue Mosque who had great information on why the colors and tulips were featured.

Unforgettable trip. I liked the Great historic monuments even if most of them had a lot of interesting sections closed to public.I disliked the Overpriced entry fees and services,specially that all the monuments were undergoing renovations

Great Location, Perfect Hotel. I like food and historical place, I dislike seller style approaching on street while your walking, It is not professional way to stop tourist in middle of the road to upsell his trip or product. It is like forcing to buy their product.

We travel to see this.. One tram stop: Sultanahmet on tramway T1 Zeytinburnu - Kabatas line (navy blue) gets you to the historic area with its many sites. If you had one day in Istanbul or hours only on a layover, this would be your stop. Literally, buy a visa at the airport; get a metro card; take metro M1 Aksaray -Havalimani line (red) from IST (Havalimani) to Zeytinburnu metro stop. Jump on tramway T1 Zeytinburnu - Kabatas line (navy blue) to Sultanahment tram stop. (Since this second leg is a tram, bonus you get to see a good clip of the city. If return trip to airport is in evening you might get lucky as we did with a full moon. It was stunning.) Boom, you could see the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia & Topkapi Palace in one fell swoop. Who wouldn't do this? Easy. Total cost for excursion (roughly): visa 20 TL, metro card with 4 transfers total 14 TL, 3 sites mentioned above 50 TL (65 TL if include Harem at Palace, highly recommended). So roughly 100 TL gets you a great snapshot of Istanbul if you have a layover at IST. Total time: 7 hours if you stay on point. Can adjust time at sites accordingly. Folks? Really? Go. Do it.
Istanbul Sites. Loved the mosques, Hagia Sophia Museum and Topkapi Palace.Worth taking a half day organised tour if you are short of time.

Strolling downtown!. I liked the easy way you can go from one place to another, how easy is to let yourself get lost in those small streets and wander around with no problems at all!.People are very helpful, just be careful as you would be on any big city... and do not save on a Bosphorus boat!!..

Amazing history. I guess words can not express the amazing old attractions in this historical area of Istanbul. this area is a must see for any tourist, therefore, as expected it is crowded. The highlight were the cistern basilica, hagia Sophia, blue mosque and the topkapi palace. Expect to queue to get tickets if you did not buy them beforehand. For me I got the Museum Pass @85 TL and valid for 72 hours from your first museum visit which saved time and money. here are my quick pointers on the main attractions:- the Basilica Cistern, the ticket is 10TL and is not covered in Museum pass, However, dont be afraid from the long queue as the line moves quickly. while at the basilica look for the wishing column and the Medusa heads. If the weather is hot, as it was when we visited, this will be a good escape from the heat.- Hagia Sophia: This is an amazing place! you can clearly see the footprints of Christianity and Islam in this Church/Mosque turned into Museum now. while there don't miss the mosaics on the upper level. it is closed Mondays, visiting hours are 09.00 and 19.00, final entry being at 18.00. ticket 25 TL but included in the Museum pass.- Blue Mosque: no shorts are allowed for men. Women need to be well dressed as well. No entrance fee.- Topkapi Palace: visit the Hareem, and the State Treasury (weaponry display). Enjoy the amazing views of the Bosphorus from the Fourth Court. Topkapi ticket 25TL, Harem ticket is 15TL. Open from 9am to 6pm. Closed Tuesday. Interesting parts were the Harem and Treasury Sections with the Spoon Makers Diamond and Topkapı Dagger.
Mosques. Beautiful area. Away from recent protests and safe. A lot of people but that is expected. Great experience.
Blue mosque. Awesome but it is not blue ! Beware of touts they are persistant. In summer remember although it is hot they have clothing regulations so no shorts

Best Attractions. The sheer amount of history in the sights here is amazing! While I liked staying at a hotel slightly out of the tourist bustle, the historic area was a great place to visit over a couple days. The "big three" of the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, and the Topkapi Palace were each astounding in their own way. Each is a must-see for amazing architecture and history. Plus, the Basilica Cistern adds in ancient Roman history to complete the full span of Istanbul's glorious past. You will want to get out of this section to get a fuller perspective on the city (go to New Town too), but this is where the tourists congregate for good reason!

historic istanbul. loved the cistern basilica and hagia sophia, was a bit dissapointed by the topkapi palace. quite boring, being in long cues with shitloads of people slowly shuffling past juwelery and clothing....

Must See Blue Mosque and Hagit Sofia!. The Blue Mosque and Hagit Sofia are in the same square facing one another. We had a recommendation to tour the Sofia but were unable to due to time constraints. Our source said the you can spend the whole day in the Sofia and never get board. The Blue Mosque is a sight to see! It's like an alien starship landed on earth. It was breathtaking and foreboding - it appears larger than any building I have even seen.

istanbul is a fame of tales of all times. It is always a nice option to find someone who will show you the way as you like, at a reasonable pace, not with bunch of group with limited time. Therefore, make a favor for yourself, go to istanbul and let yourself lost in the beauties of this colorful city of sultans, dreams, tastes, colors and people.

Beautiful old town!. You can spend hours and days exploring this rich and colorful area of Istanbul. There are three main sections to explore uphill and downhill: the Grand Bazaar, Sultanahmet and the Golden Horn. Not to give anything away but it is well worth the trip to Istanbul. The sights were awesome and the people were so very friendly.I would go back to Istanbul without any hesitation.

My Favorite Destination. Totally Awesome!!A very walkable city with all the major sights centrally located. Amazing mix of cultures and cuisines. Wonderful people. Never felt uneasy anywhere in the city.Check out some of the small non-chain hotels near the Hagia Sophia or the Blue Mosque for an even better experience.

Istanbul full of historic sites. This area of Istanbul is without question the must see place to go to on your holiday to Istanbul. You will find places such as the Blue Mosque, The Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Irene, and several museums to name just a few of the amazing places to visit. You will be approached by people trying to tout for business, simply so no and most of them will leave you alone. Istanbul is full of history, get yourself a good guide book and do it alone, no need for a tour! It is very easy to navigate to all the historic sites and will leave you money to spend on other things. Enjoy!

Historic Sites in Istanbul. Istanbul has hundreds of historic sites that are worth visiting. Unless you will stay longer than a week, you will be missing out on the major sites, so it is better to do your research before you travel to Istanbul. You can check this article http://veryturkey.com/destination-info/istanbul/everything-about-istanbul which provides info on historic sites in different sections of Istanbul. It is better to choose a hotel in an area which is close to the majority of the sites that you will visit as traffic is a major problem in Istanbul.
Great city. Thoroughly enjoyed the city, interesting place and lots to se and do.i think i'll visit again and wish i'd stayed a little longer.
Istanbul is a Great City. I liked the sights in Istanbul even though it was cold and rainy. I felt very safe there. Rode the tram from Taksim square to old part of town and it was super.

History Lovers Paradise. The core historic area of old Istanbul is very compact and walkable. We hired a wonderful personal guide, Mehmet Raci (email: racielci@gmail.com). His vast knowledge of the sites brought the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and the other historical sites to life. If you have the time, you can was off your walking with a wonderful Turkish bath experience right outside the Hagia Sofia.

Wandering around the 'Old Town'. We visited Istanbul for the first time and stayed in the 'old town' area which meant it was very easy to walk to the various sights, such as the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, the Cisterns and the Topkapi Palace to name just a few. Plus we visited the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar, brilliant interesting places to see and buy many items, we bought wonderful apple tea, turkish delight in all flavours, baclava and many other goodies.The restaurants are excellent and the food is great.

Visit to Istanbul. We went there for a wedding. The sights although very nice were not the object of this holiday. This being my first time I was not prepared for the constant hassle of either come to my cafe, buy a carpet, buy a jacket, shine your shoes, weigh you and bus trip boat trip. I was just a nervous wreck when I got home. All we wanted was to be left alone to enjoy our walks until the wedding. We will never be back to Turkey
Historic mosques. Around the country, lots of places to see.. good connectivity by bus, train, tour boats. Suleymania mosque, hagia sophia, blue mosque, grand bazzar are few to point.
Fantastic!. Make sure you visit the old town and all atractions there. It is really nice overall and most attractions have a small cost but worth it

Don't miss out!. Honestly, it's breathtaking, don't you forget to visit the catacombs, and the food is delish, and the walks are amazing. Oh, and the sweets, and the small street, all in all Istanbul is filled with history and romance.

Many things to see. Historic areas of Istanbul are the most interesting historical areas in the world. Hagia Sofia, Golden Horn, old Hippodrome, Chora Church, the walls of Constantinople... There is so much history in one area. I am glad I visited.
Birthday Treat. Istanbul is certainly very very busy but it still was very impressive, from the historical old city to the buzzing district of Istikal, and the amazing waterfront location .
Wonderful. I'm pretty sure everyone who visits Istanbul will spend at least a day in this area. Topkapi, Ayasofya, Blue Mosque, Bascillica Cistern-- all great sites to see at Istanbul.
So much to see and do.. The Museum pass was a must if you intend to spend a few days. Lots of queuing avoided. Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque all spectacular.

Observe great history. Istanbul is a unique city in the world, have parts in Asia and Europe. Nice place to take awesome photos :)No point going to Istanbul without visiting all these historical areas!

Don`t Miss it !. Blue Mosque, AyaSofia and Topkapi are a must in Istabul.The entrance fees are:- Blue Mosque: free of charge (but donations for renovations are appreciated)- Ayasofia: 25 turkish lira (12,5$)- Topkapi: 40 turskish lira (20$)
beautiful. So amazing to see so much history in one place. The nooks and crannies are wonderful to explore, with a new treasure around every corner.

exciting and breathtaking beauty. Some very beautiful mosques, with an amazing assortment of people wandering through. Lovely flowers line the walks of the Mosques, palaces. Bowled over. I am from the northern part of India which is very rich in history and grand old buildings and am not usually impressed what I see in other countries. Amazing places. I visited istanbul for three days in march 2014...my best time was at this area...everything about it was gorgous..i started my visit early before they open and this is my advice to everyone..be there around 8.30am so u can get to all the places without waiting in long Qs..I started with the blue mosque..itsvery huge and beautiful inside out..then Aya sofia, thi is my favourit place out of all of them ..its such a spirtul place,you can feel all the religons there,u gonna like it no matter if u r a religous person or not..Then i went to topcapi palace which is one of the biggest palaces in istanbul..very rich with the blue tiles everywhere..u will be amazed with the sultans jewlleries and belongings lots of gold and gems..Take lots of pix for the view from the top of the palaceThis area is full of things that u have to see..u can spend a whole day if u r into historical places

Very interesting and exciting. I loved the two days I had spent in Istanbul. I stayed in Old Istanbul to take advantage of the nearby attractions. I went both on my own and also with Erol Savda as my tour guide. Erol was fantastic and very knowledgeable about the very interesting history of the city and Turkey. Highly recommended guide...

City of sultans. Amazing city!!! A must see in a lifetime. We spent 5 days with a group of friends and it was not enough. I am a history buff and could not get enough of it. Follow the crowd to Sultan Ahmed, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern and the Bazaar, do the usual touristic stuff. But do not forget to enjoy the city itself. There are great hangouts in Taksim, Ortakoy and Bebek. You can take a walk along Bosphorus and enjoy a nice cafe in Ortakoy or Bebek with a Bosphorus view. Taksim especially is amazing. We stayed really close to Taksim and the famous Istiklal street. With a little help from the locals at the hotel, we discovered couple of hidden rooftop bars in Taksim with a great view of the city. Although a bit expensive, Leb-i Derya Restaurant was amazing. Food was good, fusion bistro style, but the view beats it all. If you want to try local cousine, Zubeyir in Taksim is a good choice, 'Ocakbasi' style. Do not forget to try raki, may not be for everyone, but apparently goes good with the local mezes. If you want a more economical choice, you can always try the fast food places in Taksim Meydan. In general, the city is safe if you stick to the main roads. I would just watch my bags in crowded places, pickpocketing is common like in most of the touristic cities. I will definitely go back to Istanbul again. And I recommend it to everyone.

Fantastic city full of beautiful, historic places. Istanbul is a fantastic city. There is so much to see particularly in the old historic center where you can wonder around for day just gaping at the fantastic building and enjoying the general atmoshere. The people are kind, helpful and not at all pushy. We loved the food in general and of course the Turkish delight and baclavas are just wonderful. The restaurants are quite inexpensive and good. Don't bother getting a city bus tour which is expensive. The public transport system is good and cheap. Don't miss the boat cruise up the Bosphorus. It can get very cold in Istanbul so be prepared if you go durring wointer.

Highly recommended!. Istanbul is safe, not expensive and wonderful to visit. Here it goes my sightseeing quick suggestion:- Basilica Cistern- Blue Mosque - Hagia Sophia Museum - Topkapi Palace- Galata Tower- Egyptian Bazaar- Sultanahmet District

Istanbul Feb. 2014. Istanbul has been always a great place to visit due to its beauty and historical places. The city is clean, full of life and a great mixture between east and west.

historic istanbul. Visited most of the renowned mosques. Amazed at their unbelievable beauty. Market places were too overcrowded and my wife did not enjoy the shopping. WE EXPERIENCED SOME UNSAVOURY SCENES INVOLVING A EUROPEAN WOMAN HIGH ON DRUGS IN THE SIDE STREETS OF THE OLD TOWN IN BROAD DAY LIGHT.

Istanbul. Recently while on my way to East Africa, I decided to stop off and to spend 5 days in Istanbul, and boy am I glad I did. As an avid traveler and history buff, I have often wondered about Istanbul, but had never had the opportunity to visit the city prior to this trip. I had however, been fortunate enough to visit some pretty remarkable places in my lifetime, but I must say, now that I have had the chance to explore Istanbul, it ranks pretty close towards the top of my favorites!I fell in love with this great city, the people and their culture. There is just no other place like it, where for millennia, East has met West and cultures and civilizations have collided. From the Roman times and Constantinople, to the Byzantine Empire and then the Ottoman, there is just no place on earth quite like Istanbul.Having done a bit of research ahead of time, I opted to stay at The Hotel Sultania. Located on the European side of Istanbul and in the Old Town, it was ideally located near many of the major sites. The Topkapi Palace was just around the corner, while The Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia were but short walks away. All three of these are must sees and do not disappoint. I highly recommend purchasing your tickets to any of these attractions well in advance however, so as to avoid extremely long lines (it will save you hours!). Also keep in mind that The Blue Mosque closes for daily prayers and you will not be able to enter during those times. Furthermore, the museums rotate which days they are closed, so be sure and check if you only have a few days so that you know how to plan accordingly. Only in Mosques are you asked to wear something to cover your head, otherwise it is not expected of you. I chose to purchase one before I left the States (from World Market/Pier One of all places), but you can easily purchase one around Istanbul (which I also did since I found them to be beautiful) or the Mosque can provide you with something. Although I am not a religious person, I found that I loved waking up in the morning to the low hum and singing of the call to prayer and did not mind covering my head in their mosques; rather I was honored they would allow us to share in some of their most sacred sites. The Blue Mosque is gorgeous inside and out and The Hagia Sophia (which is now a museum), is as well. The architecture and history of both are stunning and I will never forget how beautiful a backdrop they made against the sky. If I had had more time or better weather, I would loved to have taken a book and just spent all day there between these two giants.I would also highly recommend taking a cruise down The Bosphorus Straight. It is beautiful and will help you to better take in the incredible skyline of the city and all it's expansive bridges, buildings and homes. It also helps you to appreciate the size of Istanbul and the fact that it does expand over 2 continents.Other favorites included The Mosque of Suleyman, The Spice Market, The Grand Bizarre, The Galata Tower( for it's amazing view) and The Cistern (a 6th century underground reservoir built with Roman columns) - an absolute must. The Cistern is one of the coolest things I have ever seen and is perhaps one of my favorite places anywhere.Take the time to explore the local culture and look in all the shops. My second day there I came across this carpet and silk shop about a block away from my hotel. The second time I wandered in, the owner and his assistant invited me for some Turkish coffee and home made tea, and we sat and talked for hours on end. Halfway through we were joined by his sweet German Shepherd (who liked to be held as though he were baby), the owner's father and another customer. It was like something out of a novel and when it came time for me to go, they sent me on my way, with a lovely silk scarf - for free.Part of my favorite thing about going to any new city, is the chance to learn about a new culture and I have always found that a great way to do that is through the local neighborhood restaurants. Luckily, right outside the Hotel Sultania, the streets are littered with quaint and very authentic feeling restaurants, where carpets cover the outdoor tabletops, beautiful and colored candle holders hang from the ceiling, cats wander by to say hello and music and dancing fill the streets. I love the food while I was there and tried to eat things that were mostly indigenous to the area and I loved it all. The restaurant immediately across the alley from the Hotel Sultania was very good and another down the walkway on the left was great as well. I believe it was called The Hotel Salute Pub. While I'm not sure if that is correct, it is well worth trying to find. I stumbled in there on New Year's Eve and ended up spending a better part of the evening with the guys that worked there, who were nothing but friendly and kind. They brought New Year's things for me to wear and noise makers to use and even included me in their dancing, which would randomly break out on the cobbled streets/alleys around the restaurant. It was some of the most spontaneous fun that I have ever had. If you can find this place, please be sure and stop by. You won't regret it.Lastly, I cannot say enough my hotel. The location is unbeatable and the staff are as friendly and helpful as you could ever hope to find. Serap, who works in customer service, went out of her way to see to it that my father and I had a great trip. She booked a great Whirling Dervish show for us, showed us around the city on my map, helped with spa reservations, always checked in on us and even surprised me with a Birthday cake and gift, our last day there. Our room attendant was the sweetest man and was very attentive and thoughtful. On New Year's he left a gift for us across the beds. The hotel restaurant Olive was great on many levels, not only for the food, but on New Year's Eve, they squeezed me in, even though they were solidly booked, so that I could watch the fireworks from the roof, gave me a glass of champagne, a hat and something to wear around my waste (a la belly dancer?). The whole hotel staff was nothing short of wonderful. And the rooms were amazing to boot. While they aren't large on size, they are beautifully appointed and are luxurious enough that you feel as though you have stepped back in time and into a great Turkish retreat equipped with beautiful art work, great lighting, comfortable lounges and stunning archways.Everything about Istanbul was a delight and I cannot recommend it enough. I always felt extremely safe and the people are some of the kindest and most generous I have ever met. The culture is so rich and the city historic, and the buildings and vistas are like no other. I hadn't been gone from Istanbul a week, when I already felt as though I missed it, however odd that may sound. If you ever have the opportunity, I highly suggest getting lost in Istanbul...

A live museum. Istambul is a live museum. Everywhere you walk you will find something to see. From roman remains to bizantine walls all over. Ottoman presence is very strong also. Just walk, lose yourself and enjoy.
Charm in the Old City. Excellent tram system for navigating around city to visit sites. Avoid using public bathrooms if possible. Not clean and they charge lire to use facilities.

Fascinating!. Istanbul has much more to offer than just the hippodrome, aya sofia, blue mosque and Topkapi Palace. I joined the Big Bus Hop-on-hop-off red and blue line tours. It was fascinating to see, hear and experience more of Istanbul than the tourist areas. What a wonderful city!

An amazing city of historical significance. My first trip to Istanbul and I love it...the views are amazing and Mosques so beautiful and abundient...the view of Marmara Sea fills the eyes with beauty with ships passing buy at all times....i will return when it is warmer...

Very friendly, clean yet enchanting (for westerners). For Westerners, Istanbul might seem to be a very far away strange place. Although it is, you'll be surprised how Weternized and modern it is. A wonderful place to visit. Istanbul is one of the most interesting places to visit. It has everything. Antiquity, shopping, food attractions, warm friendly people and a sense of safety when getting around. Comparing the Turkish lire a with other currencies it is a very cheap place to visit and shop. It is a walking city so getting around is very easy but if walking is difficult the tram is convenient and easily available.Turkish people are aware of the value of tourism and the benefit if tourists. It is fun to haggle but thinking of the value of the goods in the home currency one sees the true value of the goods. Souvenirs are for tourists however look at what the country is famous for. Turkey is famous for its leather goods. The shoes and bags are very fashionable and stylish and very cheap compare to leather goods elsewhere. Looks for shoes, bags, leather gloves, men's clothing is also very cheap and very stylish.Don't forget to take the local ferry boat and go to the Asian side. Things are even cheaper and the quality is excellent. If you intend to,buy a carpet do your research and shop around for as long as time permits.Shopping in the grand bazaar is great fun but don't forget all the little arcades and lanes that are in this area. The spice market is a must and a real treat is a mackerel sandwich on the harbour . 6tl makes it a very cheap lunch.The best Turkish bath is the authentic one and not one advertised through hotels. In the old town there is one that has been operating since 1505. The old town has over 700 hotels so there are lots to choose from. They are all very competitive. The old town also has great restaurants, and some which as hidden away where the locals eat. They are the best ones and you will find them by walking around the area.One trip to turkey is not enough to enjoy all that it has to offer.
marvellous day. the historical heritage of ottoman is great, monuments & turkish hospitality, facilities to acceed to topkapi palace & sultanahmet.

Mixed feeling. As much as I enjoy the stay at Istanbul, the old town area gives a mixed feeling.All great landmarks are located there, also we also enjoyed the dance, performance, and food there. For above points, this area should have been rated as 6 stars!However, this is a very touristic area. Most shops are tourists oriented.That means, over-price, not unique and great quality, souvenir loaded.Souvenirs are usually sold at higher price.Restaurants also provide more expensive food here.It is NOT an area to experience Istanbul life with real interaction with local people.My recommendation: Have your hotel outside this area. Do the shopping elsewhere. Just come here to immerse yourselves in those great heritage sites, instead of having all your Istanbul experience here.

Very interesting place. Worth the visit. Watch the taxis. Good visit. Impressive sights and stores. Make sure you tell the taxi driver that you will pay only so much before taking it. They are disgusting humans beings that prey upon tourists at the mosques, spice market and elsewhere. Favorite trick is to change the currency. 10 Turkish lire becomes 10 Euros. Expect screaming and crazy taxi driver. One cure is to drive right othe fron of the Hotel and have the bellman argue with the driver. Do not put any packages in the drivers trunk for this will hinder your exit. Also, do not talk, bump into or deal with shoe shines. A favorite trick they have is they drop their brush while walking in front, so you good naturally tell them and they will not leave you alone. I wish Turkey had Texas' gun laws.

Loads to see and do.. We suggest that you leave Aya Sophia & Blue Mosque to later in the trip so that you have some idea how to handle the initial bombardment you'll get from various guides and touts. Learning how to say 'no thanks' in Turkish also goes a long way as they will back off.
Magnificent heritage. Nothing not to like. Love everything we saw, visited and ate. The food was good and clean. Love the promaganade juice. The cats were fat, cute and clean.

Breathtaking and Magical Constantinople. As a Syrio-Lebanese, knowing the problems we are facing in our countries, Istanbul is the last place where we can actually experience an authentic Oriental-City lifestyle.The city in itself swallows you in its immensity and you become a part of the flow. You will feel like a Seagull flying free over the Bosphorus!Istanbul is very authentic, alive, magnificent and carries a majesty from its past glories.The attractions and historical sites are very concentrated which gives it alot of charm.The common transportation (Metro, Tramway, Ferry, ...) are rather modern and decent and make it easier to get to a point to another.My favorite sites were the Grand Bazar, the Spice Bazar and Hagia Sophia for they wake in me rushes i seek when I travel. As a history and archaeology passionate, i would totally advise taking a look at the Archaeology museum for you will find impressive and interesting artifactsI advise taking the Museum card so that you will avoid waiting in long queues and in some cases you will save some money.

fabulous. I liked to walk in the historic centre. It was like walking in the past. Istanbul is a unique city, where you can experience past and present, east and west at the same time. Love this City.... We arrived in Istanbul with the cruise ship Norwegian Jade as part of a two day stopover. The ship was moored just North of the historic district so a short tram ride over the bridge got us there very fast and very cheap. (3 Lira). The historic district was packed with one attraction after the next. We arrived at the Blue Mosque just in time for prayer where we watched the men washing their feet before praying. When the Imam then called for prayer all mosques were involved. As soon as Blue Mosque stopped, Hagia Sophia started and then the next started as soon as Hagia stopped. It was like a rounder song, very eery but wonderful. People in Istanbul were very friendly and we never felt threatened once. The Grand Bazaar was so big (25.000 stalls) it could not be done in a day, especially not when you responded to the stall holders calling you in. Every time we got suckered in, we got a tea. We loved the Elma Cai, the apple tea, and I must have drunk gallons. I developed a joy in the haggling and I got two pair of leather boots for my daughter for $75.00. I was sad when the cruise ship sailed away as I would have liked to spend a lot more time in this wonderful city.

Hotel Locations for the Historic Areas. Many wonder where to stay in Istanbul to have best access to the historic sites. Here are the thoughts from a frequent visitor.1. The big name hotels (Hyatt, Renaissance, Intercontinental, etc) are not near the main historic sites. They are either closer to the airport or to the business areas. If you are in Istanbul for tourism, do not stay in those hotels. They are too far away.2. The best areas to stay are near Sultanahmet or Sirkeci. You will find older or boutique hotels in those zones. Read the reviews and you will find one best suited for your needs. You do not need to spend much to have a great experience in Istanbul.3. There is so much competition (especially with all the internet reviewers) that the staff of a good hotel will do everything they can to make your stay enjoyable. If you can endure older buildings (with character!) you will have a wonderful time there.

Dear travelers, >>Hope this classified "top 3s" would be helpful for you:>>Sultan Ahmet district (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilic Cistern)>>Kabatash (Dolma Bahce Palace, Maiden Tower, Bosphosur tour)>>Taksim (Fish market, Pedestrian path, Galata tower)>>Shopping (Egypt market, Grand Bazaar, Malls "Civaher"/"Forum")>>Eating (Kebabs/Fish, Turkish delights, Fruits)>>Drink (Turkish tea, Fresh juits, Beer)>>Transportation (Tram, Funicular, Metro/Bus/Taxi)>>Other (Miniaturk, Sea of Marmara, Princess Islands)

sadberk hanim museum -totally amazing. Hanim means "lady", so this is Lady Sadberk's Mueseum in Sariyer. Archeologically it is outstanding! It has 4000 year old glass jars and an 8000 year old quirky pot from the Lakes Region. It is well set out and labelled in English around an amazing marble staircase. Plus the other side of the museum is magnificent ornate Ottoman / Turkish stuff including fantastic clothing, ceramics and a circumcision room! To get there we took the 25E bus Kabatas to Sariyer; wonderful coastal journey ...but not on a Sunday as the road was clogged with Istanbulites at Bosphorus eateries. Any other day is good. At 7Tl it is incredible value and one of the best museums I have seen in the world!

Fantastic!. You can spend hours and days exploring this rich and colorful area of Istanbul. There are three main sections to explore uphill and downhill: the Grand Bazaar, Sultanahmet and the Golden Horn. The best is to go on foot with a camera and a guidebook. There are sights not to miss: Haghia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Süleymaniye Mosque, Topkapi and the Basilica Cisterns. There are places to go for shopping like the Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market or the shopping area below the Blue Mosque. Cafés and restaurants are everywhere: give in for a cup of Turkish coffee with some Turkish delights and eat delicious Turkish food at any restaurants (the smaller ones are sometimes the best!). This is Istanbul, a city of life, of culture and of incredible beauty!

Price incl. massage is about 12 - 20 Euro only.

Dynamic and Vibrant, Steeped in History. We visited Istanbul in February and found the place considerably warmer than Cappadocia had been. It would be easy to discuss Istanbul in terms of the inventory of sites contained there. It is an impressive list. But to do so would neither draw an accurate picture nor do justice to the city. Istanbul, once the center of the world, bristles with mosque spires and minarets. While the inventory list would include vaunted and noteworthy sites such as the Blue Mosque, which sits next to the Hagia Sofia as though the two immense structures were locked in a stare down. They stand as two of the most beautiful buildings I've ever seen. Likewise, the Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, every place on our list, were stunningly impressive. But places of such historic import can burn out even the most intrepid traveller, bringing on what we called in Japan "Temple Fatigue." Istanbul has a remedy for that as well; either head across the Bosphorous or to Taksim Square and Istikial Street. We did, and we saw a city that comes out to play at 10 PM and parties until 4 AM. Jammed streets, thriving restaurants, night markets, we were tempted to take on the night and dance in the sunrise. We thought better of it and took a cab home, but we know what we COULD have done; maybe next time. In another lifetime, Istanbul was a walled city. Those walls now stand as a reminder of the days when Constantinople was the center of the world. (While in the Old City, find the pillar from which all distances in the empire were measured.) We took our days offset, one neck-deep in history, the next very much in the present. Our history days were just what the guide books said and then some, so I am not detailing them here. It was the the balance of the two that made our trip as wonderful as it was.

History at a glance. + hagia sophia (closed monday), blue mosque, the cisterns, topkapi palace (closed tuesdays)- go there early, it will be very crowded - strictly recommended to buy a museum pass or fast entrance, otherwise you are cueing in a long, long, long, long line

Wonderful city. This is the most interesting and exciting city I have seen. I would recommend everyone to visit at least once. The Blue Mosque, Hajia Sofia, Grand Bazaar, the little cafes overlooking the Bosphorus Bridge are all an absolute must. It is an extremely busy city as you'd expect, but there is something for everyone and the atmosphere is amazing. Visit the Blue Mosque after dark, its all lit up and they have running commentaries on a daily basis in all languages explaining the history. Just be careful of the hotel you stay in. Some are extremely basic (even though they look great online).

Interesting architecture and history. Blue Mosque - cover head (women) and no shoes allowed. Beautiful stained glass. Hagia Sophia - interesting history. Underground Cistern - cool! Topakia Palace - large grounds, guide recommended.

Too Much to see in One Day. You can see all of the major attractions in one day with Travel Shop Turkey. Book via Esta Travel Group in Cyprus who work with Travelshop Turkey and ALICIA HERNANDEZ to provide the best tours of the city and the best historical attractions.....
Wonderful exotic city. An old city inhabited by different peoples crammed with great buildings, some beautifully restored and some crumbling.More interesting than London Paris and Rome put together.

There's so much to learn here!. Liked- the amount of culture and stories that Turkey offers to a traveller. Disliked- Wish I'd brushed up my knowledge of the Turkish empires and their histories before I'd gone. Would've connected a lot more to the history of the country.
Feel set back in time. Atmosphere of the markets, the numerous street cafe's, the historic buildings, simply great to walk thru the narrow streets and forget about modernism

Historical Turkey. Istanbul is beautiful because of its masterpieces include the ancient Hippodrome of Constantine, the 6th-century Hagia Sophia and the 16th-century Süleymaniye Mosque, all now under threat from population pressure, industrial pollution and uncontrolled urbanization

Beautiful Istanbul. Amazing areas! Must see all around! It includes locations such as the Galata Bridge, the Seraglio Point where the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Yeni Mosque near the Galata Bridge, the Beyazıt Tower and the Süleymaniye Mosque.
amazing history. This city has so much history. Starting with greeks, then romans, then ottomans and now a wonderful modern metropolis!
stunning sights. The mosques were stunning, really breathtaking , the topkapi palace is a must see.A lot of places close together within walking distance of each other.lovely friendly place to visit
Hire a guide. We hired a guide to spend the day walking us through Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome and Topkapi Palace (including the Haram room). It was well worth it.

It's why you come to Istanbul. The Sultanahmet area of Istanbul is surprisingly compact and lets you see an incredible amount without a LOT of walking. Mosques, museums, bazaars and markets and shops, the cistern and hippodrome, restaurants all within blocks of each other.

Even those not interested in history can enjoy it. Historic areas of Istanbul are mainly located in Sultanahmet area. It include churches, mosques, museums, palaces & cisterns etc. No fees are required if you are visiting mosques or churches. But for all the other attractions you might have to pay fees. Palaces require higher fees followed by museums & other attractions.Thus, if you are not interested in history you may skip palaces & museums. That will be a complete waste for you. But still there is some magic in roaming around the historical areas & trying road side food. Definitely worth a visit.Taksim square is another important area & you should explore options to reach there by public transportation. Trams, boats, buses as well as cable cars/metros are excellent in Istanbul.

Amazing Istanbul. My daughter and I absolutely loved Istanbul - we both want to go back but this time spend more time there ... beautiful, clean, friendly, good value and of course amazing history / sites.

The Grand Bazzar. Not to be missed but watch your wallet/purse. The Bazzar is HUGE, unlike anything I had ever seen before. You can buy virtually anything there and you are expected to haggle on the price. Be prepared to spend almost an entire day there. And try not to get lost! There are so many entrances and exits it is mind boggling - and all under roof as well.

If You Have A Layover In Istanbul. Rather than sit at Ataturk Airport for hours - take advantage of Turkish Airlines complimentary TourIstanbul program. They pick you up and take you to some of the historic sites such as the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, and the Grand Bazaar. Enjoy some of this city's amazing sights and natural beauty in a few hours. They get you back to the airport in time to catch your next flight. More airlines should think of extras like this!

Majestic and rich history. All of it is just really beautiful. You get a new appreciation of the rich history of the Ottomans and their architecture. Don't miss the chance to visit as many sites as humanly possible. Definitely worth the time and you'll be forever enriched.

When you make it to Instanbul. Make it to the Historic sights. Try to do it without tours as it makes it much more enjoyable and less crowded. Will need a few days and some change as the street food and tea is perfect. Oh and have the fresh pressed Pomegranate Juice FOR SURE.

Nothing Llike I've seen before. I've travel the world extensively. And the historical side of Istanbul is so suprising. Every corner, even underneath the earth (underground monastry) theres something to see, maybe way too much too see! Its fantastic

Rich ancient history. Clean and all ancient monuments around. Rich cultural heritage
Turkish carpet shop keepers could be annoying, forcing you to buy carpets. My least favorite experience of the trip.

Must be experienced. It will take you some days to do the "musts" of Istanbul, and another lifetime to find the hidden gems. Start early in the morning to avoid the massive hords of tourists, especially the visitors from the cruise ships. Read a lot Before, and afterwards. The history is ever present and the past centuries were quite as multicultural as the present.

Istambul: You can feel the Romance in theAir. Advice stay in Sultanahmed district, all the historical places monuments are within walking distance. Character is similar to San Francisco, slopes, ocean cool breeze and good looking people all around
Guided. If you want to learn everything about this place, book a tour so you're guide will provide you with brilliant information.It's a history-rich place so you'd want to know the most of it.
Lots of interesting things to see in Sultanahmet.. Fantastic for cultural experiences but we were not expecting to see so many beggars in an otherwise surprisingly clean and sophisticated city.

Old City - Golden Horn Area. Highly recommend staying in the old city area around the Blue Mosque-Ava Sophia neighborhood. There are lots of small affordable hotels that are friendly and helpful. You can see the majority of sites by walking. The greatest distance we talked was 800 meters. Also for more distant sites, this area has a major tram stop that can take you to them as well as to-and-from the airport with only 1 transfer for a total price of 6 TL ($3 US at the time of this writing). Finally, great Turkish places to eat the are close by (see my other reviews on restaurants). We had a great experience here!

Loved Istanbul. Had 3 free days before starting a tour of Turkey. Stayed in the new Istanbul but it was easy to catch public transport over to old Istanbul. It was our first time here and absolutely love the history and the shopping in this city. Loved the Mosques and the sights of this wonderful city. People very friendly and helpful.
in love with Istanbul. it is a surprising town where old and upcoming live together...don't forget to take a look of the poorest and genuine areas. It teaches a lot!

It's an AWESOME SIGHTS for the EYES. Beautiful Art and Antiquities!!! It's great and a lot of everything is close so you can take your time and enjoy it. Really fascinating stuff and get the Museum Pass!!! It pays for itself after you go to 3 museums, and your going to go into more than 3 museums, and you don't have to wait in the Long Long lines;)
Not to be Missed. When you visit Istanbul for the first time you simply cannot not visit this part of the city. It's a must.

A history lovers feast!. An amazing collection of sights: the mosques, bazaars, palaces, museums and the Golden Horn and harbor, all accompanied by incredibly hospitable people, anxious to help visitors. Visited first in fall of 2011 and couldn't wait to get back this past October. Looking forward to another visit in the future.

What a history!. If you are in istanbul for any reason whether for a short break or long,you must absolutely reserve sometime to see some of the historical parts of this lively city.Walk through famous Sultanahmet Area where you are going to see the most important mosques and historical monuments,or go through Grand Bazaar where you will feel the history and find a lot of souveniers to buy,stroll down the streets of the Spice Market where you get pure smell of various kinds of spices...If you have more time,walk down to Eminönü area,cross the famous Galata Bridge on foot,or&and get some drinks at one of coffee shops under the Bridge,get on a boat fm Karaköy port to Kadıköy and explore the secret beauties of Anatolian side in Kadıköy where you can walk about 5 minutes fm the port to the Kadıköy market where you will see fantastic part of lively real food,fish,vegetables and fruit market.Many kinds of small and medium sizes of different restaurants and eateries&cafes are there to make service to you round o clock.You will really love this part...
very good feeling. historical places, bazars (Markets) and the traditional context of locations exist nice feeling and positive energy.

The "top" historical places you have to visit!. The "top" historical places you have to visit when in Istanbul are the Topkapei palace, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome, Taksim square - Beyoglou street, Galata tower, Grand Bazaar, Spice Market, Saint (Agia) Sophia, Chora Church, Sultanahmet, Basilica Cistern.

All Day bus pass and you have covered Istanbul. The best way to see all the historic places of Istanbul is to take the All Day bus pass. You can get in and out at any location. The traffic is crazy and hence the bus goes at tortoise speed. But this is the quickest way to get a tour of all the historic areas of Istanbul
The Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia. Fantastic monuments. i wish they didn't have all those wires and lights in the Blue Mosque. Hard to see the ceiling tiles

Quick stop in. We were on our way to Germany for vacation and due to a lay-over at Ataturk decided to use the opportunity to visit Sultanahmet. Being that we were limited in time we decided to visit only a select few sights. We had our sights set on the Blue Mosque, Haga Sofia, the Basilica Cisterns and the Mosaic Museum. Unfortunately, Haga Sofia and the Museum are closed on Monday's so we were only able to visit the other two. The entrance to the Cistern is a very unassuming building and one could easily pass by it without realizing its location. We obtained a travel map from a nearby hotel desk and found it quite helpful. There will be plenty of peddlers shoving overpriced travel books in the face and we recommend avoiding those at all costs. Entrance into the Cisterns is rather inexpensive at 10 Lire ($5 US). Upon entrance to the cistern we were amazed at how large it was. We bristled a bit at the touristic atmosphere that permeated the historic cavern but we still enjoyed it very much.At the conclusion of our tour of the Cistern we headed for the Blue Mosque. Important to note, It may seem rude but the young gentlemen that are seemingly just trying to be friendly and engage in conversation are not. They are attempting to get you to visit their carpet shop. One can be either rude and nasty or just ignore. We recommend the later. This I know is difficult for many and trust me, they know this. The crowds entering the Mosque were immense, loud and pushy. Please keep in mind that even though thousands of tourists pass through the Mosque each and every day it is a place of worship and reverent prayer for many. With that in mind PLEASE be respectful of that as I am sure you would want them to be respectful of your beliefs. We were actually embarrassed some of the actions of others visitors. As day slipped into dusk we found a quiet and quaint table at the café dervish which is located directly across from the Blue Mosque. Sipping Turkish Coffee and nibbling on fresh crepes while listening to the prayer callers from the Blue Mosque and Haga Sophia attempt to drown each other out is a must do. If one has a decent camera of respectable quality, waiting for a low light shot of the Mosque is well worth it as well.With our time quickly running out and with us not willing to wait another 90 minutes for the shuttle we attempted employ the services of a cab driver. IMPORTANT NOTE. When getting a cab attempt to acquire one as far away from the main square as possible. This may save you a significant amount of lire. Traffic during our return trip was at best, nightmarish. However our driver gave his very best to find the quickest route and cost ended up being 70 Turkish Lire ($35 US) that included a 10 TL tip. See you out on the trail and remember...don't be one of "those"John Eric
Tokapi palace..treasury and gardends well wort a visit. make sure you buy your tickets online and print them off for all attractions before u go ..will save a lot of queing

Dont miss these treasures. Dont be snagged by any of the overly friendly carpet, Bosphous sales force (guys) wondering around offering their guidence and a cup of tea so you will buy something from them. Refer to your guide books. The Historic sites can't be beat! Do not miss the Harem in Topkapi Palace and the Chora/Kariye Mosaic Museum it is a world treasure 12 TL cab ride from center. Dont let them rip you off) the Archeological Museum just next to the Topkapi Palace and of corse the real heart, Hagia Sophia. Buy a 3- day pass and see them all. No guides needed buy the head sets. A great infomation center is next to the tram between the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia
Where ISN'T historic in Istanbul?. Stick to the Sultanamet district and you can't go wrong. Try to get in the Spice Bazaar in addition. Stroll the Galata Bridge and watch the fishing action.

4 days In Istanbul...loads to do!. From the Blue Mosque to the bustling markets there is no shortage of interesting things to in Istanbul and in the main we found it friendly and safe.Watch out for the "shoe shine" scam though....a chap will drop a brush in front of you, as you pick it up and hand it back he will furiously polish your shoes whilst telling you stories of his sick son/ daughter before requesting a large payment for services rendered.If someone drops a brush in front of you, ignore it!
Sultanhmet. The Blue Mosque is breathtaking. The Top Capi is magnificent. The spice market is amazing.I really did not realise just how busy it would be. So many people.

Outstanding. The architecture is great, and the streets seem safe, even in the dark of evening. There are lots of good restaurants and many small hotels. The historical sites are plentiful and in great repair. Just watch out that you do not spend all your money...the jewelry and carpet stores are very plentiful in every street and bazaar and the owners very persuasive. Practice saying No thank You before you go!

We like to search for Madusa's head in the Cistern. Liked the restaurants, shops, historical sights, the convenient trams and subway. We really embrace the 19:00 Saturday Mass at St.Anthony Puda and LaFontana de trevi Italian restaurant very near Istiklal Caddesi St.Didn't like the stray dogs during my early morning runs, the cig smoke (not as bad as Rome), or the distance to the airport.Great city and make sure to take the new subway tunnel under the Bosphorus (Marmaray).

Istanbul has such a glorious history. The historical places are the most sought-after attractions in Istanbul. Among these places the Topkapei palace, the Blue Mosque and the Hippodrome are my most favorite ones.The sacred relics at the Topkapei get etched in your memory and you can't help but start weeping if you are a Muslim. especially

Amazing!. I really enjoyed every minute I spent in the historic district of Istanbul. It's walker-friendly, and people were friendly. In addition, it's easy to walk to other sites as well. Don't eat in the historic area. Instead, walk a few blocks to savor fine local cuisine.

The bazaars and markets. We spent at least 2 hours touring the main bazaar by the mosques and saw and smelled the delights of spices and fruits, the glitter of the gold shops, a complete canoply of clothes and materials of all kinds. This must be the market of all markets. We were invited by many of the trades people to visit the inside of their establishments in a very polite way and we made many friends when we bought food, them inviting us to try things before buying. A truly fantastic atmosphere and although I have been to Istanbul previously I don't think I have seen so many people of all races and colours all mixing in with the pageantry of the location. Surely this is a tourist must!
Spice market a must!. Grand Bazaar is popular with tourists but if you only have time for one, the Spice Market is the best!

A lot to see in a confined area. What I liked the most about the historic district is that you can spend an entire day in the area, see multiple historical sites and travel less than a mile. The square is nice and full of life. I met people from Taiwan, Iran, Australia, Bulgaria and several other countries in the day I spent in this area. It was great to see people from so many different walks of life in one place with a common purpose. Very interesting. Not a boring moment.
"amazing istanbul". liked everything!!! the people were awesome. when asked very helpful. most spoke english. The mosques were breath taking.
Beautiful. Really enjoyed staying in and walking through the old city and visiting historical places, was worried about weather in November but it was great.
Loved it. Loved everything about Istanbul, I will certainly make another trip to enjoy their sweets, roads, people, culture, history and much more...Just loved it sooooooooo much.

Abundant views and history. The only problem we had was not enough time to see and explore everything. The Blue Mosque, Haggia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, the Hippodrome, the Bazaar and Spice Market also other places we just didn't have time to visit. Each one interesting and visually stunning. The city is hustle and bustle with many friendly faces. Thousands of years of history but only a couple of days to see it all. It was really neat and I enjoyed myself immensely.

Aya Sofya is a monument for tolerance & peace. what struck me the most is how tolerant were the Ottomans who didnt destroy the Christian relics at the site when they starting using it as a mosque . really impressive

Amazing. Blue Mosque, Yeni Cami, Spice Bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, topkapi palace are all amazing places, and it is quite surprising to have all these places stones throw apart from one another!

History of the highest quality. If you are in your mature years I think one tends to be interested in History and historical areas a bit more than you did in your teens. Istanbul's historical areas are second to none and it's been the location of many historical events through thousands of years. Istanbul is a must for you travelers out there.

Sofia, Topkapi Palace and Sultanahmet are stunning!. I really enjoyed the whole historical heritage of Istanbul and spent a lovely time discovering the City centre of Historic Istanbul.Don't forget to take a Muze kart *(Museum access card) which costs 85 Lira but grants you free entrance to 6-8 historical places like Sofia Cathedral, Topkapi Palace + Harem, Archeology Museum etc. that way you avoid queues at Tickets office and save a LOT of money :)

Prepare to be blown away.. Our 3 day stay at the Hotel Kybele in the old city allowed us to walk to the Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque, Hippodrome area, Cistern Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar.Each one has its unique history. We had a guide that we had hired over the internet for Ephesus, and arranged for him to come to Istanbul. He has been in the business for a long time, and is also a university history professor. Excellent English. We found that with a guide (there were two couples of us to share costs) we could avoid very long lines of tourists at most attractions. And, believe me, we got a lot more information. (asiltuncer@hotmail.com) Asil preferred to use public transporation - the tram - and a public tour boat for the Bosphorus to save on costs. Worked fine. l had expected the Grand Bazaar to be somewhat like the medinas in Casablanca and Marrakesh that I had visited years ago, but it was nothing of the kind. Wide lanes, permanently roofed, with rather modern shops. We had three days in Istanbul, though had also almost a full day earlier when we got on a cruise ship out of Istanbul and return. I think one can cram in everything to see in three days.

In addition to the top 25. The Mihrimah Mosque near the Edirne gate, the Zeyrek Mosque, the Sehzade Mosque are all fantastic. They Zeyrekhane resturant served delicious food and provided a fantastic view of the city.
Worth the Visit. So much to see here and you will certainly need a number of days to do it justice. Good tourist sights and wonderful restaurants. I think it is best not to go in the summer.

A City Steeped in History. We visited in late October when the historic sites were busy but not excessively so. Also the weather was warm but not hot: so just right for sightseeing. Sites in Istanbul are well run, scrupulously clean and well presented. All in all the historic sites are fabulous and exceeded our expectations.

Walk don't drive!. The main sites are close together and as the streets are very narrow and crowded with all sorts of traffic it is easy to walk everywhere.
We took 2 guided walking tours and they made the history of this fascinating city so interesting.

Improving year by year. Less hassle from hawkers than when I previously visited, better transport and more attention to amenities like toilets and pavements. And still wonderous TUrkey at it's best. Well done Istanbul!

Even more beautiful than I thought!. This is a beautiful area of Istanbul - great to see the history behind the buildings facades, the short streets and little alleyways. Beaufitul city, with lovely people!

What a pleasant surprise, a lovely city. Liked the ease of getting about the city, we used taxis but were also able to walk, use metro or tram, which we were told were very easy.We decided to buy the 85 TL ticket which gives you 72 hours to visit the main museums including Topkapi Palace and harem, Ayia Sophia and others., we did not manage to visit any others but it did allow us to go to the front of the queue avoiding queues which could save 30 mins or more.Also enjoyed the Blue Mosque which should be visited early in the morning to avoid both queues and prayers. Friday mornings and other times during the day are closed for prayers, best to check before you intend to visit. Some people queued for considerable time to then find the mosque closing.

Take the time and stay here. This is a wonderful place. So many cultures and religions have roots here. I am always amazed that there are so many historical places within walking distance from each other. Grand Bazaar is always a two day trip for me

In and Around Istanbul. What an amazing experience the people the culture the shopping and more importantly the architecture. The history of this city from The Blue Mosque to the palaces, the other mosques offers a journey and experience sitting between a city balancing on what can almost seem third world at times to highly sophisticated.We did harbour trips went to the Prince Islands,did a ten day tour saw so many places and loved it all.

UNESCO experience. Enjoy the well know tourist attractions and the spectacular no less spectacular ordinary buildings around historic Istanbul. Once you get the hang of things you can have a confident walk enjoying the history and architecture. Many people will try and sell you things or give you things for "free." Unfortunately this is usually a scam and overpayment will be demanded perhaps in an intimidating way - just keep walking and you will be left alone to enjoy your day.

Albatros great location great staff. Albatros Hotel is located close to The Blue Mosque,The Haggia Sophia and The Cistern.The management and staff are brilliant, and helpfull with all matters from local travel including throughout Turkey. The rooms are great, the food is excellent and the rooftop view is outstanding.Great place Great people.
Sultanhamet jewels. Do not miss the Topkapi Museum and you will need 4-5 hours to see it. Makes sure you visit the Harem on a combined ticket - and the audio tours are well worth the money.
Don't Miss the Grand Bazaar. I have been to Istanbul many times and I lived there for a year. I never get tired of visiting the Grand Bazaar and Sultanahmet. Not to be missed.

wear comfy shoes. What's not to like....historic buildings, bustling markets, Turkish coffee, interesting eats...and don't miss the Cistern. walk, walk, walk...but take care the pavements are shocking!.
All historical sights. This city has so much to offer - would definitely recommend that one goes on a tour with a guide so that you can be fully informed of the history
As it should be!. The historic areas were really nice. It's nice to walk around this part of the city. It's much nicer than the new city.
Great Historic sites to see.. We loved the Blue Mosque, which is free and also like the Agia Sophia and Topkapi Palace and we visited another palace. All were well worth visiting.

Have a guide. This area was so amazing. We had a guide for the first day of our 7 day stay. She set us up for a generalized understanding of the unbelievable history of the whole area. We self guided ourselves for the rest of the week, and visited many small churches and museums. We got our guide through SRM Travel in Istanbul.

Great Architecture. Just take a stroll in the old town and you will stumble upon a historic place every nook and corner. The architecture is definitely something that you will keep you interested and also the variety that the place has to offer.
Dolmapahshe Palace. Great historic adventure, they give you great guide tour and you can see the Ottomans empire in close way, the gardens great locations for priceless photos

4 days in Istanbul. This is what we squeezed into a 4 day trip, managed to cover most of the must see attractions without feeling rushed:1) Spice and Grand Bazaar and the general market shopping area. Fabulous, bustling and busy, lots of interesting food to try.2) Topkapi palace and harem, half to full day recommended.3) The mighty walls of Constantinople. Kept out invaders and barbarians for the best part of 1000 years. Quite near the Chora church so visit both at the same time.4) Basilica Cistern.5) Suleiman and Blue mosques. Although the Suleiman mosque is a longer walk away, its a more peaceful and much less crowded experience compared to the blue mosque.6) Taksim square and the main shopping street.7) Galata tower8) Bosphorus cruise9) Hagia Sophia10) Chora Church. A beautiful, pretty Byzantine church.11) The old city, wandering around the streets for hours.Really enjoyed our trip, the people of Turkey are friendly and helpful.

A walk through history. You can't not like this place. As you enter the hippodrome, you have the obelisks right in front of you. The majestic Blue Mosque grabs your attention to the left. Walking through the mosque, you will see Hagia Sofia and then just behind that, is the amazing Topkapi Palace.

A magnificent city vast in it's history.. I could not have imagined when I flew to Turkey what a grand spectacular city was awaiting me. Istanbul is full of color and historical places to visit. We stayed in the Sultanahmet district in a quaint hotel. We were able to walk to all the venues we had in mind. The Tokapaki Palace, the Aya sofya, the Blue Mosque with six beautiful minarets, The Grand Bazaar, and the Ancient aqueducts. Too many places to mention I guarantee you will have a wonderful journey thru time in Istanbul.

For history lovers. It is very magical place.. Everyone who visits istanbul must visit there and feel the history ... Amazing but should be careful about pickpockets :( also after evening women should not walk alone in quiet neighbourhoods..

Istanbul-a city where atmosphere reigns supreme!. Beautiful. Historical. Friendly. Interesting. A must-see for any world traveler.This was the first time our family ages from 20's to 70's had visited Istanbul. We truly enjoyed everyday we spent in this vibrant city! As our trip was in September, there were no lines to deal with and the weather was perfect.We pre-arranged from the States a private walking tour of the Old City guided by a very knowledgeable and personable young lady from a local tourist agency. She clearly loves her city and the history that Istanbul is embodied in. She went above and beyond her responsibilities to us as her clients. She spent a great deal of time answering our many questions regarding the Aya Sophia, the Blue Mosque, Topkaki Palace, Covered Market, Spice Market, etc...We wanted to absorb the local culture as well and when our tour ended, she was able to help us see where the locals live their everyday lives. We gained a much greater understanding of the people and culture there as a result of her kindness.We had a family of six adults, one senior included. I think Topkaki Palace was worth our time, however, it might prove to be a bit long for those with young children or anyone who has a difficult time walking uphill or on inclines. To best prepare for walking in Istanbul, wear good walking shoes. If traveling with young children, older folks or those who have difficulty in walking, pre-arrange for a wheelchair, stroller, etc to make the trip easier and more enjoyable for everyone. Istanbul has many hills, inclines, cobblestone roads, etc that may prove to be a bit more challenging for some. However, these challenges can be accommodated for by planning ahead prior to arrival in the city.Each place we went, I would recommend to any person or family visiting Istanbul, as each venue is a window to peer through to gain a better understanding of what makes this city what it is today.
Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia & Topkapi Palace. The most popular historic sites are within walking distance of each other. Not sure paying for a guide or headset are necessary.

Great atmoshere and superb photos. Sultanahmet is a lovely district of Istanbul: pittoresque, colorful, great street scenes, plenty of good restaurants and coffee houses. The great attractions like Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi are there and others like the Grand Basar are within easy walking distance. Probably the best area to stay when visiting Istanbul.

Culture meets Faith at this beautiful place.. It was a chilly, rainy, day when we visited Haga Sophia, and as everyone has noted, the lines are crazy long. But, Haga Sophia is as beautiful as it is crowded. Tourists from all backgrounds, from all over the world, visited. They all understood the historic and cultural importance of this beautiful living museum/mosque. If you are traveling to Istanbul, this is arguably the most important site to visit, and it shares scenery with the equally beautiful Blue Mosque. Since it was Friday, the Mosque was closed to visitors until late afternoon, so we were unable to go inside, but that just gives us one more reason to go back!What a beautiful, crowded (over 14 million people) city!

Great place to visit. Istanbul is a very nice city with a great atmosphere to spend hours walking around. The historic area is pretty safe and you do not need to worry about not knowing the language if even though Turkish cannot speak English properly, but they are willing to help and communicate.
An amazing city. This was my first visit to Istanbul and I was blown away by the history, beauty and friendliness of the people. I highly recommend a visit to Turkey and Istanbul in particular.

Underground Cistern. This is a must see if you are in Istanbul, take a walk through down to see the sideways head of medusa and the upside down head of medusa. Just to see the Goldfish is worth the visit! Amazing that they built this to supply water to the Palace.

The Old City is Istanbul. The Old City, including, inter alia, Sirkeci and Sultanahmet is a truly amazing place to visit. It is replete with history, and beautiful and amazing sites. For those who are better, more organized, travelers than I, reading up on Istanbul's history prior to the visit or concurrently with it would have, I am certain, added a dimension to my visit. I had initially decided to take it easy, and not visit too many sites in too short a period, and so I limited it to two sites a day which I would very highly recommend to readers (if any) of this review, although I know that many people's visits are limited in duration and many tourists would prefer to see everything possible in an unreasonably short amount of time. The choice of two sites/day gave me the option to extend or shorten a given visit to a site. The time left was used to walk around "aimlessly", seeing life as it is in Istanbul, not necessarily tourist oriented. Stopping off for cups of Turkish coffee, and sometimes glasses of beer gave the whole experience an aura of being totally unpressured. What I didn't see, I didn't see, and I don't regret it but hope to come back for another visit in the future to make up some of the things I missed. I chose a hotel in the Old City, and do not regret it. In my short visit to the New City, I realized that I was in the much better place.

Exceeded our expectations. Clean, tidy, well maintained, lovely friendly people, much nicer place than I was expecting.
Grand Bazaar well worth seeing, however the same goods could be bought on the streets for about 2/3rds the price.

Great City. Get a tour guide from the Hotel,they go straight to the tourist guide window at all the famous sites and obtain tickets before the queue has shuffled 5 metres or so. Though they cannot queue jump at the Blue Mosque.

Very compact spot packed with great sights. A tourist dream: go by tram if you can; the stop is right in the middle of the action. Short walk to Blue Mosque, Haggia Sophia Museum, Underground Cistern. A bit further to Topkapi Palace, but very pleasant park-like settings for all of them. Good spots for quick meals nearby. Very pleasant place1
Pre cruise stay. Everything was wonderful the Hotel,people in the city and the attractions all as stated in my hotel review.

Must for all travellers. Istanbul is a very vibrant city with the Sultanhamet area full of historic and grand monuments. the Topkapi palace with all its treasures is something not to miss. We stayed for 4 days but still did not have enough - we would love to come back. People are very nice too. Best food found where locals eat

Sultanamet area packed with history and culture. I stayed in the sultanamet area of Istanbul and was amazed at the history , architecture and culture . Visited the Blue mosque , Hagia Sofia , grand bazaar , spice market , Basilica systerns , Topkapi palace. Took a boat trip down the bosphorus and go to the vendors near the fountains ( blue mosque ) for the best prices .You can walk to all these areas . It would be impossible to describe the experience of each of these so simply visit these fantastic places and experience them for yourself .Varied choice of places to eat from small kebab shops , street vendors selling sweetcorn to various restaurants . It's a bustling place but not opressive . I managed to do all this in three days so it was whistle stop but I will definately return .

Great Visit. Fantastic history where West literally meets East. Great culture, sights, food and shopping with warm welcome from Turkish people. We felt very safe wandering around at night with friends or own our own. All the sights are very close and easy to reach on foot. There is always a lovely cafe nearby for coffee, tea and baklava. Smashing. (or awesome for US readers).Lovely example of liberal Islamic country and can't wait to go back. And great value from Turkish Lira. Book your visit today!

The Old Town Istanbul is wonderful. The Mosques and Palace are stunning, the Grand Bazaar, Spice Market and all the bu. The whole Old Town is Vibrant and has a Buzz to it, You will never be bored in Istanbul as long as you enjoy Architecture, design and trading. You get the best of both worlds the culture and then the fun of the haggling and trading in the markets. All most enjoyable.

History, Culture, Splendor!. Istanbul is a city like no other. For centuries, almost every nationality, culture, visited, traveled through and traded in this magnificent city where East met West. The plethora of sights, smells sounds are fascinating and sometimes overwhelming. To think that I walked on the same paths as Justinian, Suleiman, Ataturk...and so many others! It is a very clean city considering it size and population. The people are friendly and not once did I feel chastised or threatened. There is so much history and culture, one must stay in Instanbul for at least 3 days if not more to see just the major sites-- next time I intend to spend at least 5 days in the city. It was an honor and a pleasure to have visited such a significant and beautiful city!

Brilliant experience. Amazing experience In Istanbul wish I had more time Holiday with kids and visited vialand and the mall Stayed 1 week which was not enough Can't wait to go again The blue mosque was amazing grand bazaar a experience
Historic Istanbul sights. Individuals were always trying to sell us guide books near the Blue Mosque and the Hippodrome. The Arasta Bazaar was great and the merchants were very helpful.

breath taking art. if u r an artist , art student ,if u like history or at least u r are an art love you will be stunned to see the ottoman turkish art and roman diasphora in whole istanbul and turkey,, such a great experience ..feels like going was to fpr a detail study and great inspirations

Three terrific days in Istanbul. It was a vibrant sensory overload of a city. We grew up in NYC and thought we had it all. No, Istanbul has it all. You can buy anything, see fantastic sites, eat great food, experience antiquity, learn about many cultures. We can't wait to go back to see more of it.

Must see old places. Must see sultanahmet blue mosque, AgoaSophia museum, Galata tower, Make shopping and bargaining in grand bazar. Take a photo with obelisks .. And have nice dinner with oriental soufi dancers or billy dancers
Istanbul sites. The Istanbul Museum is fantastic and not to be missed. Bosphorus boat cruise, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque....all great!

Newmarket Holidays. We have traveled extensively and can honestly say Istanbul is a very interesting vibrant and exciting place to visit. Try 'out of season', and not in the hottest time as it gets very busy.

Cistern. Wonderful experience but there are queues so get a VIP guide!
Otherwise you will have to compete with the cruise ship passengers . It is very romantic visit.

Awesome City. Most of the main sites are close together making everything accessible. The sense of history, exotic buildings and decor and culture is tangible and the public areas are very clean and feel safe despite the usual hassling from street guides and sellers.

The cradle of civiliaztions. I loved the beauty and history of the city. Istanbul is built on 7 hills. The walking up and down did not bother me, the trams ran on schedule, the people were very friendly. There was nothing that I disliked about Istanbul

Beautiful!. Multiple destinations in walking distance. I LOVE IT! The neighborhood is very nice to look at and the food is great. Now if only people here wouldn't drive in such speed in such a narrow street...

Sultanahmet is the place to be in Istanbul. Without any shadow of doubt, the Sultanahmet area (Old Istanbul) is the place to be. There are quite a lot to see around a single area. I have visited Istanbul 4 times and next year I shall return there again. If you want to have fun, meet friends for a drink and eat a great food and at a reasonable price, visit Sultan Hostel (you can find it at the hosteling international website) the street where this hostel is located, is the trendiest one in Sultanahmet.
crowded and comercial. Very crowded. Long lines to enter the most important historical sites, such as topkapi palace and aya sofia. Better to visit in low season.
Old Istanbul. Walking distance from the cistern, Aya Sofya, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace and the Archeological Museum.
Beautiful city. Very crowded in September but the history and people are worth the visit. The local, small resturants were very good

Don't do a three day tour. We stayed in Istanbul for ten days and saw all the sites with enough time to do justice to them. These are not places to be visited in a flying visit, they are too important, too moving and too beautiful. We read as much as we could before we went, so did not take any guided tours, which we dislike, but wandered around for hours, just so privileged to be there.

Many cultural highlights within 5 min walk, tips. This area is absolutely packed with highlights 5 min walk will make you travel centuries and cultures like nowhere else. From byzantinium greatness to the splendor of the ottoman empire, all next to each other, clean, safe and full of friendly, helpful and english speaking people. Simply go there and you will have one full day and more full of history, marveling sights and culture. But of course full of people who want to sell to tourists, so any food and drink you encounter there will most likely be more expensive than in many other places in Istanbul. Select your choices carefully. The water may only be double to to other areas but still. At every attraction there are literally dozens of guidse willing to help you along, check the conditions first.The blue mosque plus one place in the Topkapi Palace demand decent attire so plan your trip and dress accordingly. They give out clothes for free in case the sun is too hot for you.
