A very good travel book will help you save a lot on audio guides and since there are many tours around it is hard not to hear what they are saying.Important: This place is of course crowded by tourist groups from all over the world. A few things are certain with them: They do not start too early, they do take a lunch break and they finish early. If you have the ability use this to your advantage. It gets sort of empty at 12 in the Topkapi (notice, sort of).Also important: None of the highlights are open 24/7. Check before you go.

Great feel. This is the place to be when visiting Istanbul. The sights are within walking distance or you can easily jump on the Metro. Istanbul is alive and you can feel the energy in this part of town. It is certainly a special part of the city and the world.

My favorite city. This was my third time in Istanbul, and hopefully will not be my last. I just can't get enough of it. The Sultan Ahmet area is where all the historical sights are, and close to each other so it is convenient to just walk to all major sights. I just love the ambiance where you can sense the culture and history of that region.Everybody speaks English so you don't need to worry about getting lost in translation. The people are friendly and we felt safe walking around (my husband left his bag in a restaurant, with his iPad and some cash in it, and only realized that it was "missing" when we were already back in our hotel. We returned to the restaurant and to our delight, they kept it for us with everything intact, nothing missing).On top of that, a visit to Istanbul is a great culinary experience. Lessons in history, great sights, excellent food. What more can you ask for?

Fantastic and historic places. The Blue Mosque,the St.Sophia Church, the water palace,all seemed not only historic places, but also constructional miracles.You have to see them by your own eyes at least once all through your life.

Istanbul is a magical place. There are so many wonderful things to visit in Istanbul. Its beautiful with beautiful people, great food and lots of interesting places to shop and do take time to talk with those you meet. I have been to the Sultanahmet area twice, stayed at the Best Western Premier Hotel. Its a great hotel value and I love the folks that work there.

Ottoman Cisterns. The Istanbul cisterns are underground but give you a great sense of history and how valuable water and its function are to an ancient city. Great columns of Greek background were used as well as many others to support a very efficient system for many hundreds of years. We particularly enjoyed the upside-down statue and you will to if you venture underneath this fabulously, interesting city to see for yourself! Worth a peek!

A great walking city. We were coming from a cruise ship and at the end of the day were happy to have a shuttle to take us back to our ship after a long day of walking. But all of the things we wanted to see (except for the spice market) were close to each other. It was great to see all the sights and experience such a different culture. Be prepared though to be mobbed by carpet dealers; if you look like a tourist they will be on you in a flash. Just be ready to say NO! and they will leave you alone (OK, be prepared to say "NO!" repeatedly). Also, have a good map and plan out your route as it is somewhat tricky to find things with the winding streets and the hard-to-pronounce street names. Allow lots of time for each place you intend to visit as there is much to see, long lines, and big crowds.

You feel history. When walking around the Sultameht district you can see and feel the more than 3500 years of Istanbul history. Especially you should go down to the excavation of the ancient Roman Harbor dated 400 bc, it is down at the connstruction site of the new subway line.
You should not miss this!. Historic areas of Istanbul are best thing what the city can offer. Sights are close to each other and there is nice parks to hang out.
Istanbul. Fantastic city to visit with a huge range of attractions to visit. Highlights included the Ottoman Cisterns, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazaar and Topki Palace.

History of Ottoman and Byzantium. We felt the long history of Ottoman, Byzantium and others. If we could have seen and learned about Byzantium much more, we were more happy. Wish Istanbul City administrative to develop the historic sites more.

Small excellent hotel. The room was big enough, clean and with a very nice view. The hotel is just few walking minutes from all most interesting sites in old Istanbul. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful.
Old city. The old city was better than advertise and an excellent example of preservation of the palaces and mosque of the Byzantine and Ottoman empire

città pulsante a qualsiasi ora. mi è piaciuto tutto di Istanbul, la gente, il cibo, le moschee, i mercatini, i ristoranti eccWe went in this beautiful hotel the first days in oktober 2013. we had there beautiful days. the suite is very confortable, the people there is very kind, the breakfast was very well and the rooms are very clean. we will certainly come back in this hotel during our next trip in Istanbul.gemma and pompeo Reale from Italy

Awesome place cradle of civilisations well preserved. Preservation, the amazing layers of cultures, the revelation of truthVestiges of Ottomans oppulance Very friendly people . Great city to revisit 3 days are not enough !!

Almost Disney-like Historic Highlights. The usual Top Sites in Istanbul are Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Toptkapi Palace and Bassilica Cistern. It was amazing to see how nicely situated they are -- easy walk from one to the next -- almost like a Disney planner had laid it out. Don't get me wrong -- there's nothing Mickey Mouse about these fabulous historical sites. If you like great architecture -- be prepared to have your breath taken away.

Wow. I thought Cairo was manic and this was the same without the camels and donkey carts. People everywhere so not for the faint-hearted but just being part of the millions of people who have walked these streets and seen these sights is so exciting and life-affirming.Deep breaths and go for it-its amazing!
Awesome. All the different cultures and history make this one of the most fascinating cities I have visited. I loved the Hagia Sofia, the mosques, Basilica Cistern.

CAPPADOCIA Volcanic Landscapes and "Fairy-chimneys". The visit to Goreme's rock-carved churches and the ancient frescoes in the open-air museum. The underground city of Kaymakli and the cone of Uchisar is so magnificently well preserved and everyone can able to see and explore.

Cradle of Civilization. My wife and I spent about 6 days in Istanbul, staying in several different hotels, mostly in the Old City. I would say that 2/3 of what is worth seeing in Istanbul would be in the Old City. The Hagia Sofia, various mosques, cisterns, Grand Bazaar are all in a fairly compact area. Walking is a great way to get around, once you get used to very crowded sidewalks. It is a city area of small shopkeepers, no big box stores. Some streets have shops that sell nothing but wedding invitations, or streets that specialize in shoe making. Getting lost can lead to some fascinating places, and it always seemed safe. The tram that goes through the old city is a great means to get around, easy for tourists to navigate. It is also the best way to cross the Golden Horn to get to Beyoglu. This area has a different feel to it, more the jazz music store, coffee shop, high style clothing boutiques. It involves going up and down hilly streets but we are glad we spent a couple of days just exploring that area. Most Turkish speak some English so it is easy to get around.Due to the tremendous amount of history and culture in Istanbul (Turkey in general) it is really worthwhile to read up on the Byzantines and the Ottomans. One gets a lot more enjoyment from the sites if you appreciate the history behind it. Istanbul is a unique city, a little European but the Muslim influence makes it more livable I think.

Fascinating, walkable. The Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Cistern, Topkapi, and many other sites are all very close together. I was having some mobility issues when I was there, but had no problem getting around on foot, although I wouldn't recommend trying to see all the sites in one day - each one deserves plenty of time. There's so much history and beauty in such a small space. Also plenty of places to sit and people watch (and plenty of people to watch).

Clean and friendly. Its now some time since i visited and still my memories are still what a fantastic city Istanbul is. I did not really know what to expect but i was surprised by just how clean the city was and how friendly the people were, i have since visited Cairo which was filthy and highlighted how beautiful and interesting Istanbul with historic sights at every turn. I look forward to returning asap.

Compressed History. This wonderful area gave us the opportunity to learn lots about the development of Istanbul today, without having to wear out our shoe leather. One of the earliest Christian churches sits cheek by jowl with the Sultan's palace and the blue mosque, as well as such wonders as the subterranean basilica cistern. All within 5 minutes walk of each other. And with a background view of the Bosporus and the Golden Horn...! Wow!

i have been living i Istanbul for 2 years now. The food and the culture and the history is facinating. you must go. If you want to visit Istanbul you should consider the topkapi palace, the dolmabace and the Bosphorus. Turkey is a fascinating place full of history and you will always find something to do or see.
Plenty to see and do. I loved all the places I visited but was particularly impressed by the Basillica Cistern. Istanbul is a fascinating melting pot of cultures and people

Blue mosque. Architecture and history of what the Ottoman Empire achieved .
location and peaceful with Hagia Sophia across the Blue Mosque.
People were very kind and helpful
Walking around in Istanbul. to just walk around in the historic areas of Istanbul is a treat. Because i have seen all the high lights i can take the time to visit other neighbourhoods.

Great to spend a day.... Loads to see here - The Blue Mosque, Aya Sofiya, Cistern, Top Kapi Palace. One can easily spend a whole day at these monuments and along the square. The area is lively with a few shops and restaurants. For the monuments, I would suggest that you either join a tour or get an audio guide. The place will not be as charming if you do not understand the history behind it. Aya Sofiya has the best history and is super crowded in the morning, abt 10 - 11. Hence, you may choose to go a little later when the travel groups are leaving. For the Blue Mosque, please check the prayer times and then plan your visit. Dress appropriately - shoulders and legs covered and no tight fitting clothes. However, they do have wrap arounds to offer is you are not adhering to the dress code when you arrive - so worry not. It is a place of worship - please bear that in mind.

Unbelievable history - both Christian and Muslem. So much to see, give yourself time is this historic city. Koptopi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Chora Church, Blue Mosque, just to mention a few. Give yourself time in this city....we were there 6 days!
Love it. First time in Istanbul.Loved it.fantastic transport links,tram train,ferryGood food, good shopping.We will be back. Thought it was vibrant and very busy

Lots to see in a fairly compact area. The historic areas are really very well preserved but at the same time they are lived in so are alongside some very ordinary buildings. In lots of ways this makes them more interesting and makes them belong to the city.The Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar were great.

Sultanahmet. Spend a week in and around this area with ease. So much to do and see, but I'd probably give the Tourist bus thing a miss next time. If you buy a 72 hour Museum pass (great value) be aware that you cannot visit the same site twice.

too many to see. Istanbul must be one of the most interesting cities in Europe/Asia and probably requires more than 1 visit to obtain its true worth. After exploring many of the sights during the day there are ample restaurants and interesting places and sites of interest to visit in the evenings. A 'must visit before you die,

Historic Istanbul. So many things to see, it's honestly hard to choose which is best. We used a museum pass which came in handy, but it's only worth it if you're willing to cover a lot of territory in 2-3 days. Be ready for lots of walking!

Wonders of Old city Istanbul !. Could spend days wandering around the historic areas and quaint cobbled streets. Plenty to do and eat around this area including the numerous archaeological and historical museums.

Heart of historic city. Proximity to sites is worth it. With a museum pass we were able to visit all the main attractions at a discount. Some rainy days but not a concern with hotel being on tram line.

Historic sites in Istanbul, Turkey quick guide and more. Just returned from a 2 week trip to Istanbul, where my son is living now, and here are some suggestions that might help visitors...even if they have a tour book.First, Istanbul is exciting, safe, with great sights to see and an amazing experience....but crowded and not without some hassles. We spent 6 days in the city, staying at a boutique hotel below the Blue Mosque and a 7 minute walk away. Need to remember that this is the most expensive area precisely because of the sights nearby and the number of tourists around here. After weeks of research we decided on the Tashkonak Hotel,a 14 room older place (they all are). Rooms in this are are all about half the size of a standard Hilton or Holiday Inn and bathrooms area are all tiny, as in most European cities. American are spoiled by these luxuries at home but here they are meant to be merely functional. However, this place was clean, comfortable and had a nice garden where tea was available. Cappucino and Turkish coffee could be made for a 2 euros. We often came back weary from walking and sat in the garden for an hour to relax, The best thing was the staff who were extremely helpful, even calling the airlines 10 times to inquire about our lost baggage. We took a taxi from the airport, about 40 TL ($20). The breakfasts were good, usual Turkish fare....fresh veggies, cheeses, bread, honey, jam, boiled eggs, fruit, olives, cooked eggplant that was wonderful etc.and the view of the Bosphorus from the terrace was nice. The best way to start a tour is to make your way to the Blue Mosque, the landmark visible from almost anywhere in this area and one needs to get one's bearings so as not to get lost, We entered the Blue Mosque form the Obelisk side and it is an amazing spectacle. Need to remove shoes and ladies need to cover their hair to enter and it is closed to visitors during prayer times (they will provide plastic bags and shawls). Outside, that entrance are some souvenir shops where we actually found some of the cheapest small gifts anywhere.Once out of the Mosque, the gate to the right is where you can see the Hagia Sophia across the square and as you make your way to it, before the fountain is the Dervis Cafe on the right. We sat here in the evening for a coffee and a chocolate crepe and listened to a musician playing that was wonderful. We saw the area at night the first time and it is one of the most memorable sights one will ever see. The Sophia can be seen during the day only and if on a tour, there is a long line for visitors. But if alone, there is al most no line at the entrance site at the front of the line and on the left where we walked in immediately to buy a ticket. It is being renovated now inside so part of it was not visible but amazing nonetheless....but full of tourists so going early is better. In the evening, recommend turning left on road past Dervis Cafe (in front of fountain), down the hill to Araasta Bazaar...the first place there is Mesale Cafe. Have something to eat or just a cup of tea or coffee and enjoy watching the locals enjoy a hookah and listen to the wonderful live Turkish music ....spent a few relaxing evenings here.Next, in the daytime, would recommend walking past the Sophia to the Basilica Cistern (turn right and then left on next street for entrance) but then go up the hill on the Cistern side where the tram runs and this is where the Turkish Delight shops, cafes and restaurants are in this area (also below the Cistern). A few doors up from the Puding Cafe is a lovely coffee shop with amazing Turkish Delight and Lokum (pomegranate/pistachio in wonderful)....there are stone steps leading down and there is a bookstore there). During the day it is the way to walk to the Burnt Column and turn right there and then left to enter the Grand Bazaar. This is a must see but also a zoo with your head spinning with all the stalls and goodies. We bought some jewelry and a small carpet after much haggling. Kilims are the geometric designed rugs and some are machine made and some hand made, and some of the rugs are beautiful. A small 3 ft X 2 ft good silk carpet will cost around ($700 -1200) but there are cheaper wool ones. Do not be pressured into seeing or buying and you have to say no politely and move on. We had an idea of what these things were worth and generally offered 50% of what they wanted, settling around 60-70% of asking price. But in the end, if you like it and want something. paying a little more than is OK...as long as it is cheaper than in the US. We bought semi precious necklaces, evil eye bracelets etc.....all costume jewelry and reasonable. Would not buy diamonds here or gold, unless an expert.The other bazaar that is a must is the Spice Bazaar near the New Mosque and the ferry at Eminonu. Get to it by walking in the opposite direction down the hill past Sophia to the end and turn left. The Mosque is beautiful and the courtyard behind leads to the Spice Bazaar. The shops have wonderful stuff and if you go left and out the streets around have interesting stalls and goods.We then walked to the Galata Bridge, opposite the Mosque. next to which are boats selling famous fish sandwiches. Fresh pomegranate and orange juice is available everywhere and we could not resist several glasses a day but there is a vendor across the bridge who had the best price. Turn left after the bridge and walk up towards the Tower....we did not go in, there was a long line, but after the square there turn right on Istiklal Ave that is the modern main street that is visited by 3 million people daily and leads to Taksim Square after a mile. We did not find this area of great interest and preferred to wander off on the small side streets, Returned taking the funicular and the tram (need to get a token at the machine at the station).The Topkapi is a must see and again, go early and avoid a Sunday, when locals congregate. The Treasury is on the right as one enters and opposite is the hall with the Sacred Relics (no tank tops and minis allowed)....with some beautiful objects. On the way to the washrooms (between the 2 halls) we stumbled on the Konyali restaurant (the other is a cafeteria adjacent) and had a wonderful rest and break for lunch watching the other side (Beyoglu) and the ships going in and out. Opposite the ticket office is the Harem (we did not visit and not a must see, I am told (of course not, if there are no ladies there!)) but the Privy Council and Clock Room next door are worth a visit. Best way to Topkapi is to face the Sophia and go all the way to the right where there is a wall and turn left to gate and entrance.A must is the roasted chestnuts the vendors sell everywhere (but the corn is not that great).Food: we are not great meat-eaters and this is pretty much the standard fare, in various forms. My son eats about a pound a day so we generally sampled his food. We really liked the lentil soup and lahmacun (thin crust pizza with meat or veg and cheese toppings and cheap), salads and Isme (a mixed veg appetizer). Pide is thicker crust pizza with the edges folded in and cheese inside.....too much bread for me. BUT, the fresh breads are lovely, from the Simit (donut shaped with sesame and a little hard like a bagel) to the french bread and other varieties. Most tourists will not venture here for lack of time but we went to the Asian side (Kadikoy) by ferry and spent 3 nights here and loved it. Less tourists and more locals. If you go for even a day, it is worth it....turn right after leaving the ferry and where the main street is with the train tracks, turn left and then right at the second street.....this whole area is filled with restaurants, sweet shops, fishmongers, etc and a great spot to have Turkish coffee and try a hookah. We walked through to the main street and all the way to fashionable Moda and had lunch at the Moda pier, a nice scenic spot. It was convenient for us to stay here as we were leaving for Cappadocia from SAW airport, 40 mins south by Havatas shuttle (next to ferry). Stayed at My Dora Hotel....clean, modern but very small rooms. Nice breakfast and opposite ferry.Any visit to Turkey would be incomplete without a visit to Cappadocia, a fairyland place with amazing sights and history. We landed in Kayseri and had arranged a shuttle through the Heybe Hotel (could have picked a cave hotel but were concerned with heat and claustrophobia) and this was a clean and modern place. We just loved the town of Goreme, full of fairy chimneys all around, a lovely main street and great restaurants. The Goreme restaurant is a must as a musician plays traditional music at night, you sit on pillows on the ground and we ordered a dish cooked in a clay pot.....opened by the owner breaking it with a flourish with a dagger. And the beef stew with veg was very tasty. We visited the Open Air Museum (long walk but the hotel shuttle took us), really incredible sight of churches and cave homes made by hermit monks by carving them out of the mountains. Visited Love Valley and Peshabag to see the fairy chimneys and worth seeing. We took the Green Tour the next day and this is well worth it....visited Derinkuyu, the underground city of 8 levels where early Christians carved a massive city underground to escape attacking armies...an incredible sight and experience. And then went to Ilhara Canyon for a lovely walk and lunch, ending with a visit to the Selime cliff monastery. Lovely view of the area and fairy chimneys on the way back. We did not take the recommended balloon ride over the area as did not fancy the ride but most say it is well worth it. The sights are so unique that this actually became the highlight of our whole trip.2 days minimum needed here.We then took a 4 hour bus trip to Konya, just to see the Rumi museum and it was on the way to Antalya so a good stopping point. Buses are clean and comfortable....and cheap. We stayed at the Hilton Garden, a 10 min walk for the museum. Crowded as it was a Friday, but the museum was very interesting. Nothing else much in Konya as I expected to see some of the old city....but now just shops and restaurants around the museum, so that was disappointing. Great hotel and breakfast there.Then took a bus to Antalya....really to see Kaleici. the old city and then on to Cirali on the beach for 2 days rest. Loved Kaleici....very touristy but the old narrow cobblestoned streets with shops and restaurants with views of the harbor were great. Stayed at Aspen Hotel.....convenient location. The rest of the city is like any other but should walk around this area and the Park along the harbor.We then rented a car and drove one hour to Cirali on the beach.....crowded in summer and very hot but weather in late Sept. was good....though water was cold. Driving was easy but gas prices are double what they are in the USA (rental was reasonable though (through economycarentals.com). Stayed at Anatolia Resort which was very nice, had dinner there two nights. We walked up to the Chimaera flames late one night (absolutely need a good flashlight and good shoes and be careful as can be treacherous, especially coming down) but an amazing sight to see these flames spouting out from the ground as they have been for thousands of years. On our return, stopped for lunch at Kemer, a nice town with a pleasing harbor and lunch spots.Then returned to IST for 2 nights to end our vacationThere are many other places to visit...Bodrum, Izmir, Kusadasi, Pammukale and one has to decide which is a priority. But would recommend not trying to do too much as the country is large and travelling takes time and a toll. Suggest spending a couple of days in each place and resting before moving on.ANd just a note....not all places in smaller towns or out of the way restaurants have western style toilets. Always keep some TP with youHope this is helpful.

Walk to all the attractions, its great fun. The Sultanahmet area of Istanbul offers a lot to the tourist who walks everywhere. We met such interesting people and saw lovely sights and whenever you look around you see the Golden Horn or the Bosphorus or the Sea of Marmara. Istanbul is truly an enchanting city if you learn how to smilingly walk away from the folks who employ the hard sell. Finally do go to Hafiz Mustafa near the Rustom Pasha Mosque and try their Baklava.

Fantastic City. Istanbul is so rich in culture and history it is quite overwhelming if you are on a short visit. The buildings are fantastic and have been well preserved. Many of the main sites are free. Unbelievable amount of big tour buses which impacts the overall experience. Would recommend to visit outside of the summer season otherwise you will be queuing to get into the main attractions and even walking from one place to another can be frustrating due to the volume of people around. One tip, go to the rooftop terrace of the Blue Hotel late afternoon and listen to the call to prayer while watching the sun go down on the mosque - beautiful. There are a huge amount of cats and dogs that live on the streets which are in the most part tolerated and well looked after by the locals. The dogs are tagged and are medically clean and the cats are super friendly - great extra for animals lovers. Overall great atmospheric experience and felt very safe walking around both day and night.

beautiful mosques. The blue mosque is gorgeous I love islamic tile and mosaicsIt is really neat to know this is an active mosque. Be prepared to take off shoes and cover hair.haggia sophia incredible ancient frescoespalace of sultan gorgeous grounds crown jewels are heregrand bazaar really funnegatives NO WESTERN BATHROOMS look for starbucks or go into hotels or nice restaurants turkish bathrooms are not fun periodweather was terrible cold rainy and very windy but we will return
Sultanahmet is the best area to stay in. This is where all the places of interests to tourists are. I would not stay anywhere else. Everything is within walking distance.

Too much for 4 days. Istanbul is well wearth a visit, but you should keep in mind that it take you several days just to see the major touristic attractions. It is so big and overwhelming that 4 days just isn't enough. We will certainly come back here.

Rich in history and culture!. There is so much to see and do here. Or relax and wander and soak up the environment. Lots of people, and tour groups and buses, but everyone friendly. Always felt safe when out and about, even at night.

The Cradle of Western Civilisation - at least!. Istanbul is fantastic - but go beyond there! Hot Tip:- Asian side of Istanbul ---- The Best!!!!Beyond Istanbul - Alexander the Great, Emperor Hadrian, St Paul, Mevlana. One of the great countries to visit for a big time history fix. I was gobsmacked by the antiquity that lies within the borders of Istanbul. Once you get over that, the people, the culture, the place and the food just make this wonderful place one of the best places to experience and ingest into your life experience something that is very unique. i.e.. not available elsewhere.Please don't take me too seriously, because we are going back next year and probably the year after to finish what we have started and don't want any more tourists making it even harder for us to get around. Except for the hardcore traveller like us, go for it, don't miss one moment of this fabulous place.We are going back, next year and hopefully the following year and then again! So, do go there until 2015. Much appreciated.Turkish west coast - magnificent. Kannakale - a wonderful stay. Gallipoli, an experience I'm kind of glad I've done. I found my time there tough going, only helped a little by the enormous number of Turkish people coming to mourn their loved ones. It was their country to defend after all, but I didn't realise how many Turkish soldiers were lost in defence of their homeland, particularly how young they were (some only 15) - How Wrong is That!Going there, the place does have an atmosphere. Even now writing this from my home in Melbourne, I can't help but be overcome by the emotion of the place. I didn't want to do it. Glad I did. I've digressed from the original intent here.If you can - go to Istanbul. If you can spend two weeks soaking up te vibe in this amazing city. In many ways still the hope to bring East & West together. If that doesn't happen, just go out and discover all the amazing things about this city before it changes. If you have the time to go beyond Istanbul, do not hesitate - explore - the enrichment you can experience is only a function of how much time you have to explore!! Mark my words - The richness of your experience will be unmatched by many countries.Sorry for the rambling commentary, but I only realised I may be adding to my contributions on Tripadvisor.

Let yourself be immersed in history. As a first timers, only had 3 days, we hired a local guide to show us the city. Best move ever as Ari was a fountain of knowledge and also seemed to know all the short cuts to beat the crowds.Highlights are to many to list, but we managed all of the major sites, I think 3 weeks just might cover everything. Walking is the way to go around the Old City and almost everything is whithin easy access. We did catch the tram, vernicular rail and a ferry to see Taksim Square and the harbour but again this was an easy task with a guide. One suggestion we would make is to obtain a decent travel book on Turkey before you go and prepare a must see and hope to see list. It's a city of some 15 million people and at times we thought most were at the same venue as us, but that's all part of the fun especially in the Grand Bazzar

Well preserved. istanbul history is well preserved .. dont miss the attractions especially sultanahmet area.
very safe with a lot of seating areas for all.

Historic, clean, well interpreted.. We went to all the sites, with a tour and on our own. There are guides that speak excellent English, and guide books in English.
No complaints from us on anything.

Turkish Delight. The picture in my mind before visiting Istanbul was a cross between Marakesch and Cairo, how wrong could I have been. The positive review comments about the place are spot on. The history, the architecture, the sites and sounds, the landscape, the friendly people, not to mention, in my humble opinion, the best cuisine in the world all conspire to make this city a "must see" to anyone who calls themselves a traveller. Make sure you purchase the 72 hour valid museum pass to by-pass the long queues that form outside the main attractions. Sadly it does not cover every site you might want to visit but the main ones such as Tokapi, Hagia Sophia, St Saviour in Choro plus others are certainly included. Blue Mosque is free to enter,

Dolmabache. Very intricate engravings outside and column details, and interiors are decorated with luxurious chandeliars, mirrors, and candelabra. Even the staircase is made by crystal. Luxury carpets. Visited the harem, which is basically the private quarters where the family reside. Impressive ID for the halls for visitors. Simply outstanding.

Easily walkable just stay alert. The historic areas of Istanbul are all located within walking distance of one another. Take the tram into the city core and depart at the Sultanahmet stop. From there you can access the Hippodrome, Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the Grand Bazaar, and the Spice Market.
Brilliant. Rich in Islamic history an well preserved,turkey is a country u have to spend a couple of months to finish
Beautiful. Go and see for yourself the layers of history and the guidesAre so good you feel like you are part of it.

If you have 3 days or less in Istanbul.... I was in Istanbul last week and stayed in cosy room at Baklava Hotel. The fellas managing it mentioned to purchase tickets to the main attractions online to bypass the long queue at the entrance. This saved me alot of time at Ayya Sophia and Topkapi Palace. There is also a muzekart pass that is electronic and has unlimited entry over several days so this can be useful to some passionate ppl who enjoy taking their time at some of these sites.A good way to get a sneak preview of what the city has to offer is with the \hop on hop off bus, once after that route you can plan where to visit and what my interest you better.On a personal note, i find Dolmabache Palace is alot more regal & significant compared to Topkapi Palace if you have to choose between these 2 palaces. If one has to get souvenirs there are some cheaper stalls on the way to the Grand bazaar from Ayya Sofiya via the basillica cistern, its easier to bargain { Indirim means discount; mention that and it will stun some turks & get them to lower their rates }.The grand bazaar is a unique place but rather stressful to deal with some store owners, most stalls sell similar items after awhile.In general, the local turks have mention that some Hamams in Istanbul are pretty dirty, so you might wanna try em out elsewhere.

SECOND LARGEST CITY IN THE WORLD. We really wern't prepared for the sheer size of Istanbul. This city is huge, but unlike most cities, it's pretty much 'low rise', with the city sprawled across hills and dales for miles and miles. Much of the historic areas are within a small (ish) area, which is handy, and there's plenty to see here, even if you do have to walk or take a tram as the traffic is so awful. Take time to walk the old quarter though as its amazing, mosque after mosque and palace after column are all there to see, and don't miss the Hippodrome either, or what's left of it. This is an amazing city and a must see, especiallly at sunset when everything looks twice as good. Also take a trip on the Bosphorous, the large body of water that runs between the Black sea and the mediteranean if you can, we ran out of time so book it when you get there. Hope this helps
Walk everywhere. The best way to see all places in Istanbul is by walk. The places are clean. While some have entry fee, some do not. The express card was a good idea.

intresting city. İ like İstanbul is good for tourism and bussines and a lot of history inside.Look like a story more than a city.Has a lot of history inside from otoman imperatory.Really very mister inside.

Impressive snapshot of a golden era. Istanbul's historic area is one to be rivalled. Contained with a relatively small area are the jewels of thousand's of years of history - the magnificent Hagia Sophia, it's neighbour the Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome, Topkapi Palace, the atmospheric underground Basilica Cistern and both the Grand & Spice Bazaar. Each and every one immaculately presented and maintained.
Magnificent!
Worth seeing. Highlight was the Baslicia cistern but all attractions in old town are great. Seethe Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia andTopkapi Palace.

Just packed with history. Within 500 sq. meters, there are a ton of monuments and ancient sites. You can see, smell and feel history around you. Most landmarks will provide stunning views, restaurants in the area have terraces and could be an experience by itself. Some sites are close one day a week, not always a weekend day - check their schedules.

Amazing. Great sense of rich history and culture. A step back to one of the greatest periods in history. All places were easily accessible, clean and safe. The museums shops were a great source of mementos specifically for each museum. We bought a museum card, which gave us entries into all museums. This way you did not have to stand in queues.
So much to see too little time. Many Museums, mosques, churches, Bosphorus cruise, excellent restaurants, spice & grand bazaar. Beautiful city.

Amazing Stuff. Well looked after, lots and lots to see.... everything close, just need lots of time to do it all. So many highlights in such a small area.... and to think of the number of people this place gets every year... no wonder

Two full days of interest. We booked a one day tour of the major sites with Viator, an excellent English speaking guide who was very knowledgeable.Took in Blue Mosques. Cisterns ( a must for lovers of Dan Browns new book Inferno), Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazaar, Topkia.Gave us a good grounding for a day on our own visiting the spice market and boat trip on the Bosphorous.

Our favourite city.. Istanbul has it all, history dating back to before the Greeks, through Roman, Ottoman and modern day Turkey.It is lively, easily accessible, safe and with an excellent transport system and our favourite city. One trip is not enough to take in everything we discover something new every time.

The Blue Mosque. This place is stunning! I/we were quite overwhelmed over the size of inside this wonderful building. The colours, the way the tiles have been laid to create a sense of majesty. What a feat of architecture! Words and even photos cannot adequately portray the immenseness inside this building
Yedikule Fortess. A very nice place, "7 Towers Fortress", we hope that in the future they will renovate and make a special place here...we lost here a brave king in this prison.
Lots to see.. We really liked Istanbul and found the people friendly and the attractions varied and interesting. Definitely worth a visit.

Just what we expected ...Excellent. The sites were just what we had expected, maybe even better, some breath-taking. Public transport to most sites was very easy although a little disjointed as the system is in its infancy. Signage for visitors was a bit sparse and could do with an upgrade just to make it a little easier.

Very walkable. So much to see and all is really within walking distance. We only had a full day and managed to see most of the area, although the bazaar is closed on Sunday, so we missed that. Lots of places only take cash so bring your ATM card, or get cash at the airport.
Easy to get around. Closely situated, so you are able to indulge in a lot of culture in a short time with plenty of space to soak up the atmosphere

A taste is not enough.. I LOVED Istanbul but 4 days was not enough time to see everything but I did see the major historical sights but my visit made me want to come back so that I could see more. September is an ideal time to visit as it is perfect for sightseeing - warm and sunny without being oppressively hot.

Good really. I would like to say for all friends be carefull in istanbul about people they are very aggressive
realy difficult to contact with them they are diffrent people really

Very Surprised. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia was amazing, the history behind Haig Sophia was surprising you need a tour guide. Plus look for the center of the earth Roman times when the earth was flat. Recommend a traditional Turkish Bath you want be disappointed look for Gedikpasa Bath Built 1475 a must.

Love it again and again.. I visit Istanbul 3 or 4 times a year. I feel very lucky for this. But i can not finish the places that should be seen. Every time I fell in love with Istanbul again because every time i see a new wonder, a new surprise. Even seeing a historical street that i did not see before makes beautiful surprise. I have just come back but i want more.
Great location to Beyoglu. Great location to beyoglu and very close to ortakoy, its lovely tourist area. Close to Shops and resturant.

So much to see.. Grand bazaar is a must-see but be prepared for non stop 'invitations to buy'. Refusals usually accepted graciously. A short boat trip up the Bosphorus straits as far as the modern Bosphorus Bridge is a good option giving excellent views of the waterfront on both European and Asian sides.

Beautiful city. The historic area is compact so you can walk around and see a lot of sites in a short period of time and the views are amazing. Watch out for the Turks, they will try and sell you everything and anything. DO NOT accept the price of anything offered. They offer fellow Turks about half the price they offer foreigners. Be polite but assertive. The city is well worth seeing especially at night. The fountain in the square between Hagia Sofia and the blue mosque is amazing. It changes colour. The Hagia Sofia and Blue mosque are also illuminated at night as are the obelisks on the hippodrome.
Amazing history. Coming from Australia,it is incredible seeing these ancient sites. Our history is so recent. Well worth a visit and not expensive admission charges.

Beautiful city and culture. I loved the people and culture. The historic sites (Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, etc.) are amazing to see. The only thing I did not like was the locals that at times hassled you to buy stuff, but saying "No." sufficed and they would back off. But really, you get that in most tourist locations!
Interesting and different. Be very careful walking on the streets, I was robbed at knifepoint. My fault for wearing jewellery but a frightening experience.
blue mosque is a must. calming peaceful for the highlight of my life was attending Friday prayers at the sultanhamet mosque
The City of Great Sights. Istanbul has so much to do and so much to see. This city has so much history that even 9 days was not enough to learn about everything. We will just have to go back.
Worth a look!. Although very busy with a large number of tourists we saw most of all we wanted to in such a short time.
Lots to see. Really liked the Grand Bazaar and Topaki Palace is well worth the visit. The Bosphorous trips are really enjoyable. Loads of little charming side street shops.
Grand bazaar. When I needed something i went to the Grand Bazaar which is a 5 minute walk from Sefa Hotel. I found what i was looking for and also able to buy some souvenier to take home.

Go and see all the marvelous sights in Sultanahmet!. Everything is a deloght. You can stroll in the old neighbourhood, see the camii of Suleiman the Magnificent, go to the Saint Sophia, in the Arasta Bazaar, in the Egyptian Bazar, on Galata Bridge and please, go with Orhan Pamuk in your mind! It will be a time to remember! I love you, Bosphorus!
Magical Sultanahmet. Between the Mosques, Topkapi Museum, and the Bazaar it's hard to find time to leave this district. It's magical and makes the tour books pale by comparison to the real place!

It's why people come to Istanbul, at least if it's their first time. there's a lot to see in Istanbul's Sultanahmet area (and beyond) but try to space it out if you have the time as you can easily get 'all palaced out' very quickly. If you squeeze in all the sights in a single day you could get palace overload!

Shopping with a bath. The grand Bazar was fun, lots of products, gold, silver, leather, carpets of silk and wool and lots of junk. It is a shoppers heaven, be ready to haggel the price. Be sure to know price at home so you don't pay to much.After sopping go to the Haman, and have a Türkish bath, relax om the warm stone, get soaped in, and enjoy the treatment.

Magnificent City!. I had an idea about what Istanbul would be like but the reality far exceeded my vision. I love places that skirt along the water and the impressive Bosphorus wove and glistened majestically. I loved the Mosques and the call to prayer that resonated throughout the city. Though it is the people that are the city's greatest asset - generous, funny and humanitarian. I can't wait to go back.
Istanbul Historic Places. Istanbul is a city like no other. People are nice and the area is very safe. We felt welcome everywhere. The history is mind blowing.
AGHIA SOFIA CHURCH.. Poor value for money - heavilly scaffolded preventing view of most of interior.However Blue Mosque was wonderful as was Topkapi Palace.
sites. Beautiful but crowded. Too many tourists at this time of year. The winter is a better time to visit and hotel rates are lower

great city. Enjoyed the atmosphere/people and food not forgetting the Turkish bath experience.The one dislike is being hassled for carpets and being given the wrong info by locals when asking for directions as they wanted to get you into their shop.

An unforgettable city. Istambul is one of those fascinating cities that are so completely distant from our western reality and way of life that it will leave a mark for the rest of your life. You must remember you are in a muslim country where certain rules (specially for foreigners), are a MUST.Women MUST be completely covered at all times. If not usually men pass by and rub you arms even give you a boot in your behind and some even go as far as rubbing breasts. If you respect this then you will have a great time.There are so many things to visit an see in this city that it's difficult to advise as to the order of things.ONE WORD OF ADVISE YOU HAVE TO TAKE. The Bazar and Egyptian (spice market) are an obligated visit JUST BE VERY VERY CAREFUL. To give you an idea as to the Bazar, the people selling you speak tens of languages and not only that they distinguish form where you are coming. For example if you speak spanish they know if you are from spain or central or south america. Many times they know exactly from what country you come even the region within the country (specially Spain), according to your "accent". Well this is crucial because depending where you come from is the price you get and they know you will pay. For example if you come from Spain you get a MUCH cheaper price than if you come from Mexico because spanish tourists in Turkey as seen as "Cheap" where as if you come from Mexico you have to have money just to get there. The same goes to almost every language in the planet. So be very, very careful they are the best negotiators on the planet. The Spice market is difficult because they will do just about anything to rip you off, Fore example I tried to purchase a Can of Beluga Caviar. I was offered a taste of an opened can every time I mentioned my intent. I was always given a can that loss EXACTLY like Iranian Beluga Caviar even with the government seal. I would opened the can that was given to me saying that if it was the same I tasted I would pay for it and IT WAS NOT. It was a cheap imitation. this happened over 35 times in 35 different vendors. In other word go as a tourist purchase very cheap touristy things and thank yourself for not falling for a trick that is as old as the country.Meuseums are incredible to visit. it was one of the greatest empires in human History. There is so much to see and so much to visit I would either pick hilights of everything or dedicate to one specific theme and stick to it.Awesome city, women MUST be aware of dress code EVERYWHERE, and INCREDIBLE culture.

this is the third time i visit istanbul and still istanbul one of the best city in town. Hagia Sophia Topkapı Palace and Dolmabahçe Palace and blue mosque. cistern basilica and more other site are great
Museum. Istanbul is like a museum itself. There is history everywhere, you should visit Topkapı Palace, Blue Mosque and Dolmabahçe Palace where the biggest leader of Turksish people died
Istanbul. Istanbul as a very nice city doesn't have very polite people. Specially the shopkeepers were very rude and not fair with the foreigners.

Try BOTH sides of Galata Bridge. Sultanhamet & Taksim are Both interesting to see. Old, cultural versus modern & vibrant. Galata Bridge links the 2. Couldnt choose which side represents the best as both show Historic Istanbul. Dolmabache Palace & Mosque on Taksim side, with NUMEROUS Historic sites walkable around the Blue Mosque. The Aya Sopia Hamam (Turkish Bath) is expensuve but a FANTASTIC Experience if you have never tried one before,
Fabulous City. Nothing to dislike. A vibrant cosmopolitan city. Plenty to see and do A must is the spice market.We spent 8 hours walking around the city. but there is a tram service.
Very interesting. Loved this part of Istanbul as there are so many interesting places to see and centuries of history to explore

Always tempting. Even though we live in Istanbul, we also love taking the tram and strolling through Spice Market, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and Grand Bazaar. It is a must-see for anybody visiting Istanbul. Near Spice Market eat lunch in Pandeli or Hamdi Restaurant, In Grand Bazaar look for your magical carpet and have a coffee at the coffee shop in the bazaar.

Istanbul Crossroads of History. Great combination of historical sites Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Bascillica Cistern, Grand Bazzar and much more all within a stones throw. Byzantium, Constantinople, Istanbul form the layers of Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman Empires. The historical value parallels Rome with so many layers of different civilizations. The only problem with such a concentration of sites is you get the concomitant concentration of tourists, tourist cuisine offered in tourist restraints, carpet and trinket sellers, wherever you go you have to run a gauntlet of purveyors of crap, and every one tries to rip you off, it's part of the experience.

More Med than exotic.. I thought Istanbul would have been far more exotic or oriental but I was reminded time after time of any other major Mediterranean city. Alot of places to eat near Aya Sofia were overpriced. Something I did like though were some little quiet parks and squares which gave me time to absorb the atmosphere of the city.

A must when vistiting Istanbul. You may go with an organized tour, or you may go alone, but you must go visit the historical part of Istanbul. Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Grand Bazaar, the Egeptian Market...I would recomment doing it alone, you can do it at your prefered time, and you may use the tramp and metro to get their, you will save especially if you were a group.

Super. Simply Unforgettable ..
Worth Every Minute .. Prepare your self for long Ques and Allow for some time in your Tour Trip

Try the Bazaar and Spice Market. Some travellers are put off by pushy sellers - don't be! These guys are plying their trade in the way they know best. But my experience has been positive. The traders are friendly and looking to drive a bargain. The main tip is don't be afraid to say no and walk away - but be polite about it.The Bazaar sees stalls helpfully group in sections for silver, leather, pashminas etc. So you can compare prices. An Istanbul resident told me the starting price is usually 30-40% inflated - so that is a helpful guideline. In the spice market some stalls are clearly marked "ticket price" or "fixed price" - so you know they won't haggle.Go with a friend if possible if only for moral support!

WOW!!!. We were fortunate to stay a block away from the Hippodrome, so each morning and evening we went by the Blue Mosque , the Hagia Sofia, and the Hippodrome. Simply beautiful both at day time and at night.

amazing place. every tourist will visit this area in day time but don't miss it at night !! its completely different, the lights,blue mosque, hagia sophia, water fountain, small bazar & many restaurants.

Take the time to see this area. August was a really HOT month to visit & crowds of tourists were everywhere. Once you established (in a nice friendly way) that you were not interested, or had done "that boat trip" or "already eaten" or "already bought a rug" the hawkers in front of shops were really satisfied then, just to talk to you about your holiday, or where you come from, if you are liking Istanbul and they let you go on your way with a smile and a good bye - & of course the mandatory please come back & see me if you want to buy something later, is always added. But Tourists don't have to be rude to the Turkish locals. They will take no for an answer.

Lots to see. No visit to Istanbul is complete without visiting the Historic area. So much to see. Istanbul is a huge city and the traffic and congestion is amazing. Using the Trams to get around is easy, quick and cheap. Be prepared for the rug salemen trying to lure you into their stores to view their carpets. Either ignore them or be firm in your response that you don't want to visit and they'll leave you alone.

LOVE IT. I didn't know what to expect when we decided to visit Istanbul. This place is UNREAL. The history is almost unmatched in the world, the people are amazing.. this is a place that you MUST visit

Don't miss it!. Don't come to Turkey without planning a couple days in the historic part of Istanbul! There's so much to see and do that you won't be able to get through everything in just one day. Some of the sites, especially Topki Palace and Hagia Sophia, must be given the time they deserve to fully appreciate them.

a must see!. Despite visiting the places with a tour group, go once more by yourself and really visit the places. The Topkapi Palace is large and very interesting but the place is full of people. Take your time and visit it. It is really worth it!!

Take me back to Constantinople. I wish I had had more time to explore Istanbul. This city is truly magical. I went to the Grand Bazaar (my favorite), the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. The Topkapi Palace was closed or else we would have visited that too. We toured a Turkish rug making factory and were taught how to tie a few knots. I stayed at a hotel in Sirkeci. I fell in love with Istanbul in less than 24 hours, and old love to return.

Graet Places. Graet Places to visit, fees are little high, 25 TL per place.
topkapi is the best.
sultan ahmed mosque is very unique.

WOW Istanbul. For the first time in Istanbul, we visited Top Kapi palace, Ayasufi mosque, Blue mosque, Basilic cistern and Dolmabahche.Dolma Bahcha is really astonishing and original which worth then times the tickets you buy, the same for Ayasufia mosque and Cistern. Unfortunately the Top Kapi palace is restored very badly which you feel it is rebuilt not restored, you will not see anything from 15th or 16th century.

Nice, clean and safe. There is so much to see, streets are clean, and there are decent public toilets everywhere! People are nice and helpful. Although there is lot of "advertisers" for restaurants or shops, they are not too annoying - nice smile and "no, thank you" is enough. And we felt safe even in late evening hours.All mosques we visited were beautiful and people are very tolerant for visitors.
fantastic tour. like accessibility, flexible timings & helpful staffdislike lack of organization so crowdness appear heavier than what really it is
Limited Interest For Us. Istanbul is a very busy city. Pretty clean and people are friendly. But, for me, there really isn't anything of special interest. I'm glad we visited just for the experience.

" Never enough Time". The title is too true of this magnificent city and all it has to offer historically. We are lucky that this great modern city, with its sweeping history, has been preserved enough to enable us to follow that history ; visit and appreciate the ancient monuments, walls, frescoes whilst still enjoying the very modern amenities on offer. Know what you most want to see and set off......yes, you will be hassled ( that is normal ), yes, you will see sights that upset you ( that too is normal ) but you will be more that compensated if you truly look. To me, this city is like walking through a living museum - as are many other areas of Turkey. Make the most of it.

Amazing. This city if full of history and culture and cant be missed. ive visited istanbul Historic area over 6 times and i would like to go again. Love love love Advice: choose the right season to visit (Autumn and Spring are perfect) (Winter is amazing but waaaaaay too cold) (Summer ! FORGET ABOUT IT)

Awesome history and culture!. Liked very much the ease of travelling/sightseeing around main sites of Istanbul. Lots of things within walking distances in Sultanahmet Square, and great atmosphere with locals and travellers alike, everyone very friendly, only wish is I could have stayed longer. Visited Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Basillica Cistern and Grand Bazaar - awesome.

magical!. every corner of every street is filled with the unknown and beautiful. forget the map and plannings. streets of istanbul are completely unpredictable. and yet they are full of things to discover and observe. just give yourself time to wander where the road takes you and then just catch a cab for a ride back.

ancient istanbul. I love ,love it, love it. I love going to different places but I'm not much of a tourist. Istanbul! you can spend hrs just wondering around the cobble stones meeting the fantastic people & indulging in their hospitality. Can't wait to go back.
Magical city, history around every corner. This is a magical city where I would love to have a month to just walk around the neighborhoods, sit in cafes, absorb the ambience!

experience tham. A hundred simbols are too small amount to describe everything you could experience in Istanbul, that gem on the world map. It`s a matter of prestige and measure of civility to visit Istanbul and to spend som dayes in it.

history in every corner. There is so much to see and do in Istanbul that a short trip is just not enough. I suggest people should avoid the hot months as some of the attractions like Topkapi palace where you have to walk a lot can become a bit of a nightmare for kids.I found it very crowded as we started off for attractions at around 10 am , if you leave early you can miss the crowd and the heat which really gets to you.Save your money and buy stuff from around spice market rather than buying anything from Grand Bazaar. For the cruise i suggest go for a decent slightly expensive one around sunset to catch the best view.
Istanbul. Excellent !! loved every moment from the culture to the exotic indoor bazaar to the small Irelands that are not fair to explore.

Istanbul. When staying in Sultanhemet you are within reasonable walking distance of the Blue Mosque, the Bosphorous, the Grand Bazaar and Spice Market and many other histprical and interesting sights in Istanbul

Bosphorous joy. The day trip along the Bosphorous was delightful from the moment we were picked up from the hotel to being brought back to our hotel. Although there is a "fixed" price we were able to obtain a 15 euro discount for each of us. The pick up arrangements worked very well and the boat was comfortable and in the afternoon the canopy was drawn on the upper deck to provide some shade. Don't sit near the steering area as the noise from the broadcasted information is really deafening. Drinks are available on board and at times the crew brought them round so that you did not have to move. An ear splitting commentary fully enabled one to have an understanding of the history of the buildings along both banks and was truly enchanting. The only bad aspect was being taken for the included lunch at the Loumi cafe which was well below an acceptable standard.

great. Simply great, enjoyed every minute visiting the historical places and Istanbul is rich of those.The number of mosques that are well built and beautiful are imazing, I will go back there again and again and again.
A must. If you o anything on your first day in Istanbul is to go to haga Sophia and blue mosque and visit these two.Make ure you take the audio tour of the haga sophia, plan at least three hours here

The best place have been im my life!. Sweet Turkey always shining!!! Miss a lot and hope to vizit again as soon as possible!!!! Very friendly people living in Istambul!! Food is amazing as usual just dont have words to explain the feeling? Just wonderful place in the world!!!!!
safe , vibrant and amazing. the historical sites and sounds exceeded our wildest dreams.. an absolute must visit on any travellers list... and totally safe
Exotic and amazing. Just as described in the title. I was completely amazed by the amazing architiecture from blue mosque, hagia sophia and all the hisctorical buildings along bosphorus cruise

Very Interesting City. We mostly wandered around the old city and actually stayed few nights in Sultanahmet. It is very noisy until 1-2 PM during the summer if you stay there. In the afternoon not too many people at the restaurants and coffee shops and at night when gets cooler everyone is literally on the street. People sit in the grassy areas and hang out with friends and family. Probably will go back and visit more places.

Unbelievable monuments - blurred (& not always prevalent) history- obscured by money hungry people. Istanbul is a remarkable city with rich history though unfortunately it seems to be largely influenced by money & people constantly wanting our money. We enjoyed the sights & we're glad we read up on the history of each place on our own. Walking around & travelling on trams was not a problem- Istanbul is easy to get around (when taxi drivers were willing to charge us the price according to the meter) though we were often left hungry with overpriced meals that consisted largely of bread. In previous visits, Istanbul left a remarkable impression regarding food & people. Unfortunately, with this recent visit, we were quite disheartened.

A step between past and future. Go visit basilica Cistern. My teenage daughter was immediately convinced to give up shopping and visit also other historical places after the trip to Basilica Cistern. Topkapi Palace is another must see, especially after the renovation. The audio guide is not exactly necessary. The most impressive is Aya Sophia church. I hope they will wash away the Muslim motives to reveal the fantastic byzantine mosaics and icons.
in each corner history. this city was capital of Islam and roman empire. you will have that great mix. blue mousqe area and Bazzars are must
exotic and friendly. the historic areas are well preserved and clean in spite the thousands od people that cross every street all day in Istambul. The result is fascinating and intimidating

One of the great cities of the world. A city with a heritage of three empires: eastern capital of the Roman empire, capital of the Byzantine empire and eventually it was all that was left, and capital of the Ottoman empire. There are remarkable structures of great antiquity. Mixed in is a modern city. There are places you must see in the older part of the city and things you must do. Unfortunately the city has grown to the point where a tourist (or at least this tourist) can feel intimidated. In any case everyone should see this historic city which has become a major metropolis in modern times, influenced by the east but looking west.

Grand Bazaar. We took the tram from Kabatas to Suktanahmet. Very convenient. Walked around Nuriosmaniye Caddesi and had lunch before we ventured into the bazaar. It was overwhelming in a fantastic way. The merchants were inviting, nice, and friendly. Of course there were so many things to look at and buy......It is a world of its own, a place to breathe in and explore the sights and sounds. A number one must do in Istanbul.
Amazing history class. visiting Istanbul's old town is an open air history class where people who had the opportunity to study world history to feel it alive...
Very historical city. so many place to visit maybe one week is not enough, just ask for more information from your hotel or just have a look on net before traveling.
Great City. There is so much to see and do, very inspiring. Go early to avoid the queues! ........................................
Old but charming. Walked through cobble stone streets to many significant historical sites in Sultanahmet. Very hot in July!!
Topkapı. Topkapı palace is my favorite place. I really enjoyed to walking around near Gulhana Park and Topkapı Palace.

This is a great city for people interested in history.. Aya Sofya is still magnificent. Read about it before hand and bring the book with you. Do not hire a guide. They are over-prcied and not strong English speakers. It is close to the Bue Mosque and the Grand Bazzar.

Cool city to visit!!. Please watch out for the TAXI SCAM of giving them a $50 lira note and then they hand it right back and say you only gave them a $5 lira note. They quickly do slide of hand and exchange it for a $5 lira and make you pay another $50 lira!! This happened 3 times. This happened to other tourists as well. Hold the money in your hand and say what you are handing over.

The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and museum and Bosphorus night trip as well as the Bursa Green trip, Princess Island. food, people , the places everything better and nothing to say for dislike,The local Transportation system is better weather, Rail, Road or water way,nice shopping centres like Jewahir, Ollivium and media market at Zaitunburu, nice Taksim square and all the historical places

Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. It might be a tourist trap but you have to experience it. It's very hard to walk through the Grand Bazaar without buying something - we bought a carpet and overall we have been very happy with our purchase.
Gorgeous. Hike around and peek your head into any mosque you pass by. Women should carry a head scarf so they can enter any of them. Sometimes the most unassuming looking mosques are amazing inside.
History in Istanbul. Plenty to do and see. But istanbul is a massive place so research your hotels localation well. Tourist areas keep clean and tidy.
Gorgeous. Eveywhere you step is just beautiful. Sultanhamet is lovely. Everything about it. Just go! The mosques are there ;)

Grand Bazaar. This was interesting to walk around, although a lot of stalls sell the same thing at different prices. The Bazaar is split into specialty areas which helps if you are shopping for something in particular. The building architecture is fascinating.

Hop On - Hop Off. Great way to get to know what is there and what to come back to is the Hop On Hop Off bus. Circling past the Sultanahmedt, the Roman Wall, the Golden Horn, definitely worth seeing and doing.
A must while in the city. You feel history, glory, and vibrant present, full of attactions and things to look, buy or watch, lovely area

Istanbul - worth more time to explore. Istanbul was a wonderful surprise. The historic area is full of wonderful mosques, markets, restaurants and friendly people. We wished we had allowed long time to explore outside the old city ... maybe next year.

First Experience with Trip Adviser. This is first time that I used Trip Adviser during a trip to Istanbul on the advise of my son.I found it extremely useful and handy.Best thing I found was its ability to work off line,so never get stranded,Trip Adviser is always there to help. Well done job by the Trip Adviser and keep updating all the new additions.I would recommend making it more simpler to use
Fantastic Location. So close to most of the historic sites and actually inside the histic city. The evening stroll was a highlight.

Historic Area. So what was the historic area, the Grand Bazaar, totally for tourists it felt like. The spice bazaar was more exciting to me, so many things to eat, smell and simply taste. The people there were a lot pleasanter, and did not get in your face like in the Grand Bazaar.The Mosques, buildings, all very old.I liked having lunch at the Pudding shop...yummmmmmm
Loved Istanbul. Our first visit to Istanbul will not be our last. Beautiful City, warm people, great food. We were enchanted.

difficult to go around since english is not widely spoken. since people do not speak english widely sometimes it is very confusing to go around. taxis are always robbing you in many ways so be carefull to be less robbed than average. only taxis from hotel were ok, others will charge 5x more and cheat you on the money bills.

history in abundance. impressive architectural structures! The Topkapi museum stunned us with their collections. Surprisingly did not have to stand too long in queues and could finish all the important buildings in one day and yet have time left over for a casual walk down the Bosphorus.

hippodrome in Istanbul. Visit to hippodrome was interesting.Chariot races held several hundred years ago, betting of yesteryears etc were explained by the guide, surviving obelisks/ruins the present day presented very good photo options

Galata Tower. Galata Tower has amazing views!
Blue Mosque just beautiful.
We went during Ramadan and the general environment after 7.30 p.m. was really nice. All families sharing together
This city is soooo beautiful. I was so surprised at how truly beautiful Istanbul is. I loved every experience and every corner of this fantastic place
Istanbul. good facilities great history hagia Sofia is amazing,definitely go to dolmabahce palace shows the ottoman oppulance
Love to visit again. Like everything.dislike taxi,you hv to be careful while paying to taxi driver,if it is local currency it's ok,but you may be cheated if u give him$100 note
Explore Istanbul. We found that the best way to explore the historic areas of Istanbul is by foot - so bring the good walking shoes

attractive historical places. historical places are so intresting and I enjoyed from visiting
for exampla: hagia sophia, topkapi palace

I fell in love with Istanbul!. Istanbul is a great city, steeped in magnificent history! I've enjoyed visiting several times. The people are friendly and helpful...although as a tourist, sometimes they want to be "tour guides" or take you to their carpet shop. If you aren't interested in that, politely decline and they will leave you alone. The views of the Bosphorus, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Basilica are not be missed.
Big noisey crowded. This city is evidently always packed with tourists. Join a guided tour. They will pick you up at your hotel, show you around, and bring you back. Choose the half day tours.

History. Everything is well located to the walking traveller if you are in the old city no more than half hour to most anything ,grand bazaar spice bazaar,blue mosque ,Agia Sophia ,basilica cistern,topkapi palace,bosphouros ,galata,train station of the orient express etc etc great place friendly people highly recommended
Hagia Sophia. We like the Hagia Sophia and the cistern tour. The local hucksters were a turn off, but the city was beautiful.

Fantastic. Sultanahmet is the place to be if you love history and culture. Just wandering the streets is a trip back in time and the people are friendly and helpful. Despite the political issues at Taksim, you would not notice them here. The city was crowded with tourists, and many were Americans. The city has so much to offer, so spend plenty of days here.

Very Middle Eastern. Unlike the more modern areas across the Golden Horn or the Bosphorus, old town is very Middle Eastern. Most (about 80%) of the women wear head covering of the full burqua. There are substabtially more men then women on the street. This was a shocker since Istanbul is usually presented as a mostly European city.

WOW in istanbul. So full of history and friendly people. We would need to go again to see it all. The true East meets West. We were there just before the riots and Taxim Square was full of Turkish families as were the parks around the palace.
Istanbul a walk through time. It is a place where ever you walk there is history form the market to the mosque's. A great place to visit and enjoy.
Blew me away. Istanbul is a must visit. Was only there for 2 days, want to go back soon. See the underground caverns for a special treat
Take a historic tour. We took a historic tour of the Ayasofia, blue mosque, and Topkapi Palace. Very interesting, worth doing.

City not to miss. There is so much to see.Travel is easy and organised.While the city offers all the comforts and conveniences of the West they retain their culture.So much to see.People are very friendly.Beautiful city.

A TRIP BACK IN TIME. We visited so many of the attraction area...too many to choose from. Best to get in on a tour since there is an incredible amount of history ther. The mosques are so unique and a must to see. The outer islands called the princes islands a must on your list. No cars on those islands, be prepared to walk around and enjoy the peace and quiet. The fortress was another place to see, beautiful view of the asian side of Istanbul. Enjoy.
"Amazing trip". Istanbul is different from any other city. It's amazing the musulman and occidental mix. The deep voice coming from the Mezquitas and envelopping the city is something to live.
great to visit all in a day or two. There are many famous and infamous historical areas nearby istanbul. Not all are known by taxi drivers., so must have to show them into map.
Must see. Take 2 days at least to see everything, every single thing must be seen. The sunset is a special and beautiful moment
Incredible. Simply incredible. We only visited Istanbul but I would like to go back to Turkey and travel around a lot more. There is so much history and Istanbul is so cosmopolitan.
Awesome. Everything there was awesome. You can visit all the important historical places just by walking around !!

blue house mosque. the moment you enter the prayer area the fine artistry mesmerises and spell binds the visitors.
tips:
carry a scarf(covering of head is mandatory inside the prayer area)
legs and arms are to be covered.
enjoy
Great dolmaBAhja. Great palace to visit.shows the ottman empire palaceses and office of the sultans.shows great arctic designs and geniusity
vancouver tourist. when you enter you don;t know what to expect but the architecture and the way it was built was unimaginable even the writings on the walls and some murals were outstanding

If You Enjoy Wandering This is the Place to do It!. Historic Istanbul is a wonderful world of sounds and smells and wandering the streets, indulging in the early 20th century architecture, and taking coffee at any one of a number of delightful shops is worth the time and effort.
Blue Mosque. Make sure you check out the mosques, they are truly magnificent. Be prepared to cover up when you enter but they provide scarves and skirts if you come unprepared.

street food. The great thing about Istanbul is the food. Buy small amounts of different cakes, fruits,maize,nuts fish etc and munch while walking and looking. Enjoy the friendliness of the Turkish people. They are sooo nice!
Visit Yasmak Sultan hotel and take a walk. You can visit all most important historics waliking around. This is the nicest thing of Yasmak hotel. Just do it and you can see a lot.

The colors of Istanbul. I liked it all. The Blue Mosque, The Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, the Roman Cisters, Agia Sofia (and don't miss Little Agia Sofia - quite beautiful) We took a ferry cruise ont he Bosphorus, a local ferry and enjoyed the views. A trip to the Spice Bazaar was a feast for the senses. Saw whirling dervishes. Had a turkish bath. Did a walk along the Golden Horn and took a cable car up to Pierre Loti. The view from there was beautiful. Can't wait to return.

Feel the fantastic Ottaman era. I stayed at Sultanahmet region in Fatih, It was really right choice as we were able to experience the taste of the historical Istanbul with the many attractions in the area including the blue mosque, Aya Sophia, Hammams, and many others. Just walking in this area was nice as you can feel the authentic features in every corner.

Little Aya Sofya. No tour buses or mob scene, no hawkers of Bosphorus cruises or city tours -- contemplative quiet, and a tree-lined courtyard with artisan shops . . . and a small cafe that serves Turkish tea and ayran.

Far too crowded. Undoubtedly for Americans there are very unusual and interesting sights. But, it is really a hassle. Tourist buses are everywhere, lined up one after the other. Should learn to use the tram, which is very easy. Streets are winding like snakes and never marked.Shop keepers actually come out to see if they can get you in, so I always had the feeling that we were being "hustled". This is especially true in the old city.Would strongly recommend a private tour if its possible. The tour guide will steer you around the bottle necks and jams. The grand bazar is something that can easily be missed (unless you want an experience where little shops are on top of one another). On the other hand, the Spice Bazar is very interesting and not nearly as crowded. Great iced cream.
Citytrip. Nice area with all historical monuments.All are close to each other and can easily be done by walking !
Do not MISS. The price of entry is well worth payingDo not forget to get a guide - leaflet, book or audio the choice is yoursI did not and missed too much, I will go back and get the guide next time
Fantastic trip!. Istanbul...vow!My advice: chalk out your own plan to visit places of your interest and don't take guided tour. They are expensive without much added value

Multiple cultures atop one another. The ancient part of the city of Istanbul provides a glimpse of two millennia of history - all within walking distance of one another. The Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Palaces (and the museum and royal treasury), and even the underground cistern (see James Bond's "From Russia with Love") are open for just wandering our tour guides. And don't forget the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Markets - which can be day long visits in and of themselves.

a city must see. I stayed in the historic areas of Istanbul. The streets are uneven with interlocks from hundreds of years back. The drivers are all super in order to drive through these curly narrow streets. The merchants on the streets are too friendly and a bit aggresive. Lots lots to see here. The attractions are close to each other.
amazing. everywhere you went the was alot of history about Istanbul. The sites were fantastic. We got lost a couple of times and the locals went out of their way to help you

Fantastic historical setting and beautiful buildings. Our hotel was right in the middle of the Sultanahmed area so we spent a lot of time visiting the Mosques and other places of historical interest. Excellent!

Hagia Sophia Museum. We visited this museum that once was a church, then turned into a Mosque. After building the Blue Mosque, they turned the Hagia Sophia into a Museum. You can still see faded pictures of Christ and other religous artifacts.

History abounds. All over the old city one can find history from Byzantine and Ottoman Empires to Christian influences. Make sure to get a good guide or history book of Istanbul to fully appreciate the many architectural styles the city has to offer.
A gem in this wonderful city. Go early and avoid the cruise ship queues, worth getting up early or even going in the early evening. Avoiding the heat.

so much history, so much to see. If you find yourself a hotel in the old part of town, I highly suggest that you walk, walk, walk. There's so much to see. My wife and I did about 20 miles in two days, and it was well worth it.
Fascinating. We hired a personal guide who knew a lot of background history and information as he had lived in the City all his life. Money well spent
