A must visit when you are in Istanbul. Super convenient with all the spots at walkable distance
Very well labeled
Very well connected with public transport
Convenient with hotels, restaurants and some street food around
Get the MuseumKart if you are seriously into museums as it saves a fair bit of money

Many and Countless. Each of the historical sites are one over the top of the other in terms of its ratings and how they overwhelm you, with the designs and the beauty.
Istanbul's historical past is extremely great, with touch of Greek, Egyptian, Byzantine, Ottoman and many other influences.

History in abundance. The multi faceted face of Istanbul, the centre of the Christian faith for many many years is remarkable in its acceptance multi religious places of worship. The Blue Mosque is stunning and the sights and smells of the Grand Bazaar are too many to list. A amazing city full of culture and beaty.

amazing. Walking through the historic areas of the city are amazing. I can't say enough how beautiful the city. We went all over with a one year old and a stroller, so families with young ones can do it - might be some hauling strollers up and down steps, but worth it.

Must in Istanbul!. It is important you take time out to visit all the historic places of Istanbul e.g. Sultan Ahmet, Fatih, Eyup Sultan etc. They hold amazing treasures and beautiful buildings, mosques, and gardens,
There was no sign of protests / riots and we didnt see anything during our entire stay there (13th June - 20th June 2013)

Beautiful Istanbul. We like everything in Istanbul,It's a city that we love!
Public transport is very crowdy but the people stay calm and friendly.

Totally the Best In Every Phase of Our Tour. Wow! A tour company that really cares what YOU, the traveler wants to see, do and moves at your desired speed. No rushing, slow walking is ok...and the Tour Guides are so knowledgeable, I put down my travel book. Comfortable pace, New Vehicles and a separate driver. Not a driver/tour guide combo. Two well qualified people.They took us away from the usual touristic sites, after we did the tour sites. We travelled to places most tourists do not even know existed. We ate at a seafood restaurant at the end of the public Bosphorous Ferry ride. This is where the Bosphorous enters into the Black Sea in Istanbul. Fantastic food way out of the city....on the water. Everything was inclusive, fees, ferry passes. OUTSTANDING!!!Curio Travel. knows how to treat their guests. Driver and guide was always on time, very professional and earned our ***** grade.

Location. We were fortunate to be staying at a hotel (Sultanhan) within walking distance to the major mosques (all a must see) the spice market and the grand bazaar. All worth any time you have to spend visiting.
Fascinating!. My first visit to Istanbul and we stayed in this area and toured the main attractions here. A wonderful experience.
the old town. All areas in the old town are fanatastic, try and get there early to miss excursions queues, the blue mosque opens at 0830.
Everyone should visit Istanbul!. Fascinating city - old and new, east meets west, great food, transport, friendly people. I will definitely be back!

What a city - our 6 days in Istanbul. My sister and I spent 6 days (5 nights) in Istanbul in June 2013. Time was just enough to see a lot, but not everything, so we want to come back and repeat experiance but also explore more. We were exploring city during the day, which was our aim, so we can not say a thing about nightlife. We booked hotel Agan in Sultahmet area, few minutes distance from Gulhane tram station (perfect location and choice).We used perfect Istanbul public transport. Right at the airport I bought Electronic card for public transport and refilled it with 40 TL. 6 metro stations and 17 tram station and we are at our hotel. I highly recommend Istanbul public transport which is very inexpensive, comfortable and best way for getting around.First day we bought Museum Card, 72 TL. We used it for Archeological Museum, Topkapi Palace and Harem, Haghia Sofia and Mosaic Museum. It is not valid for Basilica Cistern and Dolmabasce Palace, which are the "must see". Next time I wouldn't go for this card but for seperate tickets. It is hard to visit all cites that Museum Card is valid for in 72 hrs.Day 1 - arrival day. After settling in hotel, we walked around - Gulhane Park, Eminonu, bought Turkish Delight, had dinner at the restaurant.Day 2 - Archeological Musem, Topkapi Palace with Harem. Next time I would dedicate 1 day for Museum, 1 for Topkapi. To much to see, admire, enjoy...Day 3 - Haghia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Hipodrome, Basilica Cistern, Mosaic MuseumDay 4 - Bosphorus tour.We took ferry from Eminonu and went to Anatolu Kavagi (less than 2 hrs trip, last stop on Asian side). Round trip is 25 TL. Takes 30 min to climb to the fortress from Bizantine period. And there -breathtaking view. Nice restaurants on the way. upon return we went to Taxim by public transport ( I should mention that all before we did by foot). Galata Tower.Day 5 - Dolmabahce Palace, Spice market, Blue Mosque again, Suleyman MosqueDay 6 - checked out, went to airport, left laguage there and than went to Forum Istanbul Shopping Mall by metro and visitet aquarium.Every day was a new wonderfull experience. We will definitely going back.This trip was not expensive either: less than 500 Eur per person incl hotel, transport (public), entance fees, meals and refreshment, even some souvenirs.You must add air ticket.I love Istanbul.

The Hidden Treasures. The 3 day Galipoli, Troy & Ephesus Tour provided by †he New Deal Travel Agency is simply a must if this is your first trip to Turkey. The guides are young enthusiastic walking encyclopaedias .The sites can be breathtaking and then there is the 5 star accommodation ( i recommend this option ). Everything is organised. All you have to do is go along and enjoy !

Book a hotel in Gülhane district. I was in Istanbul for more than 2 month and visited all part of Istanbul (both European & Asian), and now I can recommend you with the highest level of confidence that "Gülhane" district is the best place for tourists who want see the Old City of Istanbul.By booking a hotel in this area you can reach "Blue Mosque", "Saint Sophia", "Basilica Cistern", "Small Saint Sophia", "Gülhane Park", "Archaeology Museum", "Topkapi Palace", "Obelisk of Theodosius", "Mosaic Museum", "Galata Bridge", "Tunnel" and many more in less than 10 minutes walking; also you can reach to "Galata Tower", "istiklal street", "Taksim Square" and some other historic places on feet in about 30 minutes (Taksim square in about 45 minutes).If you don't want walk, you can use the Gulhane tramway station which will bring you almost everywhere in European side.With about 5 minutes walking you will be in Eminonu which has several Ferry stations to many different destinations in both Asian and European side. Also you can find Bosphorous tour and Golden Horn tour ferries here.If you want to go to Prince Island, just use the Tramway and go to "Kabatash" (about 15 minutes), there will be several different ferries to Prince Islands and also other parts of the town (also you can reach "Dolmabahche Palace" from "Kabatash" by 10 minutes walking).Have fun.
Great sightseeing. Take a camera as there are lots to see and do. Great walking around the area - wear comfortable shoes!

Old City Istanbul - Sultanahmet. Liked:- the atmosphere, the people, the bazaars, the shopping!Disliked:- the street sellers (gets a little wearing after a while, found saying 'no' in German helped get ride of them).Disturbed by:- the very young children street sellers, who are out all hours, day & night; and who often sleep on the streets or the river bridge.

Fantastic so much to see in such a small area. I first went to Istanbul some 8 years ago with my teenage daughter. This time I took my wife. If you stay in Sultanahmet area (I particularly recommend any hotel on the street Akbiyik Caddesi) then you are within 10-15 minutes walk of 75% of the major sights, plus you're close to the Sultanahmet Tram stop for if you want to go further afield. Trams are easy to use, very modern and very frequent. If you're only there for a few days don't bother with the Travel Card, just buy Tram tokens (they're currently 3 Lira for unlimited distance).We only experience queues when visiting Hagia Sofia (this was around noon because we'd already done Blue Mosque first). We had to queue for about 20 minutes to buy tickets, and then another 20 minutes to actually get in, but I didn't mind, because Hagia Sofia is truly amazing when you consider how old it is. The queue for Topkapi Palace wasn't bad, just a few minutes, but once inside there were 15-20 minute queues for each of the major attractions such as the Treasury, so we did give them a miss, and enjoyed the harem tour instead. BEFORE YOU GO : do search the Internet and print the latest public transport map for Tram and Metro. The ones in the guide books are 3-4 years out of date, and they have been doing some amazing building work. We got completely lost near Taksim Square entering the wrong metro station and needed a taxi to get back to Golden Horn. Even the maps at some of the tram stops etc aren't up to date, and there's more lines and stations opening in 2014-2015.
Great. Most of the historical places are nearby like blue mosque ,hagia sopia ,grand bazaar..you can do at your own no need to take group tours.
Amazing City. We saw so much and learned a lot too. no problem with protests going on during the time of our stay.

The Olde World meets the new. This part of Istanbul reveals the very history of the Olde World to us in modern times. It's filled with old buildings, alleyways, people everywhere bustling along doing their business or simply sitting in a huddle smoking. Doing this with a group is the better way to see it as one can be intimidated by some of the approaches made by those peddling their wares. Wear a hat in warm hot weather. Sit down and share a refreshment at one of the many cafes.

Join the Crowd with your digital camera and cellphone. The top three attractions are conveniently located in close proximity. So if you have survived the lines at Disney World, you will not mind waiting in line to spend more time with the crowd taking endless pictures that will never be seen again rather than just looking and appreciating. How about the man seated on the carpet in the "worshiper's area" of the Blue Mosque texting for at least 15 minutes ? Stand in the sun for an hour to spend a moment at Topkapi gazing at the famous dagger you saw in the movie. Turkey is a nice country and some of the people do not want to see the return of the Sultan. If you are in Istanbul you must see the "big three" but it wil not be a transformative experience.

nice sight seeing. blue mosque is very beautiful and worth to see it once , hagi sophia is beautiful as well , TOPKAPI palce is a huge musem with more islami relics . you need around 7-8 to see these places together

Exotic and full of history and intrigue. Wandering aimlessly through back streets with cobblestones and protruding balconies....a great city to explore ..shades of the Orient Express and a shoppers paradise with warrens so shops filled with anything and everything
A magical experience. Whether it had been resurrected or still in ruins, the beauty of the historical areas did not fade; they tell a story of their own.

Beautiful!. I can walk around the historic areas day after day without getting bored. Every street corner may suggest a pleasant surprise in the view hiding behind. People are very friendly and the not well known, quite mosques spread in the communities are very nice to visit. Just set so destination and walk around and one will be lost in the beauty of the historical Istanbul.

Fantastic treasures remind us of the rich and valuable Turkish past. We really enjoyed the three days spent in Istanbul, and were sorry not being able to visit all the existing beautiful places in the city. We did not like the heavy traffic which made us waste precious time, although we understand all big cities have similar problems.

Ayasofia. Amazing experience of feeling the different religious beliefs over various centuries under one roof. Once an orthodox church converted to catholic and later to Mosque unfolds many centuries in front of you. A heart touching experience!
Special. Just breath the atmosphere and you feel hundreds of years blow in your hair. All your reading in books of medeveal history will stand in front of you together with a romantic scent.
you can stroll around for days.... there is so much to see that this place will not get boring. you dont need an agenda, just walk around and take it in as it comes.
Clean and nice. it was really amazing to see how the sultans was living and thier furniture and palaces and hareem rooms
Historical Must-Dos. The major sights are all close together and within walking distance. Hire a guide though to give you some history and background.
so much to see. lots of walking throughout and googling up at the high cupolas and frescoes and minarets throughout all of Turkey

Don't miss ANY of them!. Did the usual mosque, cistern, museum tour - all were EXCELLENT! Don't miss the Archeology Museum - most tours by pass this wonderful museum. If you like statues and art - don't miss it.
Historic Areas are the Best. All of the History of Istanbul worth to see...you never bore over there...Day or night...shopping or rest...everything is excellent...
A wonderful city to explore. Istanbul, a bridge between east and west, has enough beautiful and historic sites to bring you back again and again.

where to go. The city - old, new, and the Asian side is filled with history. You can easily spend a week just examining the sites of Istanbul and its monuments. There are many places to visit - the Asker Museum, the Deniz Museum in Besiktas are truly a must, the latter has been closed for a few years, but may be open now. Not many go to these excellent museums. They possess objects not duplicated elsewhere. The Asker Museum has the marching tents of many of the sultans including that of Suleiman the Magnificent. A stroll along Istiklal is enjoyable as well - this is the main thoroughfare in Galata across the Golden Horn.
Mecca of History!. The city is extraordinarily rich with history...you can't go wrong...cultural, religious, geopolitical, geographic history. Incredible city!

Best locations city Center - walking distance. Like: Haya Sofia, City Cisterns, Blue Mosque, Grand Bazar..walk around, no need for a tour. Also take Hop On-Hop Off bus..good price and lots of information.

History lesson for all. The sights and sounds all add to this amazing experience as one walks and experiences first hand what were such distant facts from texts. Study a bit prior to going so you can benefit even more!
magic. istanbul, the only name makes u imagine old legends of sultans or ancient ottoman warriors. the city is magic and you can breathe its majesty all around. very recomended
Loved Istanbul. Loved Istanbul and will return here.A very cosmopolitan city with plenty to see and doGreat shopping, bus tour fantastic to the two continentsLoved Istanbul

Historical and exotic. The Sirkeci district in Istanbul is where all the action and sights are centrally located. With some research and travel books, one can easily navigate and tour the sights without a formal tour. Most sites offer audio guides for a fee, although not essential. When cruise ships are in port, the various sites can get over-whelmingly busy. Museum pass allows for entry to multiple historic sites, buildings and museums. Restaurants and vendors are everywhere, the merchants can get somewhat aggressive, trying to get your attention. Turkish delight is a very tasty treat not to be missed. The entire area is walkable and safe during the day.

See it while you can. Istanbul is a great and historic world city which has lost some of its luster from overpopulation, rampant development and horrendous traffic. Nevertheless, it's still a great place to experience and visit.

One of the great historic town in this world. Nothing else really to add. The Byzantine and the Ottoman Empires and civilisations are some of the greatest civilisations the world has known. And you can feel this, see this in old Istanbul.

One of the world's best tourist destinations. There are dozens of great reasons that the historic areas of Istanbul are included in UNESCO's world heritage sites. The primary attractions (Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar) were magnificent. I particularly enjoyed the Spice Bazaar and the Kumkapi district.

A brilliant city. Lucky Istanbul has kept much of its historic areas as so many other Turkish cities appear to have replaced them with ugly apartment blocks (although Istanbul has more than its fair share of those too). The historic areas are fantastic. So, strap on your walking shoes, get your self a walking guide map and off you go!

magical. A magical city. Exquisite mosques such as Sultanahmet, Rustem Pasha, and Suleimaniye, glorious Haghia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, the Cistern, Galata Bridge and Tower, Eminonu harbour, Gulhane Park, Bosphorus. Fabulous!
Istanbul is an Ancient City,. And, by Ancient, I mean lots of buildings, walls, walkways, that have been there since long before Christ.
Historic areas. Be aware that Istanbul is not flat! If walking wear comfortable shoes! Look at Guide leaflets for opening times as some places are not open every day.

Visit as much as you can. What can I say? We loved Istanbul! We had the fortune of meeting very nice people, and even though one of our tour operators was not up to par, we still enjoyed all the places we visited. The mixture of traditional Islamic architecture with Byzantine elements is dazzling and spectacular. My husband and I had so much exploring all those side streets filled with cafes and shops in Sultanahmet, visiting the historical buildings and mosques, and we didn't have enough. We will go back to this lovely city.

Beautiful, walkable, safe. We were blown away by the pride Istanbul takes in its historic area. The area was incredibly clean, lawns manicured, flowers blooming. We felt safe at all times. Some vendors were pushy which could be tiring but simply keep walking. Everyone, even the pushy vendors, were very nice. They took pride in their beautiful city.
Greatest and awe inspiring sights. My god the city takes your breath away. It's so tough to rate any of the sights each one is better than the other

Busy, eclectic but fascinating. Love the hustle and bustle of old Istanbul away from the main tourist attractions. People are really friendly and helpful and you can get a long way with a little Turkish, sign language and a smile. The attractions of course are on the whole a must see, but very busy. Away from them there are small cafes, bazaars and markets in the side and backstreets that give you a true local flavour in every sense. Get walking but with a good, detailed map and explore. Will get you both fit and hungry so you can enjoy the food on offer.
amazing areas. you might dislike getting tired of alking as it is a bit huge, but you would love the history and the scenary
Great Memories. Turkey is beautiful and I want to come back definitely! Having a great time for 10 days :) Hotel very near to Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia

So much to see, so little time. My (adult) daughter and I had 3 days to experience Istanbul. It was not enough, but it was all we had. We didn't have a tour guide, we decided to be our own guide. We were glad we did. We looked at the articles on TripAdvisor before we left to give us an idea of what we wanted to see.We divided our time between the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hippodrome, Bosphorus tour and the Grand Bazaar. Fortunately, everything is in a relatively small area, so even though time was limited, we were able to see and do quite a lot.It is an amazing city, we only scratched the surface, so will definitely have to come back and explore some more.

Fun, but watch out for cons. So many sites to see, but watch out for the quite friendly con artist. We had the pleasure of seeing most of the sites and felt blessed by our experience. We were conned twice and almost a third time. Watch out for the carpet salesman that offers you a 'great view at sunset from the top floor." We got out of a stressful situation by dropping highly placed people. The second came from a taxi guy that operated outside the rules (he was not at the stand). He quietly turned on the radio to a frequency and then sadi that the station number was the fee. Instead of 25.00, it was 43.50. We handed him a 50 and he took it, turned away from us and then turned back to say I had given him a 5. He got extremely mad. We gave him the additional 50 and he had the nerve to ask for a tip. The third con was from a shoe shine guy that 'accidentally dropped his brush in front of us. When we picked it up to give it to him, he was so grateful that he offered to shine my shoes as a thank you. Afterwards he demanded 18 liras. Outside of these three incidents, the sites, the food, the climate was fantastic. A visit to the Nardis jazz club and the Sirevi restaurant were the icing on the cake for an enjoyable visit.
So much history and culture!. The two great mosques (Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque - or the Sultanahmet), the hippodrome, and the Topkapi Palace are all in the same area for convenient visiting.
Beautiful City. Lovely place to visit. So many sights and so much to see. Our local guide was fantastic and knew all the history and best places to see.
Wonderful City to visit. The sights are all easily accessable and are breathtaking . to stand in what was the centre of the Eastern Roman Empire was awesome

Meeting the past. I like historical buildings,I like hospitality of the people,I dislike rush hours - you are driving and driving and.... to reach point B from point A it takes hours but I LIKE ISTANBUL

tips for visitors in Istanbul during a cruise stop. The place is wonderful and you must visit it. The matter is for visitors that are in Istanbul for few hours during a cruise stop and prefer to avoid shore excursions organised by the cruise ship.The harbour is not so far from city center but a taxi is highly recomended. Close to the pier only taxis for half day/day sightseeing are available...then you have to walk outside to get another one., Try to stop a taxi that runs along the main road... it's the only way. I've been in Istanbul several times but I never managed to find a cab driver who could speak english. If you are in Istanbul with plenty of time, you won't find a problem but if you are there for few hours only, you need to remember that things may not always be easy and/or fast. Not all taxi drivers get euros (10 euro to get to Haghia Sofia from Istanbul port) and won't stop for tourists and Most of them prefers tourists who pay for a tour and not for a drive. Sometimes it takes a lot of time because many of they won't let you get on their taxi. Traffic can be awful and in the busiest days you'll have to queue a lot for tickets for main sites. You can't pay with foreign currency, therefore go to a moneychanger or use yr cc but remember that not all counters accept cc and when you'll get to a wrong one you'll have to queue again ...The Bazaar is great but, if you are more than 2/3 people or travelling with children, remember that it's easy to get lost and even the turistic policemen usually can't speak english.In the morning get off the ship as soon as possible and give yourself plenty of time to visit the town because in Istanbul it's easy to waste time queuing or in a traffic jam or to find a cab.When we were there in April, the ship left with 30 min delay as they had to wait some buses (ship shore excursions) that were late due to the traffic...

Variety. Istanbul has been influenced by so many cultures that the variety of historic areas and sites is amazing. Ancient Greek, Roman, Byzantine, Ottoman, Kurdish, Arab, Persian, Armenian, Jews, Venetians, Genoese, English, German and more.
Magic Place. When I planned my trip to Istanbul, I thought I would find a city that was very old and the historical places not well kept, but I was totally wrong. The historical sites are great.

Get a guide!!. The guides in Istambul are well trained and know a lot .
We asked for a guide that could speak both English and Portuguese, and got one.

Old Istanbul. The whoe of the old Istanbul area, the historic area has lots of places to explore with lots of little gems to discover. Most of the places are within walking distance but as it is hilly it can be very tiring.Pace your self and whilst teh trams and buses can be used for short local journeys, the cost soon adds up.

Lot's of historic sites close by each other. In the old city all major attractions are close by each other which makes it very easy to visit the most in a couple of days, certainly if you booked your hotel in the same area, which has plenty of choice in every hotel star class. Be prepared that Istanbul is build on hills, so walking means that your road sometimes goes up!

Remarkable experience. Our children both drooled about Istanbul after their separate visits so we had to go to check out their observations. We were so pleased we did. It is full of tourists and queues can be long (avoid early to mid morning when everybody seems to go to the main sites) but all the sites were worth it. I don't know how to do it but it is a good idea to avoid the visits of the large cruise vessels being in town. Five were in port on the Saturday/Sunday of our visit but had gone on the Monday when everything was relatively calm and tranquil. Food, history, friendly people and remarkable sites made this a memorable trip.
Better than expected. Buzzing, clean and functioning. People friendly and welcoming. Felt safe and ordered with amazing sites to see

Wonder of the world. This definitely is one of the 7 wonders of the world. The covered bazaar, the spice market, the blue mosque, Agia Sophia. Everybody should visit once and see a part of history to make you awe with wonder.

Wonderful Trip. Spent four days in Istanbul. Loved every minute of it. Good taxi service - relatively inexpensive. Drivers mostly have a little English but many speak English very well. All that we encountered were polite to friendly and helpful. Nice, clean cabs. Used public transportation also. Once you get oriented to it, it is simple and very inexpensive. Mosques, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace etc speak for themselves. All were crowded but bearable. Took a day trip to Princes Islands. Terrific. Had a buggy ride around Adalar and then lunch at Milto's. See restaurant review. Visited with many interesting and friendly Turks. Be sure to sample Turkish wines- they are great.

It is Istanbul. I went to Istanbul and visited historic areas of Istanbul maybe ten times. I can do it another 10 and 10 times and i will never be bored.I think parisians should visit Istanbul, because if she could do, Paris would come and see Istanbul.Londeners should visit Istanbul, because if she could do, London would come and visit Istanbul.New Yorkers should visit Istanbul, because if she could do, New York would come and visit Istanbul...
must sees if you are in Istanbul. The Basilica Cistern is the most memorable for me. I came in with low expectations but I was awed when I came inside.

Short break in Istanbul. Very compact, loads of queues, beautiful skyline. Pack your walking shoes, hilly. We were staying west of the main tourist sights and the train was reliable and not too expensive. The tram was manic.
Wonderful. All the historic sites including the Blue Mosque and Grand Bizzar were great to see and very educational.

Amazing Welcoming city. We spent two days in Istanbul as a part of our Mediterranean cruise. This city was a highlight of our vacation, beside Italy. It's clean, reasonably priced, local people are very helpful and accommodating, food is amazing, public transportation is very useful. We feel safe there at any time and any places.

wonderful city!. We were so impressed by the city of Istanbul. The historic areas are plentiful. Compared to other cities in Europe that we visited, Istanbul is kept wonderfully clean and the people are warm and friendly. There is so much history at every turn and so much to see. You could spend a month here and not scratch the surface. Take your time and soak in the atmosphere!

Four days is not enough. Each day I had a full itinerary and I walked until I had blisters! Still I only saw a few of the main attractions and a fraction of the city. This is a wonderful place to be a tourist there are cafes and restaurants everywhere. It is easy to get around on the trams, underground and ferries. Taxis are not expensive either but it is not always possible to find a driver with good English so you need to know where you are going. We went in May and this was not the best choice in some ways. The weather was great but every tourist in the world seemed to be in Istanbul around Easter so the queues at some sites were pretty hard going. We booked a guesthouse between the Blue Mosque and the Aya Sofya right in the centre of Old Istanbul. I recommend you do the same and give yourself at least a week.
Exotic City to Visit. So much to see! Cisterns, Blue Mosque, Haggia Sophia, and the Topaki Palace. Beautiful city to visit I hope to return!
Amazing. Visit as much and as many sight as you can whilst you are here. Can be very tiring but well worth the effort. Wear good sensible foot wear and clothing and you are away!!
Shop Istanbul's Hans. When shopping, do not ignore the hans located between the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar. Great bargains are available, and you can see some of the wares being made.

Orientation tour. The mosques are overwhelmingly beautiful in design,but long lineups for the more popular, i.e. Blue Mosque.Go early morning and take water. Loved the Spice Bazaar, its size is manageable and much to see and buy.

A tremendous amount of fascinating history to explore. Istanbul has many historical well preserved sites to see. Plan carefully because the lines are very long at peak season. If you go with a tour, the tickets are usally included in the tour price.
Waw. Loved all historical monuments. Enjoyed Topkapi palce and the Sultan Ahmets mosque. The Aya Sophia museum was amazing. The galata tower was exceptionnal

“The Sultanahmet area is an essential area to visit. Huge traffic free area surrounding the Blue Mosque and Topcapi Palace. Even though we were early in the season there are lots of people. It's a good tip to buy the museum pass as it lets you go straight in and avoid the ticket queue, but not the security. To understand what you are looking at buy the audio guides. You will be pestered continually by sellers of everything from hats to cruises, so be prepared to smile but firmly say no and walk on. If you stop to talk you may find yourself being taken to a carpet shop, be warned.
you have to be here. it's really interesting part of Historical Istanbul. everybody have to see the place where history is breathing...
vibrant city. I loved the many and varied mosques, alleyways, people, calling to prayer sounds , the spice bazaar and the food.
Amazing. Our April visit brought big queues to main attaractions possibly due to four huge cruise ships docked

bazaar, blue mosque and muesem. My wife and IO visited the blue mosque, grand bazaar and the archeology/history museum. The best part IMHO was the history museum. Well worth the trip. Istanbul is a wonderful city. Probably one of my favorites. The combination of Asian and European makes it unlike any other city. If you go to the grand bazaar there is a restaurant (cannot remember the name) but you will see it before you get to the Irish pub on leaving the bazaar heading towards the Bosphorous. Wonderful food and service. They do serve alcohol.
The Sultanahmet area is a must. No need to tell much - just visit the area and enjoy the various buildings and monuments - and also the restaurants near by.

On the Bosphorus in a boat. Did a NIght trip and a day one. Obviously the Day one was better. A bit expensive, about 70 Euro for a day trip, but you get lunch with it. You can do a cheaper trip on the ordinary ferry which takes you further to villages along the Bosphorus, but I learnt this too late.

Historic. We only visited the Blue Mosque from inside and it was beautiful. We wanted to enjoy the real feel of the city so we walked around - ate a lot of corn, doner and their delicious cay (chai). I'd definitely recommend a walk to Istiklal Street across the Galata Bridge.
A must in Istanbul. One can't really go to Istanbul without spending time in this area can one. Allow a day or better split it between 2 days to soak it up & allow for queing time

Lots to see in the Old Quarter.. Beware the Grand Bazaar! It's ultra crowded and the salesmen can be a bit pushy. But it's worth going there for the shear spectacle of colourful stalls. Hagia Sophia is more stunning than the Blue Mosque because of its age, being at least 2000 yrs old. Don't forget to go down into the Basilica Cysterns to see where the ancient water supply was stored. Topkapi Palace is very crowded so pick & choose what youwant to see there. It's impossible to see all the displays because of the waiting time to get into some.
Hist0rical sites. Expect very long queues (even with tour groups)Topkapi needs at least 3hrsTravelling on the trams congested to say the least (but vey regular and easy to use)
Sultanahmet. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi, Hamam Cemberlitas, everything is so beautiful and romantic!

Great Sites to see in this Magical City. Head to the historic part of Istanbul for history and some fantastic buildings. You will have to weave your way through the hoardes of visitors and street traders trying to sell you everything from Bosphorus tours to plasters for those blisters on your feet. But take in the beauty of the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia plus the Topkapi palace.

interesting and informative. remind us of historical past and present situationfoodwise is quite goodhave to get use to the people as they are helpful but language is a problem and they can be rude sometimes

attractions. agia sophia is certainly the main attraction in Istanbul, a perfect church of the byzantine era, the blue mosque is to see too, the sultan palace and then a cruise in the bosphorus is a must but guys be sure to take a guide with you to make the trip more enjoyable!

Local tour. For two whole days we were treated to a tour both on foot and by bus and boat, of the major attactions in Istanbul. The guides were well informed, knowledgeable and friendly and the whole experience met all our expectations.

i just loved Istanbul. i loved everything, the people are so friendly, the food is excellentand it is a very historic city. very rich culture.I just have 1 thing to say...go an visit Istanbul, and you will love it, i promise you!
Beautiful!. Very nice area with beautiful buildings! Busy area with shops restaurants and a lot of people. A must in Istanbul!
Very historical. We had a very knowledgeable tourguide who gave us a insightfull background of the history. Areas where close enough to walk or use the tramp.
cisterns. the cisterns were antastic--great photo op and relief from the heat--i very much liked thegrand bazaar and spice bazaar--you need to haggle though!

Lots to do, wear sensible shoes!. Topkapi was a good visit, Blue Mosque as well. Be prepared for lots of queueing unless you get there really early.
Egyptian/Spice Market was just big enough to deal with but not too mad.

Great Palace Mosaic Musem. I was amazed!. I had gone thinking it would be more of the decorative tile in the style that you see in the mosques, but it isn't that at all. It is what has been saved from a huge and intricate Roman tiled floor from the 6th century. The tesserae are intricate and considered providing amazing detail and shading. A must-see museum!

Veryinteresting and amusing. We spent 5 days at Istanbul and we loved it. I cannot say we just had good experiences (namely at the Tourism Office of the train station, whose staff was especially rude and impolite). But in general, the city was awesome.We specially appreciated the historic buildings and local markets. Mosques and churches are interesting, but without much value.We do recommend the city. It is definitely worthwhile.

So much to see. There is a gem on every corner. Imagine walking on a desert island ,turning full circle for the environment to then change into a blaze of life, colour, history and culture. This WOW feeling we experienced on several ocassion whilst exploring Istanbul.
watery queue. went to cistern - brilliant inside but got a load of kids at the entrance - best to try and avoid busy times as it can take time to get inside and it is more atmospheric when empty
Beautiful area. I liked all of it but especially the sultan's park. A beautiful garden with magnific trees and birds. There were also a lot of tulips in different colours.
The amazing and mistery city. I recommend when you visit Istanbul , go with touristic group, and guidance. Otherwise you can walk all day and do not see anything

Sultan Ahmet Square. If you do 1 thing in Istanbul sit near the fountain when the call to prayer starts. The 3 mosques that surround the square andd call and respond and then join in together, it was the absolute highlight of my trip. I got addicted and went back everyday that i was here to sit and listen and be moved! Plus the gardens and fountain are very pretty and a relaxing respite from the heat of the sun.

Tips for travel in Istanbul. My tips while you travel in Istanbul:1. If you are booking an apartment, which is not through a reputed web-site, be very careful, the pictures are far from reality. The apartment we booked stank, the shower cabin leaked, the bed fell apart.2. Take the orange taxi from the Airport, or if yellow, look for the Government approved taxis (with the licence number on the door of the driver).3. If you want to exchange money, change just enough for the taxi and other immediate expenses at the airport. 4. Exchange rates are best in Aksaray, Laleli - Univeristy and Beyazit areas (Grand Bazaar).5. Trams are good for exploring Istanbul. Most sites are located on the T1 Tram route of Istanbul. You can buy the ticket by investing 7 TL for the Istanbul card and then topping up money on the card from time to time. That way, you spend only 1.95 TL per trip as opposed to 3.50 TL, without the card. Many people can use the same card.6. There are quite some restaurants and Cafes in the Beyazit area (in the street opposite the Grand bazaar). They are tasty and cheaper as compared to Sultanahmet.7. While ordering, the restaurants often charge you for bread, service charges per person, water,etc. Ask before they serve you. 8. Also, sometimes, they trick you by charging you for 2 portions, instead of 1, by later claiming that it was a bigger plate. They tried doing that to us in the 'Istanbul restaurant' in Beyazit. They also offered a 10% discount on the menu flyer, which they conveniently denied, later.9. Grand bazaar is overpriced. For small souvenirs, look for the row of shops behind the Sulaimaniye mosque. They are reasonably priced. Being the University area, cafes are also cheaper.

Sultanamet. Aya Sofia (has museum status, not now used as amosque). Golden Horn entrance bridge cafes (good for views, fresh air and drinks on a hot day). Locals restauant on City wall, facing the Sea of Mamre (Fatih Beledriyesesi Cankurtarn?), just down the hill from Aya Sofia.

Historic Istanbul. Lots to see but the queues can be a bit of a bore. Some museums are closed on Mondays. The Topkaki Palace is worthwhile spending a whole day. The Islamic Relics exhibition at the palace is particularly good.

Beware illegal sales. Many shops throughout this area, including in the Grand and Arasta Bazaars, which sell shawls - such as silk and Pashmina - also advertise Shahtoosh shawls for sale. If genuine, these are made from wool of the highly-endangered Tibetan antelope. It is totally illegal to sell these products anywhere in the world. If you purchase one, and it is genuine Tibetan antelope wool, you risk its confiscation by Customs and also prosecution.I will bring this to the attention of relevant authorities, which should not be allowing this to take place. Disappointed to write such a review after an otherwise excellent first visit to Istanbul.

The mix of different cultures and influences together the cities great history made it very rewarding for us. Everything:)- Hagia Sofia!- Sultans palace- Blue mosque- Mosaic museum - Basilica cistern- Double deck bus around the old city and all the way along the old city walls- Grand bazar and Egyptian/spice bazar- and more
Grand Bazaar. Fabulous if somewhat frenetic. We'd been to the other sites before (Topkapi, Blue Mosque) and this was such a visual feast.I bought a rug, some ceramic bowls and some silk scarves.
Chaotic_Istanbul. Great place but mad. Never been anywhere like it. Would definitely go again! But please sort out the queuing or warn visitors in advance of the issues.

Istanbul. Although this was the Easter weekend and queues were long it did not take long to get into the blue mosque and hagia sofia.great choice of restaurants and the Turkish delight is worth the trip!
Sultanakhmet area - feel the flow of history.. Plan your time if you get the Museum Pass to get everywhere you want in 72 hrs. And do not forget that a lot of museums are not working on Monday.
nice. well concentrated but also a lot of people. Better to come afternoon to avoid traffic. very nice also in the evening, nice illuminations
Aya Sophia Mosk. that Mosk is stanning! If , likeme,you are a perpetuate fan of slendour architecture, MUST visit.It breathtaking!

Blue Mosque, Haghia Sophia and Hippodrome. Try to get there early to get into Haghia Sophia as there are queues. To say too much would spoil the impact but it is definitely worth getting up early for. Allow a couple of hours to visit. The Blue Mosque also involves queuing to a lesser extent and it is a fairly short visit as you just stand inside the body of the mosque and exit at the opposite side. You need a plastic bag for your shoes and ladies need to cover arms, legs and heads. A scarf and makeshift skirt are provided if you don't have your own. You can wear long trousers. The Hippodrome retains its shape across the centuries and original columns still stand. The toilets opposite the Haghia Sophia are western style and cost one lira. I haven't spoken much about the actual attractions but I don't want to spoil it for you - you will love it!
A great city to visit for a few days. We enjoyed Istanbul very much, a great city to visit for a few day. Easy to get around, good food, great weather, will be back for sure.

Excellent Place. don't miss to visit this area when you are in Istanbul, this area show you what was Istanbul before in Ottoman and before Ottoman Age, you see most wonderful architecture and art available in all place around you.

Everything is a must see!. Sad about the crowds but the history of Istanbul is amazing. There is no better time to go it will always be busy with tour groups? You have to see the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia.....Topkapi palace is stunning not to mention the Archeological museum. D them all and then leave the main area and wander the Sultanahmet area by yourself. It is gorgeous just wandering.. Take a ship down the Bosherous and stop at the Domrachi palace......it is on a par to Versailles!

Beautiful place full of history. When visiting Istanbul, stay in the old quarters (Sultanhamet). You can avoid the horrid traffic by being able to walk to most major sights in the historic area of Istanbul. However be prepared for hordes of tourists. Its worse on weekends when domestic tourists are also present. If you do take the tram because you are tired of walking, be aware that the trams are jam packed full most of the time and therefore not a good choice if you have claustrophobia. If you get pestered by salesmen and shopkeepers or restaurant owners/waiters, its best to ignore them and just to keep on walking. This may seem rude but it is the only way to deal with them. Just enjoy your visit!

Mai & philip visit Istanbul 21 -28 April.. Breathtaking beauty Blue Mosque, Haglia Sophia and Topkapi palace. Loved the Grand Bazaar you need to allow for at least 2 trips to it. Wonderful coffee bars and easy to get around on tramsTake to Bosphorus cruise from the Galatan bridge only cost about €8 for 2.

Easy but pricey!. Enjoyed being part of the cultural scene of this vibrant city but feel the embrace charges are a little OTT. Staff at the entrance to the museums are certainly not over-generous with their charm!!

Over-rated!. Too crowded, too full of garbage, locals are VERY RUDE AND PERSISTANT! Yes it is a city full if history but not preserved at all.Except Sultanahmet, there is nothing too see but filth and horrible traffic. 3 days are enough and don't go during weekend.The 1 hour city tours take 3 hours because if traffic!
Fantastic city , dreadful traffic. This is an amazing place very nearly ruined by appalling traffic jams , in a 3 day visit we must have sat in traffic jams for upwards of 6 hours. Shame.

Travel to Istanbul. The history of this place is amazing. There is no way you will escape the charm of the place. The food is amazing, the Grand Bazaar is outstanding and the Turks are the friendliest people of all. Would return at anytime.
A new Hotel striving for excellance. Enjoyed the city very much particularly the culture, histioric past and the present vibrancy and colour.

city trip Istambul. It s a nice city only it is a bit chaotic, 20 miljoen people, so it is very busy, the trams are full, for walking every where people , big long lines of people waiting to visit museums
great. the town is perfect ,very friendly people and a big big big market ,great food and the monument looks great despite the pass of time
most attractions close to one another. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi, hippodrome all next to each other with grand bazaar and spice bazaar nearby

Historical Eyecandy. Trekking around the Old City is an adventure. The shopkeepers charming you into their stores, the windows full of Turkish Delight, the beautiful people are all a sensory overload. Easy to get around.

My favorite city. Hard to kow where to begin in praising something as general as this. Istanbul is just a wonderful city full of beautiful mosques (non-Muslims can enter), and now with great landscaping around the famous areas.
Go there and see it!. Do you like walking? Do you like history? Do you like taking pictures along with the other million tourists around? It's your spot. :)

Mystical Istanbul. The Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sophia, and the Kucuk Ayasofya mosques were breathtaking with a myriad of blue tiles, frescoes, and stone stairs. The underground Yerebatan Cistern built by Justinian in 542 has Medusa heads upside down holding columns. Topkapi Palace is another "must see".
The reason to visit Istanbul. The city is full of treasures. But do a bit of reading before you go: to get the best of it you need a bit of historical context

wanderlust. you could walk the historic areas of Istanbul for a month and not get to see a fraction of the City''s amazing secrets. food is great everywhere and especially rocket salad, local cheeses and wines

Top historic areas, a standard. Top historic areas met the descriptions read in books and reviews. We also enjoyed a half day tour to the Black Sea. It allowed us to appreciate the size and diversity of the city. Taxi are to be avoided, too much traffic, public transport are very efficient and easy to manage.

Truly amazing. If you like art and history, then this city is a must. Walk along the historic areas of the city and learn about its culture and history.
Even if you are only interested in shopping, food or anything else, the city offer everything to all kind of travelleres.
Istanbul. Such an easy city to get around and so much history - loved the Old City very much and could easily visit again
Wow what a wonderful city. All the buildings we visited were wonderful. The queues were very bad after midday. The Blue Mosque was magic as was Sophia.

Beautiful. Beautiful places. Nice people. Great food and coffee. It is safe and has a great buzz around it. Just walk around, have a coffee, read about the history and soak in the sights. Grand bazaar seemed a bit overhyped but everything else was just amazing. For so many tourists and such a populous city, Istanbul has managed to keep this district in a great condition. Did not find any chaos anywhere - it was clean, signboards were present and there are enough guides available.Do not forget to try the Mevlevi Sema whirling dervishes at the hodja pasha.

istanbull. crowded and just walked around for a fabulous week till you drop. looking forward to come back istanbul noisy and quiet without you we love you. everything was very nice meals, since tissue

Istanbul Historic Sites. Found it safe and easy to get around! The sites are well managed for foreign tourists to enjoy. The street car is easy to navigate and conveniently runs through the old Istanbul areas.

Walking in History. Try to get there early before the crowds and enjoy the mystical and serenity of the place in peace. Everything is in walking distance Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Archaeology Museum, Big Bazaar, Islamic Museum and the historical square of Sultanahmet.
wonderful Istanbul. History, well maintained buildings, trees, food, people, even the carpet sellers took 'no' very well ...we particularly loved the Chora church museum out on the old city walls.

Wonderful. So much to do and so little time to do it! We had 6 days in Istanbul and loved every minute of it with the one possible exception of the carpet salesmen. Great historical sights, delicious food and charming people.
History. Bizarre's great if you like to shop. The Museum's are filled with the areas history. Mosques were also impressive.

Great sites to explore. Hagia Sophia being the most historic. There is easy tram and bus access to the world heritage area. Ticket prices are reasonable with the option to buy a 72TL museum pass for 72 hours.

Leave you wanting More!. An amazing city to visit with its rich history from Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Galata Tower, Grand Bizaar and the diversity of people that converge whereby the saying of East meets West was coined. You will be surprised, breathless and left wanting more. You can either; walk around (for the true die hard walkers) bus with the hop on tours, taxi or take the bright red tram down Istiklal street. There are plenty of coffee shops and eateries along the way. If you want to try a traditional Turkish coffee do visit their coffee and smoke houses. Definetly a city that has to be visited more than once.
Great history lessons. Blue Mosque is great, Aya Sofia is magnificent, Besilcia Cistern is misterious legend and they all woth the visits.

History written in stone. This area is the old city, where history is measured in millennia, not centuries as North America are accustomed to thinking. This is the area of Istanbul where many of the major attractions are concentrated, not only Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque but many other sights as well. This is where you want to go first of all when you arrive in Istanbul. You can spend several days here and still not see everything.
INCREDIBLE. I wish I were still there. I've never been anywhere where there was so much to do and so much to see, everywhere we turned.

Very important. The Historic Areas of Istanbul were added to the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1985.It includes locations such as the Galata Bridge, the Seraglio Point where the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Yeni Mosque near the Galata Bridge, the Beyazıt Tower and the Süleymaniye Mosque.The World Heritage site covers four zones, illustrating the major phases of the city's history using its most prestigious monuments:

So much to see and to be amazed at. All the main sites are very close and they are all incredible. There is no real hussle on the streets either I found, only occasionally do guys working for tours ask if you want to go on one or ask if you want to buy a guide.All easy to reach in walking distance in Sultanahment. If you are lost people will assist you. And like nearly al lthe Turkish people we met so very, very friendly.Loved it all!
Get the Museum Pass. on the first day, I got the museum pass and was able to bypass ticket lines, particularly at the Ayasophia. The old city is so old and so beautiful. Just wander and get lost.

Visit, don't stay here. The Old City of Istanbul has some unbelievable historic sites. Sadly, it is inhabited by residents whose only goal seems to be separating tourists from their money by any means necessary. Disappointing. Cabbies in Sultanahmet are the best (and most brazen) example of the thievery that is commonplace in the Istanbul tourist business. Solution: The Old City is a great area (and Istanbul is a great city) to see by one of the many tours that are offered. I usually hate those things, but Istanbul is not a place to see on your own (not much English, and Turkish is largely impenetrable). Don't worry about missing the "real" historic Istanbul. There is NOTHING in the Grand Bazaar that you won't find in every other souvenir shop in Istanbul. Staying across the Golden Horn in Pera, and just touring the Old City, will enable yo to see as much as you want, while avoiding the pressure sales and ripoff artistry that seems to have saturated the surrounding areas.
Divine. Diversity, depth and rich blend of cultures Christian history blending with Muslim art and architecture .
Walk and enjoy. The city center is a maze, but you're never far from the mosques, the water, a cool place to shop, or some kebabs.
Very nice area. Old city center is the best side, don't miss the Basilica Cistern and the ancient turkish baths,the hippodrome area, Aya Sophia,you may leave the Bazaar if you haven't the time

So much to see in so little time. Highlights - go to the Topkapi Palace Musem amazing!! The jewels are fantastic!! So much History
Lowlights - Cemberlithas Hamami Baths - not negative/bad but very rough and not at all for the faint hearted - a truly one of a kind experience! - wonderful history though!

great city. Istanbul is the real door between Asia and Europe,a cosmopolite city ,located in a wonderful landscape .
Istanbul is clean,well kept,rich in historycal monuments,with the most beautiful mosques in the world,great museums,incredible markets and shops.
the food is fantastic and the inhabitants open and helpful.

Dolmabahce was my favorite. The best place to go is Dolamabahce palace.
6 Sultans stayed in this palace along with Attaturk (Mustafa Kamal)
Very interesting place to go
walk around. Sultanahmet is the best side, don't miss the Basilica Cistern and the ancient turkish baths,the hippodrome,Chora Church, Aya Sophia,you may leave the Bazaar if you haven't the time
Topkapi palace. very huge turkish and ottoman museum . all travelers must visit there. specially harem room was great.

Historic. The mediteranean wheather with offer the link of Asia and Europe continent was pleasant. The blue mosque which is beatiful facing the sea view and historic items from Prophets Musa to Muhammad was really great experienced to withness with your own eyes.

Great Istanbul. Everything - fascinating - incredible - go early before there are crowds.
Buy your tickets at hotel if possible to avoid standing in long lines
Too busy. It seemed that all of Turkey children had planned a field trip the day we planned to go. It is not as organized as other theme parks or Museums as in North America.

Ancient Egypt to the Ottomans. When you can literally stand in one spot and see over three-thousand years of human history from ancient Egypt to Ancient Greece to Rome to the Byzantine Empire and the Ottoman Empire, you are in a rare place indeed. Two of the sites, Aya Sophia and the Blue Mosque are among the most magnificent buildings I have ever seen.

!Now is a Perfect Time To Travel To Turkey!!. Istanbul is a beautiful clean friendly city! There is so much to see and do in this city. You can easily spend a fortune or be thrifty and have a wonderful experience. The exchange rate is great right now. I was getting 1.81 Turkish Lira for every dollar. So many sights are within walking distance of each other that you can easily wander from place to place at your own pace. It is in competition for 2020 Olympics evidenced by the many banners and signs displayed. I didn't see many homeless which is typical in most large areas.Everything is very accessible. Most signs are translated in English also. Most everyone is very helpful and if they aren't fluent in English they know enough to be helpful.The written Turkish language at first looks impossible but after learning a few grammar lessons and pronunciation rules I was able to survive. The language is basically phonetic. For example taxi is taksi. Now is really a perfect time to travel to Turkey. The weather in Istanbul is moderate similar to Northern California. Took a trip southeast to Cappadochia and was enchanted by everything, it is truly a historical wonderment. A balloon ride is a must to enjoy the fairy chimney rock formations. I loved exploring the countryside and learning the ancient history of this area and traveling down 5 stories of a 15 story underground city! The food is very tasty while not being over hot spicy.I felt very safe as a middle aged single female traveler.

Sultanamet. See the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque. Topkapi palace is right next door to Hagia Sophia. Beware the carpet seller. You will be approached in and around all this famous places trying to lure you to their shops.

Incredible History here.... Everywhere you go in the old City you are met with centuries of history. I really recommend going to the Turkish bath that is over 600 years old.... incredible to experience this in such a historic place.....

Lots to see and lots of walking. Istanbul is a wonderful city so full of historical sites and places to check out. It is truly historian's dream although hard my bad knees. It was very helpful to get a guide which helps avoid long lines for tickets, but as was my guided tour of Ephesus these guides will also take you to a place that makes carpets and there will be a big sales pitch which you have to sit through:( But, I look forward to seeing more of Istanbul and Turkey!

Istanbul is a place one can enjoy for days and days.. The city is dynamic, a juxtaposition of the ancient and exotic with the au courant. People were very friendly, but English is not widely used, but that does not keep people from offering to help.

Istanbul well-worth a visit!. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace all well-worth time spent. Loved strolling in Sultanahmet Square. Skip Grand Bazaar unless you MUST go, very touristy and kind of tacky. Spice (Egyptian) Bazaar is better.

Amazing views. Istanbul is an amazing and surprising city, full of story. Beautiful places to visit. Mix of cultures from Europe and Asia. Excellent food. It's not an expensive city. People from Turkey are very friendly and open to tell you more about their culture. It is a very big city, traffic could be a problem in peak seasons.

Walk everywhere!. We stayed for a week in the historic area and loved every minute of it.It is a great walking area but not suitable for wheelchair users or buggys. Most of the streets are cobbled and very uneven.

Awe inspiring. Significant, historic, beautiful buildings, delightful gardens. Few cities can have so many important features packed into such a small area. The archaeological museum, often missed by travellers, is certainly worth a visit.
best city for visit. I loved the taxim area of Sultanahmet. I thought it was beautifully and despite the sweetie a good place to wandering and get amozing .. l wıll go back in july xx

Full of importance. The best part of Istanbul is that it is having both Asia & Europe Culture..People from Greece and nearby having major impact in Society..Historical buildings are well maintained by Govt..Guides are very clear in their profession..They will guide you properly..Not cheap you..Because they have fear of God..

A visual feast for the eyes and mind but mind the scaffolding!. Within these areas of Istanbul there are too many gems to mention e.g. Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern and the area is clearly steeped in history. The only downside is the necessary but abundant restoration work that is currently taking place. This means that there is scaffolding pretty much everywhere and this is inevitabley unsightly and slightly detracts from the area's appeal.

Lots of History.. If you are lucky enough to have a customer relations representative at your hotel, allow for them to arrange tours or give you an overview of the choices available. Else, be prepared to be at the mercy of many a street hustler ready to sell you on anything.
Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Higira Sophia, Cisterns. Great for persons interested in "antiquities, of which I am not one.The ancient cisterns were interesting to see.

So much to see. With Hagia Sofia, the Basilica Cistern and the Blue Mosque, there is simply so much to see in the Sultanahmet area. It is also pleasant to walk around, but you do get the street hawkers par excellence - mainly selling their cruises on the Bosphorus. We simply said that we had done it (the IDO one was really good and is not hawked) and it was great. They liked that and went away.Entry into the Blue Mosque for non-Muslims was a little confusing. Different people there said different things, but we just took the line that they are not going to allow wandering during prayers and it was fine. It is a magnificent building and they were happy for us to appreciate it by taking pictures.If that was good, then Hagia Sofia was marvellous. So much history. We spent three hours there. The Basilica Cistern across the road was lovely.

Interesting, crowded Istanbul!. We visited on Easter weekend, and city was crowded...a 3 hr. wait to see Hagia Sofia! So we missed it, but enjoyed the Blue Mosque, the Cisterns (underground Roman water system), and Topkaki Palace Museum. Also, the Bosphorus River cruise and the Spice Market were interesting! Wish we'd had at least 4 days in the city.

Istanbul. We took the Hop-on Hop-off - it was off season in late March and we had to wait as much as 45 minutes for another bus. It seemed like they were trying to fill up busses with minimum staff. But we got to see a few interesting places en route including the historic district with the Museums, the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the cisterns and so pretty fun places to eat.

Downtown istanbul. Very friendly people, the turkish tourist guides were more than helpful...our taxi driver was outstanding, he stop at the turkcell and helped us get turkish sims cards for our phones which we would have never been able to do on our own since no one spoke English at the store.
Blue Mosque. This is a beautiful place full of history. Being a history buff I was in awe of the Mosque. Its 20 million blue tiles resonated the whole building its a must see.

Very good place to visit.. Mosques are fantastic.
Tour bus can take forever due to Istanbul traffic. Go early!
Beware of "tourist guides" at all places of interest. Their tour always involves an extra visit to their family/friends shop. They get VERY offended if you don't visit the shop...

Bosphorus tour. It was a lot of fun. We got on a bus with a informative guide, and then took a ship around the Bosphorus and Golden Horn. Commentary was good while on the ship. We had a delicious lunch and then a walking tour, which took us inside the spice market.
Beautiful area. I loved the historic area of Sultanahmet. I thought it was beautifully maintained and despite the crowds a good place to wander and get fantastic views

Lovely big squares. Istanbul was a lot greener than I ever imagined - went in spring during the Tulip festival and the squares were full of colour. Just be aware that everywhere in Istanbul is up a hill
Awesome history. If you are a history buff, you can't miss Istanbul. The Archeology Museum was my personal favorite. Note: there are three levels to the main building as well as 2 other buildings.
Amazing location. If you have a soul then you will be moved by the depth of this experience. Absolutely fabulous history but lots of people

Good sites. Had a great time at all these sites. Definitely worth getting the museum pass, good savings on the full price. Good for avoiding the queues. Would have been a five rating, but the sites are a little bit too crowded at times.

Lose Yourself...On Purpose. Wandering Istanbul was an experience of constant discovery. We loved every moment of it. The history is incredible, the historic neighborhoods and sites, hospitality, food (fresh seafood!), and crafts are first-rate.
Great sites, very busy. Worth investigating getting a 72 hour museum pass to avoid the queues, which were .huge except for later in the day
Nice but tourist traps. Don't take the offers made at the place in front of Hagia Sophia. Cheaper Boshorus trips can be found near Galata Bridge

Istanbul in the rain. Hold your brolly up high to avoid the crowds but there is plenty to see whatever the weather. A really amazing place. The new and old just sit comfotably side by side. It is a city that has evolved through such a huge length of time that it puts other historic cities to shame

Mind Blowing. No dislikes. This city is a must do! Put it on your bucket list!
It is the most interesting city I have ever visited. The history is incredible and the visual aspects are awesome. If you become exhausted by the city, take a trip up the Bosphorus on a boat. Highly recommended.
The best historic lesson.. The old town is worth visting , TOP KAPI is a must , Where U can see the preserved islamic relics . Hagia Sophia, the blue mosque and the basars are worth visitng .

Good Location. All the importan sites were just around the corner from the hotel.
We went at the end of the low season and only had to queue for about 10 minutes. Plan your day early because tour buses arrive and the queue get very long quickly.
Attractions. Topkapi palace and blue mosque, can easily spend the whole day, looking around the immediate area where these historic attractions are located .

Welcome to Istambul!. As soon as we arrive to Istambul we enter in another culture, another civilization. And the best way to know them is to visit the historic areas os Istambul, a melting pot of people and cultures. Simply wonderful!
Easter 2013 Istanbul Break. Lots of history to discover and learn about. An abundance of historic relics and buildings, all well-maintained.

Istanbul was dissappointing!. Wow, not what I expected. The Grand Bazaar was a bunch of same old same old souvenirs, jewelery, tourist junk. Some antiques but feeling there is you will be ripped off. Beware of the taxi scams, start the meter before you get in the tell you 55 lire and if you give 55 they switch the 50 for a 5 and tell you that you made a mistake, happens all the time. If you feel cheated, go to the hotel (they will try to drop you off early blaming traffic) and have them call the door man deal with it! I was here 3 days and tried to happen 3 times. Also, beware at Blue Mosque of carpet salesmens possing as free guides, just say no as they will give you a quick tour and then you end up in some carpet store with high pressure sales people making you feel bad! Again, do not take any quidance from these touts and they are good at convincing you!

Great insight to human civilization. We liked everything about you Istanbul. The great monuments such as Blue mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace are easily accessible and well maintained. It was a privilege to have had access to history of mankind through the ages. For people who love history and culture, Istanbul is a haven. We spent six days in Istanbul and feel it wasn't sufficient for that we wanted to accomplish. As a result we will be coming back again. I recommend Istanbul very highly.
Must see. If you have never been to Istanbul, the historic quarter is a must. Topkapi palace, Hagia Sophia, the mosques and the basars are the highlights here.

San Francisco on Steroids. I don't really like cities much. I very happily live in rural Virginia, US, and have for my adult life. The historic district of Istanbul with Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, The Grand Bizzar and so much more is amazing. I travel a great deal and I tell my friends they really need to vacation in Turkey, starting with Istanbul. With great rates, especially off season, more Roman Empire ruins than anyplace of earth, including Rome, and with inexpensive airline tickets from major US airports, Turkey is hard to beat. I feel more safe on the streets of Istanbul, day and night, than I do in any large US city. Your purse can get snatched or pocket picked if you are not careful. I believe reliable data demonstrates more serious crime is very rate. Carpet and tour salesmen can be an annoyance in the historic district. The pitch is, in my experience usally the same and goes like this:"where are you from?" answer "Oh, I have an uncle in ______" ..."is this your first time to Istanbul?" answer "My uncle has a carpet shop just down the street, come and look, you don't have to buy...." I have found a polite "not interested" and walking away to be perfectly acceptable.
Old Town. Long queues to get in to Blue Mosque and Sophia but moves quickly and is worth the wait. The Grand Bazaar is closed on Sundays.
Wow!. All the monuments were just too great and overwhelming! Especially for people who love history and architecture

Fantastic historical city. There is so much history in the old city (Sultanahmet) all within walking distance of the Blue Mosque that it is difficult to take it all in. The Roman ruins and huge underground cistern, the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia museum, Topkapi Palace and harem, Galata Tower, Spice Bazaar, shops and mosques galore, not forgetting a trip across the Bosphorous to visit the Maiden's Tower. We were amazed how the Islamic citizens and the 'infidels' (ie us) were able to integrate so well; a lesson that certain areas of the UK could learn. We never felt uncomfortable or out of place, and the people were helpful and friendly. What we didn't like was running the gauntlet of the carpet shop owners! Almost as bad as the Souks in Cairo and Marrakech.
Excellent blend of monuments, markets, new, and very old areas close together. The Grand Bazaar and Spice market are visually very impressive if you can stand the badgering by the vendors.

Amazing city. Make sure you visit the underground water cystern. Apart from the other fantastic sites which are well known, this is a must.Also the fish market down by the Golden Horn, especially at sunset.
a good work out. All the sites are up hill. A fantastic city, steeped in history. You cannot get bored.Plenty of good cafe`s and resturants.

Wow. I consider myself well schooled in history but somehow I have only brushstrokes of Istanbul. While the West was sorting through feudalism enroute to the enlightenment, Istanbul shone as the center of learning and culture in the world. The buildings they made were incredible, and all reachable on a two day walk - Haiga Sofia (for a milennia the largest religious place in the world); Topkanapi Palance, Blue Mosque, the Roman forum area with even older Egyptian monolith, and the Solomon mosque. I am not Muslim, but the beaty of these mosques is awe inspiring in the original sense of the word. Galata tower across the Bay, a key domestic and invader watchtower, is also worth a morning visit to miss the crowds (guides help with that local knowledge a lot). Don;t miss the Gran Bazaar just for the scale and scope; and the Spice Bazaar becuase after the Grand Bazaar it is easy to deal with.We used a guide through a travel service, and it was well worth it for not just the knowledge but also the logisitics.My family is older now - three "children" aged 18-26 plus my wife and I. My wife and daughter loved the city and my boys anbd I loved the history.One general comment - food is the same everywhere at at all proce ranges. You can eat at modest cost here about as well as you can eat in the upper end restuarants.
Fascinating!. Walking in this area, I have been greatly surprised, though I expected to be impressed by what I would see in this area. All the buildings have its history in the area.

Sultanameh and all its history. Istanbul has such a heavy history. We enjoyed visiting Aya Sofya, Sultanameh Camii (Blue Mosque), Topkapi Palace, Basilic Cistern, Egyptian Bazar (Spice Bazaar), Galata Tower. You will also enjoy a 1h30 tour on the Bosphorus.
Then walking the town, getting lost in the little streets, makes this trip really enjoyable.

Old Town. enjoy this part of Istanbul. Great, loud, wide offered places to relax .. and if anyone wants to know: explore this town by feet; even you can´t see this town in 4-5 days; by feet you´ll be surprised about friendly and handsome people and wonderful places you´ll not see with HopOn HopOff busses ... Enjoy !!

Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet is the historical peninsula of Istanbul. All the popular sights are beside each other there such as the Blue Mosque, the magnificent Aya Sofia, the spooky Basilica Cistern, the grandeur of Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, the Grand Bazaar, and other sights.

A city rich in historical sites and good restaurants. This was my 4th and my partner's 2nd visit to Istanbul. We had a very pleasant 8 day visit to a business fair along with some shopping centers, restaurants, historical sites, Spice (Misir) Market, and attended 2 concerts.

A nice way to learn about an essential part of our history. We liked very much to learn about different epoques represented by buildings and ruins in the area. We disliked the aggressive way sellers tried to sell different tours to us, even that we clearly told we were not interested.
great history. liked topkapi,dolambache,ayub sultan tomb,ataturk museum,turkish history museum...hagis sophia was a down side probably has more weightage for christian religion

Nothing you have seen before!. Just walking along the streets is an experience for itself! The Mosques atmosphere, the lamps & carpets shops, people on the street... Istambul is a city to experience by feet, wide eyes (and camara) open!

Great Place to Begin Your Sightseeing. Loads of tourist buses are lined around here. It's worth seeing. There are restrooms (WC) available in the area and several food vendors. Be aware of friendly Turkish men who seems to give you free tour of the Blue Mosque or other local attractions. They tell you all the great stuff about the places then wants you to follow them to "their shop". Got suckered into this and was taken to the most expensive carpet shop in an area behind the Blue Mosque. Then the same guy told me there was a great restaurant across the street from the carpet shop but thanks to Tripadvisor I was able to see that this restaurant was not someplace I wanted to stay to eat. Trust Tripadvisor on your trip! Download Tripadvisor City Guides for Istanbul on your cellphone and it works offline so no wifi or Internet service is needed. It's helpful to find sightseeing places, restaurants, and hotels with it's GPS/compass that points you to the right direction to walk. It's way better than a map.
Awesome old city side street shops. completely liked the old city side street shops especially the centuries old grand bazaar, marzina bazaar....

Nicely planned itinerary for tourists. WC and toilets for tourists at logical locations.. Excellent planning for tourists in mind. Seamless travel modes worked like magic!But at night one felt a little spooky with very few people outdoors.

Amazing. We started our trip with the Blue Mosque at 10AM. Unfortunately it was prayer time so there were huge crowds and we had to go in a separate queue from the people who went to pray. The Mosque was very beautiful from inside as well as outside. It was so peaceful to be there even with all the crowds. Then we went to Hagia Sofia ...but there was a 500 meter long queue for the tickets and we had less time, so we skipped it. Then we saw the Cisterns which was a unique experience.Must visit the SultanAhmet square.

Superb all round. There was nothing that I didn't like - Istanbul is currently one of my favourite City's. The Turks are really friendly and even the ones trying to sell you stuff only hassle you half heartedly. Check out the Grand and Spice Bazaars, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, well, the list goes on and on and on!!!
So many photo ops in Istanbul.. galata neighborhood and the streets around the space bazaar. Have a tea at Asli cafe for a local experience

Agya Sofia, TopKapi Palace, Blue Cami,Bebek,Istinye. Visit all these places , but walk in Bosporus , Karakoy, Ortakoy, Besiktas, Bebek, Istinye. Agya Sofya is one of the great monuments of Byzantine. I think that it will the place you have to visit 1st.

A feast for the eyes!. There is so much to see and do in Istanbul, the mosques are truly beautiful, but there is so much else about the place. A trip up the Bosphorus on a sunny day, and then bus back. Shopping in the markets, or sophisticated Istakal Street. Good food everywhere, from the cheapest to the most expensive. Loads of atmosphere, and excellent transport with the tram going nearly everywhere. A wonderful destination for a few days.
Charm of Istanbul. Istanbul is so charming and clean with a lot to offer. The history is unmatched and the city tells a good story of the world. I can't wait to go back again.
Gates to GOD. I contempled the high towers of the moskeis and geamias rising up to the sky like great arms in praying.

Historical texture..... Istanbul is connecting Asia and Europe and still has history in the air from the ottoman empire and byzantium. You can find million dollar cars passing through hundred years mosque. You can see maybe newest technology metro and tram passing near the historical palaces... Istanbul is the mixture of oldest and the newest.

IIstanbu. Blue Mosque in the evening - it's magic place!!! And all that miracles in Hagia Sophia.... and in the Chora Church.... Don't forget to go there. The Chora Church is not in the centre, but you must go there.
An Hidden Gem. This hotel is great on top of everything no need for cabs or trams you can walk at your leisure and see all the great sites of Istanbul.
Avoid Top-Kapi during heat hours. The Top-Kapi Palace was super-crowded and there was not enough AC. Visit the Cisterna instead! You can avoid long queues if you select visiting hours.
great place. really nice place, lots of things to see day and night, the most important part of Istanbul i might say

A super wow.... There is nothing like Turkey anywhere in the world. Many historical sites to explore and enjoy.
Take a magic carpet ride to Turkey and you will always want to return. Many things to see, taste and buy - the people are as wonderful as the dazzling sites.

truly historical!.
