The historic areas of Istanbul include monuments recognized as unique architectural masterpieces of Byzantine and Ottoman periods i.e. Hagia Sofya and the Suleymaniye mosque . you can just imagine the history that goes in here..it's the most awesome city inthe world, in my opinion.

Delightful area to walk. The historic areas covered the most interesting places, like the Blue Mosque, the Hagia Sofia Museum, the Torkarti Palce, the Basilia Cistern and the Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar.Within the confines of the old area there is much to see and do and a day there was ot enough. The people were friendly towards Australians.I really likked exploring this part of the city. There were no dislikes, apart from the fact that it was cloudy and not sunny.
Great place to spend weekend if you like history.. Huge amount of historical places, buildings, museums and etc in one area. Plus nice people, food and shopping :)

Just wonder.... Just wonder around....use common sense and don't be afraid to get a little lost. Look for the locals, follow them to the food and enjoy! Sit at a little cafe and dink tea or coffee and just sit back and watch. Watch for the busy "tea guy" bustling around between shops picking up and delivering his only commodity - tea.

Main Sightseeing. Basilica cisterns were fabulous, as the topkapi Palace! Must See priority!Hop on Hop Off Bus, a rip Off. Far too expensive for what you get.Hagia Sophia is amazing, but 25 Lira entrance Fee is a Lot, so only go if you are really interested. You can See all the Major Features of it in any Guide Book.Street Food is Good and totally Safe to eat. Grand Bazar is interesting, but overwhelming and exhausting. The earlier you go, the better.A Highlight for Me was the hamams. Kadigra, nö frills, reasonable  Price, ok if you just want to get clean. Cemberlitas, yes , EXPENSIVE, but Wörth it if you want the whole experience. Historical, hygenic, all you Need is supplied, also Oil Massage, was Good.

safe and beautiful. so many different architectures to experience, and an easy way to learn about Islamic basics. The interplay with the major seaways and the spectrum of culture treat all of the senses

One of the world's greatest cities. Sultanhamet and Galata area are full of great places. On the not to miss list are the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, the Cisterns, and the Topkapi Palace. Keep in mind that some are closed Sun/Mon so plan accordingly. You can do all 4 in one day if you start early.

If you want to see ancient ruins, go to Turkey.. We traveled around Turkey with a Gate One tour and could not believe the ruins we visited. Entire cities, with marble streets, baths, libraries, etc. are open and explorable. We really enjoyed Ephesus, Heiropolis and Cappudoccia.

Exotic Sights to Behold. Istanbul has been a crossroads of the world for thousands of years. There is plenty to see. You should definintely plan to see the Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque, and the Cistern which are all within about two hundred yards of each other. The Topkapi Palace is not far away. I would classify all of these as the "must sees".The Grand Bazaar is another site which is fun if you have the right attitude. It is like a giant flea market with 100's of individual stalls. The salesmen try to get you to look at their wares but they were not as overly aggressive as I had been led to believe. There are too many people there for them to bother everyone.We also went to see the Whrling Dervishes. While it was somewhat interesting I would not go again. It was fairly expensive and lasted one hour with only about 25 minutes of "whirling". The first 30 minutes is mood setting music. We had been traveling and both us had a hard time staying awake during the performance which was very quiet.

Istanbul, where East meets West. Istanbul is a big old city, where East meets West. If you like old style and historic buildings steeped in history and food especially patiserrie (cakes) Istanbul is for you.It has a modern and extensive tram system and plenty of colour and life. Do not expect Dubai style shopping.

Mosques & shopping. Very clean city everywhere. Information at all sites was clearly available ( guides & audio ) The whirling dervishes was the most amazing thing I've seen for years. DON'T MISS IT!!
Center of the World. The ancient city is amazing. You have the best of 2 major continents and so many cultures. It is one of the most fascinating cities on Earth and the food is amazing!

Lots to see. Lots to see within walking distance. Easy to get around the city. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Topkapi all worth lingering in. Get a good guide - he will be worth it. Look out to be hassled by shop keepers and in the Bazaars. Pause and you will be pounced on. All part of the experience!

Mosques, museiums and all the history in one place. blue mosque,topkapi, kapalicharshi, hayasophia mosque are outstanding and you can walk in the history just by visiting them or praying God inside them

Full of history. You should definitely visit topkapi palace, hagia Sophia and if you going to tour the area do it with walking tour don't go on the bus tours most of the area is close for driving in any case you will have to walk.

All the historic sights are within walking distance. Get the Rick Steves guide book for Istanbul and follow his directions for self guided walking tours of all the major sights in and near Sultanahmet. One could spend a week there, but budget at least three days to do it justice..

Loved Istanbul. I knew Istanbul would have plenty of history but was absolutely blown away by the many things to see, excellent condition of the sites, and the knowledge and helpfulness of the Turkish people.
great break in instanbul.. The whole city is buzzing with life, and everything from the Grand Bazaar to Princes Island was breathtaking.
Have to see. The Topkapi Palce was amazing and you could easily spend a whole day there. The Blue Mosque area was very interesting and extended to local shops adjoining.

Buyer beware.... Grand bazaar: Full of cheats. You get yelled at if you look and do not buy. Do not buy anything here. There are a string of stores behind the spice market - there is where the locals buy, go there instead. You will find people more friendly.
Totally Historical. When you will arrive there, you will smell already the historical , every corner has some meaning, and good explanetion

Incredible Istanbul. Nothing can really prepare you for your first visit. It is overwhelming and we consider ourselves seasoned travelers. The sights, the sounds, the call to prayer just being there. We loved it all!It is very easy to get around. The language is not a problem.Take a good travel book, walking shoes for those cobble stone streets, make a schedule to be sure that museums are not closed. Only negative, agessive street tour guides, be assertive and just say no. Enjoy and let Incredible Istanbul all soak in!

Best City in Europe for a long weekend. Without any hesitation this is one of the best cities to stay in the world for 3-4 days. The history, the culture, the buildings, the happy and helpful people, the great food, the Bosporus, the markets, the cool bars and restaurants. The perfect blend of Europe and Asia Minor.I also would add, that Turkey is a fantastic country, really fantastic. So much to see, so varied, great people and food. Whether you are a 5star traveller or backpacker, I can thing of nowhere better - and I travel a lot. Nor am I sponsored by the Turkish Tourist Industry.Do visit, you will love it. Whether a 3 day visit to Istanbul or 6 weeks touring what Turkey has to offer

Stayed in the heart of Sultanahmet at Ottoman Imperial. Simply fantastic to see these actual historic sites in person. Another thrill of a lifetime! Please note how friendly and helpful all Turkish people were. Also, the many, many, many cats can be a real treat. Understand they are really not strays, since all have some adopted connection in one way or another.
The place of a lifetime. just superb..no negatives...the entire area deseves at least one week to entirely enjoy it and get to know the places and wonderful citizens

This is more than a city break! This is a magnificent city break!. Take time to plan your trip. There is so much to see and all interesting, exciting and mysterious. Make sure you wear socks or tights for visits to mosques as you'll have to remove your shoes, as I found to my cost, it can be very disconcerting if you're barefoot! No short skirts and a headscarf is mandatory. Watch out for the carpet sellers. However, if you're looking for a beautiful, exotic and unusual carpet then this is this the place to be! You can, if willing to haggle, get them to reduce by up to 50%! The Blue Mosque, Aya Sofya, Topkapi palace, Sulaymaniyah mosque, the Grand Bazaar, the Hippodrome, the Spice bazaar and Bascillica cistern are all amazing, but there are so many other places such as the Jewish District, the Florence Nightingale museum and the Mosaic Museum not to be missed, it needs a visit of at least 10 days. If you are taking children with you they'll enjoy a trip to the Miniaturk which is a wonderful museum which has a huge miniature village of Turkey's cultural landmarks, a children's park and, for the summer, a pool! People are friendly and the food a gastro delight. Try it!!
Well worth planning to visit and view. Too much to see in our short stay,everything very accessible.Blue mosque is so beautiful etc.....all places seen and the history behind them is amazing.

Well worth a visit to this magnificent city. This city is enormous so plan your trip. There is SO much to see. Do your research and decide what you want to see and make the best use of your time. It's important to get to places where there are queues early. Watch out for preyer times as it is impossible to shop, or see some attractions at these times. Visitors need to be respectful of different religious and cultural influences and to cause offence due to not covering up. This is a city and not a beach resort so you need to dress appropriately. It's easy to get ripped off so keep your wits about you, check prices and barter. They do try and confuse you in many places by quoting euro, lira and dollars , so get a calculator if your maths is not good. I recommend you get a map as it is easy to get lost down the side streets. Alcohol, especially wine is expensive so beware if you are a drinker - you will need deep pockets. You can eat cheaply and safely on the street stalls and there are also some amazing upmarket restaurants.

A mint of history and a hint of mystery. This is a fantastic place to stroll through, people watch, shop, eat and mingle with the locals as well as throngs of tourists.It's clean, felt safe (apart from traffic) and there are plenty of things to see and do that combine the exotic past and the commercial present. Loved it!

Lots to see. There is so much to see and do in Istanbul a week would be a more realistic time to spend there rather than a few days. with the extra time you can better experience the sites without rushing. Most of the sights are within walking distance of a central hotel so you will save on transport. one dislike it is very very very busy any time of the year, so be prepared to have to queue.
Blue Mosque & Souk. Exotic. Gems of antiquity. Not to be missed. Take your time and really experience the area. There are many other Mosque in the area that are worth a visit.
highly recommended. I Love Istanbul, especially for its historical places... i would even go there every month if i cloud and visit more and more interesting places...
Much to see. Manyauthentic buildings. Mosks and TopKapi museum are wonderfull. The Grand Bazaar and the Egyptian market are worth visiting.

WOW better than I ever imagined. We loved the sights of Istanbul. We managed to see our hiy list but there is do much more. The amazing one was the Basilica Cistern, an amazing place. We need to go back as 3 days is not long enough to feast your eyes on so many wonderful sites

you will spend lots of time seeing the many outstanding historic areas that Istanbul has to. There are so many historic things to see and do in Istanbul, was here 8 days and i could of used a month or more just trying to see everything, i spent a whole day just walking the city walls, and 2 days going to all the Mosques, the rest of my time i spent seeing the undrground cistern,palace,mausoleums,parks,museums,and waterways,and many other historic areas That Istanbul has to offer !

history everywhere. Sultanahmet is really fascinating area. close to so many sites and restaurants. we went to a tourist information to book a boat trip-in Taksim Square- ripped off- I think the chap took a commision!! Our hotel would have sorted things for us

history, culture, life, vibrance. I fell in love with the city on my second day there. The ancient mingles with the modern, the east with the west, the glamorous with the homely, and it all melds in with such an amazing ease that you are astounded by this amazing city and its absolutely amazing historical areas which are very well kept and very well preserved.

nice hotel. i like it because it's beautiful and clean and his workers are very nice they treat guests very will everything near hotel zafer and his college sonear are the best persons they treat guests very Will

Major Sites in Old Town Istanbul. The major sites we enjoyed were the Archaeological Museum (think five hours minimum), Topkapi, Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Grand and Spice Bazaars, Bosphorus cruise (six hours), and walk from Taksim to Galata area.
Fabulous. Been to Rome? Istanbul must be next on the list - many marvellous sights , variety and scale are very impressive
fantastic. A must see in the old city in Sultanahmet. Everything is very close together, so can be accomplished in a day if you are short of time. Otherwise, take you time, it's amazing.
SIGHTS OF ISTANBUL. Awesome - glad did not go in the height of summer though as would have been far too hot and overcrowded?

History, memory and inspiration. I loved the historical sites of Istanbul. I took two days to visit as much as I could, but of course many places is going to be for the next visit, God know when. But it makes me fell with desires to come back.

Amazing!!. So, I think the historic areas of Istanbul are pretty much the Sultanahmet district, which contains such sights as the Basilica Cistern, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace, etc. We stayed right in the heart of Sultanahmet at the Hotel Amira, and within walking distance from all the sights. We also used the Rick Steve's guidebook, which had a beautiful, detailed walking tour of Sultanahmet.

Historic Areas of Istanbul Very nice. Now that I'm back from Istanbul, it's definitely the Sultanahmet area that was the most memorable. Every corner you turn there's a beautiful mosque or some other building. Though the Blue Mosque has to be visited in between prayer times, the street behind it with the mosaic museum is so cute and worth a look. That is if you're not too busy with Hagia Sophia or the Grand Bazaar.
Tan Hotel's great service and location. Excellent location and service from the staff. Easy 3 minute walk to Blue Mosque and to tram stop. Friendly, helpful staff. Great breakfast. Clean room.

I love Istanbul so much I have booked to come back in 10 Months. I love Istanbul so much I have booked to come back in 10 Months, so much history about the Otaman empire and the byzetine era of Art and the Churches and Mosques and old historical buidings are amongst the best in the world and very well preserved

<3. Simply amazing. When in Istanbul, it is imperative that you walk around and get a sense of the place, its history, its diversity, and its beauty. Walk from the New Mosque to the Grand Bazaar and across the Galata Bridge you can wind through very European alleys and sidestreets until you reach Galata Tower.

Old Istanbul. We visited Hagia Sophia Museum, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and felt like we were in the old times. Luckily we visited Istanbul in February and it was not very crowded.
Splendid. All historic areas excellent we had a guide which helped us understand so much more than doing this on our own.

Not to be missed!. If you are going to Istanbul, you will definitely want to spend some time in Sultanhamet checking out the sites. But if you can find a hotel somewhere else, I would recommend doing so. Get away from the touristy areas at night and see what Istanbul really has to offer!
good sites. The main historic sites can actually be done in a day, they are close together and a half hour in each is the most we spent.
pleasure. Restaurants good and not expensive and local people friendly and helpful. The main historic areas are close together and do not involve a lot of walking.Nothing we disliked

Take off your shoes. 3,000 mosques, muezzins, architecture, cemeteries, bazaars, history, bushel of emeralds, floor to ceiling floral and geometric surface patterns. Lamb kebabs, kofte, baklava, yogurts...if you are American, you will have celebrity status in areas like Euyup.
Istanbul - A great Place to Visit. We had a great time in Istanbul visiting as many sites as we could in our 2 day trip - You need longer really

Sultanahmet area. Loved the Blue Mosque..went inside with a private guide..he was on the lookout for English travellers!
Saw Hagia Sophia from the outside, but no time for the inside.
Went on a coach trip to the Asian side
Nice places to see. Nothing bad to say about it, everything located within a short walk, with everything you need. Restaurant, shops, and attractions all top notch.
First experience in Istanbul. Was really wonderful to historic part of Byzantine (Second Rome). The atmosphere in Istanbul is really incomparable
World class. Yes, this is world class. Blue Mosque, Hagar Sofia and the Harem. These attractions is a must. You really feel the history.

fantastic. a great city to discover.
the must see places 9as any guide recommend:
- Cystern
- Agya Sophia
- Topkapi
- Blue mosque
- grand bazar
- egyptian bazar

This is a city for those who love to stroll. There are plenty of guide books that tell you about the big things to see, and they sure are plentiful, but can I recommend a few hours of random strolling. A highlight of my visit to Istanbul was being in between Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque when the call to prayer started just before midday. It was pouring rain but I just had to stop and listen as the call alternated between the buildings. It was one of those unplanned moments that make traveling a delight.

Hotel Azur. Good hotel very strategically placed very near to town and shopping places like the grand bazaar and spice market . Lots of restaurants and shops to eat out . The tram was easily accessible too

Sultanahmet. We visited the Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi Palace and the Cistern all in one day and all within 10 minutes walk of our hotel, the Yasmak Sultan. All monuments were impressive though the Blue Mosque is not as beautifully decorated as the one opposite the Egyptian spice market. Always felt safe, always near eating places, etc.

The most awe-filled 5 days I've had in decades. I can't say much more about this city than has already been said. It's timeless. I stayed n Kadikoy on the Asian side and loved the commuter ferry every day into Sultanhamet. I never once saw another tourist and didn't have to deal with traffic.And free Apple tea for the ride.I'd say you need minimum 1/2 day for Topkapi Palce in off-season, when I was there in December, half day was not enough to take in such opulence, which I have never even imagined! Bowls full of polished emeralds the size of your fist! Everything covered in presious stones, I mean everything! I had no crowds but had been told that in-season the wait to get into some parts of the palace can be hours. Same with Bluw Mosque, so I'm glad I was there off-season,,decent weather and lower prices, too!If someone approaches you on the street to but expensive perfumes, DONT. I promise you even though the packaging looks good, it is just colored water. Another scam to avoid in Sultanhamet are the "authentic" Turkish nights,very much hyped by the local travel agencies- super-expensive,very sad food and terrible, I mean TERRIBLE show. I've seen more talented and engaged performers at elementary school talent shows. The local travel agencies also sell the hell out of their Bosphorus cruises. I did both the travel agency cruise for about $50.USD and the local one you can buy at the docks at Eminounou for about $8.USD. I do have to say I met a lot of interesting people on the travel agency cruise.Just a GREAT adventure, also loved Cappadoccia, well worth the trip. If I had a choice between Cappadoccia and Ephesus, after trips to both, I'd go with Cappadoccia.
Step in the past. The beauty of the Blue Mosque, the serenty of St. SophiaThe history of Topkapi Palace and the hustle of the Grand Bazaar all make up Istambul as it was.
East, West, Cosmopolitan. What can I say - Fantastic!!! so much to see and experience - Grand Bazaar, spice markets. mosques, street markets, coffee, people, harbor, fish restaurants the list goes on

Wonderful istanbul. Istanbul's Old City consists of many old wooden houses with carved wooden shutters. Most tourist attractions are located in the old town, which is surrounded on 3 sides by the sea. We chose a hotel that was in the old town, this enabled us to reach all the sights on foot.

That is where I stayed. I stayed in Sultanahmet where all the sites are, Aya Sophia, Blue Mosque, the Bazars, Basilca Custerna, Hodja Pasha. It is spectacular and well served by public transportation. From there I could go anywhere and everywhere which I did. It took less that 15-20 minutes to goto Kabats and from ther to Taksim, Sit by the Bosphorus, take the ferry to the island, the asian side,
A very nice old city Istanbul. The Mosques and the Turkeys people!! The nice weather and the delicious foods.It was very nice to walk through all the narrow streets!!

city of sultans. EXPLORE ISTANBUL. u will enjoy every second in this great city- the people are very kind - and the food is so tasty- the historic places in istanbul will let u dream for a while .. and imagine urself as a great Sultan
Outstanding. I strongly recommend you spend some extra money and get a professional guide. It adds tremendously to the experience. The walk around the historic district is absolutely outstanding.

One of the great historic cities of the world. Give yourself half a day just to go to the Topkapi - go into every nook and cranny and as all the guide books suggest to the very popular Harem first. (It's a big pity that the audio guide and the signage doesn't explain far more about living conditions, food, clothes, how you were chosen etc, etc.. for the harem because it is such an extraordinary place.One tip. Don't pay for their ridiculously expensive coffee in their coffee shop. It's simply a rip-off and with building works going on it doesn't even have a view.The Grand Bazaar is worth almost a day. It is endless. I loved it and had great fun with all the traders who will ask you to haggle but back off immediately when you politely tell them you're not interested. My favourite comment from one carpet seller was 'Come on (to his shop) - it's ALMOST free!'The Spice Bazaar can be visited in an hour but its worth hanging around for more because it's not LIKE the Middle Ages - it IS the Middle Ages. Frenetic activity as local people do their real shopping. Fabulous.The list of things to do is endless.

Can't get enough of it.... Never get tired, always coming back....Istanbul is indeed a charming city with its timeless beauty...I have visited this historical city 8 times (see....) and I always the stopped in this exact spot of historic areas ...either to take pictures, just to sit and do nothing, to have a quick lunch and of course to do some shopping, particularly souvenirs..The most popular ones are Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, and Topkapi Palace..Well, whatever you want to see and to do are centered here, probably..Roman ruins, amazing mosques and Islamic incredible arts, historical churches, yummy food and modern comforts...my kinda city :D.... Make sure you take your time and let yourself immerse in the beauty of this timeless city..enjoooy....

An Ancient city, filled with the Young.... I have now visited Istanbul twice (I'm still here for the second time!), and both times have found it amazing and inspiring. I am an Artist, a painter, so I guess the incredible and stunning visual beauty of the city in all it's sometimes disheveled glory is almost overpowering. The sense of human history is palpable as you walk it's streets, somehow more so than even in Rome!- perhaps the vitality of this place, twenty million people, 60% under thirty, is what does it. The economy is booming here, things change from week to week, yet the Ancient is everywhere at hand, the eternally changeable and beautiful Bosphorus infusing everything with its presence.  Another reviewer wrote something about all the "homeless" animals roaming the streets- I would argue that they are home, their home is Istanbul! I have been alot of places where "feral" animals are starving and malnourished, including my home, NYC, USA, but I have yet to see a starving or mistreated cat or dog on the streets of this city. I know that the Prophet Muhammed liked Cats, so that might be part of the reason, but whatever the reason, they all seem quite well taken care of. In any case, if you are thinking of coming to this amazing city, and you have a sense of history and an interest in the Human Story, don't think twice about it, just come.

Fantastic mix of Orient and Modern style. Istanbul is full of contrasts: stunning monuments dating back to Roman Empire and Byzantine times, istlamic masterpieces, bazaars, hammams, huge traffic, noise and very quiet places, new and modern along vith ancient monuments. Fantastic jouney over time, styles, religions, flavors and frangrances. Dozens of "must-sees" on both sides of Golden Horn. Go, do not hurry, enjoy.Tip: check opening hours and days the main attractions are available. It is sometimes to get up early and go to entrance of the given place before they open - like in Topkapi - after 9 the queques are horrible both to main entrance as well as to Harem.Take a boat cruise on Bosphorus. Spent some time in Grand Bazzar or Spice Bazaar. Go to mosques, museums and parks.
Informative. So much to see and do! It's not a hassle if you go during winter and everything is less crowded and you can take gorgeous photos

Exceptional value. Coming to Istanbul there are not many other cities to compare it with. You will have to consider major cultural capitals such as Rome or Paris to find an equal number of attractions, good cuisine and lovely views. The historic area is perhaps a bit vague in definition but I take it to mean the area within the old city walls from the 5th century, maybe with the addition of Galata. Anyway this is where you find Top Kapi, the major mosques, Hagia Sofia, the great bazaars etc. It's easy to get around on foot or with tram no 1. It was not a noisy disorganised place as I thought it might be but very pleasant. Mind you I didn't see all parts of it. I can recommend choosing a hotel between Hagia Sofia and the Kennedy boulevard. This is a quiet and very central location.
Blue Mosque a Must See. Just standing outside on a clear crip January night and seeing the Mosque lit up was a great experieence
Get lost in history.. Just take you time and walk around, your guide will show you what to visit and make sure you have your camera with you. One day is never enough, so plan accordingly.
Easy and inexpensive to get around. Stunning sites, comfortable and safe city feel. No need to waste money on expensive tours. Sites are near each other. Food was excellent and inexpensive.

Too many homeless animals!. The only reason I didn't give historic Istanbul a 5-star rating are the poor little homeless animals all over the streets. They really need to start sheltering those poor things and get them off the streets! For a western vegetarian, it really detracted from the charm of the old city.

Pleasant to walk around. A "must" is proper dress and women should really not go about without a man. Bazaar is fun in the textiles/fabric section and housewares, spices and sweets. Other stuff is probably made in China.

Vague title. Title is made even more confusing by the picture, which is the back of Kariye Church, which is in the old city walls but far outside of the "touristy" area of Istanbul.To sum up Istanbul, it is an amazing city with tons of history and its most historic areas reflect this. Sultanahmet, which has its own listing, is just an incredible neighbourhood to walk around. You can feel the history, and the architecture is awe-inspiring. However, the area is very busy and touristy.The same thing can be said for Grand Bazaar, which I suggest you visit once. After this take a walk towards the Spice Bazaar. The area in-between these bazaars is great and much cheaper than each of the bazaars.Walking outside all of the above mentioned touristy areas is even nicer in my opinion. The streets are still alive and busy but with more locals, store owners don't bother you, and everything is much cheaper.

Muze Kart. Any teachers or expats with a residency permit can get the 1 year entry card to museums. 1 year and no more than 2 visits per museum but couuntrywide and only 30 TL. Good value for locals or expats with residency!

What makes Istanbul the greatest city in the world. Now that I'm back from Istanbul, it's definitely the Sultanahmet area that was the most memorable. Every corner you turn there's a beautiful mosque or some other building. Though the Blue Mosque has to be visited in between prayer times, the street behind it with the mosaic museum is so cute and worth a look. That is if you're not too busy with Hagia Sophia or the Grand Bazaar. I love you Istanbul and would go back today if I could!
Fantastic Bazzars. We did not buy anything but the Grand Bazaar and the Egyptian Spice Bazaar are amazing much bigger than we expected. The fish markets were also very interesting.
Well done Turkey. Everything and everyone. Does everyone in Istanbul smile all the time? It seems like it. Beware of the Taxis

beautiful. Beautiful mosques and views. Lots of restaurants, kebab places and street vendors.
Worth spending a day walking around.

Amazing History. Istanbul is full of absolutely amazing history. The city planners have done an incredible job of making it easy to view dozens of historic sites. Many sites have been made into museums and the displays are written in Turkish and English. The tram to and from historic areas of Istanbul is easy and inexpensive.
Everything is so unreal!. Every moment lived in Turkey was involved in an aura of magic. The places are so full of history that I felt as if transported to another era.

Old streets, old city, modern freshness of the air.... I just walked there. I even lost my way twice!!! And every time local people helped me to find the way and enthusiastically supported my attempts to speak Turkish with them. :-) One of the happy days in my life.

So Much to See and All in Walking Distance!. We began our morning at the Blue Mosque and walked through the beautiful area between the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia. Eventually we worked our way down to the Archeological Museum, where we would love to return. We walked thorugh the park and aside from the historical markers saw a bridal couple posing in front of the fountains! A quick trip outside and around the corner and we were in a shopping and dining hub. There is so much to see and all in walking distance. I know we will return!

must be seen. It is such a tresory, that I can recomend to see all and enjoy in vist.Maybe to use from Taxim bus for sight seeing and to way to miss something .I am doing this whenever I came.In Blue Mosk is so good energy we all need to feel this.

Historic Areas of Istanbul: Sultan Ahmed. I liked everything! Very interesting and informative! Everything is well organized. A lot of tourists, which means a huge interest in the history of the Turkish people of the world.

One of the most beautiful historic places on earth.. I liked everything! It is full of historical monuments of extreeme beauty. I love the historic period of Ottomans so I enjoyed visiting places I have read of.
choose your hotel here!. There are so many things to see in this area that I would definitely recommend to choose a hotel in this are so you can walk all around, several times :-)
best part of city. someone who visited Istanbul must see this area.best part of city.best part of middle east.very touristic but not boring

Put on your walking shoes and get out there!. Walking around the historic area of Istanbul is a feast for all the senses. There is so much to see - and smell and taste. It is a great way to get to know a city and its people and as the area is not so large, it isn't too onerous on the feet! Well worth it, and do be sure to stop by the many small vendors and sample the food which is DELICIOUS!
good place very different. good place clean and beautiful Bosphorus river is the best and loved visiting the place daily to see local people fishing and ships.
Amazing!. Istanbul has always been on my bucket list. It did not disappoint and the people are so friendly. My children wanted to go back and back to the Grand Bazaar. It was a unique experience.

Don't miss the Grand Bazaar. What a place to spend an afternoon! The merchants are so friendly and not hard sell. They will offer you tea or coffee while in their shops but you do not need to feel compelled to purchase. They recognized you on your next trip whether it is the next day or the next year. They do not forget faces. Stop by to Ali at Charisma Silver. Great prices on jewelry. And Ali is a real gentleman.
Galata Tower and Sultanahmet, a must!. Don't miss the Genoese quarter (the surroundings of Galata Tower) and the streets around Aga Sofia / Topkapi Palace. It's a place to wander and wonder.
Still fascinating. We have seen so much change since our 1st visit here in 1991to this lovely city, but the historic sites even better today
very nice area. i like it you can find any thing you want to buy , the turkish food there in the small restaurants is good ,try the desserts
Very touristy. Would be much nicer if there was less chinese junk and less intrusive vendors. The Egyptian Spice market is lovely.
Layers of history. Give yourself at least 7 days to overall explore the city. Do not miss the Dervish ceremony very Sunday at Beyoglu.

The Awesome Adventure!. The nostalgia of being in Old Istanbul was incredible! I love history so this is definitely the place to be. There were so many places to visit and so much rich history! I loved it and will be back!

Scammers. Wasn't crazy about the early morning calls to prayer,but the high quality earplugs worked well,also a good tip if exploring alone,totally ignore anyone who asks you where you are from,they are scam artists and do not deserve to be acknowledged

A lot of history spanning from Roman times to Ottoman era. The Ayasophia is really vast and I loved the grandeur inside it. The ancient Egyptian obelisks on the hippodrome deserve a few minutes. In exploring ancient Roman sites around Europe, the Basilica Cistern in Istanbul is probably the most remarkable site I have visited - it's amazing how something so ancient and underground has been restored and is being maintained in great condition while being so easily accessible. The Archaeology Museum right around the corner should not be missed!
Very interesting. İnteresting but avoid non official guides which are tourist trap to Get you in the shops especially carpets

Istanbul: an amazing city. lots of history... amazing sites to see and from Hotel Antioch all within walking distance. Only warning is when you are not interested in buying just smile and kep walking!
Rich history of Istanbul. All the historic attractions are close to each other, with interesting storys and beautiful decorated architecture.

History. The old town and the old bazaar in Istanbul beside the real Turkish food. The only thing that I dislike the traffic in Istanbul is horrible because sometimes you might spend more than 1 hour in the middle of the road without any movement. Beside that, every thing was great.

Chaotic and colourful. It is interesting to read about the limestone aqueduct towering over the traffic, and to walk across the Galata bridge with its crowds of fishermen and view the city with all the ferries milling around below. It is impossible to avoid the vast market area and easy to get lost. The Grand Bazaar is more expensive than the streets around, but has to be exerienced; the spice bazaar is unmissable, with its sights and smells
For history lovers. If you are someone who enjoys history, Istanbul is the place for you. It is so full of ancient history as well as modern.
city of history. Istanbul is very different from other cities with its special atmosphere of Grand Bazaar, beutiful and mystrous mosques, palaces,worth going
Sultanahmet- great!. immerse yourself in expriences.. sip salep, eat roast chestnuts and enjoy atmospheres, locals are friendly and helpful.

A must see. The places are well known, but after seeing them so many times I realized that most important aspect is to go beyond admiring buildings, to actually understand the way of life and the values of the people during the Otoman Empire.
All were worth it. interesting and fun, avoid crowds and don't plan of Christmas or New Year's time. Winter cool so dress warm.

Sultanahmet. A must for traveller with interest on culture, architecture or simply taking picture. The history, art and culture blend with uniqueness of mix old Europe and Moslem culture worth to see.
Beautiful. It is hard to write a review on the historic areas of Istanbul... It is just majestic, beautiful, amazing!!!

One of the most beautiful towns of the world. From Bisantium to the modernity. Everything was very special and very interesting, a sort of complete walking in the history, from the Roman empire until today.
Beautiful Istanbul. We really enjoyed Aya Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and Chora Church (a little further away). The queues build up at the Aya Sofia and Basilica Cistern so get there early!

Great amount of history. Every wher you go in Istanbul ther is a Historic Place to go in and see. We were in Istanbul for 41 days and still we did not see all the Historic places. We did one place of interest each day, but there are many we did not see. (These will have to wait for the next trip). The bulidinds are very well constructed and the exhibits are presented professionally. The venders on the streets, in the markets are wonderful people,as are the people of Istanbul who will welcome you with open arms. We urge people of all denominations to come and see this wonderful city and also Turkey itself, you will not be dissapointed, it holds a great amount of history here.

Too much to see, not enough time. We only had two days in Istanbul and tried to make use of every minute. A hop-on hop-off bustour took us to/past all the historic sites. Regrettably we did not have enough time to get off and go on extended excursions. Next time.

Inspiring. An amazing city.We walked everywhere without using public transport once, and got a sense of local life and culture. I agree with comments that it is like walking through an open air museum.A once in a lifetime place.

A Wonderful Old City to Explore. The city is full of very cool places, Dlomabahce Palace, Basillica Cisteen, Galata Bridge, Galata Tower, Blue Mosque, Topakapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazaar, Cruise on the Bosporus, visit the Asia side, Suleymaniye Mosque, Hippodrome, Arasta Bazaar (I liked this one the best). I can go on and on, we had a great week in Istanbul and could find another weeks worth of things to see. A great city to explore. Lots of history here!

If it is old, see it. I'm not actually sure what the point of this listing is, but it popped up and I can't resist gushing about Istanbul's historical sites. We spent four days in Istanbul and I feel like that only scratched the surface of what is here -- do take the time to explore. Most people have recommended the biggies and I have to chime in with these recommendations: Kariye Museum (The Chora Church), the Eminönü Egyptian Spice Bazaar, and Küçüksu Palace (the rococo summer palace of the sultans).

The Wealth of Istanbul is Her People. We chose Istanbul for our Christmas getaway this year. We're Americans and grew tired of well meaning people asking us "Is it safe?" "Aren't you afraid?" To be honest it was a wonderful experience to be in a country that does NOT force you to listen to Christmas music blaring from every corner. The history embraced within Istanbul is well worth seeing. The architecture is a refreshing change from other countries we have toured with its tall spiraled turrets and fascinating domes. The tile work and mosaics are extraordinary. Historic sites were reader friendly as all have English plaques beside the Turkish ones. December was a great time as the crowds were kept manageable. The merchants were very friendly and we enjoyed the fresh pomegranate juice stands and roasted chestnuts grilled on most corners. Go see Istanbul, enjoy her wonderful culture and connect with her most precious treasure of all ...her people. We felt very much welcomed and appreciated for choosing this as our holiday destination.
Wonderful historical gems. Hagia Sophia museum was beautiful, I recommend you hire a guide for both the information and skipping the horrendous line. I also highly recommend the dolmabahce palace
A lot of points of interest to see. Many beautiful mosques, Topkapi Palace, Hippodrome, fontains... But dangerous traffic and it's hard to find the street you need.

Byzantine history -- wow!. The ancient buildings and surviving art are simply amazing. The city needs a few days to thoroughly explore -- don't cut time short! While mosques are free to enter, most other sites have a modest fee. It's worth getting the museum card, which provides entry to most of the major sites/museums without waiting in lines.Really, the only negative is the constant stream of people trying to sell carpets. But it's no big deal with a firm, polite "no."Lots to do here -- spend several days and take it all in.
Attractions in Istanbul. Topkapi Palace, The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Grand Bazaar, The Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern and tons of other attractions

Never a dull moment. The city has a magic about it that you never stop feeling. The buildings are old and makes you wonder what happend there hundreds of years ago. Even though locals walk through as if nothing hapened there, it makes me appreciate what happend then to make it great now.
History buff's favorite city. I've lived here for over a year and am still in love with this part of the city. You don't have to pay to engage in history, you just walk down the street.
Worth Visiting. We liked each and every place that we could visit, some of the sites were under renovation and hence inaccessible.

Loved the area BUT Topkapi was insane. Find it hard to believe that Topkapi Palace is one if the mist visited sited in Istanbul yet it is so poooorly run. There are lines to buy tickets, which is to be expected, but the lines continued. Bummer however that no brochure or guide map us given w entrace fee of 25TL. Then after you buy ticket you get into another line that is even more crazy. There were 100's, if not 100's of people trying to get into the castle. There was no line formation or snaking of lines just a mob of prople trying to get into the palace. To make matters even worse there were just as many people trying to leave the castle through the same 10' entry way. People were pushing and shoving - it was mot at all enjoyable. Once we were in it was a little better but not much. There us still one mire major insanity line to get into the Third Palace. That was the worst. I cant imagine what it is like on a busy summer day with hest beating down on people. I could think if 5 quick ways to make the experience better fir all visitors. Being here left me depressed about fellow travelers as well. Many cut in lines or stoid in front of displsys, listening to thier interpertation devises (another 15TL) instead of moving along. If course in the end Im glad we went but it was frustrating.

a lot to see. we were in istanbul for 15 days.. there are alot to see.. It is really hard for us to manage our days... But most of them are located at sultanahmet area. and our hotel which we stay at the old city was perfect

COFFE BREAK. If you ever get to Istanbul via a cruise ship have stroll round a lot easier and cheaper to the pocket traffic is busy but do have proper crossings its hilly just go up any of the side streets to get to the top and make your way to the bus station what a sight walk through bus station over onto the right and you will come across a beautiful cafe with blue and white tiles marble floors also sells turkish delight which is tempting when you walk in every kind of flavour the cafe is Hafiz Mustafa is on Hamidiye Cd No 84/86 Bahcekapi-Eminonu I believe the owner is Afiyet Olsun what a treat we had well worth the visit and not too expensive take note its better if you have Turkish Lira than euros you get better deal and its cheaper whatever you buy in Turkey

Lots of history, lively ...lots of hustle and bustle. Full of historical buildings, lots of cafe and restaurant. Tram is quite useful if you don't want to walk. get an Istanbul card to use ion the Public transport. You will hardly need a taxi in the old town. If you do need a taxi, hail the taxi from the road, and insist that you will pay by meter. Some naughty one are standing outside the hotels, clubs, shopping malls and may ask you very high price. Make sure that you tell the correct destination to Taxi driver. If you can't pronounce give him in writing. most taxi drivers are quite friendly

Historical and World Heritage Sites are must see when in Istanbul. There is a lot to see in Istanbul to include the famous Hogia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, Museums, and other historical sites.
Historic buildings and museums very nearby. Good facilities for tourists, buildings need renovation. No need to buy a tour. Can go around on foot with a good guide book
Well preserved. Istiklal great street . Difficult to reach since there is always heavy traffic. Need to write more details in English
dreamy!. visit istanbul! it is amazing. one of the best cities in Europe. A city for all seasons with a unique mix of Europe and Asia. The food is good. The people are good. The city is exciting.

Wonderful, Grand, Different. Having travelled across europe, I felt turkey historical areas were very different. The blue mosque was amazing from outside. I did miss an audio guide to tell me more about the history. I also went to "Beylerbeyi Palace" on the bhosphorus strait. This was probably richest palace I have seen till now. The paintings, beer skin, piano, gold cielings left me Wowwed.
GOOD IDEA. I liked food, monuments ,turkish peopleAs is was december it was very cold and dark very early in the afternoon..
Old city Istanbul sight seeing. Easy walking access & great local guides to do private tours We enjoyed the spice souq , grand Bazzar, Sophia Hagia , Topkapi palace
yep, its great!. its our first time in istanbul.we where amazed by the histioric areas of the city.one needs more than a week to see all.so we will be back!
take you time. just stroll and let the feel get to you.its bussy but never too stressfull as you can take a pleasent break at a coffeshop.

Must See Before Die. Historical Center of Istanbul is one of the most unique places you can ever see. First of all this center exists on a very big peninsula that you will need at least two days in order visit every important touristic points. Topkapı Palace, Blues Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar, Spice Bazar and Basilica are the top points you need to visit. The view of Bosporus is absolutely breath taking through Topkapı Palace. Hagia Sofia is one the oldest churches that still exists and now is a museum also a place to be. Beside all these visit points I highly recommend to smoke ‘nargile’ (sisha) at the historical center of Istanbul.

must to see place. many visitors who visits Istanbul never leave sultanahmet (oldcity), which is the shame,thought understandable. This is the old part of ıstanbul, and there are many sights which you need to spend week

Curio Travel. We spent 2 days in Istanbul on our Eastern Med cruise. We used Curio travel as a private guide of Istanbul. Omer Elkay was a wonderful guide and I highly recommend him. He not only took us to the usual stops: spice market, grand bazaar, Hagia Sophia, etc but because of his intimate knowledge of the area he showed us two additional mosques that were absolutely exquisite. We had a private van as there were six of us and it was a wonderful way to tour the city. Driving in Istanbul is not for the faint-hearted. It was well worth our time taking the tour with this company and Omer was an absolute delight. He even negotiated for us an authentic hand made carpet. I highly recommend Curio travel and Omer! Thanks again for letting us visit your beautiful city.

Old Town, great feel. We stayed at Istanbul Old Town, and the best part of it, apart from it's great European feel, was the tramway transportation. It was so convenient, and accessible, and comfortable to travel by.

Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace. The above three sites are a must see while visiting Istanbul. The Blue Mosque has an aura to it, you have to be inside the mosque to be in awe of the architecture and the sheer beauty of it. The Hagia Sophia also has breathtaking architecture and history behind it. The Topkapi Palace is beautiful and the view from the top is just jaw dropping.
very near eachother. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Cistern and Grand Bazar all within a few minutes walking distance
GREAT TO VISIT. Hagia Sophia,Blue Mosque,Grand Bazar,Spice Market,Bhosphorus Tour,,a must and last but the best Prince's Island
Diverse and spectacular. Enjoyed the history but had to have patience with the haggling of people trying to sell rugs, shoe shines etc.

Top Kapi. Top Kapi Palace is one of the most wonderfull thing you must see while visiting istanbul.
wonderfull building and lovely musems.
you will see who sultans of the the otman empire used to live.

wowed. Historic Istanbul was amazing. The mosques are so beautiful and moving; the Haiga Sophia is often called the most beautiful building in the world; the underground cictern; everythingThe Grand Bizaar was fun and so too was the Spice Bizaar. The only thing I did not like was being hassled by rug dealers. Do NOT go into a store unless you expect to buy.
sultan ahmed area. is braillant site must see with alot off history sulatn ahmed mousqand hajya sofya also if can go to top kaby palace

Amazing history within walking distance. It was amazing how much history was crammed within 10 minutes walking distance from each other - the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazaar... most of them would require a half day to appreciate them in full so plan accordingly.
Interesting town. hold tight to your bags and know how to deal with shop keepers, shop for antiquity and take pictures but try not to get lost narrow streets (they all look the same almost)
really... old is gold .... the entire road across marmara sea is full of old walls, a very nice sight, pleasing in the eyes. Wether ur up or your down, you can see the beauty of the entire place
Amazing Palace!. We went to Dolmabache Palace... A Very nice place to visit.Perfect picture location outside the Palace. You cant take pictures inside it is not allowed.
Stayed here. Really great place to live in for a first time visit. Most of the sites are within 10 to 15 minutes from most of the hotels and hostels.

Definitely Worth the Trip. The Old Town is as amazing as it appears in pictures. It has more historic sights packed into its core than some countries do. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace--especially the Harem, Mosque of Suleyman, Grand Bazaar, the Spice Market, and the Underground Cisterns are all must-sees at some point in your life!
Fantastic area to be apart of. Stay in the old town, it has more life and wonderment than any other areas. Loved the markets both the old markets and the Egyptian markets.

Walk, walk and walk. Forget time and just walk around taking pictures, breathing the atmosphere or having an ice-cream. Indulge yourself ignoring the traffic and the queues, walk around an live history.

If you don't go anywhere else in Istanbul, don't miss Hagia Sofia. The building is simply amazing. That anyone in the world was able to construct a dome of that size in the 4th century; that it has survived 17 centuries and however many earthquakes is a real tribute to the architects and builders. Standing at the base and looking up is breathtaking. Seeing how much of the old Christian mosaics and other works have been recently uncovered (having been platered over when the church was converted into a mosque) has been fascinating over time. Simply imagining all that has taken place in that magnificent structure taxes one's imagination. We never tire of returning, and it is always our first recommendation in a city full of wonderful sights.
Breathtaking. The sheer scale and sense of history really does take your breath away. Crowds of tourists can be bad though, especially in the Topkapi Palace.
Amazing. So much history in Turkey - you could spend years in Istanbul and still not see it all. It has changed my view on religion and history forever. I just want to go back.
Very lively place to be. A nice compact area with great things to see, shops, sights and restaurants. Tram line near by also. Close to the harbour and mainline station.
Great time. Many are close together and do not require transport. Entry fees are reasonable and there are audio guides available to hire which allow movement at your own pace.
Blue Mosque. Amazing place not to be missed. You need to respect the customby covering your head if you are a woman and not wear shorts

Lots to see, a must-do in this city. This area includes many historic sites that should not be missed on a trip to this wonderful city including the blue mosque, hippodrome and ayasofia. Beware of the street peddlers though. The guy dressed in historic costume with a large red pitcher on his back will force his nasty "all natural juice" on you and insist you pay an outrageous fee. Some open air restaurants allow "servers" to take your order but they will charge extra. Dont fall for it - order yourself and save lira!

Christian History in City is incredible. The Chora is a must see as well as the hagia Sophia. Stop for Manta and Baklava a must. Grand Bazaar is incredible but you need 2 or more days to truly see it all and don't miss the spice bazaar near the Galatta Bridge.

Istanbul Old Town. This is not to discourage anybody planning a tourist trip to Istanbul. But in case you are from Southeast Asia (like myself) you will not find this city to be very fascinating. Yes it has got anciant mosques and the Bospherous strait connecting two continents is fascinating . But at the end of the day it is like any busy city in Asia with its traffic, street sellers and cafes.

Shopping--Wow!. I highly recommend the Grand Bizarre. What a remarkable place. During my four day visit, we visited the bizarre three or four times a day. It's a shopper's delight. I would definately return. Great textiles, leather goods and accessories.
Vacation in wonderful Instanbul. I highly recommend traveling to Istanbul. It's safe and loads of fun! Great shopping, lots of historical sights and such unique destination.

Historical and Cultural Icon of Turkey. walking distance to several historical sites from many hotels. halal food for Muslims are available everywhere and you meet many tourists who would help take photograhs for you.
A must see. This is what you come to Istanbul for, and it's a great journey; There's a strong energy about these places due to it's great history.

Walks and Joys. Walking the streets of Old Town Istanbul will not let you down. No matter where you walk you will find delights. You will feel very safe and people are very helpful. One note would be with regards to carpet shops. If you are not into getting a carpet I suggest you avoid passing buy them or simply tell them you just bought one. They are kind but persistent.
Beautiful. Old town Istanbul is very lovely. History, culture, vendors and shopping. What more can you ask for. The people are friendly and willing to barter!

Might have been good 10 years ago.. Now it's just tourist central (even in winter) it is still interesting but there are just touts bothering you constantly to buy their crap and the asking why 'lady so grumpy' sorry but insulting people won't help your case!!!
Haghi Sophia the best one. Haghi Sophia and blue mosque were the best we liked form what we've seen a must on every travellers listto istanbul
Step back in time .... to view all the best that Istanbul has to offer - history, shopping and good food! Very convenient for bus tour pick ups, etc.

Beware of the touts. Istanbul is a great city full of history. When you walk around the old city you will be stopped by so many touts who will try to sell you the overpriced leather goods, carpets and jewelery, etc. Don't follow any of those people, they offer you to drink the apple tea and chat but they won't let you go out until they sell you something. I recommend you and shop around the grand bazaar as there are so many places for those goods.

Sultanahmet. So much to explore in the old city. Take time to wander through the streets, taste the local food, preferably off the main tourist strip, as the food is quite expensive In these areas. Allow at least a week to explore the old city and beyond.

travel Insanbul. Amazing Blue Mosque and Bizare Market Istanbul they are a maze, you can spend the whole in the Market and still won't see everything.. The Country of Istanbul is amazing the most friendy i have ever met. I will go back there in a heart beat......

Great night life. This place is wall to wall with bars, pubs, good restaurants, and a great atmosphere on the weekend...I went in the winter, but I am certain in the summer it would look like Madi Gras in New Orleans of Fat Tuesday

so very historical. what you can see here is hagia sophia museum which is the place of mixed/ blending of Christian and Moslem culture. also you can see the magnificent Blue mosque, for me its breathtaking to see all the paintings aroung the walls and the ceiling within the mosque), and last is the topkapi palace which was the sultans house.
Old Istanbul. Must see Blue Mosque, Haggia Sophia and the Cistern. Can be seen in one day but please allow separate day for visit to Topkapi Palace.
excellent city. excelent city with so many things to do, everything was so perfect to feel history and modern in same athmospehere, Istanbul has so much to tell you.

Great locations ,. amazing scenery, Nature , historic artifacts , Prophet Mohammed PBUH artifacts.
entry fees are a bit high comparing to its value.

Must See. Sultahanamet area is really very traditional and beautiful with all the historic buildings, Blue mosque, Bascila cistern,Aya nsofia and Topikapi Palace.History goes way back we had a well informed guide
Tourist Sights. Magnificent, clean, long lines, friendly and helpful ticket staff, great security, good signage and audio tapes

Fabulous!. After walking across the Gallata Bridge I found myself in the markets. It was Sunday, but many booths were open with wares of all kinds! I walked uphill and came to a "flea market" at the University of Istanbul! Very interesting. I continued on to Old own and the park and Topkapi and Blue Mosque. I loved walking around the city and taking in so many sights, both people and historic things. I visited a rug shop and yes, bought a "real souvenier" - the rug is beautiful! People are very nice and friendly and it was a wonderful day.
Very interesting, but not being looked after well. Aya Sofya and Topkapi palace in particular need a lot of TLC. But they are very impressive buildings.

Magical Istanbul!!. Liked:
Hagia Sofia
Blue Mosque
Grand Bazaar
Modern And Historical Istanbul.....
Great weather, great food, great sights....
Cistern Basilica

istanbul. one of the most exciting cites in the world!. oh, no dont get a guide. oh no dont just go to all the historic stuff. just stroll. just get lost, just sit in a bar or a coffee shop or a nargile bar and watch it all going by. its one of the great river cities...you can see boats, liners, tugs, fishing boats, tankers going up and down all day. but its also one of the great people-watching cities. there might be women in headscaves, but the man is just as likely to be pushing the pram. the mosques have call to prayer 5 times a day, but you are just as likely to see drunkeness, no one judges, actually no one cares, do what you want, and the traffic can be so jammed you miss your flight. it just has it all. turkish airlines flies to more countries in the world than any other...and if you look at a european map of the world you can see why. istanbul is in the middle of the world...it is a city on the cusp of two continents...and believe you me, it feels like it. it really is one of the world cities...but no one ever considers it as such because its in turkey, and we dont even think it matters. well...its about time we all did. because it does, and it is. you should go...

Exotic and exciting. Istanbul is an intoxicating mix of East and West, and very fittingly the setting of James Bond's first movie, To Russia with Love, and the latest Skyfall.Take time to walk through the cobble stoned streets in the old city, and spend enough time at the key sites, including Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque hippodrome and the Basilica Cisterns. You can do most of these on one day, if the Q's aren't too long. Make sure you dress appropriately for the visits to the religious sites, no shorts, spaghetti straps, halter tops etc... And remember you have to remove your shoes when you enter the mosque. I appreciated that the sites are concentrated so closely together, you can easily walk between them. There are numerous restaurants, shops and hotels to suit every budget in the old city. What's there not to like? So rock up and enjoy one of the most exotic cities straddling Europe and Asia.
Istanbul--where Europe and Asia meet. Istanbul's history is fascinating and complex, so allow plenty of time to explore. Visiting a few of the city's 4000 mosques is a must as is the Grand Bazaar.
Simply fantastic. We loved all: the beautiful Hagya Sophia, the Basilica Cistern with its incredible atmosphere, the hippodrome. Less so the blue mosque, too impersonal and the tiles are not so nice.

Istanbul Tuncer Gift Shop. We loved every moment of our stay in sultanamet, old city Istanbul. The food is good & the shopping for souvenirs is fabulous, make sure you go and see Ibrahim at the Istanbul Tuncer Gift Shop, he was so friendly & helpful & I came home with some really lovely things to remind us of our stay.

evening spell. In the evening for me was the special charm of a walk through here, feel the attitude of citizens towards their traditions and culture. I had a feeling that this is part of me.And another wonderful feeling and understanding, that the Turks kept their traditions, cherish their cultural heritage, and respect diversity. Congratulations Allah will reward them well.
instanbulday tours. awesome, historical, one of the things i always wanted to see and do before i die......my bucket list

Old City is definitely a must visit. The area is compact and easily walk-able on foot to get from one sight to the next. The Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and Hagia Sophia are all steps from each other.

So much to see. Since I am stubborn and walk a lot I saw so much of this amazing city and got lost all the time. But when you get lost you find thing you did not know existed.
Both European and Asian sides have a lot to offer. Just come is spring or fall, December is cold and wet.

The Bazaar really was fun. Great energy with colorful, interesting wares were everywhere. There were nice quality items as well. The shopkeepers were polite and less invasive that we found in other bazaars we visited on our trip. There was far too much to see in a brief visit and I would have loved to have been able to spend a bit more time than our tour allowed.
Beautiful Istanbul. Nice city helpfull people and well organized . Beautiful royal sites loved historical places what an empire!, rich and luxurious one of a kind.

Visit the tourist office first!!. THe tourist office is located just down the hill from the tram stop. Be sure to get a guide book and maps. Best exchange rates are found by walking up the hill toward the Sultan's tomb. Find the calligraphy man near the cafe's. He is a retired policeman and will tell you his story. He will write your name in a truly amazing way!!

Old world charm. Beautiful, quaint and cozy. Beware of random men who "have a shop nearby". They are not dangerous, just don't actually have a shop at all, just bring you into the local shops & expect commission from the shopowners. Just avoid them.
Beautiful. Felt so safe to walk around! The cobbled streets, the restaurants were lite up, meet so many tourists, even found Burger King too
Amazing history in the country. Loved the weather, the historic places... try to get a good guide ... our guide was very grumpy and strict about timings

One day in Istanbul on your own from cruise port. from cruise port, take taxi to Cistine Basilica for 10 Tyr, entrance fee 15 Tyr. spend about 30-60 min.Walk across street to Blue Mosque, free entry, spend about 30 min.Walk to Hagia Sophia Museum, entrance fee 20 Tyr for 60-90 min.Walk down hill to the Topkapi Palace, entrance fee 25Tyr. for about 1-2 hrs. you may want to pay 15Tyr to visit the Harlem inside the Topkapi too. for another 1 hr.Walk cross town to either the Grand Bazaar or the Spice Market about 30 min, look around about 1hrLast thing is walk across a bridge over the Golden Horn, with lots of fishermen on the bridge and many restaurants under the bridge
thousands years of continuous life. like most of the museums and monumentsdislike the simultaneous muezzin cries from every part of the horizon

Impressive!. Undoubtedly, this very important area of Istanbul represents a big portion of the history of the humanity. When you say Byzantium, Constantinople, you are referring basically to this area.Here you will find many edifices and places representing the grandiosity of the Roman, byzantine, Latin and Ottoman Empires.Among others, here is the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Hyppodrome of Constantinople, etc, etc. There are also good places for shopping, like the grand bazaar and the Egyptian Spice Bazaar (Misir Çarsisi) near the Galata Bridge.The area is perfect to be visited by foot, with many open places, squares and nice views of the Marmara See (from Topkapi Palace and from Gülhane Park). There are also many signs helping the journey.
Reason for visiting... like going back in time...atmospheric and magical, although wouldnt like to visit in sunny or warm months...

Wonderful City.. Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, the Bosphorus, the whirling dervishes, the restaurants. We could feel that this place is the bridge between Asia and Europe from the culture, the food etc.

So much to see. I recommend a walking tour on your first day to orientate yourself. Then backtrack to anything of interest. A long weekend isn't long enough. I went for seven days and did most tourist attractions comfortably.

Walk til you drop, have coffee, and walk some more!. Old Town is a fabulous place to get your exercise, while absorbing culture, sights, tastes, and smells. The more you wander, the more you fall in love with the city. Streets of cobbled stone, architecture of astonishing beauty, kebabs and tea at every corner- don"t bother with a map, because you will limit yourself to the bigger sights that way. You can't get lost in Old Town, because the minarets of the Blue Mosque will guide you back. We visited Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, the waterfront, the Grand Bazaar and Silk Market, shops, restaurants, alleyways, fish markets, neighborhoods, parks, and local bazaars like the Aranza. Everywhere we went, we were charmed by the people and the experience of walking in such a historical place. We had 5 days in the city, and couldn't see all we wanted to. Best meal? Just outside the Grand Bazaar entrance, look for a menu sign saying Iskander. Do not pass this up! Sit out on the patio under an umbrella, and savor the flavor of the moist lamb with tomatoes and butter. I can't get the memory out of my brain, even after being home for 3 weeks. Where is a Turkish chef I can hire???
Grand Bazar. Bargains on which you can barter The sales men won't shut up some are funny in their banter others are plain disrespectful in their treatment of potential customers

Unforgettable. We visited in February, while there weren't many tourists in the city. The city offers modern amenities combined with an incredibly rich history. The people were friendly and there is a lot of delicious food to choose from - the candies and desserts are incredible. We took a boat tour which allowed us to see both the European and Asian sides of the Bosporus, and you can also take relatively cheap ferry rides from one side to the other. We were only there for three days so we didn't get to see nearly everything worth seeing, but what we did see made it well worth it. Oh, and don't forget to visit a hamam while you're in town!

So much to see!. This Golden Horn area is unbelievable! In the old days this is Constantinople, there is so much history and is a must see area if you want to know about today's Turkey. Everyone knows about London and Paris, so does Istanbul!

Occupied by refugees from Anatolia. This place has many historical buildings however local people damaged every historical buildings and destroyed many of them and made their caves all around the beautiful Istanbul thus; what you see here is only the remainings of such treasures.

great spectacular experience. very cool place, good service and spectacular view over the Bosphorus. Menu was ok, prices reasonably high but this is definitely an experience that one has to have during a visit to istanbul. Would pick this restaurant for the "fancy" experience in Istanbul.
Beautiful Place. Recommend every one to visit, the food and the shopping and the see side, the see tours too. there are alot of places you have to visit

Watch out to be ripped off!. Nice area... and walked a lot...Positive:Nice streets with many restaurants and bars, especially in the area of Sultanahmet. Prices are a little higher in this area, but I guess it is normal in the touristic heart of a big city! Ali Pasa Medresesi, which is a little square hidden, just in front of the Grand Bazaar. You can find a couple Nargile (water pipe) bars where you can chill, smoke Nargile and have a Turkish tea or coffee for a normal price.The local market, next to the Egyptian Bazaar... you will find the same spices and products for way less money! F.e. bought 1 kg of meat spices for 18 lira, instead of 100 lira at the bazaar!The street food is extremely good... no matter where you go, you keep on eating all day around... prices are good.The Mosques are beautiful and worth a visit... so is the Topkapi Palace.Negative:In my experience, people in general are NOT friendly... they do not care of the tourists, the only thing they care of is how to get money from your pocket!! They appear to be friendlier when purchasing something... People hardly speak English, which makes it difficult to communicate... I find this stange for the most touristic area of town, this also tells me that they don't give a sh¡t about tourists.

COSMOPOLITAN, with lots of options. Likes: the location, verdant. The historical value is immensethe food is easy to deal with, and the locals are too eager totake your moneyLacks: sign in english, taxis with meters ONLY, and a unified price . Its a constant "cold shower feeling"
Spectacular!. Easy access to Istanbul's Historic sites and area, by foot, or tram. Sites are well marked, and accessible.

Greek, Roman, Ottoman and Modern town. Brush up on your history and read up why this area is so desirable by all the ruling empires. Arrange for a guide before arriving. They can help you skip queues and point out items of interest that you may miss on the books.
Beautiful City. Istanbul is a fantastic city to visit! I viewed all the tourist spots of the old city; which were all within walking distance to my hotel.Soffia Palace was breathtaking!

Very old historical peninsula with a great location. Very pleasant weather in November. Not too crowded on the sights. Delicious food at the local restaurants. Be careful to single Turkish man around ths sights especially Blue Mosque are who offers you to guide the area. These men usually finalize the orientation tours in a carpet shop. This is their only business for them. Always prefer licensed tour guides who carries a badge on their neck with government autorization.

Days of sightseeing all within walking distance. We stayed two different places in Istanbul, and our three days in the old town was the perfect amount of time to see all the major attractions by foot. The streets and traffic are so bad that walking is best anyway, so forget about cars and tour buses and get out there and mingle with the locals on foot.

Everything in close proximity. All the top tourist attractions are in very close proximity; Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Hippodrome, Underground Cistern, Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. The last two just a short 10 minutes walk. City is very clean too.

Time stood still. The old town with the spice bazar, the main bazar of over 1200 stallholders, the jewellery workshops dating back centuries blended with the bustle of modern living is a must see. always barter and be respectful of local culture.
A cultural treat. East meets West is an understatement, the contrast is a delight and an example of how cultural and religious beliefs can work and live in harmony.

A fantastic stay in Istanbul!. My wife and I visited Turkey and Greece for the first time and also took our first cruise. Our cruise started in Istanbul but they didn't have any days set aside to see it so we went a couple of days early. We ended up staying an extra day since our cruise was delayed because of Hurricane Sandy.What got us interested in Istanbul was watching The Great Courses tape - "The Great Tours: Greece and Turkey, from Athens to Istanbul". It's available on DVD and I'd highly recommend it to anyone considering a trip to the Aegean Sea. Professor John Hale is great!He did an excellent job introducing Istanbul but it's really surreal to be there. It's so beautiful,very vibrant, and clean.We stayed at The Seven Hills Hotel. It's right in the heart of the old town within easy walking distance to all the main attractions. It has a roof top restaurant with unbelievable views of the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and the Bosporus. The service in the hotel was excellent and the room was very spacious. The restaurant has great seafood. If you're looking for gourmet food all you have to do is walk across the street to the Four Season Hotel. The food was great there but it seemed a little sterile to us as far as staying there - plus the Seven Hills' views are much better and it's probably half the cost.If you haven't visited Istanbul, your life is not complete! lol

whats there to say?. It's Istanbul... where the history comes from! Seriously, how many history changing events can happen in one place and still be preserved enough to walk around in 2012? It's so beautiful here, and sometimes you just cannot believe that you're staring at something from 300 BC.

The essence of historic Istanbul.. All of the basis tourist sights are a must see. Only the Grand Bazaar was disappointing as it is too large. A tiresome burden to be hit on by seemingly every one of the 4000 shop keepers in theplace.

The ultimate..... man versus machine. Walking is easy once you get that balance thing down, right? Babies learn to do it by crawling first, pulling up is next, followed by balancing. Well, fellow pedestrians, be sure to put some pep in your step when walking in some ares of Istanbul, for red stop lights and green crossing lights have no meaning!
Istanbul. Beautiful day and night. Loved the palaces and mosques and the whole Sultanahmet area. Food plentiful good and a good value

Absoutely gorgeous. What can I say about one of the most beautiful and historic citiscapes anywhere in the world but wow! If you have never been to Istanbul then this is surely one of the 100 things to do before you die

Istanbul Old Town. Having never travelled to Turkey before I found the Old Town absolutely fascinating. So much to see and do - though difficult to avoid the many carpet sellers, who became a "bit much"!.Nevertheless, a fantastic part of town.

traveing around Istanbul & Kusadasi. great for almost anything eatting mussels on the street, visiting the old city the markets, the Blue Mosque St Sophia there is so many wonderful sights to see the Bosporus river trip to asia Turkey the only country on 2 continents also Kusadasi is a wonderful port just to explore eat and just take in the beauty, also side trips to Ephesus and a trip to Meli's farm is a real treatto have a Turkish lunch with things grown on her farm a beautiful place to relax have a tea check out the animals and birds Turkey a wonderful place to go I will return often

so historical place, but so cosmopolitan. Istanbul its amazing city. has a mix between historical areas and modern areas (like Ninhtasi). You can proove another culture but so safe. The people is kind in general
Istanbul. The city is wonderful with so many sites to visit and so much to see. I was only there for two whole days and I think even if I had a week it would not have been enough.
AMazing. I absolutely adored every inch if Istanbul. Clean, polite, proud, gentle people!! The old ciy is amazing, the boat trip on the Bosphor is sublime.

Our very good guide made the place come alive. This is an interesting and complex site that requires a lot of homework and or and excellent guide. We were amazed at the vastness of such an early building as well as the historical connections it represents
City of the World's Desire!!!. We enjoyed walking around and the wonderful buzz of the city and the bazaars. The food in the smaller restaurants is great, more crowded the better, be bold, eat well.
Kurban Bairami 2011 and 2012. What to say, wonderful stay, nice weather this year, I really like Istanbul that period of the year.
Walking. Fantastic sights. Beware of begars, not the worse I have seen but they are arround. Castle of 7 towers amazing
