History Abounds. So much history wherever you looked, one of the highlights was the visit to the Cisterns, unbelievable that they were built over 1400 years ago.

Where to go when you've seen everything. Make a list of what you want to see before you go - or do like me and just wander around without the map until you're ready to go back to the hotel. Pick a place to eat that has a LOT of people already eating there - that tells you the food is good.
What you come to Istanbul to see. The historic centre can be covered by foot, and there is so much to see that is so fantastic, you need 3 days at least. Trams help the footweary.

Beautiful area to wander round. Lots of sites packed into a tiny space, a lovely day out.Cistern, Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia Museum, Topkani Palace, Spice Bazaar, Grand Bazaar all in easy walking distance or you can jump on the tram if you have tired feet.Top Tip - follow the tram line (even if walking) and then you'll know exactly where you are on your map - street signs appear to be non-exsistant!

the grand bazzar.... forgett cairo,the souuks of petra,algeria,tunisia or morroco...this is the mother of bazzars....streching off in all directions,you could get easily lost here....selling just about everything,including lokkum/turkish delight..alladin in the grand bazzar was unbelivably good...beware of pickpockets,hustlers and a million hagglers but this is the haggling capital of the planet...some say even more than anywhere in the middle east...if you want gen,fake,rugs,,,,jewelery,gemstone,saffron and million other items...go here...but use your head...as many scams as tourists ,target silly idiotic tourists...who think that fake turkish rugs maybe delivered too their address...even in the north pole...lolor gen fake rolexes will not be overpriced and wear off, like a bad cold....within days...try not too advertise your a tourist and be patient and calm for more haggling than you bargined for...even been asked,where are you from,your age, you married? and everyother question you can think of...hospitality in a tsunami,or too some agro-annoyance...lol
Really neat. I loved the old town, it has so much character, wonderful. I would definitely go back. The old buildings are gorgeous.

Take your time and do the homework. You need to look and look long and hard - this place rewards the effort.
This city is the crossroads and this building tells so much of that story.
Go early as queues are significant.

Sultan Ahmet. It is full of history and old city charms.
The Blue Mosque, Aya Sophia, Topkapi Palace Musem are just a few to name.
Istanbul sites. Whirling Dervish at the Galata Mevlevihanesi were worth every cent! Blue mosque is amazing and underground cistern is very cool!

An unforgettable experience.. Within easy reach of each other, we were able to walk to most sites and the tram is very very efficient. It is really safe to walk around at night and there are so many restaurants to choose from, just love the magical night sky of Istanbul.

Terrific town megapolis. Istanbul is the most beautiful city I have ever seen. And I saw a lot of cities until now. Let's count them:- historical area of Sultanahmet is a lot of streets, museums, mosques and the magnificients Aya Sofya and Blue Mosques - terrifics,- Yerebatan & Hippodrome are must of see there;- Kapali Carsi 20 min walking from Sultanahmet zone is an unforgetable experience in your life.Should I continue???City is full of living history & plenty of eating places, small stores, many commercial galerias, etc

Good city to visit.. Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, the Bosphorus, the whirling dervishes, the restaurants! We could feel that this place is the bridge between Asia and Europe from the culture, the food etc.

Very good. I was staying in the center of the old city, the arasta bazaar and a lot of cafe and restaurants are situated here. Night life is amazing tourist walking on the streets at 2 am :) something very different, The blue mosque at nite with the lights on is very nice.

History on a grand green and beautiful scale. All the major sights, Topkapi Palace, Agia Sofia museum the Blue Mosque, the Archaeological Museum, the cistern are all within a very short walking distance of each other. Not only that but the first three set in a parkland area with many obelisks and historical objects from the Byzantine era and even earlier to look at. There is an obelisk from Ancient Egypt to be seen as well with hieroglyphics to examine. The area is traffic free and criss crossed with paths. You also feel you are on the edge of Europe as the park is completely different in character to the parks of northern Europe. When you have finished sightseeing, there are reasonably priced restaurants and cafés on the street nearby including the Hisrical pudding shop.
Visit Istanbul in November. plan your day and visit as many sites as you can. November weather was really good for walking. Don't forget to visit Churh of Christ the Saviour

ISTANBUL IS SIMPLY OPNE OF THE MOST EXCITING CULTURAL VISITS IN THE WORLD. Mostly history and art of Byzantium - Aghia Sophia, Chora Church, palace Mosaics,walls, but the Ottoman sites are also wonderful - Sulemnaiye mosque, Topkapi, and aspects of the contemporary city too, Istanbul Modern, the late palaces and some new museums. Not to forget the wonderful Archaeology Museum
love it. had a few souvineirs it was very interesting but it had very rocky roads that can sore your feey not reallu suitable for disabled or elderly
Fasinating. it was very nice to see these amazing historic sites i was very interested in it there was a lot of peopl though but you cant blame them
history packed city. Visited most of the sights in the old city of Istanbul, Hagia Sophia and the blue mosque are breathtaking, especially at night
Byzantium!. Istanbul is a must for all people who long for the civilization of Constantinople and the Byzantine Empire.
Beautiful and interesting ensemble. Sultanahmet is a very interesting area with plenty of age old architecture from 3 different sophisticated cultures in 2500 years.
Al ot of people but nice atmosphere. very friendly people, not very annoying as in other touristic area of Istanbul they sell everything on the street, try pomerantgranade juice and nuts.
Fabulous!. Lots of mosques to visit. Cheap places to eat at every turn. Good traditional turkish meals. Egyptian spice bazar....... amazing! Side streets have interesting shops.

Joy of Istanbul. overwhelming history spread across 1000's years.Wonderful
friendliness and helpfulness of Turkish and ability to speak english made touring around easy to non Turkish speaking people.
Disliked touts in street.Bargaining

Not to be missed. There is nothing not to like except the Grand Bazaar is mostly for tourists. Archeology Museum is first rate. The new Museum of Innocence is also a must see. The tram system is excellent and the spice market better than ever.

Awesome. You need at least 10 days to travel around Turkey to see all the historical sites.i
I loved all the historical sites we visited especially Ephesus.
Full of heritage. Lot's to see and do. The best was a hike along the old wall and on the top of the wall and a walk back through some non-touristy parts of the city.
Lots to see and very interesting. Loved the atmosphere walking around. A maze of cobbled streets with loads of character. Plenty to keep us occupied for a four day visit.
A memorable trip to Istanbul. A good standard hotel in an area close to many of the main historic sites. Staff were very helpful when I became Ill and had to reschedule flights and tansfers.

Loved it. A must do for first time visitors. Very crowded throughout the day and the lines into various places can be quite long. Would recommend staying in the Sultanahmet district so you can get up early to avoid the crowds and also visit later at night to see everything lit up.
wow. you can really immerse yourself in ancient history, going back thousands of years. east truly meets west in istanbul.

A very beautiful city. I stayed for eleven days and there was something interesting to do every day. The Blue Mosque, Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace and many many other historic and beautiful places. There are a lot of touts but they (mostly) don't go for the hard sell and many will help you with free advice. I preferred the Asian side of the city which was cleaner, cheaper and less touristy.

Old city. the bast place to walk in Istanbul.There are 2 Bazaars (capali Carsi and Egyptian),which are plenty of visitors and useless things.It is a great experiance to walk through the paths between the Turkish people and the tourists.There is no need for public transport and it is the bet place to stay because its very close to the center of the city and there is not so much noise as Isticlal.

Unfortunately,Aya Sofia was closed both times we visited it. We did n't joined the food very much.if anyone don't like doner ,he will go hungry.The daily cruise at vosporus is very nostalgic.A great place with a lot of historical memories.

WOW !!!. What a great 1/2 day, i went to Hogia Sophia and Blue mosque, went very early so no many queues. When we finished the two places, there were long queues so if you are visiting them try to go early. its lovely history and majestic. Very nice to take pictures.this was the only thing i liked in Istanbul. City is too crowded and very tourist oriented so everything is very pricy..
A must-see in Istanbul. The Istanbul Old Town is a definite must-see! The atmosphere is unique. Recommend strolling around the center and visiting Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque.
Haga Sophia & Blue Mosque. History in your face! Crossroad of the world - and crossroad of two the worlds great religions - great place - very spiritual.
Old Istanbul. Didn't like queues and touts. Wait until later in the day when excursions have gone, this will give you shorter queues and avoid snakes of guided tours.
Day Out in Istanbul. All very interesting but so many people - the queues were horrendous. Hated Grand Bazaar - really disliked hastling

Go back to history. This is an amazing historical area that worth visiting at least once of you time life if not five times. It is very well serviced and very clean. All requirements are next door. People are very friendly

Istanbul is a must visit place. Istanbul is a must visit place in world cities. It combines the culture of East and West. To see all the historical monuments in Constantinople was unforgettable. The city which has all the modern and historic touch

Haghia Sophia, Topkapi, Blue Mosque....Hard to beat!. The sights of Istanbul are in league with all the other great cities of the Old World like Paris, London, Prague, Vienna. I personally think the exotic nature of Istanbul stands above the rest but just my opinion. To stay in the Sultanahmet district and walk between the Blue Mosque and Haghia Sophia each day on your daily sightseeing routine cannot be equaled anywhere!
loved it.. SO interesting. Walk carefully as paths are very uneven. Like all ancient places. Surprise around every corner.

Go on an adventure. The people of Istanbul are eager for tourism. While they are seeing a lot of German tourists, Americans are welcome as well. I never felt that I was unwelcome. I loved going through the underground bazaar, the Bosphorus Strait Cruise, having a Turkish Bath, Turkish coffee at a local bakery. There is plenty to do and see. Bring your camera!

Confusing streets but fun to explore. Make sure you have very clear directions of where you need to go. Couldn't find street names but used landmarks to determine where I was. Great to know that they have a preservation plan in place
Marmaris to Istanbul in two days. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi and all the other sites of the city were beautiful places to visit.

NO PLACE LIKE IT!. Although this was my third visit, my husband had not been to Istanbul previously. We were overnighting on a cruise ship so just had a day and a half which is nowhere near enough to see and do everything in this interesting city. It's east meets west with so many amazing sights. If you only have a short time there see the Hagia Sophia and the Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Basilica Cistern and take in an hamam. We visited the Arista Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar this time and missed the Grand Bazaar (which can be overwhelming). Watched the people fishing on the Galata Bridge and even stopped in the Pera Palace for a morning tea break. The public transportation system is easy and the trams are the best way to get around - for 3 lira per person (just over a dollar), you can get to the Sultanahmet area from the cruise ship dock. You just put coins (or notes) - must be Turkish lira - into the Jeton machines and get a token, insert it into the turnstyle before getting on the platform. The Turkish people are helpful and friendly, although you have to be prepared to fight off the many book, postcard, carpet, souvenir salespeople.

great back streets. No one ever told me how hilly Istanbul is, but there are advantages to that, walking through the back streets of the old town every so often an amazing view opens up of theBophorus, the Galata Tower, the Blue Mosque, and all the time you can look at the local shops, get chatted to by helpful locals (so many people stopped to assist whenever we got the map out) and generally poke around

Fascinating layers of history. very interesting to walk around Sultanahmet. Yes therea re the usual "would you like to come to my carpet shop" but they are all friendly and take no for an answer. There are layers upon layers of history here, the Romans, the Byzantines, the Ottomans and now a modern developing city, fascinating.
Perfect. Save your feets and see all in one day.This is were you find everything of "must see" in Istabul at daytime
Oustanding. All areas outstanding, ignore the "carpet sellers" and you will have a great time. Move around by using the trams, cheap and efficient

Exciting, clean, safe: brilliant. Clean streets, no drunks around late at night. Old city has all the sights within minutes of each other. Lots of restaurants in a range of prices. Hotel rooftop bars and restaurents welcome non residents for georgeous views as dusk falls (early).

Sultanahmet. A wonderful base to view all of the main Sights in Istanbul, Blue Mosque, Sainta Sophia, Topkapi, Grand Bazaar, Underground Cistern. To catch a City sightseeing bus tour to view this great vibrant city.
Interesting!. Saw a lot of interesting place in Istanbul that I never have seen in my whole life. I enjoyed my stay there!

The magnificent city!. The city of three Empires and the city on two continents, Constantinople is a place everyone must see! Abundant with arcitecture from different periods and reigns, with artwork, colours, flavours and panoramic views, the Historic areas of Istanbul well deserved its designation as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. We spent three days in this amazing city and I can say that even a week wouldn't be enough to marvel the oustatnding treasures that it possesses.
Amazing. An amazing mix of east and west with history everywhere. A beautiful and vibrant city. The bazaars, historical sites, streets were fascinating to walk around and just absorb the culture.
So magnificent!. I liked the blue Mosque,Aya Sofia,and the Grand bazar.i disliked the traffic and the hrs u need to reach your place.
Birthday present. We wandered around quite a bit and saw really a lot beautiful sightseeing things. We loved the city.
old istanbul. everythink is perfect however that is too crowed .ıf you don't go with tour or you don't have e-ticket you can spend your all day in line ):
Blue mosque. Beautiful from in and outside, well organizes entry for free, pray time is closed approximately 90 minutes.

walk through history. It is a different world, one of those things - you either love it or hate it. We certainly loved it. Old narrow streets, carpet and lanterns shops, big and small caffees, mosques, palaces and bazars - all of it is just magic. Absolutely loved Misir (Egyptian) Bazar!
Much more than expected. We throughly enjoyed our trip to Istanbul The people were friendly, the city clean, modern and the food was fabulous.

WALKING TOUR. A self-guided walking tour is really easy to do here. The historic sites of Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace are all within walking distance of each other. If you are physically-fit, enjoy walking and have time, you can even walk to the Grand Bazaar or to the Spice Market. There are lots of shops, restaurants, and things to see along the way. Otherwise, you can take a tram nearby very easily. During peak season-the traditional school break, foot traffic can be very heavy as well and there are very long lines to get into the sites, particularly the Hagia Sophia. Thousands of tourists from all over the world descend upon Istanbul,. On Fridays the number multiples as 3 or more cruise ships dock simultaneously, their passengers flood the narrow aisles of the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market, particularly in the morning.
Brilliant town, a must see full of cheats and liars. This is brilliant historical town... A must see...the problem is...It is FULL of crocks, cheats and liars.
Worth seeing. Worth seeing once in a life time. The city is great, but be aware at crocks, there are lots everywhere.
Historic Istanbul. The history. The beautiful decoration ! This was all amazing !! There is still a lot of restoration to be done.These are HUGE buildings !!
excellent. we like very much old city area than Taxim, St. sophia museum magnificent, Bule Mosque especially Topkapi palace is my favorite place.

Blue Mosque, brilliant. A very vibrant city, great restaurants, shops etc., the Grand Bazaar was an experience all travellers should take in, the people are so friendly, it was a pity we only had 3 nights there before flying to Cyprus

imposing palace DOLMABAHCE. Do not fail to visit Dolmabahce Palace, a ten minute taxi ride from Sultanahmet (cost 10TL), here again be patient with the very long lines , pay 40TL pp which includes a guided tour to the Palace and the Harem. An impressive rather recent palace on reclaimed land. When your visit is completed walk uphill for 15 - 20 minutes to Taksim Square, down Istiklal and the imposing Galata Tower little square with two great restaurants to enjoy your meal. Cicek Pasaji halfway down on Istiklal a nice place for a drink.

Venture out. If you venture beyond the tourist area of Sultanahmet you see why this is a town to return to . Walk the walls, well you can't walk along most of the tops but along the inside is a real treat even if you do get lost like we did because of construction. The city is beautifying itself with lots of planting and some of the walls have be rebuilt, but take care with the traffic! Cross the Bosphorus into the modernish area..it is a real treat to wander the steep hills with are being quickly trendified and check out the street food...great! Don't miss the sun going down over the city with a beer at one of the restaurants under the bridge, yes under, the bridge is on two levels..with eateries on the lower level with pesky touts trying to get you to eat there, but take your time and choose.

Words Fail. If you only have time for one place in this wonderful city this is the place to go. Beautiful! All my llife I have seen reproductions of these mosaics and to see them for real was a fulfilment of a dream. Stand and look carefully at anything, even the drains and the steps...
Stroll. You have to reserve yourself a time for self discovering old town without guides. Just for contemplation!
Entertaining histort. I like much the sense of ancient kept through ages and maintained well to be wittness of the history of that eara

amazing. all the historical places are fantastic and usually have an element of fun like an oppurtunity to have your picture taken in traditional dress if you visit the historical cistern. sultenahemt are is very good
Part of our lives. Monuments of other time, the monuments of two ex-empires, two different cultures and two different religions. In other words international monuments.

Wander around town. Istanbul is a great city for wandering about. Crazy near the bazaars, but exciting. Stroll around the historic streets, over the Galata brigade past all the fishermen. Find yourself a rooftop terrace for great views and a drink.

You see it everyday in Istanbul . No need to plan for this part. Choose to live in the historic district and you will see this every day... I lived in two hotels in this area - 5 mins away from blue mosque... Do check the high ranking hotels from tripadvisor review. It is very popular among hotels in Istanbul

You will enjoy it. You will enjoy either the historical, religious and fun attractions here. My GOD, Istanbul is the city with complete of everything anyone would want. Only if the country is speaking in english fluently, then maybe I wanna be Turkey residence.

Istanbul Delight. Great Atmosphere; loved walking around Taksim visiting the old city, the Grand Bazaar!! Food was delightful even at the small restaurants. The sea food was outstanding. The traffic was quite horrendous - cheating taxi drivers kept you on your toes, as did the "guides" outside the historical areas.
Facinating. Loved the atmosphere. The old buildings are charming and when the city comes alive, the vibe is amazing. Easy to get around.
timeless elegance. the cobbled stone streets, the friendly people, the divine cuisine and the safe environment not to forget the scrumptous desserts
Totally Authentic. I can't believe there are so many wonderful sights in one square mile of a city. Awesome. the sights look great in the daylight but even better at night all lit up

Quaint and not hassled. Walked all over the old city. Was a bit concerned that we may get hassle from market traders (like Egypt). Nothing like - people are friendly and amazed us that they leave out food for stray cats. Went into a number of mosques and never felt anything but warmth.

Sultanahmet area is brilliant. The mosques are great as is the grand market but get off the beaten track and walk the streets. Eat where the locals eat. We found everyone friendly and willing to make our time in Istanbul as enjoyable as possible
Don't miss out on the opportunity. The old town is very busy, absolutely heaving with life and if you want a carpet or rug, this is the place for you. Get your bargaining head on early and keep cool.

Awe-inspiring Istanbul. The main sites in Istanbul are mostly all in the Old City and to me, exceed expectations... especially Aya Sofya and the Blue Mosque. Topkapi Palace and Harem, Mosaic Museum and the Chora Church are also not to be missed. Be sure to get the Museum Pass (which covers all the sights mentioned, INCLUDING Harem now) - it will save you a lot of time in avoiding long lines and is well worth the money.

Two words: Uh Mazing!. Anyone who is interested in history must visit Turkey. It's one thing to know about the major sites, historic events, and culture, It's another thing all together to be standing in the middle of the Aya Sophia and looking at the frescoes and mosaics that will be standing long after we're wormfood. We were so blessed with an amazing tour guide who was an archeologist and teacher. Made all the difference in the world to give deep historical and cultural context and point out the tiniest nuances not mentioned in tour books.
it was fantastic area. there you can see the blue mosque with its nice decoration from inside , and aya sofia with its mixed features , and nice space to sit and rest

Great area to wander. After visiting the main sights, it is wonderful to just wander up, down and around the narrow cobbled streets and see what you find. We did visit the Grand Bazaar but found it quite overwhelming, however the Spice Bazaar was something to see - so many different spices and foods, great if you were styaing in an apartment and able to cook some of your meals. We also wandered thrugh the University area up to the Suleymaniye mosque and then over to the Prince's Mosque. We found the people to be friendly and we weren't pestered, a polite no thank you was accepted.

The illuminated blue mosque in night is absolutely fabulous. We did visit Blue mosque, Ayasofya church and Topkapi palace. The buildings are impressive, but not well preserved. Maybe because of religious holiday, but all visited places were extremely overcrowded. Fragfments of old city walls are falling apart. Dirty and shabby...

A walk back in time. Istanbul's old Town is so atmpospheric. Simply wandering the steep cobbled streets, stopping for tea, coffee or a snack, browsing through a few shops, then continuing on your way, is an experience to be savoured. it is when i am in the Old Town that I remember why I love Istanbul.
Beautiful Istanbul. There are too many toi mention. The mosques and palaces are all lovely and walking the city is just lovely.
Istanbul magic. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Roman Cistern, Grand Bazar were all breathtaking. A cruise on the Bospherous was a delight not to be missed.

So much history!. Istanbul is a huge city. In the old city there are so many historic places to visit. You will find interesting things to do every day. People are friendly and you feel vary safe walking around.

Istanbul. I like to have fish on the bosphorus area and walking on the bosphorus discovering the city was amazing, we like very much istanbul and history. we reccomend certainly for everyone to Istanbul.

Istanbul is great. Great historical landmarks and great shopping. The food is fantastic too. We wish we had more time for turkish bath and Bosphoros. You need at list 3 days to enjoy and see most of the city.
Byzantium churches. The Agia Sophia church, Yerebatan Saray and Theodosian walls are really worth visiting as well as many other churches, like The Chora Church.

The Istanbul old town gives you a taste of the real Istanbul. We stumbled on this area and just loved it. Mixing with the locals and great bargains amidst the old buildings add to the ambience of this area.

Historic Istanbul is a must to visit. These are some of the most beautiful buildings and areas I have ever seen. There were queues but everyone behaved and waited patiently and they moved fairly quickly. Buy a museum pass if you can to skip these.I spent 5 days and could have spent longer quiet easily. Tiles and mosaics are beautiful and walking around the coastline watching the boats come and go amazing. Make sure you do a boat trip. Public transport to get around was very good the trams for 3 turkish lira were air conditioned and comfortable.

Fascinating. What an amazing place! The Romans left their marks, which you can still see. The Hippodrome, Blue Mosque, Hagis Sophis and Topkapi Palace are the most obvious sites and they are all individually impressive. Put them together and it you feel so insignificant, but lucky to be there. Fascinating place, with loads of stuff to see and find. Tea gardens in a graveyard, bazaars, the atmosphere. Wonderful.

Very touritic area. Many touristic historical sites, very nice atmosphere, many restaurants.The main disadvantage is that theres many ups and down, we have 3 kids including a baby it was hard for them.

Looks just like the pictures. If you have to, pay for a guide to personally show you around - and skip the enormous lines - if you go during peak times. Otherwise, I hear the Rick Steve's guidebook is fantastic and more than enough for a self-guided tour to Sultanahmet (Blue) Mosque and Hagia Sofia.
Historic architectural and decorative beauty. Some amazing buildings - but the queues were huge for the most popular museums (including Aya Sofya), unless you arrive just before opening time.
What is not to love. Istanbul is a feast for the eyes. Plane a few days to soak it all in. You could walk for miles and still not see it all.
History. If you are at all interested in history, especially Christian history, Istanbul is a must. I would love to do more reading about Byzantium and then go back.

Top Town. Greek, Roman and Ottaman influences abound and it is a treasure trove for any student or afficionado of history. Would require many years to explore every hidden gem and alleyway.
My third visit and still captivated.

Get Lost. Get a map and get lost! So many interesting places to see. Take your time and do it over a few days. Eat at the multitude of small cafes and hope for the best with what you order. Spend some time people watching.

To be in a place that was historically so significant is like Wow!. Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, the Bosphorus, the whirling dervishes, the restaurants! We could feel that this place is the bridge between Asia and Europe from the culture, the food etc.
A modern city with an ancient heart. The old city is full of easily accessible sights, each better than the next. My favorite is the Basilica Cistern.
A modern city with an ancient heart. The old city is full of easily accessible sights, each better than the next. My favorite is the Basilica Cistern.
Culture vultures. particularly loved the Top kapi palace thought the treasury and harem were amazing especially the topkapi dagger and the HUGE diamond
Istanbul city centre. Amazing historical sights, dating back to Roman times. Bustling city, full of incredibel sights and smells

Enchanting Istanbul. Beautiful City with lots to see. The main attractions were within walking distance.We had a very good travel guide Naim who was very well informed.We thought that the Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya were fabulous.The underground water system was amazing.Finally the cruise on the Bosphorus with the belly dancer was very enjoyable.
East meets West. Breathtaking for a non historian. The mosques were such an event and quite spectacular. A trip on the Bosphorus is a must as is a visit to Sultanahmet Square.

Sultanamet is the best area to stay. This loaction is convenient and slightly upscale compared to other nearby locations. We preferred it to the Taksim and Beyoglu areas. Both are touristy areas, but Sultanamet felt more historic.

Amazing Istanbul. I was in Istanbul Old town last month. I have to say that it was one of my best vacations ever. There were so many things to see. Places I visitied are The Blue Mosque, Haque Sofia and Basilica Cistern. The architecture of these historical sites were stunning! I am hope to go there again next year .
Loved all of the palaces. Easy access via the trolley, easy walks, the palaces are stunning, the museums are interesting. So much history!
many things to do. The district is called Sultanahmet and here you can visit Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, Grand Bazar and also the spicy bazaar.

Historic Istanbul at your fingertips. A lot of historic sites are within Sultanahmet. The Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Basilica Cistern plus an easy to use tramway system.The crowds are pretty horrendous but it's the same all over the world.
It takes a bit of time to get used to all the 'traders' in the streets. A smile with a no thanks works wonders.
charming. the old town is truly wonderful.. old buildings, some almost on the verge of breaking :p and the small alleys which have so many places to be explored.. truly charming
Great Mosques and Monuments, Grand Bazaar & SEA Sights. i cant say that you would dislike any thing but obviously if you dont eat Beaf then this would trouble you

historic sights. There are too many sites mention, but the often mentioned ones are a wonderful visual delight.The truly magnificient churches & palaces are so well preserved that photos cannot do justice for the detail, painting & huge amount work done by
brilliant artisans who probably spent their life-times to complete their tasks.
Awesome. There is so many interesting places to see here, and so much history. I truely recommend the Old Town Istanbul for everyone who enjoys travelling.
Old Town. We loved the Old Town of Istanbul. Amazing area, very good transports and what a vibe! Istanbul is definitely worth visiting!

All the culture you want!. Never a boring moment in Istanbul. Too many sights to see, too many things to do and too many good restaurants. We were only there for five days and our one regret is that we didn't have enough time in the capital. The Turks are really friendly and can't do enough to help and assist. Even the carpet shop assistants were polite and not pushy. They offered tea and a chat and changed my view of hospitality. Just the queues for some of the attractions and the odd con man who wanted to lead us off the beaten path, but even they were polite when we refused their offerings.
Great location. Just a great location within walking distance to places of interest people very friendly and helpful. Our Hotel Romance is situated her.
amazing. loved the athmosphere. just didn't like people trying to sell you stuff every 2 seconds, after a while can become annoying

Worth spending a couple of days!. From the Blue Mosque to the Topkapi Palace, the Aya Sophia to the Grand Bazaar this is a great place to spend time. Go to the cistern and marvel at the technology. Eat at the Pudding Shop and watch the crowds...take your time. Don't rush through them all in one day.

Wonderful history. Loved the historic sites and history of Istanbul. Amazing basilicas, mosques and palaces. Try having lunch at the Four Seasons Sultanahment. It's a wondeful, quite place to take a break from the hustle and bustle

So Much To See & Visit.. The list of ancient and fascinating sites is endless, we spent 4 days in Istanbul which was enough for us as we managed to visit all the major sites in the old twon area. All done on foot and as it is on 7 hills, hard work at time but worth it.Any longer I think and it gets to be information and mosque overload and the food can get a little repetetive
Topkapi. Very clean and interesting, but not enough of the buildings were open or didn't have enough antiquities to make it interesting.
Ambiance. Lovely ambiance in historical Istanbul. Lots to see! Don't miss the cisterns, absolutely unique and stunning. The serenity, rhe Medusa heads and the reflections from the water.

very good!. the hotels, restaurants, travel agencies, historical old buildings around and etc. i like everything there. but the only thing i dont like there its the apache people who are disturbing tourists and trying to sell something

was really historic. i like historical areas of istanbul. it was quite good to travel around. but what i did not like it was the entrance fees. its such a big and rich country they say but still they need us to pay for entrances. i did not like it!

Walk Around The Old Town.. Fascinating streets and shops, people watching is a great past time. All the usual shops selling touristy stuff but the sweet and food shops are the most interesting. We fely very safe and not at all intimidated walking around, people very friendly and helpful. Also great to check out all the restaurants before choosing one for dinner.

Sinan's masterpieces. Istanbul is testament to what man can achieve driven by faith and noble ambition. The seat of the Ottaman empire for many generations, Istanbul benefitted immensely from the dedication of its people to erect some of the most beautiful mosques in the world. Steeped in history, these historic monuments remain well preserved and have the added benefit for visitors that they are functioning mosques. Outside, the worshipers perform their ablution. It is ideal to visit during prayertimes - 5 times a day at various times depending on the time of year. At this time you can witness the prayer being perfomed in congregation - perhaps the greatest insight people of other faiths can gain into the practice of Islam - its sublime simplicity devoid of iconography which stands it in stark contrast to most faith systems. You don't have to take my word from it but I would recommend seeking out some of the smaller mosques - Rustum Pasah and the new mosque are easily accessible from Sultanahamet.
Best Excursion to Turkey :). everything is preserved, everyone is friendly and helpful...just there are too much people on the street trying to offer you things..
Historic areas of Istanbul. In a compact area where it is easy to find your way because of the tram line. Did not like the vendors along the way - too pushy.

Delightful. The "old City" and the Sultanahmet areas sort of merge into each other. The old city is fullof businesses, wholesale and resale and goes down all the way to the piers where the ferriesleave. A vibrant area, full of life and spirits. And remarkably clean and with lots of friendly people.

TAKE YOUR TIME. To see all the historic attractions in Istanbul takes time. We took advantage of three full days walking all the areas and enjoyed it tremendously. Yes, everything is much cleaner than we expected and it was way more fun that we had tought.

Istanbul historic areas. Friends we traveled with have been to Istanbul before. They noted the city is much cleaner than it was when they had seen it. We found it to be wonderful and enjoyed all the historic sites.
one day enough. You can see the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Palace, underground cistern, and the bazaar all in one day, easily.

Old Istanbul. This is a great place to just meander arround. While the shop keepers can often be aggressive, just learn to say a firm no. The walking is a bit rigorous, but do it anyway. You will not regret it.
So much to see and do. I was blown away by Istanbul. Treat The Grand Bazaar as a game: you are an idiot if you do not haggle never ever pay over have of opening price. If that.

Amazing City!. Only metropolitan that connects two continents in the world. You should go all the way to the Black Sea entrance of the European side of Istanbul and then come back from across the other side, which is Asian part of Istanbul. Follow the coastline, visit the amazing world class restaurants and see the modern side of this beautiful city. History, climate, food, beverages, nightlife, views, boat trips, culture and so on..everything is great about this city.

Wouldn't stay here, but would visit during the day. A great place to see the city's oldest history, this area is a bit touristy, but boasts incredible mosques and Aya Sofia, which dates from early Christendom. It seems there is no good time to visit as the area is packed with tourists and school children. Stay elsewhere and visit this part of town during the day.

Live there. We chose a hotel that said "Old City" but closer to Bayazit and the university. No matter, walking in the evening is safe and wonderful street food and not so many tourists. Wandering back street you see daily activities and some great shopping that is for residents. We ate most nights in tiny shops where we pointed to what we wanted and from street vendors...try the deep fried sardines....WOW.

Sultanahmet area. Sultanahmet area is really wonderful during the evening, almost magical. However, now with all these works in progress, space of the central area looks limited. The cafe which is situated next to Hurrem Sultan Hamam and used to have wonderful traditional seats and tables in the past, now has ordinary ones, something rather disapointing. This probably happened because more tables--chairs can be there for more people to sit, but do people now want to go there as they wanted before? Personally, I don't...
Fun, fun, fun!. So much to do! Relax in the park, take the "Big Bus City Tour" or walk all around the Grand Bazaar, Mosques, little shops, hotels and restaurants.
All Historic places beautiful and well kept.. Loved it all. The good side of Istanbul, and than off coursethere is the poorer side - but generally all good.
OLD CITY. All walkable. Many places to sit, have a drink. Other interesting walkers about. Rich in attractions.

A fascinating city packed with history & atmosphere. I stayed here for 3 weeks with my teenage son on our 10,000-mile cycle expedition from Ireland to Japan (book: Long Road, Hard Lessons). We were waiting for Iran visas. It was a great place to wait. Istanbul is full of history with a vibrant atmosphere. There are several distinct areas. We loved the Taksim area, with the interesting, narrow back streets. The Asian side (by boat) is very traditional with interesting buildings everywhere. The Princes Islands are also reached by boat and very historic. The most visited historic area is probably Sultan Ahmet Square, with the Blue Mosque and St Sophia mosque. Nobody could fail to be impressed. Go early morning before the coaches arrive. It's popular.
grand pazzar. if you go to istanbul dont miss to visit this place for shopping you will find alot of fantastic clothes with good prices

packed with history. go everywhere, see everything, don't miss the museums, best time to visit: maybe october - sunny weather and not too hot. and when you get hungry, there are hundreds of restaurants to choose from

fuul of history. This former superpower is full of historical places. You can go to Istanbul 100 times, and when you come back, there will always be something new to see. I recommend: Topkapi palace, Dolmabahche palace, Kapali ccharshi grand bazaar, Historical museums, Military museum, Panorama 1453 museum, Galata tower, Yeni mosque, Sultan Ahmet mosque, Nur Osman Mosque, Dolmabahche mosque, Aya Sofia mosque, Suleymania mosque, Old city walls, Uskudar Asian par etc.
Absolutely wonderful. History has been made and un-made here for thousands of years and it is so present! Loved all the jumble of buildings and the people still live in an exotic place.

Crazy, dusty, fascinating.... Despite not really liking doing "the tourist thing", you cannot fail to be impressed by the beauty and grandeur of the ancient buildings around Istanbul, The skyline from the ferry at sunset is breathtaking.
Be prepared to walk. Really enjoyed the sights and going by foot is definitely the best way to see them. Loves Topkapi Palace and also the cistern.

Remember, Sleeves and long pants/skirts. This is very well presented and obviously the pride of Istanbul. My favourite was the Water Cistern - very interesting and the engineering involved was impressive.

Go and wander. One of the things I love about the Old Town section of IST is to just wander. Up hills, down hills, into and out of alleys and in and around the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market. You never know what you will see or find around the next corner. Thats why you should do it.

Istanbul Sightseeing. we used Plan Turizm AS for both, the full day Byzantine and Ottoman Relics tour which was great and the half day tour Golden Horn and Bosporus Cruise. Whereas we were picked up and dropped off punctually on the full day tour, the half day tour pick up was punctual but they literally dumped us at a dead end of Sult
Great History. An historical country loads to see and go well prepared as to what u want to do each day.. and how much time you want to spend

Beautiful oriental city - and around the corner western modernity. The old town is beautiful with small alleyways, shops selling lanterns, souvenirs and juices. The area between Topkapi palace and the Blue Mosque is very touristic, but equally beautiful!Just around the corner it's very modern, which makes this city mystically attractive.
must be seen. In istanbul you must see there. and you must see 'yerebatan sarnıcı'very crowded. yerebatan sarnıcı is the best I think
Sultanahmet - Blue Square and Hagia Sophia. Very well maintained and easy to enter (no long queues). You can see the grand scale of the structures and appreciate the history behind it!

Beautiful Chora Church. This church is out of the way (best to take a taxi, i think) but the mosaics all over the walls and ceiling and so beautiful. They tell the story of Ann, the Virgin Mary's mother, as well as the story of Jesus.

It's the shops in the alleys that hold the best bargains. Have a quick visit to the Spice Market which is set up for tourists and then walk right through to the end and up the streets leading up a gently slope. There are many alleys and twists and turns, but this is where the locals shop, not at the Grand Bazaar or Spice Market. You can buy literally everything you could possible need here and even things you didn't know you needed until you saw them. I bought so many things that I had to buy another bag USD5 to take them home in. As you head up the hill and after you have stopped for a cold drink or tea and watched the world go by for a while, you will eventually come to one of the gates to the Grand Bazaar. I don't like tourist bazaars so spent very little time here. I had my purchases and was happy.

Worth visiting. Crowded but very intrestin. Not to be missed. I visited basilica cistern wich is underground and the blue mosque, hagia sophia and the monuments on the main street. Dont miss the fountain specially during night its covered by lights and colors.

You must put Instanbul on your bucket list. I loved the historic sites...amazing stories and histories. It is wonderful to see them so loved and well looked after...only downside the the size of the crowds but even then they were well managed and did not spoil the visit.
Breath taking and interesting. History, the Sea, relatively authentic, amazing food, gracious people. That is what you will find. I really enjoyed this City.

Rugs and Kilims in Sultanahmet. As a collector of flat-weaves I am always looking for unusual and one-of-a-kind kilims and soumaks. On a recent trip to Istanbul I was fortunate to find Harem Carpets in the Arasta Bazaar. Their collection was the best I have ever seen anywhere. If you are interested in really unique pieces, don't miss this fabulous shop.---Barbara Waddell, Marietta, Georgia

Compact. The average tourist likes the attractions that they visit to be within a stones throw of each other. Unfortunately the city planners in the 15th century didn't understand this quality, but in Istanbul they got it right!Sultanahmet Camii, Hagia Sophia and Topkapi Palace (along with the Hippodrome, Basilica Cistern, Arasta Bazaar and Henry the rug merchant) are all within 500m of each other - tourist heaven!This is a compact collection but the real benefit is that once you've been a tourist (in half a day) you can take some time to meet the locals over at Karakoy, Kadikoy and up at Galata Tower late at night and really get a feel for Istanbul!Mimar Sinan got it right in Istanbul - enjoy his 15th Century planning skills!

Istambul Old Town. This the center of old Istambul. The grand bazaar which was established in 1461 is unbelievable in its architecure and the size and the amount of stores and different items available. In this area you many large mosques, plus the cisterns, Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque, plus the train station that was the last stop for the Orient Express. There are several mausoleums and cemetiries for the sultans and family. The Istambul university was the first sultan palace. The spice bazzar is smaller than the Grand Bazzar. As its name says it deals mostly with spices plus souvenir shops. It is also known as the Egyptian bazzar. Istambul has a nice modern tram that will take you to the other side (across the bridge) of Istambul

awesome unbelievable historic. history of istambul and turkey is huge with different cultures in the last 3000 years with each one leaving its footprint the grand bazaar, Hagia Sophia and the blue mosque are incredible the size and age of these monuments. the sultan palaces and mosques are genuine beautiful and impresive. weather was hot in july and crowds were lare for the historic places. Not enough emphasis is given to Christian sites. No information about Constatine tomb or his mother St. Helena. Difficult to find the old Christian church close to the city walls.
Fascinating. Much to see and learn but traffic was a nightmare.Many incredible places to discover but one needs a lot of time and patience.

Historic Istanbul at a glance. Although I have been to Istanbul many times I am still fascinated by this city of 14 million people and always discover something new. Like most other tourists I book a hotel in the historic part of town on the European side. Since hotel prices seem to be going up the closer one gets to the Blue Mosque and Topkapi museum I always make reservations at a place which is a little further away, say in the area of the Sultan Ahmet mosque (Fatih district) which is still close enough to all major attractions of the city. Plus the restaurants and cafes tend to be more reasonably priced.For those of you who are limited on time but still want to see the most famous attractions of the old town I suggest that your first stop should be the Hagia Sophia mosque, followed by the Blue Mosque, the Topkapi museum

Captivating city. What a city!!! İt has everything and all places i visited were much better than pictures. #1 are the beautiful, well- mannered and extremely helpful people of İstanbul. Then ayasophia, rumeli hisari, walks in sultanahmet, local weekly markets, , and Do Not skip the bosphorus cruise no matter what :-)
Mixture of East and West Culture. Yes, a country full with very culture, mixture of east and west. you can find many signature buildings related to religous

Beautiful and historical!. My husband and I sat on a bench between Haghia Sophia and Blue Mosque in the square (lots of benches provided) and enjoyed the view of the mosques, once during the day, once at night, and another time around the sunset time. Beauuuutiful sight, and lots of snacks to munch on from the street vendors. :) I loved the fresh squezed pomegranate and orange juice & roasted chestnuts! There are so many tourist attractions are in walking distance, which made it very convenient. You could technically go to Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern, and Topkapi (they are all very close to each other) along with the Grand Bazaar in one day if you're in a hurry. We took our time and visited those places in 2 days.
Touristy but fun to stroll through. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market are fun but overpriced and touristy unless you know of special shops. Walking in the back alleys is great fun.

Istanbul is truly and exciting and beautiful city.. The layers of history are many and still palpable, the architecture stunning, the location on the Bosphorus very beautiful. Friendly people, great food, easy to get around on public transportation.Traffic can be hectic; be very careful as a pedestrian. If there are cruise ships in the crowds at Hagia Sophia and Topcaki can be bad.

Topkapi. A must see; the jewels were simply out of this world. We found the english language guide was well written and appeared to offer full details on all of the areas. A special exhibition was on a the time concerning the harem; it had some fantastic exhibits on custume.
Old Istanbul. Just the way it has been preserved. This has to be oneof the cleanest cities I have visited. If you get there early you will avoiid having to queue - although it moves quite quickly

wonderful trip back in the history of istanbul. I liked all the places. Breath taking architecture both in the ceiling and on the floor. My tour guide was very helpfu because he taught me a lot and he was very kind and he even gave me books that i can bring home and read and share with everybody back home. But there are onnly few Turkish people speaking in English but it was ok, I was able to manage. Over-all my visit to the Historic Sites, A+++ :)
Sultanamet. Loved the history, enjoyed the people, disliked not having more time. All Turkish salesmen seem to go to charm school - never aggressive, never to be believed!
Best thing to do in Istanbul. My favorites were the cistern and the archaeology museum, the mosques were also quite good, but really crowded with tourists.
amazing city. top kape ...blue mosque...taksim square ....grand bazar all located in the same areas where you could enjoy the history and shop great things as well

Istanbul. Nice city lots of things to see and do. I would avoid the restaurants on Gallata bridge like the plague. Try the small back-alley restaurants in the spice market such as the one near the bag and packing materials part of the spice market

Wonderful city full of charm and interest. We loved Istanbul, its a fantastic place to visit. Its has a fascinating history and beautiful buildings, and best of all its a true meeting place for the world.

The historical atmosphere. The old town of Istanbul City which is called Sultanahmet is the place where you can actually live and witness the history, with the beautiful architecture, narrow streets, perfect views and landscape.
Do not forget to give a visit to Underground Cistern, Blue Mosque, Ayasofya and Topkapi Palace.

Great places to visit!. Istambul is a magnificent city to visit, Hagia sophia was the highest point of this visit . History pure, honest and of high quality.
I loved the city

Amazing antiquities!. We loved Agia Sofia....the history about this church is spellbinding. We also went to Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and the underground water system that was like being in a old time movie.
Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya. nice monuments and small streets around these 2 mosques especially at sunset (try to sit on the top terrace of one of many restaurants around this location)
Blue Mosque. So beautiful and inviting. You need a lot of photographs to take it all in. Every dome and corner has something to see.

4 days in the historical city. I liked all the Sultanhamed and Soliman Mosk surrounding, The Bosphore excursion.
I did not like the trafic cars !!!

Busy but great. The historic areas of Istanbul are conveniently co-located. Most of the major sites are within easy walking distance. Entry prices appear reasonably priced. Gift shops mostly good, but prices reflect it being a major tourist site/s. It was Ramadan/Ramazan when we visited, so it was a busy time and hot in August. September might be cooler and quieter.
must see, beautiful place. Lots to see, frendly city, great place to visit, do not be discouraged by the long lines a some sites they do move fast.

worthwhile.. Christian landscape and properly maintained. really worth it to see this beautiful landscape.
It includes locations such as the Galata Bridge, the Seraglio Point where the Topkapı Palace, the Hagia Sophia, the Sultan Ahmed Mosque, the Yeni Mosque near the Galata Bridge, the Beyazıt Tower and the Süleymaniye Mosque.

Great city to explore. Istanbul is very good idea for a weekend or even more. There are so many interesting places to see and Old Town is really beautiful. Food is delicious, shops are full of colours. People seem to be nice. I would like to come back some day over there.
Busy busy busy. Walking around the area we found it to be a little dirty with lots of rubbish lying around in places. The sites we visited however were well looked after and very interesting.
Fantastic!. Istanbul was beautiful, busy, exciting and interesting! Old history comes to life specially in the Topkapi palace and harem. Public transport works well.
also nice place. another nice area in Turkey , i have visited this place during night and it gives you a very nice feeling with the old style everywhere
Topkapa palace. i have visited a lot of placed , but i like the palace too much, and i was able to take photos as well and it is allowed

Fascinating, beautiful, so much to see. so many historical sights; amazing architecture and interesting areas. city is packed but vibrant and we always felt safe. found people generally friendly and considerate.
Around Istanbul. I liked everithing in Turkey.I spend 15 days aroun Turkey with Intrepid trip and it was one of the best .

Very Historical. Great History
There is lot to see around and very much a historic city. Good place for kids to explore the history of ottomon dynasty
Historic sites. All tourist sites very busy, especially when cruise ships are in. But queues are managed efficiently.
Blue Mosque, Grand Bazar, Spice Market. I loved everything about it. The main stri offered tons of shopping, sight seeing, restaurants and friendly people.

Excellent city to visit - stay at least a few days. I found this city friendly. Although somewhat choked with traffic it works. The tram and metro are efficient. Most important are the helpful, friendly people. Everyone seems to have a smile. Sometimes their expectation is to help you buy something from them. Everyone seems to have an uncle or brother or best friend who has exactly what you did not know you needed. It is possible to say no though and to thoroughly enjoy the sites, people and excellent food.

A must see. Istanbul offers a variety of things you can visit. Public transportation is perfect: the "tram" is cheap and will get you verywhere in the centre in no time. Visit the cistern, the Blue Mosque, and all the other highlight in Istanbul. You won't regret it.
Going back in time. Extremely rich historically and very well maintained. The walking tour to Sultanahmet area should cover the major sites in a sigle day

A long walk back into the history of civilization. This is one of the most impressive sites in the world. It goes all the way back to 5000 BC links to Egypt up through the Ottoman Empire and the creation of the Republic that is modern day Turkey.
Incredible!. Historical things here are incredible! It's the basis of your world and your Christian history. Places are not only interesting, but also easy to get to...mostly by walking.

A must visit. This area of Istanbul is an excellent base to visit the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace. The Grand Bazaar is also a short walk away. Lots of cafe,shops and restaurants in the area. You have not seen Istanbul if you do not visit this place. Highly recommended
Just soak it all up. A wonderful place to just walk around. Enjoy the history, atmosphere, sights and smells. Find a place to take some great photos.

Sites of old town Istanbul. People are friendly the food is great for lunch and tea the blue mosque and grand bazaar and shopping a good experience easy to get around on foot or by public transport or go on a ferry all good

Vacationing in Istanbul. The beautiful city by the Bosphorus is magnificent with its many historical sites to delight the eyes and enrich your knowledge of history and geography. Shopping is fantastic. The food excellent and the Turkish people are the best asset of Istanbul as they go out of their way to help.

just amazing. i almost visited every place in Istanbul, my wife was almost crying from spending a long time watching everything, IStanbul is a very rich place full of places to go, Sultan AHmet is one of the best "in the world" people it is very nice organized, renting this radio is amazing experience as it is an amazing guide that will give you all what you need,and it cost 25 dollars

Nice to walk around and check out street vendors. We stayed in the old town area, which was nice to walk around to see the sights. But the first evening we ended up in a touristic part for dinner, which was okay but not spectacular. It was interesting to see all the street vendors. Got a hot Salep the first night because it looked so yummy, but it was just a scalding hot glop of white, gummy stuff with a sprinkling of cinnamon powder that did not dissolve. Oh well, you live and learn. Finally tried a boiled corn on the cob the last night after eying them for 6 nights, but it wasn't anything spectacular.

Short break to see this historic city.. We only visited for 3 days as part of our longer Turkey holiday. In a nutshell we feel that Istanbul quite simply is a must visit city, it's a fascinating, vibrant, stunning, historic city in which we felt safe and also in which local people were always willing to help. Hopefully we will visit again as a priority on more occasions.
Great Mousques. Istanbul is full of Historic Mousques representing the islamic old culture. Also a lot of resonable prize resturant which you can eat a lot of Kepap

be careful there!. You must be really attentive and careful there. there are a lot of people all over and tourists with their huge cameras and wallets could become an easy victim. Always watch your back and keep your bag close to you. It is a great experience to walk all over the Istanbul but is some places you feel yourself not really safe. Take care!

Great city, great people, wonderful sights. What an enjoyable time we had! My wife was totally enchanted by Istanbul, for its great sights and sites, excellent food, and wonderful citizens. We found Turkey to be incredibly clean, and very safe despite the turmoil in Syria.
A wonderful area. A magical area full of history, but alas also full of people. If you can get up early and visit the sites it is a much better experience
incredibble. ı thing old town its hearth of city we bean grand bazaar sipce bazaar blue mosgue hagia sophia hippodrome fire tower and cagaloglu turkısh bath was georgeos

A storied and magical city. istanbul is at the cross roads of East and West and the historical buildings and sites show it. It's a great place to brush up on history and see first hand the sites that played such substantial roles in Western history.
Just wander. The whole area of Sultanamehd is just a joy to walk in. The street life is vibrant and the history just seeps into your bones.
Blue Mosque, Topkapi palace, Aya Sophia, Cistern. Great locations near to each other and very interesting. Guide books provided were informative. Some prices were a little high
Very exciting city! So many people...taxi drivers are crazy!. Very exciting city...so many things to see and do. There are so many people... difficult to walk around. Metro was great.

Istanbul - must come back. In the time available we saw and did things in Istanbul's top ten i.e. the Topkapi Palace, Haggia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, a boat trip on the Bosphorus, the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Market. The fact that Haggia Sophia was built almost 1500 years ago is mind-boggling. The architecture of the interior is stunning - it was easy to imagine the building as it looked at the time of the Roman Empire. No dislikes, only likes. We will come back.

Well Worth Visiting. Plan to spend at least three days exploring the historic parts of the city. The historic sites, the bazaars, the cafes, and the markets are an inncredible mix and contrast of cultures.
Everything walkable. Good areas to walk around and relax on park benches? Keep a scarf with you for mosque visits and wear comfortable shoes
So central. Everything is so central and all major sites are within a 20 minute walk away from the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia and of course Topkapi Palace.
Sultanahmet. is full of charm and atmosphere. After a day exploring the far reaches of Istanbul it's great to know you only have to stroll back to the centre full of restaurants, cafes, and shops.
Old Town great for travellers. There is much to see and do here from cultural interests to eating and drinking. A tramway links you up and down the city through to the Bosphorous. Very good location.

“Go everywhere. Get lost in the streets.”. Walking around the old town was amazing. So much to discover, lots of history, nice small shops, the back roads are great. Make sure you have a good pair of walking shoes on.

Old Town = Historic Istanbul = Sultanahmet district. These TA categories all refer to the same thing, the core of what makes Istanbul such a rich tourist destination. Here is where you will find the top-10 sights; the top-10 restaurants; the top-10 bazaars, etc, and the quintessential sights, sounds and smells of Istanbul.If you are thinking of staying in the New Town north of the Golden Horn, then please reconsider, unless you are more interested in boutiques, designer fashion and chic accessories.

Istanbul - a top-10 city!!. Very pleasantly surprised. This ranks with London, Paris, Rome and Barcelona any day; perhaps better for those who place a high value on variety and new types of experiences. If your travel has been confined to 'western' destinations and/or you are disturbed by different cultures and ambiance, then you might not rank Istanbul so high = obvious Islam; scruffy; chaotic; crowds; language; Rome-style dirty. I found these to be part of the charm and the experience.I was fascination by the inner tension between traditional Islam and the push to modernise in a Western sense. Why do some woman use a scarf head cover, others not, and some wear burkas? In my view dining is overrated in quality but is still excellent value. Haggling and the estimate of value is a challenge - ask around; seek advice from other travellers; learn the REAL tricks of bargaining.

Everything is of interest. An amazing city with a fantastic history. No need to take tours except by boat. Walking through the streets, looking at mosques, palace, and museums. Lots of places to sit and have a cup of coffee or a drink. Rick Steven's guidebook is indispensible.

THE BEST TRAVEL EXPERIENCE IN TURKEY THANKS TO ARGEUS TOURS. Just came back from a week in Turkey, organized by Edip from Argeus Tours.They did an extraordinary job, from email communications, to selection of hotels and tour guides in Istanbul. Ephesus and Capadoccia.I can't imagine a more perfect way to visit this gloriously beautiful country
Beautiful, breathtaking!!!. Loved the Cisterns, Bosphorus cruise, Blue Mosque, Dolmabahçe, Hagya Sophia, Topkapi, the atmosphere in general.

Istanbul. Great city with well maintained historic places like Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, and tram net work. The people are friendly and polite. Most of them start the conversation with "o my friend!"Cappadocia is another wonderful place to visit. The underground cities ballon rides are very good. The volcanic eruptions are really a feast to the eyes.

Istanbul is incomplete without this. Be it the sultanahmet district or the galata tower, be it the grand bazaar or the Egyptian/spice bazaar, the blue mosque or the sulemaniye mosque, the historic areas of Istanbul are what makes it so different from other large cities and worthy of a visit.

One of the best place I have been to.... Historical Peninsula... What a great and historical place... Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet Camii (Blue Mosque), Suleymaniye Mosque, Kapalicarsi (Old Bazaar), Yerebatan Sarnici... Too many places to visit and see the Great Ottoman Empire's architectures... And most importantly, Topkapi Palace... One can not be regretful to be in the Historical Peninsula of İstanbul...

A little redundant, since all of Istanbul is historic. But what the hey? Istanbul itself is layer upon layer of history, and it shows but without being dusty. Anywhere you go, you'll either see historic buildings, walls, ruins, houses, mosques, cisterns- you name it. So to say "The Historic Sites of Istanbul" is really just saying "Istanbul", but if you are looking specifically for a destination rich and vibrant and alive with its history, then Istanbul is the place to be. Take your time with it, and there's nothing to be intimidated by- its full of beautiful culture, friendly people, great food, and yes, many ways of traveling back in time.

What an amazing city. the history for Istanbul is just mindboggling. It is such a cool city to take in, you can't do it all in one trip. Pick and choose a few and then wander the streets, eat a kebab from a street vendor and enjoy the atmosphere, I will definitely come back. Loved it!

love istanbul. just walking around is exotic....have tea, talk to vendors, have fun with it....people watch...see all of the sites, take bosphorous cruise,
eat in grand bizarre, food there was great....

Everything is within easy walking distance. We had only a couple of days, so visited the most well known attractions - the Topkapi Palce, Aya Sofia, The Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, Mausoleum. They are all within a couple of minutes' (literally!) walk from each other, which is good on the feet, but the queues can be horrendous. Best to get there early.

Amazing and beautiful structures. The historic areas of Istanbul are easily accessible and are great for exploration on foot. When or if you get tired, the tram and funicular are safe and easy to use. I loved the massive scale, but very intricate design and architecture of the histirical areas of Istanbul, like Topkapi Palace, the Blue Mosque and the Hagia Sophia, among other sites. The Topkapi museum was also topnotch and worthy of a good 4-5 hrs.

Fascinating to walk around. It is such an iconic skyline and so wonderful to walk around. We had 4 days in Istanbul which was long enough to see the main sites, but not long enough to enjoy the atmosphere and relax in one of the many great restaurants. We tried to do everything, but didn't manage of course.
Must stay. Why would you stay any where else. This is where it happens. Lots of little streets, restaurants, bars. It is safe and friendly. STAY HERE.

Beautiful Mosques!. We were so impressed by Hagia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, The Hippodrome and the Little Hagia Sofia We also visited Topkapi Palace, the spice market and the Grand Bazaar. We wished we had more time to see other places.
who are fond of history. It was very good visit to topcapy and see how sultans are living and ruling people in the middle east
Fantastic.. Walking around the old town was amazing. So much to discover, lots of history, nice small shops, the back roads are great. Make sure you have a good pair of walking shoes on.
Go everywhere. Get lost in the streets.. Great part of town to wander around, shop and have a bite to eat. We stayed there and would definitely go back. Loved it.

Wonderful City. Istanbul has shot to near the top of our list of favourite places along with New York and Florence. For liveliness, cleanliness and all-round atmosphere it's hard to beat. We felt safe at all times of day and night.
Fantastic. I am captivated by the history. here you can see the Byzantin history (and end) and Turkish history.
History abounds.... Istanbul, from the people to the architecture and it's influence on history is all around you. It's a most colorful place to visit and should not be missed.

Very busy. I get the feeling that the people of Turkey visit historic Istanbul almost more than foreign tourists as it is very busy, with queues at most sights. That said, the atmosphere is great, and safe. A truly international city at the crossroads between Europe and Asia.

one of the best places in the world. loved it all, cant hate anything about it. i loved how the Turkish goverment is taking care of these wonderful places and making it easy for us tourists to enjoy our stay.

Stay in Old Town Istanbul. We stayed at the Sirkeci Konak located just about three blocks from the Topkapi Palace, an easy and safe walk to the Sutanahmnet Square, and were able to reach many sights on foot. Tip: be sure to wear sturdy, durable walking shoes to navigate along the cobblestone streets.

nice to visit. We took a tour from our cruise, which showed us the old town. We stop for a quick shopping in the town. People are friendly and mostly speaks english. Great architecture to see and shops to visit.
very yraditional. lovely area to explore . the old buildings give way to an array of shops and cafes, well worth the visit
Walking back in time. I found it very safe and experiencing such a variety of history is awe inspiring. There is so much to see and do, so much for then entire family to enjoy.
A must see. Lots of history. Well worth visiting this part of the city. So many places of interest to see. A vibrant part of the city full of life.

Awesome. Something that should be on everyone' bucket list. Get there early, though, on peak days. Aya Sophia is jaw-dropping, the Hippodrome is wonderful, the Blue Mosque awe-inspiring, and the Topkapi Palace is a day out in itself.
good experience. The location is very open where you can see and meet so many different cultures and there are lots of restaurants, hotels and of course museums
Hstoric and Atmospheric Architecture. Quite an array of architecture and smells. wonderful. Easy to access and something interesting everywhere to photograph

A sight to behold. One word of caution if you're planning to stay in Sultanahmet: the singing/chanting from the minarets can be very loud and very annoying when it wakes you up from sound sleep at midnight and then again at 4 a.m.

great to visit in ONE day. I rented a private car and I went around the old city and istanbul , but using the tram is perfect . or you can walk . the city is very safe and people are very kind and helpfulI had great time. the old city is good.Architecture is awesome. so lovely. you can see parts of the old city during your cruise tour.visiting the old town might not be a very good idea during the rush hour.

Limited mobility but great time. I can only walk and stand for a limited time - enough but can't do it all. We visited Hagia Sophia and it was worth the visit if you want to see the real vs pictures. If I had to choose i would go to the Blue Mosque. It for me was an awe inspiring experience. I am not Muslim but found myself humbled and in awe of the beauty and sense of the sacred in this place.

So different that anything we have seen before.. The historic areas of Istanbul were part of our tour with Sahil from My Local Tour Guide Istanbul. He explained the history of the area and kept the carpet sellers away from us while we were touring. If the locals see you are with your own private tour guide you don't get hassled to buy carpets and everything else. it is a great way to see the city of Istanbul.

Use the Tram to Get Around. You can get to every place you want in the Old City by using the convenient Tram system. It runs on tracks that for the most part are separated from all car traffic; so it runs as well during rush hour as other times. There is only one line; so you can't get confused. If you are on a cruise and don't want to go on a formal tour, the Tram is the way to go. It runs on the main street right in front of the Cruise Terminals and takes you near all the major attractions in Old Town You can buy your tickets at the stop, and they cost only about a dollar each. Most maps will have the tram route on it. Rick Steves' Istanbul info has details that are helpful.

Glory of the Past. Amazing experience! Very well maintained and organized. Try booking a private tour guide for half a day or full day; they're very helpful and professional and have the ability to cut the long lines to purchase tickets.

loved this city. so much to see and all of it fascinating. most of the well known sites are relatively close to each other. The art and culture of this civilisation is quite stunning and is a must to be seen.

Our favourite European city. The historic city of Constantinople is fairly compact and you can walk everywhere (assuming hat, sunscreen, sensible shoes etc.). Once you get used to the street traders - who are overenthusiastic rather than aggressive - the seething tumult of humanity becomes comforting rather than overwhelming. The whole place has a relaxed, friendly atmosphere and it is easy to imagine that the essentials of life here - art, trade, good food and family - have not changed that much in 3,000 years. Buy a 3-day museum pass (72 lira) and do everything on it!

Grand bazaar. Shop till you drop. Never seen so many wonderful shops in one place and really not a lot of tat. Would take a whole day to get round the whole bazaar and really easy to get lost. Wonderful lighting, ceramics, leather goods, diamonds and carpets. Take a lot of money!

Magical. Istanbul is a place to walk. Get lost around the city, that is the best way of getting to know the old town. The city is very safe and the people are very helpful although every one will try to sell you something.
it was a good exprience. you know , istanbul is a important part of world history and visiting historic place in istanbul can give you a better view to the world history.

Now that is what I call bedlinen .... Loved it: the bazaars, the shopping streets (eyeing the magnificently frilly bedclothes, buying jasmine tea), the pavement cafes, everything and everyone madly busy. A must.
Very beaituful places. Pros:Place is beautifulEasy to travelSecurity is goodTransport availableCons: Very many people , tourists.Services, foods, tickets are expensive

So much to see and do. Wandering around the old town on our first evening in istanbul was an amazing experience.. just having a drink here and supper there.. we ended up eating at Doy Doy on the roof top terrace with fantastic views of the blue mosque
Stunning City. Want to go back! Istanbul is a lively and buzzing city, with so much to see and do. The old town, the grand bazaar, the area around Galata tower....not to be missed!

very rich culture. so many things to see and do.. full of life and culture, a few things to buy and gifts... sellers can be a bit agressive so we just walk past if we dont want to buy anything... all in all very nice place to go, wear comfy shoes!!

Magical Times !. We honeymooners, went to Istanbul for the first time, and the place was delightful. We have truly enjoyed every single bit of Istanbul. We stayed in Sultanahmet at Yashmak Sultan Hotel which was magnificent by the way... Trust me when i say, that Sultanahmet is wonderfully charming at night especially when there is light rain !! just go walk under the rain ! I would visit Turkey in winter when i plan for it the next time.
Must sees!. The historic area of Istanbul is fascinating and very easy to get around - loads of people to ask for directions (and then carpet shops to visit!!). Beautiful buildings - so much history.
Fascinating but busy. Amazing place absolutely heaving, but worth it. It is such a merging of cultures and a first glimpse of the middle east.
Center of an Empire. Like Rome, Istanbul has 1000's of years of history with huge monumental structures that seem to defy the assumptions of what was possible to build 1500 years ago.
what an atmosphere. A mix of shops, great and not so great, an amazing mix of tourists and people who live and work there. This is not just a a visitor's attraction.

Authentic Istanbul. I have already reviewed this under other titles. It is nice to watch Turks go about their business, and shop at their markets, rather than head to the more western shops. That is what we are in Turkey for...to immerse ourselves in the culture.

The Real Istanbul. We walked around the Fatih area every day, mingling with the Turks shopping in the markets, eating doners etc. Nice to immerse yourself in the culture rather than looking for the closest McDonalds or Burger King.

Ideal location to visit most of Istanbul's attractions. Apart for all the historical attractions in the area which cannot be missed, the traveller may also wish to visit the Spice Market and The Grand Bazaar. The sheer amount of shops in this Bazaar/market makes one wonder how on earth can all the shops survive (it is estimated that the Boazzar offer 4,000 outlets of various forms and size). An important word of warning is to beware of taxi drivers. Although the majority are honest, some have the habit of over-charging and although they will infomr you that their charges are metered, the truth is that they will take you for a ride.

Do not miss this experience.. Stay over here.... You will figure out how to handle the traffic Even if you have to go over to the "new" city side for business. Colleagues in different hotels here but all preferred the old city.
