Worth visiting all the attractions. Istanbul was named the European Capital of Culture in 2010 and the attractions certainly live up to he reputation. The Golden Horn, a boat trip on the Bosphorous, a visit to the Princes islands, the Basilica cisterns to mention a few are a must for the dicerning traveller.

An Intriguing, Cosmopolitan, Relatively Compact Treasure Trove. Istanbul is a treasure trove of intriguing historical sites that are easily accessible! Most are located in the Sultanahmet district. Top attractions are Topkopi Palace (1/2 Day Minimum); St Sophia and the Blue Mosque (1/2 Day together with nearby Lesser attractions); and the Grand Bazaar and/or Egyptian Market for colorful atmosphere, photos, and tourist souvenirs (A few hours to 1/2 Day). The Turkish people are friendly and very cosmopolitan. Allow time for upscale shopping and fine dining. If the weather is nice, enjoy a Bosphorus Cruise. A Great City!

Old Town is the place to be for the tourist. If you stay in Old Town, you are within walking distance of many (if not all) of the places you'll want to see including the Blue Mosque, the Hippodrome, the Cisterns, the Aya Sofia, the Topkapi and Archeological Museum, the Sutanamet the Magnificent Mosque, the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar.New Town has some great shopping but more resembles a big city. Plan on eating dinner in New Town, go a few hours earlier and stroll around before and after dinner. Then, take a taxi back to Old Town.

Visit new, old, west and east. For me Istanbul represents new, old, west and east. You will visit the old town with the Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque etc. But extend your search for different cultures to other neighborhoods as well. Fener and Balat along the Golden Horn, or Moda, Kadikoy, Uskudar (Guzkuncuk and Beylerbeyi and further) at the Asian side. Take the ferry or tram to all those other historical sites, to beautiful not so famous mosques and churches. Enjoy the many, many restaurants and small streets of Beyoglu. Go shopping in Bebek, Nicantaci or Kadikoy. You will be surprised every day.
Must see. Make sure bring a note all the points to see and write down the names in both English and Turkish. Ex: Local does not know Spice Market.
Must go. If you go to Asia side, be prepared with extreme congestion. Best to take advantage of public transportation such as tram and metro eventhough tram is always full of passengers.

Lovely and quaint. I stayed there and liked to be able to walk to mosThe tram service is very efficient and affordable. Take the Blue tram line to the end of the line to Kabatas and get on a sea bus to the Prince Islands for the cost of a token 3tl. You can get off at any of the Islands and take the next boat back.

Everything you would expect. Conjour up any image of what you would expect from a medieval city and this part of town delivers. Sights, sounds and smells that bring senses to life. You can't get lost and if you do, it will be worth it as you discover a new and fascinating stall or shop selling all and sundry.
can Greece beat this?. Steeped in history. Architecture from Ottoman times and older. Ruins and well preserved. Fantastic. Get a bigger memory card.
Very nice. Loved walking thru the historic areas, learnt quite a lot by listening to the history and enjoyed seeing the old monuments. Very good blend of different cultures.
Busy,crowded and exotic.. The Spice market was very interesting and many of the vendors were real characters too. Worth the crush!

Palpable Historic Atmosphere. My hotel was in this area and it's holds all the popular tourist and historic locations. Wear comfortable shoes, catch the tram/light rail to the end and walk back, stopping at your chosen destinations along the way. Watch out for, and avoid, all the touts who approach you on the street, and try to sell you something. Research your restaurants beforehand. It's still a 21st century tourist destination with all the modern pitfalls of a tourist trap. But a place everyone should visit if you can avoid the usual problems.

Steeped in History. I stayed in "old Istanbul" with and narrow, atmospheric, cobblestone streets. Saw blue mosque and Sofia among others. Check opening days/times of museums etc. If you have more than a few days, it's worthwhile to purchase the pass which saves you a lot of money if you're going to all the popular museums etc. Wear comfortable shoes, there's still a lot of walking. It's still a very commercial, tourist area and take care to avoid all the touts who will approach you in the street and try to sell you their services as a guide or to take you to some wonderful place to shop.
We loved it,. its nice to se that the city exists on two continents and at a point you can have a foot in each, we found this fact great fun, very interesting city
clean , clean , clean. this much i can say about the city itself, and the people a friendly, considerings its a vibrant bustling city

Very Beautiful place. We are an American couple, we love to travel all the time we have been to many places around the world, that is why we appreciate this very beautiful historical place, we love the atmosphere too

History surrounds you. Evrwhere you turn in Istanbul history abounds. Whether the historic cisterns, or the mosques or the bazaar or the spice market. There is much to see and do. You can leave without touching important world history.

So Much History. Being able to see what I've read about was amazing. Spectacular views of ancient architecture. The historic areas are easy to walk to and when we went were not very crowded. We were in port for two days. We wished we had more time, but this means we will be back again for another visit.
siteseeing. liked the all the sites because some of them were walking distance form each other and the enterence fee were cheap
Historical Istanbul. Ottoman and Roman relics were full of religious and political history. Some of these however need some restorstion
Go early. For the best pictures without the crowds, wake up early and take a stroll. The city is quiet in the morning and it's much easier to walk around
Full of history.. Walking around the old town was amazing. So much to discover on these street you'll be amazed. Put your walking shoes on and go for it.
great to wonder in. full of life. great for peaople watching. take pleanty of water with you. You really get the vibe of East meets West here.

Perfect for tourists!. The historical areas of Istanbul are that kind of place that everyone must go one day. I loved. Want to come back soon as possible. Such a variety of heritage arquitecture landmarks. Amazing!

despite being summer the historical places are well organized. I visited all the historical sites in one day and it is needed much more to get to know well Istanbul. You need at least 1 week to fully enjoy the places
Nice walk. Once seen the most recognizable walk around and do not miss the streets with fish grills and local flavours.

exotic yet familiar. The whole area of the old town is great. Ancient walls jostle with commercial areas, carpet stores try to tempt you in with streetside displays, sweet shops try to outdo each others window displays. and all of the main attractions and brilliant.

FANTASTİC. Perfect experience. Twicw a year we all have city tours here in İstanbul. Every corner in every strret of this city is a surprise between now and history. Not nly the walls, bridges or mosques, churhes but people living here are surprise themselves for the ones who want to experience.

Mix of East and West as well as Ancient and Modern. A walk down the Bosphorous stopping over at the Gelato bridge for a salted Fish Sandwich. The Dolmache is a must as well as the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace

you can never see enough. it is a city that has abit of everything, history, culture, nature. it is so rich and so beautiful, as Napolion said if the world was one great state İstanbul would be the capital of it.
Wonderful Istanbul. A must visit city. Amazing history and wonderful people! I have written individual reviews of different hotels, locations and services.

east meets west. with major sites for christianity and islam the old town is a walkable lesson in ancient history, peppered with people from east and west in all forms of dress-shorts,buiness suits, hijab, burka-with many excellent restaurants as well

Visit as much as you can!. Everything!! Go over to the Asian side by Taxi to the main square then stroll down Shopping Street. Look out for thr Flower passage hidden away on your right then walk on into the music area down cobbled streets.
mixture of culture. Hard to explain my feelings about istanbul. you will see at least 3 cultures in istanbul. hagia sophia museum, blue mosque hippodrome.

Sultanahmet Mosque. Nothing disliked... it was good to visit this historical place. We offered our Juma prayers in this historical and old mosque. There was a large crowd of visitors and locals to perform Juma prayers on 31/8/2012.

An amazing city. This is truly the crossroads of ancient and modern civilizations. My husband and I have found a friendly, cosmopolitan and organized city. We'll be lucky, but we don't found defects to report.

Must Visit. Part of being in Istanbul, beautiful areas with lovely views, restaurants and delicious food. Night time is relaxing with local music and cool weather, dancing fountains with colors by Ayasofia park. Sometimes is very crowded and can be annoying.

Nice and peacful walk. its charming to walk around there, it's clean and relaxing unlike what you might think of an old town .. very historical, so many small monuments in between the big landmarks, ironically even the graveyards there are charming to look at ...

Glorious Glorious Glorious. Glorious Landmarks .. beautiful Journey -- magical times..
Top Kapi, Haja Sofia, blue mosque, Soluaminia mosque are a must see landmarks .. and walking between them is so much fun .. it will be nice to finish the say with A traditional Hammam like Sulaimania Hammam

Stayinh & Eating in Old Town. The best part of the old town is the large number of boutiques hotels and wonderful eating options. Cobbled streets open air eating establishments. The area comes alive in the evenings. Anybody visiting Istanbul should stay in this area rather than downtown. Within walking distance of the key sites of the Blus Mosque and the hagia Sophia and even the Grand Bazaar
One of the best old towns in the world. After visiting more than 35 countries I would say that Istanbul old town is one of the best. It is good to visit when tourists are out.

One of the best in the world. Istanbul historical places are super attractions. I have visited this city 5 times and wish to come more. Very nice to come in October-November and March-April where it is not too hot
Beautiful. Wonderful and great to see them so well looked after. I had heard that Istanbul was a little 'neglected' so it was a pleasant surprise to see it so clean and tidy and splendid.

Even the teenagers were facinated. The history is so facinating and the builings still in a reasonable good skape, so even our teenager found it interesting to walk through the area. Guide is reccomended.

Full of history, so much packed inn.. Very lovely area, there are lots of alley ways, so much history packed in to one area. There are restaurants, small parks to take a nice walk, places to sit around and have a nice cup of Turkish tea.

magical even though crowded. Just wandering around is a great experience, especially off the main streets....store keepers/market sellers are tough, but you get your no thanks mojo going after a few days

A wealth of things to see and do. During Ramadan the Hippodrome filled with families waiting to break their fast; picnic tables and cloths on the ground loaded with food, carry-out food being brought in, people cooking, restaurants set up for the special meal, and a festive atmosphere.

Truly wonderful. The historical areas of Istanbul offer visitors a glimpse of the old and modern combined with a seething mass of humanity that rewards visitors to this truly great city. A literally breathtaking experience.
Great. I like it very much to walk among so many architectural beautys , so many places for entertainment,,so many shops to visit and to shop,at great prices...

Historic Istanbul. A city not to be missed in your travels. Plenty for all to do. Great infrastucture, and using public transport is easy and cheap. Buy a local transport card to reduce the cost per journey even more.

Nice place to experience colour and noise.. A great place to stroll around to see the sights and colours of the activities going on. A nice people watching place to see what Turkey has to offer. Should not be missed. Though bargain for the stuff you want to get.
History. There is much history in there. You can easily imagine the old times. Narrow streets, nice buildings (even if very old).

amazing!. I cannot believe that a city has such beaitufl area with ts mosques, churchs and palaces tat are on the top of impressive hills with perfect wievs... I wanted to live n istanbul when it was ottoman empire...
Got to be done. Istanbul has a lot to offer, see it all if you can. We were there for just 36 hours as part of a cruise so couldn't really get to everything.

Real place. That is the place which you want to see when you come to Istanbul, right? So, do not complain that there are many others shoulder to shoulder with you! Yes, it is crowded but not always, it was not in April at all, for example. So, choose the time which is better for you. Loved its cobbled streets, smells, people, small squares, restaurants, cute hotels. You do not feel 21st century here and its great! Otherwise, you can always cross & go to another side!

Impressive!. Very nice places! We really want to go back! Nice city, very clean! Friendly people. All willing to help or give good advice! We had 4 wonderful days. We walked all around! really loved it! Super experience! Beautiful city!

So much to see. So much to see and in a relatively small area. You can walk easily from one site to another here. Be sure to see the famous mosques and markets where so much history has taken place over thousands of years.

So much history!. Narrow streets and very old buildings. Spend some time walking these ancient neighborhoods and think about all the history which has gone here before you. Imagine the conquerors and the conquered--Moslem, Christian and Jew.

Memories are made of this.... The old town really brings back vibes of how this magnificent city used to be. The charm and feel of the old city is mesmerising. Having been there during Ramadan was special as we witnessed the warmth and friendliness of the local people. Give yourself the chance to immerse into the way of life here. The streets may seem confusing at first but so what? We did get lost but meandering in the narrow streets and thoroughfares we met so many nice people who always greeted us with a smile. At no time did we feel threatened or in danger or awkward. This is very rare these days! Every visit to Istanbul must include some time here.

Just Wander. I could spend days wandering the streets of Old Town and never tire of it or see everything. The people are wonderful and the food and tea carts can keep you fueled for hours and hours. Leave your map in your pocket. Wander. Explore. Enjoy. When you get tired, flag a taxi and head back to your hotel OR duck into a great restaurant and eat, drink and be Turkish.

Where old and new meet. We were there during Ramadan and got to witness the breaking of the fast each evening by the thousands at the Hippodrome. There are a lot more traditionally garbed women and men in this part of the city than others.

old is correct. to see buildings in excess of 2000 years old ,still standing ,and still being used just put us over the top. the narrow cobble stone streets and all the vendors was truly a extreme pleasure
Great experience. The little winding streets lined with shops selling everything you could imagine and some you can't, gives a real feeling for how the city was in the past.

worth seeing. Mosques are free to enter and stunning
Grand Bazaar and spice market crowded and pushy vendors-don't understand concept of window shopping

Grand Bazzar. So much better than I thought it would be. Nicely paved indoor market with such a variety of goods. Haggling again not as bad as i thought,picked up a beautifull piece of amber and as the Turks say if you are happy with the price you are happy with your purchase.

Spent days touring through the Old City. We visited many different mosques: my favorites were Suleymaniye and the Blue Mosque. Also visited Topkapi, Hagia Sophia, grand bazaar, spice market, Galata bridge, Galata tower. All within walking distance, if you don't mind a few hills.
Busy area. It was too busy but nice ... I liked fruit and clothes over there ... I think price and quality of clothes are higher than Europe

Grand Bazaar!!. Everything a woman would love.. the jewelery, clothes, carpets etc.
Warning: you just might get "lost" in this amazing shopping complex of about 60 streets!

My Favorite City. Istanbul is the most wonderful city I have visited. It has a special charm that draws me back again and again. The architecture, the history, the food, the people and the ancient charm of the Sultanahamet area all make for a city that is worth a visit by everyone who loves to travel.

Grand Bazaar and Spice Bazaar. These are simply neat places to visit. Yes, you will be constantly approached by shop keepers, especially carpet salesmen (true almost anywhere in Istanbul), but the sights and concentration of people will certainly stimulate your senses. Don't miss the Spice Bazaar...it is smaller and less overwhelming than the Grant Bazaar, but the colors and smells are will delight.
So much history. So much to see and all within walking distance. Vies with the great cities of Europe. What a spectacular place.
Old Town. We liked the closeness to the main area, the restaurants, and shops. Just around the corner from the hotel was a restaurant with great food ( try the Turkish Pizza) and a view of the sea.

Nice!. Many things to see, smell, and experience. If you're into history, it's worth to remember what's going on in where in this area. Very interesting to make connections between history and the current conditions.
Tiles, tiles, tiles. The old city has everything an old city should have. Wonderful bazaars, beautiful museums, great architecture

Stunning. Istanbul is a stunning city brimming with rich history. The historic places are right in the city with real life going on all around so it doesn't feel like a theme park. Don't miss Ayasofia, Topkapi Palace, Archaeology musems and Blue Mosque.
A vast city. Istanbul is a vast city with so much to see and do. The sites are walking distance or a short tram or bus ride but worth it.

Magnificent!. I strongly agree with the previous comment, that after Rome, Istanbul is the next amazing place!!! It has so much culture, the people are polite, the atmosphere is somehow different than any other place I have ever been. Their food, their habits... everything is really really impressive!

Memorable - Get lost... Forget the map, just decide on a time limit and get lost and experience the narrow street and sights. Its worth this trip down memory lane ven though its fast dissapearing with modern structures.
Absolutely a must for any traveller. ust walk around and absorble the history, culture, sounds and smells, you willdefinitly enjoy it. Go with no expectations, its safe and worth a visit.

walk,walk, walk!!!. Walking around old town Istanbul is amazing. Put on your walking shoes and go to the obvious places AND go to less traveled streets to discover more restaurants and more turkish culture.

Fantastic!. To date, my second favourite city after Roma. There's simply so much history and culture, with a climate to match...at least in the summer! The old town (Sultanahmet) is magnificent, but there are so many other places to see too. The Galata district (across the Golden Horn) is perfect for the evening, and, whilst not at all clean and developed like the tourist areas, the area North-West of Sultanahmet gives a real taste of the how the other side lives.

Istanbul. Istanbul - relaxing over coffee and ice-cream at Konyalı Restaurant @ The Topkapi Palace and admiring the magnificent Bosphorus; gazing rapturously at the langorous and majestic Hagia Sophia, and through the gardens across water fountains from Hagia Sophia to the Blue Mosque; the Topkapi Palace with the beautiful pavillions with blue and white tiles and colored faience ceilings; a Grand Bazaar; Turkish sea-food dinner on Galata Bridge; sojourning by ferry up the Bosphorus to Sariyer, and Kilyos - Galata Tower, the Palaces, Mosques, towering bridges connecting Europe and Asia, Yalis, and townhouses and massive development creeping up and over the green wooded hills, red Turkish flags dotting the banks fluttering in the breezes..
Fascinating atmosphere. interesting sights and sounds, superb old buildings, could have happily stayed longer. Plan your route and it's surprising how much you can see in a short time

City of Cities. Istanbul is the city of cities. You don't just see history here, it permeates into you heart. If you love the cobblestoned streets of Europe and the souks of the Maghreb; then Istanbul is the city for you.

Magic atmosphere. Loved the cheap street food. 4TL for ready to eat watermelon.
1.5TL for BBQ sweetcorn. from 2TL for a kebab.
Disliked the many street vendors trying to sell knock-off perfumes and handbags.

Great from historical point of view. Old Town is, of course, a "must see" area of Istanbul. From historical point of view, it is very interesting, however, I personally didn't enjoy my trip there as, apparently, being Ukrainian makes you a target for millions of Turkish sales people. Turns out, it's that easy to spoil one's mood.

So much to see in one area!. A must see this area takes at least two days to explore. There is so much history and activity to see. A night time stroll is also suggested. A visit during Ramadan is the best time to go as this area

Wow, so much packed into such a small area. You can easily spend several days wandering this area of Istanbul. There is so much to see and do. The history and the sites are outstanding. If you can plan ahead go during Ramad(z)an the festivities are great.

Walking old town area. It is a lovely area. There are lots of little alley ways and I love exploring areas where I have not been before. You can't really get lost as the river is always on one side. There are mosques and little parks and of course you can stop for a cup of Turkish tea where ever you wander.
Blue Mosque. The ceiling is just like a Turkish silk carpet - really stunning. We were there during ramadan and it was interesting to watch families picnic and pray around the Mosque

Very nice and authentic - loved the small streets. Very nice and authentic - loved the small streets. The area is stroller friendly even though there are cobblestones. The weather in July can be hot and humid.
Safe and friendly. We were only in Istanbul itself for a short time so we chose to walk around and while the traffic is that of any big city the views are great and the people were welcoming.

One of the beautiful place. Istanbul is famous for its both old city and new city. Old city is a charm to istanbul. You have lots of things to do in Istanbul. First and foremost have to see Hagia Sophia, blue mosque. Another place near to these places is Basilica Cistern (roman aquaducts) under­ground tank. The cistern is fea­tured in the James Bond movie “From Russia with Love”, so it is nice to visit. There is a palace next to hagia sophia which is good too. You can also take a tram and go down to visit Egyptian (Spice) Bazaar (Mısır Çarşısı) which is worth seeing. Galata Tower is a nice place to visit but this is little far from sultanahmet. Eating near these places are expensive, it is advisable to eat outside tourist area. Also for transportation use tram, metro, bus which is inexpensive and fast.

Amazing. Everything very well preserved, clean and tidy. At Rustem Pasa Mosque we were amazed by its beauty plus the caretaker had clean scarves for us to use when entering the church. the same did not apply for the Blue Mosque and the New Mosque
Sultanahmet. Many mosques and museums. Historic sites, restaurants, and shopping. The area is not very big, walk and get lost in the old neighborhoods.

Sultanahmet Area. So much of Istanbul is historic that it is hard to narrow this down to one area, but I would generally think of the area on the European side but East of the historic city wall. The area is filled with Mosques, shopping, restaurants, and historic sites. This is the area where a tourist should stay and will likely spend most of their time in Istanbul, as the heart of this very old and historic city. The area is very walkable, but travelers should avoid driving.

So much to see!. So many sights right together beginning with the Topcapi Palace, the Haga Sofia, and Blue Mosque. There are many great eateries new the Blue Mosque. We found a place with great Turkish meatballs! The Basilica Cistern is there as well. Then, you are just a short walk to the Gand Bazaar and Spice Market! Enjoy!

Crowded but worth it. The Grand Bazaar was our favorite.Watch out for "free" guides by the Blue Mosque offer to tour you AND then take you to their uncle's carpet shop We fell for it and actually purchased. Good fun but be prepared to be pressured.

Very Crowded Touristy, but Near everything.. My friend and I stayed in the historical part in Istanbul because we wanted to be near everything. We were within walking distance from everything. Unfortunately we did not know that it was Ramadan and that at night from fasting all day people come out in droves. I mean super crowded, thousands of people. I was enchanted at first but after a few days it is a bit much. If you want to be close to Blue Mosque and various other historical attractions then you should stay in historical district

A wonderful couple of days. You can spend as much time as you want walking through the streets and just window shopping or viewing the old buildings and cobblestone streets...beware of the fast cars and the narrow streets...great restaurants and shops abound
Istanbul. Istanbul is very hot during June/July so pack very light clothing and walking shoes or sandals. Very well preserved.
Beautiful City. Very well maintained and access is good.Bus/tram services to all centres were excellant and very very clean country.

Old is good!. Istanbul is a city brimming with history. There is always something new to learn about the history there. Almost every building has over 100 years of stories to tell you. Take time and learn ;-)
Perfect for a walk. Just let yourselves to enjoy the little shops and try to buy everything you like at a lower price than the starting price!!

amazing walk. Advised to walk with comfortable shoes since all the attractions within walking distance . During my visit in Istanbul , I spent almost everyday walking around the area and found so many other interesting places.

So Many Great Neighborhoods. We went on a Jewish Heritage Tour, and our (non-Jewish) guide showed us several older neighborhoods that had been occupied by various ethnic group (Greeks, Armenians, etc.). Loved the working bakeries with their woodfired ovens, the lovely narrow lanes populated by produce vendors and the centuries of architecture that varied from area to area.
Almost Overwhelming. There is so much to see and do here -- make sure you allocate enough time so you don't have to rush around.
Travel back to ages.. Byzantine Empire, Roman Empire, Ottoman Empire... All actually LIVED in this fantastic city and Old Town was the center of it all.

A city you will fall in love with. Istanbul is a perfect city to meet new people and discover beautiful historic places. Book a hotel near Sultanahmet and you'll be able to walk around the central part of the city. That is cool for your experience, health and you will also save money on tram)

A True Turkish Delight. I'll admit that Istanbul was not my most-anticipated destination when we toured Europe in celebration of my daughter's college graduation. And now that I've been there, I'll admit it is the one city I can not wait to visit again. The historic areas are safe to wander around in night and day, prices are inexpensive, and down every street, around every corner, you are enveloped in culture and history. The mosques, the cistern, the old churches, the bazaars....all so old and yet so new to the eyes. The diversity of the people, the scrumptious food, the aroma in the air, the music, the calls to prayer.....it was as far from "home" as a place possibly can be, and isn't that exactly why one travels?
Amazing. one of the best experience in my life. mosquee leave you breathless, colors hugs everithing in a warm and romantic skyline

Great Layout. Old town is great because all of the historical sites are mostly right next to each other. This very old part city was well planned and has been restored very well. All of the restaurants are modern, the tram stop is located near all of the historical sites, there are many hotels to choose from, there are also a plenty of shops (of course geared toward tourist) to spend your time in. It is a very obvious tourist district,you see tourist from all over the world in droves, and there are endless touts trying to get you to spend money in their establishment. You have to take the good with the bad.
get lost. best way to explore is to let yourself get lost a little. Have your wits about you but Istanbul is a safe city with a great deal of atmosphere
Great place to explore. Great place to walk around... and not too much hastle from the locals!

Off the beaten track. You dont have to go far to get off the beaten track and its well worth getting away from the tourists and much of the hassle. This is the old Istanbul that people live and work in and although less scenic makes up for it in authenticity. We never felt threatened although we were obviously tourists. the shops sold things that the locals wanted to buy and although many of them did not speak english and we did not speak Turkish, the numbers on the till were easy to understand. Its also worth mentioning that bottled water and fruit prices drop by over 50% just a few yards into the more local areas.
everything. great city great people great history to many things to mention and two weeks is not long enough to see them all will be back

Slice of History / Slice of Life / GREAT EXPERIENCE!. If you don't see the Old Town you've missed Istanbul. People continue their life as they know it, passed down through their ancestors; while restoration and construction continue to modify and update the face of the old buildings and old houses, preserving their heritage. The narrow old cobblestone streets, cafes, butcher shops, bakery's, markets, stores and most importantly the wonderful, helpful people who welcome you every step of the way! Many Small Renovated Quaint Hotels too! Lots of Cats! WOW! A must see!

What a set of stories!. It seems that everywhere in Istanbul has a great story to tell. We could not believe how many impressive mosques there are and especially loved the Basilica Cistern. It is cool in every sense, even on a scorching hot day.
Walk through history. There is no where in the world where one can get the feeling of the history from B.C. through the 1920s as in Istanbul.
Busy Place. There's a lot going on in Old Town, feels a little touristy in parts of it. Stay focused on what you want to see.
Very Clean. Istanbul over all is very clean, the sites are very well kept too.

Worth It. You can see why the Turkish are so proud of Istanbul. It shows in the way everything is maintained. Easy to get around, smooth and efficient systems. Local very very helpful to tourists. Other countries could and should take a leaf out of their book :o)
History like few places can claim. Istanbul has history that few places can claim. I loved the Sultanahmet area where we stayed. We were able to walk to almost everything we wanted to do!
small but perfectly formed. A historical treat in a small area - so much to see and do in a beautiful warm setting
happy atmosphere. the atmosphere was happy and friendly it reminded me of happy places.

Walk through a culture & history. The major sites of Istanbul are all in close proximately. It's an easy, safe area to get around - don't waste money on a guide, just grab Rick Steves or whichever book you like and go. If you're coming from the cruise port, just take the tram or the electric train and venture out.
Ottoman and Byzantium... You can see all ottoman and byzantium relics, the greatest 2 empirements of history, in all walking area.

Charming and lovely. The town is full of culture, wonderful people and sights to take in. Just walk around observing the quite and absorbing the sights coz this is one experience you don't want to miss. The old world charm blended with the modern ways, Istanbul is one of my favourite cities in the world.
Very interesting. Enjoyed the atmosphere and varied sights around the town, lots to see and do. Felt very safe.

So much to see in Sultanahmet. there are so many historic areas in Istanbul...Sultanahmet is a must see area with all the top attractions but the Grand Bazaar and the Spice Bazaar are also fabulous. Also saw the Golden Horn area --unique historic homes, in disrepair but starting to be restored...you need two weeks just in Istanbul!
Accessible. Seeped in history and totally accessible, no outrageous entry costs

Old City. The sites in the old city are not to be missed. The Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia and the Architectural Museum were great. Don't miss the Bazaar. We wish we had 3 more days to spend in Instanbul.

Return to Istanbul. We visited Istanbul a few years ago and couldn't wait to return as it's the most exciting city we ever were in. Last time we saw the Blue Mosque, Agia Sofia, The Roman cistern, all the usual sights in fact. I find Agia Sofia a bit sad, an empty shell no longer used for worship and with its fine mosaics much vandalised, but everything else is fabulous. We went up the Bosphoros on the ferry (much cheaper than a tour) and spotted the Domabahce Palace but didn't have time to see it, so this time it was a priority. Well worth the trip on its own - real wow factor. We also went a second time to the Topkapi Palace as, having done the harem tour, we didn't have time to see everything last time. Brought home a big box of baklava!
Great Visit. We walked to most of the historic sites with a guide on a tour. Only four people on the tour, so we learned a lot of the History of Istanbul

Absolutely perfect!!. We requested Mehmet from Argeus to book us a trip to Cappadocia. It was absolutely fantastic. The hotel was great. The restaurants chosen for our meals were top class, really great food. Hur, our guide was the highlight of the trip. He is very knowledgeable and involved us totally in the process of exploring the many caves in Cappadocia. The itinerary he followed in showing us the caves was really admirable. We just loved this trip. We had children of varying age groups and they too thoroughly enjoyed Cappadocia and exploring the caves with Hur. Thanks to Mehmet and Hur for making Cappadocia a memorable trip.
My favorite city in the world!. And I travel a LOT! I am out of the USA almost once a month....yet I can't get enough of old Istanbul.
Lots of character. To see some of the history. All around the Ottomen buildings +the Mosques are amaizing

Fun and hectic. I dont think Istanbul is like the other big cities i have visited.It is more caotic and busy, but also more fun. It is a realy mixture of people you see on the streets. there are some fine buildings and a very nice skyline. A lot to shop, just remember to bargain. The bazars was fun, but I do not think you will do the best deals there. We have an apartment in the Alanya district and I am sure I will get a better price there.But if you find something you really like and you are not sure you can find anywhere else, go ahead. I must say that my experience of Turks are that they are very honest people. That was before I visited Istanbul. We were tried to be cheated several times during our three day stay. Do not thrust any seller, friendly person who contacts you"just trying to help". They are after your money. Nothing else! Thrust me.
Walk around and see everything!!. Start walking in any direction and you will find history and great food!! Take your appetites and your sneakers!

Grand Bazar. A must - I have never seen more shopping in one place - prices were good on most goods - however their are some knock offs "watches" they stop working once you get home...some clothes are cheaply made, while leather and jellery is in adundance.
Wonderful. Many to see but need lot of time. plan your route carefully, take water with you as they are very expensive when you get thier

Fun place. Istanbul Oldtown is full of great places to eat and quite a few attractions. Prices are very good and the people were quite friendly. The tram stops right in the middle of where you want to be. Go there and enjoy !

Istanbul. THere is a great deal to see in the historic areas of Istanbul. You need to allow at least 2-3 days to properly see everything. You can want to many places from the Sultanamet area and take the trolley if you want to go to the Grand Bazar.
Historic sites. The water tour was excellent and gave a great view of the city

Great & amazing. Great & amazing, many attractions & sightseeing places in one location .
You need at least 4 to 5 days to cover it all .

Great & amazing. Great & amazing, don't miss it .
You need at least 3 to 4 days at least to cover all the main attractions & sightseeing locations .

Absolutely fascinating. Exploring the architecture and the bazaars was great. Istanbul is easy to walk around and if you get tired just hop on the light rail back to your hotel. The shop owners can be persistent but if you smile and say "No thank you" (learn how to say it in Turkish is even better) they will leave you alone. After a couple of days they got to know us and left us alone.
A memorial visit. The visit to historic areas of Istanbul is memorable
Many excellent small restaurants, hidden gems. Every side street had something different and is worth exploring the unknown restaurants.
Fascinating. I'm not sure it's all that old apart from the main sights.

Istanbul Old Town. Istanbul Old Town is full of quaint sights and makes for some exciting taxi journeys. The local drivers certainly have to exercise a great deal of patience in coping with the congestion; but it is all good fun.

Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet is packed with beautiful historic sites, all within easy walking distance. With buildings it is an opportunity to soak up the beautiful architecture and tile-work. With markets, coffee shops, and restaurants, it is a chance to sample local foods and culture. Service is always very courteous.
Sofisticated. We found the old town to be both safe and we easily filled in six days of site seeing, walking about and of course the obligatory shopping.
Magical. this was our first visit to turkey and we found the whole experience to be magical, make sure you visit all of the major sites and walk around the town to get the feel of a very safe city
So many!. I love ancient history, and Istanbul has a very interesting past.

Byzantine and Ottoman Constantinople is unique in World History. Only a handful of cities rank with Constantinople, the Old City within the Theodosian walls surrounded by modern Istanbul, as central sights for World Culture. My recommendation for the Churches, Mosques, Palaces and Museums in this city is to use the Blue Guide and do not rush anything. The great Byzantine Churches and the Imperial Mosques are among the most beautiful and impressive buildings on earth. Topkapi and its Harem are evocative too. Make this city visit on your own. To do so will bring rewards few attractions anywhere on the planet can match. There are crowds at Hagia Sophia and Topkapi, even in May. Go off season if possible and do go early in the morning or late afternoon. The tour groups can lessen the experience, but they pay almost no attention to the Harem. The lesser Imperial Mosques are magnificent too. It is not useful to specify anything further. Just be sure to visit Constantinople.
Place of History. The old town is full of age old buildings and stone paved walkways. The Grand Bazar is a good stop to look at hand made carpets.
Charming, bohemian touch. Historic areas of Istanbul is simply charming with bohemian touch. It is crowded but in a good way. All attractions and historic places in one location reachable by foot.
Beautiful Istanbul. Istanbul is a lovely multicultural city, safe and affordable

Istanbul Old City. HagiaSofia, Blue Moschee, Hippodrom , Cisterne , harbour with spice bazar/egyptian bazar and departures to most of the touristic attractions (Bosporus tour day/night !) ........ great attractions within a 15 minute walk ! Even Conctantin Column and Grand Bazar are to be done in less than a 30 minute walk !Best place to start a Istanbul stay is to book a hotel in the Old City !!!!!
nice experience. You should walk through the narrow but very clean streets of this town

A place from the past. you think you live in the past Everything is very authentic...Hagia Sofia make your imagination come back to Byzantine Times...Mosques....bazars.....friendly people....A smell of East!!!

Beautiful. The historic ares of Istanbul including the Blue mosque, Hague Sophia and Basilica Cistern in the Old city are gorgeous. This part of the city has its own charm and character with the Mosaic ceramic work.
Great experience!. We experienced a sense of what it is like to live in Istanbul. Very interesting and a unique cultural experience.

Tophane-i Amire Culture and Arts Center + The Great Masters Exhibition. Tophane-i Amire is a 19th century building in Istanbul. As it is written in Wikipedia:The name of the place was driven from the armory known as Tophane-i Amire (English: Imperial armory), which was built in the reign (1451–1481) of Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II. Its main purpose was the manufacturing cannons and cannon balls. Tophane, which could be seen in Melling's (1763–1831) engraving, has not been able to survive to this day. In 1823, during the Firuz Agha fire, the barracks were burned down only to be renewed soon later. Tophane building is currently used as the culture and arts center of Mimar Sinan University of Fine Arts and it is housing many exhibitions.Moreover, at the moment there is an interactive exhibition about Michelangelo, Leonardo and Raphael, called 'The Great Masters' at Tophane-i Amire Culture and Arts Center. The curators of the exhibition are renowned art historians Dr. Francesco Buranelli, chairman of the Vatican Museum and Alessandro Vezzosi, the Director of Leonardo da Vinci Museum. The exhibition will be open until 31 July. For further details, please visit: http://www.thegreatmasters-ist.com/As Arter Tasarim (The designer and organizer of the exhibition project in Istanbul), we would like the place and the exhibition to be included in the art venues in Istanbul on tripadvisor. If required, the photos of the venue and the visuals of the exhibition could be sent.Regards,Sebla SahinArter TasarimMarketing and Communications Director
Good. Construction on going outside the mosque. It is called as blue mosque as well. very pretty from inside.

A Morning Walk. I arrived at 0700 to my hotel. I spent the morning walking through the Hippodrome, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and other sites. The perfect time to see these wonderful places and avoid the crowds during the later part of the day. Wear good supportive shoes!

History at it's Best. During a recent stop in Insanbul we did a bus tour of Old Town Istanbul. The tour company did a good job putting it together and our guide spoke acceptable English but I thought it seemed we rushed through the tour. Perhaps it was just me, in that I enjoy getting off the bus, taking photos of the 'locals', etc. Others in our group really enjoyed the tour so I won't say anything more negative about it. Perhaps I just expected more; but overall the tour was worth the cost.

So much to see!. Istanbul has so much history to offer the tourist and after doing the major attractions it's great to just wander round the streets taking in the atmosphere. It's a mad crowded city with appalling traffic and more retail opportunities per sq.m than I've seen anywhere before! We loved it.
Important ideas -- further reading required. I would recomend this part of town alot because you are in an ancient part of the city itself.
Well-designed, well-made. We loved it because we in a great part of history that was from a long time ago.
You just feel blessed!. Visiting Istanbul is a spiritual experience! And visit the Historic Areas is more spiritual, it´s really special!
nice but touristy. all the historic attractions are here and so are the tourists. if you want you experience the real istanbul you should venture to another part of town

A capital city of world culture for 1700 years. Istanbul has a lot to offer to every taste. From the busy cafes street of Istiklal, to the historical monumental Sultan Ahmet with its mosques, palaces and meuseums to the breathtaking Bosphorus (Bogaz), to the beautiful presentations of whirling Darwishes to the views from Camluca. Istanbul is a beauty that can never be forgotten...the only city in the world that truely mixes the cultures of the east with the civilization of the west. It is the most beautiful city of the world

Old town is the right place to stay. Old town Istanbul is safe area and quiet.City is more crowded and noisy too much traffic.Old town is more peacefull.If you still need to go to the center Tram is very good way of transportaion without traffic and cheap.
Old is gold. This is beauty, absolute beauty and I could even say marvelous!

Excellent place and lots of history around Istanbul. Istanbul itself is history and it speaks volume. Where you go, it is history, Galata Tower, Sultanahmet, Blue mosque, Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sofia, Grand Bazaar, Egypt Bazaar etc etc.. wow!
Shoes. This part of Turkey is made of winding, thin lanes of cobblestones. Interesting,authentic shops but ladies should not where stilettos.

A great experience. Staying in the old town of Istanbul, with it's amazing hustle and bustle, the shops, restaurants, hawkers, archeological sites and the haunting beauty of the dueling calls to prayer from all the mosques (particularly at dusk) was unforgettable.

The Heart of Istanbul. Istanbul is a huge city with 15 or million people.. and the old town is the heart of it with layers of history, hotels, restaurans, bars, museums.. You can almost walk to all major historical spots and having a break in a nice cafe is not a big problem.. You can start with Topkapi palace and get to Archeological Musum from there and on your way back peek into Aya Irini church and St. Sophie is just next to it.. You can spend days around the old town withough leaving it and whatever you will see will surprise you ...

The best place to get the flavour of Istanbul!. Don't miss the Old City - we stayed at the Ottoman Imperial Hotel - a charming boutique hotel across the street from the Hagie Sophia. The Blue Mosque and the Basilica Cistern are within walking distance. The restaurants are charming.
Cobbles, mosques, culture, history galore.. The old town is well worth a wander. Avoid the carpet touts though!
very beautiful. it was so amazing, there is alot to se of the old people that they lived and its contain the old and the new life.

walking on a history is a great feeling. Istanbul has served as the capital of four empires (Roman,Byzantine,Latin,Ottoman) and now we are walking on the same streets, touching the same city walls, breathing the same air as they did many years ago. My favorite places; Golden Horn, Beyoğlu, Sultanahmet, Kadıköy, Eminönü, Balat-Fener. Mosques, churches, city walls, Grand Bazaar, bridges (Architect Mimar Sinan), gates, squares.. Istanbul is great place to live.

Argeus Tourism & Travel. Just returned from a fantastic 2 week tour of Turkey organized by Mehmet of Argeus. It was everything we had hoped for and were promised. Out guide Sukru was very knowledgable and helpful on every aspect. It was our first trip to Turkey and we were very impressed. The people are very hospitable and gracious. The cultural/historical attractions are outstanding. We highly recommend Argeus for a very personal touch and high quality, reliable service. Turkey is a beautiful country.
A classic city view. Old, historic, laid back, interesting. Liked the cobbled streets and old market areas especially the Spice Market.
Worn out my shoes. Made several trips and think I saw all the sights. Only disappointment was that I missed a Turkish bath. 'til next time!

A good exploration!. Walking distance between all the historical places in Sultanahmet. You can reach Grand Bazaar either by walking or by Metro Tram, it is just 3 stations apart from Sultanahmet station. Since my hotel is near Grand Bazaar, I usually took Metro back instead of walking after sight-seeing the whole day. I bought souvenirs along the way, and found it was slightly expensive than other shops. I guess a good bargain skill is needed! Moreover, don't refrain from drinking water, kept your self hydrated, there are plenty of clean restroom all around. And there are also many restaurants along they way,thus, the competition is strong. Normally the restaurants guy would linger around, saying "hello, how are you", trying to get you into their restaurants. There is a yellow wooden house, which is tourist police station just opposite the basilica cistern. The police is very helpful. I suggest if you have any questions, you ask them instead of asking other locals. Overall, I would say, there are new excavation going on, worth to pay a second visit next time.
Trip back in time. Could just imagine the horses riding up and down the streets - narrow streets definitely not meant for cars. Loved the buildings, mosques and palaces

exotic. a stroll through the old town and the grand bazaar is an exotic adventure. virtually thousands of small stores line the area and offer eveything from souvenir trinkets to valuable jewellery and rugs.

Learn to say No quickly, but nicely. Having just spent 4 days in Istanbul our best advice is to learn how to say no in a nice manner. The shop sellers here are as aggressive in getting you into their shops as we have seen. Beware about buying rugs without getting some advice from your hotel staff. It seems though that everyone has the best merchandise for the cheapest price. We paid 1/2 the starting price for our rugs and after asking other people it seemed that this was about the correct price. We also found we could not get the VAT back..not sure why but the shop owner implied he did not pay VAT!We went to a shop called Mihrap, run by Musa Sahin and he was great and honest. His shop is on Alemdar Cd. Zeynep Sultan Camii Sk, No.20 /a Sulananhmet. Email musa1750@yahoo.com
Viberant. Wonderful old buildings with such history and tiny twisty streetsfull of bargains, colour and spices.

Truly wonderful. We toured the historical area (Spice bazaar, Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, and Grand Bazaar for Best done by walking versus tour bus as traffic is very congested. You can stop and grab a bite to eat anywhere. The Blue Mosque is vey moving grand space inside and worth just sitting in and watching people for an hour (also cool in heat of the day).

Amazing. Istanbul is an amazing city and the Old Town is full of history. I visited in April and although the weather was rubbish there were plenty of indoor things to do.I especially enjoyed Sophia Mosque - spectacular in the daytime or nighttime when it is lit with blue lights. The thrill of treasure-seeking in the Grand Bazaar was heightened by a constant fear that you are about to be ripped off!The people were welcoming everywhere I went. There is no food like the food in Istanbul - truly unbeatable kebaps - fresh, hot and delicious. I would go back just for that! I had a great time and plan to return again. One of the best ways to explore Istanbul is on foot on your own but taking a tour could be a real asset if the crowds get a bit much.

Lots to do in Sultanahmet. I was in Istanbul in April for a 3 night break - the sun shone down on the first day, then the rest of the trip was milky-grey: misty & drizzly!But I still had a great time - there are lots of indoor monumental buildings & museums to see in the historic area as Istanbul is a unique fusion of history & scenery & is thick with atmosphere, there's something for everyone.The capital of not one but four fallen empires, Turkey's biggest city has long been a draw for visitors - the most easterly stop on the Orient Express, previously known as Constantinople & before that Byzantium, it is one of the oldest cities in the world & for nearly 500 years, it was the capital of the Ottoman Empire, a powerful regime that, at its height, stretched from Hungary to Iraq.Your day will start early & evocatively with the amplified strain of the muezzin calling the faithful to prayer. I found one of the best ways to explore the historic area is on foot - proceeding through the city at a leisurely pace, you have time to notice all the little things, but enlisting the services of a good local guide could be a real asset. You could zoom in on a specific aspect of the city with a walking tour or class. The only city spanning two continents, most of the historical sites are on the European side.PLACES TO SEE An enticing starting point for the historic area is shopping in the 550-year-old lively, colourful Grand Bazaar - it's a consumers' paradise.For more workaday souvenirs, try the scents & sights of the city's ancient Spice Market Bazaar, Rustem Pasa Mosque stands proud within easy walking distance of the Spice Bazaar - built during the Ottoman Empire, it showcases the best Ottoman architecture & exquisite Iznik tiles.One of Istanbul's most famous sights is the Blue Mosque - colossal and wondrous.The Yerebatan underground cisterns are worth a visit for the carved stone columns.Another example of Istanbul's magnificence - the sprawling Topkapi Palace was the glory of the Ottoman Empire, the crown jewel of Istanbul's history, & the centre of power from where the Ottoman sultans ruled an empire as big as the United States from 1465 to 1853. Home to many a colourful story, today it is a museum..The 6th-century glorious, mosaic-filled Ayasofya mosque, also known by its Greek name Hagia Sophia was once a Byzantine church only for Christians; then made into a mosque for just Muslims under the Ottomans. It is a not to be missed fascinating impressive museum for all.I would recommend the historic areas to all.
Excellent. Did a walking tour with an English speaking guide using Backpackers Travel Agency as recommended by Turkeytravelplanner.com
Istanbul. Loved Istanbul, the culture the ancientness & the grand ±Bazar VERY friendly place
Great. Very nice location, tons of little shops, places to eat and things to do..

Old City. Enjoyed everything. Although I walked alone, not with group tour I was able to take in all sites without waiting long. I especially liked the Cagaloglu Hamani (Turkish Bath) It was a great experience and in such a historical venue

Best if seen with a guide. The history of Istanbul is interesting and centuries old. I would recommend using a guide, private is preferable. We hit the major sights in a full day. Don't miss the Bacilica Sistern.
A city with a lot of history. Even just walking through old streets, bazaars and seeing mosques is wonderful

A lot of hassling, specially by shue shine man... food not as good as expected.... I worked as a flight attendant for five years and traveled all around the world. Finally I got a chance to see Istanbul and to be honest I was expecting more. I guess it is because everyone was telling me all the time how beautiful that city is. Blue mosque is beautiful and Hagia Sophia is something that is nice to see and knowing that it is a building more than 1500 years old is impressive. But other that, hm... And for every attraction there is a fee at least 10 euro except for the Blue mosque which is free... Another attraction that was not bad for me was Dolmabache palace and Harem where Sultan lived with his wifes... You can see all major historical attractions in two, and even one day.I was disappointed with the food a lot that at the end I was looking for Burger King, and I hate fast food... Entree is around 15 euros per person in some average restaurant and it is small... It would be ok if the size of the portion is fine but every time it was too small even for me and I am a skinny lady and not to mention the taste... So I would say prices are European but level of hygiene and service quite below... Bazaar, nothing special in every country they are selling same pashmina, same mostly Chinese made staff, same like any Arabic country, you visit one of them you' ve seen them all... And they are trying to rip you off on every corner, starting from taxi drivers. If they see you are a tourist suddenly 20 lira ride becomes 50 at least. Even in restaurant they write sometimes additional price by hand on the receipt... I went even to Princess island as everyone was saying how beautiful it is, but not my taste, dirty and crowdy... So I would ruther spend my money to visit some other destination and Istanbul probably as a one or max two days stop...

Lots to see and experience. Istanbul is really special among the world cities. It's split between continents, between civilizations, between modernity and traditions. It has a unique flavor and charm, with friendly people, historic sights and things to do able to keep you busy for a long time. It deserves more than a city break. Take the time. Definitely worth giving yourself time to wonder around the old city.

Beautiful to walk around the streets. For first time travellers it would be great to stay in the old town - Sultanahmet. There is so much to see and experience here - just by walking around the streets you will be entertained. Look up and you will see a fantastic skyline. absolutely so beautiful!!!!. Everything about this area is just gorgeous! Just nice to walk around and check out the areas. Careful that food prices are quite expensive around here, and they won't include service tax and charge you and try and rip you off..

So much to see and do. There are so many wonderful and famous sights in Sultanahmet (Old Town), and everything is within walking distance. Wandering among the side streets is well worth it, since the main streets (Divan Yolu and Alemdar Cadessi) are very commercial, geared to tourists. The side streets have stores, of course, but they're quieter and show more of what the Istanbul resident sees and lives. Of course you have to see Hagia Sophia (Ayasofya), the Blue Mosque, the Cistern, the Grand Bazaar, Topkapi Palace Museum, and the Archaeological Museum. There's also the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art, the Egyptian Obelisk on the site of the old Hippodrome, and the Mosaics Museum (which was closed when I was there, but I was told it's magnificent). Everyone will want to sell you something -- guide service in Ayasofya, or a carpet, or something -- but you can smile and say no politely and keep walking. The rule of thumb on bargaining is DO IT. Start at 50% of what was asked, and be prepared to walk away. This applies in stores (even those that seem upscale) and with street vendors. If they're really want to sell you something, they'll offer a lesser price. Keep at it, since it's part of the experience of being in Istanbul.

What a town. We walked or took the Tram everywhere, no need for taxis here despite what others may say. The tram is far more efficient than dealing with traffic in a taxi because they come so often and have their dedicated lanes and the main line stops everywhere you need it to. This town has it all. Shops, cafes, Euro "fast" food and food carts, mosques and so much more.

If you're looking for keepsakes, jewellery, or things of that nature, odds are you will find the most authentic items at the Grand Bazaar. The cheap stuff is outside the bazaar. The spice market is like food porn and I would challenge anyone to walk through it and not salivate by the end of it all.

full of historical atmospher. I like this region biginning with sultan ahmed,ayasophia and topkapy.then we visit grand pazar which is a great place to buy gifts and suviners.I think who visit istanbul and do not go to these places not visit istanbul at all..
Istanbul. Continuous canvassing of tourists by locals selling all manner of goods plus scams to rip unsuspecting tourists off, particularly shoe shine men!

Lots of interesting things to see. There is something for everyone - visiting mosques, roaming through streets "window shopping" on the stalls, trying Turkish delights, etc. Lots of fun but watch your personal belongings.

Tips for a short break in Istanbul. book your hotel near blue mosque - better choice of restaurants. Hard city to navigate, few road signs and no "you are here" boards so make sure you have a good map. We took taxis everywhere - most were reasonably priced, but avoid using 8-10am 5-7pm rush hours as traffic is bumper to bumper, so fares can be 4-5 times the price. Make sure you have some 1 Lira coins for the public toilets. Bosphorus tour is a must - but be sure to book one with commenteay if you want to know all riverside buildings. Pedlars everywhere - mainly kids; pestering you as walk and when you sit down to eat near Grand Bazaar - tissues, socks, fake perfume, jackets, toys, etc As you try to walk passed bars & restaurants they will invite you in. Check out a few before you stop and enjoy a cold glass of Efes beer. Kayikci Restaurant served a great Tbone steak : Ticazethane Sok (just off Tramvay Yolu near Blue Mosque).

Istanbul is the most beautiful city in the world!. I went 2 years ago to Istanbul and it is an amazing city! It is full with history and grace! Everyone should see it at least once in their life. There is so much to see, you can't see even half of its beauty of your first trip. Make sure you come back every year!
A great place to visit. Lots to do fantastic culture and friendly people. The grand bazaar is superb as are all the mosques

One of the Greatest Cities in the World. There aren't really enough adjectives to describe the wonderfully rich history and beauty of this district. It's truly a wonderful part of one of the greatest cities in the world! Not to be missed.

The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market. The Grand Bazaar and Spice Market, wonderfully timeless, magical markets - just as I imagined they would be. Give yourselves plenty of time to soak up the atmosphere and history!

so much to see!. you walk around istanbul, and every street corner there is a mosque or some other monument that are probably 500 years old - for the people who live there, it is just a daily reality. I still can't wrap my mind around it.

Rich rich history. very authentic and makes for a good photo op. the grand bazar and the egyptian souk are a must see. you will not find this anywhere else in the world. The history is present everywhere and the Islamic architecture is imposing
Turkish delight. Lovley people, superb historical buildings, great food, affordable, charming, grows on you
Ideal.. So much to see and do that it is worth staying nearby. Cobbled streets and amazing buildings.
an amazing city. everything about Istanbul is lovable from the touts to the mindboggling history. one of my favourite places in the world!
Wonderful. Streets full of tourists,markets full of anything of any kind and any price level,to fulfill everybody's needs and preferences.Strongly suggest!

Lots of colours & flavours. We walked up and down, at time feeling lost but that's okay since we were not in a rush. The smell, the visual colours and the interaction with locals were enriching. You must try their apple tea and Turkish delight.

Must See. Loved the Hippodrome-one could just imagine the ancient days of the chariot races. The Blue Mosque is here and what a sight this is-magnicant. The ancient walls can be seen everywhere and it's a marvel.
Charming. Old town is very charming. Most sites are within walking distance. Do not miss the shops and restaurants around the corner.

Old and magnificent. People seem to be happy in Istanbul. Mostly pleasant and friendly. The sites easily compete with European countries. It is a clean city. You will have delicious food no matter where you eat.

kinds of varieties

friendly, helpful people , relaxing hamans, chai, hukka(Nargille) & tavla(the ethnic turkish boardgame).. beautiful glassware.. this is old istanbul
