Istanbul, Turkey Old Town. Old Town is beautiful and interesting . The sights of Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, and the colors and smells of the Grand Bazaar were incredible. Wish I was there!

Istanbul is a must see!. The sheer magnitude of Istanbul's history is there for you to view. From the Byzantine Empire to the time of the Ottoman's, Istanbul is a magnificent city to visit. I will come again.

One more reason to be proud for being born in Istanbul. With such a long history, much longer that the one of many capitals of european countries, Istanbul is and has to be treated like a treasure of Europe, a treasure of the world.The Turkey' Government has done a lot to restaure and to maintain the historic areas and monuments in Istanbul but it is a duty for all the world to contribute to this efort.
The best part of Istanbul. You can walk here for hours, and everywhere you see nice buildings and you meet frfiendly people.

Over 1500 years of history in one place. It is wonderful to have so many significant sites within walking distance of each other: Haggia Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, the hippodrome and the Cisterns. These aren't just beautiful buildings but they represent a great swathe of history and human endeavour. Inevitably they are rightly popular and can be very busy. Try to go early and avoid the crowds. The authorities are working hard to improve access to this area and make it navigable for the hundreds and thousands wishing to visit. The end result should be worth the current inconvenience. I do hope it will also allow access to the Byzantine archaeological site.

A trip of a life time your senses will thank you. Take good walking shoes to visit Istanbul. Walking can be challenging at times. The streets and walkways have uneven pavement. There also are a lot of stairs and thresholds in the museums and mosques. Istanbul however will charm you with an abundance of finely crafted textiles and leathers. You will also find those omnipresent blue eyes . All in good humor. The streets were cleaner than any European city I have visited. The parks are lovely, the people are friendly and helpful they are very genuine and kind. I felt welcome there. Do walk around, take the tram. Two turkish liras will buy you a jeton for the ram. It will take you pretty much any where a tourist would want to go.

Enchanting and amiable. The Historic Areas of Istanbul are amazing. Unfortunately, much of the architecture from the 2600 years of history in Istanbul has been destroyed (thanks to Septimus Severus). However, what remains is absolutely beautiful. You can see the Blue Mosque (formally known as Sultanahmet Mosque), Haghia Sophia (built as a church, rebuilt a few times, then converted into a mosque after the fall of Constantinople in 1453 and now a museum), Topkapi Palace (built in 1453 by Mehmet the Conqueror as the home of the Sultan and the Basilica Cistern (underground water silo). You can also see the remains of the Hippodrome and Constantine’s Column. You can then cross the inlet of water known as the Golden Horn. Here you can see the Galata Tower (great 360 degree view of the city) and Dolmobahce palace, which replaced Topkapi as the home of the Sultans after the middle of the 19th century. Even with all the destruction that Istanbul has been home to, much of the history still remains. It’s great to see Byzantine era structures, Roman edifices and churches, and Muslim mosques and palaces all in the same city.
More romantin than Paris. Istambul is on the top of the romantic atmosphere in this globe
Amazing places and very close by. We took guided tour to visit Historic areas of Istanbul and amazed by the history and construction of them
Shayne & Rob's opinion. So many things to see and do in Istanbul, with the history being so well recorded, displayed, maintained and fascinating.

Beautiful City on the Bosphorus. Highly recommend Hagia Sophia, Spice Market, Tokapi Palace, Taksim Square and a ride across the Bosphorus Bridge. Liked (not loved) the Grand Bazaar, Hippodrome and Blue Mosque.

Argeus Tourism and Travel Brilliant Tour Operator. We had a fantastic 9 day private tour organised entirely by Argeus, My father is especially interested in history and they tailored a tour that was pitched perfectly from our excellent, knowledgable and personable guide Faruk Basibuyuk, the choice of quirky specialist hotels (especially loved Nisanyan Everi in Sirince) and the delicious restaurants (see other reviews). We went to Afrodisias which was a highlight and we would never have gone there without Argeus. They organised an internal flight from Istanbul to Izmir and all our transport who were all excellent and I cannot thank them enough for making our trip memorable, informative, comfortable and tasty!!We will be returning to Turkey to visit some more of the amazing sights and to experience the fabulous hospitality and we will definitely be using Argeus travel to organise our trip.

Lots to see in historic Istanbul. Many historic sites, winding streets, good explanations of mausoleums and mosks in English, so learned lots of fascinating history of the Ottoman Empire and how it relates to other empires and the interface between the Islamic religion and other major world religions.

Changes for the better. It had been 20 years since my last visit to Istanbul. The main changes I noticed are that the streets and environs are much cleaner than before. Easy to walk around and the tram system is a breeze to use. People are friendly and helpful with directions if you are lost. Do yourself a favour, just get out and walk around
Istanbul visit. I like everything except the taxi drivers attitude and high rates sometimes.
Magnificent city. Great concentration of historical sights, shops, restaurants and hammams.
Fascinating. Historic buildings and places of interest were around every corner. There were so many that there wasn't enough time to visit all of them.
Lots to see. Plenty of things to see in and around the old city area. Recommend the Hagia Sofia, the roman cisterns, Topkapi and just walking about.

Get out and walk. We walked every where in Istanbul and the transit/train system was easy to use and understand. You see way more by walking. We actually took the hop-on/hop-off tour, saw what we wanted to visit and did all the walking and such the next day.
Not what I expected. The Old Town has such a relaxed feel to it. Everyone we met was friendly and helpful, and the streets are wide with lots of places to eat - outside as well as in.

Just amble in old Istanbul. We wandered down to the little Sofia mosque and all around that area, where there are old wooden houses. We met and talked with people who lived there, allsmiling and friendly, I'm sending photos to one old lady and her family, who let me take pictures of them, much to her deligth - and mine. We also found super restaurant
souds good!. You will get perfect information in every part of your walking .
Charming, and interesting. It's hard to visit old Istanbul without finding something either charming, fascinating, or simply delightful in some way on a very regular basis.
Great Atmosphere. Terrific to wander around and very safe - fantastic food and very nice peopld

Istanbul is full of history and magnificent. The Topik Kap Palace is wonderful and the Moskes (St. Sophie and Blue Moske) as well. But do not lose the underground unbelievable water reservoir made about 1000 years ago saving the rain water and making possible the city to resist the attacks of the enemies for years with the doors closed and the walls surrended. You also must go to the Grand Bazaar you perhaps never saw anything alike.
Old City-Sultanahmet Area. Very Walkable from one historic site to another. Wear comfortable shoes. Fountain and grass parks are under contruction.
depressing in the rain. loved it but was wet, so would like to see it in better weather
Great. I was never expecting Istanbul to be so beautiful!
same as Sultanahmet. Don't really know the difference. the oldest part of Istanbul is Sultanahmet which is stunning and the only place to be to see all the sites if you don't have a lot of time.

City of history and friendly people. I just return from a cruise with a port of call to istanbul. I joined a private tour for the first day. It was great to have a knowlege guide for all the must see's. People are very friendly and "overly friendly" at the Grand Barrzad. This is one place I wouldn't want to return. The closed by Spice Market is fasinating. The nuts and honey Turkist sweet,Truskist Delights, is very tasty and I wished I have bought more. Spices are wonderfully and can be brought for good price is you bargain. Shop keeper normally discounts 20% but can go down more. For people fancy Capsian Caviers, you would be in for a treat at the Spice Market.Next day, I walked from the port to the Spice Market and it only took 25 minutes. I could see city on foot and sense the daily life of Istanbul. People seem to be content and not in hurry a lot as in developed world. There were a quite of few people fishing along the bridge between the East and West of the city. Seeing all these activities and the faces of people are what is all about travelling.I will definitely return to Istanbul in the future.

So much to learn about RUGS!!!!. I've never been treated like this before. Walking in to a carpet shop? Not really. Walking into an experience? YES. You can't even look until you have had tea, a seat and the kind of politeness that feels so real. Who knows, as Turks are just sociable. Fun? OH YEAH! And, we ended up buying a (small) Heriz prayer rug and, were taught all about how many knots per inch made for a quality carpet. Such a fun day.

interesting. Walking through Istanbul it was very interesting learning about the strange wooden houses that looked out of place next to some of the modern buildings, funny little streets filled with odd houses and historic places. Evrey corner was a surprise

Wear good shoes. The area in the centre of Istanbul needs more than six days to give it total justice. It is an amazing area of history, in fact it pieces together all that you know about the Greeks, the Turks, the Romans and the Crusades all in one place. Do not try and do it all in a few days you will be disappointed. Let it soak in
Beautiful!. Old Istanbul provides for cultural diversity, wonderful neighbourhoods and a lively setting of beauty, scents and colours.

A wonderful city!. We fell in love with Istanbul the moment we set foot on the city.It's historical areas are really wonderful, a mixture of cultures and one really feels the importance and aura of Istanbul, a city which lives between two worlds, the old and the modern, Europe and Asia, West and East. It deserves at least one visit, but many more in the future if possible!
Great Historical area. Well preserved ancient area. I did notice that the TV Antennas are gone - but thousands of sattellite dishes.

All those corners and colours. It's a nice walk. You will be amazed of their architecture, the colours, all so many shops!!It's very nice to let get lost, suddenly find a cementery, a mosque, rare stores. People minding their businesses. You'll do incredible pictures.

Constantinopole is hard to find here. 1)Must visit the Archaeological museum.Check the timings.This is the only place you can find the traces of old Roman empire2)No good notification about Hippodrome,Serpent tower and obelix3)April is the best time as it is the time of the Tulips4)Do not miss the royal garden

Great History. The simple fact of the matter is that you will see a ton of history in this city. One side of the city is modern and the other is old and historic. Both sides offer much. If looking at the old city side then you will be happy to see everything from ancient structure to a world wonder. That in itself is rare but to have so much in such a small area is just great. There are few cities in the world that can match the amount of history and physical evidence of that city in such great condition. Plus the prices for these are great. Grand Bazaar is free, blue mosque is free and many things that are on display outdoors is obviously free. The other attractions will cost but not much and well worth seeing. I cant see anyone saying that they wouldn't pay 20 euro or so to see the inside of the hagia. I mean common. You have to go in if you are there right!
Magical”. You can see all the historical side of Istanbul like Topkapi Palace, , Grand Bazaar, Saint Sophia atc.by walking in one day

Prepare to take a lot of photos!. There is so much to see in the old town. A twenty minute stroll can take you through several vibrant neighbourhoods, all with it's own feel and architecture. The Blue mosque and Hagia Sophia are very close, and the Grand Bazaar is immense! Very characterful place.

Bring your walking shoes!. This is one place where the best, and really only, way to see it is to just step out of your door and walk around. After you dodge the rug guys, meet the Turkish people, they are warm and welcoming!

Highlight of any Istanbul trip. There is so much in this area, including many of the most famous attractions in Istanbul. We met many tourists from all over the world. We loved sitting on a bench and listening to the wonderful calls to prayer from nearby mosques.
Forward to the Past :). Good to see the art and the building done in the past, and all you can say how they did that without our technology and how much they smarter than us

carpet marketeers. It was the end of the day, tired and hiking around Istanbul for this 73 year old was telling me that I needed a happy hour soon. Walking and gwaking around old town Istanbul the first day was a shock to my soul. Walking to my base of operation hotel, Grand Penisula attempting to avoid the final verbal shout to come buy something from me, without eye contact and looking ahead, I heard a voice without a trace of accent and in perfect English, "I can tell by the way you are walking.........this pause was obvious and I could only guess that this fine vocal observation was going to be an invitation to have tea to calm an old person limping down the road. However, he finished his sentence, " That you are just the gentleman that would like to buy a carpet from me" Got to love the Istanbul marketer. and no I was not in the market for a carpet, but this end of the humor made my day
simply amasing. I enjoyed it in every single detail. small strrets, fresh air, nice people

An Amazing City. All the major sight in Istanbul are near the Hagia Sophia Museum.These soon become crowded with bus loads of tourists so arrive early.Then visit the less popular but equally fascinating places like the Archeological & The Museum of Turkish & Islamic Art.People watching on one of the benches along "The Hippadrome" is recommended too!

Old town of Istanbul. Very nice place with many restaurants, cafes and stores that you can find a lot of things. Nice place to walk during the day and at nigth. Very good view of the blue mosque and ayasophya and its splendorous minaretes.

Great for walking. We went at the end of April and the city gardens where full of beautiful flowers, especially tulips. The historic areas were not crowded, except for the Topkapi Palace. The weather was great and the historic attractions are close together so you can walk to them. Everywhere, there are benches to sit and enjoy the scenery while you rest your feet and watch people.
Great atmosphere. A lot of history concentrated in a small area, easy to walk around.

Full of Energy!!!. You can find everything here. It's a bit crowded but especially in the mid to late afternoon but this place is truly amazing. There are lots to see and a good place to sit and let time pass. This place is full of history and movement. There are restaurants, shops of various types that will keep you entertained and hopefully, not broke. Turkish crafts, food, jewelry, carpets are hard to resist. Definitely a place to put on your bucket list.
Nice stroll with a lot of sight-seeing. Nice stroll with a lot of sight-seeing, see all the must-sees in a day.

Life goes on in the old town.. Old and new side by side. The streets that specialise in hardware, kitchen ware and the likes for the locals are so near the spice market we hope people don't miss them. Although it's a tourist town normal life is to be found in the back streets just everywhere. Istanbul is the place to buy scarves and jewellry too, leather shoes, wonderful designs and everything is made in Turkey. The clothing is so fashionable it's a shoppers paradise.

Istanbul in Spring. The city has planted millions of tulips in garden beds all over the city, the designs are very creative. Tulips are indiginous to Turkey, together with the blossom trees every site was enhanced, we loved it all, so April is the time to go. Transport is easy but be prepared to walk so you don't miss anything. Plan on at least 4 days. Don't forget the pastry shops either, or the Turkish delight.
beautiful views. great for walking as they are concentrated in clusters, surrounded by cafes where you can make a break and sip some apple tea :)

Awesome. Istanbul is a wonderful and magic city. The architecture of the mosques gives the city a special flair. The call for prayers five times a day makes you feel like you are in another world. It is magic!

It is a must to visit. This is a very historical part of the town. One of oldest settlements had started in this area and Byzantium, Ottoman era had taken place in this part of Istanbul as well. A friend of ours guided us there and we found out that there are amazing old structers just beneath any ordinary cafe or any building you visit. There are so many layers below what you see on the surface. About old town, these are the first places come to mind in the first place; Topkapi Palace, Spice Market, Grand Bazaar, Saint Sofia, Blue Mosque, Gulhane Park You can easly spend 4-5 days just for these places. Besides walking around in the back streets is a real fun.
Wonderful Istanbul!. Would return in a heartbeat to revist all the areas we visited.
Smell of history is everywhere. It is better to stay in this side of Istanbul and drive to other areas such as Taksim.

the view of all those mosques, noble and not so noble is totally mesmerizing. We went from Bazar to Mosques to hotel Nomade Terrace with a terrific view. Galata Bridge is a muts. We walked all over and also took advantage of public transportation, which we found efficient, fast and costing little. The only thing we highly disliked was the Disco beneath the Hotel Zurich Lobby which prevented us from sleeping until 4AM

Istanbul is constant theatre. I love Istanbul particularly the older parts around Sultanahmet but go off into the cooler winding streets towards Galata Bridge and see real Istanbul and the Spice Bazaar for a wonderful walk.
Sultanahmet area is best. Great for Blue Mosque Hagia Sophia both Cisterns Topkapi and Galata bridge
The perfect city to stroll. Istanbul is worth extensive city strolls. We walked 8-10 hours every day, during our stay of five days. It was well worth it.
A great tour. We did a tour of Istanbul with a guide - a great idea. Saw most of the old sites, wonderful city. We saw the Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace, Spice Bazaar, all fabulous.

A city full of fantastic history. Sultanahmet is very easily walkable and can be explored on your own without a tour. The beauty of this part is how every major attraction is within walking distance. To be honest, the blue mosque is not very special on the inside and if the lines stretch around the blockş don't waste your time standing in line for hours. Topkapı and Hagia Sophia are more interesting to see and visit. See the basilica cisterns before they collapse. A recent UNESCO Heritage report criticized Turkey and Istanbul for their lack of care for the cisterns. The biggest concern is all the tour buses parking above them and that they may crack and eventually collapse. So se them while you can and find the medusa heads!
History. That was all about the old historical period of Istanbul; it was amazing.
nice place. nice place to stroll ,lot of shops but don't forget to bargain
Good place to visit in Spring or early Autumn. Try to visit Grand Bazar and enjoy bargaining! Do a walk in Topkai park, visit blue Mosque and Sultanahmet district.

Grand Bazar and Egyptian Market. Now these are great places to do some shopping. The hustle and bustle in these places is amazing. From jewelry and carpets to leader coats and drinking chi. Spices galore. It's a world of smells and taste. What fun and then to think that these places have been around for centuries. I can see Marco Polo shopping and doing business in this place.

Very nice city and people. I walked around most of the time to give myself time to see and capture the moments. Also amke sure to use the trams and public transport to get around it is very nice and very cheap.
very good. The Historical Areas of Istanbul have an unique flavour which I think that no other city have it.
One of my favourite historic cities.. So much to tell. Such a long and interesting historical city. Make the effort to see as much as possible you wont be dissapointed.
A must. Stroll around and have lunch at Hamdi! Go over the Galata bridge.
Walking a must. Take time to stroll and don't be afraid to eat the street food which is fabulous

An intriguing city. We were based in an apartment in Sultanahmet, about a two minute walk from the Hagia Sofia and the Blue (Sultanahmet) mosque. It was booked through http://www.sultanahmetaparts.com/ and had a superb view of the Bosphorus. Great places to visit are the Basilica Cisterns, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, and the Mosaic Museum. The tram system is very frequent, very clean and cheap – 20 liras gets you about 12 rides, irrespective of distance.Take the ferry on the Bosphorus for a 90 minute trip – great views and gives you a chance to rest your legs.You should also include the Spice Market and the Grand Bazaar, but you will be assailed by shopkeepers wanting your custom. ‘You wanna buy my carpets? You wanna eat in my restaurant? You wanna buy a guide? etc’ I found the best answer was to say ‘I’m Greek – no money!’The weather in April was lovely and seems a very good time to visit. Two visits a day should be enough, unless you are very fit as there is a lot of walking and standing to do.The food is generally very reasonable and very good- the fish, meatballs, lamb, ( main courses about £8) and obviously the kebabs are very edible and the Turkish bread is lovely. Be warned that the food is very expensive in the Topkapi Palace - 20 liras for a kebab!You will get an alarm call every morning from the Imams!
Busy, exotic, fun.. Cats, cats, cats!! Seemingly well fed and content. Shop owners take some getting used to, but once you get into the rhythm, it's really fun.

So much history in old Istanbul. Whether you're walking the cobble footpaths around Taksim and Galata Tower - across the Galata bridge where you'll take in the smells of mackeral being caught by the local fishermen, the mobile bread and corn vendors, everywhere you look you can see remarkable monuments to the Ottoman and early Turkish history. The old gates are a reminder of the cities attempt to protect from intruders. You'll be mesmerised by the calls to prayer from the mosque's and be swept up in an amazing cultural experience. The best way to see Istanbul is on foot and mouth. Get a guide for the Palace and Blue Mosque or do your research before you get there to truly appreciate the history of this remarkable ancient yet functional city. Be alert and hold onto your bag in the Spice Bazar and Grand Bazar, the crowds can be crazy. The samples of cheese, sausage and fresh produce at the spice bazar will have your taste buds dancing.

Touristy but very little hassle. There were far more tourists than we had expected but the locals are generally very pleasant and don't hassle you. The architecture of so many of the buildings is amazing when you consider how old they are.
Happy city. Food was really good, people very polite, and nice helpfull.
Town. All ares very clean no rubbish and wonderful buildings

Plan only a couple of tourist sights per day. My best recommendation for Istanbul: plan only a few sights per day and allow yourself enough time to just go with the flow and explore the area away from the big attractions.

Be ready for an assault. I don't like bargaining or being verbally assaulted by vendors so this wasn't fun for me. Glad I saw it...but not somehwere I would return unless I was with a large group. Did not purchase anything there. Went to smaller shops away from this madness
To smell history. Nice places full of historyDislike:the strange odors!

walk into history. all the historical monuments . as a student of history it was a treat to be able to experiance first hand all that we had only read about . though the medusa head scared us but the basilica cistern was worth a visit . the relics at topkapi were very holy though we could not see them very clearly .
WOW. Just love wandering around the old city especially the back streets

Lots to See. Lots to see around here - Hagia Sofia, Blue (Sultanahmet) mosque, Hippodrome and columns, Basillica Cisterns, Topkapi Palace, Archeological Museum, Mosaic Museum. You could probably spend your entire holiday and never leave Sultanahmet.
amazing. nice place to visit and see the combining between cultures
It is interesting. It is interesting to see and to say Thank for the possibility to see it.
Great. Wonderful sites, great places to eat, a must see!!! do not miss it. Do it all by walking take your time by the water so beautiful.
Istanbul is magnificent. Istanbul is wonderful, I will go again soon we loved, is mysterious and its people are very friendly

Good for history , abuse for strolling. Although Old town of Istanbul is such a historical capital, it really doesn't reflect real Turkey. In modern part of Istanbul, when u stroll , u never ever get abused buy touts or some merchants man ( called as hanutcu) to pull your arms to sell u amazing Turkish rugs( they re actually the best ones but it takes time to pick up )Old town , in restaurants nearly all waiters have master degrees in Economics or politics:))))) but generally they re passport hunters .. In modern Istanbul average university graduate can easily find a job in banks with at least 1800$ as beginning level ... They do not work in restaurant service business..!!! Old town is also occupied by conservatives which really doesnt reflect real Istanbul

best place to stay. You can see all the historical side of Istanbul like Topkapi Palace, Cşstern, Grand Bazaar, Saint Sophia atc.by walking in one day. Try to stay around..Very nice small hotels and restaurants are located in the old city as well.
Sultanahmet. Sultanahmet area with lots of authentic restaurant,kilim shops,etc
Loved the sites of Istanbul. Every place I visited was a good experience. I would love to go back to Turkey. I found the people friendly and I always felt safe.

Not my thing. Istanbul old tiwn is a must see for one day. Its great to see some history and see what things used to look like. Far too touristic though and not representative of what Istanbul is now. A great chic and cosmopolitan city.

Historical and interesting. There is so much to see. The area around the spice bazaar in Eminonu is a bustling market where you can buy just about anything. Definitely try the fish/bread around Eminonu piers at 5 lira its fresh and tasty and as good as anything you'll get in a touristy restaurant. The Spice Bazaar is worth a visit but be prepared to be hassled and to barter.
Lovely and impressive. We enjoyed walking around this area. So many wonderful sites and lovely atmosphere. We enjoyed seeing the Bosphorus straits and the entire view

Best bang for your buck. Most sites around historic Istanbul are free, so its easy to spend a day wandering and still have cash in your pocket for a nice meal. Blue Mosque, New Mosque, Grand Baazar, Iskitial pedestrian street.
Ist is full of historic places. Istanbul is a city full of historic places, of great importance if you want to get to know more about the Byztanine and Ottoman Empires. Great for history-lovers
Magical. Just walk and enjoy. Don't hesitate to take a boat on the Bosphorus, a public ferry to go to Uskudar or a private one for a longer trip go.
Lots of Tourists, But I can see why!. The Blue Mosque and other sites make this a place you could spend a full day or two!

See All You Can. Istanbul is one of the great cities of the world. It was the capital of the Roman Empire from about 325 or so, then capital of Byzantium, and after the Turks conquered Byzantium in 1453, as Istanbul, it became the capital of the Ottoman Empire. This city has more great history than most countries. Get a good guidebook and go with the flow. We feared that one week would leave us thirsting for more and it did. We barely scratched the surface.
crazy shopping.... we loved just walking around the historic areas - especially around the Grand Bazaar where you can find actually crafts people making their goods.
historical area. Really historical area , if you go there you will feel that you are living in the Othman empire
Must have in life!!. Really worth a whole dedicated weekend to explore!

The most popular areas of Istanbul. The most exiting are where me and my family like to walk is Fatih, near Topkapi palace, AyaSofia and Blue mosque.The streets there are narrow and ancient with a lot of shops where you can find nice carpet or some staff like dishes, swards, knives etc. made as ancient ones.I'd especially like the place near Hippodrome and the city wall.All the monuments, old houses are in good conditions and really looked after by the city municipality.Of course many restaurants, locantas, cafes with reasonable prices are located there .I'd also advise to have a sea walk by boat or ferry which go in Bosporus strait or go the Asian part of Istanbul where you can visit areas like Kadikoy, Acibadem

skip the Grand Bazaar. historica areas of istanbul are highly recommended. Just skip the grand bazaar. it is time wasted. go and visit the blue mosque, ayasofia, basilica cistern, topkapi and the museum of ottomans and islamic arts. don't forget two small bazaar very close to ayasofia and blue mosque.

skip the Grand Bazaar. historica areas of istanbul are highly recommended. Just skip the grand bazaar. it is time wasted. go and visit the blue mosque, ayasofia, basilica cistern, topkapi and the museum of ottomans and islamic arts. don't forget two small bazaar very close to ayasofia and blue mosque.

Lots to see - could occupy you for days.. Slight disappointment in seeing the Blue Mosque but the tiles were amazing. The Topkapi Palace was wonderful and worth paying extra to go into the Harem. You have to queue for everything, but queues move quickly. We enjoyed the short Bosphorus trip but was disappointed that it didn't quite reach the Black Sea (knew this before we sailed). Best part - wandering around soaking up the ambience.

I feel like home. Old Istanbul you will never feel bored there - u will feel like you are in you own place -like in a dream - something will touch your heart their and force you to miss it even if you are there but in different city
A Walk in History. I visit the historic area of Istanbul, often, and love everything about it...now I am even used to the carpet sellers :)
Walking in history!!. Why stay in the jazzed up modern part if you can see and breath the past??? There are just so many things to see and do. Need more that a week, we felt....
Not to be missed!!. One just has to see the magnificent historical sites. I can't imagine why one would travel all the way to Istanbul and not visit the historic sites.
worth seeing. Huge queues in Topkapi Palace. Go early to avoid them. Best part is the Harem
Foodies. Just magic. Raki, beautiful fish from the Bosphorous, great atmosphere, great people.
A don't miss. The history of three empires and several centuries inone place,it's a definite don't miss

10 days was just enough - plenty to see and do. We had 10 days when it was cold and snowy but nearly always very beautiful. When the sun was out it was a bonus. Getting around was very easy with a good mix of trams and fairly easy walking. Some major improvements around the main square(Topkapi, Ayasofya, Blue Mosque) hampered walking a little but suspect they may be finished by summer 2012. Walking from Galata Bridge to Egyptian Bazaar (cheaper and more manageable than Grande Bazaar) takes you by the New Mosque (faces the sea and several hundred years old- and very beautiful inside). After the Egyptian Bazaar you can walk up to the Grand Bazaar and its adjacent Mosque ( and bookstalls) stopping at a big white tent in the square for a very cheap cup of soup etc.

Well worth a visit.. If you are interested in history, the historic area of Istanbul - SultanAhmet - is a must. Walk the street that is paved over the ancient Roman chariot track (Hippodrome). See the 3,500 year old obelisk from Egypt and the 1,500 year old church that is still standing (Aya Sophia).

True View of Istanbul. Get off the beaten track and just wander around. We found it very safe. We enjoyed walking around the town soaking in the sights. Once again, you'll be approached by vendors trying to sell any and everything. Just politely say Eeest teh Mehz, and they'll let you alone.

A very walkable town. We walked from the Grand Bazaar to Taksim Square and back. It was no problem whatsoever. We really enjoyed hanging out at Galata Bridge and the area around there. The walk from Iskalal Cad. to Taksim Square was amazing. I would suggest taking the tram and funicular to Taksim square and then walk down the street from there if you don't want to walk all the way from the Grand Bazaar area.
Buzzy!. Buzzy, busy and noisy but full of character, except the number of shopkeepers who asked me "do you want to buy a carpet" was too numerous to believe!

A Bridge Between Two Continents. A bridge between two continents..A city in the middle of Europe and Asia...connecting them to eachother...You are bound to be estonished..The historical buildings, high walls of castles, the art put into the mosques and churches, the signs of the Ottomans, the stories of civilizations and the proofs of how well different cultures and religons managed to all live in peace and harmony...If you are the trypr of person who loves historical places...the historical areas of Istanbul is exactly what you want!
Worth visiting every street in the area. So many restaurants, stores, historic places that you'll love just the experience of being there..
turkey. old is very cute with the cobble stone streets and all the cafes and hooka bars its really fun at nite to walk around and enjoy the people

A place where civilizations really meet.... The Historical Areas of Istanbul have an unique flavour which I think that no other city have it. The historical attractions here are a lot and very important, you will feel like you'remany hundreds years ago in Constantinople or Bizantium (the Istanbul former names).
where East and West meet. This city is still the meeting place of so much of the world, with the sights and spices of the East added to a vibrant culture with long roots into a Roman past.
a very different experience. an experience that brings you back in time and let your imagination start working and flying trying to figure out how the life was lived then
Did not care for the tours.. The tours really dont show you much. Its all about them taking you to their PRE-ARRANGED shops to have you buy.

Impressive. So much history in one spot - it rivals Rome! Wonderful to just stroll around and discover all the little hidden treasures. Nice to see how the old wooden houses are restored and fixed up - just hope it does not become to "fancy".

Amazing history. Loved the narrow streets of Sultanahmet mixed with modern transport. The Grand Bazaar is nice, but didn't get to fully explore it. Spent more time at the Spice Bazaar (got our Turkish delights at the Hafiz Mustafa Confectionery on Hamidiye Cd outside the Spice Bazaar, but there is a huge range available inside the Bazaar).
Istanbul Old Town. Like - not only travelling round the sites but also walking everywhere. Getting completely lost has its advantages as you find out just where local people live and shop.
Spice market. All traditional stallholders here and spices we cannot even dream about in the UK. You will get pestered by the stallholders but that is the norm in this part of the world
I love it. It has spirit which you will not find on modern part of the city.

Cool. Its worth of a visit. If you are coming to Istanbul only for a shopping in Kanyon or on Eminonu Misir bazaar, dont!
Visit at least 5 hystorical place, and definitely, dont miss Bosphorus cruise. YOu will like it!

Ottoman Hotels. If you want to stay right in the heart of the old town stay in one of the many Ottoman Hotels. It is like being part of the family rooms are small and cosy but clean and the service is fantastic. It is wonderful to be able to walk to all the major sites of the city. Istanbul Old Town is so interesting but I advise you to really learn the history so you can get the most out of your stay. Be prepared for that early wake up call from at least 5 mosques in the local area.

Visit the Grand Bazaar with some time!. Because, it's really fantastic!You will find everything there, from fake clothes to the best jewelry, going by fine antiques and wonderful carpets. Walking in Istanbul. Well worth a walk all around the spice market and grand bazaar which both are hundreds of small stands
The best of Histtory. The architectural elegance of these structures is unbelievable. The scale and complexity boggles the mind.

sightseeing. as far as we could tell the old town was easily walked from our hotel and most of the main sights were close together, from the port at emimonu up the hill to sultanahmet and on to to beyazit and the grand bazaar was an easy walk for the fit or a simple two or three stops on the excellent tram service for those who are not

Here in my heart rests. I love this city. The scenery is beautiful.. Here in my heart rests. I love this city. The scenery is beautiful.

A very Interesting morning. Good to look at this old part of the city - the Grand Bazar however is over priced - go walk down the street - you will get everything cheaper and without the constant hussle from the traders !
dirty. dirty, not even one beautiful building exept some monuments
Historical Place. I felt like in the old period of the city with nice cafe-bars and restaurants
Great historical site,,. great area to stay and visit ..you will see alot of museums,mosques and Hogia Sophia,,,,

So much to see. I can recomment the city tour as it is a good way of orientation. However, do ask how often they run. We went in March and one route ran every one and a half hours and another every hour. Not my idea of hop on and hop off.

Travel back in time. The whole area buzzes and hums with life. Watch out for the constant attention from people trying to sell you their wares. it is all in good humour but can get a bit trying. We ended up just saying Haiyur ( no !) and smiling a lot. There are some incredible sights here from the old man sharpening a huge meat knife on his bicycle wheel ( have not seen that in the UK for years) to the hundred of men on the Galata bridge fishing for whitebait ! The trips up the Bosphorus are well worth ten lire for a short trip (1.5 hours) Don't be taken in by the guys who say 30 lire or more.. and definitely not the ones who say that their boat is just a couple of minutes away and they will transfer you in their car !! As you walk up and down the waterline you will smell the fantastic freshly grilled fish. Balik Ekmek only 5 lire and very tasty. It gets very busy from around 4.pm onwards until 6.30pm Walk from the Old Town over the bridge to see the fish market, definitely worth a look and lots of places to eat the fish there too.

sultanahmet is the Istanbul's old town. Here where all the history is for Istanbul,Blue mosque,Kapali carsisi or Grand bazar,Besillica Cistern,archelogical musems,suleyman mosque,Spice bazar and more,they are all here in Sultanahmet.No trip is finished unless you been to sultanahmet's area.
BEAUTIFUL. What a stunning city, will definitely return, Istanbul old town has the most gorgeous feeling and beautiful lights. Very romantic around the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia and Old Town

Old town - full of touts selling carpets. Loved the old buildings but not so impressed with the salesmen. Be careful everyone who says they are not a guide wants to show you something and usually its a carpet shop

Give the Grand Bazaar a miss!. ...but, whatever you do visit the Spice Market. The Grand Bazaar is for the tourists but the Spice Market is where the locals go and it is a lot more than just spices as well. Be amazed at all the fish stalls, the cheese stalls and stand in awe surveying the long, long queue at the coffee shop - surely it can't be that special, can it? Then have a cup of pomegranate tea (wonderful) as you haggle over the fresh spices, dried fruits, teas and Turkish Delight (the double cooked pistachio is best) to bring back. A great morning.

Very Fancy - Beautiful!. The Dolmabahhce Palace was beautiful - just beautiful. Amazing how the Sultan lived. A must see. historical but some places are missused. one should not miss visiting most of the places but beware the MERCHANTs who approximately drag u to their places.

Magical. I loved everything about Istanbul, even the fact that it rained most of the time we were there! There are, however, many annoying street hawkers who REALLY want to sell you things! That seems to be true in most cities though. Not a big deal!

Step back in time. Wander the winding back streets, get a bit lost (but don't worry, you can find your way back), drink cay (turkish tea), play tavla (backgammon), barter for anything you could possibly want or need, stumble upon an ancient aqueduct, or walk into a shop that is a hundreds of years old. A magical way to spend the afternoon.
stay there.... Choose a hotel at this area...its safe and you will enjoy much

Quaint, Different, Historic.. Before you go read some of the history of Turkey and the clash of cultures and religions which took place there. Turkey is a wonderful, inviting country. Istanbul is a great city and the sights are magnificent. I had a bit of a problem with seeing some of the formerly Christian churches which have been turned into Mosques and/or museums. We also went through an area which was the old Jewish quarter and I found the explanation of how the Jewish population left unbelievable. We went on a Trafalgar tour "the best of Turkey" as well and this included a guided tour of the city.
Walking in history. The meandering streets with things to do and see on every one. Good restaurants (no bad food in Istanbul, I think.)

Great feel but be careful of scammers. The old town has a great feel and feels that little has changed in the past 500 years. The architecture, markets, views and narrow streets has such a charm. Watch out for a people asking where you are from as they are trying to sell you fake merchandise or scam you.

Less loud neihborhood. This area felt like Im going back in past time. There are still many small traditional shops and vendor. Where you can have a chat with the owner while shopping. A step back in time. Tram easy to use to get near Galata Bridge, ferries to Asia, etc. It's somewhat touristy, as one would expect, but the sights are wonderful and very worth staying close by.

As close as you can get to living in the Ottoman Empire. I would have loved to have lived during the Islamic Ottoman Empire days. History spread all around!. Old Istanbul (Old Sultanahmet area) is the heartland of not only Turkish history but to an extend Muslim history too.The place has an old era feel, and it is a good idea if you can stay here to. There is a Four Seasons Hotel here (which I guess is the top notch hotel property in this area) and besides this there a handful of good-priced boutique hotels to choose from.When you walk through the streets, its as if you are walking back in time. The cobbled streets.. the wooden houses lining the area, the people and the shops: all are from a different era!The place is littered with places of historic importance, like the Hagia Sophia, The Blue Mosque, The Sultan's tomb, the Bascilia Cistern, The Topkapi Palace, The Grand Bazaar and many more. Inorder to ensure you do not miss out on any attractions, suggest you carry a guide and if possible plan your route in advance. Check if the hotel lobbyist can help you with it.It is strongly recommended that you stay within this area so you can stroll around at leisure. Another piece of advise is that you build your trip around the Bosphorous tour and the Princess Island tour (incase you wish to take those) as they are not operating on certain days, and on spare days do the walk-around this area for the tour of the many historical places it has to offer.
Love it, but watch out. for the touts. They are everywhere, even in December. I'm sure that is why I love the Haghia Sophia and Basilica Cistern so much- because they are quiet and hassle-free.

A look into the life in Instanbul. Enjoy the markets and shops. The spice market was a blend of people, smells, history. We were even sure what some of the spices were. Every street we explored provided us with a new experience.

Fascinating blend of old and new. We loved wondering around the old town. The shops, the people, the buildings were a fascinating blend of old and new. You definitely want to take the time to wander the streets to take it all in.

History in all corners. Istambul is really a beautiful city, that everyone should have the opportunity to visit. The historic areas are amazing, full with history, and it's great to walk through the maze of shops.

Wow!. Atmospheric, interesting and genuine with tons of character.

Interesting market. Our tour stopped off at the spice market on the way to a cruise How glad I was we went there as we had little opportunity that day to buy gifts for homeTurkish delight was the main buy of the day and how great it was going from shop to shop tasting all the different varietiesChocolate coated delight who would have guessed it and just about every flavour in existence The markets also had a good variety of souvenirs of combs, mirrors,makeup fans and of cause the biggest assortment of spices unfortunately many not sealed well enough to bring back home for this they needed to be vacuum packedIt is not a huge market but big enough to spent time looking and talking to the friendly localsOutside were Turkish women selling food to be fed to the many pigeons running aroundWhat did impress me was the way some men in the middle of the road between traffic juggled and sold large pretzels This market is nothing like the Turkish bazaar but it is well worth a lookFood was sold outside the markets in food carts including ice cream and pretzels

Know Before You Go. There is so much to see and appreciate in Istanbul's Old Town. It is not only possible, but probable that you will walk right past an important historic site if you're not prepared. To maximize your experience, pick up a guide book and do a little reading in advance to get the most out of a stroll through the old town. Top sites include the Hagia Sophia (now a museum), the Blue Mosque (a functioning mosque), the grand courtyard and fountain between the two, the Basilica Cistern, the Hippodrome with its ancient columns, several good museums, the Millionth Marker, Topkapi Palace, and many, many local shops and artisan booths. One last tip: when visiting the major sites (Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace), be aware that cruise ship days will be much more crowded. If you can, time your visits to those sites on days when there are no cruise ships in port.

History all over the place!. Visiting Istanbul Old town is like walking back in time. The pople, the shops, the bultdings...just walking carelessly one may find the cemetery, or the Sultan´s Tombs...There is the Grand Bazaar, mesquites, blue mosque, little streets with colorful wooden houses (Hostels)...We walked around day and night...very safe place.
Just fun & history. Wonderful to walk around. People are very gracious & helpful.
Love Istanbul.......... I could have spent more than my 4 nights in this wonderful city. Clean, efficient transportation, great prices, friendly people, great food, just a truly beautiful city.

There are fish swimming in the water and the arch-ways over head are drippy - it's interesting, but also kind of gross.

Fantastic place. The historic areas of Istanbul really includes the whole city...however the most well known attractions of the Blue Mosque, Sophia Hagia Museum, Basilica Cisterna and Topkapi Palace etc...are all located in Sultanahmet. The Grand Bazaar with its thousands of little shops and the Spice Bazaar are all within easy walking distance...(have fun haggling with the shopkeepers and enjoy the experience)...there is also the New Mosque, Galata Tower and so many other attractions. Best to wear comfortable shoes (as many cobbled streets) and ensure you have small notes and coins handy if you want to take the tram - currently 2TL per trip
Love to stay there. When i visited Istanbul this year I opted to live in old town which falls in Europe. Living there offers one to visit all historic places and museums on foot
Istanbul offers lot of history. Different worth seeing historic places of Istanbul are Blue Moeque, Hagia Sophia, Topkapi Palace, Kapli Carsi, Basalika Cistern, Dolmabahce, Mazar Hazrat Aub Ansari

Grand Bazaar and rugs. It was wonderful to walk the old town. Osman Varli of adnan&hasan gave a detailed explanation of rug history at his NO hassel shop. We relaxed in a Turkish bath at Cagalogu Hamami. Wonderful

Plenty to see and do. Five days was not enough. Walked everywhere to explore the real Istanbul TaksimSquare, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, Ayia Sophia...need more time to see it all.Fascinating city which grows on you as the days pass.
Great place. Really enjoyed wandering around Istanbul. Never felt hassled (woman on her own), the people are friendly and helpful. Lots of activity, people friendly and helpful. Lovely place.

Walk till you drop. Amazing, incredible, fascinating, breathtaking. Explore every last inch of it. Be charmed by the people trying to sell you everything from corn to postcards to carpets and enjoy one of the world's truly amazing cities.
The road less travelled.... See the film clip on youtube 'Latcho Drom Istanbul' for shots of the old places
Wander the streets to get a real feel of the city. Old town Istanbul is a jumble of winding streets, crowded with people and shops, and a delightful way to get a feel for the people and the place.
Very traditional town. It is a picturesue town which turns to be a never ending bazaar.It is totally built by stones.There are no cars at the most of it's part so it is very easy to walk at it.
Worth seeing. Food, shopping, and sightseeing were amazing but did not like the scam artists trying to be over-friendly with me and trying to take their bait.

More than Meets the Eye. Search out the less well known areas like the Book Bazaar quite near the grand Bazaar, the Kucuk Hagia Sophia?former church of Saints Sergius and Bacchus - built before Haghia Sophia. Recently renovated, it is an active mosque with an unusual geometric groundplan. Sokollu Mehmet Pasa Mosque also another gem with Iznik tiles featuring more reds than usual; pieces of the Ka'aba a Mecca and part of a Medrassa, the only active one in Istanbul.

Wonderful City - wonderful people. We loved this city! Never met such helpful and hospitable people like the Turkish. We would definatly come back again. Don't miss it! We loved the Bazars, great Turkish artworks like ceramics and lamps.....the Spice market and the beautiful mosques! Don't take the Hop-on-off busses.... it is not like in other cities..... tooo long waiting pauses unfortunatly!

Walked from Grand Barzaar to the Spice market. Lots of shops between the Grand Barzaar and the Spice MarketDo not buy in the Grand Barzaar, price are much higher in the Grand Barzaar then on the outside of the Market.
Incredible. One of the most wonderful areas in the world. Impeccably kept, incredibly interesting and something very hard to find anywhere in the world.
history in all directions. Same as for Sultanahmet etc - just surrounded by history
History in all directions. Liked the same as the Sultanahmet - Istanbul is just such an ancient cross roads that there is something everywhere you turn

Narrow streets can be fun. I stayed in a small hotel class 3 in the old town. If you like inbuilt adventure this is it. Watch your belonging, watch where you walk. Plus, you feel the city, you feel the time, they have some good food. Do not go if you do not like closeness or need extra clean areas. The hotel was o.K, staff had problems. In the Turkish resturants be very careful to watch you waiter and the bill. They tend to charge for things you do not order. Just because it is done on a modern adding machine. Check I got hit by both, and several friends also. They look at you as an honest food product if you are foreign, esp. English speaking and a tourist. Food may be just fine, it is the details you have to watch.
A Must See. Nothing can beat the historic areas of Istanbul, all worth the visit. Make sure you go when the weather is cool, you'll need to walk around for long hours to give it justice. Superb!
It won't be your last visit!. A charming place, so hospitable you wish you could stay forever and call it home. A very memorable experience just going back in time in a most fascinating location!

Poor 'tourist target' restaurants. Overall we tried several restaurants, but I'm afraid left distinctly underwhelmed at standard - I think there is a culture of targetting tourists, get them in, and then know you'll never see them again, so offer sub standard or ordinary food at inflated prices. Many buildings are ramshackle and suffering from poor modern building techniques - without the Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque and Topkapi, Old Town Istanbul would hardly be worth the trip ...

A time travelers delight.. If I were immortal - I would have loved to have lived here during its heyday! The variegated cultural artifacts at the crossroads of Asia and the languages are a delight. Reminds me of Iran when Alex was running the show.

Turvan Hotel Location. I enjoyed staying in this part of the city. The tramway Serkici stop was a short stroll and the system is great for reaching Taksim or airport. To reach the museums take the tram or just stroll up the hill and meet the local traders who will be happy to offer complimentary tea.
Visit the Grand Bazaar. Easy way to get to the Grand Bazaar if you don't want to walk is to take the Tram, two stops from Suntanahmet Square. A rabbit warren of shops and cafes a great experience

Take the Tram to Eminonu. Take the tram to Eminonu where the Bosphorus trips leave from. Long or short trips can be found - arrive around 10am. After your trip walk to the boats selling freshly caught barbequed fish in a roll - delicious.
Packed. Wear hiking boots the cobbles will kill your tired feet. The place is a crush of humanity but then it is were east meets west
Must Go … bucket list for sure. Never ending surprises from museums, mosques, market, bazaars, street shows, restaurants. Sellers everywhere.
Totally Interesting. SOOOO many places to go, do see and experience. Lots of Mosques, market, old and new.

Don't get lost!. Well worth a walk around to see the magnificent old buildings, butr beware of the traffic (they certainly don't care about pedestrians!) and make sure you have a good street map...very easy to get lost!

Bursting with history. Walking round old streets, past fantastic buildings, through bazaars full of colour, light and cheerful, amusing sellers displaying their wares feels a world away from my normal life and I loved it.
Great walk. Its great to talk in the historic area of Istanbul, you could spend around 5-7 days to go inside everything. If you want to see it from the outside, it takes 2-3 days.
Spice Market. Loved the market. We could have spent a full day here. Purchased many interesting and different spices. This is a don't miss stop.
must see. walk the streets and visit the Grand Bazaar and appreciate this city that is very very old. amazing history here.

Love the Architecture, Hate the Carpet Salesmen. The architecture in Sultanahmet is like no other in our world. To fully understand the significance of the Hagia Sophia, the Blue Mosque, the Basilica Cistern, the Topkapi Palace, and the museum artifacts requires much reading and studies as well as return visits. Although the architecture is incredulous, the carpet salesmen are obnoxious and pushy. They really wear on my enjoyment of the area. These salesmen can turn a nice vacation into a place I personally am ready to leave from. Just for fun, I engaged in conversation with one of the aforementioned carpet salesmen and had him show me some carpets. WOW!! my gosh, these men really value their carpets. These prices are some of the highest priced pieces I have ever been quoted. I have purchased Turkish carpets, Persian carpets, etc. here in the states for years and I get far better prices from local salesmen than I was being quoted in Sultanahmet. I guess they want you to pay for the tea they offer you as well. :)

Complicated streets and alleys make it difficult, so it's worth hiring a local guide.. The sites are in a relatively good condition, they are not so far one from the other, but, as the old city has lots of narrow streets and alleys, you will save time and it will seems much more simple and shorter if you get a local guide.
All the action is here. Blue Mosque, street life are both great and interesting.
Interesting. I found the old town a lot more interesting. Great to just walk around, explore and discover things
Stay in Old Town. Best to stay in Old Town and walk everywhere to get the flavor of old Istanbul

was great to visit all the shops. was great area to walk around and get a flaver for the city. was a bit intimidating to haggle over prices but once you tri it becomes easier. be careful of the monye exhanges as they will ripe you off when you change dollars into lira. and make sure you compare prices from one shop to the other before buying
All buildings in good shape/condition. I was surprised about how clean and in good condition everything is, the public toilets are the cleanest ever seen in a city.

Worth a visit but caters to tourists. Of course it's worth visiting this area and the attractions it offers but it seems to be set up completely for tourists. Everything is at least 10x the price so no Turkish people would be stupid enough to shop there so only tourists do. The sales people are super pushy too. I enjoyed the actual markets on the Asia side much more (even though they were more hectic) and I got much better deals on things to bring back there and in Cappadocia. The Taksim slums were also a much more interesting and "old" experience though people are advised against going there, especially at night.

Stayed Here. Quieter than across the bridge. Lots of cafes and restaurants on our doorstep. Near Topkapi Palace, Blue Mosque and Hagyia Sophia. Tram takes one across the bridge into the other part of town.
Walking the Sultanahmet - like going back in time. Everything, the mystery, the architecture, the cats, the trees, the sights, the people and good smeels of food from the vendors.
Picturesque and Charming. Old town is very well-maintained, too many smokers on the streets, but the place is friendly, safe, and clean.

Get a Guide for the Historic Insights. The historic areas are well kept, clean, and absolutely beautiful. A guide was so helpful. He gave us facts we would have never known. He also got us past long lines that people were waiting in.
Memorable!!!. Istanbul Old Town is a hidden secret to the world. What a delightful, enjoyable, romantic, intermate city. This visit is a must to all.

Excellent by the day, not so good as Istiklal Caddesi at night.. No doubt: it is the historical center of the actual Istanbul and also the heart of the former empire´s capital, Constantinopla. The main atractions of that, so, are there and during the day it is a vibrant place to explore. Eventhough, by night, we felt it not so vibrant as the surroundings of Istiklal Caddesi pedestrian street in the other side of the Golden Horn channel. As we was with a wheelchair friend, we also had dificulty to walk by the beautiful, but narrow and old paths (stone pavement), so, that is something that also could be considered by the visitor, specially those elderly and with babies.

Best area to visit and to stay. This is the old Istanbul: magic place. You can feel the power, the richness, the capital of an empire and of the merchants ... you can't miss it As a tourist stay here close to Sulthanhamet you'll find all the most important ancient places close by. You will have plenty of nice and not too expensive restaurant, and if you want to move for a dine - out in Beyouglu, with a view on the gold horn, just take the tramway and than the "funikular" ... or a taxi :)
beautiful. this is the real istanbul you feel like you go back in time

Too many!. Before actually going to Istanbul, read about the various empires and some history. The history is vast and not all negative. In fact, I think that it's beautiful history and the architecture alone will have you coming back for more. Gather all of the souvenirs you can and never forget about 'calligraphy', which is truly an art of Turkey (Istanbul). If you get the chance, spend your time in Sultan Ahmet and also visit the Greek Patriarchate of Constantinople. There is also an Armenian Archdiocese here. No matter who you are, don't limit yourself in a city with no limits!

Lots to go at. Where to start? As well as all the obvious bits of Sultanahmet et al. Don't miss The Grand Bazaar (lose yourself), The Spice Bazaar, Galata and more backstreets than you can shake a stick at. Go on - just wander.

Blue. Very beautiful, but a little let down after the Ayasofya. I would visit the blue mosque first, then the Ayasofya. You will appreciate it more. Still a wonderful experience and a peaceful respite from the busy streets.

Great area. Our hotel was in this area and we much preferred it to the new town, all you need is here from the carpet and lamp shops, restaurants, mini supermarkets, easy access to the main tourist spots and souvenir/spice shops!
store vendors. the store vendors walk right up to you with their harassing sales talk. Very very off putting.

Easy walking tour on your own. Everything is within walking distance.. Pebble path will keep your eyes away from the street shopping. Great help to avoid over shopping. Aggressive sales strolling around all tourist destination to pretend to befriend you, offer you assistance, pretend knowing someone from your home town such as claiming their English teacher is from your country, etc. They will eventually talk you into going to their shops.

Kebabs and culture. Lots to see and do, loved the Spice Bazaar and the Grand Bazaar. Easy area to walk around, plenty of places to sit and watch and world go by and everyone was so welcoming and friendly.
wonderfull. you have to stay there not only to visit the small narrow street the #real# istanbul mid class living
No comparison with the new town. For me Istambul is the old town. The new town is like hundreds of cities in the wordl. The exception is the Galata Tower
Atractive. Interesting, very busy, old houses and little streets full of surprises

Grand Bazaar worth a visit but a bit pricey. I found better bargains and vendors to be had in Cairo, but this place is a lot of fun if you can stand the crush of crowds. Vendors aren't overly aggressive, i interacted with some great people, some not as memorable...

Cozy place..loved it!. We stayed for two nights in this area. It was amazing. The streets and the alleys were very beautiful . The nights and the restaurants with the turkish music are very romanyic. Another advantage is that u can explore all the sites in the day time then relax in thr evening. Don't miss restaurants on the roofs. Enjoy!

Argues Travel good travel operators. We took a private tour with Argues Travel.Shukru who does part time work with Argues was a really good guide, specially good with small children (we had 2). He has a degree in archaelogy and guiding which is useful as he knows something about everything....he is also honest (for example, he mentioned he hadnt been to the top of the Galata Tower till date!!)....Edip who planned our itinerary was really good and despite our making multiple changes he was always willing to allow for changes. Except 1 day where we felt he should have got us a hired car (we used taxis instead), we were generally ok on transportation. In terms of pricing, I compared pricing against one other agent and their pricing was more competitive, but not sure if they are the most value for money. One important thing to note is that if you are living in the Sultanamet area, you don't spend much on travel as you walk to all the sites. Also, entry fees is really low in most places (in some cases its free) so don't think such things cost a lot.

Good for Tourist Sites, Quiet Area. This puts you 5-10 minutes walking distance from all the big sites and about 10 minutes from the Grand Bizarre. However, if you want to do anything after dinner, old town only offer hooka cafes (not to be confused with bars). You'll be back in your hotel by 11 pm at the latest.
Try to stay in a hotel in this area, you won't regret it!. Try to stay in a hotel in this area, you won't regret it!

ARGEUS TOURISM & TRAVEL HIGHLY RECOMMENDED. My wife and I recently returned from a long holiday in Turkey, and it was Argeus Tourism & Travel representative Mehmet, who helped us to book our trip and put together an excellent itinerary, which made us have a dream vacation. Mehmet was most helpful and a thorough professional, from the initial enquiry right through to the final booking. We explained to him what it was we wanted out of our trip and he took the time to go the extra mile to help us and he was easy to communicate with, clear and precise. He was also very efficient in sending the train tickets directly to our hotel upon our arrival in Istanbul for our overnight trip to Ankara.All in all, our trip went very smoothly and we would definitely recommend this travel agency to anybody because of the flawless service and arrangements as well as superb personal service from Mehmet of Argeus Tourism and Travel. We would not hesitate to use them again. Everything they arranged was as promised, and we highly recommend Argeus to anybody that might be thinking about travelling within Turkey. Almost every aspect of the trip ran flawlessly and if we did encounter a problem, which one is bound to, when one travels for such a long period, it was handled in very professional manner and promptly, with a positive outcome.We had a great time in a beautiful country, with everything organised very well by Argeus Tourism and Travel - this travel agent comes highly recommended.

Warning - beware of carpet salesmen. Ignore all men in the street who try to be friendly and helpful without being asked. Official tour guides have ID cards and charge a fee. There are also various uniformed officials who can help if you ask. I'm talking about an ordinary looking unidentified man who offers to provide something for nothing as in free, on-the-house or "traditional hospitality" He may say he can show you the sights and tell you some history. He will then suggest you come and use his WC and refreshment facilities for nothing or visit his shop but under no obligation. There is no such thing as something for nothing. If you find yourself being taken towards a carpet shop, get away while you can. You won't get out until each of you has spent a lot of money. If one of you has no credit card on you, a man will later accompany you to your hotel to get it or some other form of money. I sat outside one such place while my friends were being fleeced inside. I watched as tourists were brought in and taken to different rooms in the building to be "worked on". I was brought tea (which I refused) and the man got quite cross and said it was a turkish tradition. Then one of my friends came out and told me it was safe to go inside now! (I didn't) My friends not only bought expensive things they didn't need but then agreed to go back the following day to pick up a driver (everywhere is within walking distance) and accepted the offer of a meal for all of us "on the house" ! I managed to talk them out of these activities, but they had left their goods at the shop for "safe keeping" so they had to go back to fetch them which provided the opportunity for more persuasion. These men are like stoats with a rabbit. Don't let them catch you.

great experience Argeus Tourism and Travel. Thank you to Argeus Tourism that made my family's trip to Istanbul, Capadoccia and Efesus wonderfull, The transfers, the hotels, the guides, all perfect, my special thanks to Cintia that planned ours trip. We loved Turkey.

Sultan Ahmet's is the Heart of Istanbul. I have been to many places of the world but most fascinating and enchanting travel experience I had in Turkey. I booked my hotel at the Sultan Ahmet area in The Aya Sofia Best Western which share the wall with St Sophiya. The area is truly historic and admin of Istanbul maintained its historical value alive by not allowing mindless new construction.My hotel was tremendously accessible to be traveled to the all parts of the Istanbul. In front of the hotel metro (surface and underground train) equivalent to Underground of London and Metro of Milan and the station was on five minutes walk. I can clearly see the giant and mystic Sultan Ahmet Masjid (Blue Mosque) from the window of my hotel. Grand Bazar (Kapali carsi) is about 20 minutes walk whereas Masjid Bayazid was not far away as well. On the right turn from my hotel you could easily walk along the Metro line and entered into the Grand Park which is attached to the famous and most historical Top Kapi Palace and after passing through the park it would not be distantly far to reach to the Golden Horn.As I said my hotel wall was next to the St Sophiya, and if I walk down to the left from my hotel I can see first the underground ancient water supply ponds, which I missed to visit despite my hotel nearness to that place, and further to left, walking along the St Sophiya wall you can turn towards Top Kapi Palace. Top Kapi palace is unbelievably grand and mystic. After entering into the palace if turn your eyes towards you will see deep blue water of Strait of Bosporus which connects Black Sea to Sea of Marmara. I can not forget the beauty of the waters shades and the colorful sails of the boats floating over the waves of the sea.I would strongly suggest who like to visit Istanbul that they should stay in Sulatnahmet which is indeed a heart of Istanbul.

Istanbul where Asia and Europe Meet. Istanbul is an amazing city fun and full of life. My friends and I visited around Christmasand the lights and festivities were a welcoming surprise. We especially enjoyed Sofia Masque. This is spectacular in the daytime or nighttime when it is lit with blue lights. We sipped tea by the sea and watch as the busy ferry activity took place around us. We visited some outer areas by ferry which was so much fun. The people were welcoming everywhere we went. There is no food like the food in Istanbul fresh, hot and delicious. I would go back just for that. This is a very active nightlife there and so much shopping. We had a great time and plan to return again next year. We did not take a tour we did it on our own.
